title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LARRY G.
description: NEWMAN-Larry G., 82, of Hyannisport, MA., on February 27. Husband of Mary F. (Falvey). Father of Nancy Baumgarten, Megan Newman and Leighland Olwine. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. A Funeral Mass will be held on Monday, March 3, at 10 AM in St. Francis Xavier Church, Hyannis. Interment in St. Francis Xavier Cemetery, Centerville. Visiting hours will be in the Doane, Beal & Ames Funeral Home, Hyannis, MA., on Sunday from 2-5 PM. Memorial donations may be made in Larry's memory to the St. Francis Xavier Church Capital Fund Drive, 347 South St., Hyannis, MA 02601.

title: Bridge
description: The world's strongest annual team contest is perhaps the Forbo-Krommenie Tournament, played last week in Scheveningen, the Netherlands. In the main event, an Italian foursome consisting of Alfredo Versace, Norberto Bocchi, Massimo Lanzarotti and Andrea Buratti snatched victory on the last board, gaining a slam swing when an opponent misguessed.

title: Literature Breeds Its Own Libertinism
description: To the Editor:

title: Casino Hope Dashed, Catskills Resort Files for Bankruptcy
description: For years, it has been the gold standard of Catskills hotels, the sleek resort where Buddy Hackett and Alan King kibitzed, Muhammad Ali trained, and scores of Jewish singles met the loves of their lives.

title: Democrats Say They'll Return About $1.5 Million More in Questionable Gifts
description: After a three-month internal audit, the Democratic Party announced today that it would return nearly $1.5 million in additional contributions that it now believes may have been illegal or improper. Most of the money was raised by three Asian-American businessmen whose fund-raising practices have come under sharp scrutiny by Federal prosecutors and Congressional investigators.

title: A Dodger Who Faced Barriers, Too
description: CAL ABRAMS was buried in his Brooklyn Dodgers uniform yesterday in North Lauderdale, Fla. He was the son of a Russian immigrant father, a Jewish kid from Brooklyn whose proudest moment was the day he slipped into his Dodgers uniform and stepped onto Ebbets Field.

title: Rape Charge in Internet Case Dismissed at Prosecutor's Request
description: Charges against a businessman accused of raping a woman he met over the Internet were dismissed yesterday at the request of the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Ruler of Japan Ports Not Cowed by U.S.
description: When the United States imposed new trade sanctions against Japan this week, it was taking on not just the Japanese Government but also a far more formidable figure -- a little-known 83-year-old Japanese businessman who governs the nation's ports as if they were his own backyard.

title: At Lunch With the Saudis, F.B.I. Director Complains
description: Even as a senior Saudi Arabian delegation renewed pledges of cooperation with the United States in the investigation of a truck bombing that killed 19 United States airmen last June, Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the F.B.I., expressed frustration that the Saudis were not doing more to help.

title: Lipinski Continues To Land At the Top
description: The new scourge of Michelle Kwan, the defending world champion and the defending champion of this Champions Series Final, is not much bigger than a kewpie doll. She weighs just 75 pounds, she is only 14 years old, and she has, for the second consecutive competition, skated a better, bolder program than skating's somewhat chastened queen bee.

title: Police Criticized in Teen-Agers' Shooting
description: Two city narcotics officers shot two teen-agers in Harlem on Feb. 13 while responding to a report of a gunfight between rival gangs, police officials said yesterday.

title: Officers Charged in Videotaped Arrest
description: Two Hartford police officers were arrested today and charged with beating a Massachusetts man, whose arrest two weeks ago was caught on videotape by a neighboring police force.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, MICHAEL STEPHEN
description: DOYLE-Michael Stephen, 39, died on Wednesday, February 26, 1997. Survived by: wife, Theresa Doyle; children, Melissa Ann and Dennis Christophe Wyatt; father, Stephen Doyle; mother, Ruth Doyle; brother, Peter James Doyle; sister, Elizabeth Doyle Seda. Funeral Mass: 10 AM, Saturday, March 1, 1997, St. Anne Catholic Church, 2140 Westheimer Road, Houston, TX., Rev. James J. Doyle celebrant. Service and interment to follow in New York.

title: Technology Threatens Monopolies
description: The competitive revolution in telecommunication took two encouraging steps forward this week. News Corporation announced a merger that promises to provide its customers with a broadcast satellite service fully equal, if not superior, to their local cable service. AT&T, the long-distance carrier, then announced that it had secretly developed a technology that would allow it to bring local phone service to people's homes without using the equipment of the regional Bell companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANKER, ALBERT
description: SHANKER-Albert. The officers and members of the Italian American Labor Council mourn the loss of our brother, Albert Shanker. As AFT President, one of our affiliates, he was the conscience of labor and human rights throughout the world. We will miss him as our leader and friend. George Altomare, President

title: U.S. Aides Say Doctors May Discuss Marijuana
description: Responding to a lawsuit filed by proponents of the medical use of marijuana, Federal officials said today that the Government would do nothing to impede discussion between doctors and their patients about the drug's possible benefits.

title: THEATER
description: More Crazed Than Malevolent,

title: Wilson Makes Most of a Chance
description: When Jay Payton, a candidate to play right field for the Mets, injured his right elbow Tuesday, Manager Bobby Valentine said that Payton's setback would not necessarily change the workload for Carl Everett and Alex Ochoa, the other top competitors for the position.

title: West Side Highway Relocation Is Luxury Now
description: To the Editor,

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HILTON HOTELS CORP., Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had received about 710,000 ITT Corp. shares in response to its $6.5 billion tender offer, which it extended until March 28. The $55-a-share offer originally was to expire yesterday.

title: Plan on Gifted Alarms Some, Pleases Others
description: Chancellor Rudy Crew's proposals to broaden access to programs for gifted students met with support yesterday from many educators and school officials, but the idea alarmed some parents who said they feared the moves would dilute existing programs.

title: Youth Director Is Forced Out
description: The director of a state agency that has come under increasing criticism for failing to protect the 52,000 children in its care resigned yesterday. The State Human Services Commissioner, William Waldman, said he had asked Patricia Balasco-Barr to step down as the head of the embattled Division of Youth and Family Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOURIHAN, CORNELIUS S.
description: HOURIHAN-Cornelius S., suddenly on February 27th, 1997. Beloved brother of Margaret A. Hourihan. Retired Port Authority of NY Police Officer. Reposing Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., NYC, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10 AM, at St. Catherine of Siena Church. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, SI.

title: Aguirre Changing Roles
description: Amid the restructuring by DON NELSON, the new general manager, MARK AGUIRRE will quit as the Mavericks' director of player development after this season. Aguirre, 37, will take on nonbasketball duties and receive an unspecified ownership share.

title: Japanese Fears Give Boost to Nationalists
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. IS CERTIFYING MEXICO AS AN ALLY IN FIGHTING DRUGS
description: President Clinton certified today that Mexico is a full ally in the war against illegal drugs, but only after the Mexican Government made several commitments sought by American law enforcement agencies.

title: For Old Rhythm-and-Blues, Respect and Reparations
description: What do Grammy winners do the night after the big event? Some of them went to one more party: the eighth annual Rhythm-and-Blues Foundation awards ceremony. Bruce Springsteen, Tracy Chapman, Tony Rich, Cassandra Wilson and Keb Mo', who all collected Grammys on Wednesday night, were at the New York Hilton Grand Ballroom on Thursday night for an event that mixed respect and reparations.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Denies Giving Confidential Data to a Mobster
description: A former Federal Bureau of Investigation supervisor vehemently denied in court yesterday that he had fed confidential information to a murderous mobster who was also an F.B.I. informer.

title: T. EATON RETAIL CHAIN SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The T. Eaton Company Ltd., owner of Canada's best-known chain of department stores, has declared the equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Eaton's, which has a debt load of more than $350 million, sought court protection on Thursday under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act. This will give the company four months to devise a restructuring plan. The move could mean closing up to 40 of the company's 87 stores. Eaton's creditors and suppliers will not be paid for anything billed before Thursday until a restructuring plan is approved. Eaton's owes the Toronto Dominion Bank and the Bank of Nova Scotia $160 million. It has turned to GE Capital Canada, which will provide $555 million to let the company continue to operate.

title: POP
description: Slipping a Haitian Style

title: New Battle of Normandy Rages Over U.S. Memorial : The Wall That Never Went Up
description: WASHINGTON  When Ameri-cans visit the D-Day beaches of France, thousands head each year to Le Memorial, a war museum and garden taking shape in Caen to honor the soldiers who took part in the liberation of Normandy.

title: Knicks Extend Journey With One More Overtime
description: Do not ask them how or why. It is not pertinent. They won. Patrick Ewing, John Starks and their bleary-eyed teammates can go home and sleep.

title: Trying Loss As the Nets Lack Effort
description: Jayson Williams had become an unmentionable, someone Coach John Calipari seemed to have tucked away without a thought once the power forward decided to have season-ending thumb surgery this week.

title: Hong Kong Stock Issue Thwarted And a Beijing Role Is Suspected
description: The world of Hong Kong business which has boasted of immunity from the territory's political tremors as China prepares to resume sovereignty in four months -- was jolted out of its reverie Thursday.

title: JAZZ
description: Home Space Advantage

title: TIME WARNER ORDERS BUDGET CUTS UP TO 5%
description: Time Warner Inc. has stepped up its cost-cutting efforts with a recent memo ordering its far-flung units to shave 3 percent to 5 percent off their budgets in the next three years. Known for lavish salaries and perks, Time Warner plans to reduce costs without cutting many jobs, the memo said. The companywide memo comes almost a week after Cable News Network's chief executive, W. Thomas Johnson Jr., told employees to expect cost reductions of 4 percent because of pressure by its parent, Time Warner, to reduce debt and raise its share price. Time Warner is considering steps such as reducing its fleet of corporate airplanes and spending less on administrative functions, the memo said.

title: Stepping Up Exuberantly For a Debut
description: American Ballet Theater began its ABT Studio Company as a junior touring ensemble, a workshop for new choreography and a farm team for the senior troupe. The good-looking teen-age ensemble, which made its formal theatrical debut on Thursday night at Kaye Playhouse, is clearly a fine idea well-realized.

title: The Swiss Had Their Villains -- and Their Heroes
description: I was born in Zurich in 1945, the son of Austrian Jewish refugees. During the frightful years of World War II, my parents found safety and friendship in that country.

title: Dispute Over Ebonics Reflects a Volatile Mix That Roils Urban Education
description: It was after 11 P.M. at a routine school board meeting in December, full of long-winded tributes to outgoing board members, when the Oakland School Board hurriedly approved a recommendation many members had barely read. It said black students spoke a separate language called ebonics.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CHARGES DISMISSED -- Charges against Paul Krauth, accused of raping a woman he met over the Internet, were dismissed at the request of the Manhattan District Attorney's office. Page 27.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Tense Standoff in Jerusalem Ends, but Nerves Are Taut
description: For a few tense moments today, violence seemed about to erupt on the pine-covered hill in East Jerusalem where Israel plans to build a Jewish neighborhood despite Palestinian objections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOL, FLORENCE
description: SOKOL-Florence, on Feb. 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late David R. Sokol. Loving mother of Ellyn Goode and Andrew L. Sokol. Cherished sisters of Rose Weinstock, Violet Miller, Gertrude Schwinger and Edith Ertrachter. In lieu of flowers please make donations to your favorite charity. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: For Victim Of Attack, A Memorial Full of Music
description: While the body of his killer lay unclaimed in the Medical Examiner's morgue, Chris Burmeister was mourned and remembered with joy yesterday by his family and friends and by the woman he loved.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Loses 47.33 Points; Technology Sector Is Weak

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERAGO, BERTIEN
description: SCHERAGO-Bertien, of Port Washington, NY, on Feb. 27, 1997, after a long illness & courageous battle. Beloved wife of Irwin, loving mother of Nina Jones and Randall Scherago, mother-in-law of George Jones and sister of Emily Resnick, and many other family, friends and the community of Port Washington whom she loved dearly. Graduate of Bard College. Funeral services Sunday, March 2, 10:00AM, at The Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Development Office of The Mount Sinai Medical Center, Box 1049, One Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029

title: No Headline
description: ''It was a compliment. I was hoping she would card me.''

title: A Spray-and-Run Bandit
description: It is customary for people who take dollars away from the Mutual of Omaha currency exchange counter at Newark International Airport to hand over an equivalent amount of cash in foreign bills. But Thursday evening, a man sprayed the clerk with pepper spray, grabbed a sack containing $20,000 and fled in a getaway car, officials said.

title: Takeover Bid for Barney's Is Reportedly Turned Down
description: Less than 24 hours after Dickson Concepts (International) Inc. bid for Barney's Inc., the creditors committee for the New York retailer decided the offer was unacceptable and began a scramble for other options, people close to the situation said yesterday.

title: USA WASTE INCREASES OFFER FOR MID-AMERICAN WASTE
description: USA Waste Services Inc. said yesterday that it increased its offer for Mid-American Waste Systems Inc. to $201 million from $180 million after another company bid for Mid-American, which is operating under bankruptcy protection. USA Waste Services increased its offer after the Superior Oil Company made a competing bid under an auction process set up by the United States Bankruptcy Court. The higher offer for Mid-American is scheduled to be reviewed on March 7. Mid-American, which like USA Waste is a solid-waste management company, listed assets of $61.4 million and liabilities of $371.8 million in a bankruptcy court filing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, JACQUES
description: COE-Jacques, stockbroker, died on February 23, 1997 at age 103. Spent 88 years on Wall Street. Beloved husband of the late Florence Curtis Coe (formerly married to Clara Bartels Coe). Loving father of Jean Fink and the late Jacques Coe, Jr. and Tech/Sgt. William Coe, and devoted stepfather of the late Joan Curtis Cowen; cherished grandfather of William, Liz, James and David Coe; Nancy Ceccorulli, Lisa Fink and Lorie Cowen Levy. Also survived by nine great-grandchildren. Memorial service on Sunday, March 2, 11:30 AM at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Chess-inthe-Schools, the American Chess Center, 353 W. 46 St., NYC 10036.

title: Spring Training Means a New, Relaxed Start for Gooden
description: Dwight Gooden promised to relax. Forget that he was the first Yankee to fire a pitch in a game since the World Series title. Forget the videotaped tribute to the 1996 Yankees and the unveiling of a championship banner. Forget that he bounced through spring training last season like an empty can in a hurricane. Forget everything else and think about today.

title: Doctors Assert There Are Too Many of Them
description: The American Medical Association and representatives of the nation's medical schools said today that the United States was training far too many doctors and that the number should be cut by at least 20 percent.

title: Assembly May Stall Part of Energy Deal
description: As the state introduces competition to the electric power industry, leaders of the Assembly want to wrest control of the restructuring from the State Public Service Commission, saying that only then will ordinary consumers be guaranteed much lower rates.

title: In the Old West, a Gun With a Past
description: Reaching for something different, Showtime is offering ''Dead Man's Gun,'' a trilogy of Western yarns circa 1875, tomorrow night. Written by the brothers Spielman, devisers of ''Kung Fu'' and ''The Young Riders,'' the stories are packaged by Showtime as ''morality tales reminiscent of O. Henry and Rod Serling.'' On a more immediate copycat level, you can also throw in the successful HBO anthologies ''The Hitchhiker'' and ''Tales From the Crypt.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JUDAH
description: COHEN-Judah, a very special person whose life was devoted and dedicated to his children. His never ending concern and pride in his children, unwavering respect for his father and sensitivity to the needs of others will be his legacy. He will be sorely missed. May Shlomo Chani, Avi and Max be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Family and Friends

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: Islanders Treading Water As Senators Make Inroads
description: It was a tug-of-war that the Islanders were supposed to win. After all, the Ottawa Senators are not a rough-and-tumble team that muscles a weaker opponent.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Nuccio Bertone, a designer of Italian sports cars, misstated the origin of the Alfa Romeo Spider. It was designed by Pinin Farina; it did not originate with the Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprint, which was designed by Mr. Bertone.

title: TV's Missing Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALDSON, CLARISSE, (NEE LAFRAMBOISE)
description: DONALDSON-Clarisse, (nee LaFramboise), 86, of Palm City, FL., New York City, and East Hampton, on February 11, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. James R. Loving mother of James R. of New York City, and Jeffery P. of Charlottesville, VA. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Memorial mass Saturday March 8, 11 A.M. at Most Holy Trinity R.C. Church, East Hampton. Memorial contributions to Most Holy Trinity, 79 Buell Lane, East Hampton, NY 11937, would be appreciated.

title: A City at War
description: For New York City, 1968 was an annus horribilis like no other. Most poor neighborhoods were angry and volatile after the murder of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. The assassination of Senator Robert Kennedy broke the city's heart. Columbia University and other campuses were paralyzed by turmoil. Then came the 55-day teachers' strike, an event so corrosive that, a generation later, people say it determined many of their views about race and education.

title: Op-Ed Columnists
description: Beginning today the Op-Ed columnists will appear on the following schedule:

title: York Beats Lehman to Claim CUNY Title
description: York College finally has its banner. It took three straight appearances in the final, but last night the Cardinals won their first City University of New York men's championship by defeating Lehman College, 76-69, at Hunter College. The victory also earned York its first automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament.

title: Former King of Romania Is Welcomed Home Again
description: A handsome young monarch when he was dethroned by the Communists at gunpoint 50 years ago, Michael of Romania made an emotional homecoming today, the first where he was truly welcomed by the Government and people alike.

title: Songs of Private Turmoil, Surreally Echoing Dylan
description: Early in her stirring concert at the Beacon Theater on Thursday evening, Shawn Colvin performed one of the best late 60's Bob Dylan songs not written by Mr. Dylan. ''Get Out of This House,'' which Ms. Colvin wrote with her producer and longtime collaborator John Leventhal, is an all-purpose tirade that begins with the line, ''Go jump in the lake'' and escalates from there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMANN, ROSALIE (NEE THALHEIMER)
description: LIPPMANN-Rosalie (nee Thalheimer), on February 26, 1997, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Robert L. for 49 years. Devoted mother of Pamela Lippmann Roth and Valerie Lippmann Doran. Loving grandmother of Stacey and Scott Roth. Services, Sunday, March 2, 10:45AM, The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the cancer organization of your choice.

title: Suddenly, Religious Ethicists Face a Quandary on Cloning
description: The cloning of an adult mammal offers a striking example of how technology can outpace the moral and social thinking that would guide it, setting off a debate among ethicists, psychologists and theologians over how this new science might change the world.

title: Clean Needle Programs Face Legal Hurdles
description: To the Editor:

title: Guitarist Provides a Blend Of Technique and Touch
description: In its 70-year history, the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation has sponsored competitions for piano, voice and most of the orchestral instruments, but it was only last year that the foundation turned its attention to the guitar. Jorge Caballero, a 19-year-old guitarist from Peru, won the foundation's first guitar competition, and as part of his prize he was presented in his New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Inmate Beatings Decrease, but Continue, at Rikers
description: In the year since city officials took major steps to stem the abuse of inmates by correction officers in the punitive segregation unit of Rikers Island, the use of force by officers in the city's toughest jail has steadily declined, according to Correction Department statistics.

title: Bill on Worker Abuse
description: Businesses in New Jersey often benefit from state contracts, economic development aid and investment from the state's huge pension fund. Yesterday, elected officials and the New Jersey A.F.L.-C.I.O. held a rally at the National Labor Museum here in support of legislation to withhold those benefits from businesses that inflict hardship through layoffs or relocations. The Assembly bill was introduced in January by a Democratic lawmaker, Loretta Weinberg of Teaneck. State Senator Richard LaRossa, Republican of West Trenton, pledged at the rally to sponsor a Senate version. TERRY PRISTIN

title: What's in a Title? For Selig, Nothing
description: Bud Selig, who has been called the acting commissioner by people in and out of baseball for four and a half years, is not the commissioner of Major League Baseball, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Growth Rate In 4th Quarter Cut to 3.9%
description: The economy grew at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the fourth quarter, slower than the 4.7 percent estimated originally, the Commerce Department said today. A measure of inflation remained at a 30-year low.

title: Rutgers Union Rejects Offer
description: The union representing faculty members at Rutgers University turned down an offer yesterday that would have provided immediate raises of 10 percent to the 175 professors who have been promoted since their contract expired nearly two years ago. The union is holding out for increases of 12 percent and 13 percent, said Wells H. Keddie, the chief negotiator for the American Association of University Professors. In a counteroffer, the union said it would accept the 10 percent raise on an interim basis if the administration agreed to make up the difference after a contract agreement is reached, Mr. Keddie said.

title: Newspaper Says McVeigh Described Role in Bombing
description: One month before the trial in the Oklahoma City bombing case is to start here, a bitter row broke out today over a news paper report that a defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, told one of his lawyers that he had driven the truck used in the bombing and that he had decided on a daytime attack to insure a ''body count.''

title: Watching Out for Camden
description: New Jersey's poorest city, Camden, may need more oversight from state officials, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday. The Governor said that she would not recommend a state takeover but might seek legislation to give her administration a greater hand in Camden's financial affairs. The fiscal year is more than half over, Camden has yet to approve its budget and the state has had to give the city an extra $8.3 million to help with its $11 million deficit, said Christopher B. Wolf, a spokesman for the State Department of Community Affairs.

title: Cigna to Buy Healthsource, Vaulting Ahead in H.M.O.'s
description: The Cigna Corporation, playing catch-up in the fast-consolidating health insurance field, agreed yesterday to buy Healthsource Inc., a troubled managed health care company, for $1.45 billion in cash. Cigna would also assume $250 million of Healthsource debt.

title: Japan's Road to Deep Deficit Is Paved With Public Works
description: When the national and local governments built a $4 million ''agricultural airport'' in this small town in northern Japan, they said it would allow local farmers to get higher prices for their vegetables by flying them to market while still fresh instead of sending them by truck, a three-day trip.

title: Janet Walker, 71, Director of Musical Revivals
description: Janet Hayes Walker, the founder and producing director of the York Theater Company, an Off Broadway theater known for its revivals of American musicals from the recent past, died on Feb. 20 at Memorial Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: No 'Cleopatra' Matinee
description: Today's matinee performance of ''Antony and Cleopatra'' at the Joseph Papp Public Theater has been canceled because its star, Vanessa Redgrave, is ill. Tickets for the matinee and last night's canceled performance, will be refunded at point of purchase. Ms. Redgrave is expected to appear as scheduled in tonight's performance and tomorrow's matinee.

title: Clinton Burnishes Image as Protector of Children, Not Hotelier
description: For the second time this week, it was Vice President Al Gore's job today to introduce a youngster, who had the loftier task of introducing the President of the United States.

title: Colombia Cited For a 2d Year For Drug Trade
description: The decision in Washington to decertify Colombia's efforts to fight drug trafficking for the second year in a row -- but without imposing economic sanctions -- came as a bitter reproach but also a relief to Colombians who had lobbied hard for the country's approval.

title: Time Waster or Life Saver? Tougher Tobacco Rules Go Into Effect
description: By lunch hour today, the line waiting to pay at Discount Cigarettes' Cigar Vault was six or seven deep, and Wanda Payette, the cashier, was taking no chances. On the first day of new Federal regulations that require retailers to have all tobacco customers up to age 27 prove they are at least 18, she was checking everybody.

title: Stocks Fall Again as Dow Drops 47.33
description: Stock prices fell for the third straight day yesterday, as many technology stocks continued to slump and investors became cautious in the wake of Alan Greenspan's warning about ''excessive optimism'' in the financial markets.

title: Long Bond Unchanged in Mixed Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as end-of-month buying partly offset investors' concern that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates to keep the economy from overheating.

title: Big East Women Grumble Over Tournament Format
description: When the Big East women's basketball tournament begins Saturday at Gampel Pavilion, the teams with the best records will be Connecticut (27-0 over all, 18-0 in the conference), Notre Dame (25-5, 17-1), Boston College (17-9, 13-5) and West Virginia (18-11, 11-7).

title: Mining Gold From Black Preachers
description: A quick look around almost any mass-market bookstore will provide ample evidence that inspirational books, heavy with words of hope and encouragement, command a big market. And yet Rhinold L. Ponder, a lawyer and literary agent in New Brunswick, N.J., said he saw a gap in this abundance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, WALTER
description: KRAUS-Walter. The Board of Directors, participants, staff and members of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children/ New York City, are deeply saddened by the passing of Walter Kraus, a good friend of the Association and loving husband of Anne Kraus. We send our deepest condolences to Anne, a valued staff member, pillar of the Association and its former president, her son Lawrence Kraus and his wife Laurie, and Walter and Anne's grandchildren, Mark and Jason, on this unhappy occasion. Walter and Anne are in our thoughts and prayers. The family of the Association embraces its members. Marilyn Jaffe-Ruiz, President Michael Goldfarb, Exec Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JANE CARTER
description: JOHNSON-Jane Carter, born St. Louis, Mo., died February 25, New York City. Predeceased by father, Crawford Johnson, and mother, Jane Burns Johnson. Survived by Valerie Westheimer. Services private. Memorial to be announced.

title: For India, the Independent Numbers
description: The French find Paul Taylor's humor only too broad when, in fact, all his choreography is full of nuance. The detail is in the movement, and every Taylor work requires keen looking.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VENETIOU, JAMES JOHN
description: VENETIOU-James John. March 1, 1996. Memorial service on the 1st anniversary will be held at St. Catherine's and St. George, 22-28 33rd St., Astoria, Sunday, March 2, at 10 A.M. Your beloved memory will remain with us forever. Love, Bud, Irene, family and friends here and in Greece.

title: Estonian Conductor Presents a Compatriot's Concerto
description: The rise of Arvo Part has given us an image of Estonian music as spaced out and ineffable, so it was good to have Neeme Jarvi, himself Estonian, showing us in his concert with the Philharmonic on Thursday that his country can also produce music that is crude and unpleasant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget misstated a Senate vote tally in some editions. A proposal by Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, to exclude Social Security receipts and expenses from budget calculations was rejected by a vote of 55 to 44, not 65 to 35.

title: Family's Anger Lingers In Police Killing of Cook
description: Dozens of candles light the spot where Jose Antonio Sanchez, a cook and part-time comedian in Corona, was slain by a detective's bullet in a raid on a Queens restaurant last weekend during a routine police crackdown on unlicensed clubs.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decline in AIDS deaths gave inconsistent figures in some editions for the percentage decline in deaths nationally for the first six months of 1996. The figure for the decline stated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta was 13 percent, but the agency provided a rounded estimate of the numbers of deaths, which worked out to a decline of 12 percent. The exact numbers are not yet available.

title: In Afghanistan, a Dangerous Peace
description: After five years of fighting, the Afghan civil war finally seems on the verge of ending. Nothing is ever sure in Central Asia, where alliances are fluid and the balance of power precarious. But foreign diplomats, Government officials in Uzbekistan and aid agency workers seem persuaded that the victory of the Pakistani-backed fundamentalist Taliban militia may be only a few months away.

title: When Fiction Seems Too Real
description: A librarian and literacy teacher who works in Harlem has filed a $100 million libel suit against Joe Klein, a.k.a. Anonymous, the author of the 1995 novel ''Primary Colors,'' and his publisher, Random House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, HERMAN Z
description: FINKELSTEIN-Herman Z. Loving husband of Sybil Blossom. Beloved father of Brett and Susan. Grandfather of Harry. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM, Schwartz Bros. Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills.

title: The First Glimmers of a Planetarium Remade
description: The earth is new, the universe is new, and New York can be new again, too. That's the sunny idea declared by the design for the new planetarium that the American Museum of Natural History intends to build on its Upper West Side campus. With its shimmering, 90-foot sphere floating inside a crystal cube, the new building takes a cue from astronomy: architecture, too, can raise our sights higher.

title: A Band That Grammy Forgot
description: DERRICK DOLPHIN, a member of the group Primordial Source, has the record company lingo down pat. When he talks about his band's latest album, ''Polarity,'' he enthusiastically tosses out phrases like ''moving the product to a higher level.'' He could start by hauling seven boxes filled with copies of the disk out of the closet of his Washington Heights apartment, since the only higher level there is the roof.

Maples, a leading forensic anthropologist who sought to identify the skeletal remains of prominent figures dating back as far as the 1500's and at times sought to ascertain the circumstances of mysterious deaths, died on Thursday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. title: BIOFIELD'S STOCK FALLS AFTER F.D.A. REJECTS ITS DEVICE
description: The stock of the Biofield Corporation tumbled 55 percent yesterday after Federal regulators rejected an application for the company's Alexa 1000 breast cancer detection system. Biofield said the Food and Drug Administration did not accept the findings from a study of the device because of concerns over the study's design. The Alexa 1000 is a device for detecting malignant breast lesions without exposing the patient to radiation. Biofield would probably have to submit additional data to the F.D.A. that would be based either on completed clinical studies or on additional clinical trials, the latter of which could take 12 to 18 months, analysts said. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Biofield's stock fell $5.75 a share to close at $4.75.

title: Police Kill 2 Bank Robbery Suspects in a Wild Gun Battle

title: Finding Lost Children

Part of the problem was poor interagency communication. The Giuliani administration is now taking welcome steps to improve coordination between the Board of Education and the Administration for Children's Services.

title: Paul Otto Heyer, 60, Architecture Professor
description: Paul Otto Heyer, a professor and former president of the New York School of Interior Design, died on Feb. 22 at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived on the Upper West Side, where he also had an architectural office.

title: Compromise May Be in Works on Acquisition by Staples
description: Federal antitrust regulators have canceled a meeting planned for Saturday to review -- and possibly block -- Staples Inc.'s proposed acquisition of Office Depot Inc., officials said today.

title: INTUIT STOCK FALLS WITH PROJECTED REVENUE SLOWDOWN
description: The shares of Intuit Inc. fell to a 52-week low yesterday, a day after the company said revenue in coming quarters would be crimped by slowing growth in the market for personal-finance software. In bidding down the stock, investors sloughed off the better-than-expected second-quarter earnings that the company posted on Thursday. Though revenue in the second quarter was about $12 million to $14 million short of expectations, the company compensated by cutting costs. The company expects revenue of $600 million to $620 million in its current fiscal year, just shy of analysts' forecasts of about $640 million. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, the stock fell $2.75, to $22.625. The shares had been as low as $20.875 earlier.

title: Variations on a Spanish Theme Steeped in Tradition
description: A DEFINING CHARACTERISTIC OF modernism in the arts has been a softening of distinctions between ''high'' and ''low,'' with Picasso's discovery of African tribal sculpture, the Futurists' fascination with the machine, and the pervasive influence of jazz on composers as disparate as Ravel, Stravinsky and Copland. In Spain, isolated from the rest of Europe by the impervious wall of the Pyrenees, it was flamenco, the passionate, quasi-mystical idiom of the Gypsies of Andalusia, that exerted its magical influence on the nation's art.

title: San Diego's Spanish Accent
description: San Diego is one of the few American cities where you can get on a downtown streetcar and wind up a few minutes later in a foreign country, Tijuana being only a few miles away. Some Mexican local color has percolated northward into the town center, but most of San Diego's Mexican or Iberian look has been artificially created by English speakers. Though the city's population is only about 20 percent Hispanic, even the ''Anglo'' suburbs that clamber along the brinks of canyons and arroyos tend to break out in a rash of red-tiled roofs and round arches and little domed belfries. And though the freeway system shears on the bias through these and most other communities, most have retained a surprising degree of inner consistency.

title: Bruges in the Silent Hours
description: By 7 P.M., church bells and bird song replace the din of day trippers departing from Bruges. They've taken snapshots of each other standing arm in arm on brick and stone arched bridges spanning narrow canals that unwind behind them like ribbons. They've smiled through steam rising from bowls of briny mussels and been surprised by the punch of Straffe Hendrik, the golden, locally brewed beer. They've climbed the 366 steps to the top of the 13th-century belfry and stared through gray space across red tiled roofs and the city's medieval walls to Flanders's flat fields. They've toured opulent guild halls and humble almshouses and stood hushed before Michelangelo's delicate white marble Mother and Child in Notre Dame. Now they board buses for home and the 20th century.

title: Whatever Went Wrong With Amy?
description: IN a way, Amy Duggan Archer Gilligan might be considered a pioneer in health care in Connecticut. In the early part of this century, Mrs. Gilligan operated a home ''for elderly people and chronic invalids,'' in the town of Windsor. She offered some enticements for living there: Most of her clients were elderly men and they could get lifetime care simply by signing over their life insurance policies to her or by giving her $1,000, a healthy amount of money at the time, when they checked in. In 1916, however, Mrs. Gilligan was arrested. State police, after an investigation, concluded that she had shortened the lives of up to two dozen or so men by poisoning them with arsenic. One of them was Michael W. Gilligan, her second husband. The union had lasted three months when Mr. Gilligan turned up dead. The arrest of Mrs. Gilligan and her trial in 1917, after many bodies had been exhumed, rocked the state; there were headlines that would do credit to today's tabloids: ''Police Believe Archer Home for Aged a Murder Factory,'' screamed The Hartford Courant's Page 1 on the morning of May 9, 1916, the day after Mrs. Gilligan was arrested. It set the tone.

title: The Man Behind The Duel Between Irish Blockbusters

Overnight, the step-dance form, long regarded as a quaint pursuit of specialists, turned into a mainstream sensation. Last July, a competing show, the even glitzier ''Lord of the Dance,'' opened to similar frenzy. And on Tuesday ''Lord of the Dance'' will start its first United States tour at Radio City Music Hall, almost exactly a year after ''Riverdance'' did the same thing on the same stage.

title: An American Epic of Love and Loss
description: CONNECTICUT OPERA has created a 40th-anniversary production of one of the glories of American opera, Douglas Moore's ''The Ballad of Baby Doe.'' Moore attended the Hotchkiss School and Yale, where he wrote songs for social events on campus, but the opera's setting is Colorado at the turn of the century. And the libretto, by the poet John Latouche, is carved from a true story of dreams and defeat, love and loss. ''It is a passionate American epic,'' says the Connecticut Opera's general director, George Osborne. ''It has a melodic, romantic score.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOACHIM, FLORENCE B
description: JOACHIM-Florence B. The staff of Printing News/East announce with deep sorrow the death of our beloved Editor and Publisher on February 28, 1997 at the age of 84. A native of San Luis Obispo, CA, Florence was the loving wife of the late Leo H. Joachim, who in 1929 founded Printing News, the weekly publication she served continuously from 1948 until failing health forced her retirement earlier this year. During that time she acted as production manager, editor, associate publisher, sales director, and publisher. She also collaborated with Leo on the Production Yearbook and other special publications for the graphic arts. After her husband's death in 1985, Mrs. Joachim guided Printing News through several changes of ownership to its present successful association with PTN Publishing Co's Graphic Arts Network. A legend among printers in the NYC Metro area for her tireless efforts to promote their interests in the pages of Printing News, she is remembered with special affection as the author of Pi a la Mode, a weekly column on the doings of the paper's many close friends throughout the industry. She held nearly all of the printing community's highest honors including induction into the New York Printers Wall of Fame, the Luminaire Award from Women in Production, and the Navigators Service To Industry Award. Florence was educated at the University of Southern California where she earned membership in Phi Beta Kappa for her studies in Greek. In keeping with Florence's wishes cremation took place privately. Further information will be published in Printing News/East.

title: MOMMY, WHAT'S A CLASSROOM?
description: I'm 14 years old and have been a student in public school, in Atlanta, since kindergarten. I know some people who have home-schooled, and they say it's great, but I don't buy it. It seems to me that if your parents are your teachers, you only learn what they want you to learn, and you are only exposed to their political beliefs and their teaching styles. Also, you miss out on spending time with friends, away from parents; participating in school clubs; completing assignments without the assistance of a parent and being part of a small community (the school), which is preparation for living in the world.

But a few models were smiling on the runways recently, and in last month's Vogue, Kate Moss was smiling twice. There's even a rumor of a Smile Police at Conde Nast who enforce a smile quota per issue. This might be good news for some people, but not for me.

title: Millions in the Bank, if They Don't Stumble
description: WITH years of economic growth and restructuring under their belts, many companies are sitting on mountains of cash. In the auto industry, for instance, Ford and Chrysler have reserves of $15.4 billion and $7.8 billion, respectively. And the $17 billion General Motors had in its pocket at the start of 1997 is $6.8 billion more than it had 12 months earlier. That means G.M. was socking away about $19 million a day in 1996 -- nearly $1 million an hour.

title: Cruise Safety

I studied the item carefully to discover the number and capacity of lifeboats, but to no avail. With all the recent interest in the fate of the Titanic and her passengers, this information would have been of great interest.

title: Twilight for TV's Old Troupers
description: The recent death of Don Porter, who played Ann Southern's boss in the 1950's situation comedy ''Private Secretary,'' is a reminder that the first generation of TV situation-comedy performers is vanishing fast. Marjorie Reynolds, who was William Bendix's wife in ''The Life of Riley'' died in February, too. Jesse White, another Ann Southern veteran, died in January, as did Sheldon Leonard, a TV producer who is probably better remembered by viewers of a certain age as Danny Thomas's manager on ''Make Room for Daddy.''

He is survived by his beloved wife Sophie of 58 years; son, Dr. Gary Feldbau; Daughter, Shelly Schack; 6 grandchildren; and 2 sisters; Margaret and Edith. title: Honors for a Slain Educator
description: There is little doubt that Edward Funk was a strong influence in Queens Village. As the principal of Public School 33, he was known for his interest in students. On the first day of kindergarten, he made it a point to visit each class and lie down on a big piece of paper so the students could trace his outline. When a child did not go to school, he would circle the neighborhood in his car. He opened the gymnasium after school for children who had no place to go.

title: Confessions Of a Sybarite Sailor
description: You can't really call me Ishmael. Unlike the narrator of ''Moby-Dick,'' when it's a damp, drizzly November in my soul, I don't usually climb aboard a boat and explore the watery parts of the world. For one thing, I'm prone to seasickness. For another, I don't care for forced confinement with hundreds of strangers on long cruises. But then I learned about the M.S. River Cloud. Elegant, stylish, romantic and reminiscent of the legendary Orient Express, claimed the brochure. Color photos showed a sleek white ship, recently constructed to cruise European waterways and combining up-to-the-minute marine engineering with classic lines and a high degree of luxury.

title: Getting Fit, Far From the Macho Crowd
description: IN the early 1980's, health clubs were promoted as the new singles bars, wholesome places to meet the exerciser of your dreams. A decade later, they were known as ''the nightclubs of the 90's,'' so called by David Barton, whose self-named Chelsea gym epitomized the more frenetic, sexually charged atmosphere. Now, some health clubs are bowing out of the matchmaking business, creating women-only workout areas that appeal to the I'm-not-looking and I-don't-want-to-be-seen.

description: Tyeisha Ross, an 18-year-old who has H.I.V., is street smart but childishly innocent. So she often misses doctor's appointments and fails to take medications.

title: Murky Past
description: For SPELLBOUND (1945), his ripely romantic suspense thriller, Alfred Hitchcock began with fortuitous ingredients: the two top Hollywood stars of the day, Ingrid Bergman (above) and Gregory Peck. They portray a vulnerable psychiatrist and a new sanitarium chief, a troubled man with a secret. The smitten pair run off together as she probes his past and implication in two deaths. Hitchcock decorates his tale with Miklos Rozsa's luscious music, wintry landscapes, art by Salvador Dali (for dreams) and vignettes by a fine supporting cast. It all works entertainingly, if not always credibly -- SATURDAY at 5 P.M. and 11:15 P.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: Bookshelf
description: THE THIEF. By Megan Whalen Turner. Greenwillow. $15. (Ages 10 and up) Gen, the narrator, has been plucked from prison because the king's scholar needs a thief clever enough to pry an ancient treasure from the place where he thinks it is hidden. The setting combines ancient and modern Greece. A 1997 Newbery Honor Book.

description: C. Brooks Peters, who covered the outbreak of World War II from Berlin for The New York Times, died on Thursday at his apartment on the Upper West Side. He was 84.

title: A Style Made For the Strains Of Love Lost
description: IT MAY BE TIME TO PUT IN A WORD for the songs of Guillaume de Machaut, which seem to have slipped through whatever nets we are using at the moment to trawl the past. This was not always the case. In the early 1970's, Machaut's music was waking up after a sleep of six centuries -- and waking up to find itself in a welcoming world. Ensembles here and in Europe began to perform his songs regularly; records were made; books were published.

description: O.K., so there's no mint on the pillow, but there is one just blocks away. No, you can't sneak any dirty movies, but you can watch ESPN to your heart's content. And no, sadly, there are no ''magic fingers'' -- unless you count the ones that mysteriously extract tens of thousands of dollars from some guests' pockets without a promise of anything, no sir, not even a fluffy white bathrobe or a lousy bar of soap, in return.

title: An American Exile in America
description: Naomi Wallace is an Amerian playwright whose work has gone largely unproduced in America, her plays routinely described as ''strong but political,'' whereas in England she has had four major productions in as many years, with a striking amount of critical attention awarded each of them. Last year, however, her newest play, ''One Flea Spare,'' was the consensus hit at the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky. Now, having won a raft of awards, it is set to open next Sunday at the Joseph Papp Public Theater in New York, with Dianne Wiest in the lead role. Wallace is finally about to be discovered by her compatriots - although some of them have known for years that recognition at home was foregone conclusion.

title: Haley Mindes, Daniel Rapaport

title: Traffic Relief At Madrid Airport

title: BUILDING A ROOM OF MY OWN
description: Having built and designed both our vacation cabin and retirement home, as well as working for Habitat for Humanity, I agree with Michael Pollan that you can get tremendous satisfaction from such projects (''Building a Room of My Own,'' Feb. 9). However, I was disappointed at his choice of scarce, expensive timber for a beginner's project. Judging from the photographs, his Douglas fir corner posts are all but obscured by the bookshelves, table and window trim. A more abundant and local material might have salved his conscience and saved money.

description: DEB MARGOLIN HAS POISED herself at the brink this time. Not that the performance artist has ever shied from charg ed material -- pregnancy, being Jewish, a collaboration entitled ''Lesbians Who Kill.'' But an artist taking on the subject of criticism? She might as well rush headlong into a hungry propeller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ESTELLE GRACE (NEE LIEBERMAN)
description: FRIEDMAN-Estelle Grace (nee Lieberman), 77, on February 5, 1997. ''Eaychet Chayil''. Devoted and self sacrificing; Mother of Kenneth, Gary, and Stanley. Mother-in-law of Dayle and Jane. Grandmother of Jeremy, Kayla, Wesley, Joshua, Ashley and Courtney. Sister of Regina and Harry Presser, and Esther Lokiec. Friend. Estelle graduated Thomas Jefferson High School Class of '36 and earned a B.S. German atBrooklyn College, Class of '40. She worked for the U.S. Department of Censorship during WWII. M.S. English, Columbia University in the late 1940's. English teacher Wm. E. Grady High School, 1948-1952 and Francis Lewis High School 1969-1981. Member U.F.T. Former congregant New Hyde Park Jewish Center. Caretaker and lover of animals. Advocate of Holistic living. Author/Poet. Felled by massive brain stem strokeMarch 2, 1996. Left paralyzedquadriplegic-from mouth to toes''Locked-in Syndrome''. Mind, eyes, and ears unaffected by stroke. Only means of communication through opening-yes and closing-no, of eyes. Suffered in silence for 340 days. Each an Eternity unto itself! Only beacon of light was through bonding and compassion of caretakers: Barbara Thorpe, CNA; William Muniz, Paramedic; and Dr. George Azar Jr.,-Pulmonary/Internist; at Vencor Hospital, Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Burial was on February 7, 1997 at New Montefiore Cemetery. Donations may be made to: American Heart Association-Stroke Division, and Long Island Humane Society. Your memory will live on in our hearts, your dreams will be realized through our actions!

title: BETTER COPS, FEWER ROBBERS

description: At the very least, Doug Gilmour's arrival from Toronto has transformed the Devils into something they often weren't for much of the past few seasons: fun to watch.

title: On Safari In Grand Style
description: THE first thing to know about making a safari in Kenya and Tanzania, as I did for two weeks last winter, is that everyone except travel agents will tell you not to. Those who have not been there will warn you that it's dangerous, pointing to a very few incidents in which tourists have been killed by bandits or poachers (and very, very occasionally by the animals, mostly when the victim stepped out of the vehicle despite being told not to do so).

title: Bumped Out of Town
description: THE sight of 500 Russian children, formally dressed and primly waltzing on a Sunday morning, is one of the endearing moments of the annual ballroom competition of the Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing. The Imperial's four-day event, which began Thursday, traditionally draws Russian families from four dance schools in Brooklyn and one in Clifton.

title: In a Ring, Love's Paradoxes Unfold
description: WHY does anybody want to wear jewelry? Because the custom of adorning ourselves with baubles is both barbaric and refined. Jewels, the arts patron Lincoln Kirstein once remarked, are metaphors for perfection. They are also primitive signs of grossly material display.

title: Help Is in Place For Abused Horses

It says that it is Ms. Devlin's dream ''to turn her farm into Connecticut's first home for abused and neglected horses.'' In fact such a center has been in existence since 1981.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LENZ, ARTHUR
description: LENZ-Arthur. Dad, 25 years later we still miss you. Our memories are filled with the lessons you taught us, the love you gave us, the dairy shelf and the Mets. Give Mom a kiss from us. Love, Nina and Henry

title: THE NORTHLAND'S SWEET REVENGE
description: For those of us who soldier through a Minnesota winter without cheating (no charter to Cancun, no week on Sanibel), springtime means lilac time, that choice tenderloin of May. These heartbreakingly brief mid-May days are the revenge of the northland. Dream on, zones seven and eight. The lilac refuses you. To thrive lilacs require the winter dormancy of a hard freeze. Then, in a pent-up burst, they flood the Upper Midwest with their drowsy scent and the decadent Victorian purple and lavender-gray and clotted cream of their flowerets set amid their ''heart-shaped leaves,'' as Whitman called them.

title: Our Africa
description: The faded and sketchy map spread across the hood of the Jeep suggests that only 150 miles separate the Kenyan frontier town of Lokichokio from the Sudanese village of Chukudum. But there are no filling stations between here and Chukudum - there is nothing between here and Chukudum - wo we strap jerry-cans of gasoline to the roof of the Jeep, just in case. A Kenyan Army patrol arrives and escorts us to the border. The escort is meant to protect us from bandits and cattle raiders, who riddle the area. At the border, we are met by guerrillas of the Sudan People's Liberation Army. I am heading for a meeting with a commander of the S.P.L.A., and the guerrillas quickly pass us through the border, which is marked by a branch laid across the dirt road.

title: When the Greens Beckon in Winter

Brian Kelly, 42, of Middletown, arrived at the Leisure Resort at Banner in Moodus around 11 A.M. one recent Saturday. And it was positively balmy compared with Jan. 26 when Mr. Kelly and his friends played their annual Super Bowl Sunday golf game in temperatures that never went higher than the teens. title: Digging Deep for Treasures From Every Era of the Past
description: SONY CLASSICAL HOLDS the deed to a deep, rich vein of recording history: the legacy of Columbia Masterworks. And the new owner has already mined there often, unearthing gems of varying weight, value and condition. Now, as if laying down the pick ax in favor of digital tools, Sony has dug deeper and more purposefully to recover a glittering lode of recordings, issued under the title Masterworks Heritage.

title: Don't Worry. A Brain Still Can't Be Cloned.

Knowing that a photograph is only skin deep, people in the developed lands find such terror absurd. But the fear that one's very identity might be stolen, that one could cease to be an individual, runs deep even in places where cameras seem benign.

title: A Brazilian Wetland, Burgeoning With Wildlife

Glistening like marbles, they duck underwater in a soundless vertical drop as we pass their field of vision. There is something hypnotic and frightening about the utter completeness of their disappearance, leaving just a momentary bubble or two behind. The image spreads a chilling, primordial unease in our little fishing boat, a reminder of nature's fancy for the perfect crime. Our metal spinner trails behind us, a phony fish flashing sunlight in the water; we hope it will trick dinner, a pintado or golden dorado, into our boat.

title: Imagining Emily

Even the most diligent scholars let their hair down when they write about Dickinson, believing, as she did, that the best way to tell any truth is to ''tell it slant.'' (And one could argue that the circuitous route of fiction also happens to be the only way to tell the truth of this particular life, as Dickinson left very few traces of her life behind.) Few literary figures have occasioned such a range of creative response, the latest of which is the extraordinary epistolary novel ''I Never Came to You in White,'' by Judith Farr, which is set during the year that the 17-year-old Dickinson spent at boarding school in South Hadley, Mass.

title: Moon Over Manatee
description: Dave Barry kicks off NAKED CAME THE MANATEE (Putnam, $22.95) by introducing a 102-year-old Coconut Grove environmentalist named Marion McAlister Williams and a lovable, pea-brained manatee called Booger. Into the murky world of these two endangered species drops a metal canister whose contents could unleash ''the big one,'' the announcement Cuban Miami has been waiting for. So begins this wacky romp of a novel, originally serialized in The Miami Herald's Tropic magazine, with each of a baker's dozen of chapters contributed by one of South Florida's finest writers. Before they're done, the thermodynamic 13 (whose ranks include Elmore Leonard, Carl Hiaasen and Edna Buchanan) will have dropped into this imbroglio more than 20 delectable denizens of Dade County and a couple of cryonically preserved heads that look like Fidel Castro's. Aside from the speedboat ride of a plot -- ''a three-beer story,'' as one character puts it -- there's the pleasure of listening to these masters play with the language and conventions of the mystery genre, manipulating cliches (yes, there's a moon over Miami) and dopey lines, picking up threads previous chapter writers have left behind while deftly upping the ante. ''Naked Came the Manatee'' is a deliciously twisted paean to South Florida, to its color, corruption, cacophony and Cubano culture. Philip Gambone

title: Enough Already? Never!
description: The architect Morris Lapidus was a post-modernist long before the term existed. Shunned by architectural critics for most of his shamelessly successful career, Mr. Lapidus, the designer of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach and other monuments to excess, is just coming into his own, at the age of 94. In his autobiography, TOO MUCH IS NEVER ENOUGH (Rizzoli, $45), Mr. Lapidus traces his populist style to his first vision of electric lights at Coney Island's Luna Park as a young Russian immigrant in the early 20th century. He developed a flamboyant visual lexicon, using ''woggles'' (free-form, amoebalike shapes), ''cheese holes'' (recessed circular lights in walls and ceilings), ''beanpoles'' (ornamental metal rods) and flying ''stairways to nowhere'' that were built mainly so that hotel guests could show off their evening clothes. Though steeped in classical architecture, he went on to create a delirious melange of French Provincial and Italian Renaissance styles -- with a splashy use of color (the Fontainebleau's interiors somehow combined 27 colors) and by lavishing ornament on top of ornament -- that critics derided as ''Miami Beach French.'' Today, Mr. Lapidus has been rediscovered by a generation of post-modernist architects, including Rem Koolhaas and Philippe Starck. For one who spent decades in critical exile, Mr. Lapidus maintains a remarkably unbitter tone. However, he claims too many innovations; certainly German Expressionist architects used indirectly lighted ceilings long before he did in 1929. The book would benefit from more color plates to deliver the full impact of Mr. Lapidus's exuberant vision. Eric Nash

Torricelli, would agree to cast the deciding vote in favor of the balanced-budget amendment.

Her father, she says, would have been proud.

title: Sorry, the Professional Class Is Full
description: In the spring of 1991, professors were being laid off across the country alongside plumbers, managers and bank tellers, but I was on the inside -- in one of those comfortable college teaching jobs where bad news isn't about you. Then word started getting around Colgate University that I had been fired. A student came up to me after class one morning and gave me the lay of the land. ''Man, not another baby boomer out of work,'' he said, shaking his head. ''Every time one of you guys loses his real job, you take the jobs at Blockbuster and the mall so I can't even pick up summer work.''

I applaud Wynton's mission to educate today's generation to appreciate classic jazz, just as I welcome both his and Jarrett's interest in Bach. And I defy anyone who has heard Wynton wailing on the trumpet to question his chops or his sense of blues.

title: On Tibet's Friendship Highway Potholes and All
description: For centuries, the struggle to reach ''the roof of the world'' enhanced the mysterious appeal of Tibet. The arduous quests of the past are obviously no longer possible -- not least because of the Chinese occupation of the country -- but the idea of dropping down into Tibet by jet, then taking a taxi to the Lhasa Holiday Inn, still struck me as a shabby affront to a great tradition. Even today, Tibet ought to mean the journey as well as the place.

title: Have Loyalty Will Travel
description: He has plenty of good years left. He bats right, throws left. During tense base-running situations, he tends to order a beer. He's Michael Volpe, a 44-year-old from Falls Church, Va., and he has declared himself pprofessional baseball's first ''free agent fan''-- meaning that he's miffed at his old team and is looking for a new one. To date, four major-league teams (the Orioles, Mets, Phillies and Marlins) have brought him in for courtship rituals. The Yankees talked to him about throwing a game-opening pitch, but he didn't bite. ''This isn't about me getting something,'' he says. ''For me to sign up a team, has to show sincerity.''

We, the citizens and taxpayers of White Plains, are pleased that the double-digit yearly tax increases, the highest-paid teachers and administrators (14.75 percent cost of living increase) in Westchester County if not in New York State or the nation and the over $100 million school budget for under 6,000 students has at last shown some tangible results.

Had that been Tom Brokaw Evers chased down a hallway, America would have seen a different picture on the evening news.

title: STILL GUNNING
description: Ask Bob Dornan - the former Congressman whose fiery right-wing orations earned him the nick-name B-1 Bob - about the liberals who used to mock him, and his next career move starts to make sense. ''I spoke with passion and conviction,'' Dornan fumes during an otherwise cheerful conversation. ''To have it trashed by wimps, by people who have hired whores and tried cocaine?'' Four months after losing his seat, Dorman is planning to become - what else? - a radio talk-show host. He's talking to three major networks about syndicating his spleen-venting nationally, hoping that the exposure and bucks show detractors that he's still a significant force. ''Earning $1,082,000 a year,'' Dornan says, lumping his House pension in with the $1 million per he optimistically assumes he'll make, ''is an excellent way to humble those who wrote you off.''

''My family never paid rent,'' Mr. Pascal said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, JACQUES
description: COE-Jacques. The entire partnership of Cowen & Company mourns the passing of our longtime friend and eminent colleague, Jacques Coe, 103. Widely recognized as the oldest active broker on Wall Street, Jacques joined Cowen & Company in 1964 as a limited partner. He epitomized an exceptional standard of service and integrity in the financial services industry and will be missed by all who knew and worked with him. Jacques will be remembered for his consummate professionalism, keen market insight, vibrant personality and sense of humor. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Coe family. As Jacques was a founder of the American Chess Association, and past president of the Manhattan Chess Club, contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Chess-in-the-Schools, The American Chess Center, 353 West 46th St., NYC 10036. title: Wildlife Refuges
description: To the Editor: One of the best-kept secrets in this country is the network of 511 national wildlife refuges (Correspondent's Report: ''Wildlife Bureau Weighs Eco-tourism Policy,'' Jan. 19). Our national parks are world famous, but our refuges are often barely known beyond their neighborhoods.

title: As Mines Fade, Workers Hunt for Jobs
description: The nice paycheck made up for the fact that Douglas Sanders seldom saw the sun. For more than 20 years, Mr. Sanders worked deep underground in the coal mines of northern Alabama, providing for his family and surviving the layoffs commonplace in this part of the country.

title: State Troopers Who Patrol the Information Highway
description: Like many of his colleagues in the New Jersey State Police, Trooper Michael Geraghty rides the highway. But his is infinitely more complex to patrol than the turnpike or the Garden State Parkway.

title: After Tripping on Its Laces, Reebok Is Focused Again
description: FEBRUARY was not the finest of months for Reebok International. First, the country's largest pension fund, the California Public Employees Retirement System, named it to its annual ''top 10 financial laggards.'' Calpers, which owns around 600,000 shares, vowed to urge the company to improve its performance.

title: On the Neptune, Three Years Under Sail
description: TWO hundred years ago. the largest sailing ship ever built in New Haven set out for China on a journey that would last almost three years. The trip -- along the coast of South America, the Falkland Islands, Hawaii (then known as the Sandwich Islands), Canton and Penang -- would bring renown and prosperity to its captain, crew and owner.

title: Chasing The Beale Street Blues
description: When the old blues singers Son House and Robert Johnson and many before them had only just invented the blues from plantation ''moans,'' and had made the guitar an American instrument, they spoke of going on the road to find audiences for their songs. The road they were talking about was old Highway 61, which took the blues out of the Mississippi Delta, lured jazz and Dixieland out of New Orleans and sent them straight to Memphis. In Memphis the music changed from country blues to city blues before traveling on to St. Louis and Chicago, and from there to the rest of the world.

title: Alone, in a Crowd
description: William S. Cohen, the new Secretary of Defense, stands alone. He is the only Republican in the Cabinet of a Democratic President. Do you stand alone in your office? Are you the only woman in an office full of men, or the only man in an office of women? Or maybe you're a liberal surrounded by conservatives. Has your unique status caused any interesting situations in your office? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Crime
description: DEATH IS NOW MY NEIGHBOR (Crown, $24), another deviously constructed Inspector Morse mystery from the masterly hand of Colin Dexter, opens with a lesson on the proper use of the pluperfect subjunctive in Latin. To this lovely piece of pedantry are added surprise quizzes (with multiple-choice answers), clues to impenetrable crosswords, Latin proverbs (''Initium est dimidium facti,'' or ''Once you've started, you're halfway there''), German lieder lyrics and the cryptic thoughts of everyone from Voltaire to tabloid gossip columnists. For good measure, the author also finds occasion to put Morse on a train to Paddington that passes Cholsey, the village where Agatha Christie is buried.

title: Renovation of Church Pits Parishioners Against Priest
description: The Easter midnight Mass at St. Mary's Romanian Orthodox Church began last spring with the Rev. Casian Fetea emerging from behind the newly built altar with a lit candle. He touched it to the nearest church member's candle, and the half-built church became joyfully illuminated for the first time in years.

title: MOMMY, WHAT'S A CLASSROOM?
description: If home-schoolers need reassurance, let them turn to Thomas Alva Edison. He was hearing-impaired and uncomfortable in school. His mother's home-schooling didn't stifle his curiosity or creativity; he died with over 1,000 patents to his name.

title: Mega for a Day
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is urging the New York City Council to allow retail giants like Wal-Mart, Price Club and Toys ''R'' Us to build so-called megastores in Manhattan's vacant industrial spaces. Proponents say the stores would stanch the hemorrhage of sales-tax revenue that occurs when bargain-conscious shoppers flock to the suburbs. Opponents counter that these tacky, garish behemoths would ruin the city's identity by undercutting family-owned specialty stores, unique SoHo Shops and other distinctive Manhattan marts. This being New York, consensus is naturally impossible. But to check the grassroots mood, we assembled a group of Manhattanites, none of whom had ever been to a megastore, for a Saturday outing. Team members were carried into the Heart of Mega--suburban New Jersey's turnpike corridor--to decide for themselves. Here's a report.

But Paris was my first encounter with the leisurely, temperate, perfect European spring, a slow passage from winter dark to full summer light, and perhaps I am faithful to a memory.

title: An Art Tour Of Unexpected Glories
description: During the 19th century, the provincial cities of France often benefited from the hometown pride, philanthropy and taste of loyal sons. Perhaps in reaction to the historical concentration of art in Paris, these benefactors kept their artistic treasures at home, where they now form the basis of some truly wonderful local museums. Many of the best collections on display in the provincial museums were made by artists. As a cartoonist myself, I was delighted to find these were not just any artists, but good, solid second-rate artists with absolutely first-rate instincts -- men with tastes of a much higher order than their talents -- a condition with which I am proud to claim both personal familiarity and a fraternal sympathy. For example, three museums in the south of France were founded by artists to exhibit much better work than their own -- right alongside their own.

title: Don't Sabotage the Hearings

Mr. Lott has suggested that the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate President Clinton's fund-raising would obviate the need for the hearings planned by Senator Fred Thompson. Mr. Daschle is using Senator John Glenn as a cat's-paw to limit the budget and timetable of those hearings. Meanwhile, neither side is giving the push needed to keep campaign finance legislation moving in the Senate.

title: DIARY
description: STOCK MARKETReally, Mr. Greenspan?You can just feel investors squirming with confusion. ''Yes,'' they say, ''I bet Alan Greenspan is right when he says stocks might be too high, but I just can't bring myself'' -- the tone turns plaintive, a bit anguished, here -- ''to leave this party yet.'' All manner of theories have popped up to explain this endless party: there's a new era, a new way of defining stock value. But Mr. Greenspan dismissed this crisply on Wednesday. ''History,'' he said, ''is strewn with visions of such new eras.'' He did jolt the market that day, with the Dow off 122 at one point, but it ended down just 55 -- barely a pinprick -- and kept slipping the rest of the week. So what does history teach? Well, in 1929 and 1965, Fed officials warned of overvalued stock prices, but the real market drops were seven or eight months off. Next month you'll get out. Really. BALANCED-BUDGET AMENDMENTWe Tried, We Really TriedMost Americans focus on any given political issue for about 12 seconds. A balanced-budget amendment? Hmm. Sounds good. Shouldn't spend what you don't have. Yup, I'm for it, say 75 to 80 percent of the populace, then switch back to the ball game. Most of them have little inkling of the tradeoffs involved, and in fact only 25 percent favor this elusive balance if it dents Social Security benefits. Sound-bite politics or no, though, legislators ignore the popular will at their peril. So at regular intervals they stage this ritual of almost lining up support and then -- whoops! -- not quite making it. When this little dance was performed last week, Robert G. Torricelli, New Jersey's new Democratic Senator, was the man of the hour, potentially the decisive 67th vote. He was publicly courted by both sides, but in the end, yes, he went against the amendment -- and 66 senators could say in solemn tones that they'd fought the good fight.

title: The Living Landscape of Kenya

Herds of elephants calmly devoured tons of grass, while two rhinos crossed the road in front of our entourage. The stillness was deceptive; it belied a daily struggle for survival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DU VIVIER, PAUL FULLER
description: DU VIVIER-Paul Fuller, 82, a retired career diplomat, died of cancer Thursday, February 27 at his home in Hunt Valley, MD. Son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Du Vivier of New York and Paris and grandson of Dr. Edward Loughborough Keyes, a pioneer in Urology. Dr. Du Vivier was educated in France and graduated from Princeton University in 1938. He received his M.A. from Georgetown University and then entered the American Foreign Service, where he was posted to St. Johns, Newfoundland, and Marseilles. During WW II he was taken prisoner in France and held by the Germans for twoand-one-half years. After his release, he served in Accra, Ghana, Ottawa, Stockholm, Berlin, Paris, Bordeaux, Nice/Monaco, Edinburgh and Frankfurt. He retired in 1971 as a Consul General. In 1977 he received a Ph.D. from Georgetown University, and worked in the Rare Book section at Dumbarton Oaks. He also served on the Board of the Alliance Francaise, writing three books on French history and culture. His latest book, ''Tale of Three Cities,'' was published last year. In 1996 Princeton University honored him as ''Man of the Year'' from the Class of 1938 for his work with the French Resistance during WW II and for his long career in the Foreign Service. He was a member of the Metropolitan Club, The Atlantic Council, and DACOR (Diplomatic and Consular Officers Retired). Survivors include his wife of 53 years, Margaret; a son, Paul; a daughter, Anne; and two grandchildren. He will be buried at Oak Hill Cemetery in Washington, next to his great - great - great grandfather Nathan Loughborough, one of the founders of Georgetown. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Vision 2002, Cockeysville, MD 21030 appreciated.

description: Editors at The Dallas Morning News said yesterday that they were driven by a desire to match the immediacy of television -- and a more prosaic wish to prevent their exclusive from leaking out into competitors' hands -- when they decided to publish a major news story on their Web site the afternoon before it would appear in the daily paper.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CHEAP TRASH -- New York City is to begin exporting its trash to other states in July, and the bids for the contract are coming in lower than expected. B3.

title: Gore's Fund-Raising Casts a Political Shadow
description: On a September afternoon in 1993, eight months after the Clinton Administration had taken office, Vice President Al Gore used a borrowed room at a Los Angeles law firm to meet with about 30 members of the local Asian-American business community.

title: Sweden's Courteous Police Spoil A Hell's Angels Clubhouse Party
description: This was a bad weekend for the Hell's Angels in Scandinavia.

title: Woman Dies After Falling in Bookstore
description: A woman died after falling down a flight of stairs Saturday night at a Barnes & Noble superstore near Lincoln Center, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERMAN, PAUL
description: LEDERMAN-Paul. Of Long Beach, LI, and Delray Beach, FL, died on March 1, 1997. He will be remembered by his wife Marilyn, daughters Loren Fogelson, Sherri Mandell and Nancy Lederman, sons-in-law Richard Fogelson and Seth Mandell, and seven grandchildren in NY and in Israel. His warmth and humor will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Servies graveside, March 3, 1 PM, at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.
