title: Another Shortcut At the Gas Pump
description: Just as drivers are becoming used to paying by credit card at the pump, the Mobil Corporation has come up with an even faster way to buy gasoline -- a chore that most customers do not savor.

title: 'Parlez-Vous U.S.A.?' Means Loss of Solidarity
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing on a Nuclear Plant
description: Fans and foes of the troubled Salem nuclear power station will get a chance at a public meeting tomorrow to tell the Nuclear Regulatory Commission whether it should allow the plant, which has been closed since 1995, to reopen. The plant has been plagued by equipment and management problems that have led to frequent fines against the Public Service Electric & Gas Company, but the utility has been making repairs. The commission expects to reach a decision in April.

title: Chelsea Clinton's 22 Hours in New York
description: In the city that never sleeps, Chelsea Clinton apparently managed only a few winks. After a day of revelry that culminated in a star-studded supper, Chelsea, who was celebrating her 17th birthday, did not return to her quarters at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel until sometime between 2 and 2:30 A.M. yesterday. But she was up, dressed and on her way back to the White House by 8:30 A.M.

title: Camacho Isn't Sweet, Only Better
description: For five rounds, Sugar Ray Leonard had never looked worse. Hector (Macho) Camacho had never looked better.

title: For one drug whose original patent has expired, there are potential new uses and a silver lining.
description: SOMETIMES new uses are found for old innovations. But once a patent on a technology has expired, that technology cannot be patented again simply because a new application has been found. Thus, a conundrum: without a patent to protect them from imitators, companies are reluctant to spend money developing and marketing an old technology for a different purpose.

title: Second-Guessing Israel Stymies Peace Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Y.& R. to Link 2 Operating Units
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York said that it was forming a new operating entity by formally linking two of its largest operating units: Young & Rubicam Advertising and its direct marketing division, Wunderman Cato Johnson.

title: New Attention to Women in Military
description: In a one-room law office in a converted house here, the scourge of male traditionalists in America's military sits in a green wicker chair on a flowered cushion.

title: Cautious Americans Retreat To a Tie
description: While a buoyant crowd of 35,000 swayed to a reggae beat at Jamaica's National Stadium, the United States soccer team never found its own rhythm today as it began the final round of qualifying for the 1998 World Cup. A 0-0 tie produced a result for the Americans that was respectable, but hardly encouraging.

title: Cone Begins a New Chapter, and Reviews Are Good
description: Forget Joe Torre's attention-grabbing book for one day. Baseball returned to the forefront this afternoon. There was almost a disastrous collision between Darryl Strawberry and Bernie Williams, there was David Cone challenging Frank Thomas and Albert Belle, and there were beanballs. Torre's book was actually put aside for three hours.

title: Distribution Dispute Ensnarls Cablevision And Classic Sports
description: The Classic Sports Network has won a tiny but loyal audience for its daily lineup of vintage sporting events. Now, the fledgling cable network says that one of its biggest fans, Cablevision Systems Corporation, is punishing the network for refusing to sell it a piece of the action.

title: Q&A / Jacques Rupnik : Albania's Illusions:Life as a Lottery
description: The outburst of anti-government violence in Albania is the latest case of Balkan instability, apparently caused by the failure of democracy and prosperity to emerge faster from the ashes of Communist rule. Jacques Rupnik, director of research at the Center for International Studies in Paris, talked with Joseph Fitchett of the Herald Tribune about likely scenarios in the Albanian crisis.

title: Eager to Emulate Cloning Feat, a Team Looks to Cows
description: On Saturday, on a gray afternoon when students at the University of Wisconsin at Madison were showing their prize Holstein cattle, Dr. Miassam M. Matalipova was trying to make her own prize cow: a clone.

title: Victim in Empire State Shooting Emerges From Coma After a Week
description: A week after a gunman opened fire on the observation deck of the Empire State Building, one of the victims most critically wounded in the shooting emerged from a coma yesterday at Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, THELMA SILVERSTEIN
description: ABRAMS - Thelma Silverstein. Died on March 1, 1997, in Louisville, KY. Former resident of NYC. Beloved wife of the late Jules. Loving mother of Dr. Susan Eichenberger of Louisville, KY, and Ralph Abrams, of Ann Arbor, MI. Survived by five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was a past President of the Hillside Chapter of Hadassah and the Israel Center of Hillcrest Manor, and a Life Master and teacher of bridge. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Rd), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Accounts
description: * Tower Air, Jamaica, Queens, to Romann & Tannenholz, New York, to handle its account in the United States, previously handled by Baldin, Bloom & Whelan, New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, MILDRED
description: SLATER-Mildred. Beloved wife of Hyman. Devoted mother of Howard and Beth and the late Burton. Loving sister of Sylvia and Stanley Shapiro. Adored grandmother of Stacey and Arthur, Craig and Devorah, Ashley and Zachary, and great-grandmother of Melissa, Noah, Kayla and Miriam. Services 9:30 Tuesday at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Ghana's Average Guys
description: To the Editor:

title: Slowdown Merely an Irritation for UConn
description: Their emotions were hot, their shooting was cold and the other team slowed down every possession to 25 seconds of nothing and 5 seconds of basketball. But the Connecticut women hung in, kept their cool and made Villanova come out of its shell.

title: Behind Every Series Loss, Braves Can Still See a Silver Lining
description: The Atlanta Braves did not like losing three of the last five World Series. But what they dislike even more are the comments they hear about themselves because of their failures.

title: Fiber-Optic Technology Draws Record Stock Value
description: It happened so quietly that few besides the shareholders and awe-struck analysts seem to have noticed yet. But a small Maryland-based Internet technology company recently went public and achieved a $3.44 billion market valuation overnight -- making it the largest stock offering by a start-up company in history.

title: No Justice in Bosnia
description: A criminal justice system lacking in credibility and enforcement cannot provide justice to victims or deter future criminals. The same holds true for international humanitarian law -- a system that, among other things, aims to protect innocent civilians from war crimes.

title: Fierce Wind and Rain Tear Up Several States, Killing at Least 35
description: From Arkansas, where tornadoes devastated a small town, to Ohio and Kentucky, where floods swept cars off the roads and sucked two people down into culverts, a front of deadly storms splintered homes and killed at least 35 people over the weekend.

title: Cashless for the Weekend
description: Hundreds of Fleet Bank customers in New York and New Jersey were left without access to cash for most of the weekend when a computer glitch made their automated teller machine cards unusable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Messinger, in Trend, Puts the Spotlight on a Relative
description: Miriam Messinger is, in many ways, a typical working mom. Her office is strewn with snapshots of her 16-month-old daughter, Amani, at play, at rest, standing up, sitting down, looking concerned, looking content.

title: Food Stamps for Job Seekers
description: Gov. George Pataki of New York has done a sensible thing by applying for a waiver from the new Federal welfare law that would deny food stamps to adults who cannot find work. But his plan is flawed because it is a temporary waiver that would end on Nov. 21.

title: To Some Workers, a Nonwinter of Discontent
description: This has been the nonwinter, a point underlined last week by the sprouting of a single clump of February crocuses in Manhattan's Bryant Park. From Boston to Washington, temperatures this year have been more than 5 degrees above normal, and what snowfall there has been can be measured in mere inches.

title: At Northern Telecom, New Chief Executive To Be President, Too
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. announced last week that John A. Roth, the telecommunications equipment company's chief operating officer, would become chief executive and president in October.

title: Mastercard undertakes a review and Ammirati Puris, as it often does, says, 'No thanks.'
description: MASTERCARD INTERNATIONAL, which has had its creative work done by Ammirati Puris Lintas since 1992, said on Friday that it was undertaking a review of the account.

title: Kentucky Is Left Wilted Inside Its Own Hothouse
description: Stage fright.

title: Passion Play Gets Black Star
description: At 82 years and running, the Park Performing Arts Center's annual Passion play is the oldest in the nation. And when the producers cast a black man as Jesus Christ for the first time this year, a few eyebrows were raised. But despite a handful of protest phone calls, Desi Arnaz Giles's debut as Jesus went off yesterday without a hitch.

title: Carmichael Lynch Drops National Car
description: Carmichael Lynch Inc. in Minneapolis unexpectedly resigned from the National Car Rental System account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, after 14 months.

title: Spain's Bullfighters Go on Strike
description: A nationwide strike by bullfighters today forced the cancellation of the first event of the main season. Angry fans in the eastern city of Castellon, where the fight was to take place, lined up for refunds and a promoter said $175,000 had been returned.

title: As Brash Publisher's Empire Ends, Quest Begins for Another
description: Subdued as he may be these days, Steven Brill cannot contain himself at every moment. In one of them, speaking from behind a can of Tab last week in his glassy office overlooking Third Avenue, the editor and entrepreneur began to promote his on-line service for lawyers. ''Every venture capitalist on the planet,'' he said, ''has called me in the last three days asking to buy it.''

title: Lawmakers to Discuss Budget
description: Helping legal immigrants become citizens, establishing drug courts in four counties and providing health care for uninsured children are among the many options state legislators will consider this week as they begin budget negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLEY, WILLIAM P.
description: FOLEY-William P., age 82 of Shrewsbury, MA, formerly of Yonkers, NY, retired NYC firefighter. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude, devoted father of William, Elizabeth Foley Garvey and Marilyn Foley Semptimphelter. Dear brother of Eugene and Vincent. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Reposing David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball Avenue), Yonkers, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Barnabas Church, Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Hospice of Central Massachusetts, 120 Thomas Street, Worcester, MA 01608 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINER, ROSE
description: KAMINER-Rose. Dear sister of Sylvia Levine, Dorothy Kaplan and Benjamin Kaminer. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Services Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''Gutterman's'' (Riverside Building), 331 Amsterdam Ave, Manhattan, near 76th St. Contributions can be sent to B'nai Zion Foundation, 136 E. 39th St, NYC 10016.

title: Internet Offers New Venue for Aspiring Entertainers
description: Forget the cold calls. Don't bother dreaming of being discovered at the local coffee shop counter. Starving artists can now be discovered even while they sleep, as long as they have left their best work somewhere on the World Wide Web.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Flashes of Light, Moments of Peril
description: Metallica was testing boundaries. To be down on the floor at the Nassau Coliseum on Friday night looked dangerous: flash pots exploded at the perimeters of the round, two-ring stages; gas jets spit curtains of fire; enormous light banks on jointed arms raised and lowered and rotated, threatening to crush the front rows. Milking the crowd periodically, the band members looked like mean boys taunting lions at the zoo: all four of them ran up to the barriers, making faces and holding out their instruments, cranking up the fans into a slithering, grasping mob. Strange that the audience should play the caged role, when it had come to look at them.

title: Shoppers Lament That Many Retailers Don't Seem to Care
description: There was no doubt in Nancy Cohen's mind when she walked into the Pier 1 Imports store on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue a few months ago that she would walk out with a new set of kitchen chairs.

title: Exodus in Zaire: U.N. Faces a New Refugee Crisis
description: With more than 100,000 Rwandan refugees lost in a war zone in the jungles of eastern Zaire, pressure is once again mounting at the United Nations for another international effort to save Hutu women and children from the folly of their leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITMAN, MOLLY
description: BREITMAN-Molly, of Hartsdale, New York. Wife of the late Harvey Breitman, mother of Linda Friedman, and Carole Zelnick, sister of Syd Springer, and Ethel Forman, Grandmother of 4. Funeral service Tuesday, 1:00PM at the BallardDurand funeral home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetary. Visitation Tuesday, 12 noon-1:00 P.M.

title: Clinton Figures On the Budget Are Questioned
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that President Clinton's budget plan would leave the Government with a deficit of $69 billion in 2002, rather than a surplus of $17 billion, as Mr. Clinton asserted last month.

title: INSIDE
description: Coffers Overflow in Albany

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HOPE B.
description: HARRIS-Hope B. Of Hartsdale, New York, March 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William J. Harris. She is survived by her dear daughters Susan Harris of NYC and Barbara Krysl of St. Louis, Mo., her beloved grandchildren David and Amy Loewenberg and Mark Easter, her dear daughter-in-law Sarah Loewenberg, cherished great granddaughter Lucy-Rose Loewenberg and loving sister Barbara Cedar. Services private. She will be greatly missed.

title: Bomb Suspect's Lawyer Says Paper Stole File
description: The lawyer representing Timothy J. McVeigh, one of two defendants in the Oklahoma City bombing case, said today that the incriminating document used as the basis for an article by The Dallas Morning News was stolen from defense computer files.

title: New Guidelines Set for Trade Missions Abroad
description: President Clinton's new Commerce Secretary, William M. Daley, today overhauled the rules governing American trade missions abroad, trying to insure that companies that donate heavily to political campaigns would get no special help from the Government in breaking into foreign markets.

title: French Furniture Retailer
description: Ligne Roset, an upscale French furniture manufacturer, has leased 2,700 square feet at 1090 Third Avenue, at 64th Street, for its first streetfront retail store in Manhattan. The company has a showroom at 200 Lexington Avenue, at 32d Street.

title: Calipari Hurting Kittles's Prospects
description: Coach John Calipari came off as someone trying to doctor the before-and-after photos of Kerry Kittles, denying how his player's rookie-of-the-year odds have slimmed down since the Nets' nine-player trade last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, CARL BROOKS
description: PETERS-Carl Brooks. The Partners, Management, Brokers and Staff of Ashforth Warburg Associates extend their deepest sympathy to our President, Frederick Warburg Peters, upon the death of his father. Our most heartfelt condolences to Fred and his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, MELVIN
description: ROSEMAN-Melvin, on February 28. Family and friends mourn the passing of a devoted husband to Ruth, loving father of Sandra Lane, Shelly Benerofe, Joan Berkin, father-in-law to Arthur, grandfather to eight caring grandchildren, close brother to Arnold. In our hearts he will always be remembered.

title: Clinton Wants Deal With Congress on Cost-of-Living Adjustments
description: President Clinton gave his aides the go-ahead today to try to forge a deal with Congress to reduce cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other benefit programs, White House officials said.

title: Wolves May Reintroduce Themselves to East
description: AS the endangered gray wolf makes a comeback in the Rocky Mountains and Upper Midwest, some conservationists are training their eyes on the Adirondacks as the next target for re-introducing the great predator. But the wolves may be way ahead of them.

title: Ameritech to Review Ad Assignments
description: The recent tumult in telecommunications marketing intensified yesterday as the Ameritech Corporation unexpectedly began a review of the agencies that handle its consumer, brand and business accounts, with billings estimated at more than $100 million.

title: Lots and Lots of Dots Make Printing Clearer
description: JUST a few years ago it was far easier to create a color digital image on a screen than to get it onto paper. Color printers capable of high-quality output weighed many pounds, occupied sizable spaces and cost thousands of dollars. Their output was rarely confused with photographic prints.

title: Stepping on Major Toes With a Big Adidas Deal
description: Major League Baseball tried to roar about its marketing plans for the 1997 season yesterday, but the Yankees' stunning deal with Adidas stole the thunder.

title: Time to Get Honest About Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Going Nowhere, But Digging Deep
description: The music of Giacinto Scelsi is not like any music you know: wholly original yet profoundly conservative. Creativity, most people tell us, is an exploding universe sending out sparks and debris in unexplored directions. Scelsi's music is a black hole. It shrinks music into the unknowable center from which all sound originated and begins from the beginning.

title: AFFINITY GROUP TO ACQUIRE A RETAILER AND A PUBLISHER
description: Affinity Group said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a retailer of recreational vehicle merchandise and a publisher of sports and recreation magazines for a total of about $139 million. Affinity Group, based in Ventura, Calif., is a direct-marketing concern that sells products through membership clubs. The businesses to be acquired are Camping World Inc., a company in Bowling Green, Ky., that has 27 retail stores and catalogue retail operations, and Ehlert Publishing Inc., a publisher in Minnetonka, Minn.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GREGORY PECK is on the road again, discussing his life as an actor and film star, but don't suggest to him that the talks he delivers are lectures. ''I resist calling what I do lectures,'' he said yesterday as he prepared to head to New York from Boston, where he performed Sunday. He will appear tonight at the Tilles Center in Brookville, L.I., and on Thursday at the State Theater in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Naming of 6 Elements To End Long Disputes
description: AFTER more than three years of sometimes acrimonious debate across the borders of many nations, an international body of chemists has reached a tentative agreement on the names to be bestowed upon six new chemical elements.

title: On 2d Avenue, Murder Leads To a Dead End
description: AN unsung benefit of the shrinking crime rate is that New York police detectives have some breathing room to put more time into tough cases. That has helped them improve their ''clearance rate,'' which in cop-speak is the measure of how frequently cases are solved. For homicides, the rate used to be in steady decline, but it has crept back up and runs now at about 80 percent. Not bad.

title: C.I.A. Officer Admits Spying for Russians
description: Harold J. Nicholson, the highest-ranking Central Intelligence Agency officer ever charged with espionage, today pleaded guilty to selling secrets to Moscow.

title: A Colorful Family Made for Memoirs
description: THE SUN AT MIDDAY

title: Prosecutor Says F.B.I. Agent Misled Superiors About Informer
description: A Federal prosecutor accused a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent yesterday of misleading his superiors about a Mafia figure's crimes in order to keep the mobster as an informer.

title: Judi Bari, 47, Leader of Earth First Protest on Redwoods in 1990
description: Judi Bari, an environmentalist whose passionate defense of the California redwoods earned her national prominence and who was injured in a car bombing that might have been related to her protests, died on Sunday at her cabin home in Willits, Calif. She was 47.

title: Bundesbank Chief Says No Rate Rise Is in Sight
description: The president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said yesterday that the German central bank did not see an upturn in German interest rates in the near future. ''We do not see the turning point for an upward correction in interest rates,'' Mr. Tietmeyer said at an event in Frankfurt at which the Dutch central bank president, Wim Duisenberg, was named banker of the year for 1996.

title: Ancient German Spears Tell of Mighty Hunters of Stone Age
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS are beginning to think they have been underestimating the early Stone Age ancestors of modern human beings.

title: Chess
description: Tal Shaked, an 18-year-old international master from Tucson, Ariz., made his first grandmaster norm in the IV Anibal Open in Linares, Spain, Jan. 8 to 17. The Georgian grandmaster Giorgi Giorgadze won first prize with an 8-2 score. Shaked shared second place with 7 1/2-2 1/2 in the 10-round Swiss-system event. He needs one more such achievement to be accorded grandmaster rank. Eric C. Johnson, assistant director of the United Chess Federation, said, ''We anticipate that he will qualify for it by the end of this year.''

title: FISERV TO BUY BHC FINANCIAL FOR $211 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Fiserv Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy BHC Financial Inc., a provider of securities processing and other services for financial companies, for about $211 million in stock. Fiserv, based in Brookfield, Wis., provides data processing systems and related services for banks, mortgage companies and savings institutions. It said it would pay $33.50 for each of BHC Financial's 6.3 million shares outstanding. BHC stock surged 59 percent yesterday, gaining $11.875, to $31.875 a share; shares of Fiserv rose $3.875, to $36.625. BHC Financial, based in Philadelphia, had revenues of $81 million in 1996.

title: British Airways to Cut 290 Accounting Jobs

The decisions are part of its plan to cut $:1 billion of costs over three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, BEATRICE MINTZER
description: DAVIS-Beatrice Mintzer, 75, died February 27, 1997. Survived by her daughter, Deborah Davis Gross, brother, Arthur Mintzer, two grandchildren, Paula and Eve Gross, and beloved friend, Jane Redwine. A native of Brooklyn, Bea was a teacher for the OASIS Senior Education Program and was by profession a geriatric nurse practitioner. Services will be held at El Camino Mortuary, San Diego, Wed., March 5, at 10 AM.

title: Justices Set Aside Reversal of 'English Only' Measure
description: The Supreme Court today set aside a Federal appeals court's decision that Arizona could not require state employees to speak only English on the job, ordering a state employee's challenge to Arizona's English-only constitutional amendment to be dismissed as moot because the worker resigned seven years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, HENRY LOUIS
description: FREEDMAN-Henry Louis, M.D. Husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle; physician, teacher, sweet friend to us all. Died March 3rd, 1997 at age 86.

title: Albania Chief Tightens Grip In Crackdown On Protests
description: In moves that heightened anxiety in Europe about a flow of refugees out of Albania, the hard-line President had himself reappointed for a five-year term today and enforced a state of emergency that gave the police power to shoot stone-throwers on sight.

title: Bright Plumage
description: Attention, peacocks. Men's shirts and ties are bursting into real colors this spring. Richard Lambertson, Bergorf Goodman's creative director, suggests accenting a conservative gray or navy suit with a bright shirt and solid tie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRBY, MICHAEL S.
description: KIRBY-Michael S. Died February 24, 1997 at St. Vincent's hospital. There will be a memorial service and Mass at St. Anthony's Chapel, 154 Sullivan street. New York, NY. Saturday, March 8, 1997, 10:00AM.

title: Nation May Buy Big Copper Mine
description: The Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Julius Chan, confirmed today that his Government would try to buy the abandoned Bougainville copper mine from CRA Ltd., the Australian arm of the world's largest mining company, RTZ-CRA.

title: Plea for Transportation Fund
description: Last year, the State Department of Transportation began a five-year capital improvement program for roads, bridges, highways and mass transit. The Transportation Trust Fund provides $700 million a year for these projects, but initially, the state agency planned improvements with a total price tag of $1 billion. This ''overprogramming,'' transportation officials said yesterday, insures that another project can easily be substituted for one that stalls.

title: Wherever It Grows, a Violet Is a Violet
description: The two young women say they do not find it so curious that one of them comes from the Pocono Mountains and the other from the streets of Jamaica, Queens. That one is white and the other is black. That one's strength is a perimeter game, the other's a canny, thrusting one.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, JOAN
description: GROSS-Joan. How lucky we were to have you. Bernard, Billy, Lonnie, Renne

title: Keeping Cocaine Resilient: Low Cost and High Profit
description: They have tried to stamp out cocaine for years. Governments have sprayed herbicides on fields of coca leaf. Police have raided the primitive laboratories that refine coca paste. Counternarcotics agents have seized and destroyed hundreds of tons of cocaine powder, arresting or killing thousands of smugglers.

title: Jobless Rate Dips Below 6%
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate dipped to 5.9 percent in January, the first time in six years that it has fallen below 6 percent, according to statistics released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. Melvin L. Gelade, who was sworn in yesterday as Labor Commissioner, said that 9,600 new jobs were created in January.

title: Wallace's Victory Is Official
description: After going from Victory Lane to limbo Sunday in Richmond when his car was impounded for a possible rules infraction, Rusty Wallace was confirmed yesterday as the winner of the Pontiac Excitement 400.

title: AT&T and Ameritech Agree to Drop Lawsuits
description: The Ameritech Corporation and the AT&T Corporation said today that they had agreed to settle three legal disputes and instead battle each other in the marketplace. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on Sunday about the new police drama ''Prince Street'' misidentified the network broadcasting it on Thursday at 10 P.M. It is NBC, not CBS.

title: Rival Suitors May Split Up Conrail Parts
description: Conrail is close to a $10.3 billion agreement with the CSX Corporation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation that would split Conrail's railroad network between the two carriers, bringing to an end a bloody four-month battle for control of rail freight in the East, people familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: A Top C.I.A. Officer Admits to Betrayal

title: Gene May Help Burn Up Fat
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered a gene that might someday help people shed pounds in exchange for a slightly high er body temperature. The gene appears to make people burn off calories. The hope is that researchers can find a drug to make it work harder, so the body will burn more calories rather than storing them as fat, thus raising body temperature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEIER, MICKEY GILBERT
description: SPEIER-Mickey Gilbert, 83, of Palm Beach, formerly of New York, passed away March 2, 1997. She is survived by her husband, Ferdinand, her daughter, Jane Melrose, and son, Ross Gilbert (deceased), her nieces, Joan and Harriet. She had 13 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. Service will be on Wednesday, at 3 P.M., at Riverside Gordon, West Palm Beach, 561-683-8676. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Sea May Have Yielded a Piece of Pirate Lore
description: He was an ogre, tall, bloodthirsty, strong, with a booming voice, a savage appetite and a bushy black beard that hung down to his belly. Edward Teach, known as Blackbeard, was one of history's most famous and cruel pirates, a man who apparently loved torturing his victims as much as he loved a drunken orgy.

title: Knicks Hoping to Catch Miami This Week
description: Because they are playing their next three games against sub-.500 teams, the Knicks have a chance to catch the Miami Heat by the weekend.

title: Funky Former Icon of Downtown Finds a New Lair
description: Think of this as a kind of fairy tale, the story of an itinerant monster, harsh in appearance, incorrigible in spirit, in search of a home. It's a New York story but has a lot to do with Texas. Call it the Return of the 40-Foot Iguana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, YA'ACOV
description: RECANATI-Ya'acov. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved brother of its alumni parent and generous benefactor Raphael Recanati. We extend heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Prin. Steven R. Gross, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: In London, the Scene Has Final Say
description: Everything most people know about British fashion they know because of the scene that brought it to their attention. That was the basis of punk, mods and Carnaby Street, and it is the basis for the best moments of London's fall shows, which ended on Friday.

title: Drug Researchers Working To Design Customized Estrogen
description: WHEN it comes to estrogens, Nature seems to have given with one hand and taken with the other. In addition to making women women, these hormones help to protect the heart, bones and brain from the ravages of age. But they also stimulate the breast and uterus, increasing the risk of cancer in these tissues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, IRWIN
description: NATHANSON-Irwin. Age 91. Passed away peacefully in the early hours of Sunday morning, March 2, 1997. He is survived by his wife Mimi Bochco and stepchildren Joanna Rachins and Steven Bochco and three step grandchildren. Born January 22, 1906 in Saint Louis, MO., he had his own public relations firm from which he retired at age fifty to devote the rest of his life to his passions, archaeology, and for the past twelve years, his surviving wife Mimi. A private memorial service will be held on Sunday, March 9th in Los Angeles, CA.

title: COR THERAPEUTICS SAGS AFTER PANEL VOTES AGAINST DRUG
description: Shares of Cor Therapeutics Inc. dropped nearly 24 percent yesterday after the company's experimental heart drug Integrilin failed to win the backing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel on Friday. The shares fell $2.9375, to $9.375. The panel members voted against recommending approval of Integrilin, saying that the company's major study did not provide enough proof of the drug's effectiveness. The F.D.A. usually, though not always, follows the advice of its expert committees. When Cor, based in South San Francisco, Calif., said last month that the F.D.A. had scheduled a panel meeting, the company's shares jumped almost 17 percent.

title: Gore Says He Did Nothing Illegal In Soliciting From White House
description: Vice President Al Gore acknowledged today that ''on a few occasions'' he had made telephone calls from his White House office seeking Democratic campaign contributions. Insisting he had not done ''anything wrong, much less illegal,'' he said he would nevertheless refrain from making such solicitations in the future.

title: Latest Stunner by Stags Brings Automatic Bid
description: For most of the season, Shannon Bowman's injured right ankle was just strong enough to carry his own weight. For the past three days, it carried the entire Fairfield team.

title: Lawyers You Can Trust? Almost
description: ''They hate lawyers too,'' reads the advertising slogan for ''The Practice,'' a new show about lawyers in a small-time Boston firm. That line overstates the case for their self-loathing, but it shrewdly reflects the down-to-earth strategy behind this refreshing, immensely likable series. These characters say the things lawyers never say on shows about hot-shot legal minds, things you've been waiting and wishing they would.

title: After 4,000 Years, It's Time for Urban Renewal
description: In the late 18th century, residents of the dun-colored hills on the west bank of the Nile pelted Western visitors with boulders, sicked their dogs on them and set the strangers' boats afire. From their mud-brick homes built atop Pharaonic tombs, the local people found little reason to welcome the age of exploration.

title: Be It Ever So Humbling: Big East Tourney Set
description: The glitter will be on display somewhere else this week. When 10 teams gather at Madison Square Garden for the start of the Big East tournament tomorrow, and three more with first-round byes join the field for the quarterfinals on Thursday, survival will be the theme.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Also Around Town column of the City section on Sunday, about a panel discussion of Philippine literature followed by a reading, misstated the event's location and title. It will begin at 2 P.M. on Saturday at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue (70th Street), not at Poets House. It is titled ''Hala Bira!: A Celebration of Philippine Literature,'' not ''Hala Bria.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Utility Sues to Block New Hampshire Plan

title: Well Done, Pioneer 10
description: THE interplanetary spacecraft that kept going and going for 25 years and 6.2 billion miles will be retired at the end of the month. Launched on March 2, 1972, little Pioneer 10 sent back the first close-up views of Jupiter and became the first object of human design to travel beyond the planets of the solar system. Now its power is ebbing, its radio signal feeble and its days numbered. NASA will end the project now that its scientific output is sharply reduced, and regular monitoring of Pioneer's radio will stop. ''It's done its job very well and deserves to retire,'' said B. J. O'Brien, who managed the program for TRW Inc., Pioneer's manufacturer; he retired in 1988. The craft will then cruise silently through interstellar space on a course to pass 10 stars in the next million years.

title: New Rothschild Trust
description: Rothschild Asset Management, a subsidiary of N. M. Rothschild & Company, the London merchant bank, introduced Five Arrows Short-Term Investment Trust yesterday, an investment management company for American professional investors made up of four separate currency funds: dollars, British pounds, German marks and Canadian dollars. The new trust, which has a minimum investment of $500,000, lets investors put cash into funds composed of short-term creditworthy investments. It will invest in obligations of governments, banks and companies.

title: Clintons Should Visit New York More Often
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC leads a monthlong campaign against drugs.
description: THE ABC television network is sponsoring what may be the most elaborate cause-related marketing campaign ever undertaken by the American media, devoting the month of March to a crusade urging parents to just say yes to convincing their children to just say no to drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, LEANNE G.
description: KATZ-Leanne G. We lost a beautiful mother, wife and friend on Sunday night, March 2, 1997 after a three year struggle with cancer. She was loved by her family, her friends and all those in the National Coalition Against Censorship and First Amendment community and will be mourned, we know, by all those fortunate enough to have known her. We list the names of her close family, but we know there is a multitude who could also be mentioned who will carry her memory, her husband Alvin Katz, sons Joseph and Jamie Katz, Lisa Nocera, sister Sara Blackburn and Jeff Snider.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Portrait of a modern marriage and divorce: Neither WARNER LeROY, the restaurateur, nor his former wife, GEN LeROY, remembers when they were married decades ago nor even for how long. But they have remained friendly, and Mr. LeRoy is giving a party at his restaurant Tavern on the Green to celebrate Ms. LeRoy's debut as a playwright. Ms. LeRoy wrote ''Not Waving . . . ,'' which opens tomorrow night at the Primary Stages theater on West 42d Street.

title: Asia's Giant, After Detours, Takes Familiar Growth Path
description: On what was a cow patch not long ago, young women in white gloves and jackets snap together pieces of plastic with a pop that announces the completion of a computer mouse, each a tiny symbol of China's growing strength as an exporter. About 40 percent of these devices are exported to the United States, including four of every five computer mice sold with Apple computers.

title: 3 Posing as Officers Accused in Robbery
description: Three men posing as plainclothes officers and driving what appeared to be an unmarked police vehicle robbed two Bronx food warehouse workers yesterday of $275,000 in cash and food stamps that they were taking to deposit, the police said.

title: Whitman Picks a Prosecutor
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman nominated a Summit lawyer yesterday to fill the job of Union County Prosecutor. The nominee, Thomas V. Manahan of Westfield, is a former assistant prosecutor in that office.

title: The Stage Is Set for L.I.U.
description: From Sinatra to Elvis to Long Island University basketball, good theater continues at the former Brooklyn Paramount.

title: Desegregation Case Plaintiffs Criticize Planned Remedies
description: A state plan to desegregate urban schools is inadequate and could lead to further litigation, the plaintiffs in a landmark school desegregation case charged today.

title: Northeast Utilities Sues to Block Move by New Hampshire
description: The owner of New Hampshire's biggest utility went to court yesterday to block a state deregulation decision that it said could slash the company's revenue by $341 million over two years and ultimately drive it into bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINGALE, ANTHONY G.
description: ZINGALE-Anthony G. On March 3, 1997 at the age of 86. Attorney at Law. Loving husband of Florence (nee Pelletier). Dear father of Anthony G. Zingale, Jr., Angela McTigue, Sandy Calise, Joseph C. Zingale, Cara Pompei and Nina Zingale. Cherished grandfather of Christopher, Thomas, Jennifer, Terrence, Kerry, Michael, Andrew, Gregory, Joey, Zack, Eric, Carin and Alex. Reposing Wed 2-4 and 7-9PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson, 6110 Riverdale Ave. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 11AM.

title: Lawyers, Outnumbered
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Hearings: Another Boondoggle?
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Surplus Gives Albany New Questions
description: Legislative leaders agreed with the Governor today that New York State's coffers, swelled by the boom on Wall Street, would be awash in tax money for the next 13 months, although the state's overall economic growth continued to lag behind the nation's.

title: When the Warhorses Were Young
description: The New York Youth Symphony, now in its 34th season, seldom has trouble filling Carnegie Hall for its concerts. Sunday afternoon's was no exception. Naturally, there were many families of orchestra players in attendance, who were fairly easy to spot: you see children pointing excitedly to brothers and sisters onstage, and alert parents nudging each other during a clarinet solo or a timpani outburst.

title: Stanislav Shatalin, 62, Russian Who Tried to Open the Economy
description: Stanislav S. Shatalin, the Soviet economist who during the perestroika era was instrumental in promoting an economic plan to dismantle Communism, died today. He was 62.

title: Not So Soon, Winter Tells a Pushy Spring
description: And so, it is March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RALEIGH, BEN
description: RALEIGH-Ben. The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers mourns the tragic passing of our lyricist member Ben Raleigh in California on February 26, 1997. Condolences to his family. Marilyn Bergman President and Chairman, ASCAP

title: New President Of AT&T Sees A Profit Drain
description: AT&T's new president, John. R. Walter, made his much anticipated debut with Wall Street analysts at a meeting here today. But after the company announced a blizzard of bad news, the mood at his coming-out party turned as ominous as the storm clouds gathering over the AT&T Corporation's conference center here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESNEL, DENNIS A.
description: CHESNEL-Dennis A., of New York City, on February 28 of AIDSrelated causes. Born in Rochester, New Hampshire, August 1, 1957. Director of Editorial Development for Time Inc. Interment ceremony to be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on a date to be announced in The New York Times. The Dennis Chesnel Memorial Scholarship Fund for the Advanced Studies Program at St. Paul's School has been established. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated and may be made to the attention of Jeffrey Bradley, Advanced Studies Program, St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, New Hampshire 03301.

title: Rangers Finally End Victory Drought in Overtime
description: The San Jose Sharks are a rummage sale of a hockey team, their roster dotted with discards. The best thing about them is their uniforms, and even these teal beauties have lost their novelty value as fashion statements.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAMERON ASHLEY BUILDING PRODUCTS INC., Dallas, a building products distributor, agreed to buy Bois Daigle, a Canadian distributor of building materials with revenues of $47 million last year, from Simard-Beaudry Inc., Quebec, for undisclosed terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROPPER, NORMAN
description: PROPPER-Norman. Age 64. On March 2, 1997. President of Serica Neckwear for 20 years. Survived by wife, Anne, two daughters, Beth and Adrienne, and two grandchildren, Randy and Alec. His vision and leadership will be sorely missed. Funeral will be held at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, 9:30 A.M., Wednesday, March 5.

title: A Feminist Redefined
description: The other day, I was having lunch in a croissant shop in midtown Manhattan and eavesdropping on the people sitting at the next table. A twentysomething college-educated woman was describing her wedding plans in detail to a friend. Between discussing how much the caterer would cost and what color the bridesmaids' dresses would be, she said, with considerable embarrassment, ''I can't believe I'm actually doing this, that I'm talking about me doing this. But if I don't get excited about it, who will?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERSTEIN, ROSE
description: ALPERSTEIN-Rose. On March 2, 1997. Last of the five Jacobs sisters. Beloved wife of the late Louis B. Loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLOH, VIRGINIA G.
description: McCULLOH-Virginia G. February 25, 1997, in Westerly, R.I. Beloved wife of the late Gordon McCulloh. Mother of Gordon McCulloh, Virginia Betzler, step mother of James McCulloh, Ann de Bronkart and Jean Klein Peter. Graveside service will be held at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York on Thursday, at 3 P.M.

title: Trent Lott's Signal
description: ''We are going to have hearings, one way or the other,'' Senator Trent Lott promised over the weekend. That helped allay the fears of some of those worried that the Senate majority leader might head off an extended Congressional investigation into campaign fund-raising abuses this year. But Mr. Lott's intentions are still not wholly clear. He remains under heavy pressure from both Republicans and Democrats to let the hearings die. He should make it plain that he will back an early vote approving a broad, bipartisan and fully funded investigation to be led by Senator Fred Thompson, chairman of the Government Affairs Committee.

title: Restaurant's Liquor License Suspended
description: In what it described as an emergency action, the New York State Liquor Authority yesterday suspended the liquor license of the Box Tree, the ornate, $100-a-person restaurant on East 49th Street, after the union that has been on strike against the restaurant for 38 months pushed for the revocation.

title: More Accurate C.P.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDITH A. (BERNARD)
description: COHEN-Edith A. (Bernard). Passed away on February 28, 1997 in Rochester, NY. She was the widow of Evans D. Cohen and mother of Elliot Cohen and Amy Roth. A devoted daughter, loving wife, concerned mother and dear sister, she will be long remembered with love. Good night, sweet Adeline. Herbert

title: Mexico Accuses Top Businessman of Fraud
description: The Mexican Government has charged a leading businessman, who is a partner in a big cellular-telephone venture with the Bell Atlantic Corporation, with criminal tax fraud.

title: No Headline
description: ''How are drugs coming across the border? Probably in every imaginable way you can think of.''

title: Clinton, in Ads, Lifts Image of Parent
description: President Clinton today began a new advertising campaign that presents him as a concerned, hard-working parent, a message that the White House had been seeking to promote for more than a year.

title: Quake Leaves Iranian Villagers Grief-Stricken and Homeless
description: It took just 15 seconds for Farzaneh Akhwan's life to change forever. The earthquake that struck here last Friday swept away not just her home and her livelihood, but it took the lives of almost her entire family.

title: Patterns
description: Return of a Fashion Darling

title: Russia Accepts Eastward Growth Of NATO, but Only Inch by Inch
description: Western diplomats call it the root canal strategy.

title: White Flag in the Drug War
description: The escape of an alleged Mexican money launderer just before President Clinton certified that Mexico was cooperating fully with efforts to fight drug trafficking illustrates the folly of that decision. Senator Dianne Feinstein of California deserves support in her efforts to get the Senate to pass legislation that would correct the President's error.

title: SEARS, ROEBUCK AND MAXSERV SETTLE ON ACQUISITION PRICE
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company agreed yesterday to buy the shares of Maxserv Inc. that it does not already own for $7.75 a share, or $40 million, ending two months of negotiations over a fair price for Maxserv, the appliance maintenance company. It replaces the $7-a-share offer Sears originally made in January for the remaining 5.15 million shares, including common stock options and warrants. Sears currently holds 7.03 million common shares, or 64.4 percent of Maxserv. Maxserv, based in Austin, Tex., said a special committee of directors approved the new offer. The company had spurned the previous offer and urged shareholders to reject it. Its shares closed at $7.625 yesterday.

title: Strawberry Can Picture A Career Year
description: Darryl Strawberry did not sound bombastic or blustery while he discussed his amazing aspirations this morning. He has visions of duplicating the sort of season that turned his noticeable name into a household name with the Mets more than a decade ago. Strawberry was synonymous with the sweet swing that produced even sweeter results.

title: The C.I.A. Cleanses Itself
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's purge of foreign agents with criminal histories is an important milestone in the organization's effort to discard the bad habits of the cold war. After decades of cavalierly recruiting foreign agents, including killers, torturers, terrorists and other assorted miscreants, the agency has belatedly stopped to see if the caliber of their work for America outweighs their sordid records. In many cases, the answer appears to be no, and the agents have been dismissed.

title: Charles Dederich, 83, Synanon Founder, Dies
description: Charles E. Dederich, a reformed alcoholic who founded Synanon, the drug rehabilitation program that won widespread acclaim and amassed great wealth before it became associated with violence, died on Friday in Kaweah Delta Hospital in Visalia, Calif. Mr. Dederich, who lived in Visalia, was 83.

title: 4,100 New Rooms at the Inn? Barely Enough, Some Say
description: As New York continues to bask in a tourism boom, there has been a steady stream of announcements of new hotel projects. With last week's news that a French luxury hotel is planned for midtown, there are now about 4,100 rooms on the drawing board, and that's on top of the more than 500 rooms that were added in recent months with the opening of the SoHo Grand and the Trump International Hotel and Tower.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Thais Suspend Trading In Shares of All Banks
description: The Stock Exchange of Thailand suspended trading in the shares of all banks and finance companies yesterday after the Government ordered the industry to increase its reserves against bad loans. The suspension is likely to be lifted today. The move covered shares worth $29 billion, accounting for a third of the stock market's capitalization.

title: In Era of Satellites, Army Plots Ways To Destroy Them
description: THE United States Government, having authorized a wave of commercial spy satellites that can peer down from the heavens to pry into all kinds of secrets on the ground, is now exploring ways to destroy such orbital eyes in time of war.

title: The Jets Get Tuna's Message
description: OUTSIDE the Jets' complex, a truck with ''Serious Fitness Equipment'' was delivering weight-room apparatus that the Jets' new chief of football operations considers best for football muscles. Another of the chief's ideas, an indoor bubble, will be constructed so that those football muscles can practice efficiently in inclement weather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOACHIM, FLORENCE
description: JOACHIM-Florence. The officers and members of the Typophiles note with regret the death of our Honorary member Florence Joachim. Her purpose and energies directed to the furthering of all aspects of the printing industry were a constant source of inspiration and helped ensure many successes in the industry. Theo Rehak, President Typophiles

title: River Project Is Postponed
description: Under pressure from environmental groups, a state-appointed commission that is seeking remedies for flooding along the Green Brook River has agreed to postpone building two huge retention basins in Berkeley Heights for at least a year, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RULON, MILLER, JUDITH ROLLINSON
description: RULON-MILLER-Judith Rollinson, 53, died of breast cancer on March 1, 1997 in her home in Kingston, N.J. She is survived by her husband Patrick; daughter Sarah of New York City; and son Ian Davis of Breckenridge, Colorado. A memorial service will be held at 3PM, on Friday, March 5 at Trinity Church in Princeton, N.J. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Martin House, Box 1029, Trenton, New Jersey 08606 or to The Princeton Family Center For Education, Vandeventer Avenue, Princeton, New Jersey 08540.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFTOW, FRANCES
description: LEFTOW-Frances, 91, on March 2. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Dear mother of Joan and Alvin Weinstein. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Marc and Kate, Abbe, Peter and Jennie, David and Stephanie, Jonathan and Tamara, and great-grandmother of ten. Loving sister of Bess and Dave Schwaber. Service private.

title: The Clinton Mystery
description: President Clinton's fund-raising abuses are the focus of political attention these days. But for me there are far more serious questions about his substantive policies. Sleazy money will dissipate. Unprincipled policy is likely to leave its mark on the law of the United States for years to come.

title: For Different Folks
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Buyout Fund Raises $610 Million
description: Castle Harlan Inc. said yesterday that it had raised $610 million for a new investment partnership.

title: Pilots and Mechanics Reach Wage Deal at United
description: United Airlines reached a tentative contract settlement with its pilots and mechanics yesterday that gives the owner-employees the largest salary and benefit increases permitted under an arbitrator's ruling.

title: Holding Life Together in Belfast
description: Among the few appealing side effects of the unending Irish troubles is the advent of women who have crossed the religious divide to work together for peace and the binding of their battered communities. Joining that admirable company tonight are Geraldine O'Regan, a Catholic, and May Blood, a Protestant. As seen in ''Daughters of the Troubles: Belfast Stories,'' they are more deeply united by class and by sex than they are separated by religion or by politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMNITZ, LENA (NEE ROSEN)
description: KAMNITZ-Lena (nee Rosen). Beloved sister of Rose Federoff. Devoted mother of Mildred and Lewis Gardner. Loving grandmother of Jay, Leslie and Art Greenberg. Services Tuesday. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533.

title: A Kentucky Town of 2,400 Is Deluged
description: Mildred and Tom Mohr ran from their house just in time this past weekend to have something left from the flood that destroyed this town of 2,400 -- each other.

title: Restatement Drops Summit Medical Stock
description: Summit Medical Systems Inc.'s stock fell 26 percent today after the company said it would restate its revenue downward for the last three years.

title: Nuclear Waste Convoy Stirs Angry Protests in Germany
description: It has rolled through Germany in recent days drawing protesters and would-be saboteurs and even people prepared to lie down on the railroad tracks to block its advance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASNIK, RUTHE
description: MASNIK-Ruthe. Beloved sister, aunt, friend and colleague. She will be missed by all. Donations may be made in her memory to the charity of your choice.

title: A New Collection of Stereotypes
description: NBC's new sitcom ''Just Shoot Me,'' having a preview tonight before being tested tomorrow in its regular slot of Wednesday nights at 9:30, is valiantly determined to drain laughs out of basically pathetic characters. There's an elderly man brandishing cigars (when is this instant in-your-face cliche going to go up in smoke?) and his new young trophy-wife; his daughter who wants to be a serious journalist but winds up shilling for Daddy's fluffy women's magazine; a former model who approaches middle age with a terror better reserved for death camps, and so on into the bottomless pit of contemporary stereotypes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNING, WILLIAM J.
description: MANNING-William J. The partners of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett are saddened by the passing of their retired partner, William J. Manning. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Maryanne and his family. The Partners of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGER, IDA
description: SIEGER-Ida. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family notes with sadness the passing of Ida Sieger, beloved mother of our long time friend and colleague Francine Sieger from the Dept. of Dental Medicine. To Francine, the entire Sieger family, and all of her mother's loved ones, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Robert G. Newman, M.D., Pres. Ray E. Trussell, M.D. General Director Emeritus Charles E. Barr, DDS, Chairman Emeritus, Dental Medicine Martin Levinbook, DDS, Acting Chairman Dental Medicine

title: Former Officer of Blue Cross Is Guilty of Lying to Panel
description: The former chief financial officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was convicted yesterday of lying to a Senate subcommittee and obstructing its investigation into financial problems at the giant medical insurance company.

title: Gene Discovery May Lead to Test for Devastating Eye Disorder
description: WHEN people first meet him, John Kebodeaux says, most do not notice anything unusual. But after a few minutes, some notice that he seems to be gazing past them, and they start glancing back over their shoulders, trying to see what he is looking at.

title: Sharing Anguish of Missing Man's Family
description: Patrick McNeill's throat catches every time he thinks back to last Tuesday evening. That night, hundreds of people he did not even know, far-flung neighbors who deserved a good long rest after a full day's work, came en masse to a Westchester middle school to pass on their strength, and a few words of encouragement, to him, a man whose 21-year-old son vanished two weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINFELD, DORIS STRAUSS
description: REINFELD-Doris Strauss. Of Coral Springs, FL. Died February 28, 1997. Beloved mother of Cindy Schnur and Marcia Gold. Adored grandmother and sister. Services Thursday at New Montefiore Cemetery. Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, 800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISELMAN, FLORENCE
description: MEISELMAN-Florence. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of its long-time member and extends to Michael and the bereaved family its heartfelt condolences.

title: Report Shows Strengthening For Industry American Incomes And Spending Up
description: Activity among American manufacturers improved in February from a month earlier as orders and production accelerated, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.

title: Nothing Like a Dame
description: When Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York went onstage last weekend as Rudia, transvestite nightclub performer, he put an end to any speculation whether people would ever forget the day he and Senator Alfonse D'Amato made undercover drug buys dressed as Hell's Angels. The photos of Mr. Giuliani in biker vest and shades seem awfully pedestrian now that we have seen him in pink gown, high heels and blond wig.

title: Pentagon Says Inquiry Will Seek Missing Chemical-Weapons Logs
description: The Pentagon announced today that it had asked the Defense Department's inspector general to investigate the disappearance of most of the chemical-detection logs maintained for American military commanders during the 1991 Persian Gulf war.

title: Yes, 'Ellen' Will Find That She's Gay
description: Ellen Morgan, the character played by Ellen DeGeneres on the ABC comedy ''Ellen,'' will discover that she is gay in an episode being filmed this week for broadcast on April 30, the network announced yesterday.

title: Mistrial Is Declared For Texas Cancer Doctor
description: A mistrial was declared today after a Federal criminal jury deadlocked 6 to 6 in the case of a Houston doctor who had been charged with violating the law in administering a controversial drug treatment he developed.

title: Greenwich Declines to Put Its Manicured Hand Out
description: Practically every town in America pines for Federal money to enhance its appearance, and local politicians campaign on their success in corralling grants. But the political leaders here have decided to thumb their noses at $500,000 in Federal money that would have brightened this town's main shopping street.

title: Payton Anxiously Waits for the Arm Pain to Stop
description: This was supposed to be Jay Payton's chance to show the Mets he deserves a spot in their starting outfield. But as spring training picks up steam, Payton sits and worries, hoping he will not be confronted by a medical diagnosis that ends his season before it starts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, MONROE R.
description: GOODMAN-Monroe R. The Board of Directors and staff of VISIONS/Services for the Blind and Visually Impaired records with sorrow the passing of Monroe R. Goodman. He was a most dedicated member of the Board and Advisory Council for 18 years and a past Treasurer and Secretary of VISIONS. Our deepest sympathy is expressed to his family. Nancy T. Jones, President Nancy D. Miller, Exec. Dir.

title: Youth Surrenders With Sharpton Present
description: A 16-year-old youth wanted in the death of his girlfriend surrendered yesterday to the police as the Rev. Al Sharpton, on the teen-ager's request, served as an intermediary.

title: HICKS, MUSE OFFERS TO ACQUIRE BRITAIN'S FORWARD GROUP
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas-based leveraged buyout specialist, said yesterday that it had bid $210 million to buy Forward Group of Britain to build its electronics manufacturing businesses. Forward's board unanimously recommended that shareholders accept the offer, saying that the combination of Forward's printed circuit board operations with those controlled by other Hicks, Muse companies would provide an international scope. Hicks, Muse has already won irrevocable commitments from Forward shareholders to sell 22.2 million shares of the company's stock, a 40.3 percent stake. The commitments are binding even if a higher offer is made.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUSKER, ANN
description: GLUSKER-Ann. Shalom Fannie Zornberg/Hadassah sadly reports the death of our devoted member and extend deepest sympathy to her family. Jaki Soreff, President

title: UConn Puts Miami to Sleep After Shattering Dreams
description: As it had done all season, the Connecticut women's basketball team lulled another opponent tonight into dreams of what might have been.

title: R. H. Paschal, 88, Restaurateur Who Nurtured Rights Leadership
description: Robert H. Paschal, the Atlanta restaurateur and entrepreneur whose perfectly seasoned fried chicken sustained the civil rights movement, died on Thursday at his home here. He was 88.

title: ADT SPURNS SWEETENED OFFER FROM WESTERN RESOURCES
description: ADT Ltd. rejected a sweetened offer yesterday from Western Resources Inc., saying it remained too low. Western, an electricity and natural gas company, raised the cash portion and lowered the amount of stock in the $3.5 billion hostile bid. The new offer was for $12.50 in Western stock and $10 in cash for each ADT share, instead of $15 in stock and $7.50 in cash. Western, based in Topeka, Kan., already owns 27 percent of ADT, which is based in Bermuda and is the largest provider of home security services to United States customers. Western has said that if it succeeds in buying ADT, it will sell the company's auto-auction business and focus on services to homes and businesses.

title: CBS to Buy One-Third Stake in Sportsline
description: CBS plans to invest $100 million to acquire a one-third stake in Sportsline USA Inc., a leading on-line sports service.

title: Welcoming Arafat, Clinton Rebukes Israel
description: With Yasir Arafat at his side, President Clinton delivered a mild but relatively rare rebuke of Israel today, saying the Israeli Government's decision last week to allow construction of thousands of new homes for Jews in East Jerusalem had created ''mistrust'' and could damage the peace effort in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEEBELI, RICHARD J.
description: SCHNEEBELI-Richard J., Jr. Age 37. Died Friday, February 28, 1997 at his home. He was a self employed industrial designer in Manhattan. Funeral services private.

title: School Guard Who Admits Gang Tie Is Reassigned
description: A school safety officer, who acknowledged that he belonged to the Latin Kings gang but defended it as an organization that helps Hispanic people, was reassigned yesterday from his job patrolling Intermediate School 302 in Brooklyn.

title: France to Lose Jobs In Renault Cost-Cutting
description: Renault S.A. said yesterday that it was preparing job cuts in France in an acceleration of a cost-cutting program begun last week when the car maker announced it would close its Belgian factory. A spokeswoman said Renault was about to present trade unions with a detailed plan for job cuts. She said that she was not able to comment on the plan's contents and that no date had been picked for its presentation.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: IT'S CALLED WINTER -- Snow and freezing rain returned to the region yesterday, just a reminder of what the season can be. Page B8.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, MILDRED
description: SLATER-Mildred Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of it's member, and extends it's condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: Republican Says White House Turned a List to Political Use
description: Already beset with questions about campaign fund raising, the Clinton Administration found itself in a dispute tonight with a House Republican over the use of White House computer data.

title: DEPUY BUYING MAJORITY STAKE IN FRENCH MANUFACTURER
description: DePuy Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in Landanger-Camus, a French maker of orthopedic products, for about $144.6 million. DePuy, a maker of orthopedic devices and supplies, based in Warsaw, Ind., said it would buy about two million shares, representing an 89.6 percent interest in Landanger, from the Landanger family and certain minority shareholders. DePuy said it would seek to buy the remaining shares after the completion of the block transaction. Landanger-Camus had sales of $87.9 million in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31.

title: The Pay-Per-View Fight With Just 2 1/2 Punches
description: Oliver McCall's sobbing ring breakdown last month against Lennox Lewis came from Filene's Basement. Based on a $10 or $12 monthly HBO fee, the debacle cost a subscriber less than one cent. McCall should not have been fighting so soon after leaving drug rehabilitation, but no one could label this a consumer scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGLAS, FRANCES
description: BERGLAS-Frances of Hallandale, FL. Survived by her husband Bernard and daughters Ellen Shaw and Ronnie Solow and 3 granchildren, Marc, Laurie and Alex.

title: Bonds Retreat As Economy Shows Muscle
description: Prices of Treasury securities were battered again yesterday and remained near session lows as reports that manufacturing was showing strength added to persistent investor concern that the Federal Reserve was inching closer to an increase in interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAKEN, JOAN WALD
description: BAKEN-Joan Wald. 19 June 1945-4 March 1995

title: HFS Agrees to Pay $175 Million to Acquire Value Rent-a-Car
description: HFS Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Value Rent-a-Car from Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. for $175 million in cash, thus adding a car rental company that caters primarily to leisure travelers in Sun Belt states to its ownership of Avis Rent a Car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBLING, ROBERT W. JR.
description: EBLING-Robert W. Jr., of Greenwich, Connecticut. A memorial service will be held on March 6, at 3:30 PM at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, 954 Lake Avenue, in North Greenwich, CT. The family will welcome friends at the home of Robert W. Ebling, III in Ridgefield, CT. that evening after a brief reception at the church following the ceremony. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be directed to Big Brothers/Big Sisters of New York City.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Sunday with an article about doctors who decide against prescribing new AIDS drugs to some patients misidentified the man shown. He was Julio Torres, who devised a complex schedule for taking the 16 pills he must swallow every day -- not Eddie Ramos, a counselor to homeless men, who also takes the new drugs.

title: Hoyas' Head Honcho Gets an Early Vote
description: JOHN THOMPSON is the Big East coach of the year. No ifs. No buts. No doubt.

title: The Unfunny Business Of Making the Right People (TV Producers) Laugh
description: So, two stand-up comics are sitting in a crowded bar when the manager walks up. They have to give up their seats, he says: a cast member of ''Saturday Night Live'' has entered the building with a friend. So the stand-ups stand up.

title: Executive Changes
description: CWT SPECIALTY STORES INC., South Attleboro, Mass., which operates 51 Cherry & Webb retail stores in New England, named the former chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive and Donald Eugene president and chief operating officer.

title: E.P.A. Presses City on Water Filtration Plant
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is seeking to fine New York City for failing to commit to a firm plan to build a filtration plant to clean the water flowing from the city's most polluted reservoirs, those in the Croton watershed east of the Hudson River.

title: Many Different Drummers Keep an Audience Out of Step
description: Theater audiences, like oarsmen, tend to pull together. They laugh as one at the funny lines, fight back tears at affecting moments and clap at about the same volume. This isn't happening at ''Stonewall Jackson's House,'' an unsettling satire by Jonathan Reynolds now playing Off Broadway at American Place Theater.

title: PERU LEADER SAYS CASTRO WILL GIVE ASYLUM TO REBELS
description: After diverting his executive jet to Cuba, President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru said today that Fidel Castro had agreed conditionally to give asylum to the Marxist guerrillas holding 72 hostages at the Japanese Embassy residence in Lima, Peru.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARSON, WILLIAM BROOKS
description: LARSON-William Brooks, formerly from Montclair and Essex Fells, NJ, died on February 26, 1997, in Wilmington, NC. He is survived by his wife Mary Louise Larson; three daughters: Bonnie Louise Seehorn, Donna Jean Larson, Mary Brooks Alderson.

title: Albanian Emergency
description: Barely seven years after it shed a fanatical Communist regime, Albania veers between anarchy and a brutal new dictatorship. Either would be disastrous for Europe's poorest nation and the volatile Balkan region surrounding it. Washington and other Western governments must do their best to broker a political compromise as a precondition for emergency financial relief.

title: Zoo Owner to Appoint Board
description: The owner of a private zoo that the state wants to shut down will appoint a board of directors to take over the zoo's management, a lawyer for the owner, Harold Kafka, said yesterday. The board will include wildlife biologists, veterinarians and some of the animal rights advocates who have complained about the living conditions for the 150 animals at the Scotch Plains Zoo, said the lawyer, Thomas Mellon. One of the protesters, Sherryl Volpone, accused Mr. Kafka of keeping chimpanzees in tiny cinder-block cages whose walls were smeared with excrement.

title: Keys but No Pages In On-Line Magazine
description: Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group and Bookwire have started Bold Type, a new on-line literary magazine featuring original fiction, essays, nonfiction, interviews and audio readings.

title: Mayor to Urge Site Recycling
description: Mayor J. Christian Bollwage of Elizabeth is to travel to Washington today to urge a subcommittee of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee to spend more on cleaning and reusing abandoned industrial sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTMAN, LEO
description: GUTMAN-Leo. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Ricki Jacoby on the loss of his beloved father, Leo. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: For Stocks, if Things Are Good, It Must Be Time to Split
description: With the Dow Jones industrial average hovering around the 7,000-point level and stock prices at record levels, companies are once again indulging in that old bull market pastime: stock splitting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, HENRY B.
description: ROBERTS-Henry B., of Sherborn, MA., February 28, 1997. Born in Bala-Cynwyd, PA., on March 14, 1914, he attended St. Paul's School, Concord, NH, and graduated from Princeton University in the class of 1936. His career was devoted entirely to publishing, with the exception of five years wartime service in the U.S. Navy. He served as Vice President of Charles Scribner's Sons, and the Kingsport Press in Kingsport, TN. He was President of the Plimpton Press in Boston, MA and later cofounded the Independent School Press. Survivors include his beloved wife of 60 years, the former Paton Rauch; a brother Laurence, of Baltimore, MD; a son Henry B., Jr. of Garrison, NY; a daughter Polly Roberts of Springfield, MA and 8 grandchildren. An elder son, Brinton Page Roberts died in 1989. Interment in St. Asaph's Church, Bala-Cynwyd, PA. A memorial service will be held later in Boston. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to St. Paul's School, Concord, NH 03301 or The Friends of The Sherborn Library, Sherborn, MA. 01770. For further information contact J.S. Waterman & SonsWaring Funeral Home, Wellesley.

title: Abs of Steel: Parcells Wants His Jets Bigger and Stronger
description: Bill Parcells sent a strong first message to his new Jets troops today, saying he would revamp the linebacking corps and announcing a new off-season conditioning program that begins this month and could hardly be described as optional.

title: In Work on Intuition, Gut Feelings Are Tracked to Source: The Brain
description: IN an experiment with broad implications for human behavior, scientists have shown that people have a covert system in their brains for telling them when decisions are good or bad and that the system, which draws upon emotional memories, is activated long before people are consciously aware that they have decided anything.

title: Tory Ex-Aide Says Major Told Him to Solicit Big Party Donation
description: Prime Minister John Major was personally involved in seeking an $800,000 donation for the Conservative Party from a foreign businessman, a former party treasurer has disclosed in a new book.

title: Cut Corporate Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Face Playoff Limbo
description: Islander General Manager Mike Milbury left the door open yesterday on making a trade in time for the playoffs, despite passing a self-imposed deadline on Sunday. ''I absolutely thought I would have a lot clearer view,'' Milbury said by telephone from Toronto yesterday, referring to the deadline he had put on his team to demonstrate whether it could realistically challenge for a playoff spot. ''Needless to say, things aren't a whole lot clearer.''

title: Realty Merger
description: Insignia Financial Group, the Greenville, S.C.-based company that took over the Edward S. Gordon Company in New York last year, announced yesterday that it had acquired Rostenberg-Doern, which is a major participant in the Westchester County, N.Y., and Fairfield County, Conn., real estate markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ROBERT
description: MARKS-Robert. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the passing of Robert Marks. We offer our sincere condolences to Dr. Paul Marks, Lawrence Marks and the entire Marks family. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel Reingold, Executive VP

title: IN STORMS' WAKE, GRIEF AND SHOCK
description: In Arkadelphia, Ark., a man begged a reporter to say something nice about a woman who died in an avalanche of brick and broken lumber, and a woman and her niece searched for a missing tree.

title: Pettitte Keeps Mind on Game Instead of New Deal
description: Andy Pettitte preferred to talk about striking out Detroit's Tony Clark and Melvin Nieves to escape from a bases-loaded jam in the third inning today, but there are lingering questions about his contract for 1997 and the left-hander cannot escape them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GIBNEY, WILSON
description: GIBNEY-Wilson. Ten years and always in our thoughts. Helen, Pam and Paula

title: Palestinians Strike Over Israeli Building Plan
description: Widening their protests against Israeli plans to build a new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem, Palestinians held a general strike here and across the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, shuttering shops, closing schools and government offices and leaving city streets deserted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZLOTNICK, LILLIAN W.
description: ZLOTNICK-Lillian W. On March 3, 1997. Formerly of Stamford, CT. Wife of Louis. Mother of Doreen Testa of Woodbridge, CT. Sister of Ray Litchman of Glen Cove & the late Louis Wiener. Grandmother of Marc and Alan Testa. Services Wednesday, 3 PM, Congregation Agudath Shalom, 301 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford, CT. For further information call Shure Funeral Home, 203-562-8244.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCCHI, VELMA
description: LUCCHI-Velma. We mourn the passing and celebrate the life of Velma Lucchi, our generous benefactor and mother of the late Sr. Lucian Lucchi. Our sympathies to her family. The Board and Staff of Brookdale Center on Aging of Hunter College

title: Politics By the Old Rules
description: Despite the scandal-a-day schedule of recent weeks, President Clinton's popularity ratings are as high as ever. Washington reels with every blow it delivers at its elusive target, a man who seems not to feel the impact at all. It is a variant on Muhammad Ali's rope-a-dope tactic. This is punch-a-dope, which leaves the assailant in a vacuum, all punched out with no punches landed, so far as popular revulsion goes.

title: Renault Layoffs Test French Commitment to European Unity
description: Europe, the French kept saying, was not like the United States, and never would be.

title: Christian Rebels Wage a War of Terror in Uganda
description: The Lord's Resistance Army strolled into the village of Palabek one recent morning, a ragged bunch of teen-age boys with machine-guns and machetes.
