They announced that they were looking for three deserters whom they had abducted from the same village a few months earlier, witnesses said.

title: Nets Lose It As Blazers Get Kittles To Cool Off
description: This was the floor model. This was Kerry Kittles at his best, a talent in plain view of everyone and not hidden on the bench. He fired away tonight until the Trail Blazers slapped Stacey Augmon on him like a decal.

title: On Black Films and Breezy Lesbians
description: The politics of gender and multiculturalism, with their prickly debates about who is entitled to tell whose story, are twitted with such good-humored cheek in Cheryl Dunye's mock documentary, ''The Watermelon Woman,'' that feathers will undoubtedly be ruffled.

title: Leanne Katz, 65, Director Of Anti-Censorship Coalition
description: Leanne Katz, who served as executive director of the National Coalition Against Censorship since its creation more than 20 years ago, died at her New York home Sunday, after a three-year battle with cancer. She was 65.

title: Crispin Porter Gets Time Assignment
description: Time magazine, owned by Time Warner Inc., has named Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami to handle a television campaign to increase awareness of the publication in Latin America. Billings were estimated at $1 million. Richard Hine, marketing services director at Time in New York, said the assignment was awarded to Crispin Porter after a review of Miami agencies; he declined to identify the other participants. Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis continues as the Time agency of record in the United States, Mr. Hine said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLAIR, JEAN HEWITT
description: BLAIR-Jean Hewitt, a former writer and home economist for the New York Times, died on February 9th, 1997, in Venice, FL. A memorial service will be at 11:00 AM on March 13, 1997, at CCUN Chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza (44th Street and First Avenue) in New York, New York. In addition, a memorial service will be at 1:00 P.M., on March 22, 1997, at Christ United Methodist Church in Venice, FL. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Jean Hewitt Blair Memorial Fund at the League for the Hard of Hearing, 71 West 23rd Street, New York, New York 10010-4162.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINELLI, HERCULES L.
description: CINELLI-Hercules L., of Carmel, died March 3, at Putnam Hospital Center. Beloved husband of Jean (nee Martin). Brother of Marion Monachelli. Viewing Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9, Cargain Funeral Homes Inc., 418 Route 6, Mahopac, NY. Funeral Mass March 6, 10 AM, St. John the Evangelist church, Mahopac, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory made to St. Jude's Hospital or Memorial Sloan Kettering.

title: Rail Systems That Stretch Coast to Coast May Be in Sight
description: Robert D. Krebs -- chairman of Burlington Northern, the largest railroad in the country -- told stock analysts assembled at his Fort Worth headquarters last November that he would oppose a merger of Conrail and the CSX Corporation that left a single railroad in supreme control of the Eastern rail market.

title: KRUGER PLANS TO BUY SCOTT PAPER OF CANADA
description: Kruger Inc., one of Canada's largest pulp and paper companies, plans to acquire Scott Paper Ltd. for $451 million Canadian, or about $330 million, Scott said yesterday. Kruger plans to pay $23 Canadian a share for Scott and to assume $100 million Canadian in debt. Scott, which is based in Mississauga, Ontario, said in August that it was trying to find a buyer for the company, after the Kimberly-Clark Corporation announced that it planned to sell its 50.1 percent stake in the Canadian-based tissue maker. Kimberly merged with the Scott Paper Company in a $9.4 billion transaction in December 1995. The Canadian Government required that Kimberly sell some of its Scott operations. Kruger is a closely held company based in Montreal.

title: For Arkansas Town, Rubble and Rebuilding
description: It is hard to tell what this town might have looked like before 2:46 P.M. last Saturday, when the tornado hit. It is so hard that when some residents came back to the piles of rubble that had been their downtown, they got lost.

title: New Study on a Fuel Additive
description: Since 1992, gasoline sold in New Jersey has contained an additive intended to reduce carbon monoxide in car emissions and improve air quality. For almost as long, Oxy-Busters, an environmental group, has been trying to rid the state of the additive, methyl tertiary butyl ether, or MTBE. Barry Grossman, the founder of the group, says that more than 800 New Jerseyans have suffered from nausea, headaches and other symptoms because of MTBE.

title: Rangers Fly West and Ponder a Problem
description: As they head west for a three-game trip, their last extended journey of the season, the Rangers pack with them an awkward piece of baggage.

title: Justices Hear Arguments on School Financing Plan
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new school financing plan is constitutional, and in the first indication of how they may rule, the justices appeared ready to accept the plan's basic premise: that an equal education should be defined by what students learn instead of how much their district spends.

title: The Battle Over Gifted Programs
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is right that New York City's schools must make programs for gifted children more accessible to minorities, who are often shunted aside when they seek information from their schools. But Dr. Crew must also tend to the fears of parents who suspect him of wanting to dissolve the programs or make them less rigorous.

title: Playing the Only Game in Tinseltown
description: MONSTER

title: Valentine Hopes Baerga Is the Answer at Second
description: Carlos Baerga has done a complete turnaround from his initial reaction -- dismay -- at being traded to the Mets from Cleveland last season. But the Mets still have not decided whether the 28-year-old can play second base well enough to fit into the club's plans at that position.

title: Democrat Wins New Backing
description: Representative Robert E. Andrews of Haddon Heights broadened his support in northern New Jersey yesterday as his gubernatorial campaign received an endorsement from another Democratic Congressman, Robert Menendez of Union City. A spokesman for Mr. Andrews's principal rival, State Senator James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, played down the significance of the endorsement, noting that much of Mr. Menendez's district lies in Hudson County, where Mr. Andrews has the support of County Executive Robert C. Janiszewski.

title: Dayton Hudson's Net Income Drops, but Federated Shows a Gain
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation reported a decline in net income for the fiscal fourth quarter yesterday, while Federated Department Stores Inc. posted a gain. Both retailers recorded improved results before charges were taken for the quarter, which ended Feb. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, AUGUSTA POLLACK
description: FINKELSTEIN-Augusta Pollack. On March 2, 1997. Widow of Robert Finkelstein of Woonsocket, R.I. Mother of Naomi Eber and David Finkelstein. Grandmother of Elizabeth and David Eber. Sister of Mac Pollack. Interment is private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FROELICH, BETTY
description: FROELICH-Betty. In loving memory. Your Family

title: Cohen Says U.S. Troops Will Leave Bosnia in '98
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen told American allies in Europe today that United States peacekeeping troops would pull out of Bosnia next year even if the country was still in turmoil.

title: Diplomacy First in Zaire
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, is asking the Security Council to consider sending armed peacekeepers to Zaire. The suggestion is premature since there is not yet a peace to preserve, and international forces should not be dispatched to separate warring parties by force. But Mr. Annan usefully focuses international attention on the Zairian crisis. The urgent need is a diplomatic campaign to secure a cease-fire aimed at protecting civilians, including both Zairians and Rwandan Hutu refugees caught up in the conflict.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ON PAY RAISES -- Legislative leaders have begun discussing a proposal to give legislators, the governor and other state officials pay increases tied to the inflation rate. B2.

title: Israel's Housing Project
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Subpoenaed
description: Prosecutors from the Whitewater independent counsel's office have recently issued a subpoena to the White House seeking information about a prominent Indonesian family with ties to President Clinton, an Administration official said today.

title: Councilman Seeks Limit Of $10 Per Campaign Gift
description: Sal F. Albanese, a City Councilman and Democratic mayoral candidate, proposed a bill yesterday that would reduce the limit on single campaign contributions to $10 for candidates for city offices. The limit now ranges from $3,550 for Council candidates to $7,700 for mayoral candidates.

title: Voters Favor Current Rent Laws, Poll Shows
description: As the Legislature gears up for what is expected to be a bitter debate over state rent rules, a poll released today shows that by a wide margin voters favor maintaining those laws, which provide an array of protection to more than two million tenants.

title: Japan May Allow New Brokerage Services
description: A newspaper report said today that Japanese brokerage firms would be allowed to offer some services that compete with banks. The report, which raised optimism in the financial industry that deregulation might be accelerating, pushed up the stocks of the brokerage companies.

title: In a Mismatch, the Huskies Claim Fourth Straight Title
description: The Fighting Irish fought, but they never had a chance. The unbeaten Connecticut Huskies had too good a shooting eye, too much speed, too much quickness and, above all, too much larceny as they whipped the Irish, 86-77, tonight and won the Big East women's basketball tournament for the fourth consecutive year.

title: With Stars Gone, It's a Free-for-All
description: Steve Lappas needed just two games to know what kind of league the Big East had become this season. After two conference games, those early December meetings made necessary by the 1994 expansion, his Villanova Wildcats had a conference record of 2-0. Lappas looked over his shoulder in search of other successful starts, and he found . . . no one.

title: Restore Housing Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASSUK, BERTRAM L.
description: BASSUK-Bertram L. FAIA. Of NYC. Esteemed architect, died March 2, 1997. Beloved brother of Harold and Gloria, cherished uncle of Jeffrey and Janice, treasured cousin and friend. A memorial gathering to celebrate his life will be held at the Community Room, 343 Eighth Avenue (27th Street), 2 PM, Saturday, March 8, 1997.

title: G.O.P. INTENSIFIES BID FOR INQUIRIES OVER FUND-RAISING
description: Top Congressional Republicans stepped up the pressure today to force investigations of Clinton-Gore campaign fund-raising, both in the Senate and by an independent counsel.

title: Kingsley Davis, 88, Who Told Of 'Zero Population Growth'
description: Kingsley Davis, the sociologist and demographics expert who coined the term ''zero population growth,'' argued passionately for a wide range of measures to bring it about and then, paradoxically, warned of the dangers of low birthrates, died on Feb. 27 at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 88 and had ended his academic career as a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution there.

title: Town With Bad Luck Waits Out New Flood
description: Good luck seems to trickle into this old river town. Bad luck pours.

title: 'A Rare Combination'
description: Although gravity is, for the public, the most familiar of nature's forces, it is the least understood by scientists, and theorists have encountered many pitfalls. In 1961, Dr. Dicke and his graduate student, Carl H. Brans, proposed that gravity might have two components: one of them the familiar force impelling objects straight down and another, much weaker, component causing objects to shrink or expand.

title: Hearings on C.I.A. Nominee Will Go Forward
description: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said tonight that he would go forward with confirmation hearings next week for the nominee for Director of Central Intelligence, Anthony Lake.

title: Clinton Bans Federal Money For Efforts to Clone Humans
description: President Clinton today imposed a ban on the use of Federal money for cloning humans and asked researchers supported by private money to hold off voluntarily, saying people should ''resist the temptation to replicate ourselves.''

title: Jerusalem Can't Belong to Only One People
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel's Housing Project
description: To the Editor:

title: New Skills Produced Along With Wood
description: Along with furniture and flooring, Big City Forest is also creating dozens of jobs. Many of its employees were among the nearly 200 people who learned woodworking skills at a nonprofit training center at the company's headquarters.

title: Aide to Newark Mayor Didn't Steer Decision, Officials Testify
description: The defense in the bribery and corruption trial of the former chief aide to Newark's Mayor opened its case today with testimony from other top city officials that the aide had not influenced their choice of an insurance carrier for city employees and had not even attended the meetings at which the matter was discussed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, MARY
description: CARROLL-Mary, of Manhattan, on Sunday, March 2, 1997, at New York Hospital. Beloved sister of Joan Carroll of NYC and Anne Tamulonis of Frackville, Pa. Loving aunt to Diane Naspinski and her daughter Jennifer and son Eric. Interment will be in her home town of Frackville. A memorial service in NYC is planned for April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, HENRY LOUIS, M.D.
description: FREEDMAN-Henry Louis, M.D. Husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle; physician, teacher, sweet friend to us all. Died March 3rd, 1997 at age 86.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE letter was typical; it came from a reader who, try as he might, could not find a bottle of a DeLoach zinfandel that had been recommended here. His complaint was justified: fewer than 500 cases of that wine were made, and it's safe to assume that much of it went to DeLoach fans in California. DeLoach Vineyards is a zinfandel specialist in the Russian River Valley in Sonoma County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLER, EVELYN
description: WALLER-Evelyn. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Devoted mother of Wendy, Bruce and Gail. Dear sister of Roselle Cohan, Al Goldberg and Louis Goldberg. Cherished grandmother of Skylor, Dara and Andrew. Services Thursday 10:00 AM ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Alarm Company in Deal
description: The AT&T Corporation has entered into a joint marketing agreement with ADT Ltd., an electronic security concern, the companies said today. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Yanks' Wells Quiets His Critics for Now
description: David Wells's uniform pants were covered with grass stains because he had dived for balls like a kid during a pre-game workout. His thinning hair was wet because he is trying to sweat off some weight. His air guitar was in full rock-and-roll imitation because a radio was cranking Van Halen inches from his ear.

title: Will Special Bullets Make City Streets Safer?
description: If the New York City Police Department switches to hollow-point bullets, will the city be safer for innocent bystanders?

title: Singing, and That's All, Until Now, That Is
description: Schubert spent so much of his short life composing that he probably had very little idea what the rest of us do with our time. If pressed to imagine, he might have drawn on his experience. People in his presence tended to sing, so that must be what they are up to. An opera about real people, then, would have them singing. Hence ''Fierrabras.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: The last time PETER JENNINGS, the ABC News anchor, sang in public, he was the host for the Miss Canada pageant and the singer Gordon MacRae, who was to entertain, became ill. ''I said, 'Of course I can sing,' and the next day I was criticized for being off key and three bars behind the orchestra,'' Mr. Jennings recalled yesterday.

title: Film Boycotts Pose a Danger to Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, JACQUES
description: RECANATI-Jacques. The Board of Trustees, Medical Board, and Administration of Beth Israel Medical Center acknowledge with sadness the passing of Jacques Recanati, dear brother of Raphael Recanati, our generous benefactor and Honorary Member of the Board. To Eliane, the beloved wife of Jacques Recanati, their sons, Ariel, David and Lenny, the entire Recanati family and all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Board of Trustees Robert G. Newman, M.D., Pres. Jerome S. Breslaw, M.D., Pres. Medical Board

title: When Artists and Dealers Get Together to Take Care of One of Their Own
description: At 40, the art dealer Pat Hearn is widely respected for her professionalism, her style and her sharp eye for emerging artists. She has given debut shows for such artists as Philip Taaffe, George Condo and Renee Green; she helped found the young dealers' annual gathering, the Gramercy International Contemporary Art Fair, and she has helped pioneer art neighborhoods, from the East Village in the 1980's to her gallery's current home, Chelsea.

title: Pushing the Edible Envelope: Beyond the Venerable Tortilla
description: A LOT of interesting flavors are being kept under wraps these days, not because of any culinary cloak-and-dagger operations but because more and more cooks are wrapping ingredients in what are essentially edible envelopes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 about an apology by President Kim Young Sam of South Korea in regard to his son's possible involvement in a corruption scandal mistranslated one of the President's remarks in some editions. Mr. Kim said, ''I am to blame for not having taught my son to behave properly in everything he does,'' not, ''I taught him to do the right thing.''

title: White House Political Tightrope: Separating Business From Politics
description: A visitor to the cramped White House office of Harold M. Ickes last year might have noticed one computer in his office and several just outside -- one of which was set aside solely for campaign politics. Mr. Ickes, then a White House deputy chief of staff, also had two telephones, one for government and one for politics, two separate pagers, and a cellular phone for politics.

title: The Law According to Gore
description: We salute Vice President Al Gore's decision to come forward and answer questions about his role in the Democrats' unrestrained fund-raising in 1996. But surely Mr. Gore and President Clinton know that the situation is too messy for the American public to accept Mr. Gore's relaxed reading of the Federal law against soliciting money on Federal property.

title: Congress Again Kills Budget-Balancing Proposal
description: For the eighth time in 15 years, Congress has defeated a Constitutional amendment to require the Federal budget to be balanced.

title: Yanks Asked to See Deal
description: Major League Baseball asked to see the Yankees' whopping new marketing deal with Adidas yesterday, but the team did not turn over a copy of the agreement.

title: Treating Epilepsy With Diet
description: To The Living Section:

title: Fee Income Up 20% In Public Relations
description: Fee income for the nation's 50 largest public relations agencies rose 20 percent in 1996 to a record $1.55 billion from $1.29 billion in 1995, according to an annual survey.

title: Abortion Proponent's Lie Didn't Change Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: Plunge in Profits For Pohang Iron
description: The Pohang Iron and Steel Company, the world's second-largest steel manufacturer, said yesterday that its profit tumbled 25.7 percent last year because of slumping product prices and foreign exchange losses. Profit at Pohang, a South Korean company, fell to 624 billion won ($743 million), according to provisional figures. Sales rose 2.8 percent to 8.45 trillion won.

title: Silent at Approach of Death, Families Worsen Pain of Loss
description: Joan Siff and her father, Martin Isaacs, were as close, she thought, as parent and child could be. She had always enjoyed the facility of his mind and the generosity of his heart. Though he never went to college, they would have lengthy talks about classical literature and class division in American society. His passion was poetry, and in 1991, Mrs. Siff's sons, Andrew and Michael, published a volume of their grandfather's verse as a family legacy.

title: Boston Chicken Buying
description: Boston Chicken Inc. said it would acquire an 84 percent stake in its New York area franchisee by converting an $80 million loan and buying out some the franchisee's investors.

title: Raises Tied to Inflation Weighed in Albany
description: Without admitting that they were supporting or even seriously negotiating the idea, legislative leaders said today that they have begun discussing a proposal to give legislators, the Governor and other state officials periodic pay increases tied to the rate of inflation -- much the way Social Security recipients get automatic cost-of-living adjustments.

title: Earnings Outlook for Stocks Gets a Tougher Look
description: While the surprising downgrade in earnings expectations at the AT&T Corporation may be just bad news for the telecommunications giant, it is raising questions about the overall earnings outlook for the stock market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAAG, CECILIA
description: MAAG-Cecilia, of Pearl River, NY, Mar. 3, 1997. Beloved mother of Helen Kovarik of Pearl River. Also survived by 3 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial to be held Thursday, 10 AM, at St. Margaret's RC Church, Pearl River. Burial St. Anthony's Cemetery, Nanuet, New York. Visiting Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9 P.M., at the Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home, Inc., 100 Franklin Avenue, Pearl River, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, DEAN K.
description: HARRISON-Dean K. The faculty, staff, & students of The Graduate School and University Center of The City University of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Dean K. Harrison, founding director of the Office of Expanded Educational Opportunity and a pioneer on behalf of federal fellowship programs for minority students. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Donations in his memory may be made to the CUNY Graduate School's Dean K. Harrison Fellowship Fund (make checks payable to The Graduate Center Foundation, 33 West 42 Street, New York City 10036). Frances Degen Horowitz President

title: China Turns the Tables, Faulting U.S. on Rights
description: Each year when the State Department issues its report on the status of human rights in China, officials in Beijing seem to cringe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, BARBARA ANN
description: RUBIN-Barbara Ann, 48, died Saturday 3/1/97 Naples, FL. Survived by husband George T. Rubin. For information contact Schoedinger Funeral Home, Columbus, OH. Contributions to St Francis De Sales Scholarship Fund, 4212 Karl Road, Columbus, OH. 43224.

title: Manual Is Faulted on Overdoses
description: A LEADING reference book that many doctors consult when they treat people for overdoses of medication gives outdated, incorrect advice that may harm patients, a group of poison-control experts has reported. The book, the Physicians' Desk Reference, or P.D.R., is the one doctors most often use when prescribing drugs, but they should not rely on it for directions on managing overdoses, the researchers said. Instead, they recommended calling a poison control center.

title: Black Boarding Schools Suffer Unexpected Closings
description: In his last semester of high school, Joseph Counts has not had the luxury of worrying solely about college acceptance letters, senior proms and class rings. Instead, the Brooklyn teen-ager has been consumed with finding a boarding school that won't close before the end of the school year.

title: Abortion Proponent's Lie Didn't Change Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTERMAN, SIMEON
description: GUTERMAN-Simeon. We extend our Kos Tanchumim to Sidney Adler on the loss of his beloved brother-in-law, and to Silver Founder Abraham Guterman on the loss of his beloved brother. When a history of the Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem will be written, an important chapter will be devoted to the outstanding devotion, generosity of heart & leadership on behalf of Israel's ''Hospital with a Heart'' by Sidney and Betty Adler and members of their family. That is because from the very inception of the hospital, the Adler family has played a vital role in providing compassionate medical care to the people of Jerusalem. Sidney serves as Treasurer of the American Comittee and together with Betty is a Diamond Founder of the hospital. They have continued the family's involvement through the participation of their son David, who serves on the Metropolitan Cabinet, and who is a Founder of the Hospital along with his wife Renee. May the entire family have warm and loving memories of Simeon Guterman and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee of the Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Charles H. Bendheim, President Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Lee Weinbach, Secretary International Board of Governors Menno Ratzker, Chairman Morris Talansky, Executive Vice Chairman

title: The Wages of Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health
description: GENERATIONS of Americans have been exhorted to eat spinach or liver for the iron that supposedly made Popeye's muscles bulge or to take iron-rich tonics like Geritol to revive their ''tired blood.'' But while some iron in the diet is critical for health and life itself, the overconsumption or overabsorption of this well-known mineral is now under intense scrutiny as a possible cause or contributor to killer ailments like heart disease and cancer as well as serious infections.

title: For Eggplant, A Giant Leap Out of the Fat
description: Eggplant soaks up oil like no other vegetable. But no one ever thought to broil it until a few years ago, when people began to worry about the amount of fat they were consuming. Now, recipes in many cookbooks advise broiling. Even cookbooks written by chefs.

title: Government Is Overzealous On Secrecy, Panel Advises
description: A Federal commission on Government secrecy, only the second in the nation's history, said in its final report today that the Government kept too much too secret for too long and blamed what it termed ''a culture of secrecy'' for fostering and perpetuating conspiracy theories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINFELD, MORRIS, M.D.
description: KLEINFELD-Morris, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center expresses with sorrow the death of Dr. Morris Kleinfeld. Dr. Kleinfeld was associated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Department of Medicine for over fifty years. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. David Eddi, M.D., President Warren Wexelman, M.D. President Elect Jacob Shani, M.D., Secretary David Feldman, M.D, Treasurer

title: CHRONICLE
description: What is it like for a singer to look at an audience and see men dressed in gowns more lavish than hers?

title: Instructor Error Cited in Crash Of Plane Flown by 7-Year-Old
description: A 7-year-old girl's effort to become the youngest person to pilot a plane across the United States ended in a fatal crash last April because the flight instructor aboard tried too hard to keep an overly ambitious schedule driven by ''media commitments,'' the National Transportation Safety Board concluded today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMEIDLER, CURT A., MD.
description: SCHMEIDLER-Curt A., MD. On March 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Freda (Fritzi). Devoted father of Peter and father-in-law of Lois. Cherished grandfather of David, Debra, Susan and Karyn. Dedicated physician to the Kew Gardens community. Services Thursday, at 2 P.M., at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels.''

title: Whither Prince Albert?
description: It's not easy being Prince Albert.

title: Big Mac's Price Cut Won't Cut the Fat
description: SO the price of a Big Mac is dropping to 55 cents. According to classic economic theory, the steep price cut will draw more customers, who will buy more Big Macs, which will fatten the company's bottom line.

title: Target Store Aimed at Edison
description: Moving into one of the busiest retail corridors in the New York region, Target Stores will open a new, 125,000-square-foot store, its first in the state, at 100 Parsonage Road in Edison on Sunday.

title: In Vongerichten's New Venture, the Kitchen Is on Display
description: SEVERAL cooks were clustered around a chicken, just out of the oven, roasted with herbs and truffles under the skin. ''Come on, guys,'' Jean-Georges Vongerichten declared. ''We don't need three people to deal with one chicken. What will we do when the restaurant opens?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHGOLD, MAX
description: FISHGOLD-Max. Age 94, in Poughkeepsie, NY on March 3, 1997. Husband of the late Edith Fishgold. Loving father of Martin Fishgold of Long Beach, NY. Father-in-law of Karen. Grandfather of Maggy Fishgold Heaney and Gunther Fishgold. World citizen. Former President of the Brighton Beach International Workers Order, the Greenvale Chamber of Commerce and the Miami Beach Jewish Cultural Center. Memorial service to be announced.

title: U.N.'s Costs Are Leveling Off, Chief Financial Officer Reports
description: The senior financial officer of the United Nations said today that spending for 1998 and 1999 would come in under budget if the dollar remained relatively stable and inflation subdued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, YA'ACOV
description: RECANATI-Ya'acov. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of the beloved brother of Raphael (and Dina) Recanati, YU Guardians who endowed the University's Recanati Courses in Kabbalah and, at our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, the Raphael Recanati Fellowship in Semikhah Studies and the Raphael and Dina Recanati Israeli Exchange Student Fellowship. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: For Capital's Government, An Infusion and Cutbacks
description: Problems plaguing the District of Columbia have become so commonplace that even on a day of good news, there is often bad news to blunt it. Today the conflict was reflected on both sides of the Anacostia River.

title: Rule on Options and Warrants Could Alter Profit Perception
description: If earnings per share is the one number that investors watch in companies' financial reports, it is about to get more important to pay attention to the diluted number -- the second one on most earnings announcements -- rather than the one now called primary earnings per share. In some cases, the diluted figure is likely to be significantly lower than the primary one.

title: Robert Dicke, Noted Physicist, 80, Dies; Gravity Theorist Who Challenged Einstein
description: Dr. Robert H. Dicke, who predicted the discovery of the Big Bang echo, conducted classic experiments in gravity and for a time was a chief challenger to Einstein's general theory of relativity, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J., after a long illness. He was 80.

title: Structure Leases Space
description: Structure Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Limited, has leased the 17,000-square-foot 12th floor of 79 Fifth Avenue, a 17-story office building at 16th Street, for its first New York City office.

title: Dior's Elaborate Creations, as Romantic And Disciplined as the Garb of Knights
description: On the way to the Costume Institute's Christian Dior exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, you can walk through the Egyptian galleries, past mummies and sarcophagi beautifully wrapped, constructed and embellished, past wall paintings from ancient dynasties: exactingly drawn silhouettes in deep, rich colors; still, hieratic figures in profile.

title: Girls' School: Neighbors For, NOW Against
description: MARILYN RIOS doesn't know from N.Y.C.L.U. or NOW. The only letters that matter to her are the A's and B's she has earned at the Young Women's Leadership School, the all-girls public school in East Harlem. Gone are the boys in her old school, who used to poke her in the back and distract her during class. Gone, too, are the C's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SALLY L.
description: COHEN-Sally L. Long time resident and business owner in Yonkers, at age 84. Beloved wife of Samuel, devoted mother of Cynthia Gaines, Arleen Neustein, Michael Cohen & the late Barbara Marger. Adored grandmother of eight. Founder and CEO of Excelsior Transparent Bag Mfg. Corp. of Yonkers. Charter Member of Lincoln Park J.C., Lifetime Member of Hadassah, and member of The Soroptimists of Westchester. Services Wednesday, March 5, 1 PM, at The Riverside Memorial Chapel of Westchester, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: No Headline
description: ''Consumers who pay attention to warnings don't get hurt in the first place and consumers who get hurt typically aren't the ones who read warnings.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'GORMAN, EMMA LOUISA (CRAWFORD)
description: O'GORMAN-Emma Louisa (Crawford), in her eighty-fourth year. Beloved wife of the late Edward M. O'Gorman, devoted mother of Kathleen, Charlotte, Elizabeth and Martha. Loving daughter of the late James and Anne Kerr Crawford. Cherished grandmother of eight. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 8 at 11:00 AM at St. Mary'sin-Tuxedo, Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Contributions to the Tuxedo Park School, Tuxedo Park, NY 10987 or the Tuxedo Volunteer Ambulance Corps would be appreciated.

title: Clinton's Watergate Rerun
description: The ''high crime'' of Watergate was Nixon's abuse of his White House power to affect his 1972 re-election. That same offense -- the Clinton-Gore White House's abusing Presidential power to unfairly influence their 1996 re-election -- is at the heart of today's campaign scandal.

title: The Real Chinese Threat
description: China casts such a large shadow over the future that it has become the crux of all debate over the risks and rewards of the globalizing economy.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Styles pages on Sunday about sewing referred incorrectly to the pattern company for which Daphne Maxwell Reid produces a signature line. It is McCall's, not Simplicity.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Bans Aid for Cloning

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Home Sales Report Shows Big Gain but Raises Doubt

title: Seles Withdraws From Evert Cup Event
description: MONICA SELES, who confirmed last week that her father and coach, KAROLJ, is undergoing chemotherapy after a recurrence of stomach cancer, has withdrawn from the event that would have been her first tournament of 1997, the State Farm Evert Cup in Indian Wells, Calif., which runs until the middle of the month. Seles, who hasn't played since Dec. 4, attributed her withdrawal to continuing soreness in her broken right ring finger. Seles injured the finger while catching a tennis ball during a practice session for an exhibition appearance against 16-year-old MARTINA HINGIS in Europe in December. Seles now expects to make her 1997 debut at the Lipton Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla., later this month.

title: Housing Data Help to Push Bonds Lower
description: Treasury prices finished lower in choppy trading yesterday, hurt by a housing report that was stronger than expected.

title: Morgan Stanley Hires Mickey Kantor
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that it had named Mickey Kantor, the former Secretary of Commerce, as senior adviser to its investment banking division.

title: Seattle Superintendent to Hold Off on Allowing Ads in Schools
description: Responding to strong community opposition, the head of the Seattle public schools has proposed that the school board suspend its new policy to seek advertising revenue from corporations, postponing action while the issue is studied.

title: Chronicling the End for 20: Hard Choices Are Harder When Wishes Go Unsaid
description: Twenty people died at Beth Israel Medical Center from Nov. 1 to Nov. 11, 1995. Each death was a personal loss, but together the cases offer a glimpse of the complicated decisions that arise when death nears and the aversion people have to talking about such matters in advance. Martin Isaacs was typical of many people who died in this period: he was older, he had been sick for some time he had never spoken to his family or doctor about ''end of life'' care.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: A Plan Seeks to Inspire Civics and Big Questions
description: The University of California at Los Angeles is considering a proposal to replace traditional freshman classes like English Comp and Sociology 101 with a core interdisciplinary curriculum that encourages students ''to ask the large questions'' and become good citizens.

title: Average Hollywood Film Now Costs $60 Million
description: Sherry Lansing, chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group, said she was ''horrified.'' Casey Silver, chairman of Universal Pictures, said he was ''disturbed but not surprised.'' And Joe Roth, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, said it was ''upsetting.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: Mr. Giuliani's wife, DONNA HANOVER, had a cancerous growth removed from her face last week.

title: United Airlines will try to lure and keep passengers by offering more food on some flights.
description: UNITED AIRLINES is defying the current trend of skimping on airline food to see if quantity will attract passengers.

title: Dismantling the Secrecy System
description: It is a rare moment in Washington when someone does something sensible about the Government's obsession with secrecy. A Congressional commission has done just that in a thoughtful new report that recommends a long-overdue change in the way official secrets are made and maintained. The commission's novel contention is that Congress, not the Federal bureaucracy, should determine how and why information is kept secret by establishing a law on secrecy.

title: New-Home Sales Jumped 8.6% in January
description: The Government reported today that sales of new homes had risen 8.6 percent in January, but private analysts reacted with caution, suggesting that several factors might have skewed the figures.

title: GREENWICH STREET TO ACQUIRE TELEX COMMUNICATIONS
description: Greenwich Street Capital Partners Inc., a private equity fund based in New York, has agreed to buy Telex Communications Group, a closely held maker of multimedia communications products, for $275 million in cash and $100 million in assumed debt, Telex said yesterday. Telex, which is based in Minneapolis, makes audio, visual and multimedia communications devices and had 1996 revenue of about $166.1 million. It said the deal would enable it to pursue growth through acquisitions and product development. Telex added that Greenwich Street would refinance $100 million of Telex's senior notes due in 2004. Greenwich Street plans to buy all of the company's shares except an undisclosed amount held by certain Telex senior managers.

title: Would You Like to See Our Olive List?
description: RESTAURANTS have wine and martini lists. Now, there is an olive list. Istana, a Mediterranean restaurant that opened last Saturday in the New York Palace, 455 Madison Avenue, has an olive bar with more than 30 varieties in traditional pots on display. A special menu describes them country by country. If someone is heard talking about a Mount Pelion blond, for example, the subject is a meaty Greek olive.

title: Terse Congressman Questions Greenspan's Market Motives
description: A lot of people on Wall Street have been asking in the last few days why Alan Greenspan thought it was his place to judge that stock prices might be too high, and today a Republican member of the House Budget Committee put that question to him, directly and somewhat testily, suggesting that the Fed chairman should quit meddling when it comes to the financial markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITTLE, CANTOR STUART
description: PITTLE-Cantor Stuart. The American Conference of Cantors mourns the untimely death of its cherished officer, Stuart Pittle. A cantor's cantor, respected and beloved by his congregants and colleagues, Cantor Pittle's sweet voice was surpassed only by his magnificent spirit and his gentle and nurturing soul. We share his loss with Sherry, Aviva and Shira. Zecher Tsaddik Livracha. Cantor Judith K. Rowland, President Cantor Howard M. Stahl, Exec VP

title: Eating and Smell
description: To The Living Section:

title: Berlin Feasts On the Art Forced Out By the Nazis
description: Since the divided halves of this city were already rich in museums, a united Berlin was quick to recover its place as one of Europe's great centers of art and antiquities. Yet the unification of its collections also revealed serious gaps: early modern art had been driven out by Hitler as ''degenerate,'' Impressionist and post-Impressionist treasures had been seized by the Soviet Army and the acquisition of postwar art had been badly neglected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESCHNER, SYLVIA F.
description: TESCHNER-Sylvia F. In her 90th year. Loving wife of the late Edward. Very special mother of Helen T. Greene, mother-in-law of Alan. Dearly loved grandmother of James (Tina) and Michael (Alison) Greene. Beloved greatnanny to David, Jonathan, Jordan, Andrew and Dana. Sister of Marjorie Sandak (Charles) and the late Arthur C. Fink.

title: Democrats Assail Plan on Con Ed Rates
description: Thirty-one Assembly Democrats signed a letter today protesting a Pataki administration plan to give deeper electric rate cuts to Consolidated Edison's business customers than to residential users over the next five years.

title: At Three Dinners, a Shower of Truffles and Michelin Stars
description: IT was the food world's equivalent of a tripleheader: three events on Monday night, involving more than 20 top chefs.

title: McDonald's will play Monopoly before rolling the dice on its new price-cutting strategy.
description: BEFORE McDonald's takes a chance on a risky price-cutting program, customers will be invited to take a Chance, a ride on the Reading Railroad or a walk on the Boardwalk.

title: SFX Broadcasting Deals
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. has completed acquisitions of three radio stations in Texas and Connecticut for a combined $66 million. The company bought KQUE-FM and KNUZ-AM in Houston for about $41 million from Texas Coast Corporation, and WWYZ-FM in Hartford for $25 million from the Gilmore family. SFX already owns four stations in Hartford, the nation's 41st-largest market. The company owns two stations in Houston, the ninth-biggest market.

title: Hasid Rebels Sue Main Sect For Religious Persecution
description: In a bitter encounter in a Federal courtroom, a breakaway faction of the Satmar Hasidim yesterday accused the dominant group of religious persecution in the way it governs the Hasidic village of Kiryas Joel in Orange County. The group said it was even denied the right to build an adequate synagogue.

title: Survey Finds More Children Being Offered Marijuana
description: The rising popularity of illegal drugs among teen-agers is trickling down to their younger brothers and sisters, who are becoming more tolerant of drug use and are starting to try marijuana themselves, according to a survey released yesterday by the Partnership for a Drug-Free America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, FRANCES
description: MANDEL-Frances on March 1. Beloved mom, grandma, sister, wife. A warm, giving, outstanding lady. We will miss you dearly.

title: Alzheimer Studies Thwarted
description: EVIDENCE that taking estrogen after menopause may prevent or delay and perhaps even treat Alzheimer's disease is increasingly compelling. But it is hardly conclusive, and the precise role that estrogen may play in curbing this devastating brain disease remains uncertain.

title: EU's 'Club Med' States Get Serious About Financial Rectitude
description: PARIS  There was a time when the guardians of financial rectitude in Bonn and Paris could look down upon the laggards of Southern Europe, those countries with a reputation for being financially undisciplined and for running up debts, the so-called Club Med members of the European Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, JEANNE
description: WEINTRAUB-Jeanne. On March 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Weintraub. Loving mother to Eleanor Crames and Charles; adoring grandmother to Michele, Stefanie, Neil, Leslie and Dana & proud great grandmother to Jessica, Nicole & Jack. Family will receive friends Wed. 6-8PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind 15 West 65th Street, NY 10023, would be appreciated.

title: An Unofficial but Very Public Bearer Of Pain, Peace and Human Dignity
description: ELIE WIESEL was in pain, but not for the usual reasons that distress a Nobel Peace Prize winner: massacres in Rwanda, human-rights abuses in Bosnia, repression in China. This time, Mr. Wiesel was in physical pain.

title: Parcells on TV With Simms
description: Tunavision will arrive in New York this fall when Jets Coach Bill Parcells stars in a half-hour Sunday morning show on Channel 4 with Phil Simms, his former Giants quarterback and now an NBC Sports game analyst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBSON, MARK HULL
description: DOBSON-Mark Hull, age 43, suddenly in New York City on Tuesday, February 25th. He was a graduate of Eastmoor High School in Columbus, University of Paris, France and New York University. At the time of his death he was Vice President of Bear Stearns Investment Bankers in NY. Survived by his parents, Douglas and Helen Dobson of Reynoldsburg, Ohio. No calling hours, no flowers. Private service. Interment Greenlawn Cemetery. For information contact Evans Funeral Home, 4171 East Livingston Avenue, Columbus, OH 43227; 614-237-2553.

title: Government Sees Decline In Cost of Air Travel
description: Air fares declined last year and will continue to fall, as airlines cut salaries and travel agency commissions, and buy more efficient planes, the Federal Aviation Administration predicted today.

title: No Marine 'Poster Boy'
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, Pity the Poor, Hassled Screenwriter
description: To the Editor:

title: Has Old-Time Chicken Flavor Flown the Coop?
description: PUT some nutritional buzz words on the label -- ''all natural,'' ''free range,'' ''free roaming,'' ''hormone free'' -- raise the price $1 or $2 a pound, and what do you have? An expensive chicken that tastes about the same as chickens that are factory raised and fed antibiotics before being processed.

title: A Broker for Emission Credits
description: Under amendments to the Federal Clean Air Act that were passed in 1990, companies whose emissions of pollutants fall short of the allowable limits are entitled to emission credits that they can use later or sell to a company that pollutes more than its share. Last year, New Jersey became the first state to adopt rules that allow the sale of the credits.

title: De Beers's Earnings Rise Nearly 33%
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the world's biggest diamond producer, reported yesterday that its earnings rose 32.7 percent in 1996, which was better than expected, aided by growth in mining and investments. Earnings, including income from associated companies, rose to $1.34 billion from $986 million.

title: Fiscal Fandango Damages an Emerging Uzbek Market
description: Steve Shaulis is selling the last of his seedless raisins, settling his debts -- and getting out of this Central Asian country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTNER, HARRY
description: BARTNER-Harry, age 74, died on March 3. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice Bartner. He is survived by his loving children, Melanie, Peter, Craig and Kevin, and grandchildren, Corey and Jaime. Service will be held at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY, on March 6, at 10:30.

title: GROSSMAN'S SAYS IT PLANS TO FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Grossman's Inc., a home improvement retail chain based in Canton, Mass., said yesterday that it planned to seek bankruptcy court protection, but it did not provide an exact date. The announcement had been expected. The company has been facing a severe cash shortage and in January said it might file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Grossman's said yesterday that it had received about $3.1 million in financing from a supplier, Jeld-Wen Inc., which is gaining a 50 percent stake in the company.

title: 2 Executives In Harassment Case at CNA
description: About a month ago, two female employees of the CNA Life insurance company began complaining about offensive sexual remarks, people with knowledge of the case say. The man who the women said was making the comments was the president of the company, a unit of the giant CNA Financial Corporation.

title: 2 Interpublic Units In Deals Overseas
description: Two units of the Interpublic Group of Companies announced overseas acquisitions yesterday.

title: Trade vs. Rights: A U.S. Debate With a Burmese Focus
description: Despite pressure on Capitol Hill and a new appeal by a Nobel Prize-winning dissident, senior members of the Clinton Administration are sharply divided over whether a new law requires the United States to impose tougher sanctions on Myanmar, Administration officials say.

title: Suit Accuses Ferraro's Husband Of Theft in Project Near Casino
description: John A. Zaccaro, the husband of the former Vice-Presidential candidate Geraldine A. Ferraro, has been accused of theft and false representation in a lawsuit filed by a former partner in a hotel project near the Foxwoods casino.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOOD, KEVIN
description: FLOOD-Kevin of Staten Island, on March 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Elaine (nee Gippa). Loving father of Brian and Amanda Rose. Funeral from the Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island, on Thursday. Funeral Mass Blessed Sacrament Church 10 AM. Interment Moravian Cemetery. Visiting on Thursday 7 to 9 P.M., Friday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Kevin J. Flood Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Development Office, Lehigh University, 27 Memorial Drive West, Bethlehem, PA. 18015, would be appreciated.

title: Federal Prosecutors And Their Busy Lives
description: If there's one thing Dick Wolf, the creator of ''Law and Order,'' knows, it's how to lure an audience into the nuts-and-bolts of crime hunting and punishment, until the system itself becomes a fascinating mechanism. Detectives and lawyers serve as broadly drawn cogs in that system rather than deeply defined characters, which may be why ''Law and Order'' has survived so many cast changes.

title: Israel Tells Arabs to Shut 4 Offices in Jerusalem

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, STANLEY
description: FINK-Stanley. In Memory of the Hon. Stanley Fink, Esq. The faculty, staff, administration and students of Kingsborough Community College join all residents of the City and State of New York in mourning the untimely passing of the Honorable Stanley Fink, Esq., former State Assembly Speaker and City University of New York Trustee. Speaker Fink retired as New York State Assembly Speaker in 1986 after a distinguished record of service to the people of the Borough of Brooklyn, the City of New York and the State of New York. Stanley Fink, a longtime resident of Brooklyn, earned his baccalaureate degree from Brooklyn College in 1956 and his law degree from New York University Law School in 1959. After serving in the Judge Advocate General's Office of the United States Air Force, he returned to Brooklyn to practice law & began what would become a distinguished career in civic and public affairs. In 1968, he ran for the State Assembly & was elected to represent the Canarsie Assembly District. He became Assembly majority leader in 1977 and, in 1979, he was elected Speaker of the Assembly, a position in which he served with distinction until his retirement in 1986. In 1989 he was appointed to the Board of Trustees of The City University of New York by Governor Cuomo. As a trustee he continued his commitment to the students of the City of New York. He championed the cause of access to higher education for all New Yorkers and was a strong advocate of Kingsborough Community College's emergence as an educational force in the Brooklyn community. Speaker Fink's contributions to the College were recognized when he was awarded the Kingsborough President's Medal for his devotion to the cause of higher education, in general, and open admissions specifically. Known as a forceful leader capable of fostering bi-partisanship in the legislature, Stanley Fink leaves a record of legislative innovation in the areas of criminal justice reform, highway safety, school aid & primary, secondary, and higher education. Both as Speaker of the New York State Assembly and as a Trustee of the City University of New York, he was a strong voice for the educationally and economically disadvantaged, women returning to the workforce, and education for new immigrants. He took particular pride in the development of new programs at Kingsborough Community College to serve these populations. His commitment to access through open-enrollment became the public policy of New York State and, for this, he will be long remembered and held in the highest regard. Stanley Fink's contributions in government, in the business sector and in higher education are many. He will always be remembered, however, for his extraordinary intelligence, his great sense of humor and his innate ability to cut through rhetoric and get to the heart of the matter. His energy and magnetic personality merged to form a commanding presence wherever people gathered. Stanley Fink was a loving husband to his wife, Judith, a devoted father to his son, Marc and daughter-in-law, Laura Kirschstein, his son, Keith and daughter-in-law, Caryn, and an adoring grandfather to his granddaughter, Alexandra. His legacy of excellence as a public servant, his passion for justice, his devotion to his family and the joy he derived from their love, serve to help us remember Stanley Fink as a man who made a difference. Leon M. Goldstein, President Kingsborough Community College

description: FREEDMAN-Henry, M.D. The Board of Regents, Administration, Medical Staff and the staff of the Mary Polak Oenslager Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of The Long Island College Hospital mourn the loss of Dr. Henry Freedman, professor and former director of the department of obstetrics and gynecology. Dr. Freedman started as a resident at the hospital in 1933, becoming a full attending physician and professor of clinical obstetrics/ gynecology by 1957. In 1966, he was asked to head the department of obstetrics/gynecology where he served as director through his retirement in 1979. He was a caring physician, dedicated to his patients and the hundreds of residents he taught during his career at LICH. Dr. Freedman also served as president of the hospital's medical staff, and was active in the New York Obstetrical Society and the Brooklyn Gynecological Society. We extend our most sincere condolences to his wife Arlene and his family. Joseph L. Broadwin, Chairman Board of Regents Donald F. Snell, Pres. and CEO Daniel D. title: New Shrine for the Cult of Furnishing With Books

''Now we can change the shape of the room to accommodate parties or book signings or if we're just plain bored,'' Ms. Stubbs said. The Cecil Beatons and obscure style books that she uses to furnish idiosyncratic country-house libraries now rest on caster-foot iron bookcases designed by John Ryman. They look like the skeletons of pagodas. The new decor has an operatic glamour of spice-color sofas, leather valances and purple walls (Pratt & Lambert's 1119). Stubbs is at 330 East 59th Street; (212) 223-1066.

title: Borders Books Picks A Park Avenue Site
description: Borders Books and Music is marching to midtown Manhattan. The national chain, which opened its first Manhattan store at the World Trade Center last fall, has leased about 42,000 square feet on four levels at 465 Park Avenue, the Ritz Tower Hotel at 57th Street, for its second Manhattan shop.

title: AIDE TO FIRST LADY WAS GIVEN CHECK AT WHITE HOUSE
description: The chief of staff to Hillary Rodham Clinton accepted a $50,000 donation to the Democratic Party in 1995 in the White House from a California businessman who has emerged as a central figure in the criminal and Congressional investigations into improper fund-raising by the Democrats, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Caller Objects to Integration of Lead Role in Passion Play, but Threat Report Is Denied
description: For 82 years, the Park Performing Arts Center in Union City, N.J., has put on an annual Passion play, the story of Jesus' last days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, MARY A.
description: KANE-Mary A. Age 86. Native of Banrach County Galway, Ireland. Loving wife of the late Patrick M. Kane. Beloved mother of Michael J. Kane and Sr. Patrick Michael, O.Carm. (Saint Patrick's Home, Bronx). Devoted grandmother of Margaret A. Harrington, Deirdre M. Kane, James P. Kane and Aileen B. Bolger. Dear great grandmother of Oona Margaret Harrington. Dear mother-in-law of Margaret F. Kane. Fond sister of the late Michael, Cole and John Faherty of County Galway, Ireland. Family will receive friends Friday, March 7 from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Bdwy at 232 St, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Vincent Ferrer Church (869 Lexington Avenue at 66 St), Saturday, March 8th, 9:45 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Carmelite Sisters.

title: In Ohio River Valley, the Water's Edge Is Now Its Middle
description: As the brown water of the Ohio River coursed through downtown intersections usually reserved for cars, hundreds of people turned out to marvel at the one of the biggest floods of the century.

title: Big Play by Raiders Lands Howard
description: Al Davis likes his trophies. So he personally delivered another to the Oakland Raiders' collection today, landing one of the most coveted free agents, Desmond Howard, the most valuable player of the Super Bowl.

title: Greenspan Calms Market and Stocks Soar
description: After giving Wall Street a bad case of the jitters last week by suggesting that financial markets might be overvalued, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered slightly more soothing comments today, and investors latched onto them to drive stock and bond prices sharply higher.

title: Syracuse Has a Date To Play Villanova
description: Urgency is not spread evenly at the Big East tournament. That was clear from the opening seconds of the opening game at Madison Square Garden yesterday, when the Syracuse Orangemen set out to make a point.

title: Family in an Accord to Return $15 Million to TLC Beatrice
description: The family of Reginald F. Lewis, the former chairman of TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., has tentatively agreed to return some $15 million that the executive received from the company in 1992.

title: New Models Of Growth On a Hot, Hot Stock Index
description: Growth stocks -- the shares of companies whose profits Wall Street expects to rise rapidly -- have been the darlings of the stock market during the 1990's. But they lagged late in 1996, and have recently been downright poor performers.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Janet Hayes Walker, the founder of the York Theater Company, misidentified the creators of a musical produced by the troupe. The musical, ''Moby Dick,'' was created by Mark St. Germain and Doug Katsaros, not Ed Dixon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKEY, GEORGE HENRY III, D.D.S.
description: LASKEY-George Henry III, D.D.S. Of Bronxville, N.Y. On March 4, 1997. Husband of Ernestine Brian Laskey. Father of Cynthia Kellogg. Father-in-law of Norman Kellogg. Grandfather of Kristin and Scott Kellogg. Brother of Joan de Graffenreid. Memorial service at Christ Church, Bronxville on Friday, March 7 at 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Westchester Heart Association in his memory.

title: Bridge
description: More than 2,000 players are headed for Dallas today, planning to compete in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships. These will continue for 10 days, and the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, which begin Sunday, will be the focus of attention.

title: Doctors and Medical Marijuana
description: The tactic the Clinton Administration has chosen to head off the medical use of marijuana in California -- threatening doctors who recommend marijuana to their patients -- is a dangerous and unwarranted interference with free speech and a patient's right to hear the truth from a doctor. In its effort to enforce Federal narcotics laws, the Administration needs to make clear that it will do nothing to prevent doctors from delivering their best medical judgments to their patients.

description: Despite a seeming appeal from the visiting Israeli Prime Minister, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that he would not intervene in the case of an Israeli accused of spying who is to stand trial in a Cairo court soon.

title: 2 Arrested After Guns Are Found at Fish Market
description: Two executives of a wholesale fish distributor at the Fulton Fish Market were charged with weapons possession yesterday after a Federal search for business records turned up two loaded handguns in their desks, the police said.

title: Colombia, in Rebuff to the U.S., Halts Drug Eradication Program
description: Colombia, the world's largest producer of cocaine, today suspended all aerial eradication of drug-producing crops in a sharp rebuff to the United States.

title: Yanks to Detail Adidas Deal
description: A Yankee lawyer said yesterday that ''at some point'' the team will show Major League Baseball its $90-to-95 million Adidas sponsorship deal.

title: Ordonez Starts Off Working on Mistakes
description: Before Joe McIlvaine settled into his seat to watch Rey Ordonez's spring debut today, the Mets' general manager spoke of his expectations for the shortstop as a returning regular.

title: U.S.-Canadian Split on Cuba Tangles Wal-Mart's Pajamas
description: The battle to undermine the only Communist regime in the Western Hemisphere -- Fidel Castro's Cuba -- has spread to the pajama department at the Wal-Mart in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: Blue Monster at Doral Gets Its Bite Back
description: It was the sort of golf hole that needed a gravestone for a tee marker. And it had one. A brass plaque set in coral next to the 18th hole at the Doral Resort and Spa warned golfers that they were about to play the toughest finishing hole on the PGA Tour.

Klagholz, the Commissioner of Education, told the board that New Jersey is the only state that does not require teachers to keep taking classes in order to renew their license.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, SCOTT
description: MANN-Scott, 22 years old. Beloved son of Todd and Sarah Mann and brother to Ken Mann. Died late Sunday evening from a car crash on Saturday morning. Known in the community as a loving, loyal and hardworking person. He will be greatly missed by all whose lives he touched.

title: This Train Is Bound for Spring Blossoms
description: WHEN two ex-newspapermen down Philadelphia way read about those poor New Yorkers having to go without a spring flower show of their own, they arranged for a special six-car train to set out from Pennsylvania Station at 9 A.M. this Saturday. It will take the flower-starved straight to the door of the Philadelphia Flower Show.

description: Stanley Fink, a Brooklyn Democrat who helped strengthen the power of the New York State Legislature during his term as Assembly Speaker in the post-Rockefeller era, died Tuesday night at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 61 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Miami Goes Overtime, And Hoyas are Next
description: On a night when St. John's needed its big guns to be blazing hot, it couldn't even get them out of the holsters. And when they did fire, they couldn't shoot straight. Consequently, the Red Storm's first-round Big East tournament game against Miami turned into a disappointing nail-biter last night at Madison Square Garden.

description: THE White House has had as many personalities as tenants in its 197 years. It has been Palace of the People and Rumpus Room of State, but its most difficult role has been that of private home.

He led the Kings to their only berth in the Stanley Cup finals. And his presence in a major media market fueled a rise in the popularity of the National Hockey League that helped bring expansion teams to Anaheim, San Jose, Florida and Tampa Bay.

title: Roger Brown, Basketball Star From Brooklyn, Is Dead at 54
description: Roger Brown, the former high school star from Brooklyn who was denied a chance to compete in college or in the National Basketball Association but who played eight sterling seasons for the Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Association, died on Tuesday at the home of a friend in Indianapolis. He was 54 and had been suffering from liver cancer for the last year.

title: $2.5 BILLION PRICE PUT ON MOBIL-SAUDI CHEMICAL PROJECT
description: The Mobil Corporation and the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation said yesterday that they would spend $2.5 billion to double the capacity of their petrochemicals project on the Red Sea. The plan to increase production comes as prices for at least one basic chemical produced there, ethylene, are at six-year highs in Europe and Asia, the key markets for Saudi-produced chemicals. Ethylene is a building block for plastics, paints and fibers. Mobil and Saudi Basic Industries, or Sabic, plan to expand ethylene production to 1.6 million tons a year by the year 2000, from 800,000 tons now. The 50-50 joint venture will be one of the largest and lowest-cost producers of petrochemicals in the world, Mobil said. Shares of Mobil rose $2, to $129.50.

title: Casting Off the 'Unreliable' AIDS Patient
description: The word on the streets and in the crack houses of the inner city is that the new AIDS medicines can stop the virus that causes the disease from progressing. But not everyone can get the new drugs: Doctors are withholding them from ''unreliable'' patients. This poses an ethical problem, exposing the immense gulf between expanding scientific knowledge and the wisdom needed to deal with the epidemic humanely. The policy may also have dangerous consequences, affecting our ability to control AIDS in the future.

title: School Board Is to Create Schools for Violent Students
description: The Board of Education voted yesterday to create three middle and three high schools to educate the city's 300 most violent students. The high schools will be run by three nonprofit organizations that work with teen-agers with substance abuse and behavioral problems.

description: GOLDBERG - Joseph M. On March 2, 1997. Loving husband of Marley and caring father to Andrew and Stephen.

title: Jeter Rejects Yanks' $450,000 Offer
description: The harmonious relationship between Derek Jeter and the Yankees took a troubling turn today when the shortstop rejected a contract offer of $450,000 while seeking $550,000. The Yankees countered by saying that the 1996 American League rookie of the year would simply have his contract renewed at an undisclosed and possibly lower salary than their offer for 1997.

title: President Makes It Harder For Foreigners to Buy Guns
description: Responding to the Feb. 23 shooting at the Empire State Building, President Clinton announced steps today intended to make it harder for newcomers to the United States to buy guns.

title: Jascha Brodsky, 90, Violinist at Curtis Institute
description: Jascha Brodsky, a violinist who performed as a member of the Curtis String Quartet for more than 50 years and was renowned as a teacher, died on Monday at the Palm Garden Nursing Home in Ocala, Fla. He was 90.

title: Broderbund Shares Plunge on Profit Outlook
description: Shares of Broderbund Software Inc. plummeted today following the company's announcement late Tuesday that its second-quarter earnings would fall below analysts' estimates. Broderbund said price cuts prompted by a competitive market had eroded its profit margins.

title: Panel Cites Lack of Security on Medical Records
description: The computerized medical records of millions of Americans are vulnerable to misuse and abuse, but few people recognize the extent of the problem and little is being done to improve the security of these personal files, a National Research Council panel said today.

title: Officer's Dismissal Sought
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew plans to seek the dismissal of a school safety officer who acknowledged his membership in the Latin Kings gang, officials said yesterday.

title: Conviction in Counterfeiting
description: A Federal grand jury convicted a Brooklyn man and his son yesterday of running a counterfeiting ring that passed nearly $1.2 million through slot machines in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev. The operation came to an end on Nov. 18, 1995, four months after a prostitute told the police that she received three bogus $100 bills from a man at a local hotel.

title: EDISON INTERNATIONAL AND TEXACO TO SELL UNIT
description: Remington Energy Ltd., an oil and gas company based in Calgary, Alberta, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire B.C. Star Partners for $200 million (Canadian), or $146 million (United States). B.C. Star is an oil and gas producing partnership between Texaco Canada Petroleum Inc., a unit of Texaco Inc., and Edison International, a utility based in Rosemead, Calif. Edison said it would receive $71 million for the sale of its stake. Remington said B.C. Star's assets included reserves of 300 billion cubic feet of natural gas and 5.85 million barrels of oil and natural gas liquids.

title: G.O.P. Lawmaker Proposes Bill to Ban Human Cloning
description: A House Republican introduced legislation today to ban the cloning of humans and to ban Federal money for such experiments, proposals generally discouraged by five scientists who heard about them at a Congressional hearing on cloning.

description: IN the best of all possible musical worlds, each note is crystallinely audible, the musicians are visible, the audiences quiet and the ambient distractions few. title: MEDPARTNERS TO BUY AETNA PHYSICIAN-MANAGEMENT UNIT
description: Medpartners Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Aetna U.S. Healthcare's physician-management business, adding to the nation's largest manager of doctors' offices. Terms of the acquisition of the unit of Aetna Inc., the Aetna Professional Management Corporation, were not disclosed. The price probably was $50 million to $80 million, said Margot Durow, an analyst at Vector Securities International. The acquisition is Medpartners' eighth in the last year. The latest acquisition adds about $100 million in revenue. The company, based in Birmingham, Ala., had 1996 revenue of $4.8 billion and is expected to have $6.4 billion in revenue in 1997.

title: House Intelligence Committee to Investigate Possible Foreign Influence in '96 Elections
description: The House intelligence committee will investigate whether foreign governments tried to influence the 1996 elections in the United States, the committee announced tonight.

title: WEIRTON STEEL TO CUT 470 JOBS IF UNION RATIFIES CONTRACT
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 470 hourly production and maintenance jobs, or 8.8 percent of its work force, if union members ratify a labor agreement that was announced on Friday. The struggling steelmaker, based in Weirton, W.Va., will pay $7,500 bonuses to each of the first 350 workers who agree to quit or retire within 60 days of ratification, said Richard Garan, the director of investor relations. The four-and-a-half-year agreement is with the Independent Steelworkers Union. Weirton, the eighth-largest steelmaker in the nation, had 5,325 employees on Dec. 31. Its shares fell 12.5 cents, to $2.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, EVERETT V.
description: FOX-Everett V. The trustees, faculty, and staff of New York University Medical Center deeply mourn the loss of Everett V. Fox age 81, March 3, former Secretary and Vice President of the Medical Center. Mr. Fox joined the Medical Center in 1965 as administrator for its affiliation contracts. He was appointed Vice President and Administrator of University Hospital in 1974. Later he was promoted to Vice President and Secretary of NYU Medical Center and was an Associate Professor of Hospital Adminstration at NYU School of Medicine. In 1973 the American Hospital Association honored him for his contributions to health care. Mr. Fox also visited the Soviet Union in 1975 as a participant in the USA-USSR Citizens Exchange Conference on the delivery of health care. Mr. Fox was a founder and the first President of the National Association of Health Service Executives (NAHSE), formed by AfricanAmerican hospital executives to ensure greater participation of African-Americans in health care. Mr. Fox was a member of several other professional groups including the American College of Hospital Administrators. He also served in an advisory capacity to the National Institutes of Health, The United Hospital Fund of N.Y. and the US Public Health Services. Mr. Fox retired from NYU Medical Center in 1984. He lived in Manhattan for many years. Born June 16, 1915 in Richmond, VA, Mr. Fox earned a BS degree from Hampton Institute in Hampton, VA and an MBA degree from the University of Chicago. After a tour of duty in the US Navy during W.W. II, he married Laura Kellum. They spent 48 years together separated only by her death in 1990. Mr. Fox is survived by his sister, Aurelia Leggett, his brother Carroll Porter, his niece Pamela Pitts and nephew Duane Porter all of Chicago. Mr. Fox was a trustee of the Riverside Church, and services will be held there at 490 Riverside Drive, Manhattan, Friday, March 7, 11 A.M., with Dr. James A. Forbes presiding. Visiting will be at 10 A.M. and a reception will follow the services. Mr. Fox will be buried in Winston-Salem, NC. Thomas S. Murphy, Chairman Board of Trustees NYU Medical Center Sol J. Farber, MD MACP Provost and Dean NYU Medical Center and School of Medicine Margaret L. Mc Clure RN Ed.D Vice President of Hospital Operations and Executive Director of Nursing, NYU Medical Center

title: The Schools We Get . . . Are the Schools We Pay For

The General Accounting Office estimates that the 50 states need to spend an additional $112 billion just to put school buildings in reasonable working order. Many Americans would balk at spending that much because they see public schools as so wasteful and ineffective that more money won't help.

title: A Wayward Way With Walls
description: ROGER BANKS-PYE, the London interior designer, who died last year at 48, may have been the greatest decorator that most of the world never heard of. Behind the venerable Colefax & Fowler moniker, the irreverent Mr. Banks-Pye spent his brief 15-year career willfully subverting the firm's country-house vocabulary to avoid the esthetic rut he called ''rusting on Fowler's laurels.'' Mr. Banks-Pye is gone, but his book, ''Colefax and Fowler's Interior Inspirations'' (Bulfinch, $45), arrives in stores next week. Written with the help of Suzanne Woloszynska, it is a testament to sure-footed eccentricity and nose-thumbing style, qualities in short supply in the design world today. Famed for the over-the-top house he created for the fashion designer Valentino, he was also an egalitarian experimenter, ready to glue squares of blue rice paper onto a white wall (above), to ennoble a sheet of postage stamps with a gold frame (above right) or to glue chintz directly onto his bedroom floorboards (yes, they held up). ''Interior Inspirations'' is wickedly opinionated, too. ''Though there are moments when plain white walls might seem a relief,'' Mr. Banks-Pye said, ''those moments are rare, and should be discouraged.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGNEW, JANE ELIZABETH GILLESPIE
description: AGNEW-Jane Elizabeth Gillespie. Age 76. Of Wilton, CT. Died after a brief illness March 2, 1997 at the Norwalk Hospital. Known as Babbie, she was born June 21, 1920 to William F. Gillespie and Mabel Grace Miner in Stamford, CT.
