title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEYDET, FRANCOIS G.
description: LEYDET-Francois G. The death of Francois Leydet brings to end a life filled with joy, adventure, love and accomplishment. Born 26 August 1927 at Neuilly-sur-Seine (France), he became a U.S. citizen in 1956 after attending prep school and colleges in both France and the U.S.: bachelor's degree, University of Paris, 1945; bachelor's degree, Harvard University, 1947; Harvard Business School, 1948/9 and 1950/62; School of Advanced International Studies, Johns Hopkins University, 1952/3. Fluent in English and French, Francois spoke several other languages and delighted in puns and other word play. In recent years he devoted much effort to institutions he believed in, serving as a docent at the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum, and as an active worker and supporter of Planned Parenthood. Among his many ''careers'' were experience in investment banking, wrangler on ranches in Oregon, crewing shrimpboats in the Gulf of California, and rowing dories through the Grand Canyon, but always there was writing. Starting as a copyboy for the Washington ''Evening Star'' in 1953, Francois worked at the San Francisco ''Chronicle'', 1954/62, and ''Examiner'', 1962/3, before turning to freelance writing, specializing in nature, wildlife and conservation subjects, for the remainder of his life. He edited and wrote books for the Sierra Club (''Tomorrow's Wilderness'', 1963, ''The Last Redwoods'', 1963, the award winning ''Time and the River Flowing''-about the Grand Canyon-1964), and a comprehensive book about the maligned and misunderstood coyote, ''The Coyote, Defiant Songdog of the West'', 1977; passengers on his river trips can remember Francois climbing on the ledges above the river and howling like a coyote and in later years at least one friend often referred to him as ''The Old Coyote''. Francois' essays and articles appeared in magazines and journals as diverse as ''National Geographic'', ''American West'', ''Holiday'', ''Harvard Magazine'' and ''Vogue''. Though never published, his sonnets, odes and other poetry were a delight shared with his friends and family. Francois died Tuesday, March 4, of complications following a diagnosis and treatment for lung cancer, in Tucson, Arizona, where he lived with his wife Roslyn since 1990. He leaves cherished dogs, Bruno, Max, Mortimer and Emma. Francois is survived by the people he loved, who adored him in return, his wife of 27 years, Roslyn (Tucson), his step-children: Walter Robb (San Francisco), Dr. Rachel Avery (Portland, ME), Holly Prunty (Palo Alto), Peckie Peters (Vail), and 9-3/4 grandchildren. His siblings are brother Hugues Leydet (Montreal, Canada) and sister Beatrice Mosca (Rome, Italy). A Memorial service will be held later in the spring after grandchild 10 is born. The family requests that memorial donations in lieu of flowers or other memorials be made to the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum or Planned Parenthood.

title: Hold Off on Hollow-Point Bullets
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani made the right move in delaying plans by New York City police to switch their ammunition from conventional full-metal-jacketed bullets to the more lethal hollow-point bullets. The proposed change needs much fuller discussion and analysis. The hollow-points, which expand when they hit flesh, are banned in warfare as inhumane by the Hague Declaration and the Geneva Conventions because they cause great damage to internal organs and tissue. There is no reason to use this type of ammunition unless the administration can demonstrate that traditional bullets are inadequate in protecting public safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALL, EDWIN CRAIG
description: WALL-Edwin Craig, Jr., age 59, died on Wednesday, March 5, 1997 in Charlotte, NC. Mr. Wall was born in Conway, the son of May Howard Wall and the late Edwin Craig Wall, Sr. He was a resident of Conway and a lifelong member of Kingston Presbyterian Church where he served as a trustee. Mr. Wall graduated from Davidson College with a BA in Economics, & received his Master's of Business Administration from the Harvard Business School. He was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Canal Industries, Inc., and also served as Board Chairman of New South, Inc., and a director of the Pelican Companies, Inc. Mr. Wall served as a member of the Board of Directors of a number of local, affiliated, and national companies. Among the local and affiliated companies are Dargan Construction Company, Chicora Development Corporation, Waccamaw Clay Products Company, Inc., Litchfield Enterprises, and Power Sources, Inc. Among the national companies are NationsBank Corporation, Blue Cross/Blue Shield of South Carolina, Sonoco Products Company, Ruddick Corporation, SCANA Corporation, and RTO, Inc. He also served on the Board of Advisors of Carousel Capital, Inc. Mr. Wall was extensively involved in numerous civic and charitable organizations. These activities included service as a trustee of The Duke Endowment, chairmanship of the Davidson College Board of Trustees, serving in several roles for Coastal Carolina University, including membership on the Board of Trustees, and chairmanship of the Board of Trustees of Brookgreen Gardens. He was a member of Clemson's President's Advisory Council, the Palmetto Business Forum, a director of the Palmetto Seed Capital Fund, and a trustee of the Conway Hospital Foundation. Mr. Wall was active in a number of roles for the Horry County United Way. He was instrumental in founding this charity which is so important to our community and served as its President and as a member of its Advisory Council. Among other civic and charitable organizations that Mr. Wall has served are the Horry County Mental Health Association, the Governor's Economic Task Force, the State Chamber of Commerce, the Belle W. Baruch Foundation, Coker College, Converse College, South Carolina Mental Health Association, Presbyterian College, the South Carolina Foundation of Independent Colleges, and USC Development Foundation. His service to the Pee Dee Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America led to his being recognized with a Silver Beaver Award. Among other awards received by Mr. Wall are a Distinguished Service Award for the Conway American Legion Post III, recognition as the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce Businessman of the Year and as an Outstanding Alumnus of the Conway High School Hall of Fame. Mr. Wall was honored as the recipient of an Endowed Professorship Chair in the Humanities at Davidson College and received honorary degrees from both Coastal Carolina University and Coker College. Surviving in addition to his mother of Conway are: his wife, Judith Atkins Wall of Conway, two sons, Edwin Craig Wall III of Charlotte, NC and Benjamin Rutledge Wall II of Davidson, NC; one daughter, Judith Atkins Wall of New York, NY; 3 sisters, May Ervin Wall of Hartsville, Harriet Wall Martin of Chapel Hill, NC and Nell Wall Otto of Greenwich, CT. Services will be held Friday, March 7th at 2:00 P.M. at Kingston Presbyterian Church in Conway. Interment to follow at Lakeside Cemetery. Memorials may be made to the E. Craig Wall, Jr. Fund, C/O Robinson, Bradshaw & Hinson, 1900 Independence Center, 101 North Tryon Street, Charlotte, North Carolina 28246.

description: When Yasir Arafat came to The New York Times for a discussion the other day, he spoke respectfully of Benjamin Netanyahu. ''He is my partner,'' President Arafat said. ''He's a nice man.''

title: MORTON BUYS TWO-THIRDS STAKE IN FRENCH SALT PRODUCER
description: Morton International Inc. said yesterday that it had bought two-thirds of the French salt maker Compagnie des Salins du Midi et des Salines de l'Est for $180 million. The stake was sold by Compagnie de Suez S.A., which owned about 50 percent; Credit Agricole d'Ile-de-France, which owned about 10 percent, and the Rougie family, which owned about 7 percent, Janis Tratnik, a Morton spokeswoman, said. Salins du Midi, a leading European salt producer, had 1996 sales of $270 million, Chicago-based Morton said. The French company makes salt for food, agricultural supplies, water treatment and de-icing.

title: Tree Toppled by Wind Crushes 4 Girls in Church Van
description: Four girls riding to a church school in the back of a van -- one wearing headphones and listening to music, others cradling knapsacks and lunch bags -- were killed yesterday morning when a swaying silver maple seven stories tall toppled over in a gale and crushed them on a residential street in Queens.

title: Thomas Looks Ready to Soar to New Heights
description: THE take-home moment for Syracuse center Otis Hill, a 6-foot-8-inch senior out of White Plains, came with just under nine minutes remaining in the first half. Tim Thomas, the freshman with a future, roared down the lane with the ball, trying, as they say, to take it to the next level. Which, in this case, happened to be the airspace above Otis Hill.

title: Home Video
description: For a year it's been a scramble to keep track of all the Jane Austen on film and tape. Basically the problem has been that several adaptations of three of the author's six novels showed up more or less at once, beginning in late 1995. ''Persuasion,'' a film starring Susan Fleetwood, Ciaran Hinds and Amanda Root, came first. Then there was ''Sense and Sensibility,'' the film with Emma Thompson, and a month later ''Pride and Prejudice,'' the acclaimed BBC production, which was shown on A&E.

description: Anyone who grew up in a middle-class American suburb and itched to be one of the in-crowd should feel an uncomfortable twinge of recognition while watching John Sullivan's debut film, ''Sleepover.'' This microscopic study of adolescent summertime angst in a Connecticut coastal town follows a group of bored teen-agers as they embark on a midnight outing that leads to catastrophe.

title: HEALTH COMPANIES DROP MERGER IN FAVOR OF STOCK PLAN
description: Health Risk Management Inc. and the Healthplan Services Corporation said yesterday that they had called off their planned $80 million merger because of delays caused by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Instead, Healthplan, of Tampa, Fla., agreed to buy 200,000 unregistered Health Risk shares, representing about 4.5 percent of the Minneapolis-based company's stock, for $12.50 a share. Shares of both companies have fallen sharply since then. Health Risk's stock plunged another $2.75 yesterday, to $10.25, in Nasdaq trading. Healthplan's stock dropped 75 cents, to $16.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Great Western Accepts Rival Takeover Bid
description: Great Western Financial, moving to thwart a hostile takeover offer by H. F. Ahmanson & Company, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Washington Mutual for stock worth $6.6 billion in a deal that would create the country's largest savings and loan institution.

title: A Bloomsbury Founder, Always With an Idea

Thanks to a hallucinatory performance by Antony Sher, Spencer the matrimonial misfit is reborn in ''Stanley,'' the play now running at Circle in the Square in Manhattan. As for Spencer the painter, he will have a substantial retrospective at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington beginning on Oct. 9.

description: After meeting with his Cabinet into the small hours of the morning, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today won an agreement to withdraw in varying degrees from a further 9 percent of occupied territories in the West Bank.

title: Shift on Chips Due at Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc., having watched its profits plunge last year along with the price of memory chips, said today that it would shift its focus to the specialized chips that go into cellular telephones, computer components like modems, and automobiles.

title: Species That Teeter On Oblivion's Brink
description: IN 1732, so the fable goes, a fellow named Edwin Meeps ''spyed this day a tiny kroaker, not a bugg, flying most ably amongst the trees.'' But the Meeps Island flying frog, as the creature became known, was so modest that it mated only in dense clumps of poison ivy.

title: Cheddi Jagan, Guyana's Founder, Dies at 78
description: Cheddi B. Jagan, the firebrand who led Guyana to independence and was one of the Caribbean's most contentious political leaders for half a century, died yesterday in Washington, where he had been hospitalized after a heart attack. He was 78.

description: A day after his team ended its season with a loss to Providence in the first round of the Big East tournament, Bob Wenzel was dismissed as the men's basketball coach at Rutgers.

title: Rebel Forces in Zaire Are Closing on a Crucial City
description: Advancing by foot, by jeep and, in their stunning final approach to the unofficial capital of eastern Zaire, by dugout canoe, rebels determined to overthrow the Government now stand poised to capture Kisangani, this country's third-largest city.

title: Dad-Son Bonding Buddies
description: ''Jungle 2 Jungle'' casts Tim Allen as a tense Wall Street commodities trader who has an estranged wife (JoBeth Williams) living in a tropical paradise. When his eagerness for divorce makes him visit her there, he is surprised to learn that he has an adorable 13-year-old son. In a whirlwind of high-concept plotting, the boy decides to visit Manhattan with his father. There he wanders barefoot in a loincloth, shoots pigeons with a bow and arrow and scares the locals with his humongous pet spider.

title: Muscle Cars Return: Hey, Boss Wheels!
description: There are no cup holders in 1965 Mustangs, but that doesn't keep people from paying as much as $25,000 for the pony cars today. No one asks if a 1969 Plymouth Road Runner has side-impact air bags, or what kind of gas mileage one can expect of a 1968 Camaro Z28.

title: JUDGE TRIPLES DAMAGES IN MEINEKE MUFFLER LAWSUIT
description: Franchisees of Meineke Muffler, a unit of GKN P.L.C. of Britain, won damages of as much as $591 million in a ruling against the company by a Federal judge, the lawyer for the franchisees said yesterday. Federal District Judge Robert Potter in Charlotte, N.C., tripled jury damages that were awarded in December after the jury found that Meineke had defrauded 2,500 franchisees by skimming commissions from advertising money the franchisees had invested. The $591 million could be reduced because some franchisees had signed releases, the lawyer said, but he added that the franchisees would seek to have all the releases ruled invalid. GKN recently estimated the releases might reduce any damage award by as much as 30 percent. A GKN spokesman said the company had no comment.

title: Tax Court Rejects 'Phantom Loss' by Colgate
description: The Federal Tax Court has rejected as a sham an elaborate maneuver devised by Merrill Lynch & Company that had enabled the Colgate-Palmolive Company to avoid paying taxes on $98 million of gains it made in selling a subsidiary.

title: Apartments Rising on Site Of Fillmore East and Saint
description: A seven-story brick rental apartment building is rising on part of the site at Second Avenue and Sixth Street in the East Village that was once home to the fabled rock concert hall the Fillmore East and later to the Saint, an elaborate disco that was a center of gay night life in the 1980's.

title: Safir Says a Report Finds New Bullets Less Deadly

title: Wall Street Leads, but New York's Economy Doesn't Follow
description: Over the last year, New York City's unemployment rate has climbed even as Wall Street was cheering repeated record highs. Brokers earning seven-figure bonuses shopped for summer homes while about one in 11 people looked for jobs.

title: WAL-MART SETS STOCK REPURCHASE AND RAISES DIVIDEND
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back an additional $2 billion of stock in the next 12 to 18 months in the open market and raise its quarterly dividend 29 percent. The retailer, based in Bentonville, Ark., said the repurchase program would not curtail the company's expected $3 billion capital spending program in 1997 or beyond. Wal-Mart did not disclose the size of the previous buyback plan. The new quarterly dividend of 6.75 cents a share, up from 5.25 cents, will be distributed April 9 to stock owners of record March 19. The stock closed yesterday at $27.25, up 62.5 cents a share.

title: Irate Agency Quits Delta Account Battle
description: A closely watched contest to determine who will create worldwide advertising campaigns for Delta Air Lines Inc. -- which spends $100 million a year -- has taken an extraordinary turn at the 11th hour.

title: University of California Goes Far Afield to Fill 2 Top Jobs
description: The University of California, perhaps the country's premier -- and most troubled -- public university system, announced today that after a nationwide talent search it had finally found new chancellors to run its flagship campuses here and at Berkeley.

title: For Brokerage Houses, a New Class of Suitor Rides In
description: When executives from Citicorp and American Express met secretly late last year to discuss merging their businesses, it sent a strong message to the investment bankers at Morgan Stanley that the financial world's heavies were about to descend on Wall Street.

title: Russian Submarine Drifts Into Center of a Brazen Drug Plot
description: Around 11 on a weeknight, Porky's is half-full with young men in jeans and baseball caps who pay $5 and a two-drink-minimum charge to watch nude women with names like Gigi, Tabatha and Marbella. The women strip and dance, either on a smoke-filled stage or, for an extra $20, in the men's laps, while the men shout, tip and touch.

title: National Semiconductor Reports Strong Growth in Earnings
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported strong growth in revenue and earnings today for its third fiscal quarter, exceeding Wall Street analysts' estimates and defying a seasonal dip in sales that the company had experienced for more than a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEFTERAKIS, JOHN, M.D.
description: ELEFTERAKIS-John, M.D. His friends and colleagues at Lutheran Medical Center mourn the sudden loss of Dr. John Elefterakis. We will miss his engaging wit and personal energy as much as his medical competence and devotion to his patients. John was affiliated with Lutheran Medical Center for fifteen years, first as an intern and resident then as an associate attending physician in medicine. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Dori, his children and his entire family. His friendship, loyalty and dedication will be missed by all of us. Joseph Rando, M.D., President Lutheran Medical Center, Medical and Dental Staff Joseph P. Cerni, President Lutheran Medical Center

title: This Talk Show Guest Is Murder

The program, she says, is dedicated to rape survivors everywhere. Enter from the wings Frank McGrath, brandishing a gun and taking the entire studio hostage. His daughter killed herself after an unauthorized expose on an earlier Pia show. The daughter was callously sandbagged on the air. Now grief-stricken Frank, seeking justice, intends to execute Pia on live television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BART, SUSAN AMY (NEE KAPNICK)
description: BART-Susan Amy (nee Kapnick), died on March 6, 1997 after a long and courageous battle with breast cancer. Beloved wife and dearest friend of Jacob Bart. Adored and loving mother of Joshua and Madelyn. Cherished and most precious daughter of Syd (Sylvia) and Oscar Kapnick. Loving sister of Steven and Joan Kapnick and the late Jo Anne Kapnick. Loved and respected by her in-laws, Rabbi and Mrs. Mordecai Bart and by her aunts, uncles, cousins and many friends for her dignity and courage. Susan graduated from New York University and received a B.A. degree Magna Cum Laude. As a political science major, she was elected a Phi Beta Kappa recipient. Susan graduated from NYU Law School class of 1978. She then served as Law Clerk to Judge Edward Ryan. Later she was with the law firm of Wachtel, Lipton, Rosen and Katz. Truly an ''ayshes chayil'', a woman of valor, may she receive eternal peace. Services will be held at Beth El Synagogue, North Avenue at Northfield Road, New Rochelle, New York on Friday, March 7th at 1:30 PM. Shiva will be observed at the Bart residence, 19 Abbey Close, Scarsdale, New York.

title: In Step With Austen: English Country Dancing
description: FOR many filmgoers and television watchers, the stately dancing in the recent spate of Jane Austen dramatizations stirred a touch of culture envy: a longing for a presumably lost Eden of elegance, for forms of social intercourse less brash and brazen than our own. But for several thousand Americans across the country, such dancing is not something that has vanished, but an activity in which they engage regularly. The dances performed in the Austen adaptations and, indeed, hundreds of similar dances, some dating to a century before the time of that great limner of English country life, are known as English country dances.

description: Boris Yeltsin yesterday gave Russians a measure of the leadership they yearn for, candidly describing his country's economic hardships and the failures of his own administration. Now he must take the decisive actions necessary to stabilize the economy and give the nation an effective, honest Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKO, DAVID
description: BURKO-David. Passed away March 5, 1997 in Miami Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Doris Burko. Cherished father of Diane Burko and adored grandfather of Jessica Burko. He was an active member of the real estate community of New York and Brooklyn for over forty years. He was deeply respected and loved by all those who knew him. Family suggests contributions to ''The Zimmerman Home for the Aged Burko Wing'', mail to Burko, 275 South 19 Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ALMEIDA, ANTONIO
description: de ALMEIDA-Antonio. The Nestle Corporation and the musicians and staff of the Moscow Symphony Orchestra mourn the loss of their beloved Music Director, Antonio de Almeida. Maestro de Almeida had the courage to come to us at a time of grave national turmoil. His unflagging faith in the universal language of music and his devotion to the musicians of the Moscow Symphony Orchestra and their families shall forever be remembered.

title: F.B.I. Director Is Accused Of Missteps In Lab Furor
description: A Republican member of the Senate Judiciary Committee today accused Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, of mishandling and possibly trying to ''cover up'' problems at the bureau's once-vaunted crime laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, STANLEY
description: FINK-Stanley. Stanley Fink was one of the great leaders of New York State. As the Democratic Leader of the New York State Senate while he was Speaker of the Assembly, I was proud to be his partner in many of the great accomplishments in which he led the way: The first of several major capital financing packages for the MTA; the restructuring of the finances of the CUNY and SUNY systems; and his leadership in helping restore the City of New York to fiscal solidity, were among these projects. I was proud to work with him and to be able to consider myself one of his close personal friends. In private life he also succeeded brilliantly. He was a leading member of the team which is masterminding the pending merger of the Bell Atlantic and NYNEX systems. He took enormous pride in this work and committed the full range of his talents to it. He would have counted the successful conclusion of this effort as one of his crowning achievements. My colleagues and I join in expressing our heartfelt condolences to his wife Judy and his sons Mark and Keith. Manfred Ohrenstein Ohrenstein & Brown, Esqs. TPG Advisors, Inc., The Professional Group

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''HALA BIRA! A CELEBRATION OF PHILIPPINE LITERATURE,'' an afternoon of readings and a panel discussion at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. Among those taking part are the writers Regie Cabico, Jessica Hagedorn and Nick Carbo. Tomorrow, 2 to 6 P.M. The event is sponsored by the Poets House and the Asian American Writers' Workshop. Admission: $7; free for students. Information: (212) 517-2742 or (212) 431-7920.

title: Clinton Aides and a Proposal to Build a Chinese Power Plant
description: For American companies eager to crack the vast but frustrating Chinese market, it was a big deal when Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown announced on a trade mission to China in 1994 that he had secured an agreement for the Entergy Corporation of New Orleans to help build a $1 billion power plant 250 miles north of Beijing.

title: Embracing the Miracles In the Living of Life
description: When ''The Eighth Day'' was shown at the Cannes Film Festival last year, it was greeted with a mixture of derision and tears. I was surprised to find myself in the handkerchief brigade, by far the smaller faction because this film is unforgivable in so many ways. It's mawkish and pushy in a manner that identifies its director, Jaco van Dormael, who also made the very well-received ''Toto the Hero,'' as a former circus clown.

title: Microbe Peril From Mars Is Possibility, Panel Warns
description: It has been the basis of many science fiction stories: the rocket returning from Mars carries an unknown organism destined to cause havoc on Earth.

title: Villanova and Providence Gain Semifinals
description: Before the first nonsellout for a quarterfinal round in the 15 years that the Big East Conference tournament has been played at Madison Square Garden, Villanova and Providence held off late challenges in their victories yesterday afternoon.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Pope JOHN PAUL II has taken delivery of a sleek black Mercedes-Benz, saying it was about time he got a new car, Reuters reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIGROSSER, LAURA
description: ZIGROSSER-Laura. Members of the Canade and Kavanaugh families announce with sadness the death in Paris, France, of Laura Zigrosser (nee Canade), on February 13, 1997. Funeral rites were celebrated in Paris.

title: Big-Shouldered River Swamps Indiana Town
description: This town of 411 people is battling against the Ohio River, and so far, the water is winning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETELKA, SAMBORSKI, MICHAL
description: PETELKA-SAMBORSKI-Michal. On March 5 in his 90th year. An intensely blue-eyed handsome man of great charm to the end. A man of deep faith & honor. A sensitive artist and successful at all he did. A member of the Polish Navy (submarine) who loved the sea, nature, all animals. He passionately adored his children Michael, Ann, and daughter-in-law Kizia. He maintained his love and respect for his late former wife, Zofia, always. He was our heart. Reposing Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (207 Street) Saturday 2-5 & 7-9 and Sunday 2-9. Mass Monday 10 AM, St. George's Ukranian Church, 30 East 7th St, NYC. Interment in Cold Spring Cemetery, Cold Spring, New York.

title: FIREMAN'S FUND TO BUY CROP GROWERS FOR $81.6 MILLION
description: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company agreed to buy the Crop Growers Corporation, a crop insurer in Overland Park, Kan., for $81.6 million in cash. The acquisition will allow Fireman's Fund to expand in the business of selling Federal insurance against crop damage from hailstorms and other perils. Fireman's Fund, a unit of Germany's largest insurer, Allianz A.G., agreed to pay $10.25 for each Crop Growers share, 20 percent above yesterday's closing price. Crop Growers' shares rose $1.406, to $9.906, in Nasdaq trading. Fireman's Fund, of Novato, Calif., writes $4 billion in premiums a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVI, HILDE (NEE ADELSBERGER)
description: LEVI-Hilde (nee Adelsberger), 87, March 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Max. Dear sister of Trudi (Raja) Nehab and Walter Adelsberger. Caring step-mother of Paul and Judith, and grandmother of Rebecca. Contributions to NYC School Volunteer Program, Inc., 352 Park Ave. South, NY NY 10016.

title: S.&L. Earnings Were Brisk Last Year
description: The American savings and loan industry earned $4.8 billion in 1996, its fourth-best earnings year, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today. Still, earnings were down 11 percent, from $5.4 billion in 1995, the report said.

title: Firefighter Charged in Arson
description: A former Wallington volunteer firefighter was charged yesterday with setting eight cars on fire from Jan. 22 to Feb. 27, officials said.

title: When a Scourge Turns On the Charm
description: Put down that 10-foot pole. You can touch Howard Stern without it, now that his jokey, ingratiating performance in ''Private Parts'' transforms him from the scourge of the airwaves to a sweetheart of the screen. In this sure-fire hit comedy, a cheery autobiographical gloss on the Stern legend, our hero is a great friend, wonderful husband and broadcasting pioneer, the guy who saw the fun in flatulence long before any other broadcaster would dare. Amazingly, this all works, even if some of it looks about as authentic as Mr. Stern's movie hair.

title: 2 Newspapers Each Are Winners Of 2 Polk Awards for Journalism
description: Two newspapers, The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times, each won 2 of the 11 George Polk awards for journalism announced yesterday by Long Island University.

title: At Michigan Legislature, It's All Warmth for Clinton
description: Washington may be absorbed with the daily twists and turns of the campaign fund-raising controversy, but here in central Michigan today it barely cast a shadow over President Clinton as he became the first chief executive since Theodore Roosevelt to address a joint session of the Michigan legislature.

title: Gretzky, Messier Jog Kings' Memories
description: During their years with the Edmonton Oilers in the 1980's, Wayne Gretzky and Mark Messier terrorized the Los Angeles Kings on a regular basis. Tonight, playing at Los Angeles for the first time since being reunited with the Rangers, Gretzky and Messier recaptured the magic. They were involved in five of six goals during a 6-2 blowout of the Kings.

title: $25 and Under
description: The Hotblooded Herb

title: New Heroes Bring Honor To Brooklyn
description: THE latest steps of the homecoming were the snazziest. Charles Jones from Brooklyn dribbled between his legs, dribbled behind his back and flitted through traffic for the crushing basket yesterday as Long Island University brought joy to downtown Brooklyn.

title: Top Rusher Works Out
description: The best pass rusher in college, PETER BOULWARE of Florida State, held a private workout for National Football League teams, including the Jets, yesterday. Boulware, a 6-5, 255-pound junior who generated 19 sacks in 11 regular-season games, moved higher on the Jets' draft list in the wake of the decision by Tennessee quarterback PEYTON MANNING to stay in college. The Jets own the top pick of the draft.

title: Goldberg Variations On Fun in 'Forum'
description: DON'T even bother looking it up in the script; it's not there. And you can be sure that no matter how wildly improvisational Zero Mostel, Phil Silvers and Nathan Lane became when they appeared in ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' they never said anything like what its newest star comes up with when a skinny, geriatric fellow in a blond wig materializes in the show's opening number.

title: Nomura Securities Under Scrutiny for Unauthorized Stock Trades
description: The Nomura Securities Company said today that two of its directors made unauthorized stock trades and funneled the profits to corporate customers and that regulators were completing an investigation of the events.

title: Plea Talks With Former Texaco Official Said to Collapse
description: Plea negotiations have collapsed between Federal prosecutors and a former executive who is a central figure in the Texaco scandal, and the executive has been told that he will be indicted on charges of destroying documents demanded in a discrimination case, people with knowledge of the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASSUK, BERTRAM L. FAIA
description: BASSUK-Bertram L. FAIA. Of NYC. Esteemed architect, died March 2, 1997. Beloved brother of Harold and Gloria, cherished uncle of Jeffrey and Janice, treasured cousin and friend. A memorial gathering to celebrate his life will be held at the Community Room, 343 Eighth Avenue (27th Street), 2 PM, Saturday, March 8, 1997.

title: Lifesaving Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor and Devils Disagree About Gilmour
description: The Devils and the doctor treating Doug Gilmour apparently do not see eye to eye over the seriousness of the New Jersey center's injury.

title: Ruth Clark, 80, Pollster Who Changed an Industry
description: Ruth Clark, a pollster who left her mark on the newspaper industry with a landmark newspaper study that encouraged editors to offer more information that readers could use in their daily lives and who helped define changing American attitudes on issues from the political to the personal, died on Feb. 20 in her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 80.

title: Lives Full of Promise, Sisters Suddenly Gone
description: They were both A students. They both spent their evenings doing homework rather than going out to play with friends. And yesterday, the Washington sisters, Kimberly and Christien, 12 and 9, both suffered the same death, when a 60-foot maple tree fell on the private van taking them to school.

title: Swiss and Their Burden of Nazi Gold
description: With the proposal of a vast fund for victims of oppression, the focus of Switzerland's debate over its role in World War II has narrowed in part to a 57-year-old tycoon who has likened the European Union to the Third Reich and who believes that no Swiss public money should be paid in compensation for the Holocaust.

title: Colin Davis Conducts Verdi's Requiem
description: Colin Davis is at the New York Philharmonic for two weeks. On Wednesday he led the first of four Verdi Requiem performances; next Thursday a three-concert program of Berlioz and Brahms begins. In the 1998-99 season, Mr. Davis begins a closer association with the orchestra, with at least three subscription weeks a year. It promises to be one of the nicer things to happen at Avery Fisher Hall in a long time.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Inside Art
description: An 'Artwall' at Union Square

title: For Tree That Led to Deaths, an Inspection That Never Came
description: The silver maple tree that fell and crushed four girls to death yesterday in Laurelton, Queens, had at least once before come to the attention of city park employees, park officials said yesterday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, MELVIN L.
description: BARON-Melvin L. On March 5, 1997 at age 70. Weidlinger Associates is deeply saddened by the passing of a beloved and respected friend and colleague. As founding partner and Chairman of the Board of Weidlinger Associates, he nourished and inspired our firm with unerring judgement, tireless energy, an innovative mind and a generous spirit. His achievements in civil engineering, applied mechanics and mathematics, spanning nearly forty-five years, were founded on a commitment to excellence that was pervasive in his life as in his work. However large his professional stature, he never permitted it to overshadow his humanity that was the source of his greatness. On behalf of the Directors and Staff of Weidlinger Associates Jeremy Isenberg, President

title: Despite Denial, Peru's Police Seem to Plan Hostage Rescue
description: A day after the Peruvian police dismissed allegations that they were burrowing a tunnel to the Japanese Ambassador's residence, where scores of hostages are being held, foreign officials and local journalists confirmed today that one or more tunnels had been dug beneath the besieged residence.

title: Louisiana Auction Is Off After Charges of Forgery
description: The Baton Rouge auctioneer Ronald L. Causey will not be at his Louisiana Auction Exchange podium, gavel in hand, at noon today, as he had planned. His auction of 126 paintings attributed to Chagall, Botero, de Kooning and dozens of other renowned artists was suspended this week after New York art dealers charged that most of the works set to go on the block are fakes, including the work on the auction catalogue's cover, ''The Tow Path,'' which was attributed to Theodore Robinson.

title: North Carolina St. Beats Odds and Stuns Duke
description: The improbable does happen. Twice, in fact, in the 44-year history of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, HARRY
description: WASSERMAN-Harry. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Harry Wasserman, associated with The Times from 1966, until retiring in 1974.

title: For Women of the World
description: Imagine fashion is like a dinner party. The person to your right is a philatelist who speaks about stamps incessantly. On your left is one of those people who treats life as one long homework assignment, with a little knowledge of all the things that other people pursue passionately, including stamp collecting. That, in a nutshell, is what Milan's fall collections, which began on Saturday, are like.

title: NEW JOBS SURGE, BUT GAINS IN PAY ARE ONLY MODEST
description: The job market grew at an unexpectedly brisk pace in February, buoyed by unusually favorable weather for construction, as the unemployment rate slipped a tenth of a point, to 5.3 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEFTERAKIS, JOHN, M.D.
description: ELEFTERAKIS-John, M.D., on March 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Dori. Loving father of Maria, John, Nicholas and Michael. Devoted son of Mary and John. Dear brother of Gregory and Valerie; Katherine and Dr. Nicholas Liakas. Reposing at Dahill Funeral Home, 2525 65th St., Brooklyn until Monday 10:00 AM. Funeral liturgy Three Hierarchs G.O. Church 11:00 AM. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. Visiting Hours: Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Ducks' Duo Too Spry For the Rangers to Stop
description: What Wayne Gretzky and Mark Messier were to the Western Conference in the 1980's, the Anaheim Mighty Ducks' tandem of Paul Kariya and Teemu Selanne are in the 1990's. They are young, fast and possess deadly shooting touches, and tonight they probably made the Rangers' aging veterans nostalgic for the good ol' days.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Move Up Amid Mixed Views on Jobs Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday despite the release of February employment figures that were much stronger than expected. While 339,000 jobs were created last month -- exceeding analysts' forecast of 231,000 -- the report offered a mixed picture.

title: Hollow Bullet Is No Solution, Lawyer Argues
description: The lawyer for a woman who was shot by stray police gunfire -- a case that Police Commissioner Howard Safir highlighted as one that could have been avoided if officers used hollow-point bullets -- said yesterday that the controversy over the new bullets was ''an attempt to divert attention'' from inadequate training of officers.

description: To the Editor:

title: RJR Nabisco Raising Prices Of Cigarettes 4 Cents a Pack
description: Taking Wall Street by surprise, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation raised the wholesale prices on its cigarettes yesterday an average of 4.7 percent, or 4 cents a pack, and analysts expected the rest of America's tobacco makers to follow suit quickly.

title: 2004: I.O.C. Picks 5 Finalists
description: Reflecting geographical and political sensitivities, the International Olympic Committee yesterday narrowed the number of cities bidding for the 2004 Summer Olympics to 5 from 11, selecting Rome, Athens, Stockholm, Cape Town and Buenos Aires as the finalists.

title: Correction
description: In some editions yesterday, Anthony Lewis's column misidentified the Israeli official who criticized Yasir Arafat for taking the issue of a new Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem to the United Nations. He was David Peleg, not Gad Yaacobi.

title: Arabs Assail Israeli Move
description: Palestinian leaders today assailed the Israeli Government decision earlier in the day on a further withdrawal in the West Bank as too little, but the United States expressed satisfaction over what it described as a ''demonstration of Israel's commitment to the peace process.''

title: Governor Lifts Safety Rules for Shelters for Homeless Adults
description: The Pataki administration approved the elimination of regulations today that have required New York City to comply with specific fire, safety and health standards for its homeless shelters for single adults.

title: Soybean Prices Keep Climbing On Signs of Strong Demand
description: Soybean prices continued to climb on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on signs that strong domestic demand would erode lean inventories in the United States even more than expected.

title: Police Commissioner Has Heart Surgery to Bypass Blocked Arteries
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir underwent double-bypass heart surgery at New York University Medical Center yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said.

description: Flood Crest Hits Louisville

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, PROFESSOR GILBERT
description: RUBENSTEIN-Professor Gilbert, Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our longtime member. We extend condolences to the family. Services Gutterman's on March 7. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, DAVID T.
description: ADLER-David T. Beloved husband of Juanita. Devoted father of Jonathan and Robert. Dear brother of Lou, Florence, Renard, Ann Barnett and adored grandfather. Services Mon., 10AM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza opposite LIRR.

title: More Time for Gulf War Claims
description: President Clinton said today that he would extend to the end of 2001 the deadline for Persian Gulf war veterans to file claims for ailments that might be traced to their service in that conflict.

title: Medically Speaking, the Mets Are a Mess
description: Medical developments and injury concerns collided again at the Mets' training complex today as talk of surgical procedures, second opinions and setbacks filled the air more than baseballs hit in a game against the visiting Expos.

title: Staying Cool In a Hot Seat
description: Bill Clinton sounded today like a man pestered by a few mosquitoes, not a man threatened by a swarm of political hornets. He sounded convinced, in other words, that the uproar over his Administration's fund-raising tactics was an inside-the-Beltway phenomenon, not a national preoccupation, and that he need only stay cool and let it peter out.

title: Kevorkian Lawyer Gives Rationale for a Suicide
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian's lawyer said today that a Virginia woman whose body was found on Thursday night in a hotel near Detroit's airport had ended her own life ''after years of tortured suffering.''

title: No Starry, Starry Night on West Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Kipketer Sets a World 800 Record
description: On the first day of the world indoor track and field championships, Wilson Kipketer set a world record in the men's 800-meter run today and Gail Devers won the women's 60-meter dash.

title: Lawsuit in Woman's Death
description: A probate judge cleared the way yesterday for the father of a woman killed in a botched 1995 jewelry store robbery to file a wrongful death suit against the woman's widower.

title: No Headline
description: ''If the Dodgers were to leave, it would be a calamity, a catastrophe -- economically, socially and psychologically. People are saying they wouldn't leave Vero Beach, couldn't leave Vero Beach, but you and I know they could.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURIN, MORRIS
description: GURIN-Morris. Beloved husband of Norma (Naomi). Father of Leah Trachten, David Gurin. Brother of Noah Gurin. Beloved grandfather and great-grandfather. Service, Boulevard Chapel, 312 Coney Isl Ave, Bklyn, 11 a.m. Sun.

title: TV Curbed in Megan Trial
description: Television cameras will be barred from most courtroom proceedings during the trial of the man accused of killing Megan Kanka in 1994, a state judge ruled yesterday. Judge Andrew J. Smithson of Superior Court in Mercer County said that live coverage would be permitted only for the opening and closing statements and the reading of the verdict.

title: Why Push for Elections In Bosnia?
description: Ever since the Dayton peace accords, State Department officials have puffed themselves up with soaring rhetoric regarding the inevitable triumph of democracy in Bosnia. In practice they have ignored most of the real problems inherent in Bosnia's erratic progress toward self-government.

title: A Leader of Former Haitian Junta Is Charged With Smuggling Tons of Drugs to U.S.
description: One of the three men who ruled Haiti from 1991 to 1994 was indicted in Miami today on charges that he helped smuggle 66,000 pounds of Colombian cocaine and heroin into the United States.

title: Big East Week: A Time for Men Being Boys to Be Good Old Pals
description: At some point, the Big East tournament, now in its 15th year at Madison Square Garden, developed into more than just a series of basketball games. It became a time for prides of middle-age men to roam Manhattan streets in gaudy sweatshirts, emitting occasional indecipherable howls.

title: How a Proud Son of Irishtown Is Learning to Get Along
description: There are times when nothing seems to have changed for James Conway Sullivan, times when he is still your man in the Rockaways. Champion of all things Irish, he will sing the odd ditty, pound the table in support of a united Ireland, and demand a rightful share of New York City patronage for ''our people.''

title: Gill Is Not at All Content With Nets' Effort in Defeat
description: Anger seemed to swell so easily inside of Kendall Gill when he played in this caffeinated town. He walked around like a seam under pressure, stressed and ready to burst.

title: Now Denver's Airport Is Toasted, Not Roasted
description: Gauging changing moods, merchants here are quietly designing coffee mugs, key chains and T-shirts emblazoned with the distinctive tented peaks of Denver's new airport.

title: Camden Risks Loss of Grant From the U.S.
description: After a two-year review of cities and communities that have received money in a Federal program to spur economic development, the Housing Department said today that Camden, N.J., has made so little progress in putting the money to work that the city could lose it.

title: Police Identify Body Found on West Side Roof
description: The police yesterday identified the body of a German tourist found on the roof of an Upper West Side building last month.

title: Europe's Wine Industry Is Facing Serious Challenges
description: It's not that Paola Nuvola doesn't like wine. She simply enjoys Coke more.

description: KUSY-Adolf. Dear friend of Paul, Sylvia Edward, and Margo Daitch; Irving, Mike and Abbe Goldfarb; Larry, Tina and children; Walter, Rhoda and Neil Harris. Beloved friend to all wholesale meat dealers of NYC. Service 1 PM, Sunday at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a proposed purchase of the Physician Corporation of America by Sierra Health Service Inc. omitted a word in citing an announcement by Sierra on Thursday. Sierra said it would not buy Physician under the terms announced in November.

title: Police Release Sketch of Suspect in Bayonne Stabbings
description: Witnesses who watched an intruder fatally stab one Bayonne High School student, wound another and then flee Wednesday have described him as a light-skinned Hispanic teen-ager with close-cropped hair, a thin mustache and several facial blemishes from acne.

description: No matter how pleased Charles F. Dolan, chairman of the Cablevision System Corporation, is that his company has agreed to pay the ITT Corporation $650 million in cash and assume debt of $115 million for the half of Madison Square Garden it does not already own, some key Cablevision shareholders are very angry.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Rises Against the Yen But Closes Lower vs. the Mark
description: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday after a report on United States employment pointed to strong economic growth with little inflation.

title: Look at That! TV's a Window on Japan's Silly Side
description: On one channel, two men race around an obstacle course, clumps of slippery vanilla pudding swishing around on plates on their heads.

description: Randy Johnson is having fun again. Anyone would if he had succeeded in getting the knife out of his back and his feet out of the fire.

description: MARTIN-William R. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Perry, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1995.

title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Criticism of Israel's Construction Plan
description: The United States used its Security Council veto tonight to block a resolution that strongly criticized the Israeli Government's plan to build a new Jewish settlement in mainly Arab East Jerusalem. But all 14 other Council members voted for the measure, which portrayed the Israeli plan as a violation of international law and a threat to peace in the Middle East.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Favorite Stocks'' table in Business Day yesterday, listing the 15 issues with the most shareholders, provided outdated prices in some editions. Bell Atlantic, for example, closed on Thursday at 66 3/8, not 67, and Wal-Mart closed at 27 1/4, not 26 5/8.

title: The Sword of Democracy
description: A little knowledge can be a dangerous thing. Still searching for a new strategic vision after the collapse of Soviet Communism, some of the West's brighter lights have seized on a theory hugely popular among political scientists: that democracies do not go to war against one another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, GILBERT M.
description: RUBENSTEIN-Gilbert M. Professor Emeritus of English at Pace University died in Oceanside, NY on March 6th following a courageous struggle with lymphoma. A dedicated teacher to his students, Dr. Rubenstein served as English Dept. Chair, former President of the Faculty Council, and retired in 1994 following 43 years at Pace. He touched many people with his love of the English language. Beloved husband and father, treasured friend, he lived as a mensch who devoted himself to others in the spirit of tikkun olam, repairing the broken vessel of the world. He will be lovingly remembered by his wife of fifty years, Natalie; his children Asa and Fortune, Diane and Phillip, Susan and Carl; his granddaughter Rachel; his sister Pauline and his brother Leo. Memorial Services were held Friday March 7. Contributions can be made to the Pace University English Dept. or to Hadassah.

title: Christopher Boatwright, Dancer Known for Classicism; Was 42
description: Christopher Boatwright, a principal dancer with the Stuttgart Ballet, the San Francisco Ballet and the Lines Contemporary Ballet, died on Sunday at the Laguna Honda Hospital in San Francisco. Mr. Boatwright was 42 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Schools for Violent Students
description: The New York City Board of Education made a logical choice this week when it voted to create separate schools for violent students. Traditional public schools have never dealt effectively with these students, who pose a threat to the safety of other students and disrupt the classroom. The new separate schools -- some run by groups that specialize in troubled adolescents -- should have a better chance to succeed.

title: Hoffenberg Gets 20-Year Sentence in Fraud Case
description: Despite Steven Hoffenberg's arguments that he did not deserve such a harsh punishment, Judge Robert W. Sweet went ahead with his announced plan yesterday, sentencing Mr. Hoffenberg to 20 years in prison for defrauding thousands of investors in his company, the Towers Financial Corporation.

title: Gingrich Will Visit China Next Month
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich plans to travel to China in early April to meet with top Chinese Government officials.

title: From Jailed Mother's Lips, How Child Lived and Died
description: Carla Lockwood told her terrible story to the police early on Sept. 1, 1996, the morning after her daughter's tiny body was discovered inside her Washington Heights apartment.

title: Hempstead Appeals Voting Rights Case
description: Lawyers for the Town of Hempstead filed notice yesterday that they plan to appeal a Federal judge's ruling that the town discriminates against blacks in its at-large elections for the town board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, SAMUEL, JR.
description: HART-Samuel, Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Samuel Hart, Jr., associated with The Times from 1950, until retiring in 1978.

title: CLINTON DEFENDS 1996 FUND-RAISING BUT HITS SYSTEM
description: President Clinton said today that like Vice President Al Gore, he might have asked supporters for money during telephone conversations from the White House but that he could not remember any specific calls.

title: Russia's Most Hated Official Is Given Control of the Economy
description: Rapidly delivering on his promise to throw some human dynamite into the faltering Russian Government, President Boris N. Yeltsin named his most effective yet despised aide tonight to a position that will essentially give him control of the economy.

title: Shanker's Legacy Isn't Strife but Progress

title: HEINZ REPORTED SET TO SHUT PLANTS AND CUT JOBS
description: The H. J. Heinz Company plans to sell businesses, close plants, write off assets and cut as many as 2,000 jobs in a revamping that could lead to a $400 million charge, people familiar with the plan said yesterday. The revamping aims to pare production costs and reduce long-term debt of $3 billion. Heinz spokesmen declined to comment on the plan, which the board is expected to endorse on Wednesday. The plan is to be disclosed next Friday. Heinz said in September that it would restructure to maintain profit growth.

title: Michael Manley, Ex-Premier of Jamaica, Is Dead at 72
description: Michael Manley, who dominated Jamaican politics for a generation and became one of the most eloquent spokesmen for third-world causes, died Thursday night at his home outside Kingston. He was 72 and had long suffered from prostate cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BART, SUSAN
description: BART-Susan. Our entire community mourns the death of Susan Bart, Mother of Maddy and Josh, and wife of Jack Bart, after a long and courageous struggle. Susan was an exemplary jewish parent, who devoted herself to the wel fare of her family; Susan's commitment to her children's future was always in her thoughts and reflexed in her actions. Never did she cease to care and plan for the needs of Josh and Maddy. Susan was an enthusiatic member of our Parent's Association, tending to the needs of all our children; her quiet graciousness and kindness toward all in our community will always be remembered. We are deeply saddened by Susan's death and offer our comfort to Jack, Josh and Maddy. ''May the Memory of the Righteous be a Blessing''. M. Mac Schwebel, President Board of Trustees Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Head Master

title: LIBERTY PROPERTY TRUST ADDING PROPERTIES
description: Liberty Property Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy $130 million of office and industrial properties, mainly in South Carolina and Minneapolis, in two separate transactions. In one transaction, the company, which is based in Malvern, Pa., agreed to buy 18 office and industrial parks with about 1.24 million square feet of space from the Liberty Corporation, an insurer, for about $70 million. There is no relation between the two companies. Twelve of the properties are in South Carolina and the other six properties are in Florida and North Carolina. In the other transaction, Liberty Property is paying about $60 million for 17 properties around Minneapolis.

title: Ambassador To the World, And to Its City
description: BILL RICHARDSON has a knack for opening doors. Before becoming the United States representative to the United Nations, he dashed around the globe, freeing hostages and defusing tense political standoffs. That skill was evident on Thursday when he stepped into a room where representatives from 37 nations were duking it out.

title: Corrections

He was 67 and lived in Tempe, Ariz., where he was a geography professor at Arizona State University.

And one day she found herself cast as Carrie in ''Carousel'' and singing that most ingenuous of premarital fantasies of eternal devotion, ''Mr. Snow.''

Hearst, who passed on a reported multiyear deal with the Bengals averaging $1.3 million, agreed to a signing bonus of $600,000 and a base salary of $200,000 with the 49ers for 1997. He gets a $2 million package in 1998.

According to the Aspen Institute, manager of the retreat, the sessions will be run by Congress members who will discuss the causes of incivility and possible remedies. The activities will not include role-playing to exemplify conflict in society.

title: Ice
description: The New England winters of 1995 and 1996 had an old-fashioned rigor -- plenty of snow and temperatures cold enough to make life before central heating look improbable. So far, and with only a few days remaining, this winter has lacked that elemental sternness. The bitter weather that stupefied the Plains states has largely bypassed New England. Once or twice, snow has fallen, but to little purpose. What made this winter unusual was ice.

He's late (of course) and so blase about the avant-garde work he has been assigned to cover that he's ready to start writing before the curtain goes up: ''An investigation of some sort,'' he mutters. ''And a love of language. And some juxtapositions. . . .''

title: Checking on Aides for Elderly

Connors, Republican of Surf City, said yesterday. Starting in 1989, Mr. Connors unsuccessfully sponsored legislation that would require criminal background checks for people who work with the elderly.

title: Strains Start to Show in a British-German Merger
description: To bankers in London and Frankfurt, it was only a matter of time before the much-ballyhooed cross-border marriages of financial institutions that have been the rage in recent years would result in a public and bitter split.

title: HENRY SCHEIN AGREES TO PURCHASE MICRO BIO-MEDICS
description: Henry Schein Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Micro Bio-Medics Inc. for $117 million in stock and assumed debt, creating what it said would be the largest distributor of health care products to doctors' offices in North America. Henry Schein, based in Melville, L.I., said the purchase was valued at about $17.75 a Micro Bio-Medics share. Each Micro Bio-Medics share will be exchanged for 0.62 share of Henry Schein. Henry Schein said it would issue about 3.1 million new shares to Micro Bio-Medics shareholders, giving the stock portion of the deal an indicated value of about $55 million. Shares of Micro Bio-Medics, based in Pelham Manor, N.Y., were unchanged at $15.75 before they were halted ahead of the announcement. Henry Schein's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $28.625.

title: Public Bond Voting Is Urged

MacInnes, a Democrat, said yesterday that he plans to introduce a bill Monday that would put the pension bond financing plan on the ballot if the Legislature approves it.

title: Wildcats Roll Into the Final

title: 17th-Century Foxes Voguing, Dancing and Killing
description: The opening moments of Robert Woodruff's acid-trip adaptation of ''The Changeling'' are enough to flip a Jacobean playwright's wig. Before the first drop of blood in the tragedy is spilled, the entire cast, decked out as if it had emerged from a Versace fashion layout, assembles onstage at the Theater at St. Clement's Church for a sexy, unscripted production number.

title: APPLIED WILL NOT INCREASE READ-RITE OFFER
description: The Applied Magnetics Corporation said yesterday that it would not raise its hostile offer of $1.18 billion for a larger rival, the Read-Rite Corporation. That could kill the transaction because many Read-Rite shareholders are unlikely to accept the current terms of the stock-swap offer. Applied Magnetics is hoping that its stock price will increase. Shares of Applied, which closed at $53 the day before it made its offer, rose $1.625 yesterday, to $38.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Applied offered 0.679 share for each share of Read-Rite, so the value of the offer has fallen from about $1.8 billion when it was made on Feb. 24 to $1.18 billion as of Thursday.

Beloved daughter of Hortense and Sumner Zabriskie; cherished sister of Joan and Michael Bilt; adored aunt of Steven & Marty Bilt; loving and devoted friend to so many. She will be deeply missed for her goodness, her incredible artistic talents, her depth of character and intelligence and her compassion. Her spirit will carry on within each of us. Lindy graduated from Parsons School of Design with a bachelor's degree in Fine Arts and was later certified to practice, and was working, as a radiologic technologist. title: CHUBB IS PLANNING A REPURCHASE OF ITS SHARES
description: The Chubb Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to 17.5 million shares, or about 10 percent of the company's shares outstanding. The insurer, which is based in Warren, N.J, also said it had restated its 1996 financial results downward by $160 million related to real estate assets and to include a $22 million loss from the sale of its life insurance business. The company said its revised net income for 1996 was $512.7 million, or $2.90 a share, down from the previously reported figure of $694.7 million, or $3.91 a share.

title: No Label, No Marketers, Just Room to Grow
description: OMER AVITAL'S YOUNG sextet has a new piece in its repertory -- ''Dalia,''which Mr. Avital wrote for his mother. The band worked it out, section by section, in two rehearsals, and by its first performance a few weeks ago, at 3 A.M. in Smalls, a tiny club in Greenwich Village, it was full of the indefinite. His melodies were sweeping and singable and rejected the tight chromatic formalism of so much mainstream jazz since the 1960's; the swing, in the improvised passages, was cathartic.

title: Voices For Those Lost To Disease
description: HOWARD HORNSTEIN remembers well his despair five years ago when faced with giving up his practice in pediatric dentistry. At the age of 49, the Guilford man had been diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis or A.L.S., a degenerative disease of the nervous system.

title: A Moment for Reform
description: President Clinton used his press conference to sketch a kind of alternate universe. It was a fluid performance in Mr. Clinton's best slide-and-glide style. But most Americans do not believe in a universe where Johnny Chung hustles Presidential photo ops, Vice President Al Gore's telephoning is described as a model of political dignity and Maggie Williams's palming of a $50,000 check is praised as artful handling of a strained social situation. In this through-the-looking-glass world, Mr. Clinton makes the systematized access-peddling sound like an exercise in Athenian democracy in one breath and calls on Congress to outlaw such behavior in the next.

title: Downward Trend in Crime Continued, Sharply, in 1996

title: Records for Safeguarding

Little has been done to improve the security of these personal files, it said, and few people recognize the scope of the problem.

title: A Composer for the Eye Inspired Music for the Ear
description: MOST FILM DIRECTORS come to have an effect on composers during the course of their work, but not many continue doing so from beyond the grave. Indeed, Andrei Tarkovsky is probably unique in this respect. In 1987, the year after his death, two distinguished composers, Luigi Nono and Toru Takemitsu, independently wrote musical memorials to him. And four years after that, Claudio Abbado put on a concert in Vienna to include the Nono piece; for the occasion, he commissioned further tributes from Gyorgy Kurtag, Wolfgang Rihm and Peat Furrer.

title: Cloning Research and a Brave New World
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday with an article about multiple births mentioned that Colleen Tweedy, shown undergoing ultrasound, was expecting quadruplets. On Feb. 27, after the section went to press, they were born -- three girls and a boy.

title: Olympia Trails to Honor Airport Bus Tickets
description: Round-trip tickets issued by New Jersey Transit will be honored by the Olympia Trails Bus Company when it takes over service between Newark International Airport and the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan on April 5, said New Jersey Transit spokesman Ken Miller.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lost Without a Screen: the Fate of 'Orphan' Films
description: WHEN ''BIG NIGHT'' BECAME the talk of last year's Sundance Film Festival, Stanley Tucci figured he was all set. Instead, he found ''Big Night'' stuck in limbo for several months while his distributor, the Samuel Goldwyn Company, went in and out of bankruptcy.

title: 180-Mile Hiking Trail On Lake District's Coast
description: The Cumbrian Coastal Way, a 180-mile hiking trail that skirts the Lake District along the northwest coast of England from Ironbridge near Carlisle to Milnthorpe is now complete, following the opening of a 45-mile South Lakeland stretch. The new section from Barrow-in-Furness (265 miles northwest of London) to Milnthorpe runs around the coastline of the South Cumbria coast overlooking Morecambe Bay.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture of the violinist Gil Shaham on page 31 of the Arts and Leisure section today is reproduced in mirror image in some copies. He held the bow in his right hand.

title: Ending Mortgage Insurance
description: FOR people who have struggled in vain to amass the 20 percent down payment on a home that is typically required for a conventional mortgage loan, the availability of private mortgage insurance has been the next best thing to having a rich uncle.

title: A Depot's for Sale, With 30 Cabooses as a Sweetener
description: UNION STATION in North Canaan, said to be the oldest railway depot in continous operation in the United States, is for sale at $1.195 million.

title: Vote to Decide Merger of Two School Districts
description: PROMPTED by concerns of increased expenses and a space shortage from rising student enrollment, the Mattituck-Cutchogue and Laurel School Districts have proposed a merger. Residents of the two small communities on the Island's North Fork will vote Tuesday on whether to unite their districts this summer, to start the next school year as one school district.

title: Van Gundy, Now a Veteran of the Chicago Wars, Plays It Close to the Vest
description: Jeff Van Gundy sat in a Philadelphia hotel room at about 7:30 A.M. when he heard the knock on his door. He was breaking down game film of Chicago when he rose from his bed. He thought it was the maid.

title: Soul-Satisfying Favorites in Italian Fare
description: WARM is the word for Luigi's in New Hyde Park.

title: Easy Winter Gives Road Budgets a Break
description: THE salt and sand are piled high. The equipment is oiled and ready. An army of plowers is ready to jump into action at the sight of the first snowflake.

title: Partial-Truth Abortion
description: In the 24 years since Roe v. Wade, American women have never been more in danger of losing their constitutional right to an abortion than they are this week -- but so farcical, if far from funny, has been the debate surrounding ''partial-birth abortions'' that many Americans, Congressmen included, don't have a clue as to what is really going on.

title: Testing Younger Women for Osteoporosis
description: KATHLEEN MUCCIOLO was 35 when her mother Katherine, then 57, was diagnosed with osteoporosis. The disease seemed to come without warning, when a vertebrae in her mother's back spontaneously collapsed while she was gardening. ''She had never even complained of a backache before that,'' said Ms. Mucciolo of Manhattan. ''Suddenly, her life revolved around pain and fractures.''

title: Does Getting Old Cost Society Too Much?
description: Back in the early 1980's, before most of us had ever heard of the Internet, science-fiction writers like Bruce Sterling invented a genre that came to be known as cyberpunk. Its protagonists were usually outlaw computer hackers, battling sinister multinational corporations for control of cyberspace (a term coined by another sci-fi novelist, William Gibson). But in his 1996 novel, ''Holy Fire,'' Sterling imagines a rather different future: a world ruled by an all-powerful gerontocracy, which appropriates most of the world's wealth to pay for ever more costly life-extension techniques. And his heroine is, believe it or not, a 94-year-old medical economist.

title: Judaism on Death Row
description: The trial of a Teaneck resident who pleaded guilty to using sleeping pills, strangulation and suffocation to kill his two children raises a possibility that was once statistically remote. One who is not only Jewish but religiously observant may sit on death row in Trenton State Prison.

title: Dolly's Genetic Lineage

title: Just Plain Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounding Off About Web Sites
description: Do you find the Internet useful in getting information related to New Jersey? What would you like to see that is not there now?

title: Giuliani Says State Owes Education Aid
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is contending that the state has systematically denied New York City nearly $900 million in education aid over the last eight years, saying that the state has violated its own laws and put pressure on municipal finances by withholding the money.

title: A Walk in the Woods Brings New Shades of Understanding
description: I remember the rhyme well, and you probably do, too: ''I think that I shall never see, a poem lovely as a tree.'' Joyce Kilmer wrote it, we all had to memorize it, and most of us did our best to forget it. Who needs a quaint rhyme, a hybrid born of a mixed metaphor and a non sequitur, when you have movies by the likes of Quentin Tarantino, deconstructionist literary criticism and Calvin Klein models to get all juiced up about?

title: Lars Bergstrom, Boat and Plane Innovator, 62
description: Lars Bergstrom, an aeronautical wizard whose personal affinity for boats led to many design innovations in yachts as well as airplanes, died last Sunday when an experimental glider he was testing crashed about two miles from the airport at Wauchula, Fla. He was 62.

title: A Curtsy to Glories Past: The Tiara Is Back on Top
description: FORGET body piercing and safety-pin necklaces. Tiaras seem to be the ornament of the moment. Young women in next-to-nothing slip dresses are wearing little diamante diadems tucked into ungroomed hair, or tiaras rendered in unconventional materials like metal spikes, plastic or wood in abstract designs, sometimes topped off with feathers. Women on their way to formal soirees are dusting off old tiaras from family vaults.

title: It's Called Poor Health for a Reason
description: FROM a cerebro-vascular, genito-urinary, gastro-intestinal, psycho-therapeutic or mortuary point of view, the rich and famous have never had it so good. Yes, their children are more prone to acne and allergies. Nevertheless, during the last half of the 20th century, people in the developed world with an elevated social status have been producing health, well-being and longevity at a faster rate than those with lower social standing.

title: With Manning Out of the Running, Pace Is the Jets' Man . . . or Is He?
description: It just doesn't come easily for the Jets, even with their dictator-for-the-millennium, Bill Parcells, running the show with his longtime secretary of state, Bill Belichick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFER, JOSEPH
description: SCHIFFER - Joseph, former Brooklyn resident, and public school teacher there. Currently residing in Wilkes-Barre, PA, died there Friday. Surviving are son Morton and daughter Helena Prashker, both of Kingston, PA, six grandchildren, 7 great-grandchildren. Graveside services Monday at 1 P.M., Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. Shiva in home of Morton Schiffer, 96 North Atherton Ave, Kingston, PA 18705.

title: Buying a Home: The People Who Help
description: NAOMI DAVIS and Randi Hutton both sell real estate for a living. Ms. Davis spends a good deal of time at her computer trying to match buyers and sellers of co-ops in New York City. Often, an apartment number and an address are all she needs to visualize the basic layout of an apartment and to determine whether a prospective buyer is likely to pass muster with the building's board of directors.

title: A Party Suffused With Art
description: FOR a moment, Eric Fischl looked like a tableau vivant of one of his own paintings, those realistically rendered scenes of sexual innuendo. There he stood, dressed in elegant evening garb, with a small group of men that included Ralph Gibson, a photographer. In front of them on a raised platform, a stunning blond nude glowed like a moisturizer advertisement. The men made small talk with barely a glance in the direction of the vision, who looked as if she had just risen from the sea on a giant half shell.

title: The Kama Sutra of Reading
description: The original manual of love making, written almost 2000 years ago by Vatsyayana, has been adapted for the modern reader. Painstaking research and experimentation have resulted in the following examples designed for the most pleasurable reading experiences.

title: A Story of Love, a Saga of Survival
description: IT is a tale of survival and more, including love. In 1977 a young woman named Edna De'Lesline was walking down a street in Norwich when she caught the eye of a young man who was on a ladder, changing the letters on a movie marquee. He called out to her: ''Hello! My name is George Walker 3d. Will you marry me?''

description: Rhyme and Reason

description: HAS the balance of power changed? Is the great tenant market of the 90's in midtown office buildings finally coming to an end, with the balance of power shifting to landlords after a few years of steady economic recovery with virtually no new construction?

title: Duval Holds Lead on a Breezy Day
description: By the time the final footprint had been raked from the last of the 117 bunkers today, and the last ripple had disappeared from the lake next to the 18th hole here at the Doral Desert Classic, er, Doral-Ryder Open, there were more smiles on the sides of cut Titleists than there were on the faces of the sandblasted golfers.

description: LEVINE-Irving A. 85, of Lauderhill FL. Passed away March 5, 1997. Beloved and devoted husband of Pearl; loving father of Larry (Sherry) Lawrence; adored grandfather of Joanna Lawrence (Dean Schwartz) and Robert (Amy) Lawrence; proud great-grandfather of Eric Avery Lawrence. Funeral services were held March 7, 1997 in Florida.

title: It's a Historical House, All Right, but How Did the Garden Grow?
description: RUDY FAVRETTI strode over the grounds of the Capt. Nathaniel B. Palmer House in Stonington. ''This was the grapery,'' he said, pointing to a big stone wall that had held trellises for vines. He walked by granite posts near the house. ''This was a service yard, where you hung the clothes,'' he said, adding that the posts had supported a high fence that hid the laundry. By the front door, he eyed modern shrubbery where, he learned recently, there once were flowering quinces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIANE, EDWARD N.
description: PIANE-Edward N., 70. Suddenly March 7, in Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Glen Cove, NY. Devoted husband of Luise; dear father of Christine A. Gould, Stephen E. Piane and Lori K. Nicastro and grandson, Sean A. Gould. Reposing at McLaughlin-Kramer Funeral Home, 220 Glen St., Glen Cove, Monday 3-5, 7-9 PM. Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Patrick's Church, In lieu of flowers, memorials to a favorite charity.

title: For a Specialist In Being Abused, It's the Good Life
description: TO TRACK Paul Giamatti's career path this month could lead to cultural whiplash. In the movie ''Private Parts,'' which opened on Friday, he plays Kenny, a radio executive who becomes the superego trying to repress the shock jock Howard Stern's dangerously out-of-control id. When Mr. Stern's ratings soar, the id wins and Kenny finds himself out of a job. Throughout the movie Mr. Stern refers to Kenny by the name Pig Vomit.

This spice -- actually the dried stigma of a type of crocus, with orange and red threads that look like pipe tobacco --is wonderful when used sparingly, adding a subtle dimension to a dish.

title: New Habitat for Orlando Science Center
description: The Orlando Science Center -- a sprawling high-tech science museum that claims to be the largest in the Southeast -- opened last month in a new 207,000-square foot building about 15 miles from the city's major attractions. The center -- which had been housed nearby in tighter quarters -- now has 10 permanent exhibition halls with hands-on displays that examine the natural, physical and mathematical sciences, as well as applied technology, including computer simulation and laser optics.

description: THE new film ''Smilla's Sense of Snow'' includes major fashion moments, and not because its star, Julia Ormond, is a ringer for the Vogue editor in chief, Anna Wintour, with her bobbed hair and cool manner. The style note: when the heroine faces down villains on a frosty Greenlandic tundra, nearly everyone on screen wears down-filled jackets by the North Face.

description: Ellen Myra Braitman, an assistant editor at Consumer Reports in Yonkers, is to be married today to David Joseph Shapiro, a litigation associate at Dewey Ballantine, the New York law firm. Rabbi Irwin Zeplowitz is to officiate at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, MELVIN G.
description: MARCUS-Melvin G. With profound sorrow and an indelible sense of loss, The American Geographical Society records the sudden death of its Councilor (since 1980) and Vice President (since 1986) Melvin G. Marcus on March 2nd. His sound judgement, devotion, integrity, instinct for consensus, creative leadership, largeness of spirit, droll wit, respect for others, passion for field research, and zest for life will be deeply missed but will continue to inspire and influence those fortunate enough to have known him. Mel was to have received the Society's most venerable medal, the Cullum Geographical Medal, on March 13th. The award will be made as scheduled, but posthumously. Richard H. Nolte, Chairman Emeritus John E. Gould, Chairman Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, President Mary Lynne Bird, Executive Director
