title: A Comic Races to Stay in Place
description: ''WANT TO SEE something funny?'' Greg Fitzsimmons asks. It better be funny, because funny is Mr. Fitzsimmons's business. He is currently New York comedy's golden boy. And right now he is standing in a USA Network editing suite examining ''Temporarily Fitzsimmons,'' a segment he does for ''USA Live'' in which he experiences life in a new workplace every week. This time, he spent eight hours as an employee in a grocery store. The result: Four very funny minutes of cable television.

description: In an effort to blunt criticism of its wartime record, Switzerland last week offered to set up a $4.7 billion investment fund from revalued gold reserves; the earnings would benefit victims of oppression, including Holocaust survivors.

title: A Modest Shangri-La
description: IT'S easy to imagine yourself growing healthy and beautiful in Ojai, Calif.; you feel it will happen if you just stand there and breathe deeply. When Hollywood needed a setting for Shangri-La, mythical paradise of eternal youth, it found what it was looking for in the Ojai Valley: jagged mountain peaks that could serve as a backdrop for a procession of Tibetan monks; grassy meadows where lovers might romp; orange groves, flowering shrubs, and ribbons of water flowing into worn stone basins.

title: After Sanding, Finishing the Floors
description: SANDING wood floors was featured in last week's Home Clinic. Once the floor has been sanded, it is ready to receive a finish. If possible, the first coat of finish should be applied on the same day the sanding was completed. If too much time elapses after the sanding, the grain may rise in the floor boards. When applying any finish, it's important to read all labels carefully and to follow the manufacturer's safety recommendations regarding skin contact, ventilation, fire hazards, breathing apparatus and disposal.

title: Scientology's Puzzling Journey From Tax Rebel to Tax Exempt

title: Burial Society's Sacred Task of Performing a Ritual for the Dead
description: GEORGE BERMAN is neither doctor nor mortician, yet he deals with death on a regular basis. Two or three times a month, he enters the preparation room of a funeral home, peels the plastic body bag from a corpse and prepares it for burial. The work he does is not part of his profession -- he and his wife Rochel, both 61, own a public relations concern here -- but, he said, it is a calling, a religious activity ''of the highest order.'' Readers should know at the outset, however, that this article contains some graphic details.

description: Maybe few people in your workplace would take to the picket lines over something like the shaving of bulls' horns -- the issue in the matadors' strike in Spain last week. Then again, people go to the mat over some pretty odd grievances; regular raises and job security are far from the only things on workers' minds. Some may insist on a perfume-free environment, while others may demand an office microwave oven. What do you and your co-workers demand? title: Girls With Cerebral Palsy Dance in Face of Fate

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASTINGS, LOUISE LAURENT (LILY)
description: HASTINGS-Louise Laurent (Lily). It is with deep regret that we note the passing of Lily Hastings on March 7th, 1997 after a long illness while in St. Vincent's Hospital, NYC. Born in Lyon, France, September 9th, 1908; on December 22nd, 1945, she was married in Paris to the musician, Baird Hastings. After a distinguished career as a coutouriere, she collaborated with her husband on many artistic productions including Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Trial by Jury,'' and editing the pocket review of the arts, ''Chrysalis,'' and she managed the bookstore of the Harvard University Press, 1951-1959. For a score of years, she designed period costumes for more than a dozen OffBroadway plays and ballets. Wellknown in her circle, she was the subject of one of Virgil Thomson's unique ''Portraits in Music.'' The co-director of the French Art Theatre, James Lewis, said of her, ''She was French to the core; she was a great cook; she was a wonderful partner.'' Her only survivor is her husband.

title: A Choral Resurgence With Bach and Handel

title: The Organization of a Multifaceted Attack on Stubborn Fat

The collaborative effort of the Stamford Hospital, St. Joseph Medical Center and the Jewish Community Center offers help with programs on behavior modification, effective dieting, appropriate exercise and life style changes.

title: Where Salt and Limes Are Staple Goods

With the deft strokes of a baton-waving orchestra conductor, he hacked off the barbed spears of a ripe cactus, revealing a hundred-pound pineapple-shaped heart, the pina. Through the alchemies of fermentation and distillation, he told me, this pina would soon be transformed into about six liters of tequila. ''The agave,'' Mr. Gama said quite seriously, ''is a noble plant.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNERT, VINCENT
description: GRUNERT-Vincent, died peacefully on March 2, 1997, at the age of 100. Born in Hungary on May 26, 1896, he emigrated to the U.S. in 1923, and lived in NYC for 71 years before moving to Houston, TX, to live near his son. A pioneer in color motion picture film processing, he worked for 39 years at the Deluxe Laboratories in NYC, and had a wide reputation in the business for doing it right the first time. He was a Sunday school teacher and trustee at the First Presbyterian Church of Whitestone, NY, and also worked with the Boy Scouts, serving as a district commissioner. A prolific writer (unpublished), his works gave him great pleasure in his later years. Vincent was preceded in death by his wife, Madeline in 1976. He is survived by daughter, Audrienne C. Toomey and her husband William; son, Eric Grunert and his wife, Shirley; grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the many friends his life touched. A Memorial Service was held in Houston on March 6, 1997. His remains will be interred next to his wife at Pinelawn, Long Island. Those wishing to pay their respects may contact his daughter at 1013 Hobbs Drive, Colesville, MD 20904.

title: Highly Animated
description: From 1959 through 1964, citizens of the cartoon town of Frostbite Falls, Minn., were regularly rescued from a rash of fiendish plots and schemes by their stalwart neighbors, Bullwinkle, surely history's most obtuse talking moose, and Rocky, the world's pluckiest and most credulous flying squirrel. The pair, with their peculiar take on life and its discontents, stumbled through a series of animated adventures that somehow saved both Frostbite Falls and the rest of civilization from the sinister machinations of Fearless Leader, executed with diabolic aplomb and a Rube Goldberg-like attention to detail by Boris Badenov and his evil sidekick, Natasha Fatale. Squeaky-voiced Rocky and the intellectually challenged Bullwinkle performed their noble deeds every week with a savoir-faire grounded in pure hearts and absolute obliviousness, an unlikely combination that amazingly took them from triumph to triumph. Supporting our two heroes were other cartoons featuring such memorable characters as Mr. Peabody, a brilliant beagle with a pet boy, and the stoutly clueless Dudley Do-Right of the Mounties, all products of Jay Ward, a man with a Harvard M.B.A. and a truly weird sense of the world, and a group of writers, animators and voice actors who together produced five seasons of what might be called cartoon stand-up, in which dialogue and characterization counted for at least as much as action. In THE ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE BOOK (Bantam, $50), the entertainment journalist Louis Chunovic has gathered more information than may be strictly necessary about Mr. Ward and his band, filling the pages with press releases, illustrations, tidbits and oddities. Probably he would admit that watching Moose and Squirrel is more entertaining than reading about them, but -- Hokey Smoke -- for true believers, having a synopsis of all 326 episodes is an uncommon treat. James Polk

title: Adding Subtlety to Dishes With a Pinch of Saffron
description: IT was eating paella in a Spanish restaurant recently that reminded me of how much I love the taste of saffron. This spice -- actually the dried stigma of a type of crocus, with orange and red threads that look like pipe tobacco -- is wonderful when used sparingly, adding a subtle dimension to a dish. But saffron has a penetrating aroma that can be overwhelming if too much is used, which is why some people do not take to it. But used in the right quantities, it brings out the flavor of seafood, which makes it a natural in paella and risotto (when you add it to rice, its hue begins to darken and develop like a print in a photographer's lab). It also marries well with the acid flavor of tomatoes, making it a good foil for a fatty fish like salmon. In Spain it is often combined with ground almonds, garlic and parsley and added to stews. It goes very well with the rather bland flavors of veal or chicken.

title: Love at Last Sight
description: In the window of the dining car of a train traveling from St. Petersburg to Paris, a middle-aged French film maker named Luca glimpses the reflection of a woman raising her hand to her neck, and his heart stops. Just so had his one-time Russian sweetheart, Anna, gestured in moments of weariness or sorrow. The woman on the train has the same build, the same dark hair, but is she Anna? This question haunts MY RUSSIAN LOVE (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $18.95), Dan Franck's affecting exploration of the lasting power of first -- and lost -- love. As the train rolls toward Paris and the woman leaves the dining car, Luca does not follow. Instead, he falls into a reverie, remembering his student days, the first time he saw the 18-year-old Anna in a Paris cafe, their first walk together, their first embrace, their first night of love. Anna's parents had been determined to get their only child out of the Soviet Union, to study and be free in the West. But when news arrives that calls her back to them, she goes at once, severing herself from Luca -- except for one brief encounter that yields the secret to the book's mystery. Mr. Franck, a French screenwriter who is the author of an earlier novel, ''Separation,'' has written a book as spare as a screenplay but fully novelistic in its language, imagery and psychological insight. In this agile translation by Jon Rothschild, it captures the emotional turmoil of young lovers, of their conviction that what they are experiencing is something that ''would never again exist with anyone else.'' Zofia Smardz

title: The Age Boom
description: When my father died at 67, leaving my mother alone in Portland, Ore., I thought almost automatically that she should come home with me to New York. Considering her heavy Lithuanian accent and how she shrank from dealing with authority, I thought she'd surely need help getting along. ''Are you kidding?'' she exclaimed. Managing her affairs became her work and her pride, and it soon occurred to me that this was the first time that she, traditional wife, had ever experienced autonomy. Every few days she would make her rounds to the bank, the doctor, the class in calligraphy. Then, in her personal brand of English, she would make her telephone rounds. She would complain that waiting for her pension check was ''like sitting on pins and noodles'' or entreat her granddaughter to stop spending money ''like a drunken driver.'' Proudly, stubbornly, she managed on her own for 18 years. And even then, at 83, frustrated by strokes and angry at the very the thought of a nursing home, she refused to eat. In days, she made herself die.

He began by asking me: ''What do you think about this Swiss-Jewish thing?'' I told him the Swiss needed to be more forthcoming and he mumbled something about how the Swiss were no better or worse than anyone else in Europe. It was one of those conversations, though, where I knew if I had said, ''Those Jews, they're just blackmailing the Swiss,'' this guy would have said, ''Man, you're so right.'' Then he went on to China. What did I think of the U.S. human rights activism there? Before I could even answer, he unleashed a broadside against the U.S. for promoting human rights in China, and he added, for good measure, that one reason his oil business was doing so well there was because China didn't have all those pesky environmental rules.

He administered the last of New York's big real estate businesses based on the holdings of the early German brewing families. He worked for the J. Chr. G. Hupfel Co., Inc. while it was still a brewery and later became President. He was also with Peter Doelger, Inc., a former brewery that developed luxury apartment buildings. The family owned 350 properties in New York City before they sold out in 1961. Mr. Hupfel attended Andover and Cornell, then lived in Biarritz, France, for 15 years. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club; the Southport and Essex Yacht Clubs in Connecticut; the Gulf Stream Golf Club and Gulf Stream Bath and Tennis Clubs in Gulf Stream, Florida; and The Maidstone Club in East Hampton, New York. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Lampert Hupfel; four nephews, Manuel Sanchez de Movellan (Marques de Movellan), Juan Sanchez de Movellan and Pedro Sanchez de Movellan of Comillas, Spain and Antonio Sanchez de Movellan of Lexington, Kentucky; 14 grand nieces and nephews and 10 great-grand nieces and nephews; two stepchildren, Matt Spence of Boca Raton, Florida and Laurie Reeves of Lyme, Connecticut; and two step-grandchildren, Beth and Ross Spence. Service Wednesday 10:15 A.M. at Park East Synagogue on 68th Street, between Lexington & 3rd. For further information call Plaza Memorial Chapel 769-4400.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Tonight in New York, Prince Charles will be the guest of honor at a dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the founding sponsors of the American Associates of the St. Catherine Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKL, ERWIN
description: FRANKL-Erwin. Passed away peacefully Sunday, March 9, two weeks before his 86th birthday. Beloved husband, father, father-inlaw, dear friend and relative, who will be long remembered by all who knew him and loved him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAMAST, DAVID
description: DAMAST-David. Congregation Beth Sholom of Long Beach and Lido records with sorrow the passing of its longtime member and benefactor who served as our Chairman for Israel Bonds and UJA. His love of Israel, our synagogue and all things Jewish will long be remembered. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Shirley, his children, grandchildren and entire family. Dr. Amos W. Miller, Rabbi Solomon Mendelson, Hazzan Eugeue Oberdorfer, President

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A. Unlikely to Be Issue at Hearing on Nominee
description: Senate hearings on Anthony Lake's nomination as Director of Central Intelligence, set to start on Tuesday, might become a debate over campaign financing and foreign policy failings instead of a discussion of the future of United States intelligence.

title: 'Electrochemical Paintbrush' Wins Westinghouse Science Competition
description: A Hunter College High School senior who turned Lego, modeling clay and a pile of electronic circuits into a sophisticated microscope suspended from his bedroom ceiling by bungee cords won first prize yesterday in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the nation's pre-eminent competition for budding researchers and inventors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, JULES
description: ROTHMAN - Jules. Middlebury, CT. Jules Rothman, a/k/a Julius Rothman, 90, of South Street, died early Monday morning at his home. He was the husband of Anneke (Roosen) Rothman. Mr. Rothman was born October 25, 1906, in New York City, son of the late Harry and Esther (Friedman) Rothman, and lived in Middlebury over 25 years, moving here from New York. He was a teacher for the Board of Education of New York for many years, teaching at Curtis High School on Staten Island and Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. Mr. Rothman set up the first Nazi-free newspaper in Heidelburg, Germany. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, and studied language in Germany, in France at the Sorbonne and in Italy. He is survived by his wife of Middlebury. Graveside services will be held Tuesday, at 2PM, in Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Contact The Alderson Funeral Home of Waterbury, 70 Central Ave, for any additional information.

title: Whitman Asks State Funds
description: Though she remains unopposed in the Republican primary on June 3, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman asked the state yesterday for $589,120 in matching funds. ''Our opponent is apathy and lack of information,'' said the Governor's campaign manager, Tom Wilson. The filing deadline for primary candidates is April 10. Rich McGrath, a spokesman for State Senator James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, one of the two leading candidates for the Democratic nomination, called the Governor's request ''a wasteful use of taxpayers' money.''

title: Your Last Film Bombed? Simple: Get a New Agent
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger is turning 50 and has suffered box office disappointments. Sylvester Stallone's career is in the doldrums. Madonna failed to get an Academy Award nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINISI, BENJAMIN JOSEPH
description: SINISI-Benjamin Joseph. On March 9, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Margaret (nee Mauriello), devoted father of Joan Sinisi, Rocco Sinisi, and Beverly Ann Taki. Loving grandfather of Pamela, Blaise, Dennis, Gena, and Adam, and great grandfather of Kelsey and Devin. Dear brother of Anna, Theresa, and the late Vincent. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial St Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Ave. at 84th St on Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLETTI, PERUCCA, SONIO EDWARD
description: COLETTI-PERUCCA-Sonio Edward, died Sunday, March 9, of cancer. Age 77. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Onorio and Marc Andrea, and stepfather of Jackie Drexel. He is survived by six grandchildren. He was born in New York City, November 12, 1919. He served with distinction as an officer in the American Army. Funeral Friday at 11 AM at St. Paul the Apostle Church, Route 107, Brookville. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Don Monti Cancer Center at Glen Cove Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERMAN, ROSALIE (NEE BARATT)
description: COOPERMAN-Rosalie (nee Baratt). Beloved wife of the late Jack Schachter and Daniel Cooperman. Mother of Roberta, Heddy, Paulette, Billy. Grandmother and great-grandmother. Devoted sister of Pauline Schwartz, Henriette Bard, and the late David Baratt. Loving aunt. Services will be at Noon at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, on Wednesday, 3/12/97, 180 W. 76th St., New York City.

title: Hanoi Agrees to Pay Saigon's Debt to U.S.
description: Vietnam has agreed to pay to the United States millions of dollars in debts incurred by the former South Vietnam for roads, power stations and grain shipments during the Vietnam War, Administration officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC WEENEY, PATRICK J.
description: Mc WEENEY-Patrick J., 88, on March 8, 1997 of Elmhurst, NY. Retired federal employee. Survived by two sisters: Mary Mc Bride and Elizabeth Beirne and several nieces and nephews. Reposing Dwyer Funeral Home, Tarrytown, on Tues., 2-4, 7-9. Mass, Wednes., 10am, Immaculate Conception Church, Irvington. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Gearing Up For Indy
description: THE PROBLEMS of March are simple. For the next three weekends, all the way to the night of March 31 in Indianapolis, the attention should return to the basics that have attracted Hoopheads long before the N.C.A.A. championship became a billion-dollar event.

title: Canadian Retailer Imperiled as U.S. Rivals Move In
description: The near col lapse of the T. Eaton Company the stately department store chain that filed for protection from creditors last month -- has heightened fears that even Canada's most powerful companies are threatened by aggressive American retailers.

title: Both Sides Fail to Show At Hostage Talks in Peru
description: Talks between leftist rebels holding 72 hostages and the Peruvian Government failed to resume as planned today, with the commission overseeing talks to end the crisis waiting at the negotiating table and neither side showing up.

title: New Agreement on Scofflaw Diplomats
description: The Giuliani administration and the State Department announced an agreement yesterday that officials hoped would ease a longstanding irritation for motorists and the police alike: foreign diplomats parking illegally and claiming immunity to the fines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSTEIN, MICHAEL
description: FEINSTEIN-Michael. We extend our sympathy to the family and friends of our founding member who gave over thirty years of devoted service to our organization. He will be deeply missed. Albert Ellis Institute Board of Trustees

title: New York Should Track Its Hazardous Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: As More Sharks Wind Up on Plates, Need for Protection Rises
description: ONE of mankind's largest and least regulated harvests of creatures from the wild is ravaging many of the world's shark species, but nascent international efforts to protect the species are hampered by a deep ignorance, not only about how many are killed but also about how they live and what they need to survive.

title: Zaire's Entire Political Class Is Target of the Rebel Army
description: Almost every day, a few score members of Zaire's transitional assembly show up at the Chinese-built House of the People, a Parliament building as monumental as its name is far-fetched.

title: From All Walks of Life, a Title for Dwight
description: Since 1880, the Dwight School, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, has been turning out doctors, lawyers and corporate executives.

title: A Cadet Is Dismissed and 9 Are Disciplined for Citadel Harassment
description: The Citadel, the state military college here that has been in turmoil over accusations that female cadets were harassed, announced today that it was dismissing one male cadet for at least a year and disciplining nine others in the incidents.

title: Untangling the Chinese Puzzle
description: So now we know that people inside the White House knew about the possibility of Chinese Government political contributions for Congressional races in June 1996. President Clinton was told last month, which means that he has had several weeks to ponder the possibility that some of his aides knew months ago that China might be trying to funnel tainted contributions into American political campaigns. It would not have taken much of a leap to wonder if China was doing so through such personal friends of Mr. Clinton as John Huang, Johnny Chung and Charles Yah Lin Trie. These revelations from the White House press secretary make Mr. Clinton's no-problems attitude last Friday seem all the more detached from reality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUER, JOSEPH Q., REVEREND S.J.
description: LAUER-Joseph Q., Reverend S.J. Mar. 9, 1997. Dear uncle of Susan Lauer and Janet Micieli. Reposing at Loyola Hall Chapel at Fordham University, Bronx, Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Wed. 3-5 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wed. at 8 PM at the Fordham University Church, Bronx. For info: contact Farenga Brothers Inc. Directors

title: Man Charged and Motive Cited in Bayonne School Stabbings
description: A 20-year-old man was arrested today and charged with fatally stabbing a Bayonne High School student and seriously wounding another last week after a chance hallway encounter led to an argument over ''the way people were looking at and talking to each other,'' the authorities said.

title: No Headline
description: ''The finds are opening up a whole new world of real piracy that belies the stories. Pirates were nowhere near the monsters they were made out to be.''

title: Revenue Is as Predicted
description: Last spring, when the Whitman administration presented its budget for 1996-97, the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services warned that the budget relied on revenue projections that were about $250 million too optimistic. But yesterday, the Treasury Department said that the state had matched its estimates for the first eight months of the fiscal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENBERG, JACQUES
description: SCHOENBERG-Jacques. Beloved father of Harris, Irene and Caroline and Raymond. Loving grandfather of Daniel, Dahlia, William, James, Andrea and Steven. Esteemed President of the grandson of Okun and Board member of the Inwood Hebrew Congregation. Service on Tuesday at 1:30PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an Israeli Cabinet decision on a second phase of territorial concessions in the West Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to the change in status in part of the territory affected by the plan. Under the Israeli proposal, 2 percent of the West Bank that is still under Israeli control would be administered jointly with the Palestinian Authority; that 2 percent would not be under sole Palestinian control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, EMANUEL (MANNY)
description: LICHTENSTEIN-Emanuel (Manny), on March 8. Loving husband of Kaye and father of Joanna, both of whom predeceased him, grandfather of Emma Sheanshang and father-in-law of George. He will be missed by his nieces and nephews and their children for his generous nature and his humor. Interment private.

title: I'm a Hot Potato,' Says a Cuban Who Found a New Career (and Old Politics) in the U.S.
description: For a recent refugee, it was a fitting spot in which to remember the day her old life ended and her new one began: beside her own kidney-shaped pool in her own suburban backyard, surrounded by her makeup artist, her press agent, her pet rooster and hen.

title: MSG Plans to Woo Rizzuto
description: Where is the Scooter? Not on the MSG Network's Yankee announcer lineup. But Phil Rizzuto, who worked about 30 games last year on Channel 11, his 41st in the Yankee booth, will be entreated to enlist during a meeting tomorrow with MSG executives.

title: Revival of Chain Gangs Takes a Twist
description: In many of the nation's prisons, time behind bars is no longer punishment enough. Prodded by a vengeful public and alert politicians, jailers in some states have cut down on hot meals and visiting hours and taken away furloughs, exercise gear, racy magazines and cable television. They dress inmates in black and white stripes again, and a county in Arizona dyes the men's underwear pink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCHOWSKY, MARIE
description: MARCHOWSKY-Marie, beloved wife of the late Harry Swartz, M.D., died on March 8, 1997. Former outstanding early member and performer in Martha Graham's Dance Company. She was a dedicated teacher of the Graham technique, former director of dance at Cal Tech, Pasadena, Calif. She also organized her own dance group which toured in the USA, Europe and Canada. Annotations and discussions of Martha Graham's dances and her own are available at the Lincoln Center Performing Arts Library. Mrs. Marchowsky had been married to Milton Robertson. After her divorce years later, she married Harry Swartz, a noted allergist and medical writer. She is survived by her loving cousin, Rose Soifer, her husband, Hyman Soifer, M.D., and their daughter, Tina, as well as many loving friends. She will be missed by all for her unique personality, her talents, and her contributions to the arts. Private memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALL, PETER W.
description: BALL-Peter W. On March 8, 1997, of lymphoma. Born in Leicester, England, in 1921. Served in the Royal Navy (Fleet Air Arm) during W.W. II. Dedicated British Airways executive for 38 years, respected aviation/real estate consultant, enthusiastic world traveler and pilot. He will be remembered as the ''Perfect English Gentleman'' who always showed the utmost consideration and courtesy to everyone. He was the loving father to Katharine, Monica and Jennifer, whom he has left to join his only son Nicholas, who died in 1982. He also leaves 7 grandchildren in the UK and USA. Friends & family will be gathering for a mass at St. Agnes Church, on Saturday, March 22, at 2 PM (Chapel on 44th St between 3rd & Lex). No flowers please due to Lent. Memorial contributions may be sent to the St. Agnes Building Fund, 143 E. 43rd St, NYC 10017.

title: A Met Gets Lost Under the Lights
description: It remains a sad commentary on whatever it is that attracts attention in professional sports that Bernard Gilkey remains the most underappreciated athlete in New York.

title: Q&A
description: Swaying Buildings

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES is starting his week on more than one spiritual note. On Sunday, in a rare show of unity, he got together with his former wife, DIANA, the Princess of Wales, to attend the confirmation of their older son, PRINCE WILLIAM, 14, at St. George's Chapel in Windsor Castle.

title: Electronic Threats to Medical Privacy
description: Preserving privacy in the ever-expanding world of electronic medical records is a daunting task that health care organizations and public policy makers have been slow to address. But as managed care puts more information into more hands, consumer anxiety over confidentiality makes the issue unavoidable. While some states have enacted safeguards, there is a clear need for Federal rules that would apply to all states, particularly as more health information flows across state lines.

title: States Hit by Floods Turn to Threat of Disease
description: With water treatment plants throughout the Ohio River Valley overcome by floods, and raw sewage sent flowing downriver as a result, the authorities are growing concerned about the potential for disease across the waterlogged region.

title: Federal Judge Refuses to Dismiss Murder Convictions of 2 Mobsters
description: A judge refused yesterday to throw out the murder convictions of two Mafia figures whose lawyers had contended that prosecutors had withheld vital information about an F.B.I. agent's tangled relationship with an informer.

title: For Besieged Scientist, New Start in New Lab
description: As he exercises command from a splendid new battlement in medical science's slogging campaign against AIDS, Dr. Robert C. Gallo seems at least as resilient as his quarry.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VARTAN GREGORIAN, the president of Brown University, was presiding over a faculty meeting last week when WILLIAM WYATT, chairman of the executive committee, asked him to leave the room for a few minutes. ''I said, 'I hope this is not a vote of nonconfidence,' '' Mr. Gregorian said the other day. At any rate, he is leaving Brown at the end of June to become president of the Carnegie Corporation.

title: Jury-in-Blue Gambit Fails
description: Just because jurors dress alike, they do not necessarily think alike. That is essentially what a Superior Court judge ruled yesterday in rejecting a request for a mistrial in the death-penalty trial of a Teaneck man who killed his two children. Lawyers for Avi Kostner had asked for the mistrial yesterday after most of the jurors came to court dressed in blue, after having worn purple on Thursday and red on Friday. ''If the jury was in agreement on what color to wear, we were afraid they were surrendering their individual opinions about the case,'' said Cathy L. Waldor, a lawyer for Mr. Kostner. A death sentence must be unanimous. But jurors told Judge Jonathan Harris that the color coordination was merely a way to release tension, and the judge rejected the motion.

title: DI INDUSTRIES TO BUY GREY WOLF DRILLING FOR $102 MILLION
description: DI Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Grey Wolf Drilling Company for about $102 million in cash and stock. Grey Wolf, based in Houston, operates 18 land-based drilling rigs in the Gulf of Mexico area. DI Industries, also of Houston, provides land drilling services in the United States and South America. DI Industries said at least 45 percent of the purchase price would be in its stock. The stock closed yesterday at $2.8125, down 6.25 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLAHAN, MAVIS
description: HOLAHAN-Mavis, of Westhampton Beach on March 10, 1997. Wife of the late Edward C. Holahan, former president of Royal Bank of Canada, mother of the late Dr. Gordon Holahan. Survived by daughter-in-law Mary Holahan, 8 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Reposing Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Follet & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach. Mass of the Resurrection, Wednesday, 10 AM at the Church of the Immaculate Conception. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be directed to the Little Flower Childrens Services, Wading River, New York.

title: British Chemical Maker's Pretax Profit Is Up 12%
description: Laporte P.L.C., a British maker of specialty chemicals, reported yesterday that its pretax profit for 1996 had exceeded expectations. The pretax profit rose 12 percent, to a record $:127 million ($203 million), before exceptional items. Analysts said Laporte was reaping benefits from a reorganization program started in 1995 that is generating higher profit from its primary businesses, which include construction chemicals, polymers, pigments and absorbents. Laporte raised $:165 million before expenses last year from sales of businesses.

title: Utility Seeks to End Costly Pacts With Power Suppliers
description: In an effort to fend off financial collapse, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to spend about $4 billion to buy out costly long-term contracts with most of its independent power producers.

title: Shaking Up TV Serials As Audiences Dwindle
description: One season not too long ago, the creative team on the struggling soap opera ''As the World Turns'' planned a story line that called for a popular character to be shot on the Friday before Christmas. The maker of Tide detergent killed the idea before the villain could pull the trigger.

title: Sounding Like Old Pros and Young Cutups
description: That Gil and Orli Shaham have now teamed up on disk and in recital -- they're at the 92d Street Y tomorrow -- inevitably brings to mind the brother-sister duo of Yehudi and Hephzibah Menuhin, though in person they turn out to be more like Burns and Allen or Caesar and Coca, playing the Catskills instead of Carnegie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, JACQUES
description: RECANATI - Jacques. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the brother of its esteemed member, Mr. Raphael Recanati, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman William Schwartz, Pres.

title: INSIDE
description: F.T.C. Opposes Staples Deal

title: Merrill Lynch Chairman Made 40% More in '96
description: Need a raise? How about 40 percent? That's what Daniel P. Tully, Merrill Lynch & Company's top officer, received last year, as his pay leaped to more than $10 million, the value of financial securities soared, and the compensation of top Wall Street executives rose to record levels.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEPRIN, JACK.
description: WEPRIN-Jack. 1930-1996 A UNIQUE MAN. MY BELOVED FRIEND. Martin

title: Lawsuit in Police Shooting
description: The sister of a woman shot dead by a New Brunswick police officer filed a Federal civil rights suit yesterday against the officer, the Police Department and the City of New Brunswick. In November, a grand jury declined to indict the officer, James Consalvo, in the death of Carolyn Adams, 39, of New Brunswick. But in a suit that seeks unspecified damages, Ms. Adams's sister, Jacqueline Young, claims that Officer Consalvo violated Ms. Adams's civil rights when he shot her last September during a struggle that followed his attempt to arrest her on prostitution charges.

title: Nike's Knight Criticizes Adidas Deal
description: Saying baseball had ''screwed up'' by allowing the Yankees to make their own deal with Adidas, PHIL KNIGHT, the chairman of Nike, said his company would not rush out to sign teams. ''They have a ways to go to get their act together,'' Knight said of baseball teams last night, before the Jackie Robinson Foundation dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan.

title: Going From Serious To Lighter, Then Pop
description: Marcia Dale Weary and her Central Pennsylvania Youth Ballet have been much talked about but little seen in New York City. On Saturday afternoon Francis Patrelle presented this student group and two others in ''Young Performers' Matinee'' at Kaye Playhouse, where Dances Patrelle performs through Sunday. Ms. Weary's teen-age dancers more than lived up to their legend.

title: People
description: * Stephen G. Bowen was named to the new position of group account director at Merkley Newman Harty, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group. He had been president and chief executive at the Food Court Entertainment Network, Astoria, Queens.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Church of Scientology referred incorrectly in some editions to the settlement of a libel case brought by a Scientologist against Time magazine and Richard Behar, an investigative reporter. The settlement entailed the publication of a clarifying statement in Time, not a corrective paragraph.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, JEROME (JERRY)
description: HAHN-Jerome (Jerry). Devoted husband of Lynn (nee Lennon). Beloved father of Scott, Patti Pillinger, Haley Ferraro and Mitchell. Loving grandfather. Dear brother of Sidney and the late Bill. Fond cousin. Services were conducted and family will be observing shiva. For information, call Raccuglia and Son, 718-855-7737.

title: Archeologists Revise Portrait Of Buccaneers As Monsters
description: PIRATES are often pictured as inhuman devils, quick to maim and kill in pursuit of treasure. They fired broadsides into hapless merchant ships, sent captives down the plank and took grim pleasure in torturing victims and even one another. Blackbeard was said to discipline his crew with his bare fists and to have forced one prisoner to eat his own ears.

title: Welfare Plan Is Approved
description: Governor Whitman's welfare program received final approval from the State Senate yesterday and now heads back to the Governor for her signature. The Senate approved minor amendments to the plan, which allows municipalities to continue running local welfare offices. The program imposes a five-year limit on cash benefits and a two-year deadline to find a job but also offers incentives to ease the transition into the workplace. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Yankees And Jeter Reach Agreement
description: The discrepancy was over a mere $65,000. And that, perhaps, is why the Yankees, one day before they were planning to renew Derek Jeter's contract at their own figure, decided that they would rather reach a friendly agreement with their second-year shortstop. They came to terms for $540,000, plus bonuses.

title: Soybean Prices Are Highest Since 1988 on Supply Worries
description: Soybean prices soared yesterday to their highest point in eight and a half years on expectations that the Government will report today that United States reserves will be pushed below the seriously depleted level that was forecast last month.

title: Russian Wives Learn What Money Can't Buy
description: In the elegant Estee Lauder Beauty Center on the sumptuous grounds of the Moscow Country Club, wealthy women fill empty lives with facials, massage and the kindness of beauticians.

title: Bronx Jury Finds Hospital Is Liable In Baby Case
description: A Bronx jury has found that Lincoln Hospital botched the delivery of a baby girl in 1988, causing lifelong brain damage and cerebral palsy, and it ordered New York City's hospital agency to pay the child $9.45 million.

title: Life Insurance Settlement
description: A Federal judge approved a case-by-case class-action settlement between the Prudential Insurance Company of America and up to eight million customers who were sold life insurance policies they did not need, The Associated Press reported yesterday. An accounting firm has said the settlement could cost Prudential, the nation's largest life insurer, up to $2 billion. Policyholders have until June 1 to file for compensation. The class-action suit stemmed from charges that Prudential agents persuaded customers to use the built-up cash value of older life insurance policies to finance more expensive ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKO, GUSTAVE
description: BERKO-Gustave. Beloved father of Pauline and Sol, Paul and Lorraine, Jerome and Honie. Adored grandfather of Ellen, Iris, David, Alan, Danny, Mitchel, Karen and Amy, and cherished great grandfather. Funeral service Tuesday, March 11th, 12 Noon, Riverside, 312 Coney Island Ave, Bklyn.

title: G.M. Announces Two Steps to Streamline Its Operations
description: The General Motors Corporation announced two steps today to streamline its sprawling operations, putting all North American car making activities under a single executive and assigning the man who built G.M.'s Saturn division to develop standard management and engineering practices across the company.

title: German Coal Miners Protest Subsidy Cuts
description: With a cavalcade of motorcycles and egg-throwing protests at political party offices, restive German coal miners besieged the center of Government in Bonn for several hours today to register opposition to proposed cuts in coal industry subsidies.

title: LESLIE FAY AND BDO SEIDMAN TO SETTLE SHAREHOLDER SUIT
description: Officials of the Leslie Fay Companies and BDO Seidman, the company's former accountant, agreed yesterday to settle a class-action shareholder lawsuit for $34.7 million. Leslie Fay shareholders contended that the officials had intentionally misstated the company's financial results, and that BDO Seidman was ''reckless'' in its audit of the company's 1990 and 1991 financial reports. Leslie Fay, a women's apparel maker, filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors in 1993. The Leslie Fay defendants will pay $26.7 million, and BDO will pay $8 million. People who bought Leslie Fay shares from March 28, 1991 to April 5, 1993 are eligible to share in the settlement.

title: Guide to Fashion Business
description: The Fashion Center Business Improvement District has released a ''Fashion Center Black Book,'' a 300-page guide to more than 5,000 contractors, fashion show producers and other fashion-related firms in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOHLNER, ESTHER
description: WOHLNER-Esther. Beloved wife of the late David. Cherished mother of Grace and Steve, Ellis and Joan. Grandmother of Lawrence, Janet, Bradford and Derek. Great grandmother of Lee, Eric, Samantha, Rachel and Jared. Contributions to Hadassah appreciated. Services Today, Noon, Wien & Wien, 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ

title: U.S. TRANSPORTATION TO ACQUIRE PRECEPT INVESTORS
description: U.S. Transportation Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Precept Investors Inc. for stock valued about $135 million. Precept, based in Dallas, provides limousine and package delivery services and also distributes business forms. The company posted 1996 sales of more than $111 million. U.S. Transportation, of Elmsford, N.Y., said the combined company would have annual revenues of about $150 million. U.S. Transportation will issue 36 million common shares in the transaction. Its stock was up 25 cents, to $4 a share on the Nasdaq market. U.S. Transportation provides passenger bus transportation, a tractor-trailer service and air freight delivery.

title: Democrats Mourn Fink And a Lack Of Prospects
description: The aisles were crammed at Stanley Fink's funeral on the Upper West Side of Manhattan last week, and the hundreds of politicians and their associates -- Democrats, mostly -- who could not fit into the main chapel spilled out into the hall outside, the balcony upstairs and the holding room downstairs.

title: Army Joins Its First Conference (USA)
description: The United States Military Academy announced yesterday that it would part with tradition and join Conference USA, its first football affiliation, in the fall of 1998.

title: A Woman In Its Ranks, The Band Plays On
description: After the politics, there is the music. Women's groups provided the first last week; in three concerts at Carnegie Hall over the weekend, the Vienna Philharmonic gave us the second. Beforehand, music was turned into a peripheral event. Emphatic calls from American and international women's groups had demanded that the Vienna Philharmonic end its all-male ways; and, in what may or not be a capitulation, the orchestra put a longtime harpist on its payroll and announced open auditions in the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, ELLEN
description: GARDNER-Ellen. Of Larchmont, New York. On March 9th, 1997, in Scripps Memorial Hospital, La Jolla, Calif. Daughter of the late William Ehrlich and Evelyn Seltzer of Brookline, Mass. Survived by husband Melvin Gardner, brother Tom Ehrlich, daughters: Janet Krones, Gail Gardner, Emily Bernstein, and Diane Gardner. Also survived by grandchildren: Sarah, Jonathan, Ariella and Jeremy Krones. Service Tuesday, March 11 at 1PM, Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Family will sit Shiva through Friday, March 14 at 10 Woods Way, Larchmont, NY. Memorial contributions in lieu of flowers, Manor Park Society, P.O. Box 2, Larchmont, New York 10538.

title: Nothing 'Foreign' About Us
description: Reacting to the controversy over fund-raising from so-called foreign sources, the Democratic National Committee has decided to stop accepting political contributions from American subsidiaries of companies based abroad and from groups of their American employees.

title: Prices Decline Ahead of Data On Economy
description: Prices of Government securities slipped yesterday, with few investors willing to buy ahead of economic data to be reported this week, for fear that if the news is too robust, the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to avert inflation.

title: CASTORAMA TO BUY RENO-DEPOT AFTER HOME DEPOT PASSES
description: The Molson Companies and the Michaud family of Montreal said yesterday that they would sell Reno-Depot Inc. to Castorama S.A. of France for $147 million (Canadian), or $107 million (United States), after Home Depot Inc. declined an offer to buy the chain. Home Depot, based in Atlanta, was weighing an option to buy Reno-Depot, a retailer of home-improvement products in Quebec. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HETSKO, CYRIL F.
description: HETSKO-Cyril F., 85, retired Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Director of American Brands, Inc., died Saturday, March 1, of complications of pneumonia at The Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, NJ. Mr. Hetsko was instrumental in the diversification during the 1960's and 1970's of The American Tobacco Company into what became American Brands, Inc., a broad based international consumer products company. Prior to joining The American Tobacco Company, Mr. Hetsko was a partner in the New York law firm of Chadbourne, & Parke. Mr. Hetsko was President of the United States Trademark Association (now International Trademark Association) in 1965 and 1966. Mr. Hetsko was a key member of the management team leading the transformation of American Tobacco into American Brands with the acquisition of companies such as Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., DuffyMott Company, Inc., James B. Beam Distilling Co., Master Lock Company, Andrew Jergens Company, Swingline, Inc., Acushnet Company, Wilson Jones Company, Acme Visible Records, Inc., & Gallaher Ltd. (United Kingdom). Mr. Hetsko served on the Boards of Directors of these companies subsequent to their acquisition. Mr Hetsko was born October 4, 1911, in Scranton, PA., and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Dickinson College in 1933. He graduated from the University of Michigan Law School in 1936 where he was a member of the Order of the Coif. Immediately after receiving his law degree, Mr. Hetsko joined the New York law firm then known as Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolff, becoming a partner in 1955. In 1964, he resigned his partnership to join The American Tobacco Company as General Counsel, and was named Vice President and elected to the Board of Directors in January of 1965. Mr. Hetsko was a member of the New York, Pennsylvania and Federal Bars, including The Supreme Court of the United States. He was a member of the American Bar Association and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. For over 15 years, he served as a member of the Board of Directors of the United States Trademark Association. He also served as its President and Executive Vice President in the mid 1960's. Mr. Hetsko was involved in a number of community activities in Ridgewood, NJ, where he and his wife resided for over 40 years, including Boy Scouts, the Session of West Side Presbyterian Church, and the Ridgewood High School Jamboree, which he co-produced in 1960. Mr. Hetsko was a member of the Hobbyists Unlimited Club of Ridgewood and of The Explorers Club of New York City. He and his wife traveled extensively to remote areas of the world, and lectured on their experiences in Bhutan, Tibet, China, Ladakh and Mongolia. Mr. Hetsko is survived by his wife of sixty-five years, Josephine Stein Hetsko; two daughters, Jacqueline Kaufer of Ridgewood, NJ, and Cynthia Rainey of Lawrence, KS; two sons, Cyril M. Hetsko, M.D. of Madison, WI, and Jeffrey F. Hetsko, Esq., of Atlanta, GA; a brother, Richard Hetsko of Middlefield, CT; and five grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANGER, PERCY
description: GRANGER - Percy. Playwright, screenwriter and actor, 51, died Tues, March 10, of cardiac arrest. He was the son of Dr. Bruce Granger, retired professor of English at the University of Oklahoma, and Rosemary Ingham, painter. He graduated from Harvard University magna cum laude in 1967. He began his playwrighting career at the Provincetown Playhouse with ''The Complete Works of Studs Edsel,'' which was later produced at the Folger Shakespeare Theatre Company, Washington, DC and then at the Ensemble Studio Theatre in NYC. His play, ''Eminent Domain,'' was selected for The National Playwrights Conference at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre Center in 1977 and then on Broadway at Circle in the Square in 1982. He wrote for Radio Mystery Theatre, was one of the creators of ''Loving,'' the daytime soap, and for ''As The World Turns.'' His screenwriting credits include ''My Brother's Wife'' and ''The Comeback.'' His play ''Vivian'' premiered at the Ensemble Studio Theatre, then at The Vivian Beaumont Theatre at Lincoln Center. ''Dolphin Position'' premiered at the Ensemble Studio Theatre and then an expanded version was performed at East Coast Arts and Primary Stages in NYC. ''Scheherazade'' premiered at the Ensemble as well and was subsequently produced in Los Angeles. He was one of the founding members of the Ensemble Studio Theatre, where several of his other plays were premiered. His last finished play, ''Coyote Hangin on a Barbed Wire Fence,'' was also selected for the National Playwrights Conference in 1990. It was to premiere on Broadway at Circle in the Square in spring of '93 but Percy suffered a cardiac arrest Sept. 8, 1992, which left him unable to continue his life work. His acting career spanned thirty years. He played Verlaine in the North American premiere of ''Rimbaud'' and performed numerous other roles. He was an avid sports enthusiast and played rugby with the New York Rugby Club. He taught playwrighting at the 52nd St Project and worked in the St. Ignatius Soup Kitchen. From the time of his initial heart attack until his death, Percy often visited the Option Institute in Sheffield, MA who taught his family and volunteers to run a stimulation and education program designed for him. He is survived by his wife, MariElena Granger, and his sons, Andrew and James. A memorial service will be held at the St. Ignatius Episcopal Church, 552 West End Avenue at 1 PM on Thurs, March 13. In lieu of flowers the family requests that a donation be made in his name to the Option Institute and Fellowship, 2080 S. Undermountain Rd, Sheffield, MA 01257.

title: CHAIN TO SHUT FALTERING RED LOBSTER OUTLETS
description: Darden Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it would close 36 Red Lobster and Olive Garden restaurants, an expense that is expected to lower fourth-quarter profits by $230 million. The casual dining chain, which is based in Orlando, Fla., earned $15.7 million, or 10 cents a share, for the third quarter ended Feb. 23. The results were a penny below analysts' expectations. In the similar period a year earlier, Darden earned $35.6 million, or 22 cents a share. The closings are expected to add $15 million to $20 million to future earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, the company said. Darden has been struggling for the last year to reverse declines in profits at its Red Lobster chain, which has 674 restaurants in the United States.

title: Tenor Is Back at the Met After a Rewarding if Rocky Exile
description: In the early 1980's, Neil Shicoff was the great tenor hope of American opera. Then, in 1990, his American career came to an abrupt halt. His first marriage was ending in divorce, and the negotiations turned so contentious that remaining in this country would have meant facing possible legal action, so he took refuge in Europe. Work abroad was plentiful -- even rewarding -- but for this native New Yorker, the son of a Brooklyn cantor, staying away was painful. Recently, he and his ex-wife, the singer Judith Haddon, reached a final settlement. So, for the first time in seven years, Mr. Shicoff, who now lives in Zurich, has returned to New York. Tomorrow night, when the Met presents its new production of Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin,'' the 47-year-old tenor will sing the role of Lenski, which he sang in the previous production with great success. Then on May 9 he will join the bass-baritone Bryn Terfel for a Gala Pension Fund Concert.

title: 360 COMMUNICATIONS WARNS OF BLOWS TO RESULTS

It said losses from theft of cell-phone numbers and other fraud were expected to average about $3 million a month more than in the past. The cellular provider, based in Chicago, also expects a change in its pricing to reduce first-quarter revenue by as much as $5 million, or less than 2 percent of fourth-quarter sales. The outlook comes two months after fourth-quarter earnings failed to meet analysts' expectations because of fraud losses and an earnings shortfall from some units. The company was spun off from the Sprint Corporation a year ago.

title: Beethoven With the Storms Understated
description: Vladimir Ashkenazy's recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday was decent, good-natured and even-tempered. In the first half, he offered two sonatas from Beethoven's Opus 31, the G major and the D minor, and seemed not concerned to point up any contrasts of spirit. His playing was fluent, except for one or two awkwardnesses in the fast runs of the G major's first movement, and modest. He didn't want to tell us anything about Beethoven we didn't already know, and the storms of the D minor sonata were notably underplayed. Rhythms were precise, at the risk of blandness. Dynamic extremes were modulated so as to do no serious harm. Phrasing was clear and articulate, but so as to convey the minimum of personality.

title: Wine Talk

Wascana said Talisman's offer was inadequate. Shares of Wascana rose 15 cents, to $19.10, on the Montreal Stock Exchange, while shares of Talisman, which is based in Calgary, fell 35 cents, to $43.90, on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: More Light, Students Demand

The lamps caused four fires earlier in the school year, and the university decided last month to banish them from dormitories beginning next fall. Jostens, which makes yearbooks, class rings and other products, said the move would eliminate about 200 jobs in Porterville but create the same number in Shelbyville. About 35 percent of the Porterville workers have been transferred to Tennessee. The remaining workers in Porterville will be offered severance and outplacement services, the company said. Jostens, based in Minneapolis, expects costs related to the move to reduce its first-quarter earnings by $3 million.

A man of extraordinary humility and a sense of selfeffacement and modesty, Dr. Guterman worked closely with his dear friend, our former president, Dr. Solomon Simonson, in seeking to improve inter-group relations through exposition of cultural contributions of the Jewish people to humanity. We extend deep condolences to his beloved wife Bette & his devoted family, sister Hazel and his brother Abe. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Hana Simonson, President. American Jewish Museum of Art and Culture

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAULDING, CHARLES
description: FAULDING-Charles. The 100,000member Transport Workers Union of America mourns the passing of our retired Secretary Treasurer on March 9, 1997 after a brief illness at Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 81. He had retired in February 1991 after a distinguished 48-year career as a member and officer of TWU's flagship Local 100 in New York City and the national TWU of America. In 1980, as Secretary Treasurer of the 35,000-member Local 100, Mr. Faulding played a key role in the 11-day New York City transit strike. Despite his retirement from TWU, Mr. Faulding remained 1st Vice President of the New York City Central Labor Council's Black Trade Union Leadership Committee; an officer of the Municipal Credit Union; a member of One Hundred Black Men, a life member of the NAACP, and was founder of the Senior Citizens Garden Club in Roy Wilkins Park, Queens. During his nearly five decades as a union officer for TWU, Mr. Faulding held almost every elected position in Local 100, except President, including 26 years of service as Shop Steward, Vice Chairman and Chairman of the Local's United Motormen's Division. Born in Spotsylvania County, Virginia, in 1916, he came to New York at the age of 11. He became involved in the union movement for transit workers when he became a Trolley Motorman. He joined Local 100, and soon after was selected Shop Steward and immediately became a solidifying force. Mr. Faulding joined the national union's staff in 1985 as Secretary Treasurer, a position he held until his retirement. He is a charter member and former President of the BMT Surface Operators Club which was founded in 1943 when minorities were first hired into New York Surface transportation. Our deepest condolences to his son George, five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Friends may pay their respects at J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, 179-24 Linden Blvd, Jamaica, NY Friday, March 14, 1997. Funeral Services Saturday 9 AM, Trinity Lutheran Church of Locust Manor, 121-02 Merril St, Jamaica, NY. title: U.S. Agency Secretly Monitored Chinese in '96 on Political Gifts
description: A Federal investigation into whether the Chinese Government had a concerted plan to influence American officeholders began early last year when the National Security Agency surreptitiously monitored a series of communications between Beijing and Chinese officials in the United States, law-enforcement representatives said today.

title: MFS EMERGING GROWTH FUND BUYING NEW USA FUND
description: MFS Investment Management said yesterday that its Emerging Growth Fund was acquiring the assets of the $200 million New USA Growth Fund, created by William O'Neil, the founder of Investor's Business Daily. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. MFS, which is based in Boston and oversees about $54 billion in assets, has bought individual mutual funds in the past. The assets of the New USA Growth Fund will be merged with the $7 billion MFS Emerging Growth Fund, Mr. O'Neil said. The merger proposal still needs approval from fund shareholders and the receipt of legal opinions confirming that the transaction will be tax free, Mr. O'Neil said.

title: Warnings on Toys Are Often Ignored, Causing Injuries
description: OVER the past few months, reports of defects in children's toys and equipment have left parents to wonder: Are the incidents an aberration, or a signal that the 90's nursery is unsafe?

title: Perils of Free Air Time
description: It's a Thursday night in the year 2000, and you've flipped on the tube to catch your favorite new comedy about a gaggle of zany pals chasing romance and their dreams through the canyons of the Big Apple.

title: A Bargain on the Yellowstone Mine
description: President Clinton's announcement last August that a Canadian company had agreed to abandon plans for a huge gold mine that threatened Yellowstone National Park brought an audible sigh of relief among all Americans who cared about the sanctity of the country's first and foremost national park. But there were two loose ends that needed to be tied up. The first was to find some way to compensate the company and its stockholders for property that was legally theirs. The second was to win Congressional approval of the deal.

title: Accused of Delays, Oxford H.M.O. Agrees to Pay Doctors Faster
description: After complaints about late payments to doctors, Oxford Health Plans, the state's largest health maintenance organization, has agreed to pay physicians' claims within 30 days, New York State's Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: SAPERSTEIN - Abraham. On March 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Rose; loving father of Carol and Allan; grandfather of three. He will be missed by all.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: But This Time, Developers Are Keeping Things Simple
description: They're back. The nation's real estate developers, after their crazed overbuilding in the 1980's helped ruin hundreds of banks and savings and loans, are starting to put up speculative office buildings again, breaking ground before they know who will fill most of their floors.

title: Can Plants Be Happy With Cars?
description: HIDEAKI ARIIZUMI and Glynis Berry, husband and wife architects, wanted a greenhouse and a garage when they built their country house in Orient, L.I. In an unusual pairing, the greenhouse and garage became one.

title: Agency Says J.F.K. Rail Plan Is Ready, but Mayor Balks
description: The Port Authority said yesterday that it expected construction to start this summer on a project considered among New York City's most pressing transportation needs: a rail connection to Kennedy International Airport.

title: A museum markets endangered species to a mass audience
description: THE subject: a museum exhibition on endangered species. The problem: how do you design an advertising campaign to attract visitors?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FANTEL, RHODA GAIL (NEE MANDELBAUM)
description: FANTEL-Rhoda Gail (nee Mandelbaum). Died Mar. 11, 1997. Beloved wife of Spencer, mother of Ann Dee, Linda, Ronnie and Rosemary. Grandmother of Robyn, Karyn, Deborah, Toby, Randy, David, Peter, Matthew and Rochele. Services Mt. Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to be made to the American Heart Association & Diabetes Foundation.

title: Peruvian Hostage Talks Resume, Then Collapse
description: Talks to bring a peaceful end to the hostage crisis here broke down today with both sides saying they had failed to reach agreement on important points.

title: We Already Have a Superport
description: In all the discussion about New York City's proposal to build a rail freight tunnel to New Jersey and a superport in Brooklyn, one issue seems to have been overlooked: Whether the shipping industry believes the project is feasible or even necessary.

title: For Bar Mitzvahs, A Revival of Spirit
description: IN the months before Shira Rockowitz's bas mitzvah, she and her parents gave a lot of thought to the best way to celebrate her coming of age. ''Shira was against disco bas mitzvahs,'' said Noah Rockowitz, her father. ''We felt an active good deed would appeal to her.''

description: Cornelian Cherry

title: HUGHES ELECTRONICS BUYS LANGUAGE TRAINING CONCERN
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Door Training International to better serve international training clients and expand its Hughes Training Inc. unit. Terms were not disclosed. Door Training, based in Paris, specializes in local-language training in sales, marketing and customer service for the automotive, insurance, financial and other industries. It has 200 employees and franchises in Europe, Asia, the Middle East and Africa. Hughes Training plans to expand the closely held Door Training in the next 18 months, Hughes Training's president, Stuart Moore, said in a statement. Hughes Training, based in Arlington, Tex., has 4,100 employees. Hughes Electronics is based in Los Angeles and is a unit of the General Motors Corporation. G.M. class H shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $57.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELLINGER, JOHN J., M.D.
description: ZELLINGER-John J., M.D. The Board of Governors and Administration of Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester mourn, with deep sorrow, the passing of Dr. John Zellinger. Dr. Zellinger served the Medical Center, with distinction, for 49 years. His surgical skills, compassion and devotion to his patients were recognized & admired by all who were fortunate to know him. His leadership in Medical Center Commitees enhanced patient care services and his visionary efforts in establishing the hospital-wide Disaster Plan continue to be appreciated. A talented surgeon, dedicated physician and astute innovator, Dr. Zellinger will be missed by his former patients, Medical Center colleagues and friends and all who were fortunate to know him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife jean and children Mary, Martha, Peter, Elizabeth, Katherine, Thomas and James. Frederic B. Powers, Jr. Chairman, Board of Governors John R. Spicer, President & CEO, Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester

title: Col. John Boyd Is Dead at 70; Advanced Air Combat Tactics
description: Col. John R. Boyd, a legendary Air Force fighter pilot whose discovery that quicker is better than faster became the basis of a far-reaching theory that helped revolutionize American military strategy, died on March 9 at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 70 and had lived in Delray Beach.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Dow Average to Replace 4 Stocks To Better Reflect the U.S. Economy
description: Dow Jones & Company announced yesterday that it would replace 4 of the 30 stocks in the closely watched Dow Jones industrial average -- the first change in the index in nearly six years.

title: 'Fed Up' With Criticism, Netanyahu Lashes Out
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared today that he was ''fed up'' with accusations that everything he did violated the Israeli-Palestinian peace accords. Even more criticism is expected this weekend at an international meeting on peace issues being convened by the Palestinians in Gaza to which Israel was not invited.

title: Assembly Plan Has 50% Rise In School Aid
description: The Democratic leaders of the Assembly, staking out education as their top priority this year, proposed today to increase school spending by more than 50 percent over five years, including money to make preschool available for all 4-year-olds statewide and a $2 billion bond act for school construction.

title: When a Healer Is Asked, 'Help Me Die'
description: Two months ago, Dr. Joel Potash made his monthly house call on an elderly man who had spent a year confined to bed, wasting away from kidney cancer that had spread to his bones. Dr. Potash was about to discuss the futility of further treatment, when the patient startled him with another suggestion:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, BLANCHE SILVER
description: WOLFF-Blanche Silver. A great lady. Wife and soulmate of Lester Wolff; loving mother of Diane and Bruce; caring grandmother of Sonya, Maeve, Michael and Scott; and adoring great-grandmother of Amanda. The guiding light for her entire family, whose passing brings great sorrow. Services on Friday, 10AM at Temple Emanuel, Hicks Lane, Great Neck.

title: Irabu of Japan Inching Nearer To the Yankees
description: The Irabu affair continued without resolution today, a development that prompted the head of the players association to suggest that legal action could loom.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: KENNEDY AIRPORT RAIL PLAN -- The Port Authority says it will go ahead with a plan to build a rail connection to Kennedy Airport, but the Giuliani administration may stand in its way. Metro Business, B7.

title: Adelphi Sues Ex-President Over Demand For Payments
description: Adelphi University's new trustees moved in court today to block the demands of the school's deposed president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, for millions of dollars in compensation and ownership of a Manhattan condominium.

title: 2 Brokerages In Insurance To Join Forces
description: Two giant New York insurance brokerages that began doing business more than a century ago, the Marsh & McLennan Companies and Johnson & Higgins, announced yesterday that they were merging. The $1.8 billion deal will make the combined company the world's largest insurance broker.

title: Fed Survey Says Higher Pay Mostly Eludes Workers
description: Despite a persistently low unemployment rate, American workers have generally been unable to win significantly higher pay, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of economic conditions suggested today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEAN, COL. GORDON WILLIAM
description: McKEAN-Col. Gordon William. U.S. Army Ret. 88, February 18, 1997. He received his BA and MS from CCNY and an LL.B. from Fordham University. He was a partner in the NY law firm of McLaughlin, Stickles, McKean & Hayden, and later general counsel & executive VP of Grolier, Inc. Col. McKean also served in the U.S. Horse Cavalry; in the North African and Italian campaigns in World War II, and in the Army Active Reserves. He was awarded the Legion of Merit, the Papal Medallion and the Royal Crown of Italy, Grade of Cavalier. He married Eleanora Krausz who survives him with their children: Janet Lyon Behre, Joyce Weaver, Gordon A., Leonore E. and John P. McKean. A Memorial Service will be held 1:00 PM, Sunday, March 16, at the Bay Shore Yacht Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKO, GUSTAVE
description: BERKO-Gustave. Very sincere condolences to Jerry Berko and his family on their terrible loss. We all hope for happier days to come. The Schwalbe Family

title: Congress Seeks Ways to Chastise Mexico on Drugs
description: Bending to Clinton Administration pressure, Congress began struggling today for a way to criticize Mexico over its lapses in fighting drugs without disrupting the Mexican economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, BARRY
description: BENJAMIN - Barry. Beloved friend. We will miss him.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Gov. GEORGE W. BUSH of Texas isn't running for anything just now. He's on crutches, following arthroscopic surgery on his left knee yesterday at the Columbia Bailey Square Surgery Center in Austin to repair cartilage he damaged while jogging.

title: Bronx Man Is Arrested In Death of a Bellhop
description: A Bronx man was arrested yesterday and accused of firing a stray bullet that killed a 50-year-old bellhop during a gun battle at a Times Square hotel in December, the police said.

title: PACIFICORP TO ACQUIRE NATURAL GAS COMPANY
description: Pacificorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the TPC Corporation, a natural gas company based in Houston, for $288 million, or $13.41 a share, plus $147 million in assumed debt. The acquisition is the latest in a string by the utility, which is based in Portland, Ore., as it seeks to become a major energy-services company in preparation for utility deregulation. TPC, formerly the Tejas Power Corporation, has focused its business on gas transportation and marketing. It reported revenue of $617 million in 1996. TPC stock rose $2, or 18 percent, to $13.125 a share, while Pacificorp shares were unchanged at $20.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, MARGARET M.
description: O'BRIEN-Margaret M. Passed away after brief illness on March 12, 1997. Daughter of the late William C. and Margaret Tully O'Brien and sister of the late John P., she is survived by Jeanne P. O'Brien of Tampa and Msgr. William B. O'Brien of New York. A long-time Scarsdale resident, she pioneered early childhood education, after receiving a Masters in Education at Columbia University, at renowned Children's Corner Nursery School in Scarsdale. Viewing at Bennett Funeral Home in Scarsdale, Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Resurrection on Saturday morning at 11 AM at Our Lady of Fatima Church in Scarsdale.

title: On-Line Ads Grew In '96, Survey Says
description: On-line advertising in the United States, as expected, grew substantially last year, according to an annual survey by Jupiter Communications, a New York company specializing in on-line research.

title: Bridge
description: There were four nail-bitingly close finishes in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championships here Tuesday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. In one of them, the defending champions, led by Zia Mahmood of Manhattan, trailed by 8 imps against Walter Schafer of Bloomingdale, Ill., and his team, but pulled out a 12-imp win.

title: Tiffany Lamps: Back to the Old Neighborhood
description: SOME Tiffany lamps are coming home to glow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCAS, ELIZABETH ZIEGLER
description: LUCAS-Elizabeth Ziegler, of Noroton, CT., on March 11, 1997. Mother of Melinda Pierson Page. Sister of Barbara Ziegler, Helen Ziegler Steinkraus and William Ziegler III. Grandmother of three and great grandmother of one. Memorial services will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT., on Saturday, March 15, 1997, at 11:00 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Post 53-Ambulance, PO Box 2066, Darien, CT. 06820 or Person to Person, Box 3128, Darien, CT. 06820.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, LEONARD
description: ALDRICH-Leonard. Unexpectedly on March 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Mimi. Devoted father of Patricia Still and Ellen Schorr. Adoring grandfather of Yael Meisler, Adam Schorr and Andrew Still.
