description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * David Carlick, executive vice president for interactive business development at Poppe Tyson Inc., Mountain View, Calif., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, resigned to join a start-up company, Power Agent Inc., San Diego and San Mateo, Calif. His successor at Poppe Tyson was not named. Mr. Carlick will remain on the Poppe Tyson board and consult for that agency.

title: Cyberspace offers instant reaction to a magazine cover.
description: IMAGINE you are the editor of a new shelter magazine still in the test-market stages. It is time to choose a cover, but there is a problem: your magazine's title includes the name of a middle-aged man known for his home-improvement expertise. But men rarely grace shelter-magazine covers, and you need to attract newsstand customers, particularly women. What should you put on the cover?

title: No Missile on Radar Tape, T.W.A. Crash Investigator Says
description: The radar tape that Federal agents confiscated from a retired airline pilot who cited it as proof that Trans World Airlines Flight 800 was hit by a missile contains radar signatures of the T.W.A. jet and other planes, but no missile, a Federal law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: 4 Charged in Nynex Theft
description: A Nynex manager and three others were charged yesterday with stealing $2 million from the company in a scheme that paid dummy companies for services.

title: Stockton Steals the Show From Under the Nets' Noses
description: Tonight's performance was the kind that makes John Stockton a great player.

title: Loved and Lorn in a Triangle of Four Sides
description: Don Quixote, who loved to read about the exploits of Amadis of Gaul, might have been perplexed and disappointed by the showing his hero makes in the Handel opera on the subject, ''Amadigi di Gaula.'' One can imagine him tapping Sancho Panza on the shoulder, or more likely kicking his squire awake, and traipsing sadly out to resume his own enterprises. Not that there are many windmills these days in Brooklyn, where ''Amadigi'' is being presented at the Academy of Music's Majestic Theater.

title: Congress Uses Leadership PAC's to Wield Power
description: During the 1996 election campaign, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, took in $1.7 million from corporate lobbyists and handed out $1.3 million of it to other Republicans running for the House and the Senate.

title: Nine Charged in Mob Inquiry That Led to Official's Arrest
description: The State Attorney General announced the arrests today of nine people he described as associates of the Genovese organized crime family, including Anthony J. Rizzo, who was overheard on a wiretap last year boasting that he wielded influence over the chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, CONSTANCE D
description: GIBSON - Constance D. The Trustees of Gramercy Park regret the passing of their Honorary Chairman, Constance D. Gibson on March 10, 1997. Mrs. Gibson was elected a Trustee of the Park in 1964 and served as Chairman from 1980 until 1992. Her wisdom and charm will be missed. Funeral service will be held today 12noon at St. George's Episcopal Church, Rutherford Place at E. 16 St.

title: Long Bond's Price Falls On Rate Fears
description: Prices of Treasury securities were flat to lower yesterday, as investors continued to be cautious for fear that new economic data could prove unduly strong, leading the Fed to raise short-term interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIGMAN, CHAIM
description: STEIGMAN-Chaim. The National Officers of EMUNAH of America mourn the passing of Chaim Steigman, beloved brother of our esteemed friend and benefactor, Jonas Steigman and brother-in-law of our dedicated Officer Gisela Steigman. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family. Dr. Rosalie Reich National President

title: Swim, Sink or Get Out of the Way
description: During the Hebron negotiations, one of the key demands of Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel's Likud Party Prime Minister, was that the Palestinians draw up a new charter that would explicitly define their relationship with Israel. But it's not only Yasir Arafat who needs a new charter. Mr. Netanyahu needs one too, because too many people don't know where he's heading. How can you get behind him, they ask, when you don't know where his front is?

title: Toys 'R' Us Says Earnings Rose; Woolworth Reverses Earlier Loss
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said yesterday that its fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings increased more than fourfold, reflecting both a multimillion-dollar charge in the quarter and a much larger restructuring charge in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: N.F.L. Owners Say No To Replay
description: Instant replay will not be used this season in the National Football League. The owners voted, 20-10, for replay today, falling three votes short of the number required for passage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSON, MAURY
description: HANSON-Maury, on Monday, March 10, peacefully at age 89, in Naples, Florida. Beloved husband of 57 years to Margaret Hixon Hanson, loving father of Robert Hixon Hanson of Cody, WY, Michael Francis Hanson II of Bonita Springs, FL, and Barbara Hanson Pierce of New York City and Salt Point, NY; adoring grandfather of seven. A resident of Greenwich, CT. for 50 years, he founded The Nutmegger Magazine of Connecticut in 1968, which he published in Greenwich until his retirement in 1989. Yale, his major interest, awarded him the Yale Medal for distinguished service. He served as secretary of the Class of 1930 for 65 years. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 15, at 11 AM at St. Michael's Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Yale Alumni Fund, New Haven, CT. 06508.

title: Knicks Showing a Soft Side Against the Weaker Teams
description: It is hard being No. 2, the Knicks have found. Everybody except Michael Jordan is gunning for you. You beat Chicago, become enamored of yourself and forget about where you came from and what made you nearly reach the pinnacle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, JAMES MILTON, M.D.
description: BELL-James Milton, M.D., L.F.A.P.A., F.A.C.P., Col. USA (Ret.), of Canaan and Croton-onHudson, NY. The Board of Directors, staff, children and families of Berkshire Farm Center & Services for Youth mourn the tragic loss of our esteemed and cherished colleague, friend and inspiration. Throughout his long and distinguished career, Dr. Bell was known for his extraordinary ability to reach even the most troubled children and for his dedication to excellence in the field of child and adolescent psychiatry. We are joined in sadness by Dr. Bell's family, and by the many individuals across the country and around the world whose lives were touched by this great man. Charles H. Mott, President, Board of Directors Rose W. Washington, Executive Director

title: Lawsuit Over Tunnel Project
description: Three Middlesex County mayors sued yesterday to block the state from spending $220 million to help build a tunnel and road to serve Stephen A. Wynn's planned Mirage resort in Atlantic City. In an injunction request filed in Superior Court in Middlesex County, Daniel J. Gallagher of South Plainfield, James M. Cahill of New Brunswick and H. James Polos of Highland Park contend that Mirage should pay for the project and that public transportation money should be spread around the state.

title: A brisk guide to Buckingham Palace, corgis, dorgis and all.
description: HERE are a few tidbits about Britain's royal family currently circulating over the World Wide Web: the Princess of Wales's favorite foods are pasta, salads and fruit. Princess Anne's favorite drinks are chilled white wine and Coca-Cola. And Prince William, 14, admires the actress Pamela Anderson.

title: Valentine Has a Keen Eye on Everett
description: It is fast approaching the point in spring training where there could actually be a connection between the lineups managers put together for exhibition games and the one likely to appear on opening day.

description: DELLER-Roslyn. On March 12, 1997. Beloved wife of Harold. Devoted mother of Lisa. Cherished sister of Judith Eichel and Stanley Moldow. Real estate broker and community leader. Services Friday 12 noon, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: When Money Counts
description: WHO says magazines are light reading? They never stop piling up -- week after week. Now there are storage ideas beyond the basket as rack or under the bed. Well-designed magazine racks fit current issues waiting to be read and back numbers too good to throw out. There is even one (No. 1) that serves heavy-duty readers, made for a San Francisco coffeehouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOK, HILDA S.
description: KOOK-Hilda S., on 3/12/97, (age 95). Cherished for her common sense, her style and grace and love of the arts. Wife of the late Edward Kook. Mother of the late Patricia Gibbs; mother-in-law of Bud Gibbs; grandmother of Lauren Gibbs and Kenneth Gibbs; great-grandmother of Jeremy, Leah, Ethan and Nathaniel Cramer Gibbs; aunt of Bob Schiller. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St on Friday at 1 pm. The family wil be at the Chapel Thursday 6:30-8PM. Contributions may be made to the Dept. of Education of the NY Philharmonic for their Young Friends Program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDWIN, DAVID
description: BALDWIN-David. Raconteur, actor, painter, beloved son of Berdis Emma Baldwin and brother of the late distinguished writer James Baldwin, died March 10th, 1997. His survivors include a son, Daniel, his wife, Marion Russell Baldwin, two brothers George and Wilmer, five sisters: Barbara Jamison, Gloria Karefa-Smart, Ruth Crumm, Elizabeth Dingle, and Paula Whaley, and a host of nieces, nephews, and friends. Services will be held at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 112th Street & Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, 10:30 A.M., Monday, March 17th. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution to your favorite charity.

title: West Bengal Finds It Creates Child Beggars for Export
description: When Kabirul Islam emerged into a corridor at the child welfare center here, it was not hard to see why he caught the attention of the recruiters who prowl local villages looking for children to work as beggars.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFLIESE, PAULINE HARNISCH
description: DEFLIESE-Pauline Harnisch, 75, of Englewood Isles, Florida, died on Saturday, March 8, 1997, at the Venice Hospital in Venice, Florida, after a long illness. She was born October 13, 1921 in Queens, New York and was the only child of William and Louise Zimmer Harnisch. She married Philip L. Defliese on April 28, 1946, who later became chairman CEO of Coopers and Lybrand and now is Professor Emeritus of Columbia University. She was a resident of Garden City, New York for 39 years where she raised her family and was a member of St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church and the Garden City Country Club. She was a past president of the Garden City Chapter of the Children's Medical Fund of New York where she was an active volunteer. In 1991 Mr. and Mrs. Defliese retired to Englewood Isles, Florida where she was living at the time of her death. She was a member of St. Raphael's Catholic Church and Boca Royale Golf and Country Club. Surviving with her husband are two sons & daughterin-laws; Robert and Jennifer of Garden City, New York and Philip and Lenore of Mercer Island, Washington; a daughter, Jeanne of Manhattan, New York and six grandchildren. A funeral mass will be held 10 AM, Thursday, March 13, 1997, at St. Raphael's Catholic Church and then she will be taken to Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, New York where friends may call from 2 until 5 and 7 until 10 PM on Sunday, and a mass of Christian burial will be held at 9:45 A.M., on Monday, March 17, 1997 at St. Anne's Catholic Church in Garden City, New York. Burial will follow in St. John's Cemetery in Queens, New York. Memorial donations may be sent to the Children's Medical Center Fund of New York, 3000 Marcus Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York 11040.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SQUIRE, JUDGE SIDNEY
description: SQUIRE-Judge Sidney. Comrade, friend, mentor, rock. 30 Days. We miss you. Martin J. Warmbrand, P.P.C. Corp.Sydney Rosenberg Post

title: Carld Jonaissant, 35, a Dancer of Many Styles
description: Carld Jonaissant, a dancer with Dance Theater of Harlem and American Ballet Theater, a choreographer and a designer, died on Feb. 28 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 35 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Office Depot And Staples To Sell Stores
description: The office supply discounters Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc., facing a threatened antitrust lawsuit to block their proposed merger, agreed today to sell 63 stores to their lone remaining competitor, Officemax Inc.

title: Congress Is Cautioned Against Ban on Human-Cloning Work
description: Scientists and ethicists testifying at a Senate hearing on cloning urged Congress today not to rush to ban research on the cloning of human beings.

title: New York Detectives Go West, Pursuing a Killer
description: Like the producer Steven Bochco (''Hill Street Blues,'' ''N.Y.P.D. Blue''), Dick Wolf is a master at creating crime thrillers. His best show, ''Shannon's Deal,'' with Jamey Sheridan and a score by Wynton Marsalis, wasn't given enough time to make it on the ratings charts, but his ''Law and Order,'' having survived seven seasons, has gradually become a television phenomenon.

title: The White House and the F.B.I.
description: For all the grief that has come of their association over the years, the White House and the Federal Bureau of Investigation still have not got the relationship right. That is painfully evident from their bungled dealings over possible Chinese efforts to influence last year's election. There may be an innocent explanation for the mishandling of this matter, but it would be hard to guess that from the exhibition put on by the White House and F.B.I. On Monday evening they were firing accusations and denials across Washington like artillery fire.

title: Burst of Pride for a Staccato Executioner: AK-47
description: One of this city's proudest exhibits is not a religious icon or a portrait. It is the Kalashnikov assault rifle that a North Vietnamese soldier used to kill 78 Americans in the Vietnam War.

title: The Return Of Tikkanen The Agitator
description: THE night three years ago when the Rangers won the Stanley Cup, one by one they skated around Madison Square Garden holding the trophy aloft, then they gathered on the ice with it for the photographers.

title: Gilmour Is Likely To Face Whalers
description: Coach Jacques Lemaire and Doug Gilmour would not make a firm commitment yesterday. They simply said after practice that they expected Gilmour to play for the Devils tonight when the Hartford Whalers visit Continental Arena.

title: Top Executive To Join D.M.B.& B.
description: Patrick Sherwood, an agency executive with extensive automotive experience, is joining D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications as managing director of the agency's important Troy, Mich., office, which handles the accounts of the Cadillac and Pontiac divisions of the General Motors Corporation.

title: In Separate Studies, Costs Of Hospitals Are Debated
description: Investor-owned hospitals have significantly higher administrative costs than nonprofit hospitals, in part because they are less efficient, two health care researchers said today.

title: Parents See a Conspiracy
description: The parents of a woman who died in a jewelry store holdup filed a lawsuit Wednesday contending that her husband conspired with the robbers and deliberately killed her, the A.P. said.

title: Staff Urges Steinbrenner to Keep Outfield Prospect Out of Trade Talks
description: While George Steinbrenner was apparently being persuaded by his staff this afternoon behind closed doors to hold off on including Rick Ledee in a prospective deal for the rights to Hideki Irabu, Ledee nevertheless had the feeling that he would not be a Yankee much longer.

title: C.I.A. Nominee Works Hard to Sway Panel
description: Anthony Lake worked hard today to convince members of the Senate Intelligence Committee that he was not too mild-mannered, too inexperienced or too liberal to run the Central Intelligence Agency and oversee the rest of the nation's spy services.

title: New ideas go beyond handouts in the war on African poverty.
description: WITH much of the third world busily freeing markets and imitating the export-led growth policies of the Asian tigers like Taiwan and Hong Kong, economic development is the order of the day everywhere. Everywhere, that is, but sub-Saharan Africa, where population growth has outpaced output for two decades and most people live on the edge of subsistence.

title: Tax Evasion Is Charged In Operation Of Nightclubs
description: Peter Gatien, the former king of the New York nightclub scene, faced deepening legal problems yesterday as state prosecutors announced his arrest on tax evasion charges.

title: A Caribbean Supplement
description: The Daily News will begin on March 19 to publish a once-a-month Sunday magazine supplement aimed at New Yorkers with roots in the Caribbean, who make up one of the city's fastest-growing communities.

title: Patient Held in Shooting Of Doctor in Queens Office
description: A doctor well known in his Queens neighborhood for treating poor people and immigrants was shot by a patient who was enraged that the physician would not write a letter backing up the man's workers' compensation claim, the police said.

title: UConn Ends Iona's Season
description: A poor Big East team is still better than the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference's best. At least that was the case tonight as Connecticut scored a 71-66 victory over Iona in a first-round game of the National Invitation Tournament at Gampel Pavilion.

title: Republican Demand: A Realistic Budget
description: Trying to turn up the public and political pressure on President Clinton over budget negotiations, House Republicans today approved a nonbinding resolution that would require the White House to submit a second budget to replace one that Congressional analysts say is flawed.

title: Good News for Injured Mets
description: Mets pitcher Armando Reynoso and shortstop Rey Ordonez, out with a sore elbow and shoulder, respectively, received good news today after examinations revealed that neither player is seriously injured.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a rebellion in Zaire misstated the date that Yoweri Museveni took control in neighboring Uganda. It was 1986, not 1979.

title: Finding Toil and Sweat Instead of a Spring Break
description: Michael Morton had expected three days of spring break bliss -- meeting girls on the beach, watching the sunset, cruising the bars -- but his plans went terribly awry. On the second day, he spent eight hours picking up trash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, J. JULIAN HOWARD JR.
description: MARSHALL-J. Julian Howard Jr., age 74, of Biddeford Pool, Maine and formerly of Irvington, NY, died Tuesday at a Maine Hospital. He graduated from Princeton University where he was on the 1941 National Champion LaCrosse Team. He served in W.W. II as a liaison pilot with the 43rd Artillery in the Pacific, attaining the Rank of Captain. In 1949 he graduated from Harvard Law School. Practiced Corporate Law with Root, Ballantine, Harlan, Bushby and Palmer, later with Dewey, Ballantine, Harlan, Bushby, and Palmer and Wood 1949-1955. Also a partner in Morgan Lewis and Bockius 1978-88. Retired in 1988. Trustee of the Masters School, Chairman of the Irvington Planning Board 1966-1989. A memorial service will be held 2:30PM, Saturday at the Church of St. Barnabus, Irvington, NY. Resident of Irvington from 1956 to 1996. There will be a service on Friday at 2:00 PM at St. David's Episcopal in Kennebunk, and Fr. Gerald Burt will be officiating. Contributions to be made to The American Diabetes Foundation, 1660 Duke St., Alexandria, Va.

title: Happy Birthday, Undead

Byron, the ultimate Romantic, took a crack at a vampire tale. So did the earnest turn-of-the-century American writer Mary Wilkins Freeman, who gave her New England vampire the homespun name Luella Miller.

title: The Only Thing That's Missing Is the Stanley Cup
description: The Washington Capitals might not qualify for the Stanley Cup playoffs this season and the Rangers might not go far in the tournament. But when these two Atlantic Division rivals met last night at Madison Square Garden, they battled as intensely and as entertainingly as any two teams will in any post-season encounter.

title: Scandals Past and Present

Instead, with discussion of today's fund-raising scandals rising in volume, I would like to contribute some recollections that illustrate the vast distance between President Clinton's troubles and President Nixon's Watergate.

The acquisition would include development and manufacturing in Bosch's Berlin-Spandau plant, Bosch's Radiocom A.G. unit in Switzerland, and sales organizations in Germany and other European countries. The business had sales of $200 million in 1996. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., makes communications equipment and semiconductors.

The progress of peace is neither as meager as King Hussein complains, nor as impressive as Mr. Netanyahu suggests. But the peace effort has arrived at another crucial juncture.

title: More Generous Transit Plan
description: President Clinton's proposed transportation financing bill, presented to Congress yesterday, would give New Jersey an average of $580 million in Federal highway aid for each of the next six years, up from $490 million under the current plan. The plan is also more generous than one pushed by Sun Belt lawmakers. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman told Congress last month that the Sun Belt plan would cost 15 Northeastern and Midwestern states more than $1 billion a year in aid. The President's proposal is a middle ground between the Sun Belt plan and one proposed by the Northeastern and Midwestern legislators.

He provides tips along the way on proper cultivation (plenty of light, not too much water), but, as the program's title, ''Pot of Gold,'' hints, his interest is less in horticulture than in the economics of what he says may be America's biggest cash crop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISGALL, DR. HUGO
description: WEISGALL-Dr. Hugo. The officers and members of the Cantors Assembly record in deep sadness the passing of one of the great American composers of our generation. Superbly skilled in opera and lied composition, recipient of numerous prestigious awards, a stubbornly dedicated teacher and mentor, a gifted conductor and scholar in a wide variety of disciplines, a truly learned and observant and talented Jew. For us, of the Cantors Assembly, he wil long be remembered as the driving force behind the organization of the Cantors Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary in 1952. He quickly managed to bring to the faculty of the new school a wide array of important figures in the cantorate, in liturgical composition, and well-known instructors in the field of classical music. He vowed to devote the Institute's resources toward developing the great tradition of Jewish music and the training of Hazzanim who would some day serve the great American Jewish community's synagogues. As Chairman of the Faculty, his chief aim for the school would be to communicate through the medium of music, the spirit inherent in Judaism. He succeeded in both of his high goals beyond his own dreams. After four decades, his school and his curriculum produced over one hundred and seventy graduates, who day in and day out strive to carry out his plan for them. They, and we who helped establish the school, are a living memorial to his vision and talent. May his memory abide as a blessing for us all. Hazzan Abraham Lubin, President Hazzan Samuel Rosenbaum, Executive Vice President

He was fascinated with Russia and he published two letters in The New York Times on November 5, 1992 and November 24, 1996. He was the first American to be sent by the IESC to help Ukraine. He was passionate about education and helping children with dyslexia. His humor and charm kept us all in high spirits and we treasure his memory. He was an inspiration to us all. Dad is deeply missed and loved.

It lies open to an illustration, elegant and linear, of toga-clad figures in a leafy landscape. Its naturalism makes it look like something from Pompeii and a thousand years older than it is, a reminder that during the Middle Ages the legacies of Greece and Rome were kept alive in Constantinople, not in the Latin West.

The 1983 film's original victory party on a moon of Endor has been augmented with simultaneous celebrations on Tatooine, Cloud City and Coruscant, the Imperial headquarters planet. It's Independence Day across the universe, and the heavens in all four locales light up with good old-fashioned fireworks. Yippee!

title: Boy, 3, Dies After Fall From Window in Bronx
description: A Bronx toddler visiting his father died yesterday after he tumbled head-first out of a kitchen window, the police said. The toddler, Selvin Adams Jr., 3, fell from a third-floor window at 2438 Morris Avenue about 9 A.M. and landed in an alley, witnesses and police officials said.

title: BELL ATLANTIC AND DSC SETTLE SUIT AGAINST LUCENT
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and the DSC Communications Corporation said today that they had settled their antitrust lawsuit against Lucent Technologies Inc. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. Bell Atlantic and DSC settled claims related to a similar suit against the AT&T Corporation last month. Claims brought against Lucent by DSC and a counterclaim brought by Lucent were voluntarily dismissed. Bell Atlantic and DSC filed suit against AT&T and Lucent in 1996, seeking nearly $3.5 billion in damages. The suit alleged that AT&T designed its telecommunications switches specifically to prevent the interconnection of other manufacturers' equipment. AT&T subsequently filed counterclaims against Bell Atlantic.

title: The 16th-Seeded Stags Take Smith's No. 1 Heels to Limit

After the final buzzer sounded, the coach of the North Carolina Tar Heels walked toward the Stags' bench and shook their hands.

title: When a Comet Passes By
description: Those who got up at 4 A.M. yesterday and ventured into the bracing Westchester darkness could easily confirm that Comet Hale-Bopp, first sighted almost two years ago in the distant reaches of the solar system, is finally here. There it stood, some 20 degrees up from the horizon in the northeastern sky, clearly visible to the naked eye, the brightest and largest object around. After the anticlimactic fizzles of Comet Kahoutek in 1973 and Halley's Comet in 1986, not to mention the blurry image of Comet Hyakutake last year, it was a relief to find Hale-Bopp so instantly recognizable, a fuzzy ball with a short but luminous tail.

title: Ford Chairman to Stay On Past Usual Retirement Age
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that its chairman and chief executive, Alexander J. Trotman, would stay on 18 months beyond the customary retirement age of 65 for Ford executives, buying time for the company to decide on his successor.

title: OHIO OFFICIALS BAR HEALTH INSURANCE MERGER
description: The Ohio Department of Insurance has rejected the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's proposed $299.5 million purchase of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio. Columbia/HCA proposed last March to buy Ohio's biggest health insurer for its 1.5 million participants and four Cleveland-area hospitals. Ohio officials challenged the bid, saying that Columbia/HCA was not offering enough and that other offers were not adequately considered. In the ruling, the insurance department said the proposed transaction would have violated state law. It said it would issue an order on May 9 rejecting the transaction unless Ohio Blue Cross requests a hearing within 30 days. The deal would have represented the first acquisition of a nonprofit Blue Cross plan by Columbia/HCA, which is based in Nashville.

title: DILLON, READ NEGOTIATING REPURCHASE OF STAKE FROM ING
description: Dillon, Read & Company is in talks to buy back the remaining stake in the firm held by ING Barings, the investment banking arm of the Dutch bank ING Groep N.V., the company said in a memo to employees dated Feb. 18. The New York investment banking firm has an option, which can be exercised in June, to repurchase the shares now held by ING Barings. The Barings Holding Company, which was taken over by ING in March 1995, bought a 40 percent interest and some preferred stock in Dillon, Read in 1991. Dillon, Read bought back 20 percent of its shares in May 1995 for about $30 million. Dillon, Read's executives own the firm's remaining shares.

title: The Hunchback, Without Singing Gargoyles
description: Oh, no, not again! The hunchback is, so to speak, back. Victor Hugo's 1831 novel ''Notre Dame de Paris'' is receiving yet another cinematic spin. The first was a 1906 French adaptation called ''La Esmeralda.'' Later versions include a 1923 silent film, ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame,'' starring Lon Chaney; the classic 1939 remake with Charles Laughton and Maureen O'Hara, in her first Hollywood film; a 1982 television version with Anthony Hopkins; and, of course, Disney's peculiar gargoyle romp last year.

title: Dishonor Among Thieves

Or the child casually beating a plastic toy to death on a frazzled little strip of grass in view of the harbor. Or the refinery where a chimney periodically belches out a tongue of fire just as a late-night gun battle is about to erupt.

title: Inside Photography

description: An obituary of the composer Hugo Weisgall in some editions yesterday misstated his tenure as president of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He was president from 1990 to 1992, not at his death.

title: Sexual Identity Not Pliable After All, Report Says
description: A classic case of a gruesome surgical accident and its consequences that was long used as evidence of the pliability of sexual identity turns out, in follow-up, to suggest the opposite: that a sense of being male or female is innate, immune to the interventions of doctors, therapists and parents.

title: Lee Kuan Yew Apologizes for Remarks That Angered Malaysia
description: SINGAPORE  Seeking to prevent a serious rift in relations with Malaysia, Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's senior minister, apologized "unreservedly" Thursday for remarks that brought a storm of protest from Malaysians.

title: Japan's Economy Expanded At 3.9% Rate in 4th Quarter
description: With exports starting to surge again, Japan's economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the fourth quarter, capping a year in which the nation emerged, at least partly, from an extended economic slump, the Government said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONO, HARVEY
description: KONO-Harvey. Beloved husband of Francine. Son of Bella. Brother of Roberta Geula and Carl. Cherished father of Marc, Eric, Evan, Jonathan and Amberly. title: Form Holds Up in Super-G
description: Form prevailed today in the super-giant slalom of the Cafe de Colombia World Cup finals here as Andreas Schifferer gave Austria another top step on the podium in the men's race ahead of a countryman, Josef Strobl, and Katja Seizinger led a three-way German podium sweep in the women's super-G.

title: MURPHY OIL PULLS OUT OF THREE-WAY CONSOLIDATION PLAN
description: The Murphy Oil Corporation said yesterday that it had decided not to merge its Murco Petroleum Ltd. unit's British refining and marketing business with those of Elf Oil and Gulf Oil. Murphy, an oil and natural gas concern in El Dorado, Ark., said the transaction would not significantly improve its refining and marketing operation in Britain. Elf Oil is a unit of Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine of France and Gulf Oil is part of the Chevron Corporation of San Francisco. Separately, Elf Aquitaine and Chevron reaffirmed their commitment to the original plan to merge their British refining and marketing interests.

title: Dow 8,000? Almost, With 4 New Stocks
description: Would you believe an 8,000 Dow Jones industrial average? Had Dow Jones made the changes announced this week back in 1991, the last time the bellwether index was adjusted, this week would have seen the Dow come perilously close to that level.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAULDING, CHARLES
description: FAULDING-Charles. The 100,000member Transport Workers Union of America mourns the passing of our retired Secretary Treasurer on March 9, 1997 after a brief illness at Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 81. He had retired in February 1991 after a distinguished 48-year career as a member and officer of TWU's flagship Local 100 in New York City and the national TWU of America. In 1980, as Secretary Treasurer of the 35,000-member Local 100, Mr. Faulding played a key role in the 11-day New York City transit strike. Despite his retirement from TWU, Mr. Faulding remained 1st Vice President of the New York City Central Labor Council's Black Trade Union Leadership Committee; an officer of the Municipal Credit Union; a member of One Hundred Black Men, a life member of the NAACP, and was founder of the Senior Citizens Garden Club in Roy Wilkins Park, Queens. During his nearly five decades as a union officer for TWU, Mr. Faulding held almost every elected position in Local 100, except President, including 26 years of service as Shop Steward, Vice Chairman and Chairman of the Local's United Motormen's Division. Born in Spotsylvania County, Virginia, in 1916, he came to New York at the age of 11. He became involved in the union movement for transit workers when he became a Trolley Motorman. He joined Local 100, and soon after was selected Shop Steward and immediately became a solidifying force. Mr. Faulding joined the national union's staff in 1985 as Secretary Treasurer, a position he held until his retirement. He is a charter member and former President of the BMT Surface Operators Club which was founded in 1943 when minorities were first hired into New York Surface transportation. Our deepest condolences to his son George, five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Friends may pay their respects at J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, 179-24 Linden Blvd, Jamaica, NY Friday, March 14, 1997. Funeral Services Saturday 9 AM, Trinity Lutheran Church of Locust Manor, 121-02 Merril St, Jamaica, NY. Sonny Hall, International President Frank McCann, Executive Vice President John Kerrigan, Secretary Treasurer

title: British Regulators To Review a Merger
description: British regulators will investigate Technicolor's proposed acquisition of Metrocolor London Ltd. from Time Warner because of concerns about competition in the film-processing industry. Technicolor is a unit of Carlton Communications P.L.C., one of Britain's three biggest independent television companies.

title: Eastman Kodak Cited for Marketing
description: The Eastman Kodak Company in Rochester took top honors last night at the 11th annual Edison Best New Product Awards ceremony, sponsored by the American Marketing Association.

title: At the Chasm's Edge
description: We may never know exactly what led a Jordanian soldier yesterday to shoot down Israeli schoolgirls: political rage, hatred of Jews, madness. If only there could be grief without politics in the Middle East.

title: Reno Says Her Warning on China Failed
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she knew last May about evidence of Chinese efforts to influence American politics, but left the task of alerting the White House to the F.B.I. after trying and failing to reach the national security adviser, Anthony Lake.

title: The Lord of a Universe in Which Peculiar Anatomies Intermingle
description: QUITE some time ago, an artist called Roberto Sebastian Matta Echaurren, born and reared in Chile, became just about as ubiquitous as a painter can be.

title: Pact Reached To Break Up Con Edison
description: Preparing to transform the electric power industry from monopoly to a competitive market, state regulators and Consolidated Edison agreed today on a sweeping reorganization of the utility that would break it up into several pieces and give deep rate cuts to large industrial customers.

title: Retail Sales Soar, Making a Rate Rise by the Fed More Likely
description: Americans shopped at a brisk pace last month after a surprisingly strong surge in retail sales in January, Commerce Department figures showed today, making it more likely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in the near future.

description: Cordiant P.L.C., owner of the advertising agencies Saatchi & Saatchi and Bates Worldwide, said yesterday that it returned to profit in 1996. Pretax profit was $:41.8 million ($67 million), the company said, after a loss of $:22.6 million a year ago.

title: Coffee Prices Sag as Growers Add Exports From Stockpiles
description: Coffee posted its biggest one-day drop in two and a half years on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York yesterday as a recent surge in prices lured additional supplies to futures exchange warehouses.

title: City of Berlin Expels 2 Bosnian Refugees, Hinting at Exodus Plan
description: Increasingly uneasy with their role as hosts to a costly population of Bosnian war refugees, the Berlin city authorities today ordered the deportation of two refugees to Sarajevo -- a symbolic gesture signaling what is planned as a much greater forced exodus.

title: BITTER ALBANIANS, FACING ANARCHY, ARM THEMSELVES
description: Albania crumbled into anarchy today as the authorities flung open weapons warehouses in the capital to arm civilians they apparently hoped would help defend the embattled Government.

title: Airline Stops Use of New Jet Over Atlantic
description: British Airways has voluntarily suspended trans-Atlantic flights with a new model of the Boeing 777 because of repeated problems with the model's engines, which are the most powerful in the world.

title: Months of Therapy Will Accompany Healing
description: For President Clinton, the 2-hour 4-minute operation he underwent here today to repair a torn knee tendon was the easy part.

title: The Hospital That Noticed Its Neighbors
description: DON'T even think about it. Like the signs posted to ward off illegal parking at hospitals, that sentiment captured Dr. Jose Contreras's feelings about getting admitting privileges at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Although his urology practice was only four blocks away in Washington Heights, for 18 years he referred patients miles away to New York University Medical Center or Cabrini Hospital.

title: Zaire Rebels Begin Attack On Key City of Kisangani
description: After a three-week siege of Kisangani but little fighting there, Zairian rebels attacked tonight, setting off a panic among Government troops and civilians alike.

description: A television review of ''Law and Order'' on Thursday included an erroneous previous credit for its producer, Dick Wolf. ''Shannon's Deal,'' also a crime series, was produced by Stan Rogow.

title: LORAL COMPLETES BUYING AT&T'S SKYNET SATELLITE
description: Loral Space and Communications Ltd. said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the AT&T Corporation's Skynet Satellite Services for $478.1 million. The company said the price, down from the original agreement of $712.5 million, was adjusted to reflect the sudden loss in January of Telstar 401, one of two Skynet satellites. Loral Space, a New York aerospace and telecommunications concern, said it expected to expand Skynet into an international network of satellites that would connect with other networks. Skynet is a United States satellite operator specializing in the distribution of entertainment and educational programming.

title: Today's Explorers Have Places to Go, Cocktails to Drink
description: If it's not one thing, it's another. Ninety years ago, the debate at the Explorers Club raged over which member made it to the North Pole first. Lately, researchers have pretty much proved that neither of the two mentioned, Dr. Frederick A. Cook and Adm. Robert E. Peary, did.

title: Oklahoma Bomb Suspect Seeks Trial Delay or Dismissal of Case
description: Citing ''paralyzing pretrial publicity,'' the lawyer for Timothy J. McVeigh, one of two men charged in the Oklahoma City bombing, yesterday asked the Federal judge who will hear the case in Denver to dismiss the indictment against his client.

title: The Very Models of Civility
description: To help them re-learn manners, members of the House of Representatives hired a specialist in civil discourse to plan their sessions at a retreat last weekend. Judging by the harsh partisanship that erupted only a few days later, the lawmakers might have done better to hire a zoologist. Out in the wild, an outlandish thought is gaining credence: that morality was not invented, but that it evolved.

title: Seeing Threat to His Plan, Crew Lobbies Justice Dept.
description: Worried that the Justice Department will stand in the way of the most significant overhaul of New York City's school system in a generation, Chancellor Rudy Crew urged Federal officials yesterday to allow the hard-won law to take effect, as scheduled, on April 1.

title: Killings Erode Cairo's Claim to 'Control' Militants
description: The Egyptian Government recently seemed on the verge of declaring victory in its war against Islamic militants who have been engaged in a campaign of violence for more than five years. But a series of attacks that left 23 civilians dead in central Egypt in the last month has undercut the Government's claims of triumph.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GANZ, SALLY W.
description: GANZ-Sally W. A memorial service for Sally W. Ganz will take place at 10:30 A.M., Tuesday, March 18, at The Museum of Modern Art, 11 W. 53 St, NYC.

description: Bertram M. Gross, a public policy specialist, author and academician who was a forceful and persistent advocate of full employment, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday in Walnut Creek, Calif., his widow, Kusum Singh, said. He was 84 years old.

But the connections to his newer dances are intriguing.

title: Bank of New York Is Denied Bid To Double Its State Street Stake
description: Massachusetts bank regulators today denied the application by the Bank of New York Company to double its stake in the State Street Boston Corporation to 9.9 percent, a plan that has been widely regarded as a step leading to takeover, analysts said.

title: Moscow Is Offered A NATO Concession
description: In a new concession to Russia, NATO said that in its planned expansion, it would not put permanent ground troops in the former Warsaw Pact nations. The alliance previously said it had no plans to place nuclear weapons there.

title: Graves Does the Trick for Rangers
description: Still appearing to be very much in a haze, Alexander Daigle of the Ottawa Senators walked through the hallway of the Corel Center after tonight's game with a goose egg sprouting from his forehead.

title: Replacing the Raw With the Refined
description: Fashion shows have become the sitcoms of the industry, complete with stock characters and settings so artificial they are jarring. The overexposure of publicity that made ''Friends'' virtually unwatchable and has stolen the mystery from movie stars has worked the same black magic on runway shows: they feel so passe that the biggest joke seems to be that an industry that prides itself on its prescience hasn't figured out that its rituals are the most unfashionable thing of all. All that's missing is the canned laughter.

title: In Switch, U.S. Allies Consider a Rival : Russia Making Inroads In Asian Arms Market
description: SINGAPORE  When the Philippines makes a final decision later this year on an order for new fighter aircraft worth as much as $1 billion, Russia hopes to have put itself in a winning position with a bid that will defeat those of rival Western suppliers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FREDERICK L.
description: COHEN-Frederick L., attorney, 89, of Brooklyn Heights, beloved husband of Helen, died Saturday, February 22, at Long Island College Hospital, after a short illness resulting from a fall. Attended NYC public schools and City College. Graduated St. John's University Law School. Veteran of World War II with two years of overseas service. He was senior attorney with the New York State Labor Relations Board for 27 years, until his retirement. He was a member of the Jewish War Veterans and the Knights of Pythias. In 1952 he ran as a Republican candidate for the then Municipal Court. He also ran for State Senator.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review yesterday about work of the installation artist Francis Cape, on view through April 5 at the Steffany Martz Gallery, misstated the address. It is 580 Broadway, near Prince Street, in SoHo.

title: NATO Says It Won't Base New Forces In the East
description: NATO declared today that it had no intention now or in the foreseeable future of permanently stationing foreign ground-combat forces on the territory of member nations that did not already have them. The announcement was a new and significant concession to Russian concerns about the planned eastward expansion of the alliance.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the unconditional offer of the Detroit newspaper unions to return to work after a lengthy strike misstated the position of the United Auto Workers. It supports the newspaper unions and has not opposed the decision to return to work, said Frank Joyce, its public relations director.

title: The Man Behind The Mark
description: THERE will be many friends of Dean Smith's program rooting for him to become the top-winning major college basketball coach this afternoon, but none will have more of a nothing-could-be-finer perspective than a man who is a local institution in his own right.

title: Clarkson and Cornell in Title Game
description: Todd White, the national scoring leader, had three goals tonight as Clarkson defeated Princeton, 5-1, in a semifinal game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Division I tournament in the Olympic Arena.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

description: WORKING TOGETHER -- In a new era of cooperation, a delegation of Chinese police investigators is visiting in New York. Page 27.

title: Cracking Paris:The Inside Loop of Hip Professionals Out on the Town
description: PARIS  The hot fashion restaurant Anahi has tripled its order of Perrier. The Hotel Montalembert has been fully booked for this week for over three months. At the designer boutique Maria Louisa expect tears: The waiting list there for a Galliano floral sprigged dress peaks at 10, and there are only six dresses.

title: French Panel Cites Fraud at Credit Lyonnais
description: The Finance Committee in France's Parliament said yesterday that past instances of fraud have cost Credit Lyonnais, a state-controlled bank, as much as 5 billion French francs ($870 million). Earlier this week, the committee estimated the cost of the bank's bailouts at a higher-than-expected 130 billion francs, and the bank's Ghent branch, in Belgium, reported large withdrawals yesterday in the wake of the arrest of a longtime employee for attempted embezzlement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about arts advocates who lobbied Congress for money misidentified the distributor of the film ''The Watermelon Woman.'' It was First Run Features, not Women Make Movies.

title: Fielder Said to Be Closing In on Deal
description: With the clock ticking down on Saturday's midnight deadline for Cecil Fielder's trade demand, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, and Fielder's representatives appeared today to be close to a deal that would keep the slugger in New York for at least two more years, according to a person familiar with the talks.

title: A Makeover For Stars From Britain
description: Rock bands who know history may be destined to scramble it. Blur, which performed on Tuesday night at the Supper Club, has taken up a certain strain of English songwriting: tuneful, observant and eternally preoccupied with the way grand expectations collapse into everyday drabness: ''Had my chances, they had me,'' Damon Albarn sang in ''Country Sad Ballad Man.''

title: Election Risks in El Salvador
description: Elections in El Salvador do more than choose Governments. Sometimes they start wars. In 1972, the army stole the apparent presidential victory of Jose Napoleon Duarte. El Salvador's left concluded that politics was useless and began to create a guerrilla movement. The 1977 presidential elections were again marked by extensive fraud. Two years later, the left launched a civil war that lasted 12 years and produced 75,000 deaths.

title: For Designers, Inspiration From the 80's
description: It now seems clear that designers' fascination with the 1980's is likely to take fashion right up to the year 2000. Designers' other pursuit these days is artisanal work, a trend forecasters link to turn-of-the-century nostalgia.

title: Israeli Cabinet Votes to Build in East Jerusalem Next Week
description: The Israeli Cabinet resolved today to go ahead next week with the building of a new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem despite warnings from security officials of a large potential for violent Palestinian resistance.

title: Barney's-Isetan Dispute to Require a Trial
description: Barney's Inc. has lost a round in its effort to have a court find that the Isetan Company is an equity partner of Barney's rather than its landlord.

title: Applied Magnetics Cancels Hostile Offer for Read-Rite
description: The Applied Magnetics Corporation said today that it was withdrawing its unsolicited offer to buy the Read-Rite Corporation, a larger rival supplier of disk drive components, because recent declines in Applied's shares had trimmed the value of the proposed stock swap from $1.76 billion to $1.06 billion.

title: Lost In Byteworld
description: If you don't hear from me for the next few months, folks, don't worry. I have to buy a new computer, that's all.

title: For One Night, The Nets Perform Like Worldbeaters
description: No big deal, not to Xavier McDaniel. But there was a melee around him, Nets players leaping, fans throwing cups into the air. To heck with the Coke stains.

title: Just Hit Redial
description: In an era of cell phones and electronic pagers, not to mention the ever-resourceful White House operators, it is hard to believe that the Attorney General could not reach the White House national security adviser on a matter of some importance. But that is what Janet Reno says happened in May 1996 when she tried to call Anthony Lake at the White House to tell him about possible Chinese efforts to channel money into American political campaigns.

title: New Guidelines on Sexual Harassment Tell Schools When a Kiss Is Just a Peck
description: For school officials uncertain about how they should handle sexual taunting on the school bus, lewd advances by a teacher or an unwanted kiss by a classmate, the Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights this week issued its guidelines for dealing with sexual harassment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAFER, LOUIS
description: LAFER-Louis. To a special person, who will be greatly missed. His joyous love for life shall never be forgotten. Our sincerest sympanthies to Claire, Sandy, Barry and Alan and family. Enid and David Horne

title: POOR EARNINGS SEND EMPLOYEE SOLUTIONS' STOCK DOWN
description: Shares of Employee Solutions Inc. plunged yesterday for the second straight day as the staffing company said its fourth-quarter earnings would fall below Wall Street's expectations. Employee Solutions was expected to release its earnings on Thursday. Instead, after the market closed, the company announced that it would delay reporting its results because several matters needed to be resolved. Before the announcement late on Thursday, the company's shares fell $4.50, to $15.375, on the Nasdaq, movement that some market insiders attributed to short-selling by investors who bet on individual stocks to fall. Yesterday, Employee Solutions stock dropped by $9.125, to $6.25.

title: Jury Awards $37 Million to Man Shot by Police
description: A mentally retarded man who was shot by the police in 1983 when he pointed what turned out to be a toy gun was awarded $37 million yesterday by a jury in State Supreme Court in Queens. The award was more than twice the amount his lawyers had requested.

title: NORTHWEST IN TALKS TO BUY REGIONAL CARRIER
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that it was in talks to buy Express Airlines I Inc., one of its two major regional carriers, from the closely held Phoenix Airline Services Inc. Northwest received an early antitrust clearance for the purchase on Monday from the Federal Trade Commission. Express Airlines I employs 1,600 people and had 1994 revenue of more than $150 million. It operates 66 aircraft on 346 daily flights that feed passengers into Northwest's Minneapolis and Memphis hubs.

title: Corrections

description: To the Editor:

Ehrlich and son in law Peter Ehrlich of Bedford, NY; grandsons Peter, Jr., James, Timothy and John; and three great-grandchildren. Services in Rochester, NY. For information, Anthony Funeral Chapel.

description: In percent

title: Young Designers Reinvent Couture
description: PARIS  After being declared dead, haute couture, or at least its spirit, is enjoying a revival. During the past decade, faced with the fading loyalty of their private clientele, many couture houses have chosen to hype their image rather than pay more attention to the changing needs of their clients.

title: Trump Sues on Casino Road
description: In his latest attempt to stop Stephen A. Wynn from building a casino complex in Atlantic City, Donald J. Trump filed suit in Federal District Court in Newark yesterday, charging that a proposed $330 million highway and tunnel project in Atlantic City violates the state's Constitution.

title: Death Penalty Is Dropped In 1995 Kidnapping Case
description: Reversing her earlier decision, Attorney General Janet Reno announced yesterday that the Government would not seek the death penalty for a reputed Chinese gang member if he is convicted of taking part in the kidnapping, torture and murder of an immigrant Chinese woman in a ransom plot.

title: Bulls Go Down, and Hopes Go Up
description: At least the Chicago Bulls are making this season more interesting. Lately, they have been neither unbeatable nor unflappable.

description: MULLIN-Thomas J. March 15, 1955-June 19, 1996. In loving memory from your fiancee. I'll love and miss you always. Naomi M. Kemp

title: 'Europa, Europa' Was Our Cry
description: We should support President Berisha.'' This was the last sentence in a fax from the German Government to its diplomats in Albania.

title: Defense Raises Race as Issue In Bribery Case
description: The issue of race, avoided through most of the Federal corruption and bribery trial of a top Newark official, became the focus of a heated argument today after the judge honored the prosecution's request to dismiss a juror who had been sleeping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, DR. HERBERT
description: SHAW-Dr. Herbert, 76, of New York City, died Sunday evening in Chapel Hill, NC. A native of Manhattan, NY, Dr. Shaw was a practicing dentist in New York City for 45 years. He is survived by: wife, Eleanor of New York; son, Gary Shaw and wife Kate of Chapel Hill. Daughter Robin Clarke and husband Arthur of Enfield, CT. Four grandchildren, Thomas and William Clarke of Enfield, CT and Nicholas and Emma Shaw of Chapel Hill. Memorials may be made to the New York Public Library. A memorial service will be conducted at a later date.

Loving grandfather of Michael, Paul, Susan, Joseph and Matthew, and soon to be great-grandfather. He was an intelligent and playful man. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, March 16, at 2:30 P.M., at the 92nd Street YMHA.

title: State Will Buy Old Shipyard For Oyster Bay Waterfront
description: Using funds allocated 25 years ago, the state is providing $5 million to buy a crumbling shipyard that dominates the waterfront of Oyster Bay, a sheltered haven that yields 90 percent of the oysters harvested in New York State.

title: Combining Sentimental And Chirpy
description: The stage at Phil Collins's sold-out performance on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden was designed like a large, circular life raft. But it was difficult to figure out how much life there was on the raft. Mr. Collins is at a strange juncture in his career. He is half adult-contemporary rock perennial, littering the middle of the road with a steady stream of passable pop. And he is half oldies act, an English progressive rocker of the 1970's fated to spend the rest of his career as a popular but irrelevant star performing sentimental ballads of the 80's like ''In the Air Tonight'' and ''Against All Odds (Take a Look at Me Now)''.

A wonderful husband to Lucille, proud and adoring ''Daddy'' to Peggy and her husband Marty, loving ''Gwampa'' to Nicky and Jake, loyal and loving brother of Betty Beranbaum and the late David Samson, brother-in-law to Hazel, Marvin, Rowie and Sam and caring uncle to their children. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Israel Of The City of N.Y. or a charity of your choice.

title: New York's Job Market Is Alive and Well
description: It was reported last week that New York City was lagging behind other cities in economic growth, experiencing increased unemployment and depending too much on Wall Street. Looks ominous? Look again.

title: Ex-Teller Admits Holdup
description: A former head teller of a bank in Bergen County recruited three friends to hold up the bank, she admitted yesterday in Federal District Court in Newark.

title: Temple's Defense Handcuffs Ole Miss
description: This was Mississippi's first appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in 16 years. And wouldn't you know they had to draw Temple, which turns opposing offenses into pretzels with its confusing matchup zone defense.

title: For Susan Graham, Two Performances In One Day Are Part of the Job
description: At a hastily convened rehearsal on Tuesday afternoon, Sir Colin Davis, the English conductor and a renowned Berlioz expert, sat with a score of ''Les Nuits d'Ete'' open on his lap, and hummed the cello lines while Harriet Wingreen, the New York Philharmonic's pianist, played a reduction of the orchestral score. During the weekend, Sir Colin's mezzo-soprano soloist, Markella Hatziano, bowed out because of a viral infection, and now the conductor was going over the score with Susan Graham, an American mezzo-soprano in her mid-30's who has had several successes on New York stages this season and who had just agreed to step in.

title: A City of High Calories, And People Proud of It
description: The news that a recent health study ranked New Orleans as the most obese city in the United States did not exactly send the city's reporters lunging for their notebooks.

title: How Oversize Racquets Restored Company's Game
description: Almost as soon as he accepted a job as president of Dunlop Sports, David A. Haggerty got a call from two old friends at Sports Authority, the national mega-outlet for sporting goods. ''They said, 'Hi, welcome aboard; just want to tell you we can't carry Dunlop tennis racquets anymore; the brand just doesn't sell,' '' Mr. Haggerty recalled.

description: Either the San Diego Padres are still seriously considering other teams, or they are trying to induce the Yankees to enhance their offer for negotiating rights to Hideki Irabu by continuing to talk with other clubs.

title: Bonds Improve on Outlook for Inflation
description: Bond market participants bracing for the worst yesterday were surprised with a better-than-expected producer price report that temporarily supplanted the notion that a rate increase was a given at the Federal Reserve's coming policy meeting.

description: The collapse of authority in Albania worsened today, as close confidants of the President fled the country and the Government failed in its effort to seize weapons from roving bands of thugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, GERTRUDE
description: RESNICK-Gertrude. Beloved and devoted mother of Jerome, Rhoda Perry and Rita Millner. Dear sister. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services on Sunday, 11:45AM at ''Parkside'' Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Heinz Cutting 2,500 Jobs In Revamping
description: In what it called the largest revamping in its history, the H. J. Heinz Company announced yesterday that it would sell or close at least 25 plants around the world and dismiss 2,500 employees, or 5.8 percent of its work force of 43,300. The company will take a $650 million charge in the current quarter to pay for the cutbacks.

title: Student Cuts Hand of Teacher Who Was Trying to Stop Fight
description: A science teacher who was trying to break up a fight between two students in the hallway of a Bronx intermediate school was injured yesterday when one of the students pulled out a box-cutter and cut the teacher's hand, the police said.

title: Chapter 11 Filed After Fraud Case
description: Systems of Excellence Inc. has filed for Chapter 11 protection, just weeks after its former chairman was sentenced to 46 months in prison after pleading guilty to charges of securities fraud and money laundering.

title: Where Australia's Chief Just Won't Hang His Hat
description: This totally planned inland capital was designed early in this century to look a little like Washington.

title: Even a Big Donor Can Find Political Dividends Elusive
description: Few have spread money around this city like Carl H. Lindner, the man behind Chiquita Bananas. He let Bob Dole fly around on jets that belong to his family's financial empire. He and his company, American Financial Corporation, donated more than $400,000 to the Democrats since 1993, enough to insure that he got both coffee at the White House and a night in the Lincoln Bedroom.

title: PHONETEL TO BUY COMMUNICATIONS CENTRAL
description: Phonetel Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Communications Central Inc., an operator of public pay telephones, for about $12.85 a share, or about $165 million in cash and debt. The purchase has been approved by the boards of both companies. Communications Central operates 26,000 pay telephones and inmate phones in 41 states and the District of Columbia. Phonetel owns about 41,300 installed public pay telephones. In Nasdaq trading, Communications Central's shares were up $2.25, or 25 percent, to $11.125, while Phonetel remained unchanged at $3.50 on the Amex.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: The Record That Smith Is Chasing Is 2-0
description: Dean Smith laughed when asked if he had considered the possibility of a victory shower on a basketball court. Belly laughs are not normally his style. But when the possibility was raised, the day before a victory by his North Carolina Tar Heels would become a record 877th of his 36-year career, Smith laughed so hard he shook.

title: Krolikowski's Barrage Leads the Violets
description: Jen Krolikowski, New York University's career scoring leader, showed last night that her timing is as accurate as her 3-point shot.

title: Resilient Boston College Keeping Its Alumni Happy
description: It used to be, said Boston College Coach Jim O'Brien, that the greatest pressure was simply getting into college basketball's national tournament. No more. Now, he said, you have to win at least one game, maybe two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEECHER, MARGERY
description: BEECHER-Margery. Age 86. On March 13, 1997 after a prolonged illness. Beloved wife for 63 years to Lawrence (Larry) Beecher. Loving mother of Andrew and Robert. Dear grandmother of Amy and Owen. Devoted sister of Stanton Gottlieb. Family will receive friends Saturday 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street with service on Sunday 11AM. She will always be remembered for her style, humor and love of the ballet, opera and travel. She will never be forgotten. Contributions in her memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Psychologist Is Sentenced
description: A Ridgewood psychologist convicted of swindling nearly $3 million from health insurance companies was sentenced yesterday to five and a half years in prison.

title: INSIDE
description: Key Battle Starts in Zaire

title: Producer Prices Decline Again, With Inflation Still a No-Show
description: The economy displayed almost no signs of inflation on the producer level last month, the Labor Department reported today, further straining the view that strong growth and low unemployment lead inexorably to rising wages and prices.

title: Lauding and Forgiving a Patron
description: As a benefactor of dance, Rebekah Harkness (1915-1982) did not enjoy smooth sailing. She was roundly criticized in the dance world and in the press for everything from the neo-mannerist taste of the small Harkness Theater she established briefly in the 1970's near Lincoln Center to her penchant for changing artistic directors of her Harkness Ballet.

title: Leonard Buder, 69, a Reporter Honored for Education Coverage
description: Leonard Buder, who specialized in the coverage of education during his 41 years as a reporter for The New York Times, died on Thursday at University Hospital in Cleveland. He was 69 and lived in New Milford, Conn.

title: Killing Frogs for Art, Student Lends Life to a Debate
description: In the abstract sense, art can be said to animate life, but when an artist employs the reverse principle, he risks controversy -- if not more serious consequences. So David Arnold is discovering.

title: No Headline

title: The Labor Deal Is Now Official
description: Representatives of the baseball club owners and players signed the new five-year collective bargaining agreement yesterday, officially ushering in what officials said would be a new era for the sport.

title: More Social Workers Sought
description: Saying that social workers for the Division of Youth and Family Services are severely overloaded, unions that represent the caseworkers announced yesterday that they would ask the State Legislature for $40 million to hire 450 additional caseworkers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, MORRIS M.
description: SCHNITZER-Morris M., 86, died on March 8, 1997, in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, NJ, following a short illness. He was a distinguished lawyer, legal scholar and teacher. His colleagues on the Editorial Board of the New Jersey Law Journal pay him honor.

title: Tide of Albanian Refugees Again Floods Italian Port
description: An odd collection of boats from a freighter to a yacht to antique torpedo boats -- have brought scores of Albanians to southern Italy this week and led Italians to worry that they face a repeat of the great exodus of 1991.

title: Principal Tied To a Scandal Is Retiring
description: Three weeks after the school board here began proceedings to dismiss the principal of an award-winning elementary school in a test-tampering scandal, he announced his retirement today.

title: U.S. Banks' Earnings in 1996 Highest Ever
description: United States commercial banks earned $52.4 billion in 1996, the highest level ever, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: A Little-Heard Russian Masterpiece
description: On Thursday night, somewhere deep in the west corner of the Metropolitan Opera House, Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin'' was being played. So difficult was it to hear and see, one can only assume that a strategy of concealment was at work. In Robert Carsen's new production, towering blank facades and a deep raked stage render people small and music distant.

title: $2.5 Million a Year for Ex-WMX Chief
description: WMX Technologies Inc. will pay its former chief executive, Phillip Rooney, $2.5 million a year until 2002.

title: Fred Zinnemann, Director of Many Classics, Dies at 89
description: Fred Zinnemann, the director who grappled with issues of moral courage in such Academy Award-winning films as ''From Here to Eternity'' in 1953 and ''A Man for All Seasons'' in 1966, died yesterday at his home in London. He was 89.

title: Hong Kong Retailer in Deal With China
description: Giordano International Ltd., a Hong Kong retailer, has sold an equity stake of about 5 percent to companies backed by the Chinese Army and powerful ministries. The sale is seen as an effort to overcome official moves to block the company's expansion in China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARY ALICE
description: MURPHY-Mary Alice. On March 13, in Essex, CT. Beloved daughter of the late Peter and Lillian Murphy, of Scarsdale, New York. Sister of Claire, Emmett, Gerald and Daniel, and cherished friend of many. Mass of Christian Burial March 17, at 11 A.M., St. Aloysius Church, New Canaan, CT., followed by burial at Holy Mount Cemetery, Eastchester, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family appreciates memorials to Parkinson Disease Association, 800-223-2732.

description: CHANIN-Marcy. Dear friend and neighbor. We will always remember and miss you. Marie and Sam

title: Chattanooga and Copping State Give the Brackets a Jolt: South Carolina Falls to 15th-Seeded Eagles
description: Coppin State's backup point guard, Danny Singletary, knew from the moment he saw the bracket. He was sitting in the basement of the school library, eating cake and watching the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament selection show with his teammates, when he discovered that Coppin State, seeded 15th, would play second-seeded South Carolina.

title: Deadbeats in Albany
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is only the latest in a long line of City Hall occupants to charge that state government shortchanges New York City in all sorts of programs. But he may be the first mayor to accuse the governor and the Legislature in Albany of being deadbeats. Mr. Giuliani declared this week that the state had systematically withheld $900 million in education aid for which claims had been filed and validated under existing programs. The Mayor is right to demand the payment, but the city must accept a share of blame for the problem.

title: Dow Gains On Favorable Price Report
description: Stock prices rebounded yesterday after a disastrous performance on Thursday, helped by economic data that showed few signs of inflationary pressure.

title: Page's Cold Shooting Ousts Georgetown Early
description: The matchup that Georgetown prefers Victor Page versus the world -- did not pan out. It is not a Hoya possession until Page lets one fly from 25 feet, on Coach John Thompson's orders, and the result this afternoon was two air balls, two backboard-only balls, two blown finger rolls, 7-of-23 shooting and a quick flight back to the nation's capital.

title: Research Team Takes Big Stride In the Mapping of Human Genes
description: Reaching a significant goal in the project to explore the mysteries of human genes, biologists have completed a high-resolution map of the X chromosome, one of the pair that determines whether a baby is a boy or a girl.

title: Vying for Bottom Honors
description: There is a deliciously wicked idea behind ''The Second Civil War,'' a satire that takes aim at a wealth of deserving targets: the immigration issue, politics as imagery, television news.

title: Newspaper Sues to Open Investigation Files, but Giuliani Aides Cite a Need for Privacy
description: Lawyers for The Daily News tried in court yesterday to gain access to reports of investigations into corruption and misconduct by city officials, but the Giuliani administration continued to argue that many of the records should be closed to protect employees' privacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LOUISE HAWLEY HIGGINS
description: STONE-Louise Hawley Higgins. Peacefully, at the Balmoral Club, Toronto on March 9, 1997, in her 94th year. Beloved wife of the late Louis Higgins and the late Edgar Stone. Dear daughter of the late Fred and Miriam Hawley. Sister of the late William Hawley. Stepmother of Richard Stone and Elizabeth Elliott. Aunt of Louise, Kay, Helen, Evelyn and the late Fred. Louise was a longtime patron of the Royal Ontario Museum, serving on the Board of Directors and especially the Bishop White Committee which she chaired for many years, establishing the Far Eastern Endowment Fund. In 1996, she created the Louise Hawley Stone Chair of Far Eastern Art. Private service was held followed by cremation. Memorial donations may be made to Far Eastern Endowment Fund. The Bishop White Committee, The Royal Ontario Museum, 100 Queen's Park Crescent, Toronto, Ontario M5S 2C6.

title: Evidence in Queens for a Trial in China
description: It was a brutal example of a type of crime that has plagued illegal immigrants from China in recent years: a woman was kidnapped on a Queens street corner in January of 1996 and raped and tortured while her captors demanded ransom money from her family in Fuzhou. The lead that helped the New York Police Department crack the case and rescue the woman came from an unlikely quarter: their police counterparts in China, who traced phone calls that the kidnappers made to the victim's relatives.

description: BUCK-Margaret Waring, 91, of Mystic, CT on March 13, 1997. Noted author and illustrator. Graduate of Art Students League. For information, call Dinoto Funeral Home, (860) 536-2685.

description: To the Editor:

description: TREMBLAY-James. June 25, 1958-March 15, 1996. Not a single day goes by. Perry
