description: STEVENS-Kate. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Ira and Laurie and Judy. Adored grandmother and great grandmother. Services will be held on Sunday 10am at the ''Dix Hills Chapel'' of I.J. Morris Inc., Long Island.

title: WABASH TO ACQUIRE FRUEHAUF TRAILER ASSETS
description: The Wabash National Corporation, the largest United States maker of truck trailers, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the retail network and other assets of the rival Fruehauf Trailer Corporation for about $49 million. Fruehauf filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in October. The sale must be approved by the bankruptcy court. Wabash will pay $15 million in cash, $17.6 million of a new issue of convertible preferred stock and one million shares of its stock, which rose 50 cents yesterday, to $16.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The acquisition includes Fruehauf's sales and distribution network; a trailer plant in Huntsville, Tenn., and the Fruehauf trade name in North America. It excludes plants in Mexico and Fort Madison, Iowa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORENZ, ANNA STELLA
description: LORENZ-Anna Stella, age 85, died March 13, 1997. For 58 years devoted wife of Gunter Lorenz, MD, beloved mother of Linda Marion Gerstman and son-in-law Stephen Gerstman, DDS, cherished grandmother of Elissa Eve Fullerton and husband John Fullerton, III, JD and Sherry Michelle Gerstman. Loving sister of Malka Schumm and husband Werner. She will be remembered by her family and friends for her boundless love and kindness. Service at Temple Beth Abraham Conservative Chapel, 25 Leroy Ave., Tarrytown, NY 10591 Sunday, March 16, 1997, at 1 PM.

title: Delta Blues, Including Long Jokes And Lust
description: It felt like the early-60's blues revival all over again at Wetlands on Thursday night, except this time the young idolaters wore bell-bottoms and baby T-shirts instead of corduroy jackets and desert boots. They were there to see R. L. Burnside, a 70-year-old northern Mississippi blues singer and guitarist whose one-chord style is the antithesis of shiny Chicago blues; his new fans are the fallout from his recent collaborative album with the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, and now his own records are distributed by Epitaph, a West Coast punk label.

title: Army of Strange Bedfellows Battles Spending Limits
description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and longtime antagonist of limits on campaign spending, assembled an array of strange bedfellows to stand with him today and declare their own opposition to spending limits.

title: Clinton Has Knee Surgery to Repair Tendon After Fall
description: President Clinton underwent successful surgery this afternoon to reattach a tendon that tore from his right kneecap with a loud pop when he stumbled down shadowy steps outside the golfer Greg Norman's house in Florida early this morning.

title: Sponsors Unite to Preserve Mount Sinai Monastery
description: Ever since the Byzantine emperor Justinian ordered it built at the foot of Mount Sinai 1,470 years ago, the Monastery of St. Catherine has drawn pilgrims from far and wide.

title: Chattanooga and Coppin State Give the Brackets a Jolt
description: The decisive blow was delivered in the game's first five minutes. But not until an attempt at a tying 3-pointer was blocked at the buzzer did 14th-seeded Tennessee-Chattanooga secure its stunning 73-70 defeat of third-seeded Georgia in this afternoon's opening round of the Southeast Regional of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: 7 of 9 Faces Seen Near Bomb Site At the Olympics Are Identified
description: Less than 24 hours after releasing images of nine people wanted for questioning in last summer's bombing at Centennial Olympic Park, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had located seven of the nine.

title: Dairy Cartel Serves No Public Interest
description: Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman blundered last year when he approved a dairy cartel in the Northeast that would jack up consumer prices by perhaps 25 percent. Fortunately, Mr. Glickman can now make amends. A Federal judge ordered him to show by March 20 that the cartel would, as Congress required, serve a ''compelling public interest.'' Mr. Glickman should admit that he cannot meet that challenge.

title: Pace Performs for Jets
description: ORLANDO PACE, college football's top-rated player, put on a show for BILL BELICHICK, the Jets' assistant head coach, and BILL MUIR, the team's line coach, in a series of agility drills yesterday at Ohio State University.

title: Radioactive Water Found in Lab Tank
description: Adding to public concerns about the handling of radioactive materials at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, Federal energy officials said yesterday that they had found high levels of two hazardous radioactive substances in 750 gallons of water pumped from an old underground tank there.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALI, SYED AMJAD
description: ALI-Syed Amjad. Memorial services for Ambassador Ali will be held at the United Nations Church Center, 11:00AM, Friday, May 9th at 1st Ave at 44th St. For info call 201-342-5700 or 212-749-2658.

title: Spielberg Seeks Access to Bluff Point
description: In 1975, the State Legislature created the Bluff Point Coastal Reserve and State Park -- 800 acres of pristine forest, wetlands and beachfront on Long Island Sound. Hemmed in by housing projects, strip malls and an airport, the rectangular peninsula remains the state's only coastal preserve and, by law, is open only to pedestrians, bicyclers and horseback riders.

title: Accused Mexican Says Chaos Led Him to Ship Out Money
description: Mario Ruiz Massieu, who deposited $9 million in a Texas bank while he was a Deputy Attorney General of Mexico, said in a Federal court here today that he had assembled the money and shipped it out of the country in suitcases because of fear that Mexico was sliding into chaos.

title: Demand Propels Soybeans, While Coffee Prices Recover
description: Soybean prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after a report signaled domestic demand was at a record pace amid rising consumption of livestock feed.

title: A Band of the 60's With Mushrooms on the Mind
description: During Tuesday's opening of its 10-night stand at the Beacon Theater, the Allman Brothers Band had about 20 friends at stage left, sitting or visibly milling around; it looked like a backyard performance. It's a gesture of looseness, but the members of the band radiate dedication; they played hard, said nearly nothing between songs, and though they sometimes sauntered off after finishing a solo, nobody missed a returning cue.

title: Apple to Trim Jobs and Its Product Line
description: Saying it was finally turning a corner, but leaving many questions unanswered, Apple Computer Inc. announced today that it would lay off 4,100 employees and temporary workers. Apple will take charges totaling $250 million over the next three quarters to pay for the job cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISGALL, HUGO
description: WEISGALL-Hugo. The faculty, students and administration of the Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College mourn the death of Queens College Distinguished Professor Emeritus Hugo Weisgall. His ruggedly beautiful, deeply emotional and superbly crafted operas, choral works and song cycles brought Dr. Weisgall international recognition and brought honor to this institution. Joining the music faculty in 1960, Dr. Weisgall inspired generations of young composers, directed the opera workshop which gave New York premieres for many contemporary works, and conducted the choir and the orchestra. We offer Nathalie Weisgall and their children Deborah and Jonathan our heartfelt condolences. Allen Lee Sessoms, President Queens College, City University of New York Hubert S. Howe, Jr., Director Aaron Copland School of Music Raymond Erickson, Dean, Arts and Humanities

title: Repairman Dies in Fall From Roof of Hotel
description: A repairman died yesterday after slipping and falling at a midtown Manhattan hotel where he was servicing the air-conditioners, the police said. The accident happened before noon at the Ritz Tower Hotel at 57th Street and Park Avenue, said Officer Eve Serrano, a police spokeswoman.

title: Staying Over? This Theater Has a Bunk Stage
description: The Studio Theater here thinks it has solved the problem of what to do when it has a hit but has another show coming in: it has built an almost identical copy of itself on the floor above.

title: Centers Stays With Cardinals
description: The Arizona Cardinals re-signed the free agent LARRY CENTERS to a three-year contract, keeping the National Football League's top receiving running back with the team and making him the fifth highest-paid running back in the league.

title: Bridge
description: Two teams led by New York experts clashed in the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here this afternoon. After 32 of 64 deals, Richard Schwartz of East Elmhurst, Queens, and his squad led Jim Cayne of Manhattan and his team by 56 imps.

title: Return of the Wrestlers
description: Professional wrestling may be staging a comeback in New Jersey.

title: New Government Rule Seeks to Stem Danger From Air Bags
description: Responding to reports that air bags had killed automobile occupants, most of them children, in 62 crashes during the last decade, the Federal Government told car manufacturers today that they would now be permitted to make bags that open with less force.

title: AIDS Drug Is Approved As Therapy For Children
description: Children infected with the virus that causes AIDS became eligible today to receive a potent new class of drugs that has sharply reduced the virus's level in adults.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RUBBERMAID INC., Wooster, Ohio, said its Little Tikes unit would close its third toy-making plant, eliminating a total of 725 jobs since November because of slow sales and stiff toy industry competition.

title: Participant on Trade Mission Was Aided by Labor Nominee
description: President Clinton's nominee for Labor Secretary, Alexis M. Herman, helped secure a seat on a Commerce Department trade mission last year for a company owned by the woman who bought Ms. Herman's private consulting firm in 1993, the White House said today.

description: NEW YORK  It is hard to trace the exact moment when Madison transcended Fifth in the role of most chic avenue.

title: PREMISYS STOCK FALLS, WITH QUARTERLY LOSS EXPECTED
description: Shares of Premisys Communications Inc. dropped sharply yesterday for the second straight day as the company said it expected to report a loss for its third quarter. The company, a maker of communications equipment, expected a loss of 10 cents to 14 cents a share in the third quarter ending March 31, on revenue of $10 million to $12 million. Wall Street had expected the company to earn 24 cents a share in the latest period, according to First Call Inc., which tracks analysts' earnings forecasts. On the Nasdaq stock market, Premisys stock, which dropped 21 percent on Thursday before the announcement, fell another 28 percent, or $3.1875, to close at $8.0625.

title: Offspring Of Clashing Influences
description: Performing in his Denver-based quintet on Wednesday night at Iridium, Ginger Baker sounded at first as if he wasn't playing jazz right. Mr. Baker was the drummer for the band Cream from 1966 to 1969, and he retains a rock overgrip like a war wound. But he is a deceptive musician who implies a lot with a little, and often -- conversely -- a delicate idea with a heavy technique.

title: But Today's Dandies More Fake Than Real : Decadence Comes Back Into Style
description: PARIS  Excess is its own reward, of course, and the more wretched the better. With the usual glossy fashion magazines full of vulnerable looking children  of both sexes  with come-hither poses and heroin-addict palor, with ads for big-name designers projecting debauchery, wanton luxury and perhaps worst of all stupidity, has fashion reached some kind of ultimate decadence?

title: Unwelcome in the Oval Office
description: The Indonesian businessman Mochtar Riady, founder of a $5 billion business empire that contributed to the Democratic National Committee, met personally with President Clinton twice. His son James Riady had six meetings with the President, some of which included policy discussions about Indonesia. But the President, regrettably, had no time to meet with a Nobel Peace Prize winner from Indonesian-occupied East Timor who recently visited the United States for two weeks.

title: Dwight L. Wilbur, 93, President Of A.M.A. Who Aided Medicare
description: Dr. Dwight Locke Wilbur, a prominent San Francisco gastroenterologist and past president of the American Medical Association, who helped overcome the organization's aversion to Medicare as ''socialized medicine,'' died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 93.

title: China Rising
description: The Coming conflict With China By Richard Bernstein and Ross H. Munro. 245 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: Healing Through Reliving
description: Robert W. Maras was sent home from Vietnam in 1968, but he says he did not really come home until more than two decades later. His nightmares and night sweats surface less often these days, but the two pieces of shrapnel that punctured his right inner thigh are still kept in a plastic jar inside a kitchen cabinet.

title: Praise for the Stately Salvia, in All Its Forms
description: SALVIAS are coming into their own, helped along in no small part by the Perennial Plant Association. The trade group selects a Perennial of the Year as the plant to promote and propagate and this year's winner is May Night, a hybrid salvia that was bred in Germany by Karl Foerster.

title: Adventures In Dance
description: THE accent is on the international in European dance festivals this summer. Audiences will be able to travel to the Far East and Africa without leaving the Continent. Much of the most imaginative festival programming takes place in northern Europe. Festival-happy Finland takes top dance honors this year, with the always lively Kuopio Dance Festival leading the way in late June. Now in its 28th year in the pretty town, which is in the country's eastern lake district, this major event will focus on dance from Finland and Western Europe, with a little Japanese Butoh dance, puppetry and Arabian dance for good measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KEEFE, MARY ELEANOR, R.D.H., L.H.S. (NEE GILMARTIN)
description: O'KEEFE-Mary Eleanor, R.D.H., L.H.S. (nee Gilmartin). On March 14, 1997, of Forest Hills, NY. Active member Ladies of Charity, the Legion of Decency, Volunteer Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital, Bellevue Hospital, American Red Cross and United Hospital Fund. Beloved wife of John J. O'Keefe, D.D.S., for over 62 years. Daughter of the late John and Mary Gilmartin. Sister of Daniel and the late Robert. Dear aunt of 14 nephews and nieces and many grand- and great-grandnephews and nieces. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY, Sunday, 7-9 PM, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Tuesday, March 18, at 10:15 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: FOUR GIRLS ABDUCTED, RAPED, MURDERED. A COUNTRY ON TRIAL.
description: Can the Belgian justice system's failure to protect Belgium's daughters be compared with the New York City child welfare system's inability to protect our own (''Four Girls Abducted, Raped, Murdered. A Country on Trial,'' by Timothy W. Ryback, Feb. 23)?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, FRED D.
description: FELDMAN-Fred D. Died Mar. 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Louise (Koeppel), devoted father of Arlee and Richard Weiss, Jacalyn and Andrew Aaron, Carol and Mark Feldman. Loving grandfather of Michael Weiss, Robert Aaron, Meredith Aaron, Mindy Weiss, Stephanie Aaron, Alison Feldman, and Megan Feldman. Devoted brother of Leonore and Jerome Tesler. Funeral Services March 16, 1997, 10:30 AM, Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY.

description: Correction Appended

title: Ms. Holland And Mr. Weiss
description: Elizabeth Nan Holland and Alvin J. Weiss were married last evening in New York. Judge Ilana Diamond Rovner of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago officiated at the University Club.

title: Milestone Victory Puts Smith in a Class by Himself
description: The buzzer sounded, an achievement Dean Smith called his ''so-called record'' was secured and Serge Zwikker took off across the basketball court. An instant after North Carolina's 73-56 victory over Colorado increased Smith's career total to 877, one more than that of Adolph Rupp of Kentucky, Zwikker, the Tar Heels' 7-foot-3-inch center, took the basketball from the hands of a Colorado guard, held it over his head and carried it into history -- until he was stopped by security.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Photos That Lie -- and Tell the Truth
description: WHAT'S GOING ON IN THIS photograph? Two girls on the edge of puberty are wading a stream. One is pensive, turned inward. The other looks around and stops in mid-action, spying something that frightens her in the darkness of a tunnel. What a decisive moment, and how fraught with sexual symbolism! Jeff Wall, the photographer, must have been poised to take the picture at the second the revelation occurred.

title: Milbury Torn as Islanders Lose Key Game
description: It is three days until the Tuesday trading deadline, and Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury is still not sure if he wants to add or subtract.

title: All Talk, No Action, on Irabu
description: The pursuit of Hideki Irabu continued to run in place today. Despite a belief in baseball circles that the San Diego Padres would trade negotiating rights to the Japanese pitcher by this weekend, they did not seem prepared to make that move.

title: Starbird Hurts Her Ankle In Stanford's Easy Victory
description: Stanford, hoping to reach its sixth Final Four in eight years, easily dispatched Howard, 111-59, tonight in the first round of the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

description: President Mary Robinson's decision not to seek a second seven-year term has thrown Irish politics into turmoil.

description: A picture last Sunday with an article about a planned buyout of a Sunbeam Corporation textile plant in Biddeford, Me., was published in error. It showed part of the former Bates textile operations in Saco, across the Saco River from Biddeford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: EPSTEIN-Dorothy. Mother of Phyllis Florin and Irwin Epstein. Loving grandmother of Toni, Jody, Gale and Abby. Great grandmother of six. She will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONO, HARVEY
description: KONO-Harvey. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Harvey Kono, beloved brother of our devoted members Roberta and David Geula. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Multimedia Show Tells Stories of Jewish Life
description: IN an effort to demonstrate to children that the history and values of Judaism are as applicable today as they were ages ago, the Chabad Lubavitch of Westchester will be the host to a multimedia, interactive traveling exhibition demonstrating the religion's practices, holidays and heritage.

title: Ding, Ding, Ding . . . The Trolley Goes Again
description: TO Mae Hodge, a life-long resident of Danbury, the bright red trolley that traverses the downtown district on weekends is pleasing; enough so that she recently took her granddaughter Sterling Karakula, 4, along for a Saturday afternoon ride. As the pair stepped in, Mrs. Hodge dropped two quarters into the fare box to pay Sterling's way, and four more to pay her own.

title: An Unwelcome Stowaway Comes In on the Basil
description: Sweet basil is among the most reliable of herbs, an easy-care plant that ordinarily asks little in the way of special care and gives back much in the way of pesto. So, it was a great mystery four years ago when my basil plants began to die at the peak of the season.

title: Linda Walsh, Peter J. Ward
description: Linda Walsh, a daughter of Ellen Walsh of Old Bridge Township, N.J., and the late John Walsh, was married yesterday to Peter Joseph Ward, a son of Mary S. Ward of Piscataway, N.J., and the late John F. Ward. The Rev. Eugene Gniewyk performed the ceremony at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: The Law and the Lawless on the Road
description: CRUISING of Vehicles on This Roadway Is Prohibited 9 P.M. to 4 A.M.''

title: African Burial Ground Is Documented in Film
description: HISTORY has a way of shaping reality. Eric V. Tait Jr., a veteran journalist and documentarian, has produced a film that has reshaped the contours of the past and gives life to a track of history that has gone largely forgotten.

description: Ragtag Police Recruits Roam Capital of Albania

title: Blowing Smoke
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE ISLAMIST WHO RUNS TURKEY, DELICATELY
description: Stephen Kinzer's failure to mention Cyprus in an article purporting to examine the West's problems with Turkey is a troubling omission. Along with widespread human rights violations and the ethnic cleansing of over a million Kurds from rural areas in Turkish Kurdistan, Turkey's nightmarish 1974 invasion of Cyprus -- leaving Nicosia the last divided European capital -- is perhaps the most recurring reason offered by European Union ministers for Turkey's exclusion from Europe.

title: Opera Deep in the Brazilian Rain Forest
description: After a 90-year absence, opera returns next month to the Teatro Amazonas, a 19th-century Belle Epoque opera house deep within Brazil's rain forest. The hall will be the site of the Manaus Festival, a two-week international music festival April 5 to 20, with three opera productions, chamber and symphonic concerts, and recitals.

title: CLINTON CRAZY
description: Kudos to Philip Weiss for taking on the ''Clinton crazies.'' Speaking from personal experience with many of the same crowd Weiss talked to, I can say that they may seem crazy but their wrath is very real.

title: A Young Film Maker's Road Movie That's Bound to Family Ties
description: FEW years ago, during the Christmas holidays when grown children tend to return to suburban nests they previously had flown, Greg Mottola and his older brother, Thomas, were in the family car driving around their hometown Dix Hills on the way to visit a relative.

title: Player Works Toward N.B.A.
description: AT 21, 7-foot Mark Blount's checkered past is still close behind him. The basketball media guide for the University of Pittsburgh, where Blount, as a sophomore, is currently the starting center, lists three high schools he attended before settling in at Dobbs Ferry High School where he played his senior season. In all, Blount enrolled in seven high schools in South Carolina, Virginia and New York.

title: Close Knit, but Closed Out
description: In a kitchen on 86th Avenue in Briarwood, Queens, Istam Kaziyeva, a 67-year-old Bukharian Jewish woman from Tashkent, Uzbekistan, rolls a stiff, tan ball of dough into a flat circle about the size of a medium pizza. She then carefully places the bread over the rounded bottom of a wok turned upside down and slides it into her natural gas oven to bake.

title: Every Funny Family Is Funny in Its Own Way
description: NAKED By David Sedaris. 291 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $21.95.

title: To Have and to Hyphenate: The Marriage Name Game
description: WHEN I first met my husband-to-be at a publishing party several years ago, he glanced at my name tag and saw Kismet. Actually he saw ''Peterson,'' but it was the opening gambit he was searching for.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 16, 1997
description: Correction Appended

title: Drug Arrests Rise 18% on Major College Campuses, Survey Finds
description: Drug arrests on major college campuses climbed by almost 18 percent in 1995, according to the annual survey of campus crime by The Chronicle of Higher Education. Some college officials attributed the rise to stricter enforcement of drug laws rather than to increased drug use.

title: Under Attack, Clinton Gets No Cover From Party
description: Democrats in Congress are offering no defense of President Clinton as he struggles against one accusation of improper campaign fund-raising after another.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Prelude to Spring
description: A lightened-up fashion look has appeared as winter lingers and spring is yet to come. It's the small, fitted proportion of the short coat in light-colored wool or leather. The shortest coat (second from right) has three inches of slip dress showing . A lightweight leather sash-tied coat (center) has a nonchalant style. Winter's scarf is being replaced with an open-neck white shirt and a black jacket collar showing over a white waffle-textured coat (far left).

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Plate Spinner

title: Lifting the Veil From Marrakesh
description: ''I MUST be with you when you see the sunset on the snows of the Atlas Mountains,'' Sir Winston Churchill told President Roosevelt after the Casablanca Conference in 1943. So they went to take in the view from the perfect vantage point: Marrakesh, a city on a dusty plain surrounded by crumbling 12th-century ramparts, made of pink clay called pise, and phalanxes of olive trees watered by runoff from the High Atlas.

title: A New Life for an Old Club
description: Even for the sake of survival, it may have seemed unseemly or humiliating for members of the Montauk Club, Brooklyn's version of Boston Brahmins, to allow three floors of their historic clubhouse to be carved up as condominium apartments.

title: THE LOOTING AND SMUGGLING . . . OF WILD THINGS
description: Donovan Webster contrasted beautifully the insatiable lust for material objects of many Americans with indigent peoples' simple desire for basic necessities (''The Looting and Smuggling and Fencing and Hoarding of Impossibly Precious, Feathered and Scaly Wild Things,'' Feb. 16). Perhaps the environmental organizations can factor into their budgets payments to the lowest end of the hierarchy not to catch these precious animals. I imagine this could easily satisfy people who have not been socialized for greed regardless of the monetary or environmental costs. As for the Americans, I suggest that they get a dog or a goldfish.

title: Way Out West and Under the Influence
description: IT was like the buzz of 1,000 cups of coffee, Joy said. It kept her up for days at a time, and set her to cleaning the house like the old white tornado commercials for Ajax. It whisked away her post-partum depression and made staying slim a breeze.

description: To the Editor:

title: On Law Firms And Teacher Contracts
description: I read with interest the article on law firms that ''dominate'' teacher contracts $(''3 Law Firms Dominate Contracts for Teachers,'' Feb. 16$). I am a teacher in Massapequa as well as an officer and negotiator for the Massapequa Federation of Teachers.

title: The Cut-Rate War
description: SHOOTING AT THE MOON The Story of America's Clandestine War in Laos. By Roger Warner. Illustrated. 436 pp. South Royalton, Vt.: Steerforth Press. Paper, $18.

title: Mob Rule
description: RESURRECTION The Struggle for a New Russia. By David Remnick. 398 pp. New York: Random House. $25.95.

title: Friends of 'Freeland'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Zealand Trek
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''A Hiking Trip Proves Sweat Free'' by Philip Shabecoff (Jan. 5) about the Hollyford trek in New Zealand. Another great walk in the region is the Routeburn trek. This involves a moderate amount of hill climbing, but the views are spectacular. I took an escorted hike, but ''freedom walkers'' can use the trail, provided they carry food and cooking gear and can find a bunk at the first come, first served huts on the trail.

title: Talking About Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Definition Politicking
description: President Clinton asked broadcasters last week to give away air time to political candidates so they would be freed from raising money for television commercials and could ''talk directly to the voters without gimmicks or intermediaries.'' In exchange, Mr. Clinton proposed that the broadcasters would get new licenses to provide digital high-definition television. The broadcasters protested, saying the plan would cost them dearly and would violate their First Amendment right to free speech and their Fifth Amendment right not to have their private property taken for public use without just compensation.

title: Albania Arming a New Police Force
description: Scraggly-looking men with rough faces and disheveled clothing jostled outside the gate of police station No. 2 here this morning, some wielding automatic rifles, others waiting for their weapons to be issued by the police chief inside.

title: Teen-Agers Sound a Lot Like Grown-Ups
description: BACKSTAGE AT THE Grammy Awards last month, Fiona Apple, 19, did a teen-age double take when she was informed that LeAnn Rimes, the country singer who was named best new artist, was only 14. ''No way!'' Apple yelped, then calmed down. ''Well, I guess I'm not the youngest person in the room anymore.''

title: In Its Reward in Cosby Case, Tabloid Tapped a Tradition
description: It is not the same as posting ''Reward -- Dead or Alive'' on the wall of some Western saloon, but the $100,000 reward offered by The National Enquirer that helped bring an arrest in the killing of Ennis Cosby was only the latest expression of a newspaper tradition extending to the most lurid days of the yellow press.

title: Daddy's Big Test
description: He putters along the palm-shaded walk of the Breakers West tennis club in a golf cart. Birds chirp in the palms under a yellow sun and a blue sky. His wife, wearing a sweatshirt with a cartoon figure on the front, walks behind, bouncing a basketball. His two daughters, in tennis whites, are carrying racquets and giggling. He is wearing tennis whites, too. He is a burly, hunched-over black man in his 50's with a grayish beard, smoking a thin brown cigarette and clutching a cellular phone. He stops at an umbrella-shaded white metal table between two green tennis courts.

title: 'Karma' Doesn't Explain Bad Health of Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Counting Heads
description: The 1990 census almost surely missed several million people, most from minority groups. In the year 2000, the Census Bureau plans to use statistical sampling to make up for the households that do not respond. The Supreme Court has not ruled, though, on whether statistical sampling can be part of the ''enumeration,'' or whether an actual head count, however flawed, is required by the Constitution. DAVID STOUT

title: The Road to Babbittville
description: A SUPPOSEDLY FUN

title: From the Ice All the Way To Viewers
description: THIS winter, the airwaves have been wild with figure skating: professional competitions, Rock-and-Roll championships, Stars on Ice, Disney characters on ice and the old familiar amateur contests. Amid this avalanche of on-ice warfare, there has been one constant: ABC's coverage of the United States Figure Skating championships, which the network has broadcast faithfully, up close and personally, since 1964.

title: For Friends Seminary, New Classroom Space
description: Friends Seminary, on Rutherford Place near Stuyvesant Square, plans to buy the German Masonic Temple across the street, and to relocate some of its upper-school classes there.

title: Steer Clear: Trouble Spots on the Roadways to Avoid, if You Can
description: Trouble spots you can expect to encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of the State Department of Transportation.

title: A London Bridge Is Falling Down
description: Driving in traffic-clogged London isn't getting any easier, with construction work on two main west London routes. An area that already suffers from severe congestion has been worse than ever since the Hammersmith Bridge was closed to cars and trucks last month. And the M4 highway elevated section between junctions 1 and 2, and the adjacent A4 road, the main routes between Heathrow Airport and central London, will also be closed occasionally until May. Both structures need major repairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACK, ROSE
description: PACK-Rose, on March 12, in Florida. Devoted mother of Harvey Pack and Carol Katz. Adored grandmother of Michael Pack, Julie Blewis, Noel Katz, Jillian Pierson, and 5 great-grandchildren.

title: Lively Lessons In African Tradition
description: LAST MONTH AT RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL, the gala opening of the documentary ''When We Were Kings'' included appearances by B. B. King, the Fugees and the film's subject himself, Muhammad Ali. But 38 New York City schoolchildren nearly stole the show. They were members of Batoto Yetu, a troupe that performs African dances. Dressed in grass skirts, their bodies painted with colorful stripes, they shimmied, jumped and circled their hips wildly to the beat of djimbe, conga and songba drums, all the while chanting in two African dialects: Tshiluba, a language of the Luba tribe of Zaire, and Kimbundu, from northern Angola.

title: Measuring Inflation: Can't Do It, Can't Stop Trying
description: THE votes are in and, not surprisingly, they are unanimous: the Consumer Price Index fails to measure inflation accurately. For many economists, fixing the problem is a technical matter, and they argue over the degree of inaccuracy and how to fix it.

title: New Building Boom in Hamptons
description: THE allure of the Hamptons and prosperity on Wall Street are creating a bull market for land and new housing in the towns of Southampton and East Hampton, where development of farmland and other open areas is rivaling the pace set during the real estate boom of the mid 1980's, according to some conservation groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, HELEN I.
description: DAVIS-Helen I., 100, formerly of NYC. On Feb. 27, at Heath Village Retirement Community, Hacketstown, NJ, her residence since 1975. Memorial service Mar. 18 at the Village. No family survivors.

title: Welfare Reform Spurs Worry About Effects
description: AMID uncertainty about how welfare reform will be interpreted at the local level, advocates for the poor crowded into a standing-room-only session at the public library here early last month to discuss the potential impact of the changes with local, state and Federal legislators.

title: Sotheby's Realty Buys A Hamptons Firm
description: Sotheby's International Realty has bought Braverman Newbold Brennan, a two-decade-old Hamptons brokerage with 28 agents and two valuable office locations in East Hampton and Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about politicians who justify unethical behavior on the ground that their opponents also engage in it referred incorrectly to a prominent child development expert at Tufts University who said children should be taught to take responsibility for their actions. He is David Elkind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRIS, ADRIAN G.
description: FERRIS-Adrian G., passed away peacefully in Coral Springs, FL., March 3, 1997. Devoted, loving husband of Tina, adored brother of Dr. Craig and Nancy Ferris, uncle of Sam and Ian of Aurora, Ohio, and the late Norma Garcia Ferris, revered son of the late Samuel William and Norma Ferris of NYC. We shall miss him terribly.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 23 about ''Blood on the Fields,'' Wynton Marsalis's oratorio about slavery, referred incorrectly to commissions by the Jazz at Lincoln Center program since its beginning in 1987. Eight works -- not none -- have been commissioned from white musicians.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a wholesaler's reporting error, the paperback fiction best-seller list on page 32 of the Times Book Review today includes two books erroneously and omits two. ''Harm's Way,'' by Stephen White (No. 9), and ''Rebel,'' by Heather Graham (No. 10), should not be listed. The books listed as 11 through 16 should each appear two positions higher.

title: BALANCING ACT
description: On Thursday, Donna Henes -- a self-described urban shaman -- will usher in spring by balancing 360 raw eggs on their broad ends at the plaza of the World Trade Center. Henes believes that the eggs are balanceable because of the vernal equinox, when the sun crosses the equator -- this year at 8:55 A.M., to be exact. Scientists retort that eggs are simply balanceable, period. (In 1945, Albert Einstein was reportedly dubious about a similar outbreak of springtime ovomania in Chungking.) According to Robert Novick, a Columbia University physicist, each of Henes's eggs will feel a two-and-one-third-gram tug from the sun's gravity, but the pull, if anything, would tend to topple them. On the other hand, who needs science? When I feel the yolk shift in my hand, Henes says, I feel the earth still spinning, and I know that everything will be O.K.

title: The Bones of a New Machine
description: WE'VE been drinking out of it, hitting baseballs with it and pedaling bikes made of it. It's aluminum, and it could someday supplant steel as the metal of choice in automobiles.

title: Murderous Places
description: To the Editor: What a promising series Marilyn Stasio inaugurates with the Edinburgh of her ''A Wonderful Place for Murder'' (Jan. 12). I wish it the best, and so call attention to the provincialism of the announcement saying the series will discuss the ''link between a city and its fictional detectives.'' Yet the ''place'' in the headline includes more than urban and megapolitan areas; it includes towns and villages, even the countryside and wilderness.

title: Will Electric Bills Go Up or Down?
description: CONNECTICUT is coming late to the table of deregulation concerning the electric utility industry within its borders. But, though the issue may not spark wild enthusiasm among most state residents, legislation now under consideration could have a profound impact on consumers' wallets, as well as the state's environmental quality.

title: Butterflies at a Wedding? It's Only Natural
description: SINCE throwing rice or confetti has been deemed environmentally incorrect, wedding guests have been inventing more earth-friendly alternatives, from blowing soap bubbles to tossing rose petals and birdseed and breakfast cereal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEECHER, MARGERY
description: BEECHER-Margery. Age 86. On March 13, 1997 after a prolonged illness. Beloved wife for 63 years to Lawrence (Larry) Beecher. Loving mother of Andrew and Robert. Dear grandmother of Amy and Owen. Devoted sister of Stanton Gottlieb. Service Sunday 11AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. She will always be remembered for her style, humor and love of the ballet, opera and travel. She will never be forgotten. Contributions in her memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Yes, We Have No Tolerance
description: Got a problem? Don't know how to solve it? Take a tip from the nation's top bureaucrats. Declare a ''zero tolerance'' policy.

title: A Century-Old Block That Retains Its Integrity
description: FROM the top of a stoop, a New York street looks very different, more balanced. The lines of parked cars recede, and the block has the sense of a room rather than the bottom of a canyon.

title: The Faithful Are Casual At This Sunday Service
description: It is Sunday night and the faithful are assembling, dressed in sweats, baseball caps and the classic Northwest mix of hiking boots and shorts over thermal underwear.

title: Historic, Sparsely Settled -- and Loving It
description: ALTHOUGH at the midway point of the congested New York-Philadelphia corridor, the 13-square-mile township of Cranbury has just 2,800 people and fewer than 1,000 homes.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Legend of Pulpit Takes a Surprising Twist
description: The myth and the winning streak came tumbling down today when Pulpit, the 3-year-old star of the racing world, ran second in the $500,000 Florida Derby to Captain Bodgit and threw the Kentucky Derby picture into sudden confusion.

title: Safety First When Using a Ladder
description: IF you own a home, you should own a ladder. It's almost impossible to maintain a house properly without one. Most people know what a ladder is used for, but they don't always know how to use one properly. The Consumer Products Safety Commission estimates that every year about 65,000 people are hospitalized because of ladder accidents.

description: To the Editor:

description: Everything for Restaurant Or Chef, Under One Roof

title: Pondering Children and Water In Color Woodblock Prints
description: GALLERIES and museums thin out as one heads eastward in Connecticut. Helping to relieve the sparseness is a new gallery in Madison, P. Hastings Falk, which has just opened on the ground floor of what was once a sturdy clapboard house.

description: RICHARD NIXON.

title: Out With the Downers
description: The Dow Jones industrial average is getting restructured for the first time in nearly six years. And it's out with the losers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a letter to the editor from Dr. Marshall J. Glesby, medical director of the Community Research Initiative on AIDS, appeared last Sunday with parts of two sentences omitted, altering its meaning. A corrected version appears today on page 17.

title: Corrections
description: The Lives column on March 2, a show-business satire by Steve Martin, carried an erroneous illustration credit. The illustrator was Natasha Tibbott.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGERMAN, EMS
description: BERGERMAN - Ems. Devoted wife of the late Milton M. Bergerman. Passed away peacefully at home on Thursday, March 13. Born in Lyon, France, one of 11 children, she became a proud U.S. citizen in 1945. She was the beloved mother of Jane (Martin) and Jill (Tom). Devoted grandmere of Christen, Jennifer, Sara, Samuel and Jill. Great-grandmere to Jacob. Aunt to Jacqueline (Jean). Great-aunt to Francoise. Deeply loved companion of Edith and Selma. A truly elegant, gracious and compassionate woman, she will be forever missed and loved. Funeral services will be private.

title: Bond Act Battles in Albany
description: The passage of New York's $1.75 billion Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act last November counts as one of Gov. George Pataki's greatest achievements. But Mr. Pataki can boast about this accomplishment only as long as the public is confident that he is spending the money fairly and wisely.

title: Communicators Cited for Work
description: THE panel of judges for the Clarion awards, given by the Association of Women in Communication, Westchester Chapter, was impressed with the quality of this year's entries.

description: It was widely expected when the Federal General Services Administration announced last week that it would go ahead with the construction of a 17-story, $371 million Federal courthouse in downtown Brooklyn. And also as expected, a group of nearby residents threatened to file a lawsuit to stop it.

title: A Developer Navigates the Recycling Path in Harlem
description: THE totally private, nonsubsidized residential construction projects undertaken in central Harlem are few and far between, but one of them is now under way on Manhattan Avenue at 115th Street in one more attempt to bring home ownership into an environment of older rentals.

description: Albania, Europe's poorest nation, was consumed by violence and anarchy as civilians wandered through the streets of the capital city of Tirana firing guns that they had taken from military sites.

description: Karen L. Berman and Jonathan E. Yellen were married last evening in Avon, Conn. Rabbi Camille Angel performed the ceremony at Avon Old Farms Inn.

title: Hi, Winter!
description: When the sun sets on March 22, the 28 people now at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station will take a good, long look. They won't see it again for six months, and they won't see any new faces until the first airplane returns in October -- bearing replacements and a psychologist specializing in group dynamics. The day I arrived a fistfight broke out, recalls Brent Jones, a systems engineer and veteran of two cabin-fever-inducing Antarctic winters. You had people who could not stand to be in the same room with each other.

title: New Drugstore Rx: Free-Standing and Huge
description: DRUGSTORES, like supermarkets and multiscreen cinemas, are increasing their presence in the marketplace in a big way. Often they are moving from their traditional slots in strip shopping centers to free-standing corner locations along busy main streets across New Jersey.

title: Cornell, ECAC Champ, Awaits N.C.A.A. Bid
description: Cornell beat Clarkson, 2-1, today at Olympic Arena to win the ECAC tournament for the second year in a row. Jason Elliott, the Cornell goaltender, was named the tournament's most valuable player for the second year in a row, too.

title: YANKEE, COME HERE
description: 1. When President Bill Clinton meets with Boris Yeltsin in Helsinki this week, he'll feel right at home. 2. Finland had to perform a delicate East-West balancing act throughout the cold war, but in recent years it has avidly Americanized, embracing everything from fast food to the Hell's Angels. 3. In 1993, the Finns scrapped their old, half-Soviet air force stock, replacing it with 64 F-18's. 4. On the pop-culture front, credit (or blame) Renny Harlin, the Finnish film director. His films ''A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master'' and ''Die Hard 2: Die Harder'' were hits in Finland, and he helped found Helsinki's Planet Hollywood. 5. Jaakko Laajava, Finland's ambassador to the United States, says that if Clinton gets hungry, he can get anything he wants. Even, say, Tex-Mex? ''That can easily be arranged.''

description: PROSNITZ-Gerry. Our deepest sympathies are extended to her sons Eugene and Leonard, and their families. Robert N. Levine, Sr Rabbi Jack B. Levitt, President

title: Sleeping With the Enemy
description: Women anywhere are understandably reluctant to report rape. But in much of Latin America, women have a particularly potent reason to keep silent.

title: Voices Pour Out for Silenced Educator
description: Arnold Willens could not stop smiling that night in late January. The play he directed at Public School 41, ''The Butler Did It,'' was a hit. During the last week of rehearsals, Mr. Willens, who had AIDS, fought bronchitis and laryngitis, and finally resorted to hand signals to communicate with the student cast. But as the audience roared with approval and stood for an ovation, his face lighted with joy.

title: Patterns Of Crime
description: Crime on Long Island fell from 1990 to 1995, and 1996 projections based on figures for the first 11 months of the year show that, by and large, it has continued to drop. The main exceptions is Hempstead, where violent crime increased 36 percent last year; even so, both Nassau and Suffolk Counties are considerably safer than the nation as a whole. These tables show crime rates per 100,000 residents in towns with their own police departments, as well as aggregate numbers for the vast areas of both counties that are patrolled by the county police. ANDY NEWMAN

title: So Many Concerts, So Little Time
description: THIS is going to be a long and circuitous journey, but our ideal summer tour of European music festivals starts out in Norway, toward the end of May, for a few days in Bergen. One of the joys here is the mix of local talent (including the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes in several concerts) with international visitors, among them the Komische Oper of Berlin and the Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan. The varied program goes all the way from medieval Italian songs to a new Norwegian opera, from Asian dance (Indian as well as Taiwanese) to European string quartets, from Pierre Boulez to Scandinavian folk music.

title: Filling a Hole in an Under-Bageled County
description: NOT many years ago the notion of a freshly baked bagel, hot out of the oven, was a foreign concept in many parts of Westchester. The bagel bakery, like the coffee bar, just didn't exist, especially in the county's smallest towns and villages.

title: In Danbury, 'Peter and The Wolf'
description: MADELINE CAVALIERI will be the violin soloist this afternoon in a young people's concert at the Danbury High School. Ms. Cavalieri will play two movements of Bruch's G Minor Violin Concerto, and James Humphreville will lead the Danbury Symphony in Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf.'' Eugene Eriquez, the Mayor of Danbury, will be the narrator for ''Peter and the Wolf,'' while the Robert Rogers Puppet Theater offers portrayals of the cat, the bird, the duck and the big bad wolf. The concert begins at 3 o'clock and is free of charge.

title: The Sky's the Limit
description: Workers can demand all kinds of things. Matadors in Spain recently went on strike over the issue of shaving bulls' horns. Closer to home, employees may insist on longer coffee breaks, an office refrigerator or a smoke-free workplace. What do you and your co-workers demand? Has anyone in your office made a fuss over anything bizarre? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: CLINTON CRAZY
description: As the flinty-eyed fellow who graced the cover of your Feb. 23 issue (''Clinton Crazy,'' by Philip Weiss), I hope you will allow me to comment briefly. First, I believe your story should have described the substantive reasons why many people of good faith are posing serious questions about the Government reports concluding that the White House Deputy Counsel, Vincent W. Foster Jr., committed suicide where his body was found in Fort Marcy Park. Your ''Foster Fixation'' sidebar simply failed to furnish the evidence, drawn from the Government's own underlying investigative record, needed to permit the reader to make an informed judgment.

title: Michele Mayron, Richard Deutsch
description: Michele Susan Mayron, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Mayron of New York, was married last evening to Richard David Deutsch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Deutsch of Laredo, Tex. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski performed the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: To Save the Diamondbacks
description: The diamondback terrapin, New Jersey's signature salt-marsh turtle, needs our help fighting a growing threat -- commercial crab traps -- if it is to survive.

title: 'Literature' Bores Me
description: The Henry James revival? I'm having a problem with it -- with the books, I mean. It's terrific that Hollywood has discovered him -- that Jane Campion found ''The Portrait of a Lady'' worthy of the big screen and that Ismail Merchant and James Ivory, who in 1984 brought James's novel ''The Bostonians'' to the screen, are now developing ''The Golden Bowl.'' And there has been a lot of erudite commentary lately on James in forums that don't ordinarily give a lot of space to literature: witness the on-line debate between two biographers in Slate about James's sexuality. I don't want to rain on the parade, but I have a question: Does anyone like to read him?

description: John Gross, the labor lawyer whose firm represents school districts in contract negotiations, is quoted as saying ''Public coffers are seen as a bottomless well'' by school employees.

description: For Robeson's Allen Griffin, Washington Irving's Bradford Jones and August Martin's Tanesha Seaton, each of whom led their teams to Public Schools Athletic League championships yesterday at Madison Square Garden, what a difference two years makes.

title: Gunmen Can Act Alone. But Not Entirely.
description: IMMEDIATELY after a Jordanian soldier opened fire on a group of Israeli schoolgirls Thursday, two notions quickly spread here: one, that he was unstable, and two, that he had been driven to his terrible act by the rise in political tensions. Israelis charged that it was the bitterly personal letter that Jordan's King Hussein sent to Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu last week, accusing the Israeli of destroying progress toward peace, that must have incited the man to his deed; Palestinians said that Israeli provocations had prompted the letter, and that Israel was therefore to blame.

title: Two Shows by Women, One Fulfilling a Mission as a 'Platform'
description: COINCIDENTALLY, all the artists reviewed this week are women, eight of them at the Hopper Art Center in Nyack and four at the Hostos Art Gallery in the Bronx. A melange of paintings, photographs and sculpture, the Hopper Center's ''Power of Suggestion'' does not compare with ''Four Women in Form,'' the all-sculpture display at Hostos. Still, to contrast the two is to see that the success of a show depends to some extent on the way it is conceived and presented.

title: A Sudden Sage on Soft Money
description: A FEW weeks ago, The New York Times published my letter to the editor on the subject of soft money -- those unlimited contributions that go to political parties for ''party-building'' and ''good-citizen'' activities and other uses. Much of the money, of course, has wound up circumventing the limits on political contributions to individuals, by being used for advertising that trumpets all of a candidate's slogans while never specifically naming whom you should send to Washington. But if the ad says, in effect, ''when you care enough to send the very best,'' you know what the sponsor has in mind, even without the brand name.

title: Satisfied Parents In White Plains
description: I find it unfortunate that your article $(''County's Reaction to the Report Cards,'' Feb. 2$) chose to quote only one opinion on the White Plains' public schools, that of a couple with no apparent experience with our school system. I would have thought that journalistic balance would have dictated that an educator or an active parent in the system might have been asked as well for a statement regarding the recent State Education Department report cards. This would have been appropriate since The Times itself, by its own recent evaluation of the report cards, found the White Plains elementary schools to be in the top-rated group, with weighting for factors such as the percentage of children from disadvantaged families, and so on.

title: Yearly Tea to Benefit New Rochelle Library
description: NICHOLAS LEMANN, an author and the national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly magazine, was happy to say yes when asked to take part in an event to benefit the New Rochelle Public Library.

title: President Feels Some Pain as He Recovers From Knee Surgery
description: With his anesthesia reduced, President Clinton felt sharp pains in his right leg while being helped back into bed at Bethesda Naval Medical Center this afternoon, but was recovering normally from surgery for a torn tendon in his knee and was otherwise resting comfortably, his spokesman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, EVA (NEE FEINBERG)
description: FELD-Eva (nee Feinberg), 88. Passed away peacefully in her home in Clifton, NJ, March 15. Beloved wife of the late Morris and mother of the late Stanley. Survived by two sisters, Adeline Kramer, Sylvia Gurevitz; two brothers, Harold and Saul Feinberg. Also survived by ten nieces and nephews. Together with her husband, she was a benefactor to American Folk Art Museum, The Jewish Museum, The Metropolitan Opera, Daughters of Miriam Center for the Aged, Clifton, Temple Emanuel, Passaic, the Passaic-Clifton Jewish Federation and Beth Israel Hospital, Passaic. Funeral will take place Monday at noon at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, Passaic.

And then a lot of them get lazy, just living for welfare. I can see why people look at all this and get frustrated.''

title: An Arrest in Cosby's Killing
description: Mikhail Markhasev, an 18-year-old Russian immigrant who moved to Los Angeles eight years ago, was arrested Wednesday and charged Thursday with the murder of Ennis W. Cosby, Bill Cosby's son, who was killed on Jan. 16 while changing a tire on his $125,000 Mercedes-Benz on the shoulder of a Los Angeles freeway.

description: T.S. ELIOT WAS ONE OF THIS CENTURY'S pre-eminent poets, a great artist and perhaps the premier modernist. He was also an anti-Semite, a racist and a misogynist.

title: Giuliani Eases Marriage Rule For Foreigners
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that immigrants who applied for marriage licenses in New York City could not be turned away if they were in the country illegally and used a foreign passport with an expired visa as identification.

title: U.S. Civil Jury Traces Ex-Mexico Aide's Millions to Drug Bribes
description: Ending an extraordinary civil action in which American prosecutors virtually put the Mexican Government on trial for narcotics corruption, a jury decided today that most of the $9 million confiscated from the former coordinator of Mexico's drug program had come from traffickers' bribes.

title: Where to Reel In a Microwave-Ready Seafood Dinner

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 23 about Necmettin Erbakan, the Prime Minister of Turkey, misstated the change in Turkish printing made in the 1920's by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. Latin script replaced Arabic, not vice versa.

title: It's Poverty of Imagination to Find Only the South Guilty
description: WILL THE SOUTH Overcome the Bigotry of the Hate-Laden White Aristocrats?'' asked the ads for Otto Preminger's utterly forgettable 1967 film ''Hurry Sundown,'' which was cited in one recent book as the single worst picture ever made about the South. The answer is no -- at least as far as the mainstream of American movies over the last 30 years would have it.

title: Finding the Human Drama in a Monument by Bach
description: ''RESTORATIONS'' ABOUND in the world of early music. But when the English director Jonathan Miller speaks of restoration in connection with Bach's monumental ''St. Matthew Passion,'' he is not thinking, in typical early-music terms, of the work's first performance, in 1727. Indeed, there could have been little about that occasion, with chorus and orchestra crammed into two organ lofts at St. Thomas's Church in Leipzig, to stimulate the imagination of a stage director. Nor does Mr. Miller suggest that Bach ever envisioned any overt dramatization of this expansive meditation on Christ's waning hours and final agony.

title: Citizenship Wars
description: IN the seven years since Noel Gaynor left a prison in Northern Ireland and arrived in the United States, he has married his long-time American sweetheart, begun to raise a family and supported them by fashioning everything from wood harps to shingle roofs. On weekends, he has coached junior soccer, and on St. Patrick's Day he has marched in the parade.

title: Antarctica
description: To the Editor: Almost a year ago I read ''Penguins and Politics in Antarctica'' by Rebecca Pepper Sinkler, who traveled with her husband under the sponsorship of the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences. They had just returned and she wrote rhapsodically of the experience. The academy was to do a second trip in the austral summer of 1997. I immediately called the academy and left a message for a reservation, it being Sunday; the call back came on Monday. Success!

title: THE ISLAMIST WHO RUNS TURKEY, DELICATELY
description: Stephen Kinzer's article ''The Islamist Who Runs Turkey, Delicately'' (Feb. 23) describes Necmettin Erbakan's wariness about the possibility of a military coup. Accustomed to the convention of undemocratic military coups in Latin American countries and elsewhere, Americans are far too seldom aware that recent military coups in Turkey instead protected democratic traditions and stability.

title: Through the Wronger
description: ''IT IS WRONG,'' I wrote in medium dudgeon (as opposed to high dudgeon, in which I would have written, ''It is morally corrupt'' -- a dudgen or dudgeon is an archaic word for a wood-handled dagger, and nobody knows how it came to mean ''a fit of indignation,'' with its first citation in 1573), and what kind of tangent am I off on? Begin again.

title: THERE'S NOTHING CONSERVATIVE ABOUT THE CLASSICS REVIVAL
description: Garry Wills's splendid article vividly recalled my experience teaching Euripides in the early 1960's (''There's Nothing Conservative About the Classics Revival,'' Feb. 16). I was fresh out of graduate school, where of course we had studied Euripides. For most of us, though, he evoked less enthusiasm than did Aeschylus and Sophocles: his plays seemed too focused on the particulars of his own time, the speech of his characters often too ordinary, and many plays seemed to lack either dramatic unity or organic bonds between characters' deeds and their destinies.

title: An Actor Building a Career as Not-Johnny-Depp
description: SKEET ULRICH WOULD RATHER be compared to Gena Rowlands than to Johnny Depp, but everybody seems to think the two young actors were separated at birth. Even ''Saturday Night Live'' has contributed to the relentless Depp-clone jokes; on a recent show, David Spade flashed a picture of the photogenic Mr. Ulrich and announced: ''Skeet, Johnny Depp called. He wants his DNA back.''

title: Milestone Helps Keep The Devils On a Roll
description: A determined band of drummers toured the halls and seats of Continental Arena during today's Devils game, and that was appropriate. The beat went on for the home team, which delighted the capacity crowd of 19,040 with yet another victory, this time a 3-2 decision over the Washington Capitals that put the Devils into a tie with Philadelphia for the Eastern Conference lead.

title: Debate Over Pathmark Jobs Leads to More Wrangling
description: It was supposed to be a moment of triumph for the East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle: the announcement that James A. Smith Contracting of Long Island had been picked to build the Pathmark complex on 125th Street in East Harlem. But no sooner was the announcement made two weeks ago than arguing resumed between the group and community leaders in East Harlem.

title: Revving Up the Dow
description: The Dow Jones industrial average is the barometer by which many Americans measure good or bad times. Though only aficionados know how the stock index is constructed or what its ups and downs mean, people take it to be a measure of overall stock performance and -- on the dubious assumption that what happens on Wall Street is intimately tied to what happens on Main Street -- economic performance. If the Dow rises, times are deemed good. If it falls, run for cover. This week, the overseers of the Dow, the editors of The Wall Street Journal, will make a change that could signal better times ahead. They will drop four laggard stocks from the Dow and replace them with potentially stellar performers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, KALMAN JACOB
description: MANN-Kalman Jacob. Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the passing of Professor Kalman Jacob Mann, beloved former Director General of the Hadassah Medical Organization from 1951-81. Seventh generation Jerusalemite, Professor Mann was the builder of the Hadassah Medical Center at Ein Karem and rebuilt Hadassah Hospital on Mt. Scopus after its liberation in 1967. A pioneer of health care administration and public health care in Israel, he was renowned as a visionary and a pragmatist, and was awarded the Israel Prize for his service to his people. A devoted father and grandfather, an educator and author, mentor and friend, Professor Mann was universally loved and respected for his warmth and wisdom. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Our deepest condolences to his wife Bluma, his children and grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post, National President Beth Wohlgelernter, National Executive Director

Most people know what a ladder is used for, but they don't always know how to use one properly. The Consumer Products Safety Commission estimates that about 65,000 people are hospitalized every year because of ladder accidents.

title: Mr. Wizard
description: Once upon a time in the Kingdom of Fashion there was a sovereign called Haute Couture, who was glorious and grand and who swathed her followers in made-to-measure silks and plush velvets to their utter delight. Then one day, a young warrior named Ready-to-Wear galloped into Fashion and launched a revolution, leaving Couture to her court of 200 nobles, who watched in dismay as she doddered about in $2O,OOO day suits and taffeta ball gowns. ''Couture is dying,'' they'd whisper. ''Why won't she just go away.''

title: In Greenwich, Clubby Style and Sun Porch
description: IN Greenwich, an attractive clapboard house where Boodles long held sway, has a new tenant, Sitting Duck Pub. Despite serious, though redeemable, shortcomings, the pub's central location near town hall makes it hard to ignore. The eclectic menu borrows from various cuisines. Unfortunately, the results reminded us of the admonition whispered at the beginning of a mystery movie, ''nothing is as it seems.''

Ms. Lorkavic remembers the bombing of her childhood home in Belgrade. Her family fled to an uncle's home in Sarajevo. That was April 1941. title: 'A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again'
description: MANY readers young and old (but especially the young and media-saturated) regarded David Foster Wallace's mammoth novel, ''Infinite Jest,'' with suspicion. Jaded by too many middling writers heralded as the Next Big Thing, they wondered if, as its title intimated, this daunting tome wasn't just a big joke. ''Infinite Jest'' itself didn't quite clear things up. Messy, demanding and stubbornly unresolved, it was also frequently brilliant. Yet Mr. Wallace's penchant for pointed satire and flashy tricks often obscured the book's passion. Ultimately, ''Infinite Jest'' felt noncommittal, leaving some readers unconvinced that Mr. Wallace offered anything more than a lot of energy and a dazzling but heartless cleverness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, CHARLES H.
description: DYSON-Charles H. Financier and philanthropist, died March 14, 1997, at the age of 87. Mr. Dyson lived in Millbrook, NY, and Barbados. At the time of his death, Charles H. Dyson was chairman emeritus of The Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, a private company that he founded in 1954, which became one of the largest privately held companies in the country. Charles Dyson was born in NYC and grew up in Englewood, NJ. As a young man, Charles Dyson worked as an accountant, and attended Pace University (then Pace Institute) at night, graduating in 1930. During the war years, he was a Special Consultant to the Secretary of War and worked with the Army and Navy on helping to design the Lend Lease Act. He later worked for the Department of the Treasury and after helping to organize the International Monetary Fund, he represented Treasury Department at the First IMF conference at Bretton Woods. Commissioned as a colonel in the Air Force, he was decorated with a Distinguished Service Medal and was made a Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire (CBE) for his wartime service. After the war, Mr. Dyson worked for several national corporations before beginning his own company in 1954. That year he bought his first company with $10,000 of his own money and $5 million borrowed from a bank. Mr. Dyson became known as a pioneer in the field of leveraged buyouts. The Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation's manufacturing and industrial businesses currently generate annual sales of close to $600 million. In addition to Charles Dyson's many accomplishments in the business world, he was a noted philanthropist and community leader. He served as chairman of several boards of directors, including Pace Univeristy and the American Ballet Theater. The liberal arts school at Pace University is known as the Dyson College of Arts and Sciences, in recognition of Mr. Dyson's leadership and contributions to that institution. He lent his support and leadership to a long list of voluntary organizations and served as a trustee for many including Rockefeller University Council, Hospital for Special Surgery, White Plains Hospital, Common Cause, Center for Defense Information, Westchester County Medical Center, Greer Children's Services, New York Law School, and the Metropolitan Opera Association. Charles Dyson's commitment to philanthropy and the importance of the voluntary sector was lifelong. In addition to his personal philanthropy and that of his whole family, he and his late wife Margaret founded The Dyson Foundation in 1957. He later created The Dyson Charitable Fund as another adjunct to his family's charitable work. In recent years, major gifts were made by Mr. Dyson, and by the Dyson Foundation to many important institutions, including Pace University, Cornell University, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College, Marist College, the American Ballet Theater, and the Metropolitan Opera. Charles H. Dyson was the widower of Margaret Macgregor Dyson to whom he was married in 1941. Margaret Dyson passed away in 1990. Survivors include his second wife, June Marston Dyson; his three sons and one daughter; John S. Dyson, Robert R. Dyson, Anne E. Dyson, M.D., and Peter L. Dyson; 10 grandchildren; and a sister, Laura Bucciarelli. Private services and burial will be held in Millbrook, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Pace University in New York City or to Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, NY. A memorial service has been scheduled for April 1, 1997, at 11 AM, at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NY NY.

title: Ridin', Ropin', Rhymin'
description: Rodeo life is the subject of ALL THIS WAY FOR THE SHORT RIDE: Roughstock Sonnets, 1971-1996 (Museum of New Mexico, cloth, $29.95; paper, $17.50), a lively collection of poems by Paul Zarzyski, a former bareback rider, illustrated by Barbara Van Cleve, a photographer who was recently inducted into the National Cowgirl Hall of Fame. Though both Mr. Zarzyski and Ms. Van Cleve are from Montana, their very different styles work to capture a chorus of contradictory moods: her luminous black-and-white images seem etched from some archetypal landscape, while his verses bristle with audacity and whimsy. Mr. Zarzyski alternates between bluster and lyricism. For the former, he uses lopingly metered stanzas and punch-drunk, self-mythologizing bravura, which heightens both the flair and the corniness of rodeo lingo. (''Running on Bute, LeDoux songs and caffeine / You rollicking, rosined-up, spurring machine.'') But he proves equally adept at meditative free verse, as in the title poem, in which he compares a cowboy killed by a throw from a bronc to ''a bride's bouquet / pitched blind.'' Ms. Van Cleve's facing photo reveals the impossibly calm center within such a moment, as the leaping horse hovers delicately above the ground and the rider, despite his flailing body, leans back with a peaceful expression. Together, these artists offer a rare slice of what Mr. Zarzyski calls the ''real West, the sunset into which -- / imagine why, if you will -- the cowboy rides off.'' Megan Harlan

title: La Vie Boheme
description: Alice Prin, known as Kiki, was the embodiment of bohemian Paris in the 1920's. Audacious and high spirited, she was an artist's model as well as the star attraction in cabarets, where she sang bawdy songs, lifting her skirts to reveal she wore no underwear. Man Ray was her lover, Jean Cocteau, Chaim Soutine and Tsuguharu Foujita her treasured friends. She was featured in Fernand Leger's famous film ''Ballet Mecanique'' and was the subject of Man Ray's greatest Surrealist photographs of the 20's. An illegitimate child, Kiki was born in Burgundy in 1901. She lived with her indigent grandmother until the age of 12, when she was summoned to Paris by her mother. Drawn to the artist's life in Montparnasse, she survived by her wits, charming all who crossed her path. When her memoirs were first published in 1929, they were an instant sensation. Parisians queued up to obtain an autographed copy -- and a kiss. But the publisher, Edward W. Titus, who commissioned the American journalist Samuel Putnam to translate and Ernest Hemingway to write an introduction, was less successful in getting Kiki's memoirs into the United States; they never got past Customs. Even as late as the 1970's, the memoirs -- short, fancifu1 vignettes about Kiki's sexually adventurous existence in Paris -- were still held in the section for banned books in the New York Public Library. Billy Kluver and Julie Martin, the editors of a lively new edition, KIKI'S MEMOIRS (Ecco, $23), have included fresh biographical material, familiar as well as lesser-known photographs of Kiki by Man Ray, portraits by other artists and reproductions of Kiki's own paintings. Though hardly the stuff of scandal today, ''Kiki's Memoirs'' is nonetheless suffused with a wayward charm as insouciant as Kiki herself. Andrea Barnet

After Ms. Neal finished her shopping, she headed for the one checkout lane that was open. A line formed behind her as the clerk checked out groceries with the efficiency of a sleepwalker. Then the clerk picked up a telephone and began a conversation with her boyfriend. Finally, the store manager came by and told the clerk to hang up the phone and get back to work. The clerk swore at her boss, slammed the phone down and walked off.

title: PUSHING THE RIGHT BUTTONS
description: Job seekers at the Sunset Station Resort and Casino in Las Vegas are first routed to a new automated phone line that asks very leading questions. Like: What is the total value of cash or other items not belonging to you that you have taken from your last employer? The test contains more subtle questions, of course, and Brooks Mitchell, whose Aspen Tree Software markets the system, says some responses that seem right might be the opposite. (In one study, for instance, Mitchell found that people who rarely socialize make better telephone operators.) Still, common sense can help. Slouching grumps do not make great cocktail waitresses, and applicants are also asked: During a typical day in your current job, how many times do you smile? Hint: The right answer is not option No. 1: I don't smile every day.

title: Quasimodo: Grotesque but Embraceable

At 63, the renowned mezzo-soprano could afford to sit on her laurels, but the fact is, her laurels are too numerous to be sat on by one person. Any single accomplishment that would be a crowning achievement for others is only one stone in Ms. Horne's many-faceted crown.

I organized a diving trip to the Red Sea in 1992 that left from Hodeida, Yemen. We met in Sana and spent several fascinating days touring the countryside, followed by a bus ride from Sana to Hodeida. The good news: Yemen is fascinating. Many of the people are friendly and helpful.

Survivors include her daughter Jane Bloom, son Michael and his wife Lora, son Roger and his wife Marjorie, sister Sarah Yellin, brother Sandy Yellin, grandchildren Rachael Bloom, Beryl Bloom, Ona Bloom, Richard Schultz, Douglas Schultz and his wife Natalia, Wendy Gray and her husband Robert, Cynthia Aldrich and her husband Tom, Daniel Schultz and great-grandchildren Nicole Gray and Michael Gray. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorials be made to Children's Home Society, 800 Northwest 15th Street, Miami, Florida 33136.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, CHARLES H.
description: DYSON-Charles H. Financier and philanthropist, died March 14, 1997, at the age of 87. Mr. Dyson lived in Millbrook, NY, and Barbados. At the time of his death, Charles H. Dyson was chairman emeritus of The Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, a private company that he founded in 1954, which became one of the largest privately held companies in the country. Charles Dyson was born in NYC and grew up in Englewood, NJ. As a young man, Charles Dyson worked as an accountant, and attended Pace University (then Pace Institute) at night, graduating in 1930. During the war years, he was a Special Consultant to the Secretary of War and worked with the Army and Navy on helping to design the Lend Lease Act. He later worked for the Department of the Treasury and after helping to organize the International Monetary Fund, he represented Treasury Department at the First IMF conference at Bretton Woods. Commissioned as a colonel in the Air Force, he was decorated with a Distinguished Service Medal and was made a Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire (CBE) for his wartime service. After the war, Mr. Dyson worked for several national corporations before beginning his own company in 1954. That year he bought his first company with $10,000 of his own money and $5 million borrowed from a bank. Mr. Dyson became known as a pioneer in the field of leveraged buyouts. The Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation's manufacturing and industrial businesses currently generate annual sales of close to $600 million. In addition to Charles Dyson's many accomplishments in the business world, he was a noted philanthropist and community leader. He served as chairman of several boards of directors, including Pace Univeristy and the American Ballet Theater. The liberal arts school at Pace University is known as the Dyson College of Arts and Sciences, in recognition of Mr. Dyson's leadership and contributions to that institution. He lent his support and leadership to a long list of voluntary organizations and served as a trustee for many including Rockefeller University Council, Hospital for Special Surgery, White Plains Hospital, Common Cause, Center for Defense Information, Westchester County Medical Center, Greer Children's Services, New York Law School, and the Metropolitan Opera Association. Charles Dyson's commitment to philanthropy and the importance of the voluntary sector was lifelong. In addition to his personal philanthropy and that of his whole family, he and his late wife Margaret founded The Dyson Foundation in 1957. He later created The Dyson Charitable Fund as another adjunct to his family's charitable work. In recent years, major gifts were made by Mr. Dyson, and by the Dyson Foundation to many important institutions, including Pace University, Cornell University, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College, Marist College, the American Ballet Theater, and the Metropolitan Opera. Charles H. Dyson was the widower of Margaret Macgregor Dyson to whom he was married in 1941. Margaret Dyson passed away in 1990. Survivors include his second wife, June Marston Dyson; his three sons and one daughter; John S. Dyson, Robert R. Dyson, Anne E. Dyson, M.D., and Peter L. Dyson; 10 grandchildren; and a sister, Laura Bucciarelli. Private services and burial will be held in Millbrook, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Pace University in New York City or to Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, NY. A memorial service has been scheduled for April 1, 1997, at 11 AM, at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NY NY.
