title: 'Dracula,' Beyond Bram Stoker's Darkest Dreams
description: Ben Stevenson's ''Dracula'' is spectacle of an order ballet audiences seldom see today. The sets, costumes and lighting are not just lavish but exquisitely beautiful and atmospheric. The ballet, danced to music by Liszt arranged and conducted by John Lanchbery, is crammed with ingenious stage magic, just as the Romantic-era ballets of the late 19th century were. Count Dracula and his ghostly undead brides fly. The Count dies in a flash of light atop a candlelighted chandelier. And a rattling old coach careers on and off the stage in the ballet, a co-production of the Houston and Pittsburgh Ballets, which opened on Thursday night at the Wortham Theater Center here. For once, $1 million, the cost of ''Dracula,'' looks like a million.

title: Fielder and Yanks Say It's Time to Just Play
description: Cecil Fielder could have been a defensive back considering the way he backtracked over and over again today. He could have been a spin doctor because some of his comments were so twisted. He could have been a suburbanite temporarily plopped in New York the way he talked about saying goodbye to the Yankees after this season. Fielder was all these things today because he gambled against George Steinbrenner in his search for a contract extension and lost, if a player earning $7.2 million ever loses.

title: Teen-Ager Is Stabbed On Way to Queens School
description: A 15-year-old Queens boy was stabbed as he walked to school yesterday morning in what appeared to be a robbery attempt, the police said.

description: In a city where no war monument seems to get built without a second war over how it should be done, it appears that the $100 million World War II memorial planned for the National Mall in Washington will be no exception.

title: Time Warner may get a big tax break, thanks to accounting.
description: TED TURNER refers to his Time Warner shares as ''a $60 stock in a $40 body.'' But Mr. Turner, who became the company's vice chairman and a major shareholder when Time Warner acquired the Turner Broadcasting System last year, may have to wait at least until summer for a chance at body beautiful.

title: ADT and Tyco Plan to Merge In $5.4 Billion Stock Swap
description: Seeking to thwart a hostile takeover by Western Resources Inc., ADT Inc., the world's largest provider of home security systems, announced yesterday a friendly merger with Tyco International in a stock deal valued at $5.4 billion.

title: S.E.C. May Ease Regulation On Mutual Fund Disclosure
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering removing its requirement that mutual funds disclose to shareholders all the securities held in a fund's portfolio, the agency's chief mutual fund regulator said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, BERTHA
description: NEUMAN-Bertha. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a cherished member of its extended family, and wife of our esteemed Board Member, Mr. Irving Neuman. Most of all we express our sorrow at the loss of a valued friend. Bea was a warm and caring soul whose love for her family was both legendary and inspirational. A partner in life and philanthropy with her devoted husband, the Neumans shared their blessings to improve the quality of life for countless others. They regarded the students of Boys Town as ''their boys'', endowing The Irving and Bea Neuman Electronics Laboratory and the Irving and Bea Neuman Major Scholarship Endowment, to provide disadvantaged Israeli youth a brighter future. May Bea's lifetime boundless good ensure her rightful place in Heaven and be a source of blessing to all. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family and pray that Bea Neuman's soul will be bound in the bond of life eternal. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Alexander S. Linchner, Vice Chair Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: CAIRN ENERGY SAYS IT MAY PUT ITSELF ON THE BLOCK
description: Cairn Energy USA Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. to assist it in the possible sale of the company. Cairn, a Dallas-based company whose primary operations involve drilling for oil and natural gas in the Gulf of Mexico, has faced concern from investors about its offshore wells. One of Cairn's most important wells, for example, which is operated by another company, recently reported lower-than-expected production results. Donaldson, Lufkin was retained for six months to oversee a possible sale, Michael Gilbert, Cairn president, said. Cairn's shares rose 75 cents, to $10.875, bringing the company's market capitalization to $191 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ahmanson Sweetens Bid For Great Western Financial

title: Man Injured in Shooting Begins to Talk and Walk
description: Matthew Gross, the musician from Montclair, N.J., who was shot in the head by a gunman at the Empire State Building last month, is beginning to talk and walk again, his brother said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, EVA
description: FELD-Eva. Eva Feld's enthusiasm for Jewish culture will be remembered fondly. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her family. E. Robert Goodkind, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: Democrats Cry Foul; Republicans Say They Were Fair
description: Anthony Lake's withdrawal from consideration for Director of Central Intelligence tonight reignited the controversy over Senate confirmation procedures.

title: Bonds Ease on New Talk Of an Interest-Rate Increase
description: Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday, as investors worried that the Federal Reserve would pre-emptively raise rates and the dollar eased in trading against the German mark.

description: Its permanent California quarters are either in construction or on the drawing boards, but the young Dreamworks SKG entertainment company has already found a mid-Manhattan home for the next decade.

title: Those Who Dare, Those Who Don't
description: What must it be like when the fashion ground beneath designers' feet begins to shift? A chasm has opened between the signature work of some long-established designers and the new prevailing esthetic.

title: Russian Prisons Breeding Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis, Officials Warn
description: Russian prisons and labor camps have become incubators of virulent, drug-resistant tuberculosis that is spreading through the region as prisoners are released, officials in Moscow and at the World Health Organization said Monday.

title: A Tyrant's Crisis in Zaire
description: For more than 30 years Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, made himself one of Africa's richest and most powerful men by relying on a simple, cynical formula. He crushed, corrupted or co-opted domestic dissent, made sure his army was too weak to threaten his rule and cultivated the West with a militantly anti-Communist foreign policy, thereby insuring outside military help to put down the occasional armed revolt.

title: Stocks in Late Rebound as Dow Gains 20.02
description: After slumping for much of the day, stock prices rebounded late in the afternoon yesterday, partly offsetting another broad selloff in the technology sector.

Darling grandpa to Nechama, Yocheved, David, Yair, Mendy, Yosef and Miriam. Services Tuesday 1:45PM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: The recreational vehicle industry rolls out a campaign to lure baby boomers.
description: WHEN Cash Barber retired from the Navy in 1971, he and his wife, Eileen, bought an Airstream camping trailer and spent the next decade traveling around North America. Today, they are on their 10th recreation vehicle.

title: Van Gundy Takes the Rap For That Horrid Nets Game
description: He played the tape of the Nets game and pointed out each blunder: how his players were standing too close to one another on offense and too far away from their opponent on defense. After it was over, Coach Jeff Van Gundy put the Knicks through a practice today that he wished he had put them through last Wednesday.

title: New Cloning Attempts Meet No Success So Far
description: DR. IAN WILMUT, the man who cloned a sheep, went on a lecture circuit in the United States last week, telling eager scientists how he had done it. Within a few days, he spoke at a meeting in Baltimore, sponsored by the Cambridge Healthtech Institute, he gave a lecture and visited the Department of Agriculture's research center in Beltsville, Md., and he lectured at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. In between, he sandwiched in testimony before the United States Senate.

title: Albanian Refugees in Italy Are in a Kind of Crowded Limbo
description: Three days into the latest exodus of Albanians to Italy's southeast coast, this ancient port city has run out of room.

title: Scientology Won Tax Exemption on the Merits
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Is Badly Hurt in Fight Near Parade Route
description: Just a block away from the revelry of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, a wild fight erupted yesterday that left an 18-year-old man critically injured, the police said.

title: Bridge Title to Kaplan Team
description: Two major titles were decided here Sunday night at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships.

title: Not All Presidential Advisers Talk Politics
description: In his 50 months in the White House, seeking succor in the bad times and a check on his ego in the good, President Clinton has turned to a small circle of mostly Protestant clergy members who have offered him spiritual counsel, in private meetings, phone calls and faxes.

title: SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS COMPANY PLANS STOCK SALE
description: Iridium World Communications Ltd., which plans to create a network of low-orbit communications satellites, said yesterday that it would offer 10 million shares in an initial public offering expected to raise $188 million. The company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the shares are expected to sell for $19 to $21 each. Iridium, of Hamilton, Bermuda, is an indirect subsidiary of Motorola Inc.

title: Victor Vasarely, Op Art Patriarch, Dies at 90
description: Victor Vasarely, a leader of the short-lived Op Art movement of the 1960's, died at a private clinic in Paris on Saturday. He was 90.

title: Irabu to Take His Fastball and Go Home
description: Hideki Irabu, the most talked about player in or not in spring training, has travel plans Wednesday, and the San Diego Padres apparently have no immediate plans to try to alter them.

title: Singing Sands
description: MARCO POLO heard mysterious booming noises in 13th-century China, and throughout history there have been many accounts of booms, squeaks and ''singing'' apparently emitted by beaches or desert sand. Theorists have suggested many possible causes, including impending earthquakes and subterranean gas explosions, but naturally occurring ''brontides,'' or loud noises, are still enigmas.

title: Looking for Violators
description: State officials announced yesterday that they would try to cure New Jersey motorists of some unappealing habits. Until Labor Day at least, state and local police officers will be looking for tailgaters, lane-changers, and others who practice offensive rather than defensive driving. Fines vary, but a summons for tailgating adds five points to a driver's license. The special patrolling will be done in the six counties that had the most car-crash deaths in 1995: Atlantic, Bergen, Burlington, Essex, Middlesex and Monmouth.

title: YELTSIN SHAKES UP CABINET TO SPEED ECONOMIC CHANGE
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin filled the senior ranks of the Russian Cabinet with economic reformers today, making good on his pledge to overhaul his Government and quicken the pace of economic change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUDEK, ROBERT
description: SAUDEK-Robert. The Musicians, Trustees and Staff of the Marlboro Music School and Festival extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Robert Saudek, who served as a valued member of the Board of Trustees since 1968. We celebrate his lifelong love of music and his wonderfully creative use of television for the arts. His gentle but innovative spirit brought to Marlboro an enthusiastic advocate and friend whom we will all miss. Stephen Stamas, Chairman Board of Trustees Marlboro Music School & Festival

title: Cassell Fitting In Now, But What of Future?
description: Sam Cassell popped his head out of the locker-room door like a cuckoo bird, cooing this simple phrase: ''Calipari, coach of the year.''

title: Minnesota Weekly Closed
description: Stern Publishing, the owner of the Village Voice, last week bought and then closed a Minneapolis-St. Paul alternative weekly, Twin Cities Reader, a major competitor of City Pages, a 100,000-reader weekly it had bought earlier this year. City Pages, which has a circulation of about 95,000, should see a strong sales gain, David Schneiderman, the president of Stern, said. The purchase price was not disclosed.

description: LINSKY-KLEIN-Mollie. On March 17, 1997. Beloved mother of Patricia Linsky Rudick and Ellen Linsky. Mother-in-law of Sam Rudick. Grandmother of Lyris and Charles Mansoor, Daniel Rudick, Jennifer and Jonathan Goodman. Great grandmother of Jake Oren Mansoor. Sister of Florence and Henry Neidich, Jack and Helene Forman. title: H.M.O.'S LIMITING MEDICARE APPEALS, U.S. INQUIRY FINDS
description: Elderly people in health maintenance organizations often find that they cannot obtain the medical services they need because H.M.O.'s limit their ability to appeal adverse decisions on treatment, Federal investigators said today.

title: 3 Prime Sites in Times Square Renewal Plan Go Up for Sale
description: Development rights to three large parcels in Times Square have been put up for sale, and many real estate experts said yesterday that they expected builders to respond with offers swiftly, providing fresh momentum to development plans that had languished for more than a decade.

description: BERNSTEIN-Maurice H. On March 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Leemarie. Dear brother of Frances. Loving uncle and great uncle. Services Tuesday, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Start on U.N. Reform
description: The plans announced yesterday by United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan are a strong sign that he wants to deliver on his commitment to reform. Mr. Annan proposes to combine overlapping departments, cut the budget and bureaucracy and improve efficiency. His proposals for a larger restructuring of the U.N. will come later, but these measures are a sound start and should be rewarded with full payment of America's back dues.

title: Like the Color Green, Giuliani Is Everywhere
description: With the political stage almost completely to himself, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani joined New York in celebrating St. Patrick's Day yesterday, walking -- and rewalking -- the Fifth Avenue parade route for more than three hours before a boisterous, shivering crowd decked out in green ties, green scarves, green hair and even green eyelashes.

title: Holder Expected to Buy Rest of Belgian Utility
description: Powerfin S.A., a Belgian utility, said yesterday that it had delayed its earnings report until today and would hold a joint news conference with Tractebel S.A., which holds 63 percent of Powerfin shares. The announcement has heightened speculation that Tractebel will bid for the Powerfin shares it does not own.

title: Mexico's Ruling Party Is the Loser in State Vote
description: President Ernesto Zedillo's political party suffered sharp setbacks in a closely watched state election on Sunday regarded as a harbinger for national elections in July, according to official results made public today.

title: The Irish Finally Stop To Remember
description: THE way these things get argued in public, you would think that the only issue Irish-Americans have to worry about is whether the homosexuals among them should be allowed to march in the St. Patrick's Day parade. That, and the often-heard lament that the holiday has become amateur night for young drinkers who pour into Manhattan and end up three sheets to the wind before sundown.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Great Lakes Naval Training Center misstated the position of Capt. Cory Whitehead. She heads the center's boot camp but is not the commander of the entire training center.

title: British to Vote on May 1 and Get Their First TV Debates
description: Prime Minister John Major called a national election today for May 1, a vote that is widely seen as likely to end his Conservative Party's 18 years in power. He said he would face his opponent, Tony Blair, the leader of the Labor Party, in televised debates, a first in British politics.

title: New Competition for Old Clips
description: There is an ugly free-for-all in the world of nostalgic sports television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, ROBERT C.
description: PORTER-Robert C., age 85, died of heart failure on March 12. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Elizabeth W. Porter, two children, and two grandchildren. He was raised in Philadelphia, spent most of his life in Summit and Chatham, NJ, and summered in South Harpswell, Maine. He graduated from Bowdoin College and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. He began his long career of legal and investment work in New York at Cravath, Swaine and Moore, was Vice President at Chemical Bank & Trust, and head of investment banking at Shearson, Hamill & Co. He became partner and later President, Chairman and Director of F. Eberstadt & Co. and Eberstadt Fund Management, Inc. Before his retirement in 1987, he was President and then Chairman of Chemical Fund, Inc. and on the Board of Directors of the Alliance Fund. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Lost Tree Charitable Foundation, North Palm Beach, FL, 33408. Memorial services will be held at the Lost Tree Chapel, North Palm Beach on March 24. For information contact Wm. N. Howard Funeral Home, North Palm Beach, FL.

title: Who's Lite Now: TV's Hard Charges on Soft News
description: Last week, Roone Arledge -- for almost 20 years the president of ABC News and for almost 20 days the network's chairman -- said ''NBC Nightly News'' was using soft feature stories to entice audiences. Andrew Lack, the president of NBC News, which has recently been falling behind ABC's ''World News Tonight'' in ratings, retorted that ABC ran even softer features. Dan Rather, whose ''CBS Evening News'' is languishing in last place, called his competitors ''news lite.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELNICK, HAROLD H. RET. SGT. NYPD
description: MELNICK-Harold H. Ret. Sgt. NYPD. Services Wed. 11 AM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: TKTS War? Producers May Offer Competition
description: The discount TKTS booth in Duffy Square has attracted long lines since it opened nearly 24 years ago. Now it is at the center of a Broadway battle pitting the Theater Development Fund, which operates the booth, against the League of American Theaters and Producers, which has drafted a set of proposals to open its own indoor box office in the hope of making ticket-buying easier.

title: LAKE PULLS OUT AS NOMINEE FOR C.I.A., ASSAILING PROCESS AS ENDLESS POLITICAL CIRCUS
description: Anthony Lake withdrew his nomination to be Director of Central Intelligence today, telling President Clinton that he could no longer tolerate endless delays that were damaging the intelligence community, people's reputations and the body politic.

title: Chess
description: Garry Kasparov, at 33, remains superb. He showed that in December by winning the elite Las Palmas International Tournament, and he showed it again last month by winning the elite Linares International Tournament in Spain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOV, DR. S. ZALMAN
description: ABRAMOV-Dr. S. Zalman. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death in Jerusalem of Dr. S. Zalman Abramov, Chairman of the Board of Overseers of our Jerusalem School. A generous benefactor of the College-Institute, Dr. Abramov, with his wife Ayala Zacks-Abramov endowed the S. Zalman and Ayala Abramov Library on the Jerusalem campus of HUC-JIR. An outstanding public servant and a former member of the Israeli Parliment, Dr. Abramov was a tireless champion of the cause of Liberal Judaism in Israel and a dedicated and faithful friend of HUC-JIR. May his memory be a blessing for us all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ayala Zacks-Abramov, his children, grandchildren and great grandson. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, President Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: Russian Envoy Describes Helsinki Summit as Crucial
description: After meeting President Clinton today, Yevgeny M. Primakov, the Russian Foreign Minister, emphasized Moscow's openness to a new relationship with NATO but maintained a tough public stance against the alliance's expansion.

title: Zaire Rebels Face 'Hard Part': Rebuilding
description: A rebel commander surveyed the war wreckage this morning at the international airport outside this riverfront town and shook his head sadly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, ALPHONSE, DR.
description: JORDAN-Alphonse, Dr. The Department of Medicine is saddened by the death of our long time colleague, Dr. Alphonse Jordan. An expert in cardiac catheterization, Dr. Jordan was a member of our faculty since 1956 and rose to the rank of Associate Professor of Medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. As such, he trained a generation of cardiologists and improved the lives of countless patients. Board certified in Cardiology, he was a member of the Alpha Omega Alpha medical honor society. He was active in numerous organizations, including the National Medical Association, and he received the Walter Booker Award of the Association of Black Cardiologists. We express condolences to his family. James Scheuer, M.D. Chairman Milford Fulop, M.D. Vice Chairman J. Anthony Ware, M.D. Director of Cardiology Edmund H. Sonnenblick, M.D. Distinguished Professor of Cardioogy

title: H.I.P. Unit Decides To Review Agencies
description: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its consolidated insurance plans, which has been divided among several agencies on a regional basis. Estimated combined billings could reach as much as $15 million.

title: Corel WTA Chief to Step Down
description: ANNE PERSON WORCESTER, chief executive of the Corel WTA tour, has informed her board that she will not seek to retain her position when her contract, estimated to be worth $250,000 annually, expires at the end of this year.

title: When Maturity Is the Enemy
description: For the first time in three figure-skating competitions, Michelle Kwan did not fall today. But while she maintained her feet, she is still struggling to maintain her confidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, BENJAMIN
description: FELDMAN-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Tessie for 63 years. Devoted father of Stanley, Eleanor, Stephen and Henrietta. Cherished grandfather of Jill, Michele, Randi, Steven, Allison and Gary. Loving brother of Ceil Aboff. Funeral services on Tuesday, at 9:30 A.M., at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Study of Ocean Currents Offers Clues to Global Climate Shifts
description: As scientists struggle to understand how and why the earth's climate is changing, they are increasingly looking deep into the oceans, where oscillations in water temperature that travel on stately currents from one continent to another may cause weather trends to change from decade to decade.

title: Politicians Emeritus Enlist in Fight for Campaign Changes
description: The White House broadened a publicity blitz today on behalf of stalled legislation to regulate political fund-raising, enlisting two political dignitaries to whip up public support for political reform.

title: Canada Says U.S. Falls Short With Proposal to Bolster Air Quality
description: In an unusual formal criticism of another country's domestic policies, the Government of Canada maintains that proposals in the United States to toughen air quality standards -- denounced by industry as too demanding -- do not go far enough.

description: HOROWITZ-David. You will be missed and remembered, dearest David. Our hearts go out to Edith, Richard, Marjorie and Harold. Rae and Julian Nelkin

title: Zaire's Leaders Call for Calm, But Few in the Capital Listen
description: With its military crumbling in the face of steady rebel advances, the President rumored to be dying of cancer, and the country's political class badly divided, Zaire's Government today sought to reassure citizens that the chaos in the countryside would not arrive here.

title: What L.B.J. Knew
description: Sometimes the most startling stories barely make it into the papers. Here's one that ran Feb. 15 on an inside page of The Times. It discloses that Lyndon Johnson, as early as 1964, viewed the Vietnam War as pointless.

title: Pecs First, Feet Last
description: In ''Tap Dogs,'' the Australian beefcake tap-a-thon that opened Sunday night at the Union Square Theater, six husky hoofers show off more than their fancy footwork. They preen and strut with the vanity of bodybuilders. Two of the sturdiest strip to the waist for no other reason than to flash their glistening pecs.

title: Cone Has Fastball Humming Again
description: The request was simple. To provide them with a compelling story, reporters jokingly asked David Cone to either pitch very powerfully or very poorly today. Cone nodded convincingly, did three more interviews less than an hour before the game, and then obliged.

title: A Stir Over Bartoli's Cancellation
description: Singer cancellations in opera are hardly rare, particularly in winter, when colds and flu find fertile ground in the world's opera houses. But when a star singer drops out of a Metropolitan Opera Saturday afternoon broadcast virtually at the last minute, as Cecilia Bartoli did this week, and when the Met's program insert notes only that she is being replaced by Marie McLaughlin, while citing illness as the reason for three other replacements in the cast, stories of diva temperament and backstage drama spread quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, REBECCA GLICK
description: EPSTEIN-Rebecca Glick. Age 98, died March 15. A beloved mother, grandmother, and greatgrandmother. Forever a teacher and passionate advocate. Memorial service to be announced.

title: March's Upstarts
description: There are still two weeks left of March Madness, but already the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament has shown us that for unpredictability and spontaneity, no other major sporting event can touch it. This is a monthlong exercise in the unexpected, where teams that nobody knows emerge from nowhere to upset the laws of probability. Coppin State upsets heavily favored South Carolina and loses by a single point to Texas. The College of Charleston, seeded number 12 in its bracket, defeats number 5, Maryland, and barely loses to number 4, Arizona. Tennessee-Chattanooga, a 14th seed, dispatches Georgia and Illinois and remains a threat to face Kansas, on paper the best team in the tournament, in the Final Four.

title: Court Worker Says a City Judge Struck Her
description: A female court employee has accused a City Housing Court judge of swatting her with his hand while they were standing in a courthouse hallway, according to the judge's lawyer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPNICK, OSCAR
description: KAPNICK-Oscar. Died at age 84 March 16, 1997. Beloved husband and dearest friend of Syd (Sylvia) Kapnick, devoted and loving father of Steven Kapnick, the late Jo Anne Kapnick and the late Susan Kapnick Bart. Devoted and loving father-in-law of Joan Kapnick and Jacob Bart. Adored and cherished grandfather of Joshua and Madelyn Bart. He was a warm-hearted and generous man, deeply loved and respected by all those who knew him. His many charitable activities and contributions included long-time support for Sound Shore Medical Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, United Hebrew Geriatric Center, The Guidance Center, and Temple Israel of New Rochelle, of which he was a trustee. Services will be held at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pine Brook Boulevard, New Rochelle, NY on Tuesday, March 18 at 10AM. Shiva will be observed from Tuesday-Thursday at the Bart residence, 19 Abbey Close, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Corps Plans To Dredge Harbor Silt
description: The Army Corps of Engineers will soon begin dredging thousands of tons of silt from the clogged navigation channels and marine terminals in New York Harbor, officials announced yesterday.

title: The Micro-Mini's Return
description: It's back. The micro-miniskirt, a mere swath of fabric barely 16 inches long, resurfaced in the fall European shows as well as the pre-fall American collections. For some, of course, it never went away, and so spring versions are already available.

title: Zaire's French Connection
description: There seem to be few experiences in politics as satisfying as expressing high-minded principles while acting for reasons of low self-interest. Case in point: the French Government's repeated calls for a cease-fire and a multinational force to end civil war in Zaire.

title: Cosmic Debt
description: In a previous time, before science knew what these mysterious visitors were, comets were often viewed as harbingers of war or death. In 1456, during an impressive passage of what is now called Halley's Comet, some in Europe prayed for protection from ''the Devil, the Turk and the Comet.'' In 1910, when Earth passed through Halley's tail, some sold ''comet pills'' to guard people from the supposedly poisonous gas.

title: Group Accused Of Disrupting Work Program
description: In an unusual dispute pitting one homeless advocacy group against another, the operator of a homeless shelter in Harlem accused the Coalition for the Homeless yesterday of disrupting a 10-month-old program that requires residents to work and pay for shelter.

title: The Job Engine Sputters
description: Joe L. Roby, president of the securities firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, took home $33 million last year. Perhaps shareholders did not mind, because the company, like most of Wall Street, had a very good year. But Mr. Roby apparently did not spend much of his wealth in New York's bodegas, for the city's unemployment rate rose last year to 9.9 percent, one of the nation's highest big-city rates. And therein lies a historical disjuncture.

title: Biggest Danish Bank In Swedish Expansion
description: Denmark's largest bank, Den Danske Bank, has bought 76.9 percent of the shares in the Swedish provincial bank Oestgoeta Enskilda for 2.2 billion kronor ($286 million) from Lundbergs, a Swedish holding company. Lundbergs realized a capital gain of 1.4 billion kronor ($182 million) on the sale. Den Danske Bank will bid 50.5 kronor a share for the rest of the Oestgoeta shares, the same price it paid Lundbergs. The total price would be 2.8 billion kronor ($364 million).

title: EQUITY INNS TO ACQUIRE 28 HOTELS FOR $182 MILLION
description: Equity Inns Inc. said yesterday that it would buy 28 Hampton Inn hotels for about $182 million from Growth Hotel Investors and Growth Hotel Investors II, raising the number of Hampton Inns it owns to 64. Equity Inns, a real estate investment trust, said the hotels have a total of 3,487 rooms and are primarily in major urban and suburban markets in the Southeast and Midwest. The purchase needs to be approved the limited partners of the closely held Growth Hotel Investors and Growth Hotel Investors II. Equity Inns, based in Memphis, owns 55 hotels in 28 states, with a total of 6,554 rooms. The hotels operate under such names as Hampton Inns, Residence Inns, Homewood Suites, Comfort Inns and Holiday Inns.

title: UConn Rolls On Without Super Sub
description: Sometimes, when the going gets tough, the tough play better. That is what happened tonight, when Connecticut, in its first game without the injured Shea Ralph, decimated Iowa, 72-53, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: The Scientific Method
description: If there was any concern that the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search had become ''soft,'' as many of the nation's top high school students entered social science projects, those fears have been allayed by this year's competition. The three social science projects that made it to the final ten were all very rigorous, and the top prizes went to traditional ''hard science'' entries.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALUMINUM CO. OF AMERICA Pittsburgh, agreed to sell an aluminum bottle-cap plant in Richmond, Ind., that had sales of about $45 million last year to Silgan Holdings Inc., of Stamford, Conn., for an undisclosed price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, CHARLES H.
description: DYSON-Charles H. It was a Spring morning, a quarter-century ago, when word first traveled down to the Village Green in Millbrook that a handful of young teenagers had moved into the little white house on the hill, formerly The Millbrook Manor. The word was ''Daytop'' and the currency was ''drug abuse''. The Town was still recoiling from the blemish of Timothy Leary's sojourn there and his gospel of 'dropping out' and hopelessness. Charles Dyson was the very first to arrive at our door, greeted by the radiant, hope-filled faces of young Daytoppers, bent on recovery of their lives. He found it difficult to tear himself away that morning and down through these years remained ''our Kids' best Friend'' and Neighbor. Each Christmas Eve, our love unfolded all over again as our Daytop Christmas Choristers made their way to his door. Oftentimes, I mused that he surely meditated upon O. Henry's somber reflection: ''No calamity so touches the common heart of humanity as does the straying of a little child. Their feet are so uncertain and feeble; their paths so steep and strange.'' His incredible capacity for caring has left with us indelible footprints of a life well-lived. May he be welcomed home by his beloved 'Lord of the Little Ones.' Our prayerful support for the Dyson Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President Daytop Village, Inc.

description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, America's largest public pension fund, said yesterday that it would suspend all trading with the Nomura Securities Company because of a scandal at the Japanese brokerage.

description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that the Republican Party should consider shelving its demand for a big tax cut to advance the prospects of balancing the budget.

In ''Carmina Burana,'' Carl Orff and his medieval versifiers produced a hybrid between cantata and spectacle, though for the purposes of concert halls the spectacle is detachable.

Active as well in the professional theater, she worked for the New York City Center, the Theater Guild, was a fund raiser for the origination of Joe Papp's Public Theater, worked on Broadway for several company managers booking theater parties, was a force behind the Royal Poinciana Playhouse Children's Theater, and had a long time involvement with the Palm Beach Opera and the Miami City Ballet. P.L.C. and partners that include Rolls-Royce P.L.C. won a contract yesterday worth almost $:2 billion ($3.2 billion) to build three British nuclear missile submarines, ending 15 months of talks over price. The Ministry of Defense said in December 1995 that it would award the contract to the Marconi military electronics unit of the British G.E., picking it over the VSEL shipyard as prime contractor. The ministry had held up formal signing of the contract until the price was agreed.

title: G.E. Counters on Lawsuit
description: The General Electric Company charged in a lawsuit Friday that a group of artists had only themselves to blame for losing their investments in a mercury-contaminated factory they converted into lofts in 1993. The artists, who were forced to move out last year, sued G.E. to regain their losses, claiming the company was responsible because it made mercury vapor lamps there until it sold the building in 1948. But on Friday, G.E. filed a countersuit in Federal District Court dividing the blame between the artists, who knew of the contamination before they moved in, and the man who sold the building to the artists.

Mr. Gross, who emerged from a coma on March 2, spoke a few words to his family at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan on Saturday -- ''mostly yes and no,'' his brother said -- and now walks, with assistance, from his bed to a chair nearby.

It also marks a setback for the effort to restore stability to the Central Intelligence Agency, which is reeling from changes in leadership and discoveries of traitors in its ranks.

title: Credit Card Default Rate Is Climbing

The bad news is that a growing number cannot pay their bills, and in recent months the problem has been getting worse.

title: Mexican Data Suggest 30% Overstatement of Oil Reserves
description: The Mexican state oil monopoly has begun to release data that suggest that it has overstated its proven crude oil reserves by perhaps 30 percent or more since the late 1970's. The effort appears to be an attempt by Mexico to lay to rest a long controversy over the true size of the country's readily extractable petroleum wealth.

title: Avis Finds Itself at the Center Of Discrimination Complaints
description: ''The rental of an automobile is not an inalienable right granted in the Constitution,'' Richard Aronow, president of the New York Rental Vehicle Association, observes. Yet the scope of those rights has provoked a growing, national brawl, with Avis, the No. 2 rental agency, at its center.

title: New Gene Research Aims at Lowly Yeast
description: Without beer, wine and bread, the rise of civilization would scarcely have been possible. All are the gift of yeast, and now the microscopic, one-celled fungus is being asked to fork over yet another grand donation: the genetic working manual common to all plants and animals.

title: Pearson's New Chief Discloses Big Plans for Financial Times
description: Marjorie M. title: C.I.A. to Examine Possible Links Of Agency to Democratic Party

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, EAMONN

Eamonn's devotion to the Foundling began in 1980 with the first Eamonn Doran Golf Classic. Through Eamonn's untiring efforts and boundless energy over the last 17 years, public awareness and significant funds were raised for the children and families that the Foundling serves. With Eamonn's passing, the world is a less warm and friendly place and he will be greatly missed by all who knew him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Clare, his sons, Dermot and Edward, his family and his many friends on their profound loss. title: VALERO ENERGY TO BUY SALOMON REFINING UNIT
description: Salomon Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its oil-refining unit to the Valero Energy Corporation for $485 million in cash and stock, shedding a business that has steadily lost money. The agreement to sell Basis Petroleum Inc. will result in a $290 million after-tax loss for Salomon, which is based in New York, requiring it to restate its fourth-quarter earnings to a loss. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Salomon fell $1.50, to $52.625, while Valero rose $1.125, to $33.625. Valero, of San Antonio, said the agreement would not affect plans to spin off its refining and marketing business, of which Basis now will be a part, and to merge its natural-gas services business with the PG&E Corporation. Valero will pay cash and $120 million of its stock.

title: Bad Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: AETNA, Hartford, named Joseph T. Sebastianelli president.

title: Esquire Writer Gets No. 2 Editing Slot
description: Esquire magazine has announced that Randall Rothenberg, a writer and columnist, will become the editorial director, the second in command. The change moves Mr. Rothenberg above the longtime deputy editor, David Hirshey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, CLARK H.
description: JOHNSON-Clark H. The Greater New York Chapter of the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America mourns the passing of a great, compassionate and generous friend. Board of Trustees

title: RALCORP TO ADD WORTZ TO PRIVATE-LABEL CRACKER UNIT
description: Ralcorp Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Wortz Company, one of the largest United States makers of store-brand crackers and cookies, to expand its private-label food business. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The closely held Wortz, which is based in Poteau, Okla., and has annual sales of about $65 million, will be added to Bremner Inc., Ralcorp's private-label cracker and cookie unit, which had $77.8 million in sales in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Shares of Ralcorp, which is based in St. Louis, rose 37.5 cents yesterday to close at $10.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Auditioning for College, They Hope to Acquire Both Cool and Contacts
description: Nathan Blehar, a 17-year-old just in town from Sterling, Mass., was waiting in a classroom at the New School, on the fifth floor of its new West 13th Street building. ''Did they say I could warm up in here?' he asked anxiously, as he opened his saxophone case. He played a few notes. Then Arnie Lawrence, the principal member of the school's four-person admissions jury, entered the room. Nathan's shot at a jazz education was about to begin.

title: TV Bureaus at Marriotts
description: WCBS News said last week that it would soon open five bureaus in Marriott hotels in the metropolitan area. Each bureau, expected to open ''sometime in May,'' will be staffed with a reporter and will have live remote-controlled cameras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, JOSEPH
description: FUCHS-Joseph, 97. On March 14, 1997. Renowned teacher of violin for over fifty years. Devoted husband of the late Doris Levy, cherished brother of the late Lillian Fuchs Stein, violist. Beloved father of Elinor Fuchs and grandfather of Katherine Eban and Claire Oakes Finkelstein. Service Tuesday, 11:15 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Beth-El Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNES, RUTH
description: GRUNES-Ruth. The New York Freudian Society deeply grieves the death of our dear colleague, Dr. Ruth Grunes. She will be missed personally and professionally by the members of our Society, where her important contributions touched many aspects of our lives and functioning. She was Vice President of our Executive Board, Director of our Training Institute, and in her last position, Chairperson of our Ethics Committee. No one could have given more than she, and we are thankful that she gave so generously and so wisely. We will honor her memory. Harriet I. Basseches, Ph.D., Pres. New York Freudian Society

title: Coffee Prices in Steep Drop On Signs of a Supply Buildup
description: Coffee prices retreated sharply yesterday, as the recent run-up in prices drew in new supplies.

title: Making Sophistication Look Natural
description: Nancy Meehan's recent choreography creates a vibrant splash of rhythm. ''Night Suspension,'' a premiere, and two older works that the Nancy Meehan Dance Company presented on Friday night all burst into strongly defined rhythmic patterns from the start.

title: Modest Comforts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCK, FURMAN
description: FINCK-Furman. Age 96. Died March 10th. Members and friends of both the Salmagundi Club and the Artists' Fellowship, Inc. mourn the passing of Furman, a renowned portraitist, teacher of art and longtime member. A memorial service at Salmagundi, 47 Fifth Ave. is planned.

title: Devils Score Once for Each Side in Uncharacteristic Loss
description: The Devils, who are hardly prone to beating themselves, appeared to do just that tonight. An accidental shot on his own goal by Bobby Holik beat Devils goaltender Mike Dunham early in the third period, broke open a tight game and helped lead the Florida Panthers to a 4-1 triumph at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, FRED G.
description: ARMSTRONG - Fred G. The American Geographical Society notes with regret the death on February 21, 1997 of its Councilor since 1974, Fred G. Armstrong. His good humor, good will, and insights will be missed. Richard H. Nolte, Chairman Emeritus John E. Gould, Chairman Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, President Mary Lynne Bird, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MATORIN, MERVYN
description: MATORIN-Mervyn. March 18, 1918. Today marks your birthday. Remembered every day with love and loss. Toujours, Ellie

title: Dreaming of Dodgers
description: To the Editor:

title: Cott Buys U.S. Company
description: The Cott Corporation said today that it had acquired Texas Beverages Packers Inc., a soft-drink maker, for about $19.8 million, continuing its plan to increase its manufacturing capacity in the United States. Texas Beverages, based in San Antonio, had 1996 sales of $32 million. Cott, a Toronto maker of private-label beverages, said it expected the acquisition of Texas Beverages to allow it to export to Mexico.

title: KEY ENERGY TO PAY $20.6 MILLION FOR WELL-CO OIL SERVICE
description: Key Energy Group Inc. said yesterday that it intended to buy Well-Co Oil Service Inc. for about $20.6 million in cash and stock. Key Energy, an oil and natural gas producer based in New Brunswick, N.J., said Well-Co operates 82 rigs in the northern Permian Basin in western Texas. In addition, Key Energy said it had acquired certain assets of Tri-State Wellhead and Valve Inc. for about $1.6 million in cash and stock and signed a letter of intent to acquire certain assets of Elder Well Service Inc. for $609,000 in cash. Key Energy said that the acquisitions would bring its total well-service rig count to 495.

title: Blue Jays Aiming to Gain Attention
description: Dan Plesac called Cam Bonifay last November and accused the Pittsburgh Pirates' general manager of lying to him. Last week Plesac saw Bonifay and profusely apologized to him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHANKER, ALBERT
description: SHANKER-Albert. A memorial service will be held Monday, March 24th, 3:30 P.M., at the NY State Theater, Lincoln Center.

title: Jet Forced Back at Newark
description: A Continental Airlines jet flying from Newark to Cincinnati was forced to return to Newark after pilots noticed reduced pressure in one of the jet's hydraulic systems, an airline spokesman said. Flight 1059, a Boeing 737, took off shortly after 4:35 P.M., said the spokesman, David Messing, and landed about 5 P.M.

title: Cyril Brickfield, 78, Leader Who Made A.A.R.P. a Power
description: Cyril Francis Brickfield, former executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons and once the No. 2 official at the Veterans Administration, died on Friday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 78 and lived in Bethesda.

title: Diabetic Ulcer Drug Clears Clinical Trial
description: Magainin Pharmaceuticals Inc., a biotechnology company based in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., said yesterday that its first drug, a new type of antibiotic compound discovered in the skin of an African frog, had shown positive results in a clinical trial against infected diabetic foot ulcers.

title: Johnson Settles H.I.V.-Test Suit
description: Johnson & Johnson said today that it had settled a dispute in an agreement that lets it keep control of its H.I.V. home-testing business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUSCHER, DOROTHY
description: RAUSCHER - Dorothy. Beloved wife of the late Hilbert. Adored sister and best friend of Jean Hurwitz. Devoted aunt of Michael Wellner and Susan Merrett. Cherished grand-aunt of Jonah, Keith, Jonathan, Molly and Sam. Services were held.

title: A Bug in the Bug-Zapper
description: Bug-zappers, those sizzling, glowing fixtures in many a suburban yard, kill billions of insects each year -- but hardly any are mosquitoes or other biting pests, a study of six of the devices has found.

title: Firetruck in Fatal Collision in Queens Had Sirens On, Officials Say
description: One day after a firetruck went through a red light and collided with a car in Queens, killing three young people, the Fire Department defended itself, saying the truck had its sirens and horns blaring and had slowed down as it approached the intersection.

title: PHYSICIAN MANAGEMENT COMPANIES COMPLETE MERGER
description: FPA Medical Management Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired AHI Healthcare Systems Inc. for stock worth $107.4 million, creating one of the largest doctors' office management companies in the United States. The deal calls for FPA to exchange 0.391 share for each AHI share, or a total of 5.69 million FPA shares for AHI's 14.55 million outstanding shares. The exchange values AHI shares at $7.3801 each based on yesterday's closing price for FPA of $18.875, down $1.6875. FPA, of San Diego, and AHI, of Downey, Calif., are physician practice management companies, which handle doctors' back-office chores and contract negotiations with insurers and health care companies. AHI shares fell 37.5 cents, to $7.50.

title: FTP Software Narrows Review to 3 Agencies
description: FTP Software Inc. in Andover, Mass., has narrowed a review on its account, with billings estimated at $3 million to $4 million, to three finalists. The account had been handled by Matzell, Richard & Watts Inc. in Boston. Rick Hooker, managing partner at Pile & Company in Boston, a consulting company helping with the review, identified the finalists as: Anderson & Lembke in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, and Houston Herstek Favat in Boston. A decision is expected at the end of the month, Mr. Hooker said.

title: Students Share the Spotlight
description: Eliot Feld's choreographic ability to disrupt formal orderliness with imaginative eccentricity made it fun to watch the program Ballet Tech presented Sunday afternoon at the Joyce Theater. The company shared the matinee with Kids Dance, the troupe from the Ballet Tech School.

title: Play Ball? It's Too Much Like Work
description: NOT long after the Pittsburgh Pirates won the 1979 World Series, their fatherly first baseman and philosophical slugger, Willie Stargell, was talking about the game he played so well.

title: Backyard Astronomers Enlist as Foot Soldiers of Astrophysics
description: WITH little more than a 10-inch telescope and a laptop computer, Tonny Vanmunster is a mere foot soldier in the struggle to understand the universe, vastly outgunned by the world's major observatories.

title: ITT SAYS IT MAY SELL ITS EDUCATION SERVICES UNIT
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday in a Federal filing that it might sell its education services business, valued at about $562.5 million, as part of a plan to fend off a $10.5 billion hostile offer from the Hilton Hotels Corporation. ITT, which owns the Sheraton hotel chain and the Caesars World casinos, has an 83.3 percent stake in ITT Educational Services Inc., which provides post-secondary technical degrees. ITT, whose headquarters are in New York, is resisting Hilton by focusing on Sheraton and Caesars and selling other assets. ITT's shares fell 50 cents, to $59.50. Shares of the education unit rose 37.5 cents, to $25.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASDON, MILDRED
description: LASDON-Mildred. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and benefactor Mildred Lasdon. Mrs. Lasdon, along with her late husband William S. Lasdon, will be long remembered for their generosity and commitment to the Medical Center. From the establishment of the William and Mildred Lasdon Biomedical Research Center and the Stanley S. Lasdon Teaching Laboratories to the endowment of the Nanette Laitman Distinguished Professorship in Public Health, their devotion to the advancement of health care, medical research and education has left an indelible mark on the medical and scientific community. Our deepest condolences are extended to her children, Nanette and Robert, and the entire Lasdon family. Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Cornell University Medical College Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean Cornell University Medical College John F. McGillicuddy Chairman, Board of Governors The New York Hospital David B. Skinner M.D. President The New York Hospital

title: Howe's Plan Called 'Crazy'
description: Gordie Howe may be planning a one-game comeback for a minor league team on April Fool's Day, but Maurice Richard has no such notion. Richard is six years older than Howe, who will be 69 on April 1 when he is scheduled to play for the Syracuse Crunch of the American Hockey League.

title: Rockwell Intends to Spin Off Its Automotive Parts Operations
description: Continuing to reposition itself as an electronics and communications company, the Rockwell International Corporation announced yesterday that it would spin off its automotive parts operations as an independent, publicly traded company.

title: CUNY Trustees Question the Value of Remedial Programs in Math and Writing
description: Led by Gov. George E. Pataki's appointees, the trustees of the City University of New York are questioning whether the system's extensive remedial programs for students who cannot perform high school-level math, writing or English are worth the cost.

title: Striking a Balance Between Deer and Residents in the Florida Keys
description: For two years, the endangered Key deer have died in record numbers. That, some residents of the Florida Keys say, may be good news.

title: A Tale Seen in the Mind's Eye, Told by the Body's
description: It was January 1996 and Jean-Dominique Bauby lay in Room 119 of the Naval Hospital at Berck-sur-Mer in northern Normandy, the victim of a stroke that had plunged him into a 20-day coma and left him paralyzed from head to foot. Only his left eye was open. He was asked to blink once if he understood what he was being told.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVBERG, HERMAN
description: OVBERG-Herman, 93. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of William and (Anita), cherished grandfather of Diana and Paul, dear great-grandfather of Leah. Service is today, at 2:15 P.M., ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: People
description: * Steve St. Clair was named creative director at the New York office of Earle Palmer Brown, succeeding Michael Drazen, now the agency's chief creative officer. Mr. St. Clair had been associate creative director at W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore.

title: C.I.A. Data Suggesting Wider Spread of Gulf War Nerve Gas
description: Evidence gathered by the Central Intelligence Agency shows that clouds of nerve gas from the March 1991 demolition of a vast Iraqi ammunition depot may have spread over a much larger area than previously reported, raising the possibility that hundreds of thousands of American troops were exposed to very low doses of chemical weapons shortly after the Persian Gulf war.

title: Irish Faith and Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian's Comeback In Pairs Is Stunning
description: Fourteen months ago, her former skating partner sliced a deep cut into her head, which required emergency surgery and left her temporarily unable to speak. Even now, Yelena Berezhnaya of Russia talks deliberately and with an accent that her coach cannot quite place.

title: People
description: * Lynne Christopher was named to the new position of executive vice president and corporate media director at HMS Partners, Miami. She had been executive vice president and executive media director at David Cravit & Associates, Chicago.

title: Disney, McDonald's Plan Joint Campaign
description: The McDonald's Corporation and the Walt Disney Company yesterday announced a series of promotional campaigns that will be the first cosponsored by the two companies under a 10-year cross-promotional agreement that took effect on Jan. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, DAVID
description: HOROWITZ-David. 82 years old, of Lake Worth, Florida. Husband of Edith, father of Richard, Marjorie Schultz, and Harold, and grandfather to six grandchildren. Will be missed by all for his friendship, wisdom, and humor, but most of all, for his love of family. Donations may be made to the Leukemia Society of America, 600 Third Avenue, NY NY 10016.

title: Israel Begins Jerusalem Housing Project Without Confrontation
description: Surrounded by a thick cordon of soldiers and cameras, Israeli bulldozers scraped the first muddy ruts today for the construction of the new Jewish neighborhood at the focus of the latest crisis in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's stormy dealings with the Palestinians.

title: Peripheral Perplexity
description: To the Editor:

title: Healthier Is Cheaper With True Prevention
description: To the Editor

title: Remedial Education at College
description: The City University of New York's trustees made a reasonable decision this week when they decided to re-evaluate remedial programs through which many students enter the public college system. Given tight times, all programs need to run as efficiently as possible. Even so, the trustees should beware of foreclosing access for bright but poorly prepared students for whom some remedial programs will always be necessary. Before hacking away at remediation, CUNY officials should make sure that programs to offer richer courses in the public high schools have had a chance to work.

title: Lease for Pension Adviser
description: The Frank Russell Trust Company has leased about 18,000 square feet, part of the 40th floor, at 590 Madison Avenue, the former I.B.M. building at 56th Street, for its New York offices.

title: Taking the Heat
description: David Brinkley, in his book ''Washington Goes to War,'' recounted that as the Senate was about to vote on Dean Acheson's nomination as Assistant Secretary of State, a friend called Acheson with an invitation. ''If you're confirmed, will you come for dinner?'' she asked. ''If not, will you come after dinner for dancing?''

title: Galbreath Officers Defect to Cushman
description: The competition between real estate companies in New York is as hot as the midtown office market.

title: Byte of Advice: Now Make PC's Buyer-Friendly
description: To the Editor:

title: Tuning In to Puerto Rico
description: ''One of the strangest consequences of the Second World War,'' Aaron Copland wrote in 1967, ''has been the belated discovery that there is music to the south of us.'' This was, of course, a rhetorical flourish: Copland, of all people, knew listeners were still getting used to the idea that music was composed on the Western side of the Atlantic, and it cannot have surprised him that audiences were slow to recognize Latin American concert music. He crusaded for it, using its rhythms and melodic turns in works like ''El Salon Mexico'' and ''Danzon Cubano,'' and forging professional links between North, Central and South American composers. Yet for all that, the ''music to the south of us'' remains largely uncharted territory in the United States and Europe.

title: 25 Arrested in Raids On Mob-Run Betting
description: Law enforcement officials said yesterday that they had broken up a major mob-run sports-betting operation that had moved some of its sites to Philadelphia from New York to evade a crackdown.

title: Ralph S. Abascal, 62, Dies; Leading Lawyer for the Poor
description: Ralph S. Abascal, a pioneering legal-services lawyer in California who won landmark decisions on behalf of farm workers, welfare recipients and undocumented immigrants, died on Monday at his home in Berkeley. He was 62 and had been suffering from cancer.

title: Four Top-Seeded Teams Take Lumps and Carry On
description: Connecticut (32-0) has lost the freshman who made things happen. The best player for Stanford (32-1) has a sprained ankle and a misplaced shooting eye. Old Dominion (31-1) and North Carolina (29-2) have survived overtime games against eighth-seeded teams from the Big Ten.

title: Burnett Buys Share In Williams-Labadie
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago said yesterday that it had acquired a minority interest in Williams-Labadie Advertising in Itasca, Ill., an agency that specializes in medical advertising. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Easing Crisis, China Lets North Korea Defector Go
description: China defused a five-week diplomatic crisis today by spiriting a senior North Korean defector out of the country and sending him by special plane to the Philippines, where he is expected to stay for a decent diplomatic interval before traveling to South Korea.

title: Novartis Says Profits Fell 45% in 1996
description: Novartis A.G., the giant drug company that was formed by the merger of Sandoz A.G. and Ciba-Geigy A.G., said today that profit fell 45 percent last year, reflecting a reorganization charge.

title: Intel Seen Facing Fight On Chips
description: The Intel Corporation might finally get a run for its money when Advanced Micro Devices Inc. releases its powerful K6 chip next month.

title: Technology Stocks: Heroes to Bums
description: For a time this year, they were the high fliers -- the darlings of a magnificent bull market that was soaring to new heights.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VAUGHN, DOLORES.
description: VAUGHN-Dolores. I remember geese, mermaids, and your beautiful face. You were too delicate for this earth. I was blessed to know you. You live on, fiercely, within me. You are my faith and you are my spirit. As sure as I will always love you, I will see you again. Justine

title: How One Fantasy Land Holds Onto the Heart of Another
description: One thing the Academy Awards will not have this year is a speech on Chinese repression in Tibet by Richard Gere, the actor who has led the way in Hollywood's growing concern for Tibetan rights. But in a larger sense, Mr. Gere -- banned as an Oscar presenter after his televised denunciation of China in 1993 -- no longer needs to steal a platform to advance his favorite cause. Whatever happens at the Academy Awards on Monday, Tibet is looming larger than ever on the show business map.

title: Japanese Official Meets Fujimori on Hostages
description: The Deputy Foreign Minister of Japan met today with President Alberto K. Fujimori and members of a commission mediating talks with leftist rebels holding 72 hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It has been a decade since her ''Just Say No'' emerged as a representative slogan of the Reagan era, but NANCY REAGAN is still being honored for her work in the antidrug campaign.

title: CB COMMERCIAL AGREES TO BUY KOLL REAL ESTATE SERVICES
description: CB Commercial Real Estate Services Group, the nation's largest commercial property broker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Koll Real Estate Services, the largest property manager, for $145 million in stock. The combined firm would have about $759 million in annual revenue and 6,600 employees. CB Commercial's shares rose $1.25 yesterday, to $25.75. The news was released after the close of trading. Under the agreement, Los Angeles-based CB Commercial will issue about six million of its shares, or a 30 percent stake, to the owners of closely held Koll, based in Newport Beach, Calif. Koll's primary owners are management, the investment bank Freeman Spogli & Company and Leon Black's Apollo Real Estate Advisers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about discrimination complaints against Avis, showing William B. Ward, a former Avis employee, carried an erroneous credit. The picture was by Mike Wyke, not Tyler Hicks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREHY, JAMES A.
description: TREHY-James A. On March 17, 1997. Beloved brother of John J., Robert and the late Mary Mc Govern and William Trehy. Also survived by loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch & Sons Funeral Home, 4307 Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside, N.Y. Funeral mass Queen of Angels R.C. Church, Friday, 10:30AM. Interment Calvery Cemetery. Visitation Thursday, 2-5 & 7-9:30PM.

title: Fresh from London, Saatchi & Saatchi's new chief executive in the U.S. is off to a fast start.
description: ADVERTISING American-style has baffled more than a few foreigners. But a top British agency executive, whose initial foray onto Madison Avenue is not yet three months old, is already making her mark.

title: Sound Tested to Blast Heart Clots
description: THE treatment of heart attacks has changed dramatically in the last 20 years. While once doctors stood by and did what they could to pull a patient through the crisis, today they try to stop the crisis, using aggressive treatments aimed at actually interrupting the heart attack and preventing permanent cardiac damage.

title: Angiograph Use Questioned
description: CHALLENGING the way many cardiologists treat patients, a study by researchers at the Department of Veterans Affairs suggests that routine early use of coronary angiography testing may be harmful to survivors of one kind of heart attack.

title: Power Brokers In New York: Beware Iridescent Ties
description: JOHNNIE L. COCHRAN JR. may be, as he proclaims, the King of Los Angeles, but he hasn't figured out where to have lunch in this town yet. The most famous lawyer in America right now, he is intimidated by Manhattan, where he has been living four days a week since January, working as a moderator for ''Cochran & Grace,'' a nightly legal analysis show on Court TV.

title: Novell Selects Internet Guru To Lead Struggling Company
description: Novell Inc., the struggling network software company, tapped one of the best- known visionaries of the Internet to be its new leader today. Eric Schmidt, chief technology officer of Sun Microsystems Inc., was named Novell's chairman and chief executive, ending a seven-month search.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACROIX, MARIAN E.
description: LaCROIX-Marian E., of Bronxville, N.Y. on March 17, 1997. Daughter of the late Harry and Marion Harte LaCroix; sister of Jean Westman; aunt of Marian T. Westman, Esq. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 9:30 and 10:30 a.m. Friday. Mass of Christian burial St. Josephs Church, Bronxville on Friday, March 21 at 11:00 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, DAVID HAZZAN
description: MANN-David Hazzan. We record in sorrow the passing of the Hazzam Emeritus of Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, NY for over four decades. Quietly and gently he served the spiritual needs of his congregants with great dignity, warmth and care. A dedicated hazzan, he became a member of the Cantors Assembly in its earliest days, and remained an active participant winning the admiration and respect of collegues and congregants alike. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Frances, his children Thelma and Zachary, and all his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Abraham Lubin, President Hazzan Samuel Rosenbaum, Executive Vice President

title: The Finns, East-West Headwaiters, Feel Ill-Served
description: For 40 years, Helsinki had been known mainly for saunas, spying and summitry. Finland, the tiny Nordic neighbor of the vast Communist empire, kept its hard-won independence after World War II by pledging a friendship for the Soviet Union that it never really felt.

title: Two Premieres Planned by the Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera is to present two company premieres and three new productions during the 1997-98 season. In addition, the director and set designer Robert Wilson, well known for his striking productions in Europe and in other opera houses in this country, is to make his first appearance at the Met with a new staging of Wagner's ''Lohengrin.''.

title: Pact Reported For New York Lilco Takeover
description: Gov. George E. Pataki plans to announce an agreement today on a multibillion dollar state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, including billions of dollars in debt from the defunct Shoreham nuclear plant, participants in the negotiations said last night.

title: Healthier Is Cheaper With True Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disney Series
description: ABC announced yesterday that it would include a number of the Walt Disney Company's most famous children's movies in its new ''Wonderful World of Disney'' show, which will return to weekly television next September on Sunday nights at 7. The Disney company owns ABC.

title: With Tour in a Bit of a Decrescendo, the 'Shine' Pianist Plays Manhattan
description: The David Helfgott juggernaut seemed to have lost some steam by the time it stormed New York yesterday evening, perhaps slowed by the rough treatment it received on the way.

title: It's the Era of the Civilized Hostile Takeover
description: Ronald C. Cambre, chairman of the Newmont Mining Corporation, was prepared for the looming takeover battle. Newmont had survived an assault once before, at the height of the 1980's hostile takeover frenzy, fending off one of the most aggressive corporate raiders, none other than the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens.

title: From Subways to Las Vegas Strip
description: To hear Roger Ridley tell it, his wife never once complained. Not when he quit his day job at Con Edison to sing in Manhattan's subway stations, working his way up from the lesser byways of Avenue D to the platform at 59th Street and Columbus Circle. Not even on those days when he came home with only $20 for his efforts.

title: Inmate on Release Program Deserves Due Process, High Court Says
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the State of Oklahoma had violated the due process rights of a convicted murderer when, without a hearing and on fewer than five hours' notice, prison officials ordered him back to prison after months of trouble-free freedom under an early release program.

title: Michelin Says Profit Rose 3.2% in 1996
description: Michelin, Europe's largest tire maker, said yesterday that its 1996 earnings rose a lower-than-expected 3.2 percent as it continued to take charges for reorganization. Michelin earned 2.89 billion French francs ($507 million) in 1996, up from 2.80 billion in 1995.

title: World Too Tiny for Foreign Relations
description: After five decades of incremental growth through a series of adjoining limestone and brownstone town houses on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the Council on Foreign Relations is poised to build a new midblock structure that would serve as a study center and conference hall.

title: William DuBois, 93, Playwright and Editor
description: William DuBois, a playwright, novelist and longtime editor for The New York Times Book Review, died on Sunday at his home in Farmington, Conn. He was 93.

title: Newcomers' Retreat
description: Something happened to the networks' plan to use the two months between the February and May ratings sweep periods as a laboratory for developing new shows: Most of the experiments have blown up.

title: No to McCain-Feingold
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about frozen human embryos created through in vitro fertilization and placed in storage misspelled the surname of a physician who is active in that field, and misstated his affiliation. He is Dr. James Grifo, not Griffo, and he is at the New York University Medical Center, not New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Committee to Hear Whitman
description: Governor Whitman will testify about auto insurance today before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, which is considering a plan that would offer consumers lower rates in exchange for less coverage. If the Federal plan is enacted, states will be able to modify it or opt out of it. Governor Whitman's own auto insurance plan is expected to be introduced in the State Legislature ''very soon,'' an aide said yesterday.

title: '96 Was a Very Good Year for I.B.M.'s Chief Executive
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chief executive of I.B.M., took a scant $5,000 cut in his nearly $5 million salary and bonus last year, the company's proxy statement showed yesterday.

title: NASA Plans to Study Forests and Global Gravity
description: The space agency announced today that it would sponsor two low-cost satellite projects to study the distribution of Earth's forests and provide a detailed map of the planet's gravity field.

title: Numbers Fail to Support Baerga's Sunny Outlook

His opponents generated a blizzard of irrelevant questions, and some Republican senators were clearly eager to kill his nomination as Director of Central Intelligence. In the end, Mr. Lake was undone by Mr. Clinton's reckless 1996 election campaign and the failure of top White House officials, including Mr. Lake, to insulate American foreign policy from fund-raising efforts.

title: NORTHWEST IN TENTATIVE DEAL FOR AIRBUS JETS
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation has tentatively agreed to to buy 40 long-range A330-200 jets valued at $4.4 billion from the European consortium Airbus Industrie, a person familiar with the transaction said yesterday. The sale would be a coup for Airbus because its A330 family of twin-engine jets faces stiff competition from the Boeing Company's 777 and 767 aircraft. A spokesman for Northwest, the fourth-largest United States airline, said the carrier was ''in discussions'' with Airbus but declined to give details. Airbus, too, said only that it was in talks with Northwest. The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that Northwest had tentatively ordered as many as 40 of the A330 jets worth $4.2 billion.

He is survived by two sons Henry M. Jr of Ridgewood, N.J. and Bingham of McLean, Va. and 5 grandchildren. A past Vice President of the Prudential Insurance Company, he served as President of the Life Advertisers Association and as a Director of the Association of National Advertisers. His interest in health care lead to his serving as the first Chairman of the New Jersey State Health Planning Council, as well as other regional councils. He served as a trustee of the Hospital Center at Orange Foundation. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Presbyterian Homes Foundation, P.O. Box 2184, Princeton, N.J. 08543.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, CHARLES H.
description: DYSON-Charles H. The board of trustees and staff of the Metropolitan Opera Association mourn with profound sadness the loss of Charles H. Dyson, distinguished managing director of the board for more than a decade until his retirement in 1996. We recall with great affection his personal enjoyment of the Metropolitan Opera and his dedication to the Met, both as a board member and as a generous leader in our activities, including the Centennial Fund, Silver Anniversary Fund and our Golden Horseshoe Program. His example will continue to be an inspiration for generations to come. We deeply appreciate the Dyson National Council Endowment Fund recognizing his commitment to nurturing the talents of young artists seeking careers in opera, especially the Metropolitan Opera. He will be missed by all his friends and colleagues. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Dyson family. James W. Kinnear, Chairman of the Board Bruce Crawford, President and Chief Exec. Canadian Occidental, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, has operations in western Canada, the United States and overseas. Wascana, based in Regina, Saskatchewan, had been speaking with suitors to ward off the hostile bid from Talisman, based in Calgary. The United States shares of Canadian Occidental rose $1.50 yesterday, to $18.625, on the American Stock Exchange. Shares of Wascana rose $1.05 (Canadian), to $20.40, on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Wetlands Changes Shelved

The new guidelines would have made it easier for developers to run drainage pipe and build road crossings through wetlands, The Associated Press reported. Robert Friant, a spokesman for the Governor, said environmentalists' pressure caused the state to ''take another look'' at the rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOV, S. ZALMAN
description: ABRAMOV-S. Zalman. The officers, members, and staff of the American Jewish Committee are deeply saddened by the death of Zalman Abramov, chairman of the Israel Advisory Board of AJC's Institute on American Jewish-Israeli Relations (IAJIR) from 1983 to 1994. In a distinguished career, Dr. Abramov served as a former deputy speaker of the Knesset and as a member of the Israeli delegation to the U.N. General Assembly and of numerous Jewish organizations. A prolific author and scholar, he dedicated his life to the betterment of the Jewish condition worldwide and to greater understanding and cooperation between American Jews and Israelis. His wise counsel will be sorely missed. We send our condolences to his wife Ayala, his three children, and the rest of his grieving family. Robert S. Rifkind, President David A. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, JOSEPH
description: FUCHS-Joseph. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of distinguished violinist Joseph Fuchs, whose lifetime spanned the entire history of the School from his enrollment as a student in 1906 to his appointment as a faculty member in 1946, which continued to the time of his death. Through his extraordinary accomplishments as a performing artist and as a teacher, he helped establish the standards upon which the music profession in America and around the globe are now based. He was a greatly respected colleague and a revered teacher and friend. He will be deeply missed by us all. His legacy will continue to live on at The Juilliard School. Our condolences are extended to his entire family. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President

title: Ann Reinking Is Injured
description: A back injury has forced Ann Reinking out of the Broadway musical ''Chicago.'' Ms. Reinking sprained her lower back on March 8 while dancing in the finale. While she is out her understudy, Nancy Hess, is to take the role of Roxie Hart, a former chorus girl who winds up on death row after murdering her boyfriend. Ms. Reinking has been ordered to rest through next week, said her spokeswoman, adding, ''Ann is coming back the second her doctor says she may.''

title: Where a Vampire Walked, Tastes Clash
description: The way Al Copeland sees it, he has come into possession of a famous New Orleans vampire, and no amount of bad-mouthing by Anne Rice, the best-selling author who created that particular creature of the night, is going to make him give it back.

title: A NOMINEE BOWS OUT: THE AGENCY
description: For the fifth time in little more than four years, the Clinton Administration is looking for someone to fill the job of Director of Central Intelligence. Today the President considered asking George J. Tenet, the Acting Director, to take the helm, Government officials said.
