They were from Dalva Brothers, the antique store in Manhattan.

title: Grant Supports Art Education
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's pledge to restore art classes to the city's public schools received significant backing yesterday when the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced that it had received a $2 million grant to establish teacher training in arts education.

title: Zaire Deputies Dismiss Unpopular Premier
description: Zaire's Parliament voted today to unseat the country's unpopular Prime Minister just hours after he left the capital to attend a regional meeting on the nation's civil war. The action by Parliament deepened a growing power vacuum in Zaire and further crippled a state under siege.

title: Greg Louganis, Out of the Water
description: ''My secrets have become overwhelming,'' the Olympic diver Greg Louganis wrote two years ago in his best-selling autobiography, ''Breaking the Surface.'' Any one of those secrets holds enough drama for a movie. In the book, he revealed his long-rumored homosexuality and the fact that he has AIDS. He looked back to a difficult boyhood. His father was a tyrant and Greg's dyslexia was not diagnosed until he was in college. And even while he was winning two gold medals in Seoul in 1988, his private life was in turmoil. He was living with a lover named Tom, who hit him and cheated him out of money and who later died of AIDS. Avoiding the tacky tell-all tone of most celebrity biographies, the book assumed an understated style that made its emotions compelling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOIS, WILLIAM
description: DUBOIS-William, 93, died March 16 in Farmington, Connecticut. He was born November 29, 1903 in St. Augustine, Florida, son of the late Virginia Markel DuBois and William Henry Thompson DuBois. Mr. DuBois graduated from Columbia University in 1925 with a degree in Journalism. He joined the 'New York Times' upon graduation and worked for many years in the Sunday Book Review department before retiring in 1973. During the 1920's and 30's he had several plays produced on Broadway, including ''Pagan Lady'' with Lenore Ulric and ''I Loved You Wednesday'' co-authored by Molly Boehnel with Humphrey Bogart and Franchot Tone. He was later the author of ''Haiti'' which was produced by the Federal Theatre. He wrote three novels and three mystery novels and was a silent collaborator with Frank G. Slaughter on 27 historical novels. In 1950 Mr. DuBois and his family moved from New York City to New Canaan, Connecticut where he lived for 42 years prior to moving to Farmington. He was a member of the Country Club of New Canaan and a former member of the Players Club of New York. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Barbara Castle Dubois; two daughters: Virginia Blackall of Farmington and Caroline Hutton of Westport and by four grandchildren: William Brewster Blackall, Caroline Castle Blackall, David Scudder Blackall and Virginia DuBois Hutton. He was predeceased by his sister, Virginia DuBois Edwards and a grandson, Edward F. Hutton, Jr. Funeral arrangements are private. Contributions may be made to Columbia University, Care University Development Office, Suite 964, Mail Code 7724,475 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10015, Attn: Yvonne Boothe.

description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A., Europe's biggest telecommunications equipment maker, said yesterday that it returned to profit in 1996 and said earnings would rise in the coming years as cost-cutting measures take hold. The French company posted a higher-than-expected net profit of 2.7 billion French francs ($473 million), helped by revenue from asset sales. description: THEY have almost unpronounceable names, like Laphroaig (lah-FROIG) and Craigellachie (craig-el-LOCK-ee); they are rare, not always easy to find and have a taste that is not always easy to love. They are single-malt Scotches, and all over the world they are a resounding sales success.

description: Lucy Kroll, a longtime New York talent agent whose clients ranged from Carl Sandburg to James Earl Jones to Norman Mailer, died on Friday at her home in Glendale, Mass. She was 87 and had moved to the Berkshires eight years ago.

description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, still groping for an on-line strategy, has been negotiating to buy the Internet information distributor Pointcast Inc., but the two sides remain far apart on price, a person close to the situation said yesterday.

Sure, the Grizzlies had the worst record in the National Basketball Association, at 11 victories and 56 losses. And yes, the team just happened to have lost its last 13 games. And, well, O.K., the team has the most difficult time over all in the league in seeking to locate the hoop, hitting on 43.6 percent of its shots from the field and 70.6 percent of its free throws.

Blackened redfish was followed by blackened steak. Blackened whatever has finally gone the way of most fads, but the delicious spicy crust on this pork tenderloin makes this a recipe worth keeping.

title: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL UNIT SELLING 29 PROPERTIES
description: A subsidiary of Marriott International Inc. has agreed in principle to sell 29 of its residential communities for the elderly to the Host Marriott Corporation in a deal valued at about $540 million, the companies said yesterday. Under the agreement Marriott Senior Living Services would sell all of the common stock of Forum Group, which owns the communities, to Host Marriott. Host Marriott would pay about $433 million for the communities and has set up a $107 million plan to add 1,075 residential units by January 1999. Marriott International operates and franchises hotels. Host Marriott owns controlling interests in 83 upscale and luxury hotel properties. Both companies are based in Bethesda, Md.

title: Police Mechanic Indicted
description: The police in Newark said they thought there was something familiar about the emergency lights they saw flashing atop a tow truck in Hillside last year. That was because, an Essex County grand jury charged yesterday, the custom-made light unit had been stolen from the police garage by a night mechanic there and sold to the tow-truck operator. The mechanic, Henry Purefoy, was indicted on charges that he sold police car parts at least nine times between January 1993 and last April. Mr. Purefoy, 51, who has worked at the garage since 1971, has been suspended without pay pending his trial, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVERBERGER, CHARLES G.
description: OVERBERGER-Charles G. The Board of Trustees, President David C. Chang, Chancellor George Bugliarello and the entire Polytechnic University community mourn the passing of Charles G. Overberger, a distinguished professor and leader in the Chemistry Department. In the 1950s and 1960s, Professor Overberger was instrumental in helping to develop Polytechnic's cutting-edge polymer program and was the second director of its Polymer Research Institute, as well as Dean of Arts & Sciences. Among his many honors were the presidency of the American Chemical Society and the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. He was also former editor of the Journal of Polymer Science. He will be remembered as a gentle man and an outstanding scholar. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family.

title: Irabu Goes Home, but Could Come Back

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, MARTIN H.
description: GILBERT-Martin H. Martin H. Gilbert, 75, Ventura, California, died on Tuesday following a long illness. Mr. Gilbert was born NYC. Mr. Gilbert was a raconteur, a salesman's salesman, a life long student of history and enjoyed a good hot dog & a baseball game. Mr. Gilbert was in the garment industry in N.Y. and Los Angeles retiring as Executive Vice President of Adorence Company West, subsidiary of Talley Industries in 1982. He was a former partner of Durlacher and Sons, Inc. in NY. In retirement he became part of the legal community, owning RIL Services in Ventura and as a real estate agent. He served through the duration of W.W. II in the U.S. Navy. He was a devoted husband to Patricia, his wife of 31 years, and father to son Taylor Gilbert, both of Ventura. Info: Ted Mayr Funeral Home, Ventura, CA.

title: Inside Media Is Sold To Rival Mediaweek
description: Inside Media, a biweekly magazine that carved out a solid share of the market for media-company news against the more frequent Mediaweek, closed its doors yesterday.

title: Another Family Sits for an Intimate Portrait, Coming to PBS
description: The little cafe-size table was set for dinner, swathed in a gold lame cloth. Gold balloons and a dusting of gold sparkles added a festive, elegant touch. A dried stalk from a cotton plant, placed in a vase, hinted at the theme, a 1940's evening at the Cotton Club, right in the living room of the two-bedroom apartment in Flushing, Queens, where Bill Sims and Karen Wilson live. The stage was set for another Sims-Wilson wedding anniversary, No. 18, staged, as the celebrations had been for many years, by the couple's daughters, Cicily Wilson and Chaney Sims.

title: Willem de Kooning Dies at 92; Reshaped U.S. Art
description: Willem de Kooning, who came to New York City from his native Rotterdam and radically altered the shape of American art after World War II, died yesterday at his home in East Hampton, L.I.. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAUTHORN, MARJORIE RUTH
description: CAUTHORN-Marjorie Ruth, age 83, of Rutherford, N.J., on March 19, 1997. Beloved friend of Rose Cordero, Anne Toohey and the late Eunice Brown. Funeral at the First Presbyterian Church of Rutherford, Saturday at 10:00 AM. Interment Hillside Cemetery, Lyndhurst, NJ. Friends will be received on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Collins-Calhoun Funeral Home, 19 Lincoln Avenue, Rutherford, N.J.

title: As Rents Move Up, Roommates Move In
description: AT age 35, Antonio Da Motta thought he was too old for one particular rite of passage. But in October, pressed by a 30 percent jump in his rent, Mr. Da Motta, a designer and showroom manager, decided to take in a roommate so he could stay in his home of four years, a 700-square-foot loft in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. It was not an option many people would relish, and for a designer it was doubly scary: ''The prospect of living with a stranger terrified me,'' he said, ''not just because I wouldn't know how they would act, but because I couldn't be sure of what kind of taste they'd have.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTEL CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., will buy nearly 10 percent of the outstanding stock of Standard Microsystems Corp., Hauppage, L.I., a maker of integrated circuits for computers, for $14.6 million and receive rights to buy an additional 10 percent stake.

title: Amusement Park on Mountaintop

title: Jacques Foccart Dies at 83; Secret Mastermind in Africa
description: Jacques Foccart, who masterminded clandestine military coups in French-speaking Africa for Charles de Gaulle and three French presidents after him, died at his home this morning. He was 83.

title: 20th Century Unlimited
description: Dianne Pilgrim has been director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum -- housed in the old Carnegie mansion on Fifth Avenue -- for eight years, but only a few months ago was she able, as she puts it, to ''walk'' through its front door.

title: Again, Dissident Takes On Head of Local

title: Krupp to Drop Bid if Thyssen Cooperates on Steel
description: Marking an abrupt shift in the relationship between the two companies, the German steelmaker Krupp-Hoesch said today that it would drop its unsolicited takeover bid for Thyssen A.G. if they could reach an agreement to combine their steel operations.

title: Spending Up 11.4% In 5 Major Media
description: American advertising spending in five primary media outlets totaled $66.7 billion last year, an 11.4 percent increase from $59.9 billion in 1995, according to an annual survey by Competitive Media Reporting in New York, a unit of VNU N.V. that tracks advertising spending.

title: Cable Industry Leaders Downgrade Satellite Threat
description: Rupert Murdoch was expected to cast a long shadow over the cable industry as its members gathered here for their annual convention. His ambitious satellite broadcasting service, Sky, has been described by some industry analysts as the ''Death Star,'' a menacing airborne weapon aimed right at the cable industry.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Price Report Sets Off Fall In Treasuries
description: The prices of Treasury securities slid yesterday, after a report of a bigger-than-expected increase in consumer prices raised investors' concern that inflation will accelerate and that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to cool down the economy.

title: No Favorites . . . Just Equal Treatment
description: Each team has an angle in the Midwest Regional. Each has a chance for the final dance.

title: Sex Bill Aims at Prevention
description: Arguing that New Jersey must update its laws to reflect the problem of AIDS, a state senator has introduced a bill that would make it a felony for anyone who has a sexually transmitted disease to engage in an act of sexual penetration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, BARBARA
description: KEMPNER-Barbara. On March 11, in her 95th year. Violinist. Wife of the late Fredrick C. Kempner. Aunt of a multitude of devoted nieces and nephews for whom she served by her example as affectionate guide and musical mentor. Date of memorial celebration to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to Marlboro School of Music, 135 South 18th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

title: Studio Contingent Leaning Toward 'Maguire' for Oscar
description: The countdown to the Academy Awards, which pits a lone studio film, ''Jerry Maguire,'' against four independent movies, has struck a discordant note in Hollywood.

title: The Humorous Insights of Being Optically Challenged
description: As Spalding Gray brings improbable merriment to describing his ocular troubles in ''Gray's Anatomy,'' he mentions one doctor who called him Gary Spalding. On the other hand, the surgeon to whom Mr. Gray ultimately turned, after following all the wild detours he could pack into this monologue on health and frailty, made a videocassette of the operation for his celebrity patient and called it ''Swimming to Macula Pucker.'' Practically everyone who encounters Mr. Gray these days must know that his private-sounding experiences are grist for the monologue mill.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Feb. 6 about potential combinations among Wall Street firms described the business of one firm, Salomon Brothers, incompletely. It has a major asset management business, in addition to investment banking. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Chief of Police In Los Angeles Suffers Setback
description: Lacking the necessary votes, City Council members who had been trying to overturn the Police Commission's decision not to rehire Chief Willie L. Williams gave up their effort today.

title: In Honor of a Teacher
description: Josef Gingold, the noted Belarussian-born violinist and teacher, had many successful students. But none has been more publicly devoted than Joshua Bell. On Monday night, Mr. Bell paid homage to Gingold, who died two years ago, by dedicating his Carnegie Hall recital, his first in the hall, to his teacher. With a frequent partner, the French pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet, Mr. Bell performed a program of works closely associated with Gingold.

title: GRANCARE TO EXPAND INTO ALABAMA WITH NORTHPORT DEAL
description: Grancare Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Northport Health Services Inc. for $84 million in cash and stock. Northport, based in Tuscaloosa, Ala., generated about $100 million in revenue in 1996 at its 19 nursing homes and assisted-living centers with more than 2,000 beds. After the deal, Grancare, which is based in Atlanta, will operate 140 nursing homes and assisted-living operations in 15 states. Grancare's shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $8.25.

title: Reichel Lifts The Islanders In His Debut
description: It took Robert Reichel all day to get from Calgary to New York, but just 87 seconds in tonight's game to get into the hearts of Islander fans.

title: Ingalls Moranville Preparing Sun Ads
description: A finalist in a review for the account of Sun Microsystems Inc. is creating a campaign that marks the company's first national television advertising.

title: INSIDE
description: School Expulsions Widened

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 11 about restaurant owners in New York City creating groups of restaurants that, though commonly owned, are each one of a kind referred incorrectly to the ownership of Restaurant Associates, a New York-based company. While it was sold to a Japanese company, Kyotaru, in 1990, it was bought back by an American investment group led by its own management in July 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, MAX A.
description: GOLDBERG-Max A., 94. Of Margate, Florida, formerly of Brooklyn. Died 3/18/97. Warm, wise, gentle, kind, loved and loving husband of Charlotte for 67 years. Father of Rita and Charles Goldberg and Robert and Arlene Goldberg. Grandfather of Steven and Sara Goldberg, Bruce and Leslie Goldberg, Jayne and Richard Woolf, David and Janet Goldberg and Robin Goldberg. Great grandfather of Danielle, Jesse, Joshua, Jennifer, Andrew and Evan. Brother of Sue Rockower and Jack Gilbert. Memorial services at 12 noon on Friday, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES ACTING C.I.A. CHIEF AS AGENCY LEADER
description: Moving to end another political crisis for the nation's intelligence agencies, President Clinton today chose George J. Tenet, a son of Greek immigrants who made his name serving Washington's espionage overseers, as his new nominee for Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Mexican Drugs: A Semi-Censure Reported Near
description: The Clinton Administration and Senate negotiators agreed tonight to a resolution that criticizes Mexican anti-drug efforts but does not bar the President from certifying Mexico as an ally in the war on drugs.

title: Arson Is Suspected as a Third Fire Sweeps a Storehouse in New Jersey
description: A ferocious fire that officials believe was deliberately set swept through a warehouse yesterday that holds important records for thousands of companies and government agencies. It was the third fire at the storage company in South Brunswick Township, N.J., in the last 11 days, and it forced businesses in the town to curtail water use as firefighters battled the stubborn blazes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In his days as Secretary of State, HENRY A. KISSINGER was known as an erudite orator. Still, it is hard to imagine him hunched over a microphone at a basketball game bellowing, ''Yes! And the foul!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, PAUL, D.D.S.
description: LANG-Paul, D.D.S. Beloved husband of Charlotte, loving father of Gail Wainer and Richard Lang, devoted father-in-law of Andrew Wainer, dearest Poppy of Allison Wainer, wonderful brother of Rosalie and Sheldon Frank and Marilyn and Martin Berger. Services Friday, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Long Island. For further information, 516-764-9400.

title: Sleeker Design for Staten Island Ferry Terminal Is Unveiled
description: The gigantic clock is out. The electronic message board, no more. Instead, the city's Economic Development Corporation has proposed that the new Staten Island Ferry terminal in lower Manhattan be a sleek, simple glass-walled building.

title: The Stay-at-Home Life as Muse
description: Joseph Cornell is officially known as an American Surrealist, but he might better be described as a homebody artist. In 1989, I began work on a biography of him and wondered a bit nervously what it might include. A biography, after all, needs a hero, preferably a profligate one, someone with a taste for noisy arguments, lavish seductions and drunken nights at fashionable bars.

title: Jury Trial as Contest
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONLIN, REV. LEO E.
description: CONLIN-Rev. Leo E., C.S.P., on March 19, 1997, at age 81. A native of Worcester, MA., he was ordained a Paulist priest on May 11, 1946. Fr. Conlin served six years in campus ministry in TX. and MA., and 14 years in mission work in South Africa and New England. The better part of his lifetime was caring for prisoners through detention ministry in New England and San Francisco. A wake will be held at Old St. Mary's Cathedral on Friday, March 21, 1997 from 3 to 8 P.M. Mass will be at 10 A.M., on March 22, 1997, followed by interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, San Francisco.

title: I.B.M. SETS ITS SIGHTS ON A MAJORITY STAKE IN NETOBJECTS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has agreed to buy a majority interest in Netobjects Inc., a closely held provider of software for creating World Wide Web sites on the Internet. I.B.M. said that Netobjects, based in Redwood City, Calif., would continue to be run independently, with its chairman and chief executive, Samir Arora, at the helm. It will also continue to provide software that is compatible for all brands of computers, I.B.M. said. Terms were not disclosed. Netobjects sells Netobjects Fusion, software for creating web sites that can operate on computers running the Microsoft Corporation's Windows system as well as the Macintosh system made by Apple Computer Inc.

title: Wanted: Girls To Learn Golf
description: The Ladies Professional Golf Association, the United States Golf Association and the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. have joined forces in a landmark union aimed at attracting more young women to play golf.

title: Threats to Peace Don't Come From Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Brodeur Gets Shot on Knee, but Caps Can't Capitalize
description: The Devils' season flashed before their eyes in the second period.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIEBERG, EDWIN
description: NIEBERG-Edwin. Devoted husband of Dannie. Loving father of Harry, Stanley, Peter, Mary, Jane and Theresa. Adored grandfather of Gregory, Jaime, Michael, Jessica and Patricia. Services on Thursday, 1:00 PM, at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, Inc, 1625 Coney Island Avenue (corner Avenue M) Brooklyn (718-377-2700).

title: Accounts
description: * Eastern Group, Alexandria, Va., to FGI Inc., Chapel Hill, N.C., as the first agency to handle advertising for the energy company. Billings have not been determined.

title: Can't the Great Rooms Outlive Movie Sets?
description: THE cult of decoration is a cult of extinction. Rooms, houses, rich or humble: domestic spaces are mutable, evanescent. They are created, lived in, refreshed, dismantled, dispersed. Their inhabitants marry, divorce, die, relocate. Most of all, they redecorate.

title: School Principal Is Indicted
description: Nothing at Morris Catholic High School was safe from its former principal, the Rev. Dominic A. Scolamiero, prosecutors said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARTHA STEWART, the doyenne of decorating and the kitchen, has won a fight in the garden.

title: German Pair Win World Title
description: On a clumsy night of pairs competition, in which performers fell like bowling pins, Mandy Woetzel and Ingo Steuer of Germany skated inelegantly but took first place at the world figure skating championships.

title: Making Housing Affordable
description: On empty lots and abandoned waterfront property, 259 units of affordable rental housing were built last year in Camden, Newark and Trenton by the Housing Opportunity Fund, a two-year-old nonprofit group that asks banks and other investors for donations in exchange for tax credits.

title: EL PASO ENERGY TELLS OF $157 MILLION BUENOS AIRES DEAL
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 29 percent stake in the Argentine energy concern Capsa for $157 million. Capsa, short for Companias Asociadas Petroleras S.A., is based in Buenos Aires. Its main asset is a 55 percent stake in Capex S.A., an electricity generator with a 374-megawatt plant. In the deal, El Paso Energy can increase its stake in Capsa to as much as 45 percent. El Paso Energy, a natural gas and pipeline concern based in Houston, recently acquired Tenneco Inc.'s energy business.

title: Griffin Remains Unfazed by Jones Fight
description: Both were Olympians. Neither has lost a fight as a professional.

title: Does Rock Show Past Life on Mars? The Jury Is Still Out
description: The intriguing meteorite from Mars has been sliced, zapped and photographed in ultramicroscopic detail. It has undergone scores of chemical, mineralogical and magnetic tests. And what have the scientists learned in the months of rigorous investigation since the announcement last August that a rock that fell to Earth bore possible evidence of early primitive life on Mars?

title: Boston Uncovers Its Craftsman Roots
description: The Boston Society of Arts and Crafts was founded in 1897 with the goal of elevating the works of the blossoming Arts and Crafts movement to the level of fine art. And for the society's 100th anniversary, Jim Messineo and Mike Witt, partners at the JMW Gallery in Boston, have organized an exhibition and sale: ''Affirmation and Rediscovery.''

title: Pataki Outlines Accord to Cut Electric Rates for Long Island
description: A jubilant Gov. George E. Pataki flew to Long Island today and announced details of an agreement to cut the Island's electric rates up to 23 percent through a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: The Pop Life
description: Aerosmith's 'Nine Lives'

title: LVMH to Share Managing DFS
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton said today that it would manage the DFS Group together with Robert W. Miller, a New York billionaire, instead of buying Mr. Miller's 38.75 percent stake.

title: Message Is Clear as Rangers Blow an Opportunity
description: Sometimes, few words say more than many. That seemed to be the case last night after the Rangers lost by 5-4 to the Montreal Canadiens, their second consecutive sloppy one-goal defeat in Madison Square Garden to a team with a record below .500.

title: Revered Or Reviled In the Name Of Biography
description: Celebrating the 10th anniversary of its ''Biography'' series, A&E offers as one of its centerpieces ''Judy Garland: Beyond the Rainbow,'' a two-hour special (well, 90 minutes plus commercials) Sunday night at 8. A&E has every reason to celebrate.

title: Jets' Money Pinch Cancels Siragusa's Drill
description: The Jets, still stifled by a salary cap problem after last year's glut of free agents, were forced to cancel a scheduled workout yesterday by the highly rated defensive tackle Tony Siragusa because they do not have enough money to pay him, his agent said.

title: The New Iron Curtain
description: If you have any doubts that the cold war is over, I suggest you watch CNN's coverage of Albania.

title: $11,000 for Report on Kennedy Killing
description: Reflecting a growing interest in news memorabilia, an Associated Press teletype printout reporting the assassination of President John F. Kennedy was sold yesterday to a Manhattan autograph dealer for a higher-than-expected $11,000.

title: House Approves the Substitution of Time Off for Overtime Pay
description: Making a political statement about its concern for working women and its antagonism toward organized labor, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives voted today to allow employers to offer workers compensatory time as a substitute for overtime pay.

title: Johnson Helps Carry The Load for Knicks
description: He was brought in to ease some of the scoring burden on Patrick Ewing's broad shoulders. And tonight, Larry Johnson was the perfect complement to the Knicks' version of Old Reliable down low.

title: Ailing Pianist Replaced
description: The pianist Olli Mustonen has canceled his appearances this week with the New York Philharmonic because he has the flu. Replacing him is Anne-Marie McDermott. The program, conducted by Christian Thielemann, is unchanged. Remaining performances, at Avery Fisher Hall, are tonight and Saturday at 8, tomorrow at 11 A.M. and Tuesday at 7:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, CHARLES H.
description: DYSON-Charles H. The marvelous example of the civic leadership of Charles H. Dyson is a living legacy for his family and the organizations with which he worked. As a member of the Center For Defense Information Board of Advisors for 23 years he gave us his wise counsel, great insight, and generous support. We will miss him and extend to his wife and family our heartfelt condolences. Center For Defense Information

title: Court Opens Species Act To Wider List Of Challenges
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that people can sue the Federal Government not only for doing too little to protect endangered species, but also for doing too much.

title: For Majerus, No Place Is Like the Final Four
description: Home is a loading dock, a hotel suite, a father on the picket line with a bullhorn, a bratwurst sandwich and a three-hour practice.

title: Asian Paid $100,000 to Hubbell Days After Visits to White House
description: In late June of 1994, the Indonesian businessman James T. Riady saw President Clinton and some of his aides in five days of White House visits ending on a Saturday. Early the next week, one of Mr. Riady's Hong Kong companies paid about $100,000 to Webster L. Hubbell, the President's close friend, who was then facing a rapidly unfolding criminal investigation, according to people in the United States and abroad familiar with the arrangement.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Adonis Forsaken

title: New Rules on Investment Advisers Delayed
description: Sweeping new rules covering investment advisers, which were approved by Congress last year and scheduled to go into effect in April, will be delayed until early July.

title: U.N. Agency Is Optimistic On Treatment To Fight TB
description: The World Health Organization said today that millions of lives could be saved through a tuberculosis treatment that has been used successfully in such disparate places as New York City and rural Tanzania.

title: Valentine Is Looking for the Right Stuff, but It's Not Easy to Find
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine keeps arranging and rearranging his batting order this spring, the way a tenant might push a couch and coffee table around a living room. Valentine is searching for something that looks just so, and he hasn't found it yet. Lance Johnson will be at the top of the Mets' lineup and some pitcher will be at the bottom. In between, there's no telling who will emerge in what order.

title: A chain loses executives yet still maintains its reputation.
description: IMAGINE this scenario: Directors at a publicly traded company, on their way to a board meeting, learn that the chief executive they chose only two months before has stabbed himself to death in a Motel 6 rather than face them at his first board meeting as chief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNIN, JACOB
description: KUNIN-Jacob, in Boca Raton, FL. March 17, predeceased by Kate, his wife of 72 years. Beloved father of Phyllis Ratner and Harriet Herskowitz, grandfather of 8, and great grandfather of 14. Mr. Kunin immigrated from Russia to Bridgeport, CT., in 1925, and founded Kays Department Stores. Services Friday at 12:00 noon from Cong. B'nai Israel 2710 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, with interment following at B'nai Israel Cemetery, Fairfield, CT. For information contact Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, Bridgeport, CT.

title: Hard to Say No
description: In announcing a deal today that promises to lower Long Island's high electric rates, Gov. George E. Pataki may have found a way to cut the Gordian knot of Island politics, a problem with important political and economic implications, and one that the Governor has invested heavily in solving.

title: Asserting Illegal Donations, Hoffa Challenges Balloting
description: In a campaign finance controversy, this time involving labor unions, James P. Hoffa is seeking to stop the inauguration this Saturday of Ron Carey, who narrowly defeated him last December in the race for the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: MAGELLAN HEALTH TO SELL PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITALS ABROAD
description: Magellan Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its two psychiatric hospitals in London and one in Nyon, Switzerland, for a total of $76 million. The hospitals were sold to Priory Hospitals Group, a British provider of psychiatric care that operates 16 hospitals. Priory is owned by Britain's Mercury Asset Management Group P.L.C. The sale would result in a gain that would raise Magellan Health's earnings by $45 million, though the Atlanta-based health care provider did not say when it would reflect the gain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERVER, ELI
description: GERVER-Eli. Age 71, of Fearrington Village, NC. Beloved husband of Edith, father of Laurie (deceased), Amy and Kenneth and grandfather of Alanna and Avi. In lieu of flowers please make donations to National Neurofibromatosis Foundation

title: Dry Cleaners in New York Face New Emissions Rules
description: After three years of negotiations, state environmental officials approved more stringent emission standards for dry cleaners yesterday. But the new rules do not ban cleaners from using hazardous chemicals in residential buildings in New York City, a chief complaint of some apartment dwellers and environmentalists.

title: Aegis Expanding Further in U.S.
description: Aegis Group, which owns Carat, Europe's largest media services agency, said yesterday that it would further expand its American operations by acquiring two companies, International Communications Group and Media Marketing Assessment Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Brokerage Houses Come Out Winners in State Takeover of Lilco
description: Analysts on Wall Street expressed some reservations yesterday about the attractiveness of the $7 billion bond issue -- the largest municipal bond issue in history -- that is the central element of the partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: A Multiculturalist With Regrets
description: WE ARE ALL MULTICULTURALISTS NOW

title: G.O.P. Fears Narrow Scope of House Inquiry
description: Fearing a public backlash against partisanship, Republicans on the committee conducting the main House investigation into campaign fund-raising practices have told their chairman to try to be fairer to Democrats.

title: Wheat Prices Surge on Fear That Floods May Delay Crops
description: Wheat prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade on concern that spring planting might be delayed by flooding in the northern Plains.

title: Taking to Connecticut Hills Isn't New
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stuff Nightmares Are Made Of
description: BY now, Clarence Jackson's late claim to a $5.8 million lottery prize is the stuff of legend, high school debates and every Lotto's player's bottom ring of hell.

title: Rights Group Buys Air Time on 'Ellen'
description: The Human Rights Campaign, a homosexual rights organization, said yesterday that it had bought time on stations affiliated with ABC to run a commercial during the April 30 episode of ''Ellen,'' when the title character of that sitcom is to disclose she is a lesbian.

title: A Sea Change in Policy by the Trustbusters
description: Observers were quick to note the irony of the brouhaha over the proposed merger of Staples and Office Depot. This union, like the blocked merger of the Rite-Aid and Revco drugstore chains last year, would never have been contested by the Federal Trade Commission if the two companies did not offer rock-bottom prices and superior service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAGHEY, CHARLES DENNIS
description: DONAGHEY-Charles Dennis, 41. Died March 16 in an accident in Key West, FL. He was born June 26, 1955, to Charles and Mary Anne Donaghey in Oil City, PA. A graduate of the University of Houston, Texas, he was a resident of New York City where he was a Vice President Fixed Income Researcher at Merrill Lynch. In addition to his father Charles, he is survived by his brothers Regis and Mark of Houston, his sisters Betsy Edwards of Melbourne, Australia and Patsy Shropshire of Dallas, Texas, and their companions and families. Charlie was loved, admired and respected by his friends and colleagues, and will be greatly missed by all of us. A funeral will be held in Houston on March 22 at 10:30 at St. Thomas Moore Church. A memorial service in New York will be announced. Contributions in Charlie's name may be made to God's Love We Deliver.

title: Trade Group Backs Effort To Ship Bananas to Europe
description: After spending years trying to get leaders of both political parties to pay attention to his trade problems around the world, Carl H. Lindner, who controls Chiquita Brands International, has finally won a victory: The World Trade Organization has backed his right to ship bananas to Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMANN, STANFORD L.
description: HERMANN-Stanford L. March 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Naomi B. Father of Jay. Grandfather of Alexandra, Luke and Matthew. He will be greatly missed. Services Thursday, March 20 at 10:45 AM, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTROFF, LEO
description: ASTROFF-Leo. The Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation of Old Westbury, New York mourns the passing of our beloved member, Leo Astroff. Funeral Services will be on Friday, 10 AM, at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation. Seth Sternstein, Rabbi Jacob Merlis, Cantor Judi Winters, President

title: U.S. Scolds Mexicans Over Drug Money
description: The United States has sharply criticized Mexico for failing to seize more than $160 million that American officials say they believe was deposited in Mexican banks by a drug trafficking suspect.

title: Taco Bell and Saab Cars Shift $250 Million In Accounts
description: Two big national advertisers ended unexpected reviews yesterday, affecting accounts with billings estimated at $250 million, by changing agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENBERG, LARRY
description: EISENBERG-Larry. 3/24/52-3/20/ 93. No morning dawns, no night returns but what we think of thee. Mother and Arlene

title: A Hunch Pays Off for Texas Coach
description: An indelible first impression earned Reggie Freeman a scholarship to the University of Texas. Coach Tom Penders had only one left, and it was earmarked for a sweet shooter who played up the road. But Penders was intrigued by the bony kid from Rice High School in Manhattan.

title: School Board Votes to Expel Violent Pupils
description: In a major shift in punishing students accused of violent behavior, the New York City Board of Education yesterday voted to expel from the school system any student 17 or older who brings a gun to school or attacks someone with another weapon, like a box-cutter, knife or billy club.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ON WORK, FROM ONE WHO KNOWS -- One area in which Mayor Giuliani finds common ground with Republicans is his feeling that work is a tonic for one's esteem, particularly for those on government aid. B3.

title: Israel's Tunnel Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, GERTRUDE
description: GOLDMAN-Gertrude. On March 13, 1997. A great lady. Beloved sister of Herbert Goldman. Aunt of Michael and Edward Goldman. Sister-in-law of Muriel Goldman. Great aunt of Ashley Goldman. She will always be missed and remembered.

title: Offering by France Worth $8.82 Billion
description: France Telecom S.A. said yesterday that the Government would sell shares in the company in May worth as much as 50 billion francs ($8.82 billion) in the nation's biggest initial public offering ever.

title: Albanians Restless in Neighboring Land
description: In an office above the streets of this ancient city of Albanian people, where the clothing and crowds reflect the flavor of the Middle East, a quiet, obviously thoughtful man said the words that make many Macedonians fear theirs will be the next Balkan country to fall into ethnic turmoil.

title: Bell Atlantic, Nynex Merger Set to Advance
description: New York State regulators are expected to give qualified approval today to the $22 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex. And in a victory for Nynex, the chairman of the Public Service Commission indicated that the regulators were reluctant to demand cuts in local telephone rates as a condition for endorsing the deal, according to people who attended the meeting.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a 25th-anniversary party in Paris for Le Bernardin, the restaurant, misspelled the given name of a guest. She is Aerin Lauder, not Erin.

title: A Day for Stonehenges, All Across the U.S.A.
description: When the first sunset of spring smudges the skies above this small town during the vernal equinox on Thursday, the curious and the devout will gather in a secluded grove here, among a mysterious complex of stone chambers and monoliths, just as they believe others did 4,000 years ago. All eyes will focus on a toppled boulder that marks, within a quarter of a degree, the exact spot where the sun dips below the horizon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, KAREN A. (NEE O'BRIEN)
description: BRADY-Karen A. (nee O'Brien), on Monday, March 17, 1997, of Westport, Connecticut formerly of Wayne and Upper Montclair. Beloved wife of Charles Brady; loving Mother of Jessica L., Jennifer L. and Charles J. Brady III; devoted daughter of John and Jean (nee Kelly) O'Brien, loving sister of Gail McGeady, Mary Beth O'Brien, Erin DiDia, Lynn Quinn and John R. O'Brien Jr. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, at 9 A.M., from the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, 567 Ratzer Road, Wayne then to Our Lady of The Valley RC Church, Wayne at 10 AM. Friends may call Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM.

title: Play It Again, Boris
description: After comparing surgical histories in Helsinki, Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin will slip some coins into the diplomatic jukebox and play a few top hits from the cold war. Among the old favorites will be nuclear arms reductions, the balance of power in Europe and the future of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The agenda of the convalescing Presidents reflects both the enduring importance of the nuclear weapons issue and the misplaced emphasis the Clinton Administration has given to NATO expansion.

title: Patrick R. Wallace, Times Confidential Assistant, 79
description: Patrick R. Wallace, who for many years was the confidential assistant to successive city editors and metropolitan editors of The New York Times, died on Tuesday at home.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Advertising column yesterday, showing Jennifer Laing, the new chief executive of the North American operations of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, carried an erroneous credit. The picture was by Keith McMillan for Saatchi & Saatchi, not for The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORG, HAROLD
description: BORG-Harold, on March 18, 1997. Husband of Dr. Anita Borg. Father of Laura, Terry, Meredith, Jessica and Brooke. Son of Sally Borg. Brother of Brenda and Estelle. Service Friday, 10AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR) Great Neck.

title: British Company to Add Stake in a Mexican Bank
description: HSBC Holdings P.L.C. signed an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire a 19.9 percent stake in Grupo Financiero Serfin of Mexico. The value of the investment is likely to approach $300 million, depending on the final calculation of net asset value to be agreed at completion, it said. The bank holding company, which is based in London, said it would also insist on a successful recapitalization of Serfin to ''acceptable capital ratios'' before the deal is completed. Banco Serfin, the principal subsidiary of Grupo Financiero Serfin, is the third-largest bank in Mexico, with assets of $19.5 billion.

title: Taking to Connecticut Hills Isn't New
description: To the Editor:

title: Din of Israel's Bulldozers, and Arab Silence
description: The roar of Israeli bulldozers plowing up the earth for a new Jewish neighborhood on an East Jerusalem hill overlooking this Palestinian town was met here today with the silence of resignation.

title: SNYDER PLANS TO ADD AMERICAN LIST AND BRANN
description: Snyder Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the American List Corporation for $125 million in stock and Brann Holdings Ltd. of Britain for about $77.5 million in stock and debt to increase its marketing business. Snyder, based in Bethesda, Md., would issue one share of stock for each of American List's 4.5 million shares if Snyder's share price was at least $32. The exchange ratio would increase if Snyder's price was less than $32. The stock closed at $26.625 yesterday, up 37.5 cents. Stock of American List, which is based in Mineola, L.I., rose $3.25, to $25.625. For Brann, Snyder would issue 2.7 million shares of stock and take over $5 million in debt.

title: San Diego Council Approves 'Model' Nature Habitat Plan
description: After squabbling and negotiating for the better part of a decade over where to build and where not to build, preservationists and developers have finally come up with a nature conservation plan for San Diego that is so revolutionary it is being called a possible national model.

Waldor, told the jury that will sentence him to death or to life in prison that he looked like anyone else, maybe a lawyer, maybe an accountant.

description: Conagra Inc. said today that it would pay $8.3 million to resolve criminal charges that its Peavey Grain unit illegally sprayed water on stored grain to increase its weight and value and also bribed Federal inspectors.

title: Oh, the Stress Of Trying To Relax
description: IF only I could have brought Dexter home from the pink-tiled spa on the island of Grenada. He was the masseur who kneaded and soothed the tense muscles in my back and limbs with strong hands and plenty of lavender-scented oil. And then he would go to work on my face, quick, nimble fingers doing a rejuvenating dance on my cheeks, neck and forehead.

title: U.N. Asks $324 Million for Africa Refugees
description: International aid agencies will need $324.5 million this year to feed and care for the roughly 1.4 million people uprooted by civil war and ethnic strife in central Africa, the United Nations said today in a formal appeal for contributions.

description: Solid as an anvil in a well-worn buff jacket, granite-eyed behind bristles of beard, Mike Smith is one of the urban Maori called ''nga tamatoa,'' or ''young warriors.''

title: DALLAS DEALERSHIP IS REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES' LATEST ONE
description: Continuing to acquire auto dealerships around the country, Republic Industries said yesterday that it would buy Bledsoe Dodge Inc. for $42 million in stock. Bledsoe Dodge owns and operates Dodge franchises in Dallas, Arlington and Duncanville, Tex. It has annual revenue of about $150 million. Republic is a conglomerate based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., led by the entrepreneur H. Wayne Huizenga. The dealership acquisitions are part of Mr. Huizenga's effort to create a nationwide chain of automotive superstores called Autonation. Republic's stock slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $33.875.

description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will visit South Africa from June 17 to 29 on a tour that includes master classes and lecture demonstrations in the townships and 13 performances at the Civic Theater in Johannesburg, the troupe announced yesterday. The Ailey troupe is the second major American dance company to perform in South Africa, following a tour by Dance Theater of Harlem in 1992.

title: Don't Rearm Domestic Abusers
description: Last year Congress passed a law that prohibited anyone convicted of misdemeanor domestic-violence offenses from purchasing or owning guns. Federal law has long barred convicted felons from possessing guns. But that law left a deadly loophole for spouse and child abusers, who often are prosecuted under misdemeanor statutes. The new statute sensibly plugged that gap.

title: Towns Are Slowing Invasion of Farms by Bulldozers
description: Mark Greene's family has been farming in Pittsford, N.Y., since 1812, but until recently the prospects that his 400-acre farm would be in business for another generation looked dim. A local ordinance requires developers to set aside 50 percent of any new project for farming or open space, but even that did not knock land prices down enough to slow the relentless sprawl of Rochester, 10 miles to the northwest.

In spirited questioning, the Justices pressed lawyers to explain how the law would protect children from offensive images and messages, without making criminals out of parents who make the Internet available to their children on home computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMBLE, GEORGE E., SR.
description: TRIMBLE-George E., Sr., a retired Exxon & RJR Executive, age 76, of Wyalusing, PA., Millerton, New York and New York, New York, passed away March 12, 1997. George was born in Newark, NJ. Son of the late Elmer G. and Harriett Pulford Trimble. He graduated from the Pennsylvania State University in 1942 with a Bachelor's degree in Petroleum Engineering. He served with the U.S. Navy as a Bomber Pilot during World War II. He married the former Patricia Vaughn of Wyalusing and she predeceased him in 1973. He married the former Diana Temple, NYC on July 20, 1985. After the War he joined Exxon Corporation. He worked in Venezuala for twelve years and rose to head of production. He then went to Libya for three years. In 1968 he was transferred to Iran where he headed the Iranian Consortium in which Exxon had an interest. In 1976 he was recruited by RJR Industries to head their energy unit Aminoil. He retired after the sale of Aminoil in 1984. Surviving: Spouse, Diana Temple of NY, NY, Millerton, NY. Son, George E. Trimble Jr., Tulsa, OK. Daughters, Cheri Dempsey, Boston, MA, Michele M. Cotton, Houston, TX. 7 grandchildren. Funeral services were held March 14, 1997 at the P. Dean Homer Funeral Home, 1 Grovedale Lane, Wyalusing, PA. Memorials are directed to Geisinger Medical Center, Danville, PA 17821 or the Geisinger Nursing School, Geisinger Medical Center, Danville, Pennsylvania 17821.

The Puerto Rican musician lived with her from 1935 to 1939 and fathered her son Richard; but he took off with a ''young and glamorous'' saleswoman at Lord & Taylor soon after the boy was born.

description: Tidewater Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Ocean Group P.L.C.'s O.I.L. Ltd. unit in Britain and its related international marine operating companies for about $525 million. The O.I.L. companies own a fleet of 100 vessels that operate in most major oil and gas exploration areas other than in United States waters. Tidewater, based in New Orleans, owns a fleet of about 650 vessels. Tidewater said the acquisitions would allow the company to provide greater services to its customers worldwide. Tidewater's stock rose $2.75 yesterday, to $46.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

But one trend has been going on now for years, and the result is that an indicator of relative valuations has reached extreme levels previously seen 24 years ago, just before the great bear market of 1973-74.
