description: Bill Bradley, who created the Broadway tradition of the Gypsy Robe, a long-running theatrical good luck symbol, died on Monday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 73 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Ending Silence, Palestinians Battle Israeli Units
description: As clouds of tear gas billowed over the area, stone-throwing Palestinian students clashed with Israeli soldiers on the outskirts of Bethlehem today in a protest against the construction of a new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem.

title: HANSON TO BUY CONCRETE PIPE AND PRODUCTS OF RICHMOND
description: The British conglomerate Hanson P.L.C. said yesterday that its United States building materials unit, Cornerstone Construction and Materials Inc., had agreed to acquire the Concrete Pipe and Products Company for about $125 million. Concrete Pipe, based in Richmond, is a privately held company that makes and sells concrete pipes and other concrete products. The acquisition includes the assumption of an undisclosed amount of debt.

title: A Short Life Remembered With Songs and Sunshine
description: Gregory Nava's bland, upbeat hagiography of Selena Quintanilla Perez (Jennifer Lopez), the Mexican-American pop star who was shot to death two years ago at the age of 23, doesn't contain a single word or image that suggests the Queen of Tejano music was ever anything less than a perfect angel.

title: Listen Up, Rasslin' Fans: Santa Exists!
description: IT was Doug Sages who went before a New Jersey legislative subcommittee earlier this week and said, ''I don't want to be the one to tell the kids there is no Santa Claus.''

title: An Orgy of Bent Fenders and Bent Love
description: On its scandalizing surface, David Cronenberg's ''Crash'' suggests exploitation at its most disturbingly sick. Adapting the cult novel by J. G. Ballard (the ''Empire of the Sun'' author who will never again be thought of as that nice little boy growing up near Steven Spielberg's Shanghai), Mr. Cronenberg explores a newly pornographic realm of screen sex. The characters in ''Crash'' are aroused by violent car crashes, and their fetishism extends up to and even beyond the point of death.

title: Delta Picks Boeing in Exclusive Deal
description: In the kind of deal that is likely to become more frequent as the global aircraft manufacturing industry settles around two major poles, Delta Airlines announced Thursday that it would buy its planes exclusively from Boeing Co., starting with a firm order for 106 aircraft worth $6.7 billion to be delivered by 2006.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARIAS, HERNANDO
description: ARIAS-Hernando. March 21, 1994. Three years and so many tears. You are profoundly missed, forever loved and perpetually remembered. Love Cuca

title: In Church and Elsewhere, Voices Raised in Song
description: Here is a sampling of special choral works for the Easter season in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations).

title: Condominium Offering Plan on Upper West Side
description: One of the West Side's largest landlords has begun the process, rare in recent years, of converting a 48-unit prewar rental apartment building on the Upper West Side into condominium apartments.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: First Bank Agrees to Buy

title: A Chinese City Is a Model of Good Behavior
description: In Mao's day, people all over China were taught to ''learn from Dazhai,'' the rural commune where selfless peasants reaped ever-larger grain harvests that, it turned out later, were largely imaginary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROULETT, GERTRUDE E.
description: ROULETT-Gertrude E., of Westhampton Beach on March 19, 1997. Wife of the late Edwin J. Roulett. Beloved mother of Mary E. Markell, Edwin J. Roulett, Jr., Sara Rachich, Joan E. Endres, Anne Wood and John P. Roulett, also survived by 6 grandchildren. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, Westhampton Beach, NY. Mass of the Resurrection on Saturday 9:30 A.M., at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach.

title: Doctors Say It's Just One Way
description: During two years of stormy debate over ''partial birth'' abortions, the doctors who actually perform late abortions sat on the sidelines, listening to the impassioned, and often incorrect, rhetoric wrap itself around a medical procedure that few of them use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNIN, JACOB
description: KUNIN-Jacob, in Boca Raton, FL. March 17, predeceased by Kate, his wife of 72 years. Beloved father of Phyllis Ratner and Harriet Herskowitz, grandfather of 8, and great grandfather of 14. Mr. Kunin immigrated from Russia to Bridgeport, CT., in 1925, and founded Kays Department Stores. Services Friday at 12:00 noon from Cong. B'nai Israel 2710 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, with interment following at B'nai Israel Cemetery, Fairfield, CT. For information contact Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, Bridgeport, CT.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL REPORT
description: A Dream Ending?

title: Market Share Rises For Store Brands
description: Store brands, which are also known as private labels, achieved record levels of market share in supermarkets, drugstores and mass-merchandise stores in 1996, according to a study by the Private Label Manufacturers Association of data from Information Resources Inc.

title: Nynex Merger Is Approved By Albany
description: New York State regulators approved the $22 billion merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic yesterday, but as a condition ordered Nynex to spend $500 million on its telephone network and hire hundreds of new employees to improve its long-troubled customer service.

title: Gerber Sponsoring Service Campaign
description: A Federal public service campaign intended to prevent the occurrence of sudden infant death syndrome, also known as SIDS, is receiving support for the first time from a marketer.

title: INSIDE
description: Record Award in Libel Suit

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a new report on Mexican oil reserves in the Bay of Campeche misidentified the engineering firm that audited the report. The firm was Netherland, Sewell & Associates of Dallas.

title: Giuliani Pushes Plan To Change Welfare Law
description: Faced with the impending cutoff of Federal benefits for 200,000 legal immigrants in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani came here today to lobby Senate Republicans for a change in the new welfare law that would minimize the effect on immigrants already in the country.

title: Commercial Time Grows on TV
description: Clutter on television -- the time devoted to commercials and promotions -- reached a new high last year, according to an annual report on advertising.

title: One Man's Junk Is Another's Medium
description: If he didn't quite invent junk sculpture, Richard Stankiewicz (1921-1983) was certainly its prime manipulator. In 1951, digging a garden in back of his Manhattan studio, he kept tossing aside rusty old pieces of metal he found among buried brickwork, then stopped to rest. The scrap pieces were ''staring'' at him, he later told an interviewer, imbued with an ''overpowering sense of presence, of life.'' He bought a welding outfit, mask and gloves, and a how-to-do-it book, and he finished his first junk piece in a day.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the withdrawal of President Clinton's nominee for Director of Central Intelligence defined Muhammad Ali's ''rope-a-dope'' boxing style incorrectly. Ali's tactic (which an official compared to the Senate confirmation process) was to lean against the ropes, his gloves protecting his face and his elbows close together, and let an opponent exhaust himself by raining blows on Ali's arms and body. Ali did not evade his opponent's punches.

title: Companies Could Be Plagued By Scrutiny and Regulations
description: The Liggett Group Inc.'s latest move to duck out of the tobacco companies' fight with 22 states has further unsettled already edgy investors and could pose fresh public relations and regulatory headaches for the tobacco industry.

title: Giants Pick Up 4 Free Agents
description: The Giants announced yesterday that they have signed four free agents: tackle Alan Kline; safeties Picasso Nelson and Brandon Sanders, and tight end Brandon Jessie, who played basketball at the University of Utah from 1994-96. The Giants were still trying to sign running back Keith Elias, but yesterday they lost wide receiver Lawrence Dawsey, who agreed to a two-year, $1 million deal with the Miami Dolphins.

title: Amniocentesis for the Gay Factor
description: The Golds of Showtime's ''Twilight of the Golds'' are your typical upper-middle-class family with a pool, a two-car garage and a chronic habit of fretting. Walter (Garry Marshall) is a doctor with a tennis obsession. His wife, Phyllis (Faye Dunaway), regularly dyes his graying eyebrows. Their daughter, Suzanne (Jennifer Beals), has done them the big favor of marrying a doctor, Rob Stein (Jon Tenney), and their son, David (Brendan Fraser), is an aspiring theatrical producer putting together an offbeat Off Broadway production of Wagner's ''Ring Cycle'' for younger audiences. David is a homosexual. Mom and Dad don't think that's such a favor.

title: Delta to Buy Only Boeing Jets for 20 Years
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would buy only Boeing jets for the next 20 years, and announced an initial order for 106 aircraft worth $6.7 billion. It also announced options to buy an additional 124 jets worth $8.3 billion.

title: Utes to Face Kentucky for Regional Title
description: A lot of people stood up to be heard tonight: an assistant coach, a homesick freshman from Helsinki, Finland, and a point guard playing with the first shaved head of his life.

title: New York State Buys 24 Acres For Preserve on Staten Island
description: In what Gov. George E. Pataki billed as the largest expenditure ever made from the State Environmental Protection Fund, New York State bought 24 acres of Staten Island woodlands and wetlands yesterday for $10 million.

title: Holiday Celebrations: From Eggs to the Parade
description: Here is a sampling of holiday celebrations, including dance and drama events, in Manhattan. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: Court Backs Pataki On Death Penalty Case
description: A state appeals court has affirmed a lower court's ruling that Gov. George E. Pataki had the right to order the State Attorney General to take over a death penalty case from the Bronx District Attorney.

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''RUSSIAN SACRED MUSIC: GREAT STRUGGLE AND GREAT AWAKENING,'' Kaplan Penthouse, Rose Building, 10th floor, 165 West 65th Street, Manhattan. A free lecture by Maya Pritsker, a Russian music scholar, at 1 P.M. precedes a concert at 2 P.M. by Chorovaya Akademia, an all-male a cappella ensemble from Moscow, at Alice Tully Hall. Concert tickets, $30. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: How a Knowing Child Shapes Up Her Parents
description: Sometimes silence speaks much louder than words. And when the unnamed 7-year-old girl (Chloe Ferguson) who is the central character in Rolf de Heer's magical film ''The Quiet Room'' senses her parents' worsening marital strife, her instinctive reaction is to clam up. Her refusal to talk as the weeks go by becomes both an exasperating form of protest and a calculated maneuver to try to reunite them through their worry over her.

title: With Aid, Staten Island to Get a Banana Warehouse
description: To prevent the area's last banana importer from leaving, the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey each promised yesterday to contribute $2 million to help build a new warehouse on Staten Island for the company that distributes Bonita bananas.

title: Art in Review
description: Nicola Tyson

title: First Bank System to Buy U.S. Bancorp of Oregon
description: First Bank System appears to have finally reached the Pacific. The acquisitive Minneapolis banking company, which tried unsuccessfully a year ago to buy the First Interstate Bancorporation of Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy U.S. Bancorp of Portland, Ore., for $9 billion in stock.

title: Sampling of Musical Events for the Easter Season
description: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the Easter season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). This selection, compiled by Anthony Tommasini, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations.

title: First Victory for Parcells: Jets' Conditioning Program
description: The first week of an all-out drive to capture the body and soul of the Jets, a beleaguered franchise looking for its first winning record of the 1990's, ends Friday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about computer security experts who test companies' systems omitted the given name of one such expert. He is Mark Seiden of Belmont, Calif.

title: Carlo Fassi, Skating Coach, Is Dead at 67
description: Carlo Fassi, a prominent coach who guided four figure skaters, including Peggy Fleming and Dorothy Hamill, to Olympic gold medals, died today of a heart attack. He was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORG, HAROLD
description: BORG-Harold. A lawyer's lawyer whose loyalty to his clients and friends will never be forgotten. Sid Davidoff

title: 60 Cars Are Seized In Raids on Garages
description: In raids on garages in Queens, Federal, state and city officials seized 60 cars yesterday that had been stolen or listed as having outstanding warrants and violations, after an investigation in the Willets Point industrial area, the police said.

title: Rights Groups File Complaint on Bias Policy
description: A coalition of civil rights groups has filed a complaint with the United States Department of Education accusing the University of California of violating Federal anti-discrimination laws by using a ''race blind'' admissions policy for its graduate programs.

title: Securing a Proper Fit In Children's Car Seats
description: A car seat that will soon go on sale will be the first to conform in part with new standards recently announced by the Federal Government.

title: Black Clerics Criticize Torricelli on Hiring
description: A group of black clergy members who played an important role in helping Robert G. Torricelli win election to the United States Senate in November is now criticizing him for failing to appoint blacks to important positions on his staff, saying he has not made good on a campaign promise.

title: House Derails Bill for Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: In a stunning setback to its Republican leadership, the House tonight derailed a bill that would have paid for an investigation into White House and Democratic campaign fund-raising.

title: Let Debate Turn to C.I.A.'s Size and Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: Stojko Leaps to Another Championship
description: Elvis Stojko of Canada had landed a quadruple-toe, triple-toe combination jump and eight triple jumps in the most technically difficult program ever performed at the world figure skating championships. The Italian judge had given him a perfect mark of 6 for his extraordinary leaping ability. Still, the door was left open tonight for Todd Eldredge of Chatham, Mass., to defend his men's title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, RACHEL
description: MANDELBAUM-Rachel. Wife of the late Jacques Mandelbaum of New York City and Antwerp, Belgium. Sister of Jacques Adler and the late Albert Adler, also of Antwerp. Mother of Jacqueline and Peter, grandmother of Jamie, Steven, Bruce and Jason, greatgrandmother of William and Sam. The family will be receiving friends Friday morning from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, GENEVIEVE N.
description: GRAF-Genevieve N. On March 19, 1997, at her residence in Greenwich, Conn. Wife of Carl N. Graf. Mother of Elizabeth G. Gaynor, Christine and Alexandra Graf. Sister of Alice Karnavas and Janet Littas. Funeral services will be held Saturday, March 22 at 1 P.M., in the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour, 28 Westchester Avenue, Rye, New York. Burial will be private. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to O.C.D. Clinic and Research Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital East, Building 149-13 Street, Charlestown, MA. 02129. For information contact Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Greenwich, Connecticut.

title: Interest Rate Rise Hinted By Greenspan
description: Faced with an economy that by all rights should be generating inflation but is not, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, hinted today that he would raise interest rates next week as a precautionary measure to keep the nation's six-year expansion on track.

title: Banc One uses promotional tie-ins to a movie about Selena to reach out to the Hispanic market.
description: A BANKING powerhouse is proclaiming ''Hooray for Hollywood'' with a Spanish accent.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: High School High

title: A Decade-Old Activism of Unmitigated Gall Is Fading
description: Back in its heyday, when its shock troops seemed omnipresent and their ire resonated throughout the nation, Act Up had to move its weekly New York City meeting from a community center in Greenwich Village to a more commodious auditorium at Cooper Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORCHARDT, LILO, M.D.
description: BORCHARDT-Lilo, M.D., on March 19, 1997. A celebration of her life will be held at the Plaza Hotel, Central Park South, on Wednesday, March 26, from 3PM-5PM. Call 212-586-4394 or 207-583-4921 for more information.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KATHARINE HEPBURN, star of stage, screen and . . . garden?

title: Diner's Journal
description: A week before he finally opened his new restaurant, Jean-Georges Vongerichten refused to divulge the menu. All he would say was that it was going to be different from the food he was serving during preview dinners in the lounge.

title: House, by Broad Margin, Backs Ban on a Type of Late Abortion
description: The House voted today for the fourth time to ban what opponents call partial-birth abortion, producing more than enough votes to override a near-certain veto by President Clinton.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Text of House Speeches By Foe and Backer of Ban
description: Following are excerpts from today's House debate on the bill to ban a late-term abortion procedure. Representative Charles T. Canady, Republican of Florida, was a leading sponsor of the bill; Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, was a leading opponent of the measure.

title: Hit-and-Run Bills Toughened
description: A Senate committee yesterday approved two bills that would increase charges against hit-and-run drivers from misdemeanors to felonies with mandatory jail time.

title: For Children
description: Just for Kids Expo

title: Home Video
description: Whatever else distinguishes a month's worth of video releases, count on variety. Take the next several weeks, when the selection stretches from an emerging breed of movie made only for video to a silent voice from the 1920's to a strange and haunting classic available on tape for the first time.

title: Art in Review
description: Elizabeth Peyton

title: A Summit That Blurs Strength and Weakness
description: The 66-year-old Russian President strode down the gangway of his shiny new $50 million Ilyushin 96-300 presidential jet with the relish of a man back from the dead.

title: Little Leaguers Can See Mattingly Isn't Through
description: Moments after showing a group of Little Leaguers the way to hold a bat, Don Mattingly conceded yesterday that he had finally come to grips with his retirement.

title: A Marquee Role for George Tenet
description: George Tenet, President Clinton's new nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence, knows the espionage terrain as well as anyone in Washington. He has been immersed in intelligence matters for better than 10 years as a senior Senate aide, a White House official and most recently the deputy chief of the intelligence empire. The question is whether he has the leadership strengths to reshape some of the most important, troublesome and intractable agencies in the Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, BARBARA
description: KEMPNER-Barbara. On March 11, in her 95th year. Violinist. Wife of the late Fredrick C. Kempner. Aunt of a multitude of devoted nieces and nephews for whom she served by her example as affectionate guide and musical mentor. Date of memorial celebration to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to Marlboro School of Music, 135 South 18th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

title: Though Left in the Dark, Raines Sees the Light
description: Tim Raines has heard the whispers that Darryl Strawberry will be the left fielder, whispers that have escalated to screams. But a disappointed Raines said he had sensed it before anyone else because he could see the writing on Joe Torre's potential lineup card.

title: Afraid to Compromise
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, took a chance last week when he called for a commission to reduce cost-of-living adjustments, an act that would lower Social Security benefits and raise income taxes. This would be a sensible, fair way to cut the deficit. President Clinton and Vice President Gore dismissed the idea, afraid to take on factions of their party that want no part of slowing Social Security increases.

title: Reid Ready To Take Next Step
description: The condominium David Reid just bought in the high-rise next to the Philadelphia Museum of Art is not so far removed from the rough streets of North Philadelphia where the 23-year-old Reid grew up with his single mother and six younger siblings.

title: Big Board Record in Short Sales
description: Investors sell stocks short, meaning they sell borrowed shares, to bet on a decline in price, but they also do so as part of a wide variety of other strategies, including merger arbitrage.

title: Tokyo Stocks Post Gain
description: Japanese stocks posted a small gain today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues climbed 139.45 points, or three-quarters of 1 percent, to close at 18,633.16. The exchange was closed on Thursday for the Vernal Equinox Day holiday. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 48.51 points.

title: Liggett Pact: Harbinger Of Legal Battles to Come
description: As the Liggett Group Inc. resolved one set of lawsuits, it set the stage for a new and thorny round of litigation that will keep tobacco companies and plaintiffs' lawyers battling among themselves for months, if not years.

title: U.S. Expands Search of Columbia/HCA in Texas
description: Federal investigators widened their search of medical offices around El Paso yesterday, seizing documents from doctors affiliated with the local hospitals operated by the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, people familiar with the situation said.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: WATER SYSTEM SALE STRUCK DOWN -- New York City's plan to sell the city's water and sewer system to raise money has been struck down as an illegal budget gimmick. B3.

title: P.G.& E. WILL SELL ASSET AS PART OF LEGAL SETTLEMENT
description: The P.G.& E. Corporation said yesterday that its Pacific Gas and Electric Company unit would sell the system that delivers electricity to 30,000 San Joaquin Valley customers to the Modesto Irrigation District for $110 million. The sale is part of a settlement between the district and P.G.& E., the largest utility in the United States. Both also agreed to end pending lawsuits that stem from the district's attempt to sell power to one of P.G.& E.'s industrial customers. P.G.& E. stock fell 25 cents, to $23.375, in trading of almost three million shares.

title: Don't Disarm Albanians
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Stabbed Near Brooklyn School
description: A 16-year-old student was stabbed and injured a block away from his Brooklyn high school yesterday and two teen-agers were arrested and charged with the crime, the police said.

title: Art in Review
description: David Black

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIALICK, RICHARD A.
description: BIALICK-Richard A. Congregration Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the tragic and untimely death of our cherished member, Richard A. Bialick. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Firm Awarded $222.7 Million In a Libel Suit Vs. Dow Jones
description: A Federal jury in Houston awarded $222.7 million to a local bond brokerage firm yesterday in a libel suit over a 1993 article in The Wall Street Journal. The award is nearly four times greater than the previous record award for libel.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Flirting With Disaster

title: Ex-Executives Guilty In Panasonic Scheme
description: Two former top executives of the Panasonic Company and a New Jersey electronics wholesaler pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to tax evasion charges that arose from a two-year scheme to embezzle and resell hundreds of thousands of dollars in Panasonic merchandise in New York City and the region.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Ceramic Sculpture From Han and Tang China'

title: Merrill Lynch Reorganizes Into 4 Groups
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it was reorganizing into four business groups to help sales of stocks and bonds.

title: Inside Art
description: A Donor From Television

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, FLORENCE
description: SILVERMAN - Florence. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved wife of its esteemed member, Mr. Murray Silverman, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Fearing Deportation, Immigrants Try to Beat a Deadline That Isn't
description: At 3 A.M. yesterday, hundreds of apprehensive immigrants huddled in the darkness outside the Federal Building in lower Manhattan, a hulking monolith that houses offices of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Club Owner Charged With Arranging Drug Parties
description: Peter Gatien, the prominent nightclub owner already charged with turning two of his clubs into virtual drug supermarkets, was accused yesterday of also giving lavish private parties in luxury hotels at which he and friends would ''binge'' on illegal drugs for days at a time.

title: From Prison to Presidency: Life and History Entwined
description: ''Mandela'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: An Entrepreneur's High-Stakes Move
description: In settling tobacco lawsuits brought by 22 states, the cigarette baron Bennett S. LeBow looks like both a traitor to the close-knit tobacco fraternity and an improbable hero to the antitobacco movement.

title: Minnesota, U.C.L.A. and Utah Survive in Overtime
description: Minnesota and Clemson tangled in one of those up-all-night, let's-stay-alive tournament games that make college basketball special. Forty minutes of regulation and five minutes of overtime were not enough. Let's do two.

title: CIGARETTE MAKER CONCEDES SMOKING CAN CAUSE CANCER
description: In an extraordinary admission, one of the nation's major cigarette makers acknowledged today that tobacco is addictive and causes cancer, and said tobacco companies had for decades consciously marketed their products to children as young as 14.

title: Charles R. Richey, 73, Judge in Watergate and Rights Cases
description: Judge Charles R. Richey of the United States District Court in Washington, who was appointed to the bench because of his friendship with Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and quickly found himself ruling on Watergate-related cases, died on Wednesday night at the Washington Home hospice. He was 73 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Broadcasters Offer New, Faster Timetable for High-Definition TV
description: Leaders of the broadcast television industry, responding to criticism of their slow-paced schedule for introducing digital, high-definition television, gave Federal regulators a new, more aggressive timetable yesterday, under which 43 percent of the nation's households would be able to receive the new programming in the next 18 to 24 months.

title: Immigration Agency Hires Accountants for Full Review
description: In a sign of just how broken the nation's citizenship process is, the Justice Department awarded a $4.3 million contract today to one of the nation's largest accounting firms to overhaul the entire process, from testing immigrants' knowledge of English to computerizing thousands of paper files.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINS, MICHAEL B
description: ATKINS-Michael B. The Officers, Board and Fellows extend our sincerest condolences to the family of our former Chapter President and National Vice President. Mike was a leader in the field of Family Law and was esteemed by all his colleagues. American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers (New York Chapter) Alton L. Abramowitz, President

title: Players Get Back Pay
description: Major league baseball clubs gave players more than $3.5 million in back pay yesterday as the first act under the new collective bargaining agreement, the Players Relations Committee said.

title: A.C.L.U. Is on Wrong Side of Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Tony Zale, Prizefighter, 83; Ex-Middleweight Champion
description: Tony Zale, who brawled his way to the middleweight championship twice during a Hall of Fame boxing career punctuated by three memorable -- if not legendary -- title bouts with Rocky Graziano, died yesterday at a nursing home in Portage, Ind. He was 83.

title: 2 of Mobutu's Rivals Draw Closer to a Fight to Rule Zaire
description: When Zaire's embattled Prime Minister returned to this city from a regional summit meeting in Kenya today, the recognition accorded him hardly extended beyond his own Cabinet and tepid statements of support from a few Western embassies.

title: Help From Cutting Room
description: Promising a trove of buttons, bows, fabric remnants and other colorful material for art students in the public schools, the Fashion Center Business Improvement District said yesterday that it had enlisted many of the city's top design companies to donate what is left on their cutting room floors.

title: A Tale of Two Sisters And the Guy They Covet
description: The big fish in the tiny pond is Ken Sherry (George Shevtsov), the wonderful comic invention of Shirley Barrett's ''Love Serenade.'' This clever, deadpan comedy won a well-deserved Camera d'Or as best first feature at the 1996 Cannes Film Festival for its depiction of world-weary Ken, the two sisters whose hearts he sets aflutter, and the picturesque but miserable little backwater of Sunray, Australia, which suddenly finds itself home to Ken's urbane charms.

title: Narratives Snagged On the Cutting Edge
description: BEFORE its last biennial, the Whitney Museum of American Art trumpeted the names of the artists to be included, and the pre-show hoopla caused the predictable grousing. So this time around, the names were treated for months like state secrets, which also provoked grousing: the Whitney was acting like the Pentagon.

title: In Talks on an Airlift Out of Albania, Albright Rattled Her Saber
description: In the harried hours after gunmen fired at Marine Corps helicopters evacuating Americans from Albania last week, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright suggested sending a larger, stronger force from NATO to occupy Albania's main airport and the port at Durres, Administration officials said today.

title: Study Plays Down the Importance of a Sleep Disorder
description: At a time when American doctors are becoming increasingly convinced that high blood pressure, heart disease and strokes can be caused by sleep apnea, a common disorder in which breathing is interrupted repeatedly during sleep, British researchers have challenged that view. They say the importance of the condition has been exaggerated.

title: Art in Review
description: Mark Greenwold

title: Deal for Taxi-Top Ads
description: The Metropolitan Taxi Board of Trade has granted the Medallion Financial Corporation the right to advertise atop more than 1,800 taxicabs, thereby giving Medallion 3,500 cabs under contract, or 96 percent of all taxi-top advertising in New York City.

title: Broadway Tickets
description: To the Editor:

title: Teamsters' Head Returns More Disputed Campaign Donations
description: With his opponent demanding a new election because of questionable campaign contributions, Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has returned $126,000 in donations beyond the $95,000 he already gave back, campaign officials said yesterday.

title: Stragglers Turn Into Big-Time Contenders
description: At some point in the last three months, the four basketball teams here had good reasons to suspect that their seasons would be over by now. Texas had its second-lowest victory total in the nine seasons Tom Penders has been the coach. Louisville had lost 6 of 11 games going into the first round. California had to compensate for the loss of its leading scorer with three regular-season games to play. North Carolina, with its 0-3 start in Atlantic Coast Conference play, still felt vulnerable in early February.

title: Dow Drops for Third Day, but Technology Stocks Rally
description: Continuing fears over higher interest rates rattled the stock market yesterday, even as technology stocks rallied for the first time in more than a week.

title: A Lesson in Cruelty
description: Ruth Silver is 76 years old and lives alone on the Lower East Side. She retired some years ago from her job as a legal secretary, but she's an active, curious woman with a variety of interests, and she likes to keep up on current events.

title: Captain Enters Guilty Plea In Sexual Abuse of Private
description: The Army captain who was the highest-ranking defendant in an investigation of sexual misconduct at the Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland was ordered today to serve four months in prison and dismissed from the military after he pleaded guilty to adultery and sodomy.

title: Times Co. Lifts Profit Forecast; Nominates 2 Executives to Board
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it expected first-quarter earnings to be sharply higher from a year earlier and well above analysts' estimates.

title: Computer Account Finalists Named
description: Logitech Inc. in Fremont, Calif., which makes computer devices like scanners and mouses, has named four finalists in a review of its account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Democrats Propose Spending On Police Instead of Jail Cells
description: Rebuffing Gov. George E. Pataki's prison construction proposals, the Assembly's Democratic leaders today proposed making large investments instead in hiring new police officers, expanding drug treatment programs and providing shelter for domestic violence victims.

title: Strong U.S. Export Sales Push High Soybean Prices Higher
description: The price of soybeans surged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as unexpectedly strong United States export sales showed that prices close to eight-and-a-half-year highs have not slowed international demand. Wheat prices also rose.

title: Restaurants
description: Capsouto Freres was a TriBeCa pioneer, moving into a fine old 1891 landmark building long before the area became chic. Over the last 16 years the attractive bistro has gained such a large reputation that everyone I invited to meet me there was excited. ''I've always wanted to eat at that restaurant,'' was a typical reaction.

description: ''Washington has gone haywire,'' Anthony Lake said in withdrawing his nomination to head the C.I.A. He said it in relation to the Senate confirmation process. I think it is true in a larger, more menacing sense.

The figures included a 36 percent increase in the deficit with China that will further complicate the politics of Vice President Al Gore's trip to Beijing next week.

description: Larry Johnson has rediscovered his favorite move. In turn, the Knicks look like they finally have discovered another weapon to complement Patrick Ewing down low.

description: The North Carolina women's team, playing at home, trailed Michigan State by 6 points in the final minute of regulation play in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. With elimination looming, the Tar Heel coach, Sylvia Hatchell, made sure the ball remained with Marion Jones, her junior playmaker.

title: $25 and Under

He even owned a fancy Park Avenue restaurant, Malvasia, in the early 1990's. But Mr. Picone has given it all up for his own little storefront on Amsterdam Avenue, Gennaro.

description: Burton Lane's songs struck so deep into the American psyche that it is not unusual to hear people absent-mindedly humming them. Today, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers will honor the composer's six decades of work with a musical tribute at the Booth Theater.

title: White House Is Taking a Look Around Town
description: On Monday, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, visited a high school here to talk about careers in health care. On Tuesday, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley and Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, visited another high school to talk about computer skills.

title: Church Mouse At Long Last Learns to Play
description: THE Paris commonly seen in films is a place of bistros, baguettes and solemn young lovers, a city of refinement and endless romantic possibility. But ''When the Cat's Away,'' a gentle breeze of a Parisian film by the refreshing new film maker Cedric Klapisch, unfolds in a very different place. Mr. Klapisch's urban backdrop is a city in transition, scarred by the demolition and graffiti of changing times yet also charged with the energy of everyday life. Mr. Klapisch looks beyond familiar notions of romantic Paris, and in his clear, unsentimental fashion he discovers a city with heart.

title: Backup Catcher Substitutes Passion for Weak Bat
description: They say Alberto Castillo is a take-charge kind of catcher who will stomp to the mound and order a sluggish pitcher to start concentrating. He will also grab the fingers of a reporter and pull them against a bump on his left temple.

description: Charles A. Gargano started reeling off a list of companies forced off Long Island by high electric bills.

description: While a third of Jersey City's white families own their own homes, only 23 percent of black and 18 percent of Hispanic families are homeowners, city housing officials said.

description: Since she arrived at New York University 15 years ago, Janice Quinn has known nothing but success.

description: A group of Defense Department researchers has found genetic material from the notorious Spanish flu virus that killed at least 20 million people worldwide in the influenza pandemic of 1918.

description: These days, it's hard to be an Asian-American and a contributor to the Democratic Party. New allegations about illegal or improper donations to the Democratic National Committee from Asians and Asian-Americans seem to surface every week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, CHARLES HENRY
description: DYSON-Charles Henry. In grateful memory of Charles Henry Dyson, a man for all seasons and a staunch advocate and supporter of education. Entrepreneur par excellence, no investment in his illustrious career paid or will pay greater returns than the contributions to the education of the young men and women at the colleges and universities he and his wife, Margaret, supported. He will be sorely missed, but his legacy will live on for generations to come in the richness of the education that he and Margaret provided to so many. Roger H. Hull, President of Union College

title: The Comptroller and the Bond Lawyers
description: New York State's Comptroller, Carl McCall, may have let his own political needs overwhelm common sense when he blasted a proposal by the New York City bar association to restrict campaign contributions by lawyers to government finance officials. Mr. McCall says the restrictions would infringe the free speech of lawyers. The real issue is that the proposal would end what amounts to the legal bribery of municipal officials by lawyers seeking contracts to help government sell bonds.

title: Warehouse Fire, and Mystery, Smolder in New Jersey
description: In the wake of Wednesday's mysterious fire that destroyed a warehouse full of corporate documents, investigators interviewed dozens of witnesses but refused to offer any theories for the apparent arson.

title: INVESTCORP OF BAHRAIN TO BUY FALCON BUILDING PRODUCTS
description: Investcorp, an investment bank and holding company based in Bahrain, whose assets include the Saks Fifth Avenue department store in New York, agreed yesterday to acquire Falcon Building Products Inc., a building products supplier in Chicago, for about $365 million in cash and the assumption of about $225 million in debt. Falcon's shareholders will receive about $17.75 a share in cash. Falcon's shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $17.125, on the New York Stock Exchange before trading was halted. Falcon had 1996 sales of $633 million.

description: For 28 years Bill McKinstry taught economics at Miami University here, including a course on Social Security in which he warned that the system faced an inevitable crisis.

title: A Fair That Travels Through Centuries Of Asian Creativity
description: THE debut of the International Asian Art Fair in Manhattan last spring was an undisputed hit. Top-flight dealers were on board; the art was spectacular. The swell of foot traffic from Park Avenue surpassed even the most optimistic expectations: New York had clearly discovered Asian art in a major way.

title: The Truth Shall Set You Free. Not!
description: Two little words: Jim Carrey. That's all it takes to transform ''Liar Liar'' from a formulaic Hollywood comedy into an uproarious one-man free-for-all. Well into his tumultuous career, Mr. Carrey finally turns up in a straightforward comic vehicle, and the results are much wilder and funnier than this mundane material should have allowed. Mr. Carrey is so straitjacketed by his routine nice-guy character here that he bursts the bounds of conventionality with a liberating fury that offers the last word in Jekyll-Hyde fun.

description: IN the TKTS booth line in Duffy Square, the theater district's tempest du jour produced no fears that the age of discount tickets may be nearing an end.

description: A proposal to enlarge the United Nations Security Council from its present 15 members to 24 was presented today by the chairman of a panel that has been studying ways to reform the Council for three years.

description: Pilots at American Airlines have shown an unpredictable streak before. But for reasons that have as much to do with image and perception as with the terms of their tentative agreement with the airline, another strike seems unlikely.

description: Channel 31's slogan should be amended to ''Sports rights fees, business and, oh, yeah, life'' because becoming a busy nighttime sports station is not cheap.

title: NOVELL AND NETSCAPE FORM JOINT SOFTWARE VENTURE
description: Novell Inc. and Netscape Communications Inc. said yesterday that they planned to form a new privately held company called Novonyx, to be based in Utah, initially employing about 80 people. Novonyx, which is expected to open within a month, will adapt, integrate and sell Netscape's Suite Spot server software modified to run on Novell's Intra-netware network operating system. The product will be available within six to eight months, the companies said. Novell's shares closed yesterday at $10.25, up 31.25 cents, and Netscape's shares closed at $31, up $3.25, both in Nasdaq trading. The deal between Netscape and Novell was negotiated by Joseph A. Marengi, Novell's president and chief operating officer, and James Barksdale, Netscape's president and chief executive. Novell and Netscape are competitors in some areas, primarily in the groupware market, and Mr. Marengi said that the separate company would work to avoid possible conflicts.

title: China's Long March to the Law
description: Advocates for freedom in China will find little immediate comfort in the country's new legal reforms. The criminal code passed last week, for example, abolishes the crime of counterrevolution. But the acts it encompassed can now be prosecuted as crimes against state security, and in some cases carry even longer sentences.

title: Hunting Un-Americans: A Witch's-Eye View
description: Seven members of the legendary Group Theater gather in a room in the Algonquin Hotel. It's the red-baiting year of 1952, and the House Committee on Un-American Activities is deeply into its witch hunt. What it wants is names, big names. And the frightened theater folk, mysteriously summoned to the room, suspect that they may be targets.

title: On the Ancient Silk Road, an Industry Unravels
description: Fifteen centuries ago, historians in Bursa say, a couple of Christian missionaries arrived here after a long journey from China with an unimaginable treasure hidden in their underclothes and walking sticks. They had smuggled out silkworm larvae, laying the basis for an epochal shift of world power and, in the process, turning Bursa into one of the world's great silk producers.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Wednesday about ''Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde'' at the Greenwich House Theater misstated the background of a cast member, William D. Dawes. He was an understudy in the play ''Sex and Longing'' but did not appear in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE KOONING, WILLEM
description: de KOONING-Willem. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art join the art community in mourning the loss of Willem de Kooning. Above all, however, we wish to honor his life. A great painter, he used that life to the full and contributed immeasurably to the medium he personified for over half of this century. ''Space,'' he said, ''is given to the artist to change if he can.'' No one of his era changed the space of modern painting more, or left a richer creative legacy. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman, Agnes Gund, President, Glenn D. Lowry, Director, The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Can Its Private Pension Plan Offer Lessons to the U.S.?
description: ''It's such a difference,'' bubbled Isabel Margarita Perez Moore, a 45-year-old secretary in Santiago. ''I love my pension plan.''

title: Swinging Shakespeare Gets Aboard the A Train
description: ALL Tonya Pinkins has to do to capture an audience is stare at it. In the lively but disappointing new musical ''Play On!,'' which opened last night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, there comes a moment when this Tony-winning actress, portraying a love-crossed Cotton Club diva, peremptorily interrupts a big production number to step to the front of the stage and fix the house with an angry, woeful gaze you don't dare look away from.

title: STATE REGULATORS SAID TO REJECT ENRON MERGER
description: The staff of the Oregon Public Utility Commission will recommend that the planned purchase of the Portland General Corporation by the Enron Corporation be blocked, Portland General said today. The utility said that it had been told about the recommendation by a senior staff member. The staff's final report is due April 11, and members of the commission will then vote on whether to approve the transaction. Enron, a Houston-based energy company, said in July that it would buy Portland General, offering $2.13 billion in Enron stock and agreeing to assume $1.1 billion of the utility's debt. The staff found that Enron's offer of $61 million in cost savings and rate reductions did not offer sufficient benefits to meet the statutory burden needed to approve the transaction, Portland General said. The acquisition must also be approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG TERMINATES MERGER DEAL WITH IVAX
description: The Bergen Brunswig Corporation said in a statement late yesterday that it had terminated its agreement to acquire the Ivax Corporation and that it planned to sue Ivax, accusing the company of breaking the terms of the agreement. Ivax said in a statement that Bergen Brunswig unilaterally terminated the pact ''without good cause.'' While details of the breakup were not available, there had been speculation that the deal would be altered or dropped not long after the $1.4 billion merger was proposed in November. The deal would have combined Ivax, based in Miami, a troubled maker of low-cost generic drugs, with Bergen Brunswig, based in Orange, Calif., one of the nation's biggest drug wholesalers. The companies issued their statements after the stock market closed.

title: Ex-Tennis Star Out of Jail
description: Roscoe Tanner, the former tennis star, was released from jail yesterday after coming up with $8,000 in child support for a woman who says he is the father of her 3-year-old daughter.

title: UNITED ASSET TO ADD PACIFIC FINANCIAL TO AFFILIATES
description: The United Asset Management Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Pacific Financial Research Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., a money manager best known for its top-performing Clipper mutual fund. United Asset Management declined to disclose the terms of the transaction. Analysts estimated that United Asset Management of Boston would pay about $125 million to purchase Pacific Financial, which oversees about $4.2 billion in assets. United Asset Management manages more than $175 billion in assets through its 47 affiliates.

title: Norway's No. 5 Bank Increases a Bid
description: Fokus Bank, Norway's fifth-largest bank, increased its stock and cash bid for the regional bank Bolig-og Naeringsbanken yesterday to 2.059 billion kroner ($307 million) after the country's biggest bank, Den Norske Bank, made a competing all-cash bid earlier in the day. Fokus Bank offered the equivalent of 3.4 Fokus shares per Boligog Naeringsbanken share, up from its offer on Tuesday of 3.3 shares. Fokus would pay 80 percent of the price in shares and the rest in cash. The bid is calculated excluding dividends for 1996. At yesterday's share price, the bid corresponds to 211.10 kroner per Boligog Naeringsbanken share.

title: Safir Appoints Former Chief Of Detectives As His Deputy
description: Moving to consolidate the Police Department's top management, Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday named Patrick E. Kelleher, a 28-year veteran of the force, as the department's first deputy commissioner -- the second-highest ranking job on the force.

title: A Kiss Intrudes on Solitude
description: The affecting German drama ''Little Angel'' presents an unstable, terribly lonely woman and the events that conspire to push her over the edge. Ramona (Susanne Lothar) is seen living quietly with a pet bird and watching the stormy, violent life of a neighboring family, fearing that her own dreary existence will never reach such a fever pitch. Then, by chance, she is kissed by a Polish stranger who hopes to dodge the police by pretending Ramona is his girlfriend. Suddenly Ramona has hopes for a wild romance of her own.

title: In British Airways Promotion, Carrier Lands on Its Feet
description: Perhaps not since Mae West dared Cary Grant to ''come up sometime and see me'' has there been a come-on as tempting as the one in British Airways' current ad campaign: a free round-trip ticket for travel within the United States or Canada to any of the airline's business class passengers who think the carrier's service to Britain is not the most comfortable in the air.

title: A Spy and His Wife, or 2 Spies, or None?

Many Americans, apart from the doctrinaire left and right, have believed for decades that the evidence against Julius was compelling, the evidence against Ethel was flimsy, and the death penalty was abhorrent.

title: A Useful Helsinki Summit
description: After surviving elections and surgical operations over the last nine months, Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin got together again this week and accomplished more than they expected. The two men essentially agreed on some new ground rules for relations that will allow important business like nuclear arms reductions to proceed despite Russian objections to the eastward expansion of NATO.

title: GEOWORKS STOCK FALLS ON LOWER REVENUE FORECAST
description: Investors abandoned the stock of Geoworks Inc. yesterday after the company, a provider of cell phone operating systems, said its fourth-quarter revenue would be below expectations. Geoworks is known for its high-end operating systems used in ''smart phones,'' digital cellular telephones that can send and receive faxes, organize data or cruise the Internet. The company said after Thursday's market close that it had adopted a more conservative approach to estimating product revenue. Under the new method of revenue recognition, fourth-quarter revenue will be $1.8 million to $2.2 million, below expectations. Geoworks stock plunged $4.75, or almost 40 percent, to close at $7.25 a share in Nasdaq trading.

title: Mobutu Back in Zaire
