title: Words and Bombs in the Mideast
description: Terrorism has again dealt a blow to peace in the Middle East. The bombing of a Tel Aviv cafe yesterday killed three people, including the attacker. The radical Palestinian group Hamas has claimed responsibility for the bombing, and the Palestinian Authority's President, Yasir Arafat, has denounced it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNICK, SYLVIA
description: SKOLNICK-Sylvia, March 20, 1997. Loving sister of Sol and Betty. Aunt of Joy, Wendy, Robert and Colleen. Great-aunt of Benjamin and William Sardinsky. Lively and endearing sister, aunt and friend. Will be missed very much. Services Sun. 1:45PM, ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: C-PHONE STOCK UP AS CHAIN AGREES TO CARRY VIDEO PHONE
description: The shares of the C-Phone Corporation soared almost 69 percent yesterday after the company said it would begin retail sales of its $350 video phone by Mother's Day, May 11. The phones will be carried by Nobody Beats the Wiz, a consumer electronics retail chain in the Northeast. Shipments to stores will begin before the end of the month. C-Phone shares gained $4.625, to $11.375, in Nasdaq trading. The company did not disclose the size of the Wiz order. The manufacturer plans to sell its phones for less than they cost to make, but intends to earn a profit by requiring purchasers to pay between $9 and $20 a month and about 38 cents a minute.

title: Devil Rays Sign Polonia
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays signed outfielder LUIS POLONIA, who will spend the 1997 season with the Mexico City Tigers of the Mexican League. Polonia, 32, split last season between the Baltimore Orioles and Atlanta Braves, batting .267 with 2 home runs and 18 runs batted in over 80 games. He hit .419 in 22 games for the National League champion Braves after joining the team on Aug. 17.

title: Now, It's Anyone's Guess: Kansas Jolted by Arizona
description: If they were going to reach the Final Four, much less win a national championship, the Kansas Jayhawks, the No. 1 team in the nation and the top-seeded team in the Southeast Regional, knew they would eventually run into a team that would force them to use all of their grit, guile and muscle.

title: 'Peanuts' for Orchestra
description: Charlie Brown will come to Carnegie Hall today at 2 P.M. with the world premiere of ''Peanuts Gallery,'' a piece for piano and orchestra by Ellen Taaffe Zwilich, based on the ''Peanuts'' comic strip. The piece, performed by the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra and the pianist Albert Kim, features movements devoted to the strip's characters. It will be preceded at 1 P.M. by storytelling and musical demonstrations. Other works on the program are musical pieces that tell a story. Tickets are $5. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: N.Y.U. Advance to Div. III Title Game
description: Jen Krolikowski simply would not allow her brilliant career at New York University to end last night the way her season had ended last year. There would be no loss in the semifinals of the Division III National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament this time. Not at home, and not on the night she became the university's career leading scorer for both men and women.

title: Philip Morris Announces Dance Grants
description: Philip Morris Companies says it will give $1 million to 25 American dance companies in celebration of the 25th anniversary of its first grants to dance. For the creation of new works, grants of $10,000 to $150,000 are to be given to companies that previously received support from the corporation.

title: Georgia Senate Intervenes To Stop a Hostile Takeover
description: When you are fighting off a hostile takeover, there's nothing like having a state government on your side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, SYDNEY
description: ROGERS-Sydney. On March 21, 1997, born Jan. 13, 1907, London, England. Husband of 62 years to Beatrice, father of Teri Lehmann and Michael Rogers, grandfather to Bruce, David, Mark and Amy Lehmann and their spouses and Lisa and Jessica Rogers. Great grandfather to Dylan, Justin, Robert, Nicholas, Kate and Merideth Lehmann and Samantha and Joshua Sklare. Father-inlaw to Jack Lehmann and Gail Rogers. He affected all the lives he touched. In lieu of flowers a donation to the Pulmonary Fund, St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital would be greatly appreciated.

title: Beliefs
description: Was Paul of Tarsus, rather than Jesus of Nazareth, the real founder of Christianity? The pioneering German Scripture scholar Ferdinand Christian Baur raised that question a century and a half ago, and scores of thinkers have hashed it over ever since.

title: SUMMIT TALKS END WITH AGREEMENTS, BUT NOT FOR NATO
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin agreed today to differ over NATO expansion but formally determined that Russia would negotiate its own partnership agreement with the military alliance that would be signed before NATO began adding members in July.

title: Coach Pushes Illini to a Date With UConn
description: A year ago, after Theresa Grentz's first season as the Illinois women's basketball coach ended with a 13-15 record, she sat down with her players.

title: Tesco of Britain to Buy Irish Supermarkets
description: Tesco P.L.C. said yesterday that it would pay $:630 million ($1.01 billion) for Associated British Foods P.L.C.'s three supermarket chains in Ireland. Tesco will pay cash for the Stewarts chain in Northern Ireland; Quinnsworth, which is the second-largest supermarket chain in the Irish Republic, and Crazy Prices, which is in both Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

title: 2 Executives Squeezed Out At Ad Agency
description: In a stunning palace coup at one of the biggest, best-known advertising agencies in the world, two top executives of the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago unexpectedly resigned yesterday after being told they had lost the support of other senior managers.

title: Tobacco's Crumbling Barricades
description: The crack in the tobacco industry's facade has reached seismic proportions, bringing new hope that legal and public pressures may finally force the industry to stop pushing its addictive and lethal product on unwary youngsters. The settlement announced between the Liggett Group and the attorneys general of 22 states confirmed what most of us already knew. Liggett conceded that tobacco is addictive and causes cancer, heart disease and other illness. It also acknowledged that the industry has long directed some of its marketing toward teen-agers as young as 14, seeking to lure them into a lifelong smoking habit. The breathtaking element in these extraordinary admissions was not what was said but who was saying it.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Bill Bradley, the creator of the Broadway tradition of the Gypsy Robe, which is passed from musical to musical for good luck, omitted one stop on its most recent travels. From ''Chicago,'' the robe was passed to ''Once Upon a Mattress'' before being handed over to ''Play On!''

title: U.S. Says Immigrants Must Apply by Mail
description: Hundreds of anxious immigrants who hoped to apply for legal status at the Federal Building in lower Manhattan were instead sent away with a flier yesterday. It explained how to apply by mail and promised that their applications would be processed promptly.

title: Pact for Peru Hostage Crisis Is Said to Be on the Table
description: Mediators between the Peruvian Government and leftist rebels holding scores of hostages have outlined a tentative agreement to end the standoff, by which the rebels would give up their captives and leave Peru in exchange for a chance at early parole for some of their jailed comrades, according to a diplomat close to the negotiations.

title: $2,500 for an Operatic Fund-Raiser (And the Mayor Won't Even Sing)
description: Couldn't afford the Lincoln Bedroom? You can still contribute your way into Lincoln Center, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is holding an operatic fund-raiser next month and choice $2,500 seats remain available.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROSNITZ, GERRY
description: PROSNITZ-Gerry. The Board of The Jewish Association of Retired Professionals mourns the passing of its founder and past President. She was a dedicated and tireless leader for many years. We extend our condolences to the family.

title: On Road, Big Vehicles Use Size to Intimidate
description: To the Editor:

title: His Lordship's Celery
description: In this nightmare I am appointed to run the C.I.A. and Senator Richard Shelby is questioning me. I do well at first.

title: Harm to Highways
description: To the Editor:

title: A Black Joins Merrill Lynch's Top Ranks
description: As part of this week's reorganization of some of Merrill Lynch's top managers, E. Stanley O'Neal became one of the firm's top executives, making him one of the most senior African-Americans on Wall Street. But that appointment has resulted in a focus that leaves Mr. O'Neal feeling ambivalent.

title: Ex-Official In Newark Is Convicted
description: Jackie R. Mattison, the former chief of staff to Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, was found guilty today of taking bribes from an insurance broker in exchange for lucrative contracts. He is the first official from the Mayor's inner circle to be convicted in an intensive investigation into corruption at all levels of Newark government.

title: Ex-Defense Chief to Join Hambrecht Board
description: William J. Perry, a former Defense Secretary, is joining the board of Hambrecht & Quist and will also be a senior adviser for the firm's growing merger and acquisition business and international operations, the San Francisco investment bank said yesterday.

title: 6 Degrees of Falling in Love
description: An all-but-forgotten 50's pop song called ''C'est la Vie'' sighs about how ''John's in love with Joan, Joan's in love with Jim, and Jim's in love with someone who's not in love with him.'' After describing a daisy chain of unrequited love, it moans, ''As they say in old Paree, c'est la vie.''

title: Argentina Evades Its Nazi Past
description: Congratulations are due to those who finally cajoled the Swiss into admitting their role as bankers to the Third Reich. Indeed, other so-called neutrals of World War II -- Spain, Sweden and Portugal -- who did brisk fencing for the Nazis would do well to follow suit before they face a similar international browbeating.

title: U.S. Again Vetoes a Move By U.N. Condemning Israel
description: With the crisis in the Middle East deepening, the Clinton Administration cast its third Security Council veto today in defense of Israel, and blocked the latest and most moderate resolution calling on Israel to halt construction of a Jewish housing project in predominately Arab East Jerusalem.

title: Watching Calories, Not Gunshots
description: HE trotted onto the floor of the Carrier Dome, rather light on his feet, considering his bulk. You couldn't miss the 6-foot-9-inch, 360-pound Troy Jackson on the Louisville layup line here last night, the way the gunmen miraculously did in the drive-by shooting back in St. Albans, Queens, almost six years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the 1997-98 season of the Metropolitan Opera misspelled the surname of the singer who is to appear as Micaela in ''Carmen'' on opening night, Sept. 22. She is Norah Amsellem.

title: North Carolina and Louisville Move On
description: The coach with the most victories in the history of major college basketball sounded as if his team had lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANAHAN, WARREN
description: SHANAHAN-Warren. On March 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Sarah (nee Pedicini). Loving father of William, Christopher, Mary Dalia and Claire DeMartino. Cherished grandfather of Carly, Michael, Jo nathan, Nicholas, Justin and Demi. Devoted brother of Anita and Patricia. Funeral mass on Saturday 9:15 A.M., Holy Family RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: 4 Are Killed in a Suicide Bombing in Tel Aviv
description: A blast touched off by a suicide bomber ripped through a crowded Tel Aviv cafe today, killing the bomber and three other people, wounding dozens and striking a new blow at the tottering Israeli-Palestinian peace.

title: L.I. Lutheran Defeats LaSalle
description: What was shaping up to be a showdown between New York City's Catholic and public schools champions -- LaSalle Academy and Paul Robeson -- in the New York State Federation basketball tournament final went up in smoke tonight at the Glens Falls Civic Center.

title: Childhood Abuse Can Cause Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Tony Zale, 83, Middleweight Boxing Champion in the 1940's
description: Tony Zale, who brawled his way to the middleweight championship twice during a Hall of Fame boxing career punctuated by three memorable -- if not legendary -- title bouts with Rocky Graziano, died Thursday at a nursing home in Portage, Ind. He was 83.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL TO PAY FOR INQUIRY INTO FUND-RAISING
description: Temporarily quelling an internal revolt, the Republican-led House today approved a measure to pay for its investigation into questionable Democratic campaign fund-raising practices.

title: Corrections
description: The New Video Releases section of the Home Video column on March 14 misidentified the director of the film ''The First Wives Club.'' He is Hugh Wilson, not Hugh Smith.

title: New (Watery) Frontier
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar and Jackson: The Guards in Charge
description: Cameron Dollar grew up without a mother. Bobby Jackson grew up without a father.

title: Arms Cache in Nicaragua Casts a Long Shadow
description: On a quiet Sunday in early February, Nicaraguan police officers raided a ranch outside Managua belonging to a retired Sandinista Army officer.

title: USA WASTE TO BUY CANADIAN UNIT OF WMX
description: USA Waste Services Inc. agreed yesterday to buy most of the Canadian solid waste business of Waste Management Inc., a unit of WMX Technologies, for about $186 million in cash and stock. USA Waste's Canadian Waste Services unit expects the newly acquired businesses to generate $124 million in revenue annually. USA Waste will pay WMX Technologies $124 million in cash and $62 million in stock. The stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $37.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. WMX Technologies said the sale of its Canadian solid waste assets was part of its plan to cut as many as 3,000 jobs, sell $1.5 billion in assets and retrench overseas. On the New York Stock Exchange, WMX's shares slipped 25 cents yesterday, to $30.625.

title: For One Man, Spring's Song Is Grating
description: A THUMPING rhythm rippled through John Dallas's chest the other day as he walked down the Grand Concourse. Spring was near on Wednesday, the last day of winter, but the beat wasn't the song of a heart that embraced the season of breezes and blossoms. It blasted from a maroon van cruising the wide avenue, pumping music like a disco on wheels.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STALLER, BELLA
description: STALLER-Bella. August 14, 1915-March 22, 1987. You will always be missed and remembered.

title: A True Story About a Dog and a Mayor With a Story to Tell
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had a cold yesterday, so his voice was a bit scruffy. But probably nothing short of pneumonia could have deterred him from his late-morning visit to Public School 33 in Queens Village, where he sat in front of a gaggle of giggling second-graders and read one of his favorite children's books, ''Firehouse Dog.''

title: 2 Posed as Nuns, Police Say
description: Two Brooklyn women were arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with criminal impersonation and fraudulent accosting by the police, who said the women were posing as nuns to solicit charitable contributions in the Bronx.

title: Keep Vending Laws Fair
description: Until 1995 the permits needed to sell food on New York City's streets were monopolized by a few powerful individuals, who rented them illegally -- and at scandalous rates -- to those who had been shut out. The City Council brought equity to the process with a law that allowed only one permit per individual. But a vaguely worded bill now pending before the Council could reverse this progress, returning more than half the city's permits to bulk holders.

title: Police Release Man They Arrested at Bank
description: A 27-year-old ambulette driver was arrested yesterday and accused of trying to rob a bank in the Bronx, but the police said they released him after realizing that he had apparently been trying only to withdraw $1,300 in cash from his own savings account.

title: Western Teams Win in Tourney
description: Colorado College and Denver, both of the Western Association, were winners tonight in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey tournament.

title: Student Held in Burglaries
description: The nicely dressed young man seemed to blend in perfectly in the upscale Morris County towns where he was often seen jogging or strolling, prosecutors said.

title: Exams Urged for Neighbors Of 1945-51 Atomic Leaks
description: Government researchers are recommending that thousands of people exposed to radiation leaked from a Washington State site 50 years ago be monitored for possible thyroid problems.

title: Updated 'Elektra' Matched With a Traditional 'Traviata'
description: Richard Strauss's clangorous setting of the classical tale of the vengeful Elektra, in a stark, updated staging by Elijah Moshinsky, and Verdi's melodious account of Violetta's ennoblement through sacrifice in ''La Traviata,'' given a lavish conventional treatment by Marta Domingo: the final productions of the Washington Opera season at the Kennedy Center are as mixed as any bag of two can possibly be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYLIE, JOAN E.A.
description: WYLIE-Joan E.A. of Rye and Port Chester, NY. Died March 15, 1997. Artist, poet and sailor. She was 79. Widow of Amos K. Wylie & J. Norman Anderson. Survived by J. Norman A. Wylie, Joan W. Minich, Winifred W. Walden and five grandchildren. Memorial 4/12/97 Rye Presbyterian Church. Donations to the Hemlock Society.

title: Knicks Get Well for the Road
description: The Knicks flew to Milwaukee after practice today a healthier team. Allan Houston, who sat out Wednesday's victory over the 76ers with a stomach virus, is expected to start Saturday night against the Bucks. Chris Childs will also start despite an assortment of nagging injuries.

title: In a Holy Land of Kitsch, Politics and Terrorism
description: With a strong sense of irony and a deadpan visual style, the Palestinian film maker Elia Suleiman creates a two-sided portrait of his homeland. His ''Chronicle of a Disappearance'' is divided into complementary sections, each conceived and executed with extreme restraint. At its best, this structure offers both formal and political interest, since the film's segments are described respectively as personal and political diaries.

title: CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON TO TAKE STAKE IN VOLPE
description: Credit Suisse First Boston said yesterday that it would take a 25 percent stake in Volpe Brown Whelan & Company, a boutique investment bank specializing in technology and health care, to increase its business in those industries. The investment bank, a subsidiary of Credit Suisse, said its alliance with Volpe Brown would include setting up a $100 million merchant banking fund in which Credit Suisse First Boston would be the lead investor. Volpe Brown would manage the fund, which would invest in health care and technology companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREW, MARTIN
description: DREW-Martin. The Board of Governors, Administration, his associates and the entire staff of The Parkway Hospital offer their deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Esther, his devoted children Diane and Steve Rukavina, Howard and Ina Drew, Michael and Zindy Drew and his dear grandchildren Jason, Lisa, Alex, Sarah, Shonna and Brian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, HAROLD CHRISTIAN, SR, M.D.
description: SCHAEFER-Harold Christian, Sr, M.D. Of Brooklyn, New York, on March 20, 1997. Funeral Mass Monday, 1 PM, Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, New York City. Kindly omit flowers. Inquiries M.J. Smith Sons.

title: For Danes, Private and Public Upheavals
description: How much control do we exert over our own lives and how much of what happens is determined by sheer accident? That unanswerable question haunts ''The Eighteenth,'' Anders Ronnow-Klarlund's engrossing, skillfully plotted study of several Danes whose lives dramatically intersect on May 18, 1993, the day Denmark voted to join the European Union.

title: Art Doesn't Justify All Means of Expression
description: To the Editor:

title: Sherle Wagner, 79, Creator of Luxury Fixtures for Bathrooms
description: Sherle Wagner, a designer whose company, Sherle Wagner International Inc., became synonymous with luxury bathroom fixtures, accessories and hardware, died of heart failure on March 14 in Palm Beach, Fla., his son-in-law, Vincent Geoffroy, said this week. Mr. Wagner was 79.

title: Rowan Becomes a University
description: If you try calling Rowan College from now on, the operator will answer ''Rowan University.''

title: Shares of Ivax Tumble 14% After Its Suitor Drops Deal
description: Shares of the Ivax Corporation plummeted 14 percent yesterday after the collapse Thursday of a plan under which the troubled generic drug maker would have merged with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation in a stock deal originally valued at $1.66 billion.

title: Kozlowski and Falcons Agree
description: Tight end BRIAN KOZLOWSKI has agreed to terms on a one-year deal with the Atlanta Falcons. Kozlowski, who had been with the Giants since 1994, is expected to sign his contract on Monday pending a physical. He is the second Giant to join DAN REEVES, the Giants' former coach, in Atlanta. Running back GARY DOWNS signed with the team earlier this week.

title: Judge's Speech at Abortion Rally Sets Off Dispute on Free Speech and Impartiality
description: An hour after he was sworn in as a Supreme Court justice of the State of Washington last year, Richard Sanders attended an anti-abortion rally at the state Capitol holding a red rose and made a one-minute speech that consisted mainly of these words:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAILATI, ERMINIA
description: VAILATI-Erminia, at the age of 97, died on March 20, at the Cape Regency Nursing Home in Centerville, MA. She was formerly of Osterville and New York City; wife of the late Anthony Vailati; mother of Josephine Zampedri of New York City and the late Elsie Van Voorhis; mother-in-law of Shepherd Van Voorhis of Osterville, MA; grandmother of Thomas Van Voorhis of Hopatcong, NJ and James Van Voorhis of Osterville, MA; great grandmother of Gearht Van Voorhis of Hopatcong. NJ. Calling hours and services will be omitted. Donations in her memory may be made to Cape Regency Nursing Home Sunshine Fund, 120 So Main St, Centerville, MA 02632. For information contact Doane, Beal & Ames Funeral Home, Hyannis, Massachusetts.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter published March 17 from Jim Wright on campaign contributions rendered a sentence incorrectly. The sentence should have read: ''The First Lady was just being sociable to her friends, while Mr. Gore was doing things he is proud of and will never do again.''

title: Dick Morris, Moral Philosopher
description: Think about it. A well-known, married female political consultant is the chief architect of the President's re-election campaign. She polls, she counsels, she triangulates, she fights off jealous White House staffers and emerges on the cover of Time magazine as the one who really whispers in the Presidential ear.

title: Award for Victim's Family
description: The family of a 23-year-old New Jersey graduate student who was killed when a Korean Air Lines jet was shot down by a Soviet fighter plane in 1983 was awarded more than $2.1 million yesterday, lawyers said.

title: Childhood Abuse Can Cause Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: The Latest Wrinkle
description: I dimly recall a time when women talked about books, plays and politics. Now all we talk about is skin.

title: From House Floor, Speaker Seeks to Clarify Position on Tax Cuts
description: Trying to rid himself of a storm cloud of criticism over his suggestion that Republicans consider delaying tax cuts, Speaker Newt Gingrich made a speech on the floor of the House of Representatives today, arguing that he had been misunderstood.

title: Health Chief Quits to Take Job as Adviser In Washington
description: Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg, the City Health Commissioner, resigned yesterday after five years on the job to take a senior position in the Clinton Administration, city officials said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Sues Public Relations Executive
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit this week against an executive of the New York public relations firm of Ruder-Finn Inc., contending that she passed inside information to her husband about Sandoz Ltd.'s 1995 acquisition of Genetic Therapy Inc.

title: Sleuth Dusts Off a City's Storied Past
description: This port city and oil town doesn't have a long modern history -- a hundred years or so -- and its appearance today is rather dusty and timeworn. But for a brief moment at the turn of the century, few places on earth were as glittering.

title: Coleman Leaves The Nets Blinking
description: It is Derrick Coleman's indicator light. It is the one thing that lets you know if it is safe to proceed or if there is danger ahead: it's his face.

title: No Headline
description: ''There must be a hidden agenda. Probably the next step is, you can own cigarettes but you can't smoke them.''

title: New York's Wily Molecules
description: The world looks to New York City for culture. Who dares to smash the petri dish?

title: V.S. Pritchett, Master of the Short Story And Literary Criticism, Is Dead at 96
description: V.S. Pritchett, the versatile and astoundingly prolific English writer who over a six-decade career became a master of fiction, nonfiction, biography and literary criticism, died on Thursday at Whittington Hospital here. He was 96.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYNNE, MINNA
description: WYNNE-Minna, on March 20, 1997, of Lauderdale Lakes, Florida, formerly of New York. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister and aunt. School teacher and mentor. Graveside services are Sunday, March 23, 2:00 P.M., at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey. For further information call the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, Tamarac, Florida, (800-758-1151).

title: Kodak Shares Plunge on Surprise Disclosure of Flat Sales
description: Shares of the Eastman Kodak Company plummeted yesterday after the company said that revenue for January and February was flat compared with the period a year ago. Analysts had been expecting revenue growth of 4 to 6 percent.

title: Unemployment Rate Drops
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate for February fell to 5.5 percent, its lowest level in more than six years. But the rate is still slightly higher than the national rate of 5.3 percent, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Television Notes column on Wednesday incorrectly described a proposal by two Senators, Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, and Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican, to limit violence and sexual content in television programming. The Senators said they would propose an antitrust exemption for the television industry to allow collaboration on a programming code. Their proposal would not require that the industry establish one.

title: In Birmingham, a Big Iron Man Gets No Respect
description: From a distance, the massive statue seems to be aiming a giant Popsicle at the face of Zeus.

title: Bronx Man Stabs an Officer And Is Fatally Shot by Police
description: A police officer responding to a domestic dispute in a Bronx apartment building was stabbed in the shoulder last night by a man who was enraged following an argument with his daughter, the police said. The officer and his partner then shot the man to death.

title: Dairy Farmers' Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: New Tony, Toned-Down Clubs For Dancing the Night Away
description: It will be 20 years next month since Studio 54 opened, and few people would dispute that now is a leaner, less glamorous time for night life in New York City and for dancing in particular. This is the era of the lounge, of sumptuous sit-down places where bottoms rarely leave fuzzy couches and the entertainment, as Leticia Roman complained on a recent Friday night, is ''all about looking beautiful and sitting there and who do you know.''

title: No Name Change for Track
description: A proposal to rename the Meadowlands Racetrack was killed yesterday after objections to the new name, Seagram Park, were raised by both Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Police Unit to Seek 2 Youths In Pellet Attacks on Subway
description: The Police Department has created a task force to search for two young suspects who are believed to be responsible for a recent string of 10 pellet attacks on subway riders across the city, investigators announced yesterday.

title: Aggressive Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally Stepping Off a Ledge To Explore the Empty Space
description: Not all improvisation in jazz is equal, and for every deeply improvisational performance there are 100 in which a musician brings memorized ideas, runs and figures to a solo. To improvise a solo out of the great spaces of silence surrounding a stage, using melodies or new ideas without recourse to practiced lines, is one of the great jazz challenges. On Tuesday night at Iridium, where he remains through tomorrow night, the guitarist Mark Whitfield showed that he's moving into that territory.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7

title: Two Met Patients, Recovered Now, Give a Recital
description: The Metropolitan Opera's walking wounded, the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli and the conductor James Levine, retreated to the smaller stage of Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening. Ms. Bartoli dropped out of an internationally broadcast performance of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Met last Saturday, citing a strained back, after Mr. Levine and the two male leads had already withdrawn because of illness.

title: INSIDE
description: New Warning, Old Attitude?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUTLU, HALDUN CEMAL, M.D.
description: MUTLU-Haldun Cemal, M.D., suddenly on March 16, 1997 of Kings Park, L.I. Physician at LISVH at Stoney Brook and The Jamaica Hospital. Devoted husband of Suzanne, beloved father of Haldun and Kenan. Dear son-inlaw of Charlotte and brother-inlaw of Tomrul. Also cherished by relatives in Turkey and Maryland. Services to be held in Instanbul, Turkey.

title: 'Bad Boys' Among House Republicans Make a Point
description: A day after their most pointed revolt against Speaker Newt Gingrich and other House Republican leaders, some of the self-described ''bad boys'' of the Republican caucus threatened today to stage an even wider rebellion, if necessary, to make their point.

title: When Strawberry Speaks About Drugs, Kids Listen
description: Everywhere Darryl Strawberry turned, another seventh-grader pointed at him or posed a question. He could not budge an inch after completing a speech denouncing drugs, alcohol, guns and gangs to three dozen students inside the cozy library at Oak Grove Junior High School.

title: 15 Fourth Graders Sickened And Then Treated at Hospitals
description: It could have been the hot dogs they ate for lunch. Or the stuffed shells. Or perhaps the chocolate milk. Whatever it was, more than a dozen students in a Bronx fourth-grade class became sick to their stomachs yesterday and had to be taken by ambulance to hospitals.

title: Iditarod Cruelty? Mush! Dogs Are Well Kept
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Senate vote on a bill to support President Clinton's certification of Mexico as an ally in the war on drugs misspelled the name of a Georgia Republican who co-sponsored the bill. He is Senator Paul D. Coverdell, not Coverdale.

title: With Jazz in the Family, Lincoln Center Moves To Adopt Pop Standards
description: Ten years after throwing open its doors to jazz, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is about to expand its nonclassical music programming with a potentially major new series tentatively titled American Popular Standards. Jonathan Schwartz, the New York radio personality and author, has been named artistic director of the program, which will present its first concerts in the 1998-99 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMBOULY, SOURIA
description: STAMBOULY-Souria. March 19, 1997. From Brooklyn Heights, NY and Cinnaminson, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Gofril Stambouly. Survived by her brother Izzat Soyegh of Calif, also her nephew and his family, Dr. H. Kelly of Phila. and NJ, many other nephews, nieces, great-nephews, greatnieces. Relatives and friends are invited to her viewing and Mass, Sunday, March 23, 1997 in St. Marons Maronite RC Church, 10th and Ellsworth Street, So. Phila. PA, 4 P.M. Funeral Monday from the church, 10 A.M. Interment, Brooklyn NY. In lieu of flowers family requests donations be made to the above named church. For information, Joseph V. title: The Perversity of Everyday Life
description: Ines Arredondo's collection of short fiction, UNDERGROUND RIVER AND OTHER STORIES (University of Nebraska, cloth, $30; paper, $12), is nothing short of spellbinding. Mostly set in a small town in northwestern Mexico at the beginning of this century, it provides a stunning expression of the erotic perversity found in seemingly ordinary lives: in each story, hovering just below the placid surface of daily existence, lurks a tragicomic opera of battling desires. Arredondo (1928-89) uses sharp prose to create a paradoxically dreamlike reality; the details in her work are so vividly rendered that they make scandal, madness and horror seem fascinating. In ''The Shunammite,'' a young woman reluctantly agrees to her uncle's deathbed wish that they marry, only to find that her transgression is his cure. In ''Mariana,'' a young couple's erotic obsession leads one to insanity, the other to death, while their neighbors avidly track their downfall. The narrator of ''The Nocturnal Butterflies,'' who works as a butler, describes how his relationship with his employer is forever altered when he procures for him the sexual services of an unusual adolescent girl. And the narrator of ''Shadow in the Shadows'' tells of her passion for a handsome young man, a passion so strong that she is willing to share her lover with her aging husband. Arredondo, although she published only three small volumes of stories during her lifetime, is one of modern Mexico's most highly regarded writers. Cynthia Steele's able translation, the first appearance of Arredondo's work in English, should secure a new audience for her powerful and distinctive voice. Jenny McPhee

title: Kara Walker's Shock Art

Hundreds of long, skinny braids quiver down to her waist, fraying at the tips in Botticelli-brown waves. Squinting at some ghostly faint, tentative sketches in white pencil, she breaks a blade segment off a slim X-Acto knife and lets it drop to the floor. Then with swift, sure strokes, holding the metal knife like a pencil, she begins to slice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, SAM
description: GOLDEN-Sam, Lake Worth, FL. Mr. Sam Golden, 82, of Columbus, NY died unexpectedly at Wellington Community Regional Hospital, Wellington, FL on Tuesday, March 11, 1997. He was predeceased by his wife of 51 years Adele, and is survived by four children: Tom Golden of Tenafly, NJ; Mark Golden and his wife Barbara of Earlville, NY; Jo-Ann Golden of Lake Worth, FL; Steven Golden and his wife Marilyn of Easton, PA; grandchildren Jean Marc Golden of Tenafly, NJ; Tania Golden of Buffalo, NY; Callen and Emma Golden of Earlville, NY; Michelle Golden and Joshua Golden of Easton, PA; and one great grandchild Joshua Golden-Asseo of Buffalo, NY. Sam Golden, the founder of Golden Artist Colors, an internationally recognized manufacturer of artists colors in Columbus, NY, started his paint making career in New York City in 1936. Sam, a partner in Bocour Artist Colors, Inc., with his Uncle Leonard Bocour, until his first retirement in 1972, was called a ''20th Century alchemist'' for his breakthrough work in modern synthetic paints for artist's use. Sam collaborated with many well known artists, providing custom materials for their individual use. Sam's innovative work has been credited as having a profound influence on the direction of modern art and its use of acrylic paint. After a long career as paintmaker, inventor, chemist, and a brief try at the retired life, Sam, at the age of 67 with wife Adele, son Mark and his wife Barbara and Chuck Kelly, formed Golden Artist Colors. This new company was created to perpetuate Sam's lifelong dedication to serving the professional artist. Sam had, in recent years, begun painting and had exhibited his work at both the Chenango County Council of the Arts and the Earlville Opera House Gallery. In 1996, Sam was honored by receiving the first Entrepreneur of the Year Award given by the Chenango County Chamber of Commerce. A family graveside service was held at the Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, Long Island on March 14. A memorial service for friends of Sam will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Sam and Adele Golden Foundation for the Arts, c/o Golden Artist Colors, Inc., 188 Bell Road, New Berlin, NY 13411.

title: How Many Light-Bulb Jokes Does It Take to Chart an Era?
description: Unlike knock-knock jokes, dead-baby jokes, dumb-blonde jokes and why-did-the-chicken-cross-the-road jokes, the light-bulb joke is uniquely political. Not only does it make references to current events (how many Canadian separatists, how many Branch Davidians), it also summarizes, in epigrammatic form, the history of the latter half of the 20th century, excoriating in virtually the same breath the illegal immigrant and the gainfully employed bureaucrat, big government and big business, homosexuals and homophobes, shrinks and paranoids. And because the light-bulb joke involves a piece of electrical equipment, it mirrors our ambivalent attitudes toward technology, which, ever since Thomas Edison invented the incandescent bulb in 1879, has become so complex that we can no longer install and repair our appliances without enlisting the services of price-gouging experts. In the light-bulb joke, the ancient literary genre of the riddle demonstrates its versatility and wickedly dissects the problems of the machine age.

description: A game that threatened to be dominated first by the Pittsburgh Penguins and then by their public address announcer, wound up being taken over -- and won -- by the Devils today at the Civic Arena.

title: Political 'Success' Leaves Many Asian-Americans Bitter
description: Asian-Americans organized better than they ever had for the elections in November, and they delivered a majority of their votes to President Clinton, while donating -- completely legally -- at least $10 million to his campaign.

title: Long Ago, Far Away
description: Frank Craven plays a small-town druggist who is the guide and narrator of OUR TOWN (1940), a sensitive, warm replica of Thornton Wilder's play, dealing ever so simply and profoundly with life and death in a New England village. This is the story of several people living in Grover' Corners, N.H., during the early years of the century -- chiefly of a boy and girl, children of neighboring parents, who fall in love, get married and have a child. Sam Wood directed a cast that includes William Holden (above), Martha Scott, Fay Bainter, Thomas Mitchell, Beulah Bondi and Guy Kibbee. But it is Aaron Copland's marvelous music that is the picture's heart and soul -- SAT.-SUN. at 12:30 A.M. on CHANNEL 13. Howard Thompson

title: The Ups and Downs Are Part of the Ride
description: IT WAS SUPPOSED TO BE A banner year for Harold Prince, the veteran man of the theater whose credits include producing ''West Side Story,'' directing ''Cabaret'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' and working with Stephen Sondheim on some of the most innovative musicals -- ''Company,'' ''Follies,'' ''Sweeney Todd'' -- ever done on Broadway.

title: Lure of Fly Tying Is in the Preparation
description: As the angling season approaches in the Northeast, many fly fishermen are hunched at their desks, work benches or dining room tables of an evening, creating hook-bearing imitations of insects, minnows and other creatures on which fish are wont to dine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIORENZA, NICHOLAS A.
description: FIORENZA-Nicholas A. Retired Professor at St. Francis College. On March 2. Interred on March 4 at St. John's Cemetery. Survived by his family.

title: Delicately Oriental, but 'Practical'
description: THE Flatbush Development Corporation's annual house tour on April 27 will feature about a dozen buildings, but one of them is worth the trip all by itself -- the 1903 Japanese-style house at 131 Buckingham Road in Prospect Park South, perhaps New York's most unusual residence.

title: For an Australian Wunderkind, the Glitter of Hollywood
description: AT THE END OF ''The Destiny of Nathalie X'' William Boyd's scathing short story about Hollywood -- a character who has tried to corrupt a young African director consoles him by saying: ''It's just a dance. It's just a dance we have to do.'' To the amazement of the hard-bitten Hollywood character, the young director just laughs. The point of the story is that he still can.

title: Jacqueline Norden, Andreas Kruger
description: Jacqueline Ashley Davis Norden, the daughter of Jacqueline Davis Norden of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Robert Norden of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Andreas Wilhelm Kruger, the son of Monica and Wilhelm Kruger of Essen, Germany. The Rev. William Pindar performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: 'Downtrodden' Freelancers Aren't Party's Only Guests
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau College Being Sued Again Over Nature of Sex Education
description: EIGHT years ago Frank J. Russo Jr. of Port Washington sued under the state's Freedom of Information Law to see a sexually explicit film from a course at Nassau Community College. He won.

title: The Garde as Hope Aglimmer
description: THE Thursday evening event by the Paul Taylor Dance Company at the Garde Arts Center -- three of the troupe's most acclaimed ballets: ''Airs,'' ''Company B'' and ''Esplanade'' -- will actually commence 24 hours earlier than the stated 8 P.M. Which indicates why the coming of a big time company to New London can rightfully be called an event, not merely a performance.

title: Chicago Trial Could End Long Reach of Man Said to Run Gang From Jail
description: For nearly a quarter of a century, Larry Hoover, a high school dropout from the struggling side of town, has been locked away in one Illinois prison or another for the slaying of a rival drug dealer.

title: Shanker Service Planned
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., are expected to be among the speakers at a memorial service for Albert Shanker tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. in the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, 63d Street and Columbus Avenue.

title: In Your Face
description: At American Airlines, the issues have been pilots' pay and who gets to fly those commuter jets. Although wages and other big issues are often at the center of labor disputes, many smaller concerns can also set workers' teeth on edge. Sometimes the rallying cry is as basic as ''We need an office microwave!'' What are the issues in your office and what happened when you fought for them? Has anyone gone to the mat over issues you thought were silly? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: At Cafe on Troubled Street, Ode to Art
description: Mention the block on 207th Street between Broadway and Cooper Street, and many in Inwood are quick to point out its persistent drug problems. Despite a recent raid on an import-export company that the police said was a front for the drug trade, dealers still peddle their stuff from an apartment complex nearby.

title: Time to Tend the Grass Roots: Community Board Meetings Coming Up
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, DAVID J.
description: MANN-David J. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Gates of Zion mourn the passing of our devoted and beloved Cantor Emeritus. He served our congregation with distinction for over 39 years. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Frances, son Zachary, daughter Thelma and husband Albert Nicolas, grandchildren Daniel, Elexa and Jenny Rose. May he, together with his beloved son Daniel, rest in eternal peace. We will never forget them. William Last, President Temple Gates of Zion, Valley Stream, N.Y.

title: E-Z Pass Deal In New Jersey Is Not So Easy
description: While drivers using the E-Z Pass electronic payment system glide through tollbooths at New York City bridges and tunnels and on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, a battle over a lucrative contract to bring E-Z Pass to New Jersey's fabled toll roads could keep drivers there fumbling for change for many months to come.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 23, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Officials Are Starting Early in Their Defense of the 2000 Census
description: The Census Bureau is already offering a spirited and detailed defense of its plans for the census three years from now, and says it expects to be sued if it does what it wants to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, JARVIS, ANTOINETTE C. (NEE COZELL)
description: BENTLEY-JARVIS-Antoinette C. (nee Cozell) age 59 of Far Hills, NJ on Wednesday, March 19, 1997. Wife of Frederick H. Jarvis. Mother of Robert S. Bentley of New York City and Anne W. Bentley of Chevy Chase, MD. Daughter of Rose Vila of Northampton, PA and Joseph Cozell of New Orleans, LA. Also survived by her daughter-inlaw, Nicole Bentley of New York City, four stepdaughters, Margaret Lynn Hathaway and Helen Cleveland, both of Atlanta, GA, Elizabeth Murphy of Beverly, MA and Nancy Stewart of Basking Ridge, NJ and many loving friends. A memorial service will be celebrated on Monday, March 31 at 2PM at St. Mary's Abbey at Delbarton School, Morristown, NJ. Memorial gifts may be made to the Carol G. Simon Cancer Center, Morristown Memorial Health Foundation, 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: Merrill Lynch Growth Fund
description: FIND a sector of the stock market that is out of favor and bet big on it.

title: They've Kidnapped 'The English Patient'
description: THE Canadian novelist Michael Ondaatje has long had a vested interest in the Academy Awards. ''Once, I'd bet like mad on them,'' he said over a recent lunch at Nirvana, an Indian restaurant high over Central Park South. ''Suddenly, I'm in a different location.''

title: Rental Car Insurance: Staying Out of Financial Potholes
description: Q. Is there a way to beat the high cost of insurance on car rentals?

title: Basketball Gains the World and Loses Its Soul (and Profits Nicely)
description: There are probably enough Federal agents who care about hoops to slow down the current point-shaving investigations involving Arizona State and Fresno State until we get through this last critical week of March Madness. This is not to suggest that any team in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament is dealing with gamblers. But it would certainly stain the old school tie to even think that this youth festival could be about anything other than winning games to finance higher education.

title: Tropical Beauties, Windowsill Friends
description: NORTHERN gardeners who head to tropical climates for a time should have no problems identifying many of the plants growing there. The reason? Most of the popular tropical landscape plants have become house plants in the Northeast.

title: Red Sox May Be Classified as a Lost Cause Before the Start of the Season
description: Mo Vaughn tries hard to shackle his thoughts, but sometimes they just happen, like a home run that he doesn't try to hit.

title: Telling the Truth Is Tough for a Liar
description: Liar, Liar

title: Bermuda, A First Scent Of Spring
description: IN mid-February in New York, spring can seem far away. In Bermuda, the freesias are said to be in bloom, and the mere idea of these most divinely perfumed of flowers, growing outdoors and not just as part of a florist's bouquet, is enough to set my husband, Tom, and me to counting our pennies.

title: Clinton's Loyalty Pays Dividends
description: ''I know you trust me,'' Boris N. Yeltsin once told Bill Clinton, American officials say. ''But I know it's because you are afraid of what may come after me.''

title: Time to Check and Clean Rain Gutters, Carefully
description: NOW that the weather is warming up, it's a good time to clean and inspect rain gutters. They probably have accumulations of leaves and dirt that can block the flow of rainwater. The weight of debris and rainwater can cause the gutters to sag and pull away from the house. Once the gutters are cleaned out, you can inspect them for damage and make repairs.

title: Gurwin Nursing Home Gets High Mark
description: WHEN a representative of the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organization reviewed the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center in Commack in November, she called it ''the Tiffany of nursing homes.'' The designation delighted staff members and residents, but did not entirely surprise them. Since the center opened in 1988 it has strived to make quality a main priority.

title: OUR AFRICA
description: As an executive with more than a quarter century's experience trading profitably with many African nations, I find Jeffrey Goldberg's panacea (''Our Africa,'' March 2) for Africa naive as hell. Fortune 500 companies will not finance African development. Sorry. They have researched and re-researched Africa for decades, and continue to do so.

title: Around the Globe, Oscar's Siblings Multiply
description: AND THE GOLDBAGGE goes to. . . .

title: Driving the Dream Machines
description: THE auto companies create concept cars to explore new ideas or to hint at products to come, and while these one-of-a-kind vehicles serve as futuristic fantasies, they are not often driven by anyone except the engineers and executives who bring them to life.

title: HEY, THANKS!
description: T.S. Eliot once dismissed his poem ''The Waste Land'' as ''a personal and wholly insignificant grouse against life.'' On tax day next month, 3,000 copies of Eliots grouse will be given to grumbling taxpayers as they rush to file their returns. Volunteers from groups like the Academy of American Poets and the American Poetry and Literacy Project plan to hand out 75th-anniversary editions of the poem in front of U.S. Post Offices in six cities, wearing sandwich boards printed with its ubiquitous opening line, ''April is the cruelest month.'' The gesture may trigger a few impromptu nervous breakdowns do you really need to hear this on April 15? -- but verse boosters figure it will help. Its all being done as part of National Poetry Month, four weeks of events meant to raise the profile and sales of poetry in America.

title: Nursing Homes Face Stricter Standards
description: FEW industries undergo as much public scrutiny as nursing homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLOVER, MURIEL
description: SKLOVER-Muriel. Temple Israel of Long Beach and its Sisterhood extend sincerest condolences to our Co-President Bruce Sklover on the sudden passing of his beloved mother. She will be remembered as a woman of warmth, kindness and indomitable spirit. To Bruce; his wife, Tamar, Co-Administrator of our Pre-School; his father, Jerry; his brother, Andrew; and the entire family, we pray that they will be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Jacob Chiger, Rabbi Mark I. Samuels, Co-President Mollie Consor, Sist. Pres.

title: Jobs Fueling a Push For Cheaper Energy
description: After years of having the nation's highest electricity rates, New York is pursuing a drastic reorganization of the state's three biggest utilities as it follows the lead of other states to try to stem a painful loss of industry and jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MASLANSKY, MICHAEL
description: MASLANSKY-Michael. Beloved son, brother, husband, father, uncle and friend. Michael, we miss you. ''For he who lives more lives than one more deaths than one must die.''

title: At Middle-of-the Road, Go With Daily Specials
description: PICCOLO'S successfully straddles the middle of the road. This 12-year-old, easy-to-pass-by, family-run Italian restaurant, sandwiched between body shops, convenience stores and auto parts outlets in a Mineola commercial area, at 150 East Jericho Turnpike (248-8110), is almost in the center of Nassau County.

title: Out of the Shadows to Cooperstown
description: THE best shortstop not enough people saw, Willie Wells, was 80 when he died in 1989 of heart disease, but he never doubted that someday he would be elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Japanese Cult Said to Have Planned Nerve-Gas Attacks in U.S.
description: The religious cult accused of organizing the poison gas attack on the Tokyo subway system two years ago had also planned to release nerve gas in the United States, according to new court testimony in Tokyo.

title: Jeffrey Freymann and Garret Weyr
description: IN her novel ''Pretty Girls'' (Crown Publishers, 1988), Garret Weyr described a group of friends who called themselves the Amazon Club, three tall strong-minded young women with terrible love lives.

title: Headless House
description: When the editorial pages of both The Washington Post and New York Times praise the House Republican leadership for being marvelously responsible about budgets and taxes -- watch out.

title: Up and Over
description: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, our country's oldest full-scale commercial nuclear reaction, has a very special problem. And so too, therefore, do the people of New Jersey and the other Middle Atlantic States.

title: 3-Year-Old Florida Boy Is Found Dead Near 11-Foot Alligator
description: A trapper found the body of a 3-year-old boy in Lake Ashby this morning and then, with three shotgun blasts, killed the 11-foot alligator that was pushing the child through the water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKES, MOLLIE
description: PARKES-Mollie. Psychotherapist and clinical social worker, died at home March 21, 1997, after a short illness. Survived by daughters Nancy and Alison, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. She was always learning. Among her many loves were books, music, gardening, travel and her family, friends and patients. Those who knew her are invitied to visit with family at her home, Monday, March 24, 3-7 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, FANNIE, NEE ZIMMERMAN
description: GOLDBERG-Fannie, nee Zimmerman. August 28, 1907-March 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Irving J. Loving mother of S. Elayne Bergman, Allan, the late Irene Marshall. Devoted sister of Bessie Abrams. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Housing Starts Dip, Prices Rise as Fairfield Prospers
description: ECONOMISTS are calling the climate in Connecticut mostly sunshine with some light showers. Housing starts were down by about 7 percent in 1996, compared with 1995, but employment inched up nearly 2 percent since 1990. Moreover, housing prices have been rising in a brisk market driven by a mild winter.

title: Knight's Time To Look In the Mirror
description: ''GOOD morning,'' Dean Smith said wearily late Friday night, as he settled into his seat for a news conference following another saga of March Madness that had stretched maddeningly past midnight.

title: No Headline
description: ''Some of them can't wait till they turn 18 so they can get paid to vote.''

title: Down to the Sea -- Again and Again
description: TAKE YOURSELF BACK A long, long way, to a time of mystery and adventure, when a tale of a demented genius could fire up a child's imagination. Yes, we're talking about the 1950's and early 60's, when the fantasies shaping many young minds were not the cynical fare on television these days but earnest films of exploration like ''Journey to the Center of the Earth,'' ''The Time Machine,'' ''Jason and the Argonauts'' and, perhaps best, the 1954 classic ''20,000 Leagues Under the Sea.''

title: Tara Fracalossi And Thomas Lail
description: Tara Ann Fracalossi and Thomas Robert Lail, artists and art instructors, were married yesterday at Jingle Bell Farm in New Paltz, N.Y. Town Justice Jonathan D. Katz of New Paltz officiated.

title: Susan Skerritt, Brian O'Keefe
description: Susan Elizabeth Skerritt, the daughter of Elizabeth S. Skerritt of Rochester and the late Robert D. Skerritt, was married yesterday to Brian Edward O'Keefe, a son of Joan and Edward O'Keefe of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. Cheryl Minor performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Stickers Offered For Child Car Seats
description: IT is a frightening scenario. A car is in a serious accident. The driver and other adults are killed or left unconscious. A child has survived the crash but is too young or hysterical to tell the police to whom he or she belongs.

title: Seeing Hints of Suharto in His Old Friend's Business Deals
description: He owns forests, paper and plywood mills, airlines and banks, and last month he brokered a deal that gave him a major share in what may be the world's largest gold deposit.

title: French Dishes With a Dash of Caribbean
description: HEAD north on Port Chester's Main Street, past seemingly endless culinary temptations, and as they dissolve into more utilitarian buildings, a mirage rises and promises one more possibility: Cafe Mirage, an oasis for refreshment, good cheer and some fine dishes, which could, when this restaurant develops a track record, raise its rating to excellent.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption on Feb. 16 with an article about law firms that specialize in teacher labor contracts misidentified the clients of the three lawyers shown. Their firms represent boards of education, not teachers. The Times was made aware of the error in a letter received on March 13.

title: Getting Into National Parks
description: FAMILIES planning to camp in the most popular national parks this summer should be sure to catch up with a major change in reservation methods. In January 1996, the phone reservation system used for 4,500 camp sites in the most popular National Park Service areas was given a wider window: It is now possible to reserve a site five months in advance instead of only eight weeks, or in the case of Yellowstone, a year in advance.

title: The $1 Trillion Dogfight
description: YOU would think they were selling cans of cola to the chief executives of the world's airlines instead of flying machines that can cost more than $125 million apiece.

title: How to Play on a Piano Without Making Music
description: SKYSCRAPERS, CLOCKS, EVEN sunglasses: anything a leading architect or designer creates generally comes out well. Well, almost anything. Only one form seems to elude the talents of those professions: musical instruments, especially the piano. History records that only Jacques-Emile Ruhlmann, the supreme ''artiste decorateur'' of the 1920's and 1930's, managed to pull off the challenge.

title: MetroStars Are Edged by the Clash in Shootout, Spoiling Coach's Debut
description: The MetroStars and the San Jose Clash opened Major League Soccer's second season tonight with a game that looked more like a pre-season matchup.

title: A WINNING SEASON
description: American style has moved to the forefront this spring, from clean-cut business suits to colorful swimsuits, with plenty of jaunty sportswear in between. On the following pages, the world champion New York Yankees set the tone of our tribute to home-grown style, wearing simple yet sophisticated casual clothes.

title: Old Catholic Ritual Serves as New Tool To Recruit Converts
description: For years Ron Lacey felt like a man adrift, casting around for spiritual mooring. He believed in God and Jesus Christ, but had been raised without an affiliation to any one religion. So he sampled many, visiting Methodist, Baptist and Lutheran congregations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, NETTIE
description: SILVER-Nettie, on March 20, 1997. Beloved wife of Lee, cherished sister of Dorothy, Miriam and Bernie, adored mother of Judy & Roberta, devoted grandmother of Noah. Her grace, beauty and brilliance illuminated the lives she touched as teacher and counselor. She helped us all discover our best possible selves. Services today, Sunday, 3/23, 1 PM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard, at 76th Road.

title: At the Casinos
description: Atlantic City Hilton

title: Hispanic Council Member in Texas Capital Protests Ethnic Seat
description: As political protests go, this one is pretty mild. And the protester, Gus Garcia, a soft-spoken 63-year-old accountant, can hardly be described as a radical.

title: Samm Sinclair Baker, 87, Author Of Dozens of Self-Help Books
description: Samm Sinclair Baker, whose 30-odd self-improvement books counseled readers on how to help themselves to anything from svelte figures to good sex to making money by writing books, died on March 5 at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Mamaroneck.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: PRAIRIE REUNION

title: Home Is Where the Work Is
description: THE second week of February was a milestone in the home-based business that my husband and I run together: it was our first week of daily U.P.S. pickups. But we are far from alone. United Parcel Service trucks are ubiquitous in our middle-class neighborhood on the northern edge of Seattle because, as is increasingly true in many neighborhoods of our city, home-based businesses are ubiquitous, too.

title: In 1995, Ralph Friedgen Was in the Super Bowl. Two Years Later, He Was Looking for a Job.
description: Ralph Friedgen, a five-year assistant coach with the San Diego Chargers, resigned in January along with Bobby Ross and the rest of his coaching staff. General Manager Bobby Beathard cited ''philosophical differences'' as the reason for the parting. An 8-8 record in 1996, after the Chargers' 1994-95 run to Super Bowl XXIX, was largely laid to the moribund one-back offense. And Friedgen, who became the Chargers' offensive coordinator before the 1994 season, became a lightning rod for critics.

title: Sehorn Being Sought By Falcons' Reeves
description: The Giants may soon have to fight off someone who knows them extremely well. What's at stake? One of the best young cornerbacks in the league, that's all.

title: Mouths of Babes
description: To the Editor: Don Wallace's article ''Pass the Pate, Daddy,'' (Feb. 17) reminds me of meals on trips with my three grandsons. In 1995, the oldest had just turned 9 when he surprised us all by ordering the rack of lamb and adding, ''For my appetizer, I'll have the calamari.''

title: Guess Who's Giving the Voters a Choice
description: IT is not what one might expect from Iran.

title: FACING SUMMER
description: 'DO WHAT WE CAN, summer will have its flies,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson once wrote. ''If we walk in the woods, we must feed mosquitoes.'' Emerson's observation illustrates some of the hazards ahead. As the warm season approaches, you must ward off not only biting bugs, but burning rays as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, HELEN ELIZABETH
description: FLEMING - Helen Elizabeth. March 19, 1997. Beloved mother of George and Joseph Thieringer and Helen Donahew. Sister of Courtney and Grace Fleming and nine grandchildren. Reposing Fairchild Funeral Home, Garden City, Monday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9. Funeral Mass on Tuesday, St. Joseph's Garden City, 10 A.M. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: An Essential Stop Along the Bunny Trail
description: The first hint that Holsten's Brookdale Confectionery sells Easter candy is the person in a bunny costume on the sidewalk waving at you.

title: India Dello Strologo, C.S. Frazier Jr.
description: India Dello Strologo, the daughter of Jenifer Grant Marx of Indialantic, Fla., and Sergio Dello Strologo of Viareggio, Italy, was married yesterday to Christopher Simon Frazier Jr., the son of Moffat Collingwood Welsh of Landenberg, Pa., and Mr. Frazier of Plymouth Meeting, Pa. The Rev. Gary Spencer, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Robert F. Marx.

title: If the Price Is Right, Do You Have a Right to Know?
description: COMPARISON shopping is as American as apple pie. After all, what's wrong with getting the best deal for that pie by checking the prices at several bakeries? But if the bakery knows what you're doing, can it refuse to tell you its price or even shoo you out of the store?

title: Home Buyers Out in Force in a Humming Market
description: WHEN the Quartos put their four-bedroom Cape Cod in New Hyde Park on the market in January for $249,000, they were not unduly worried about selling it. Their target date for moving to St. Augustine, Fla., was June.

title: Arranging for Health Care Decisions
description: IN the event that you become physically or mentally incapacitated as a result of a catastrophic illness or accident, who will make your health care decisions?

title: Cornwall
description: To the Editor: I was most interested in ''Cornwall in the Winter'' by Paula Boyer Roughny (Feb. 23). I was disappointed she did not mention the Q memorial on the cliffs at Penleath Point in Fowey. Q, Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch, was a great Cornishman and his memorial is quite a landmark.

title: Ludlow Street Resists More Bars
description: Saturday night, or rather Sunday morning around 2 A.M., Matthew Curlewis heard a sound he said he had never heard since moving to Ludlow Street in 1989: ''Drunk guys yelling stupidity to one another.''

title: Oh, You Could Tell Her
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Opponents Jump to Use Admission About Addiction
description: Critics of the tobacco industry, along with lawyers representing both private citizens and states, have moved quickly to exploit the Liggett Group's dramatic decision to split from the rest of the tobacco industry and acknowledge that cigarettes are both hazardous and addictive.

title: Ham and Cheese on Oscar Night
description: REMEMBER the 1988 Academy Awards when the actor Rob Lowe, looking like a deer caught in the headlights, sang ''Proud Mary'' with a singer dressed as Snow White? (Disney sued.) Or 1972 when Sacheen Littlefeather showed up instead of Marlon Brando to read a statement about American Indian rights after the actor won an Oscar for ''The Godfather''? Or 1994 when David Letterman, the master of ceremonies, made so many awful jokes about people's names and physical attributes that Tom Hanks could be seen shaking his head in the audience?

title: Principal Retires in Fairfield
description: AFTER a nearly year-long, $175,000 test-tampering investigation that drew national attention and badly divided the Fairfield school community, the mystery of whether the Stratfield School principal, Roger Previs, tampered with standardized tests at his award-winning school may never be resolved.

title: Emelin To Offer 4 Plays In Summer
description: WHEN David Watson, a man with theater in his soul, took over as executive director of the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck in 1994, the first thing he had to cut back was theater.

title: Yankees Hope Bullpen Saved Some of Its Magic
description: The seemingly simple question went unanswered for a few moments, long enough for Mariano Rivera to register his doubts without opening his mouth. Rivera, the next John Wetteland, was asked whether the Yankee bullpen that will begin the season in 10 days is as formidable as the bullpen that led them to a World Series championship last October, and he hesitated.

title: Redesigning Society
description: To the Editor:

title: There Is No Chinese James Bond. So Far.
description: IN the spy-versus-spy atmosphere of the cold war, countless millions of readers everywhere followed the modern world's Great Game, both the reality of it and the fiction of it. The espionage business was -- is -- a culture, the culture of spying and spies, their codes, their honor or lack thereof, their secret victories, their spectacular failures, their wonderful gadgets and even their sexual dalliances out there on the edge.

title: After Preparation, Musical Celebrations Key Up for Easter
description: ENHANCING services with music week after week is not without challenge, most church music directors agree. But mounting a special holiday program that requires an 80-voice choir, vocal soloists and a 30-member orchestra can really raise the anxiety level.

title: Master Classes for High School Students
description: LIKE a basketball coach on the sideline, Jonathan Dinklage, a professional violinist, called out suggestions and encouragement as Elana Arian, 15, and Madeline Cavalieri, 17, students at Mamaroneck High School here, played Bach's Double Violin Concerto in D minor.

title: Blue Cross-Blue Shield Now Applies Overseas
description: The Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans have begun a program to enable many holders of their medical insurance to use selected hospitals in Europe, Japan, Israel and Mexico as if they were going to a hospital at home. Instead of the patient's paying the whole cost on departure and filing for reimbursement, the foreign hospital will bill the Blue Cross-Blue Shield plan directly and the patients will be responsible only for the extra charges they would pay at home: co-payments, noncovered services and deductibles.

title: At Peace, Guatemala Is Ready for Visitors
description: AFTER 36 years of civil war, this country, the largest in Central America, is finally and officially at peace. Under the terms of an armistice signed Dec. 29 that is being supervised by the United Nations, guerrillas and soldiers began demobilizing on March 3, making Maya ruins and Indian market towns that are in former zones of conflict once again accessible to tourists.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: UNSPEAKABLY BESPOKE
description: THE ULTRA-ELITE CUSTOM clothing emporium is suddenly spreading faster than an inkblot on a silk shirt. More gentleman's club than mere men's store, it pampers its well-heeled clientele with everything from catered Lucullan repasts to pedicures to limousine rides home. Extreme personal service, indeed. Where will it all end? Try these scenes on for size.

title: Lipinski, 14, Is Youngest World Champion
description: A year ago, it seemed unimaginable. A month ago, it was unlikely. Now it is unprecedented. In one of sport's most improbable victories, 14-year-old Tara Lipinski of Houston today became the youngest woman to win a world figure skating title.

title: In Pacific Race to Usher In Millennium, a Date-Line Jog

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE KOONING, WILLEM
description: DE KOONING - Willem. The Trustees and Staff of The Parrish Art Museum, Southampton, New York, join the international art community in mourning the loss of Willem de Kooning. His career spanned eight decades and saw the triumph of American painting in the world arena. His move to the eastern end of Long Island in the 1960s transformed his painting and made perceptible that light so distinct to this place. We extend our deepest sympathies to his daughter Lisa and her family. Mildred C. Brinn, Chairman Trudy C. Kramer, Director The Parrish Art Museum Southampton, New York

description: When the history books are written, if they are written in Hoboken, they will no doubt contend that the city gave America not only baseball and Frank Sinatra but also steam engines, Oreos, the America's Cup, draft beer and an early form of the zipper.

title: James Dickey, Size XL
description: James Dickey was a member of that puzzling and self-punishing tribe of American writers -- a tribe that included Hemingway, Faulkner and Robert Frost -- who wanted the public to think they were anything but artists. As Hemingway was the big-game hunter, Faulkner the gentleman farmer and rider to hounds, and Frost the cracker-barrel codger, so Jim Dickey worked hard to be taken for an archer, a country guitarist, a lady-killer or a Viking berserker stoked with mead. Anyone who spent more than two consecutive days in the Dickey presence, however, knew that -- at least as much as Hemingway, whose sensibility was as delicate as eggshell -- Dickey was an artist, a poet to the utter bone.

title: A New York Village Recalls Its Move Uphill
description: A hundred years ago New York City needed to enlarge its reservoir system and several Westchester villages were in the way. The residents of Katonah picked up and moved a half-mile south to higher ground. Mail was delivered to the relocated village for the first time on April 5, 1897. The ''new'' Katonah is starting its centennial celebrations on the 100th anniversary of that day.

title: Photographing A Mexico Where Silence Reigned
description: ART IN THE 20TH CENTURY devised several new vocabularies, some of which changed the way we saw our surroundings. Cubism, abstraction and Surrealism looked like entirely new modes of representation belonging more to imagination than to vision. But in fact they had any number of correspondences in the daily world. The urban, industrial environment turned out to be rife with abstraction, and modern life was quickly understood to be suffused with surrealism. Few had noticed that before; it was art that made such things visible.

description: While cramped commuters on the No. 7 IRT train will receive some long-awaited relief this month when full express service is resumed, local politicians and riders are grumbling that riders will be squeezed again this summer when the Transit Authority cuts back on service.

title: The Green Book, Long Delayed, Speaks Volumes
description: Rifle through the desk of any pencil-pushing bureaucrat, plugged-in lobbyist or muckraking reporter and you're bound to find a slim faux green-leather-bound book crammed with the names, office phone numbers and salaries of thousands of New York City officials. Since it was first published in 1918, The Green Book, as it is now called, has been an indispensable tool for navigating City Hall and its ever-changing cast of deputy mayors, commissioners and press secretaries.

title: When You Come to the Fork in the Road, Paint It: The Yogi Berra of Art
description: WILLEM DE KOONING, the Abstract Expressionist best known for his furious paintings of women grinning like hellcats, died at the age of 92 on Wednesday morning in East Hampton, L.I. Mr. de Kooning, a native of Rotterdam, moved to New York in 1926, expecting to find no art at all in this country. He was mostly right. By the 1950's, though, he, along with Jackson Pollock, Franz Kline, Mark Rothko and Clyfford Still, created a modern American art that came to be called Abstract Expressionism. Mr. de Kooning became an icon, and not just for his painting. He was boyish, charismatic, witty, slippery and handsome, with shiny blue eyes. He drank like a fish. And in his thick Dutch accent, he would talk about anything. At times, he sounded like Wittgenstein. And at times like Yogi Berra. Here are excerpts from his writings and interviews. SARAH BOXER

The secret is strong colors, clean patterns and trim lines, which work whether you're making waves in a speedboat or simply biking around town. Beyond T-shirts, this season offers collared V-necks and even classic polos, which are back in style with a slimmer fit. Stripes are preferred, often in colors that might seem a bit over the top in a more serious setting. Look for red, lime, yellow and chartreuse, along with a range of blues.

The laminated chart contains graphic symbols representing 15 basic patient needs and figures of the human body for pinpointing problems. Using the chart, patients could point out their needs to staff, family and friends. Professor Robbins, (212) 724 3844, sells Talkcharts mainly to nursing homes and other institutions.

title: I Want You to Want Me
description: On Wednesday ''The Big Picture,'' the first novel by Douglas Kennedy, arrives in stores. Never heard of it? You will. A thriller about a photographer on the run from his homicidal past, the novel is getting a $750,000 promotional send-off -- not much compared with what Hollywood spends, but a huge amount for a debut novelist. It will be peddled coast to coast, on everything from billboards to commuter trains to Cineplex Odeons 807 movie screens. These efforts -- the ''sell-through,'' the industry term for selling a book to the public -- are only the most visible parts of the story, though. First came the ''sell-in,'' a long, prepublication hype siege designed to convince bookstores to order a lot ofcopies. Here are highlights from the campaign you never saw.

We love to hate the Hubbards in ''The Little Foxes'' as we did the fiendish little liar of ''The Children's Hour.'' Indeed, so skillfully does Hellman allocate the vices among Ben, Regina, Oscar and Leo that we almost take sides in their internecine strife. Ben and Regina, for example, have power and style in their wickedness; it is hard not to be gratified when they combine to cheat the sneaky Oscar and the whining Leo.

title: A Polymath, At 80, Tries To Simplify

He has become fluent in Esperanto and American sign language; he has developed an exquisite calligraphic style, and he continues to paint and to write poetry.

title: Locked Out

title: Sailing a Hotel Barge Under a Loire Chateau

By restoring eight 18th-century locks, the French Government is reopening the Cher to commercial traffic, and the barge company plans to truck its newly refurbished six-passenger, 80-foot-long barge overland on April 23 from Nevers in Burgundy to St. Agnan on the Cher.

title: A Family Assembled, in All Its Complex Linkages and Contrasts
description: THE title ''All in a Family,'' sends a signal to look for off-the-canvas dynamics. The show with that name at the New Britain Museum of American Art is, thankfully, mainly about esthetic relationships but it does encourage speculation about how artists in close physical and psychological proximity must interrelate.
