title: World of 'The Godfather': No Place for Women
description: IN THE FAMOUS ENDING OF ''The Godfather,'' Francis Ford Coppola's grandly mournful 1972 gangster epic, Diane Keaton's Kay, having been lied to by her husband, Michael (Al Pacino), about his business (the murder of their brother-in-law), leaves his study, shaky but smiling, to fix herself a drink.

title: In His Father's Large Shadow, a Tiepolo Romped
description: FEW VISITORS TO THE Metropolitan Museum in recent weeks seem able to summon the energy to take on two Tiepolos in a single afternoon. But the stalwarts who do find their way to the Robert Lehman Wing are rewarded with an unheralded but revelatory exhibition, ''Domenico Tiepolo: Drawings, Prints and Paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art,'' devoted to the work of Giambattista Tiepolo's little-known son and artistic heir. Often dismissed as a charming pasticheur of his father's grand manner, Domenico Tiepolo (1727-1804) emerges through this exhibition as something quite different: witty and fanciful, certainly, but also humane and occasionally sublime.

title: Domination, Submission and the Chevy Suburban
description: MOST people have heard the rationalizations offered by buyers of Chevrolet Suburbans, Ford Expeditions and other gigantic sport utility vehicles: They want to look over the surrounding cars to spot and avoid traffic hazards ahead. They truly need to be ready for weeklong blizzards or car-eating potholes. They may someday take a camping vacation in the Rockies and find themselves at the end of 20 miles of dirt roads in a rainstorm -- really.

title: The Next Wave

description: NEWMAN-Arthur Andrew, 92, June 14, 1904-March 12, 1997. Died peacefully at home in New Mexico. Preceded by his wife of sixty-two years, Judith and son Lionel. Loved by his daughter Corinne and Stanley Shaftel, granddaughters Lynda and Martin Rothstein, Lisa Shaftel, Amy and Brian Trubee, great-grandchildren Jed and Abbey Rothstein, Robert and Philip Trubee, sisters: Lynne Snyder and Kitty Shnapier. Arthur enjoyed two successful careers: Andrew A. Newman Fine Dry Cleaning and as stockbroker with Fahnestock. He lived in Forest Hills, New York and Bal Harbour, FL. As patriach of the Newman's, he hosted many special family functions. Always a gentleman, he was loved and respected by all.

title: The Objects of Princeton Alumni's Desires
description: SOME art exhibitions have a story to tell; others have a point to make. Every once in a while, one comes along in which the works were chosen for no other reason than that they are very good. If the selection is made with a sharp eye, these can be some of the most pleasurable exhibitions of all: the art gets to tell its own stories, make its own points.

title: Proposal for 80 Subsidized Town Houses Opposed in Moriches
description: A PLAN to build 80 subsidized town houses is upsetting Moriches residents, who say their area is flooded with affordable rentals and the school district is stressed because of transient students.

title: The Last Supper, Seen Six Ways
description: WHEN I was 9 years old, I painted the Last Supper. I did it on the dining room table at our home in Connecticut on Saturday afternoon while my mother ironed clothes and hummed along with the Texaco-Metropolitan Opera live radio broadcast. It took me three months to paint the Last Supper, but when I finished and hung it on my mother's bedroom wall, she assured me it looked just like Leonardo da Vinci's painting. It was supposed to. You can't go very wrong with a paint-by-numbers picture, and even though I didn't always stay within the lines and sometimes got the colors wrong, the experience left me with a profound respect for Leonardo's achievement and a lingering attachment to the genre.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, the last two words were omitted from an article last Sunday about the London theater. The last sentence should have read: ''The Royal Shakespeare Company may be leaving London for the summer, but a piece of it is staying behind.''

description: THE Home Depot wants to open a store here, and so far, the effort has taken five years, been the subject of dozens of hearings and generated multiple lawsuits, which involve at least 10 law firms.

title: Albania Is Cast Adrift
description: WHEN James A. Baker 3d visited this dilapidated capital as the American Secretary of State six years ago, hundreds of thousands of Albanians thronged the streets, and those who could get close enough kissed his car. While here, Mr. Baker met with the opposition leader Sali Berisha, a tall, ruddy-faced heart surgeon with leonine hair and a tempestuous personality who had been anointed as the man Washington would do business with.

title: SORRY, THE PROFESSIONAL CLASS IS FULL
description: I enjoyed Don J. Snyder's personal essay ''Sorry, the Professional Class Is Full'' (March 2). One feels that Snyder now knows something about the way the world works, which oddly enough makes him more qualified to teach literature than he had been. Whether he can find a university in this country to respect that fact is doubtful, but I wish him all the best in trying.

title: God Is My Co-Counsel
description: ''He didn't need a lawyer,'' says Jay Sekulow, chief counsel of the American Center for Law and Justice, contemplating Jesus' trial and crucifixion. ''He chose to remain silent for the redemption of mankind.''

title: Two Seasoned Voices, Together Raised for a Cause
description: SUBTLETY HAS RARELY BEEN less in vogue among singers of popular music. Rock vocalists in the post-Nirvana world prize ferocity over finesse -- the edgier the emotion and the raspier the tone, the better. Country singers climb the charts with the clean efficiency of professionals ascending the corporate ladder, their music's rural roots a dim memory at best, a nostalgic fantasy at worst. And mainstream pop and rhythm-and-blues are mostly studies in overstatement, exploiting every formula and mining sentimentality.

title: The Ballet of the Concrete Golfer ...
description: IT was a beautiful spring Saturday morning as I rode uptown on the First Avenue bus to do rounds at the hospital. I was feeling depressed and sorry for myself as I stared out the grimy window at the pavement and the endless line of towering buildings.

title: When a Justice Needs a Friend

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASDON, MILDRED
description: LASDON-Mildred. Cornell University mourns the passing of a beloved friend and benefactor. Mrs. Lasdon and her late husband William S. Lasdon, are recognized and remembered for their devoted support of medical research and education at the Cornell University Medical College, where the William and Mildred Lasdon Biomedical Research Center, the Stanley S. Lasdon Teaching Laboratories, and the Nanette Laitman Distinguished Professorship in Public Health are among their many legacies. Mrs. Lasdon's abiding commitment to ease the pain of those touched by illness and disease through the application of medical research and education to patient treatment and care stands as an inspiration to all. We extend our deepest sympathy to Mrs. Lasdon's children, Nanette and Robert, to the entire Lasdon family, and we share their loss. Stephen H. Weiss Chair, Board of Trustees Hunter R. Rawlings III President, Cornell University

title: TRAVELING LIGHT
description: As the temperature starts to climb, the desire to wear a serious suit wanes. Fortunately, this spring there is another, more practical course to follow. Designers have come up with a vast array of suits in pale to medium tones and, still more important, in lightweight, predominantly cotton cloth. With the emergence of this trend, traditionalists can take heart, since two of the most classic American summer fabrics are center stage: seersucker and khaki cotton twill.

title: Pillage as Protest
description: When calm returns, Albanians will have to rebuild their country not just politically, but physically. They did not just protest after the collapse of the pyramid schemes that took the vast majority of the country's savings. They razed and looted. They set fire to the library at the main agricultural university, burning 150,000 books. They torched buildings considered historical treasures. They destroyed not only the symbols of a hated Government, but also their own achievements and patrimony.

title: Snap, Snap, Snap
description: To the Editor: Only another traveling camera junkie could fully appreciate Margot Kaufman's hysterical ''Snap, Snap, Snap.'' I even have the very same camera (OM2)! And, I just visited our 17 photo albums to find my version of the ''two kittens emerging from a terra cotta urn'' carefully framed with the romantic hills of Positano in the background.

title: Some Investors Just Won't Deal Without the Net
description: BRUCE BENNETT would rather spend his money on fishing equipment than on commissions for his stock trades. That's why Mr. Bennett, a fourth-year medical student at the University of Mississippi, has used three different brokerage firms in the last year. Interestingly, those three firms share another trait besides cheap deals: they all offer trading over the Internet.

title: M.L.S. Set to Build on First-Year Success
description: Major League Soccer has taken several steps to build on the considerable success it enjoyed in its inaugural season last year. Rabid supporters even point to the players' antitrust lawsuit, which charges that the league tried to unjustly keep down salaries, as evidence that professional soccer has established itself in the American sports mainstream. After all, what sports league worthy of its salt isn't full of salary controversy and litigious fervor?

title: Patterns Of Crime
description: Bucking a regional and possibly a national trend, violent crime in Connecticut rose slightly in 1996, according preliminary data. The violent crime rate -- that is, the number of murders, rapes, robberies and aggravated assaults per 100,000 residents -- increased by 1.5 percent last year although the total since 1990 is down 26 percent. Connecticut remains much safer than the nation as a whole. A look at how the towns and cities compare. Page. 12.

title: City Will Limit Concert Vendors At Grant's Tomb
description: In a move intended to reduce rowdiness around Grant's Tomb, the Parks Department says it will drastically cut the number of vendors allowed to sell their wares at the Jazzmobile summer concerts to two concession trucks from 100 peddlers. ''We had a number of problems with the vendors last year,'' said the Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern. ''They stayed open after the 9 o'clock deadline and as a result there were a number of incidents and the city cleaning crew had to work until 2 in the morning.''

title: Business District Looking to Stretch Its Boundaries
description: Three years after its formation, the 125th Street Business Improvement District, which runs from Fifth Avenue to Morningside Avenue, has received a grant to study whether to expand its boundaries to Second Avenue and 12th Avenue.

title: Two Generations of M.D.'s Talk About the State of Medicine
description: THERE are few places Dr. Herbert Chessin can go without running into one of the thousands of patients he has cared for over the years. They have stopped to say hello near a pool in Bermuda, at a restaurant in Antigua and on the streets of London. Dr. Chessin, an obstetrician and gynecologist, started practicing medicine during the dawn of the baby boom era. He helped organize the first gynecology and obstetrics department at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City and delivered the hospital's first set of twins and of triplets. In 1953 he started a solo practice in Long Island. There he set his own fees, sometimes on a sliding scale because few people had insurance at the time. He eventually delivered many of his early patients' grandchildren. By 1992, Dr. Chessin had delivered 14,000 babies.

title: A Sinking Ship Whose Star Never Sets
description: AT LEAST THEY WENT DOWN WELL FED. By the time the Titanic's stern tipped sickeningly upright, then plummeted to the ocean floor, the first-class passengers had made their way through a gastronomic decathlon that began with canapes or oysters a la russe, reached midpoint with a Calvados-glazed duckling, and wound up with chocolate eclairs, cognac and cigars. It is all lovingly evoked in ''Last Dinner on the Titanic,'' a history and cookbook, to be published next month by Hyperion, that lavishes a lot more care on the ship's restaurants than the White Star Line did on lifeboats. For gourmands, too, April 14, 1912, remains a night to remember.

title: EXECUTIVE MENDACITY
description: 1. If bad Presidents are interesting, loathsome Presidents must be fascinating that, anyway, is the premise of a forthcoming novel that stars a devilish chief exec. 2. In First Victim, by Douglas MacKinnon, President Turner Ryan beats his wife on election night. She trumps him later by burying a trophy in his skull. 3. Such books are a modern tradition. In last years Exclusive, by Sandra Brown, the First Lady is drugged into a stupor at the behest of ... guess who? 4. The Multiple Man (1976) features a President who clones seven versions of himself, and then starts rubbing them out. 5. Do these novels say something fundamental? Presidents have become antiheroes, says Richard Norton Smith, the director of the Gerald R. Ford Library and Museum. From there its a short step to fiend.

title: AN AMERICAN EXILE IN AMERICA
description: The difficulties described by Vivian Gornick (''An American Exile in America,'' March 2) related to politically relevant theater in this country today are sadly reminiscent of the experiences of many actors and writers during the Depression. As former members of the Workers Laboratory Theater, we remember vividly how truly perceptive and anxious the English were to read and use our agitprop and play materials. Paul Robeson, the great actor-singer, gave up many profitable concert engagements to work in a London workers' theater production of our pro-sit-in strike comedy, ''Plant in the Sun.''

title: REX-IN-WAITING
description: Now that enraged Albanian citizens -- who recently lost $1.5 billion in failed pyramid schemes -- have effectively demolished their Government in an ongoing display of anarchy, they might want to consider restoring their monarchy. Ready, as always, is His Majesty King Leka I, who was but 2 days old when his father, King Zog, fled the country in 1939 before Mussolinis advancing horde. Leka is all grown up now (he's 6 foot 8) and living in exile in South Africa. He declined to be interviewed, but did forward a recent proclamation urging his people not to despair -- and letting them know he's available. ''I cannot give you back your money,'' writes Leka, ''but I can give you back your country.''

As the administrator of Goldwater Memorial Hospital, I would like to note that for decades Goldwater has been providing high quality diagnostic and therapeutic treatment for its long-term and rehabilitative patients and residents. The term incurrable, which was used in your article to describe some of our patient population, is not a term recognized by our staff; we continue to be a place where each patient or resident is helped to reach his or her highest practicable level of function. In most instances, patients and residents return to the community with greater ability, confidence and autonomy.

The church, faced with overcrowding, sought a permit to demolish most of its 74-year-old Mission Revival structure and expand into Boerne's historic district. When the permit was denied, the church sued the town, alleging a violation of its religious freedom under a Federal statute called the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. The city responded by challenging the act's constitutionality, raising the core issue that the Court must now decide.

He volunteered his time to cultural institutions, and avidly pursued a lifelong love of music, art, history and languages. title: OUR AFRICA
description: Reading ''Our Africa,'' I was reminded of a 1972 bus trip from Benin City to Lagos in Nigeria. The bus broke down, and I asked the driver what the problem was. He told me that he could probably start the bus if we all pushed it. ''Well, why don't you ask the people to push?'' I asked. ''Oh, they'll never push if I ask,'' he said. So I asked everyone to try to push the bus at once; we all did, and it started. That is what Africa needs today -- a push, not mere aid or money.

I said be brave my darling. You cannot leave me now. It broke my heart to lose you, but you did not go alone. For part of me went with you, the day God called you home. If I could have a lifetime wish a dream that could come true, I'd pray to God with all my heart for yesterdays and you. You gave me many things in life treasures great and small but most of all you gave me love the greatest gift of all. Though heaven and earth divide us and the distance seems a lot there is a flower that grows between us it's a sweet forget-me-not. Someday I hope to see again the one I love so well Someday I'll clasp that loving hand never say farewell. Sadly missed by your loving wife SHEILA

title: Winning Words
description: ''The English Patient'' is a strong favorite in the Academy Awards tonight, but to some literate viewers the real winners are (pass the envelopes, please) the creators, judges and recipients of the Booker Prize for fiction, the most interesting of its kind. In the past few years, film versions of three Bookers -- ''The Remains of the Day,'' ''Schindler's List'' and ''The English Patient'' -- were nominated as best picture, and ''Schindler's List'' won. What makes this especially interesting is that winners of the Booker Prize are for the most part not household names and their novels tend to deal with difficult, depressing and unformulaic subjects that would stop a conversation in Beverly Hills.

Planet Hollywood said Planet Hoboken would face legal action unless it stopped using the name by today.

description: Zaire's ailing President, Mobutu Sese Seko, made his first public appearance today since he returned home on Friday, promising to unite his shattering country.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sophomores Spring Eternal In Gophers' Powerful Blend
description: To reach the Final Four, experience says, a team needs experience. It needs seniors. Rugged warriors who have toiled in the trenches, who have trudged through the emotional waves of great highs and sullen lows. Seniors to take the big shot or make the big block. Seniors -- they are more likely to handle the moment.

title: Gunman Kills Woman and Himself in Apartment
description: A man fatally shot his estranged girlfriend inside her Inwood apartment early yesterday and then killed himself in front of the woman's teen-age daughter and 2-year-old son, the police said.

title: Redefining Drunken Driving
description: The Law and Public Safety Committee in the State Senate is scheduled today to consider a bill that would lower the threshold for what is considered drunken driving.

Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York had handled those duties for six years until that agency and the division agreed to part ways in mid-January.

description: Funeral homes would be required to treat the fluids drained from bodies before discharging them into sewer lines, under a bill up for a vote before the State Senate Law and Public Safety Committee today.

title: Bill Clinton's Moment on Myanmar
description: The decision whether to apply sanctions to Myanmar for its human rights abuses now rests with President Clinton. Last July, Congress passed a law calling for a ban on new American investment in Myanmar if that country's repressive Government harmed or rearrested the democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi or cracked down on the democracy movement. The President's top foreign-policy advisers are divided. For the sake not only of democracy in Myanmar, but also of American credibility when dealing with other dictatorial regimes, President Clinton should invoke the law.

title: CHRONICLE

The one offered by the Metropolitan Opera has the visual style of 1940's Disney, much grayed with age. Its antiquity, though, accords well with the projection of the opera as a period piece: a testimony to bygone taste and an occasion for excellent performances, of which the current revival has a couple.

He looks at the sagging buildings that used to house grocery stores, clothing shops, a pizza parlor and like a mantra he utters the obvious: ''Empty. Boarded up. Empty. Boarded up.''

He is survived by two sons, Dr. Anthony J. Policastro and Ronald J. Policastro, M.D. and four grandchildren, Matthew, Amanda, Richard, and Edward. title: Census Contract Awarded
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation have received a $49 million contract to design and support a data-capturing system for the United States Census Bureau, the companies said today. Under the six-year agreement with the Commerce Department, the companies will supply equipment and services for a document imaging system that will digitally capture information from completed census forms in the year 2000. The system will reduce data-collection costs while increasing accuracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPOVIC, TATYANA

title: MAGIN ENERGY TO OFFER $58.5 MILLION FOR DISCOVERY WEST
description: Magin Energy Inc. said yesterday that it planned to acquire the Discovery West Corporation for about $58.5 million in cash and stock and $10.2 million in assumed debt. Magin, of Calgary, Alberta, said that the acquisition of Discovery West, of Toronto, would increase its daily production to more than 7,100 barrels of oil. Magin said the offer, which it expects to make April 11, would be subject to a minimum of two-thirds of Discovery's shares being tendered. Rayrock Yellowknife Resources Inc., which holds 38.9 percent of Discovery, has agreed to the offer. Magin Energy and Discovery West are oil and gas companies. Rayrock Yellowknife, of Toronto, is a mining company.

description: Gore to Endorse Deals To Expand China Trade

title: In a Sealed Lab, A Warrior Against Pollution
description: DR. JOANN M. BURKHOLDER looked into the television monitor attached to a powerful microscope. Before her, a swarm of tiny killers swam into view. ''Oooo, look at all those,'' she said as the microbes darted by the dozen across a glass slide covered with human blood and attacked the red cells, sucking them dry.

This town was the birthplace of atomic energy in Japan -- site of the country's first research reactor and first commercial nuclear power plant -- but in the future it might be remembered more as a place where Japan's nuclear ambitions took a severe blow.

Before there was the paradigm of the computer tycoon in khaki pants, Bill Gates, there was the I.B.M. pinstripe suit. And in the 80's, when women had only the pretense of power, there were padded shoulders, sharp suits and hard makeup for aspirants smashed under the glass ceiling trying to pretend they had a shot at the top.

title: ESSEF AGREES TO PAY $68 MILLION FOR GENERAL AQUATICS
description: The Essef Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy General Aquatics Inc., a privately held maker of swimming pools, equipment and accessories, for about $68 million. Essef said General Aquatics, of Moorpark, Calif., had sales of $166 million for the year ended Dec. 31. Essef, based in Chardon, Ohio, makes engineered-plastic products that move, store and treat water. The company had sales of $200.9 million for the year ended Sept. 30.

title: Roche Holding Profit Climbed 16% Last Year
description: Roche Holding A.G., based in Basel, Switzerland, reported yesterday that its profit rose 16 percent in 1996 to 3.90 billion Swiss francs ($2.67 billion) from 3.37 billion, just under many analysts' forecasts of a rise of 17 to 18 percent. The company also announced a planned increase of 17 percent in the annual dividend to 75 Swiss francs ($51.47) a share from 64 the year before. Roche, however, failed to say anything about a rumored repurchase of some of its dividend-right certificate equity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIGERMAN, ALAN
description: KLIGERMAN-Alan. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Repairing Lives Torn by the Past
description: COMFORT WOMAN

title: Saudi Prince to Buy 6 of 8 Princess Hotels
description: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has agreed to buy six of the eight hotels in the Princess chain of Lonrho P.L.C. for almost $600 million, a spokesman for the prince said yesterday. The hotels will be managed by the prince's Fairmont Hotels chain, according to the spokesman, who was in Saudi Arabia.

title: Mets Make Reed No. 5 In Starting Rotation
description: Rick Reed got great news today, learning he was all but assured of being the Mets' No. 5 starter and pitching against San Francisco on April 5.

title: New Chief Named At Unit of Havas
description: Bob Schmetterer, a managing partner at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive at the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising.

title: INTEL'S PURCHASE OF A STAKE IN AVID SENDS STOCK UP 21%
description: The shares of Avid Technology Inc. rose 21 percent yesterday after the Intel Corporation bought a stake in Avid, a software maker. The shares rose $2 to close at $11.50 in trading of nearly 1.5 million shares. Intel shares declined 12.5 cents, to $130.625. Intel's purchase of the 6.75 percent stake comes after two years of declining earnings at Avid, which is based in Tewksbury, Mass., and makes video editing software and systems. Intel, whose chips power 85 percent of the world's personal computers, is betting that Avid's products will benefit as more corporations and consumers use video clips as part of their everyday computing.

title: British Payments Surplus In Last Quarter of '96
description: Britain's balance of payments in the fourth quarter of 1996 showed a seasonally adjusted current account surplus of $:873 million ($1.4 billion), in contrast to a revised deficit of $:293 million in the previous quarter, the Office for National Statistics said yesterday. The third-quarter deficit had been reported as $:71 million.

She will be sorely missed and fondly remembered. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her husband, David; her daughter, Sarah, and to all her family. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, New York 10601.

Mother of six, Harold, Irene Weinberg, Harriet Miller, Sylvia Schulman and the late Albert and Martin. Grandmother of twenty-two, great grandmother of nineteen. title: Misapplying the Voting Rights Act
description: The Voting Rights Act of 1965 assigns the Justice Department a major role in protecting the rights of minorities in the electoral process. But the department lost sight of its mission last week when it held up approval of hard-won changes in the governance of New York City's public schools approved last December by the State Legislature.

title: The 'System' The N.F.L. Must Change
description: WHEN the St. Louis Rams were looking for a new coach two months ago, Johnny Roland deserved to be interviewed.

title: A Hybrid 'St. Matthew Passion' With a Bicameral Chorus
description: Storytellers give us people, places and events and leave the listener to imagine what they look like. Theater provides intermediaries to imagine for us: a casting director who will make the features of a protagonist the same for everyone, a set designer to fix the dimensions of a space or the colors of a wall.

title: Y.& R. Promotes Two Executives
description: The New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising yesterday promoted two top executives.

title: The Dance of Death Inside the Body
description: To describe ''Death by Design'' as an elaborately illustrated lecture on the body's cells is to do small justice to this intelligent and imaginative work. The inventively choreographed images are essential complements to what the on-camera scientists from several countries are telling us about the endless sacrifice of individual cells for the good of the larger organism.

title: UConn's Season Ends, a Week Short of Perfection
description: No perfect season for Connecticut. No national championship for the women's basketball team ranked No. 1 in the nation for the last three months. No anything except heartbreak for a team that had known little adversity all season.

title: Insecure or Jobless, Europeans Renew Protests
description: Worker unrest is resuming in much of Europe as hundreds of thousands of people take to the streets, driven by the fear of job losses, social-welfare spending cuts and a growing sense of financial insecurity.

title: Graham Hawks, Physician and Professor, 85
description: Dr. Graham Hawks, an obstetrician and gynecologist at Cornell University Medical College for many years, died on Feb. 15 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Regions Defy Yeltsin to Start Talk of a More Perfect Union
description: Ask most Russians about this grimy old center for gunsmiths and ironmongers and you can expect a long, blank stare. Few know it was once a mighty seat of war: the thunderous cannon that drove Napoleon from Russia were made here, and in time the city's factories graduated to the Kalashnikov rifle and the ballistic missile.

title: With Poulenc's Continuity Added to Gounod's Arias
description: Modernism comes in great waves, which break. In 1923, only a decade after ''The Rite of Spring,'' it seemed to Diaghilev that what the future now demanded from him was the revival of three minor operas by Gounod, which he gave to three French composers who were working for his company, for them to set the spoken passages that had originally separated the songs. Poulenc got ''La Colombe.'' On Wednesday night at Tully Hall, we got it too, in his version, from L'Opera Francais de New York.

title: Tenant Is Held In Explosion At Apartment
description: A man who had a years-long feud with his neighbors over noises they made was charged yesterday with setting an explosion that blew out his own apartment, left most of his immediate neighbors homeless and resulted in injuries to 20 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAKO, NICHOLAS
description: CHAKO-Nicholas, died after a short illness on March 18 at age 86. Devoted husband and father, surviving are his wife of 46 years, Bernardine, and son Alexander and family. Born in Epirus, he came to the United States in 1929, earned a Ph.D. in mathematics from Johns Hopkins in 1934, and Dr. des Sciences avec Honours from the Sorbonne in 1966. He made major contributions to the theory of diffraction in lenses and organic materials. He was a member of American Mathematics and Physics Associations and internationally sought lecturer. Worked with OHSS, Signal Corps, and NASA and then spent the last 28 years as professor of mathematics at NYU and Queens College until 1981. True gentleman and scholar, who will be missed.

title: A State Budget. Guess What. It's Late Again (No Surprise).
description: One week before the end of the state's fiscal year, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders conceded today that the state budget will be late for the 13th consecutive year because they remain far apart on a number of issues. And they agreed to extend the current budget until May 9 to buy themselves time to negotiate a full-year spending plan.

title: Variable annuities boomed. Will their providers do as well?
description: YOU'VE probably already heard the pitch for one of the hottest investment vehicles around: variable annuities. They promise to blend the advantages of a mutual fund with a tiny life insurance policy so you can defer Federal taxes on all the gains until retirement. The assets held in variable annuities have soared from less than $10 billion in 1989 to more than $500 billion today.

title: Rockefeller Center Lease Is Signed By Christie's
description: Christie's signed a 30-year lease yesterday for space in Rockefeller Center for an undisclosed figure. The auction house, increasingly cramped for space, signed the agreement with RCPI Trust, the owners of Rockefeller Center. After more than two years of searching for a larger space in Manhattan, Christie's will move its New York headquarters from Park Avenue and 59th Street to 20 Rockefeller Plaza, a new address that will have its entrance on 49th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, HAZZAN SAMUEL
description: ROSENBAUM-Hazzan Samuel''Nafla Ateret Rosheinu...the crown of our head has fallen...'' The entire membership of the Cantors Assembly mourns the loss of its beloved Executive Vice President of more than four decades and the Cantor Emeritus of Temple Beth El of Rochester, New York. Since 1959, he served as the Executive Vice President of the Cantors Assembly, the largest organization of cantors in the world. He labored untiringly and was successful in elevating the status and role of the Cantor in Jewish worship. He was deeply involved in winning four landmark court cases to gain recognition for the Cantor as a Clergyperson. As past President, officer, and member of the Cantors Assembly since its inception, he is responsible for much of the organization's innovative programs and growth. An author, poet, and visionary, Hazzan Rosenbaum was particularly well known for his moving texts to more than a dozen major musical works presented on radio and television. His translations of Yiddish poetry and folk songs earned high praise. He authored four text books that are in wide use in Jewish religious schools across the country. He lectured extensively on Jewish music, culture and folklore. His works include ''Yizkor: In Memory of the Six Million'', an oratorio presented on ABC Television with Richard Tucker and Howard da Silva that received an Emmy nomination in 1973; ''The Last Judgement'', an oratorio with music by Lazar Weiner, presented on CBS Television; ''Stars in the Dust'', a commemorative composition of the 50th anniversary of Krystal Nacht; and ''Ever Since Babylon'', marking the 500th anniversary of Columbus' first voyage to America and the expulsion of the Jews from Spain. Numerous solo and choral works and four Holiday recordings, narrated and written by Hazzan Rosenbaum, comprise another segment of his creativity. He was managing Editor of the Assembly's ''Journal of Synagogue Music'', consultant to the ''Prayer Book Press'' and author of ''A Yiddish Word Book for English Speaking People''. He was a graduate of New York University and of the Herzliah Hebrew Teachers College. He studied music and voice privately and prepared for the Cantorate under Cantor Jacob Beimel and Cantor Adolph Katchko. Cantor Rosenbaum was granted a Doctor of Music Degree, honoris causa, by the Jewish Theological Seminary in May 1985 and received three Cantors Assembly Kavod Awards for originality and variety in Jewish music programming. At the time of his demise, he was writing a major commentary to the High Holiday Prayer Book entitled ''Machzor 101''. We lift our ''Kos Tanchumim-Cup of Consolation'' to his beloved wife, Ina, and to his children Judy (and Thomas) Witt, Michael Rosenbaum , and David Rosenbaum, and to his grandchildren Abigail, Daniel and Adam. Hazzan Abraham Lubin, President Hazzan Abraham Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Torre Puts a Premium on Kelly's Defense
description: The hints just keep on coming. Manager Joe Torre is making it obvious that he wants Pat Kelly, the prodigal Yankee, on the roster because he wants a defensively sound second baseman available behind his talented pitchers. Kelly's rise could signal Tim Raines's fall.

title: INSIDE
description: Attack on Health Care Fraud

title: Investigation May Alter Photran Results
description: The Photran Corporation said today that it was investigating possible financial and accounting irregularities that might force it to restate financial results for last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, RHEA (NEE RAGOVIN)
description: LEVINSON-Rhea (nee Ragovin). Wife of the late Louis A. Levinson, died on March 22, in Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved mother of Floren Shivitz, Irwin Levinson, mother-inlaw to David Shivitz and Dede Levinson. Dearest grandmother of Stefanie Roth, Richard and Ren Roth, Lori and Carl Stewart, Barbara and Wayne Maultsby. Many nieces and nephews. A former World War II Red Cross Ambulance Driver, Rhea was also involved in numerous philanthropic activities. title: The Beat, Beat, Beat of the Drums
description: The six-man group Percussions de Strasbourg was founded in 1962, and is therefore probably older than any of its present members. Clearly the career of a Strasbourg percussionist is short, as short as that of a gymnast, and for similar reasons. Like a gymnastics team, these people run into action, perform with peak precision and energy on their array of equipment in polished metal and wood, and run off again. Watching them operate is part of the game. Even before they come on, the stage full of gleaming possibilities -- drums of different shapes, sizes and colours, groups of suspended gongs -- has set one up for an experience that is as much visual as aural.

title: IDEXX STOCK PLUNGES $20 A SHARE ON EARNINGS OUTLOOK
description: The stock of Idexx Labs Inc. lost a sizable part of its value yesterday after the company, a diagnostic-products concern, said its first-quarter profits would be far below analysts' expectations. Idexx, based in Westbrook, Me., said it expected to earn 2 cents to 5 cents a share for the quarter ending March 31, compared with 18 cents a share in the corresponding period a year earlier. Analysts had predicted earnings of 21 cents a share. Idexx attributed the decline in part to weak sales of veterinary diagnostic products and to its decision to slow shipments to distributors to reduce inventories. Idexx's shares plummeted $20 each, to $12, as more than 22 million shares changed hands.

title: A Long Run of Misfortune
description: When Dick Beardsley, a former marathon champion, ventures out to the wilderness trails that surround his home in northwest Minnesota, he inhales the crisp air, listens for wolves and moose and proceeds to do an hour's worth of snowshoeing, his daily workout. He counts every day, every minute of peace, as a blessing. He wonders if he will be a runner again.

title: The Yankee Analysts Do Play by Play, Too
description: Study the roster of the Yankees' television announcers -- Jim Kaat, Ken Singleton, Bobby Murcer, Al Trautwig, Rick Cerone, Suzyn Waldman and Steve Palermo -- and you will discover the absence of a full-time play-by-play voice. No one from the lineage of Mel Allen, which was continued solidly by Frank Messer and Dewayne Staats and poorly by (oh no!) Bob Gamere. For the past two seasons, the MSG Network had Dave Cohen; for the last few, Channel 11 had Paul Olden.

title: Mysterious Images, With Hints of Death
description: The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble, a junior company of professional-level graduates of the Ailey school, has become an entity in itself over 23 years of existence. Its well-trained young members have the dynamic performing skills of far older and more experienced dancers. The company also serves as an incubator of new dance and new choreographic ideas. And all that came together in an provocative yet problematical program presented on Saturday night at Davis Hall of City College.

title: CUNY Trustees Vote to Hire Own Staff
description: In a move that reflects the split between the trustees of the City University of New York and the university's administration, the trustees yesterday approved a budget of up to $1 million to finance their own research, auditing, management consultants and legal counsel.

description: * National Association of Home Builders, Washington, to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore and Washington, as its first agency. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Wendy Moore, 29; Created Wall Hangings
description: Wendy Moore, an artist whose work ranged from installation sculptures to computer-manipulated photographs and drawings, died on Saturday in a hospital in Cleveland. She was 29 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Albert Key, 71, Broker, Dies; Led Historical Society in 80's
description: Albert Lenoir Key, a stockbroker and former investment banker who, as a trustee, president and chairman, helped steer the New-York Historical Society through its heaviest turbulence in the 1980's, died on Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 71 and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Lawmaker Proposes New Prayer Amendment
description: For the third time, religious conservatives are mounting an effort in Congress to pass a ''religious freedom'' amendment to the Constitution that would explicitly assert the right to pray and display religious symbols in public places, including public schools.

title: A Peek at the Minuscule
description: Scientists striving to master the minuscule have added another instrument to their Lilliputian toolboxes. Researchers at International Business Machines and Stanford University have fashioned a microscopic cantilever, thousands of times thinner than a human hair, that can be used to measure unimaginably small forces. A rough metaphor is a tiny scale capable of weighing a single protein.

title: F.B.I. DENIED DATA THE WHITE HOUSE SOUGHT ON CHINA
description: The White House tried last month to obtain sensitive counterintelligence information from the Federal Bureau of Investigation about Beijing's plans to influence American politics, but Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. rebuffed the inquiry, Administration officials said today.

title: Court to Weigh States' Legal Reciprocity
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether, and under what circumstances, the courts of one state can refuse to honor rulings by the courts of another state.

title: Calipari's Unfunny 'Joke' Has Telling Punch Line
description: Just when you think you've seen John Calipari at his worst -- the tantrums, the controlling, the charming deception -- the Nets coach and vice president of basketball operations manages to discover and sink to new depths.

description: In an epilogue that could prove heartwarming to some readers on the Upper East Side, two admirers of Books & Company, a 20-year-old bookstore, are negotiating with the store's landlord, the Whitney Museum of American Art, to keep the store from closing.

title: Suspect for an Old Case
description: A dead body found burned beyond recognition in a trash Dumpster at a Willingboro shopping center had stumped county prosecutors since its discovery in January 1995.

description: There will be no national championship this season for the University of Connecticut, the No. 1-ranked women's basketball team. Instead, there will be only heartbreak.

title: Prey Is Replaced at Y
description: The baritone Herman Prey is ill and will not appear tomorrow in the opening concert of the 1997 Schubertiade at the 92d Street Y. William Stone is to replace him. The pianist Brian Zeger is to step in for Michael Endres, and the tenor Steven Tharp is an added performer. The concert, at 8 P.M., is a re-creation of Schubert's only public concert, on March 26, 1828. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: CHRONICLE
description: America's celebrities are literate, or at least claim literacy, judging from the ''Who Reads What'' list published yesterday by GLENNA NOWELL, a librarian in Gardiner, Me. Ms. Nowell began asking celebrities and world political figures what their favorite books were 10 years ago, Reuters reported, and she distributes the list to promote National Library Week, which begins April 13.

title: Internet Lobbying Group Tries to Guard Cyber Rights
description: Last week, as lawyers argued the first case before the Supreme Court testing the limits of free speech on the Internet, volunteers from a small but increasingly prominent New York City group made sure people with access to the Internet knew what they thought was at stake.

title: Danger From Uranium Waste Grows as Government Considers Its Fate
description: Of all the uranium ever mined, about half has ended up here and at two similar sites in row after dismal row of steel cylinders, some still their original green or tan but others now completely covered with rust, having sat for decades mostly forgotten by the Government.

title: Earnings Rise 9% At British Cement Maker
description: Blue Circle Industries P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 9 percent in 1996, as a doubling of earnings from its heating division offset a drop in British and Chilean cement profits. Blue Circle, which makes half of Britain's cement, said pretax profit totaled $:297.6 million ($476 million), which was at the low end of analysts' forecasts but still up from $:272.8 million a year earlier.

description: DDB Needham New York has won back a portion of the Amtrak account, involving national brand advertising, that the agency had lost during a review last April. Though billings were not disclosed, the trade publication Advertising Age estimated that they would almost double this year from an estimated $8 million last year.

title: Workers Deserve a Choice
description: The ''comp-time'' bill passed by the House gives workers the attractive option, impossible under current law, to take their compensation for overtime work in time off rather than extra pay. It might seem odd that Democrats would oppose a sensible idea that most workers say they want. But sensible or not, comp time is opposed by labor unions, which paid over $30 million during the fall campaign to guarantee that Capitol Hill Democrats would do their bidding. President Clinton also opposes the House bill, but at least in his case he has proposed a reasonable, if overly restrictive, alternative.

title: In His 'Safe' Station, Subway Clerk, 60, Is Killed
description: With 28 years under his belt, Robert LeBright had seniority over all but six of New York City's 3,600 token-booth clerks. Not only was he less than two years from retirement and a decent pension, but he also could choose any shift he wanted, at any of the city's 468 subway stations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALAIN ROBERT, a 34-year-old rock climber from Valance, in southern France, is a Gallic Spider-Man who has been temporarily foiled in his attempt to climb the 88-story Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

description: In backrooms in the Depression-era Alabama Department of Archives and History Building here, the South's two patron saints stand at attention, melancholy, proud and banished.

description: Margaret Beals reminisced with words and movements in ''Pathways'' on Sunday afternoon at the Loft Theater. Each episode in this suite of five solos concerned the death of a friend or a relative. Ms. Beals contributed the texts and choreography and, under Lee Nagrin's direction, she made dance seem a form of speaking and let her words become a dance of thoughts.

title: A Penalty for Soliciting
description: Soliciting for prostitution is not a crime in New Jersey if it occurs on private property, including a hotel room.

Her son, Jeffrey Stern, is a leader in the Jewish community and is active in the Wall Street Division Steering Committee. Her daughter-in-law, Susan Stern, is a member of our Board of Directors as well as incoming chair of the Women's Campaign. We extend our deepest sympathies to her children, Jeffrey and Susan Stern, and Gail and Michael Lenvin; her grandchildren, Michael and Peter Stern, and David and Amanda Lenvin; and the entire family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

description: WHILE Israel's attention is understandably focused on nursing its wounds from the latest terrorist bombing, it cannot ignore a legal time bomb that is ticking away in, of all places, lower Manhattan.

title: Lehman Brothers Earnings Climb by 38.5% in Quarter
description: Lehman Brothers reported quarterly net income yesterday of $144 million, or $1.16 a share, surpassing analysts' forecasts, as the Wall Street firm benefited from the sales and trading of securities.

A corrected chart appears today on page C7.

title: German Drug Company Doubled Profit in 1996
description: Gehe A.G., a German pharmaceuticals maker, said yesterday that its profit more than doubled in 1996, helped by the sale of five drug production units. Last year's net income of 440 million marks ($261 million) compared with 211 million marks in 1995. Pretax profit rose 15.6 percent, to 407 million marks.

title: Gingrich on a Slippery Surface With a Firm Base
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich's position is at once unusually shaky and quite secure.

title: Morris Schaeffer, 89, Virologist Who Tightened Controls on Labs
description: Morris Schaeffer, a microbiologist and virologist who helped New York City rein in potentially hazardous medical laboratories in the 1960's and left his imprint on the national level as well, died on Jan. 4 at a hospital in Eugene, Ore. He was 89 and had moved to Eugene in 1988.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: PACT ON SCHOOL REPAIRS -- New York City is ready to begin spending $1.4 billion on school repairs. A school-by-school listing of how the money will be spent. B3.

title: Illegal Contributions
description: A power plant construction company, Ansaldo North American Inc., has admitted making illegal contributions to Representative Maurice D. Hinchey of New York, who was narrowly elected to Congress in 1992.

title: Father Is Spared Death Penalty in Killing of His Children
description: Avi Kostner, who murdered his two children after losing custody of them in a long court fight, was spared the death penalty today when a jury failed to agree on his punishment.

title: Inchcape Profit Up 12%; Car Distribution Revives
description: Inchcape P.L.C., a British auto distributor and marketing company, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 12 percent in 1996 as it posted a ''strong recovery'' in its distribution division, offsetting a drop in marketing profits. Pretax profit rose to $:165.1 million ($264.2 million) from $:146.8 million, as sales at the company, a worldwide distributor for the Toyota Motor Corporation, fell 1 percent, to $:6.3 billion.

title: For Nets, It's a Day, And Night, To Forget
description: Nets Coach John Calipari exhaled a long, high-pitched sigh, which sounded a lot like a distress signal.

title: McCann-Erickson Adds AT&T Duties
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York by naming that agency to handle its American advertising for local telephone services. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $100 million.

title: Judge Halts Marvel Board Reorganization
description: Carl C. Icahn and other Marvel Holding Inc. bondholders were stopped today by a federal judge from replacing the board of Marvel Entertainment Group.

title: Dow Up 100, But Late Rally Skips Nasdaq
description: A rally late yesterday lifted blue-chip stocks out of their worst downturn of the year. But it was not enough to salvage technology stocks, which extended their slump.

title: Lam Announces Deal and Predicts Loss
description: The Lam Research Corporation agreed today to buy Ontrak Systems Inc. for $225 million in stock, as the company seeks to compete better with Applied Materials Inc., the leader in the chip-making equipment industry.

title: September School Repairs Finally About to Start as Political Accord Frees $1.4 Billion
description: Nine months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council agreed to spend $1.4 billion on badly needed school repairs, an agreement to actually begin the repair work was signed yesterday in City Hall.

title: AVENOR SAYS NOT NOW TO A MERGER OFFER FROM DOMTAR
description: The Canadian pulp and paper company Avenor Inc. said yesterday that it had been approached by Domtar Inc. about a merger but rejected the offer to pursue its acquisition of Repap Enterprises. Shareholders are scheduled to vote tomorrow on Avenor's proposed acquisition of Repap. Avenor is offering to swap one of its common shares for every eight Repap shares, for a total value of about $379 million (Canadian). But a number of institutional shareholders are worried about the $2.26 billion (Canadian) debt that Avenor would assume. Avenor said Domtar's bid would be conditional on Avenor and Repap's merger receiving shareholder approval. All three companies are based in Montreal.

title: A Half-Year Into Rebellion, Zaire's President Grabs the Reins
description: After emerging from seclusion, Zaire's ailing President, Mobutu Sese Seko, began consultations today aimed at forming a new Government and negotiating an end to the rebel onslaught.

title: Coastal Physician Deal
description: The Coastal Physician Group said today that it had signed a financing agreement with National Century Financial Enterprises Inc. to retire Coastal's outstanding debt. Earlier this month, Coastal, a struggling physician-management services company, missed a $78 million debt payment to its bank lenders. Coastal's agreement with National Century also provides working capital.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FELCOR SUITE HOTELS INC., Irving, Tex., a real estate investment company, and Doubletree Corp., Phoenix, a hotel management company, agreed to buy three Doubletree Guest Suites hotels in Maryland, Michigan and Texas for $80 million. The sellers are three separate limited partnerships controlled by New England Investment Companies.

title: DEAL FOR CARTER-CROWLEY ASSETS WORTH $383 MILLION
description: Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $383 million for the assets of Carter-Crowley Properties Inc., the Dallas office developer, including a 12 percent stake in the Dallas Mavericks of the National Basketball Association, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Crescent, a real estate investment trust based in Fort Worth and controlled by the billionaire investor Richard Rainwater, did not disclose the terms of the purchase or other details when it was announced on Feb. 13. At the time, analysts estimated that Crescent would pay $350 million for the assets.

title: Samaranch Unhappy With U.S. Track Chief
description: The president of the International Olympic Committee signaled strongly over the weekend that the United States track and field federation should buy out the contract of its lame-duck leader and get on with the business of trying to rebuild a slumping sport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNSTEIN, GERTRUDE
description: HORNSTEIN - Gertrude. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a cherished member of its extended family. Gertrude Hornstein, together with her beloved husband, Moses, who served as Chairman of the school's Building Committee, transformed the Boys Town dream into a reality as they led the effort to develop a tract of barren land into a magnificent 18 acre campus. Their more than three decades of generous support went far beyond the school's bricks and mortar as they invested in the lives of its students, both past, present and future. The perpetual scholarship assistance made possible through the Moses and Gertrude Hornstein Scholarship Endowment enables Boys Town to continue its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. May Gertrude's soul be united in the bond of everlasting life with her beloved Moses, and may their memories be a source of eternal blessing. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Alexander S. Linchner, Vice Chair Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. VP Rabbi Simcha Freedman, Exec. Dir., Florida Friends of BTJ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MARTIN

title: DOW JONES TO SELL DEMOGRAPHICS UNIT TO COWLES MEDIA
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its American Demographics Inc. unit to the Cowles Media Company for an undisclosed price. The unit consists of American Demographics and Marketing Tools magazines, the newsletter Forecast and a catalogue of books and CD-ROM's. A subsidiary, Cowles Business Media, will operate American Demographics, which has been owned by Dow Jones for about 15 years. Cowles Business Media, based in Stamford, Conn., also publishes Cable World, Directory World and Catalog Age magazines. Dow Jones, based in New York, publishes The Wall Street Journal and operates the Telerate financial information service.

title: GORE WITNESSES BOEING-CHINA DEAL

description: To call Al Gore a cautious politician is greatly to understate the case, like calling Robin a polite sidekick or cauliflower less than spicy. The Vice President is a man so pinched in public that he uses the passive voice to issue a call to action.

title: Surgeons Step Inside Device That Gives Them a Clearer View

Now surgeons can have patients wheeled into a new imaging device, then step inside themselves to operate while using live, sometimes three-dimensional images to guide them as they work on brain or body.

title: Tracks of Ancient Ice Lead to a Picture of 'Snowball Earth'

But that is nothing compared with what appears to have happened in the truly distant past, when all or most of the planet may have been frozen -- Snowball Earth.

title: Turkey's Meddlesome Generals

While the generals' defense of secularism appeals to many Americans, the United States should recognize that another period of military rule in Turkey would do more harm than good. Washington needs to make clear that it favors civilian governance and would be obliged to distance itself from any military-dominated regime.

Dr. Potoker was born in Newark, N.J. and was educated at West Side High School. He was an alumnus of Dartmouth College, 1953, where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa. He received a Master's of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy from the Graduate Faculty of Columbia University. He was a retired Professor of English at Bernard Baruch College, CUNY. title: The People of Sarila
description: Sarila is a small farm town without electric power, telephones, a sewage system or enough water for its fields.
