title: Sabres' Hasek Still Out
description: Buffalo Sabres goalie DOMINIK HASEK will most likely be sidelined for at least three more games with a hairline fracture in one of his ribs. The Sabres, who have already clinched a playoff berth, are expected to start the backup STEVE SHIELDS against the Islanders, Detroit and Chicago. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, ROBERT LEE
description: ROSENBAUM-Robert Lee ''Manhattan Fats''. Died March 23rd in Palm Springs, CA. He is survived by two sons, Richard and Jeffrey Rosenbaum and two daughters, Robin Potenza and Leah Rosenbaum. Private services were held in California.

title: Pataki Offers to Mediate In Rent-Control Debate
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he had no plans to offer his own proposal for changing the state's rent regulations, arguing that the most productive role for him would be to stay above the fray to broker a compromise between Democrats who want to maintain the current system and Republicans who want to abolish many protections for tenants.

title: For Radical Freemen, All the Courts Are Stages
description: One year after an F.B.I. siege pushed Montana's Freemen onto the national stage, the once-feared right-wingers are starring in an absurdist drama that could be called Alice in Wonderland on the Yellowstone River.

title: Offshore Drilling Deals
description: Transocean Offshore Inc. said today that it had received contracts valued at $119.8 million for deep-water drilling services using three of its semisubmersible rigs. Transocean said two rigs were contracted to Texaco Inc. The third will drill for Talisman Energy Inc.

title: Bananagate
description: I'm Chiquita Banana and I've come to say / Bananas have to ripen in a certain way . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITTAL, MALLAPPA
description: VITTAL-Mallappa, on Saturday, March 22, 1997, of Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Kumudini Vittal, father of Devadas Vittal and Jeevan Vittal. Also survived by four sisters and one brother. Friends may call at Hines-Rinaldi Funeral Home, 11800 New Hampshire Ave., Silver Spring, MD on Thursday, March 27 and Friday, Mar. 28, from 6 to 9 P.M. Services will be held at Grace United Methodist Church, 7001 New Hampshire Avenue, Takoma Park, MD, on Saturday, March 29 at 11 A.M. Graveside services will be held on Monday, March, 31 at 11 A.M., at George Washington Cemetery, Adelphi, MD.

title: Theater in Review
description: Courtroom Drama In Clubhouse Setting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILEN, RHEA
description: SMILEN-Rhea. Beloved wife of Hyman. Loving mother of Steven and Francine. Devoted sister of David and Sara. Mother-in-law and friend of Tod Ensign and Ilde. Cherished nanny of Rachel Ensign. A woman of valor.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTIT, ESTELLE FITCH
description: PETTIT-Estelle Fitch, wife of the late Karl D. Born in Brooklyn in 1892, moved to Princeton in the 1920's. Survived by six children, twenty-seven grandchildren, fifty great-grandchildren & three greatgreat grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Sunday April 6, 1997, 2PM at Nassau Presbyterian Church, 61 Nassau Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Nassau Presbyterian Church, Princeton, N.J. 08540.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, PETER
description: DOYLE-Peter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Peter Doyle, associated with The Times from 1957 until retiring in 1984.

title: Judge Orders Assessments For Workfare Recipients
description: A State Supreme Court justice has told the city to stop assigning welfare recipients to workfare programs unless it first does a full assessment of recipients' needs and skills to determine whether they should be put into educational programs instead.

title: Lawyers for Simpson To Seek a New Trial
description: Lawyers for O. J. Simpson notified a Los Angeles court today that they would seek a new civil trial, citing 12 irregularities, including jury misconduct and judicial errors.

title: Judge Upholds Dismissal Of Gay Man
description: A Federal district judge in Philadelphia ruled yesterday that Air Force Reserve officials did not have to rehire a man they dismissed from his civilian job after he told his supervisor he is gay.

title: Did Arafat Abet Violence? A Complex Tale
description: For several days now, the Israeli Government has pummeled Yasir Arafat with charges of deliberately resorting to violence and terror, depicting the Palestinian leader as a master manipulator capable of loosing bloodshed at will to achieve his political ends.

title: Malaysian Car Maker To Buy Gear Company
description: The Malaysian car maker Proton plans to buy the Belgian gear-box maker of Royal Begemann N.V., in a move aimed at cutting its reliance on outside parts suppliers.

title: Harriet Pratt Morris, 66; Fought Capital Punishment
description: Harriet Pratt Morris, a leader in the movement against the death penalty in Georgia and nationwide, died on Sunday at her home in Atlanta. Mrs. Morris, who was known as Patsy, was 66.

title: State Argues New Evidence Didn't Justify Releasing Inmate
description: Almost a year after being freed from prison as an innocent man, Lawrence J. Miller could not bring himself to appear in court today to hear prosecutors argue that the judge who released him had been wrong.

title: At N.Y.U., a Global Strategy to Encourage Foreign Study and Travel
description: When L. Jay Oliva, the president of New York University, remembers his days at Manhattan College the memories are pleasant but unremarkable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Streak Ends: Back to Books for UConn
description: Spring break is over at the University of Connecticut. So are the Huskies' chances for a second unbeaten season and a second national championship in three years in women's basketball.

title: Electronic Tolls Are Coming
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority awarded a $488 million contract yesterday to bring the E-Z Pass electronic toll system to the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: TRIZECHAHN TO DEVELOP 45 ACRES OF DOWNTOWN TORONTO
description: The TrizecHahn Corporation said yesterday that it had been selected by the Canadian Government to develop a large area of downtown Toronto for a major entertainment and retail complex. Under the pact with the Canada Lands Company, the federal corporation that owns the site, TrizecHahn would develop 45 acres near Lake Ontario, west of the CN Tower, the world's tallest structure. The project, called City Place, will be phased in over a number of years. TrizecHahn, based in Toronto, will handle construction of the retail component. Terms were not disclosed. TrizecHahn's proposal called for a complex with up to 400,000 square feet. The company will also lease the CN Tower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGAN, ELEANOR (NEE SILK)
description: HAGAN-Eleanor (nee Silk). Beloved wife of Mickey. Devoted mother of Patricia Weiner, Michael and Barbara Gambino. Adored grandmother of Heather and Michael Hagan. Cherished mother-in-law of Jack Weiner, Carol Hagan and Richard Gambino. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call Frank E. Cambell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral blessing at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47th Street, Thursday, 9:30 A.M. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Diet Coke Returns To Its Hunk Theme
description: The Coca-Cola Company is hoping to get lucky again with a television commercial for Diet Coke that tells a role-reversal tale about women ogling a hunky man.

title: Consumer Confidence Index Shows a March Dip
description: Americans' confidence in the economy slipped this month, and their expectations for coming months dimmed as well, but both gauges remained close to the high levels registered recently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKAVISH, JOHN
description: McKAVISH-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John McKavish, associated with The Times from 1992 until retiring in 1996.

title: Taking Tea, Mysterious Rite of the West
description: THIS year, T-Salon, which was formerly in the basement of the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, reopened at 11 East 20th Street, a little mid-19th-century landmark building. After renovation, the owner, Miriam Novalle has opened a charming tearoom done in Charles Rennie Mackintosh style on the ground floor. Tea is served daily from 2:30 to 8 P.M. On the second floor Ms. Novalle sells teas and tea-making equipment. Many of the teas are her own blends; she stores them in antique canisters. Occupying the third floor is an antique-filled tea-tasting room.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EA ENGINEERING, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY INC., Hunt Valley, Md., an environmental consulting company, will lay off about 124 employees as part of a plan to reduce annual costs by more than $9 million.

title: Dr. Thomas W. Smith, 60, Heart Specialist
description: Dr. Thomas W. Smith, chief of cardiovascular medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, died on Sunday at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 60.

title: Life-Changing Sushi And Other Revelations
description: HIS hands looked too big to manipulate a pair of flimsy wooden chopsticks. But after a lifetime of playing the flute in concert halls around the world, Jean-Pierre Rampal's thick fingers were deceptively nimble: he had no trouble plucking a pasty circle of ankimo from a bowl and swirling it in vinegar sauce.

title: Labor Leader Warns of Trouble If Social Spending Cuts Persist : Germans Growling
description: PARIS  John Schmid in Frankfurt contributed to this article.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, HAZZAN SAMUEL
description: ROSENBAUM-Hazzan Samuel. Combining inspiration and intellect, initiative and integrity, Sam ''Sang Unto The Lord'' with beauty and spoke to mortals with conviction and grace. Our Friend and Advisor, he leaves behind an adoring family and countless admirers. The Prayer Book Press Rabbi Jonathan D. Levine, Editor; The Directors of Media Judaica

title: School Buys Laptops for All 7th Graders
description: Hoping to level a high-tech disparity among students, the school system here has bought laptop computers for every student in the seventh grade -- all 36 of them.

title: Proposal to Exempt Home Improvements
description: Saying that homeowners should not be penalized for improving their houses, the Nassau County Executive yesterday proposed a state law to exempt additions and other improvements from tax assessments.

title: Marinovich Arrested in California
description: TODD MARINOVICH, the former U.S.C. and Los Angeles Raiders quarterback, was arrested Monday after deputies said they found a marijuana plant and drug paraphernalia in his home. Lieut. KEITH BROWN of the Orange County (Calif.) Sheriff's Department said yesterday that Marinovich, 27, was arrested for investigation of cultivation of marijuana and possession of narcotics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORCHARDT, LILO, M.D.
description: BORCHARDT-Lilo, M.D., on March 19, 1997. A celebration of her life will be held at the Plaza Hotel, Central Park South, on Wednesday, March 26, from 3PM-5PM. Call 212-586-4394 or 207-583-4921 for more information.

title: Pride Before the Fall? Don't Tell Bob Watson
description: Bob Watson behaved today as if he had to attend a meeting with George Steinbrenner or had to phone Bernie Williams's agent or had to find a team to trade Tim Raines to. Maybe it was all of the above because the Yankees' general manager barely spent enough time on the field this morning to even eat a slice of pizza.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At the Academy Awards Monday night, there was a fashion horse race of sorts. Which designer had dressed the most celebrities? Providing gowns and suits for what is essentially the world's most watched fashion show has become a merry contest.

title: Likely Impact: Less Disruption Than Last Time
description: Three years ago, a move by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates set off a huge retrenchment in a bond market where prices had been driven up by speculation. This year, such a move is likely to have a much smaller effect on the financial markets. For it is Japan's central bank, not America's, that has done the most recently to foster speculation.

title: Ted Williams Has Advice for Belle
description: TED WILLIAMS, who was known for a tempestuous relationship with the news media, has some advice for ALBERT BELLE. Williams, the 78-year-old Boston Red Sox Hall of Famer, lavished praise on the $11 million Chicago White Sox outfielder's playing abilities. But during a conference call yesterday to promote next Sunday's hourlong profile of Williams on ABC-TV, Williams said Belle should make a fan out of everybody he ever meets or wants to meet him. ''It'll help him and all of baseball,'' Williams said.

title: Republican Wants Ouster Of Gingrich
description: A Republican Congressman from Long Island says Newt Gingrich is ''road kill on the highway of American politics'' and ought to be replaced as Speaker if Republican lawmakers are committed to the agenda they embraced after taking control of Congress.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP., Madison, N.J., appointed Kenneth Martin president of its consumer products unit, Whitehall-Robins Healthcare. Mr. Martin replaces Terrence Stecz, who has been appointed to the new position of assistant to the president of American Home Products. The company also named Robert Essner president of Wyeth-Ayerst Global Pharmaceuticals, responsible for both the domestic and international pharmaceutical businesses. Mr. Essner was most recently the president of Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUZA, IRENE
description: RUZA-Irene. Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of our beloved colleague and friend Irene Ruza. Devoted to Hadassah, Israel and the Jewish people, Irene served as President of the Queens Region and was a member of the National Board for over 20 years. An ardent Zionist, she represented Hadassah at the World Zionist Congress in 1978 and 1982. Our deepest condolences to her family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post, National President Beth Wohlgelernter, National Executive Director

title: Greenspan's Limited Faith in the Nation's Productivity
description: For weeks, Alan Greenspan has been saying that the nation's productivity is greater than the statistics acknowledge. American workers, the Federal Reserve chairman suggested, were managing to produce ever greater amounts of goods and services, thus avoiding the shortages and inflation that so often come with a strong expansion. Just last Thursday, Mr. Greenspan told Congress that Fed policy makers would have to decide whether the expansion ''will continue to be met by solid productivity growth.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Stock Prices Move Down On Rate Rise
description: Stock prices slumped yesterday after Federal Reserve policy makers moved to raise short-term interest rates in an attempt to moderate a fast-moving economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPARTA, ROBERT
description: SPARTA-Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Sparta, associated with The Times since 1977.

title: TV Notes
description: Cooperating on an Interview

title: A Good Deal on Missile Defenses
description: According to some Congressional Republicans, last week's Helsinki agreement between Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin on missile defenses dangerously threatens American security. They are wrong on two counts. The Helsinki deal permits all current American missile defense programs to proceed as planned. Beyond that, it is crucial to a larger arms-control package that will make Americans safer by helping to lock in radical reductions in Russian offensive nuclear weapons arsenals.

title: U.S. Rebuffed By Syrians Over Bombing
description: The United States has failed to win Syria's cooperation in the investigation of a terrorist bombing at a military residence in Saudi Arabia last June that left 19 Americans dead, senior Administration officials said today.

title: 2 More Are Charged In Beating Near Parade
description: Two more Brooklyn teen-agers were charged yesterday with beating a Bronx teen-ager into a coma during a street brawl just a block away from the St. Patrick's Day Parade in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Let's Get Our Superpowers Straight
description: Two simple facts define the geopolitical landscape today -- Russian weakness and Chinese strength. In the North Atlantic, across Eurasia, in East Asia, these two realities form the backdrop against which daily events occur, from the chaos in Albania to the cautiousness in Hong Kong. Yet increasingly the Clinton Administration's foreign policy looks as if it were intended to meet precisely the opposite challenges.

title: What Danny the Cat Learns About Hollywood
description: Mordant comedy, a meaningful message and a homage to Hollywood come in the candy-colored cartoon package that bears the title ''Cats Don't Dance.''

title: How Rail Lines Test for Color Perception
description: Other rail systems in the region have color tests for engineers that do not seem to differ markedly from the tests New Jersey Transit has used.

title: WISCONSIN ENERGY TO BUY ELECTRIC UTILITY IN MICHIGAN
description: The Wisconsin Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Eselco Inc., which owns the Edison Sault electric utility in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., for about $71 million. Under terms of the agreement, shares of Eselco will be converted into $44.50 worth of Wisconsin Energy shares. In Nasdaq trading, Eselco's stock rose $6.50, or 21 percent, to $37. Wisconsin Energy stock was up 12.5 cents, to $24.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: R.L. Richards, 98; Du Pont Pioneer In Cellophane Use
description: Robert L. Richards, a longtime executive at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company who helped introduce cellophane to North America, died on March 8 at his home in Wilmington, Del. He was 98.

title: Doris Day and Other Matters of Cultural Importance
description: ''Love and Other Catastrophes,'' the scrappy, amiable campus comedy that is the first feature by Emma-Kate Croghan, unfolds on familiar terrain. The Australian students who are the film's main characters bring the pluckiness of situation comedy stars to facing problems of less than earth-shaking magnitude. A roommate crisis, a $663 library fine, a junk-food addiction and a transfer from one department to another provide some of this film's impetus, as do the breakup of a lesbian couple and the lady-killing of one local stud. Charm and spirited acting are all that keep this slight but good-humored film from sinking beneath its trivial pursuits.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, JOSEPH F.
description: MILLER-Joseph F., of Deal, NJ, whose 90th birthday would have been today. Greatly missed by Marjorie, Ken, Kitty, Keith, grandchildren and great grandchild.

title: CHRONICLE
description: This Sunday, children in many parts of the world will hunt for Easter eggs. But on April 15, an egg created in 1900 by Peter Carl Faberge can be had: a cobalt blue enamel egg studded with diamond crescents to resemble a pine cone, enclosing a silver Indian elephant automaton that walks when wound, head swaying and tail swishing.

title: Hunt Pressed For Killer Of IRT Clerk
description: Investigators yesterday continued to search for the gunman who killed a subway token booth clerk in Long Island City, Queens, Monday morning, as three organizations offered rewards totaling $30,000 in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SYLVIA
description: GREENE-Sylvia. March 25, 1997. Loving wife of Harry H. Greene, married 63 years. Dearest mother of Judy and Paul Kunitz, Abbie and Joseph Lovinger, Rosalind and Dale Howard. Cherished sister of Rosalyn Trenk and Paul Kupferberg. Adored grandmother of Sharon, Lisa, Dawn, Heidi, Elizabeth, Daniel, Marissa, Jeffrey, and Nicole. Loving greatgrandmother of 11. We will miss you forever. Burial in Huntsville, Alabama, March 27, 1997.

title: Labor's New Organizing Tactic
description: American labor leaders are developing a new tactic to boost union membership. Frustrated by repeated losses in secret-ballot elections to determine whether companies must accept a union, key labor leaders now want to go for voluntary recognition without a formal election. In exchange they would offer managers the prospect of labor peace and even workplace concessions. As a desperate effort to thwart management's stunningly successful opposition to unionization elections, the new tactic makes sense. But the tactic is not likely to reverse labor's 20-year slide because managers will still be able to manipulate the ballot process in ways the labor laws never intended.

title: Ericsson to Cut Jobs In Subcontracting Plan
description: The Swedish telecommunications equipment maker Ericsson said yesterday that it would cut as many as 1,400 jobs as it subcontracts some electronic-component production to two United States companies and revamps other operations. Ericsson has signed agreements with the Solectron Corporation and SCI Systems to produce electronic printing boards used in Ericsson's AXE switches. Ericsson's printing-board plant in Norrkoeping, which employs 700 workers, will be shut.

title: BUCKEYE CELLULOSE PLANS BID FOR MERFIN INTERNATIONAL
description: The Buckeye Cellulose Corporation of Memphis said yesterday that it planned to make an offer to buy Merfin International Inc., a maker of absorbent materials, for about $108 million. Merfin, based in Delta, British Columbia, makes materials used in feminine hygiene and incontinence products. Buckeye's offer equals $6 a share (Canadian). Merfin's stock rose 55 cents a share yesterday, to $6.50, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. But Merfin expressed displeasure with Buckeye's proposal. Ivan B. Pivko, chairman and chief executive of Merfin, said, ''The Buckeye offer doesn't recognize the value'' of Merfin's technology. The company said that it would seek other strategic alternatives.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ELLIOTT
description: COHEN-Elliott. 1915-1967. When I am very still, I feel your kisses and I am again connected to you, Dad. I love you so. Janie

title: Giving Collaboration a Bad Name
description: FRANCE UNDER THE GERMANS

title: HEALTH WATCH
description: Race and Weight

title: To build basketball sneaker sales, Converse tries a novel double team: Dr. J and Dennis Rodman.
description: CONVERSE INC., the sneaker company that outfitted the basketball stars of yesteryear, has hit upon a clever marketing concept: If you can't beat a path to the future, why not indulge in the gloried past?

title: CHECKERS AND RALLY'S TO MERGE RESTAURANT OPERATIONS
description: Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy Rally's Hamburgers Inc. for about $113.5 million in stock. Under terms of the agreement, each share of Rally's stock will be converted into three shares of Checkers stock. The company will operate 949 Checkers and Rally's restaurants, including 473 company-operated and 476 franchised restaurants. For 1996, Checkers and Rally's had combined revenue of $327.8 million.

title: Plane Hits Truck in Landing Mix-Up at La Guardia
description: Ordered to abort its landing only after it was already on the ground, a private jet arriving at La Guardia Airport before dawn yesterday smashed into a maintenance truck parked on the runway, narrowly missing two workers who had been given clearance to change bulbs in the runway lights.

title: Van Gundy Wants Houston to Find His Game (Tonight)
description: Allan Houston received a pep talk behind closed doors from Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy. And Buck Williams decided, enough already. He is coming back, misshapen finger and all.

title: U.S.C.'s Russell Drills for Jets
description: DARRELL RUSSELL of Southern California, perhaps the top-rated defensive tackle in college, ran his injury-delayed 40-yard dash yesterday in Los Angeles, showing the athleticism National Football League scouts crave. DICK HALEY, who runs the Jets' draft, timed the 6-foot-5-inch, 312-pounder in 4.85 seconds. The Trojans' strength coach, JAMES STROM, said that the only U.S.C. lineman to run faster than Russell was WILLIE McGINEST, now a Patriot.

title: Guests may grumble about rising hotel prices, but they have a lot more choices to pick from.
description: WITH the average daily hotel rate increasing by more than 6 percent last year, to $71.73, after almost a 5 percent jump in 1995, travelers continue to find life on the open road ever more costly. But if they can complain about prices, they cannot complain about lack of variety. Between 1980 and 1966, according to a new Coopers & Lybrand analysis, 113 new chains were introduced in the lodging industry -- 10 in just the last 12 months. While many have since failed, the forecast is for even more hotel brands.

title: Governor Freelance
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Often Misread Results Of Genetic Tests, Study Finds
description: AS genetic tests become commercially available, people with a family history of cancer who are thinking about being screened must weigh the pros and cons of such tests. Is the anxiety of not knowing whether they have a cancer gene or genetic defect worse than the anxiety of knowing that they have it? Can the information help save their lives? How can they keep the results private so they do not risk being dropped by their insurance companies or fired by their employers?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMIREZ, GABRIELE
description: RAMIREZ-Gabriele, of Princeton, NJ, on March 24. Sister of Annemarie Maass and Gitti Sinding. Mother of Ronald, Catherine and Deborah. Memorial service to be held at the Unitarian Church of Princeton on Thursday, March 27th, at 1 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, DORA C.
description: REID-Dora C. On March 24, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Devoted mother of Edith Flaster and Anne Demner. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey and Helen Flaster, Michael and Sandra Flaster. Services were held on Wednesday, March 26, 1997.

title: Food Notes
description: Low-Fat Cakes Just in Time

title: New York Cuts Hauling Rates For Garbage
description: In a major move to reduce private garbage-removal costs in New York City, a new city agency imposed mandatory price cuts yesterday, saying it would reduce costs for small and medium-sized businesses by a total of $300 million a year.

title: Nurses Charged with Neglect
description: On Oct. 1, after being hospitalized and treated for a massive stroke, Issac Barron, 74, was admitted to the Roosevelt Care Center in Edison, prosecutors said. He died there less than a month later while undergoing rehabilitation. Yesterday, five nurses who had tended to Mr. Barron were indicted on charges of criminal neglect for violating a statute aimed at protecting the elderly.

title: Toyota to Sell Hybrid-Power Car in Japan
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would become the first company to sell a low-polluting hybrid vehicle, with both an electric motor and a gasoline engine, to a mass market.

title: A Dazzler Of a Drunk, Full of Gab And Grief
description: There are, on the one hand, the jokes, which are artfully told, epigrammatic and often lewd. On the other hand (and it's the ruling hand), there are the pauses between and within the jokes, in which the teller's eyes go glassy with a soul-searing fear. He has seen something unspeakable, and words like failure, ruin and even death don't begin to describe it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, ROBERT J.
description: WRIGHT-Robert J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert J. Wright, associated with The Times from 1977 until retiring in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MURRAY
description: STERN-Murray. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Murray Stern, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1988.

title: Packers Say Goodbye to Rison
description: Wide receiver ANDRE RISON, who scored the first touchdown of this past Super Bowl on a pass from BRETT FAVRE, had his contract terminated by the Green Bay Packers yesterday. General Manager RON WOLF, announcing the decision, said the team's receiver corps doesn't have room for the eight-year veteran as a starter. ''The feeling here is that Andre is a starter,'' Wolf said, ''and with the situation we presently are in, he wouldn't be a starter.'' (AP)

title: Prosecutor's Husband Calls Job Political
description: For months, the political future of District Attorney Jeanine F. Pirro has been clouded by allegations that her husband, a prominent development lawyer, paid a $5,000 bribe to win approvals for a 10-screen movie theater in Yonkers.

title: Crisis in the Housing Program
description: Housing Secretary Andrew Cuomo and Attorney General Janet Reno this week jointly announced a vigorous program to stamp out fraud in the Government's major housing program for low-income families. The abuses in the Section 8 program, as it is called, are real -- as New York learned when Federal authorities took over a housing project in the Bronx two weeks ago after sanitary and building conditions had deteriorated to appalling levels. But fraud is not the program's major problem. A financial time bomb is. The Administration understood that Congress would not fork over the money needed for continuation and expansion if the programs were riddled with fraud and abuse.

title: Hard-Luck Seles Aims to Move Ahead, a Day and a Match at a Time
description: For Monica Seles, life has gone wrong, but life has gone on. The alternative, she said today after escaping into the semifinals of the Lipton championships with a 3-6, 6-2, 6-3 victory over seventh-seeded Irina Spirlea, is to ''sit in a dark room thinking dark thoughts about all the bad things that are happening around you that you can't control.''

title: Nasdaq Posts 6.5% Increase In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Short-sellers became more active in recent weeks as the Nasdaq stock market declined sharply, according to figures released yesterday by the market.

title: Whitewater Counsel Wants to Reduce One Man's Sentence
description: The Whitewater independent counsel has asked a Federal judge in Arkansas to reduce the prison sentence of David L. Hale, a major prosecution witness who has accused President Clinton of helping to arrange an improper federally backed loan in the 1980's.

title: McGreevey Gains in Race For Governor
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey broadened his support in northern New Jersey today with the endorsement of the Essex County Democratic Party, giving him a considerable advantage in the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: NEW KERR DRUG TO BUY 161 J.C. PENNEY DRUGSTORES
description: The J.C. Penney Company plans to sell 161 drugstores in North Carolina and South Carolina to the newly formed New Kerr Drug, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. Penney said in December that it would sell the stores to satisfy antitrust concerns over Penney's acquisition of the Eckerd Corporation. The F.T.C. still must approve the sale. Penney completed the purchase of Eckerd in February, making its Thrift Drug business the second-largest in the country with almost 3,000 stores. Penney is also planning to buy 190 more stores from the Rite Aid Corporation. New Kerr Drug is a closely held corporation owned by Anthony N. Civello, former president of Penney's Kerr Drug unit, and Laurence F. Ross, owner of Ross Moulds Inc.

title: Oxford Drops Referrals
description: Oxford Health Plans said it would begin letting members visit specialists directly rather than forcing them to first seek referrals from family doctors.

title: The Soup That Sustains the Andes Through Holy Week
description: IN the villages of Ecuador's Andean sierra, where soups are a mainstay, women traditionally gather a few days before Easter to cook an enormous pot of a meatless, milk-based, vegetable soup known as fanesca. It is flavored with dried salt cod and enriched with cream and cheese.

title: Patton to Stay With Colorado
description: RICARDO PATTON, who coached Colorado to its first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance in 28 years, is staying in the job, with a new contract. Patton agreed to a deal worth at least $325,000, Colorado's athletic director, DICK THARP, said yesterday. (AP)

title: Grilling Belongs Outdoors
description: To The Living Section:

title: Japan's Dockworkers to Protest U.S. Move
description: Japan's two biggest dockworkers' unions will refuse to work night shifts to protest the sanctions that the United States plans against Japanese shipping companies.

title: As Comfortable in the Kitchen As They Are in the Pulpit
description: WITH its white steeple and Federal-style parsonage, the Saugatuck Congregational Church offers a postcard-like testament to New England cultural history. But when its pastor, the Rev. Alan Johnson, chooses a way to illustrate God's grace, he looks not to the Puritan past, but to something more universal -- the preparation of food.

title: Eye on the Bottom Line, Braves and Indians Trade
description: After ''kicking the tires of this deal all spring long,'' the Atlanta Braves and the Cleveland Indians made a stunning trade today that was fueled by the economic concerns of both clubs. The Braves sent two-thirds of their outfield, David Justice and Marquis Grissom, to the Indians for Kenny Lofton, who is considered the best leadoff hitter in baseball, and relief pitcher Alan Embree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSMAN, MARY ELLEN
description: GOSMAN-Mary Ellen, died on March 23, 1997. Born in Ireland, June 17, 1909. Beloved mother of Roberta, John, Emmett, William and Richard. Another son, Hubert predeceased her. Grandmother of Karin, Robert, Sharon, Diane, John Christopher, Michael, Richard, Bryan, Asa and Lilah. Great grandmother of Matthew and Brendan Vilar. Beloved sister of Theresa Harrington of Montauk, Brigid Brohan, Nan Quigley, Una Herbert, Christine Noon, Pat Harrington, Michael Harrington and Hubert Harrington of Ireland. She came to this country in 1927, settled on the East End of Long Island. With her husband Robert, who predeceased her, she founded Gosman's Dock on Montauk. She is reposing in Williams Funeral Home in East Hampton. Viewing hours are Wednesday and Thursday, March 26, March 27 from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be held at Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton Saturday, March 29, at 11 AM and burial at Fort Hill Cemetery, Montauk. Donations to the Saint Therese Church of Montauk Building Fund, Montauk Library Building Fund or Montauk Ambulance Squad.

title: COMMERZBANK TO BUY MONTGOMERY SUBSIDIARY
description: Montgomery Securities Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its money management subsidiary to Commerzbank A.G., Germany's third-biggest bank, for an estimated $250 million. The acquisition gives Commerzbank access to one of America's fastest-growing mutual fund companies. About half the assets of Montgomery Asset Management, or $4 billion, are spread among 19 mutual funds. Montgomery Securities, based in San Francisco, said that it would use the proceeds from the sale to finance growth in its investment banking and brokerage businesses. The transaction still needs approval from the Federal Reserve.

They think of eating as entertainment.''

title: Sizzler's Revamping Plan
description: The restaurant operator Sizzler International Inc. has filed a reorganization plan with the Federal Bankruptcy Court. The company said on Monday that the plan called for full payment of creditors' claims, estimated at $70 million. Sizzler added that the plan did not include any provisions to dilute the value of its stock or sell any profitable operations. A court hearing is scheduled on April 21. Sizzler filed in June for protection from its creditors.

title: Off His Turf, Giuliani Gets A Real Earful
description: It is not often that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani holds a monthly town hall meeting in a neighborhood where he does not have substantial support, and last night's meeting in the largely black Brooklyn neighborhood of East New York was, indeed, not typical.

title: SANOFI SELLS DIAGNOSTIC ASSETS TO BECKMAN INSTRUMENTS
description: Sanofi S.A., a French drug company, said yesterday that it had sold assets related to its Access Immunoassay System diagnostics kit to Beckman Instruments Inc. of Fullerton, Calif. The assets, which include a factory in Chaska, Minn., and patents in a number of countries, are worth about 280 million French francs ($49 million). Further financial details were not disclosed. The Access diagnostic kit can perform a number of medical tests at one time, up to 30,000 tests a year, and operate 24 hours a day. Sanofi and Beckman will also work together in a 10-year partnership to develop new tests for the Access kit. Sanofi now expects to sell 1,000 Access kits a year, up from its previous goal of 500.

title: Penders Tours Campus at Rutgers
description: TOM PENDERS, coach of the University of Texas, took the grand tour of the Rutgers campus yesterday and returned home while his agent worked on a deal that might make Penders the Scarlet Knights' next basketball coach. Penders, who guided Texas to the third round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament last week, left the Piscataway, N.J., campus of the Big East school, while CRAIG FENECH, his agent, was involved in negotiations with the Rutgers treasurer, JOE WHITESIDE. (AP)

title: KLM Pricing Policy Investigated in Europe
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that the European Commission was investigating its pricing policy in relation to a competing British discount carrier, Easyjet Airlines. A KLM spokeswoman, Marjolein Wenting, said ''the inquiry is aimed at whether KLM is abusing its market position in its pricing policy.''

description: In ''The Devil's Own,'' Brad Pitt plays an Irish Republican Army operative who flees Belfast and comes to live in Staten Island. He is supposed to be incognito, but he sure is hard to miss. Mr. Pitt moves through this unexpectedly solid thriller with dazzling confidence, showing off all the star power that he usually works overtime to hide. With a temporary goodbye to bad haircuts and grunge affectations, he gives a first-rate, madly photogenic performance that will win him new respect along with fluttery fan-club adulation.

description: From France to Fargo, from England to Australia, there were celebrations yesterday in the aftermath of the 69th Academy Awards. Failure may be an orphan, but success always has many parents.

title: IDX TO ACQUIRE PHAMIS IN MEDICAL DATA SYSTEMS MERGER
description: IDX Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Phamis Inc. for about $147 million in stock to increase its share of the health care information systems market. Under the agreement, Phamis shareholders would receive 0.73 share of IDX common stock for each of their shares. Based on IDX's closing price yesterday of $31.75, the transaction is valued at $23.18 a share. Phamis had 6.35 million shares outstanding as of Dec. 31. Shares of Phamis, based in Seattle, were up $3.375, to $22.25, before trading was halted. The companies sell computer information systems to doctors' practices, hospitals and other medical centers. IDX is based in Burlington, Vt.

title: Johnson Returns To Cheers Of Fans
description: Howard Johnson played nine years for the Mets. Nine years of home runs and position changes and errors. Nine years of maximum effort and minimum headlines. Then he faded away, without the standing ovations or a final farewell.

title: CHINESE ASK GORE ABOUT THE INQUIRY ON CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: The uproar over campaign financing intruded directly into foreign affairs as Vice President Al Gore assured Prime Minister Li Peng of China on Tuesday that a Justice Department investigation into whether the Chinese tried to influence the 1996 elections would not affect Washington's relationship with China while the inquiry was under way.

title: ARCO in Stock Plan
description: ARCO said today that it might buy back as much as $150 million of its stock to finance its long-term executive compensation program. The oil and gas company, which is based in Los Angeles, said that in 1996 it purchased 480,000 shares in connection with the compensation program. The company's shares finished at $135 today, a gain of $1.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: New Law Forces a Reversal In Oklahoma Bombing Case
description: Complying with a new Federal law, the judge in the Oklahoma City bombing case today reversed his order forbidding attendance at the trial by any victim who wants to testify during the penalty phase.

title: VF Plans to Bolster Position By Acquiring Maidenform
description: The VF Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Maidenform Worldwide Inc. for an undisclosed amount, shoring up its position as a leading manufacturer of women's intimate apparel.

description: Legislation to expand Medicare coverage of preventive health services is all the rage on Capitol Hill as Republicans and Democrats trumpet the value of tests to detect breast cancer, prostate cancer, diabetes and other diseases.

description: The way his mother tells it, Musa Ghneimat gave no sign that he was about to embark on a suicide mission when he had his last cup of tea in her house last Friday morning.

title: Chemical Blast Injures Two
description: A nontoxic chemical exploded yesterday at a plant owned by the Fairmount Chemical Company, injuring two employees of a nearby trucking company, fire officials said. Thomas Ludlow, 36, was thrown against a door and Alban Aldeurozco, 24, was blown from the top of a tractor-trailer when the chemical, diazidostilbene disodium sulfonate, a hardening agent, exploded at the Fairmount plant, 200 yards from a trucking company, Rapid Transport. The explosion could be felt hundreds of yards from the plant, Larry Krieger, a spokesman for the Newark Fire Department, said.

description: As the sages say, there is always a first time for everything. title: Kidnap Victim Recalls Brutality by a Gang Seeking Ransom
description: A 30-year-old Chinese immigrant testifying yesterday in a fatal-kidnapping trial told in harrowing detail how he had been beaten, stabbed and tormented by kidnappers in Brooklyn who shot him and left him for dead when his family could not meet their ransom demands.

title: A Year-Old Wound Remains Unhealed
description: After leading his Colorado players through a long practice earlier this week in suburban Philadelphia, Avalanche Coach Marc Crawford removed his outer clothing, revealing the T-shirt beneath. The words on the front said ''U.S. Olympic Team,'' a curious garment on a leading candidate to coach Team Canada next year at the Winter Games in Japan.

title: Fiction Prize Nominees
description: The five nominees for the 1997 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction have been announced by the PEN/Faulkner Foundation. The nominees are Daniel Akst, for ''St. Burl's Obituary''; Gina Berriault, for ''Women in Their Beds''; Kathleen Cambor, for ''The Book of Mercy''; Ron Hansen, for ''Atticus,'' and Jamaica Kincaid, for ''The Autobiography of My Mother.'' The winner, to be announced in April, receives $15,000; the others get $5,000.

Nearly all are initiatives that the Mayor proposed in his State of the City address in January -- to fortify teaching in the arts, computers and reading.

title: Radar-Device Maker Sold

Cincinnati Microwave filed for protection from its creditors under on Feb. 14. The company said it would sell its radar business and property to Escort Acquisition, owned by Matthew Coleman.

title: 2 German Builders Plan To Link Operations
description: The German construction companies Hochtief A.G. and Philipp Holzmann A.G. intend to link operations wherever ''economically rational,'' Holzmann's chairman, Lothar Mayer, said yesterday. Hochtief announced on Monday that it would pool its 24.9 percent stake in Holzmann with 25.1 percent held by Holzmann's other major shareholder, Deutsche Bank A.G.

title: Royals Release Hamelin
description: BOB HAMELIN, who hit 24 home runs in 1994 and was voted the American League rookie of the year, was released yesterday by the Kansas City Royals. ''We tried to trade him, but we couldn't do it,'' Manager BOB BOONE said. Hamelin, 29, never regained his stroke after the player strike shortened his rookie season. Today is the last time teams can place players on waivers and not be responsible for the entire 1997 salary. (AP)

title: Setback Dealt To Owners Of Barney's
description: In a blow to the owners of Barneys New York, the upscale New York retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection last year in a dispute with its Japanese partner, the Isetan Company, a judge yesterday ordered them to pay Isetan $197 million in loans.

title: Insurers Turn To Retraining Injured Workers
description: Lisa Kay Standard struggled to lift herself out of her long green canoe as it nosed onto the white sandy beach on this tangle of mangroves and palmettos on the edge of the Everglades. At first, her legs failed her, as they often do. But with an extra heave the 26-year-old woman pitched forward and was finally able to step ashore.

title: Corrections

They range from $1.75 to $3.50 each way, and E-Z Pass users save 50 cents per trip. (The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge has a $7 toll in one direction only, and E-Z Pass users save $1).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELHARDT, JACOB O.
description: ENGELHARDT-Jacob O. Of Brooklyn, N.Y. Formerly of West Palm Beach FL and Southbury CT. On March 24, 1997, age 94. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice, beloved father of Helen, Daniel, Alice, cherished grandfather of Alan and Tamara, great grandfather of Aaron and Zoe, brotherin-law, uncle and great uncle. Jack was a lifelong teacher and student. He was a master teacher of mathematics which he taught in the NYC high schools and Brooklyn Friends. He was a resource of Yiddish language and lore for his friends. A gifted amateur artist, musician and linguist, he was a lifelong member of the Teachers Union. Passionately devoted to political and social concerns, he retained a keen interest in the news and affairs of the day until the end of his life. He will be remembered by his many students and friends for his rare abilities as a teacher, his kindness, his devotion, his optimism and his appetite for life. His wish was to be cremated. In lieu of flowers, please give to a charity of your choice. Memorial service will be held privated in May. For further information, contact Helen or Dan.
