Mark Whiten rushed into the clubhouse and implored Cecil Fielder to come and join the dozens of fans who were observing the awesome hitting display.

title: Clinton to Send Envoy to Middle East
description: President Clinton has decided to send his special envoy for the Middle East, Dennis B. Ross, back to the region to try to stop a further spiral into violence, senior American officials said today.

title: A Life in Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Toasted In China
description: The Vice President stood as still as a terra cotta warrior, facing the cameras in the Great Hall of the People with a fixed smile as the Chinese tossed him bouquets of Buicks and Boeing jet deals worth $2 billion.

title: Region's Economic Optimism Level Soars
description: The level of economic optimism about jobs and business conditions in the Middle Atlantic states of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania soared over the last year, increasing at a faster pace than any other region of the country, a nonprofit business research group said yesterday.

title: President Named By Servicenet
description: Servicenet, an Internet commerce joint venture of Andersen Consulting and the BBN Corporation, has named John M. Whiteside as its president.

title: Terror in a Voice, Even 40 Years Later, Tells a New Generation What It Missed
description: ''I tell my children today they don't know anything. You know, when I hear young folk talking about what they ain't gonna take, I like to sit down and tell 'em: 'You haven't seen anything. You just don't know what it's all about. I don't know what it is you can't take.' And when I go back to telling them some of my history, you know, they have to perk up their ears.''

title: Agency Puts Off A Stock Offering
description: Frankel & Company, a marketing and promotion agency in Chicago, has decided to postpone an initial public offering of shares, citing unfavorable market conditions.

title: Auditors Raise Question of T.W.A.'s Continued Operation
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that its auditors had included a qualification in the annual report of the carrier regarding its ''ability to continue as a going concern.''

title: Unusual Relationship Lessens Capital Tension
description: It might have been her salty use of Spanish to mock Cuban fighter pilots who shot down two civilian planes. Or maybe his courtly, Southern way. Or maybe yet a mutual zeal for blunt talk about Communists and other international scoundrels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNSTEIN, GERTRUDE
description: HORNSTEIN-Gertrude. The Directors of The Long Island Hearing and Speech Society join our Vice President, Larry Hornstein, in mourning the death of his mother. We extend our condolences to the entire family in remembering a warm, intelligent, community minded leader. We know she will be dearly missed. Jonathan Leigh, President

title: Mikan Makes a 'Comeback'
description: IT wasn't quite the Case of the Missing Sports Legend, but for several decades the 6-foot-10-inch, 250-pound basketball star had been in a kind of eclipse. George Mikan? ''Yeah,'' people would say, ''whatever happened to him?''

title: Russia and NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: Island Fairy Tales With Spicy Rhythms

title: When Welfare Seems a Bully, Not a Savior
description: JUAN TOMAS ABREU received an urgent letter two weeks ago at his Brooklyn home. It was from the Social Security Administration, and just in case he missed its gravity, the first line fairly shouted out in bold, blunt print: ''Important Notice: Juan Tomas Abreu May Lose His S.S.I.''

title: At 72, Bush Leaps Into the Open Sky
description: A half-century has passed since Japanese gunners knocked Lieut. (j.g.) George Bush's torpedo bomber out of the Pacific sky, forcing him to bail out and take an unwanted swim before being plucked to safety by a passing submarine.

title: Special Lanes Are Criticized
description: The high-occupancy vehicle lanes on Route 80 are a failure and should be eliminated, a Morris Township lawmaker said yesterday. Afternoon rush-hour traffic in the other three westbound lanes has increased between Route 287 and Route 15, while use of the special lane has declined slightly, State Senator Gordon A. MacInnis, a Democrat, said. But Dave Brown, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation, defended the special lanes, pointing out that for every car in the lanes, at least one more car is off the road.

title: A Suburban Exodus
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Rating System May Actually Lure Youths to Violent Shows, Study Finds
description: Television still glamorizes violence, and the new ratings system being used to alert parents to violent or sexually explicit programs may attract children to such shows, according to a study issued yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Orders for Durables Jump, A Sign of Stronger Growth

title: Clinton Gives Freeh Measured Support
description: President Clinton gave a measured vote of confidence today to Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I., saying, ''I don't have any information at this time which would call into question that confidence.''

title: Another Executive Moves to Leap Group
description: Another top executive from TBWA Chiat/Day has joined the new Santa Monica, Calif., office of the Leap Partnership unit of Leap Group.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: U.N. Complains New Parking Rules Are a Violation of International Law
description: Lawyers for the United Nations said yesterday that after studying the issue, they had determined that New York City's plan to take tougher action against diplomats who violate city parking laws was a breach of international law.

title: Johnson Is Cut and Retires as a Met
description: There are the inevitable goodbyes as rosters are pared at the end of spring training. Howard Johnson made one today as he retired, thanking the Mets for giving him a last hurrah, and a chance to find out whether his career was over.

title: Clinton Offer of Island to New York Is Stalled
description: President Clinton has offered to help transfer control of Governors Island to New York if the city and the state come up with an acceptable plan for public use of the 174 acres in New York Harbor, officials said yesterday. As the President proposed it, New York would ''buy'' the island from the Federal Government for $1 and turn it into a grand public resource for everything from boating to education.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 19 about Bert-Olof Svanholm, chairman of Volvo A.B., misstated the name of the school in Goteborg, Sweden, of which he was chairman. It is the Chalmers University of Technology, not Chalmers Technical High School.

title: Giuliani Again Presses CUNY's Chancellor for Changes
description: Despite weeks of growing criticism of the City University of New York and its administrators, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was not trying to force out W. Ann Reynolds, the Chancellor, but he made it clear that he expected an improvement in the system's standards if she was to remain.

title: U. Alexis Johnson Dies at 88; Led Arms Talks With Moscow
description: U. Alexis Johnson, a career diplomat and one of the shepherds of the first strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union, died on Monday in Raleigh, N.C., where he was living in retirement. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, HENRY E.
description: COE-Henry E., of Lawrence, Long Island, suddenly on March 25, 1997. Age 71. Beloved husband of Penny. Beloved father of Nancy Bell, Elice, Cynthia, J.P. and Alexandra, and grandfather of three. Fond brother of Sylvia Coe Tolk of San Francisco. Memorial service 10 A.M., Saturday, March 29, at Trinity-St. John's Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to Groton School, Groton, MA 01450, The Nature Conservancy-L.I. Chapter, 250 Lawrence Hill Road, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. 11724, or charity of your choice.

title: Channel 5 Apologizes
description: Because of the persistence of a Staten Island schoolteacher, WNYW, Channel 5, issued an on-air apology yesterday to viewers for having shown an R-rated movie largely unedited on Sunday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, CHARLES
description: LEHMAN-Charles. Loving husband of Evelyn, dear brother of Leonard and Abraham. Services Friday 11AM at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 14-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Man Charged With Murder Of Fiancee
description: Federal prosecutors charged a Connecticut man yesterday with kidnapping his fiancee and murdering her in Manhattan just days after she had obtained a court order of protection against him.

title: F.T.C. Staff Seeks Action Against Joe Camel
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission wants the agency to lodge an unfair-advertising complaint against R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, charging that the company's Joe Camel advertisements are designed to lure children into smoking, officials said today.

title: NAMING OF ENVOYS SLOWS TO A CRAWL
description: A leading candidate for ambassador to France has withdrawn, tired of waiting for the call from the White House. There is no American ambassador in important countries, like Russia, Japan and Germany. And many top jobs under Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright await appointees.

title: Combining Elemental And Songful
description: Anthony Korf's group Parnassus gave a typically useful, varied and balanced program on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, featuring a 20th-century classic (Ravel's ''Chansons Madecasses,'') pieces by two senior European figures (Henri Dutilleux and Roland Moser) and two new American compositions.

title: Queens Home Yields Cache Of Chemicals
description: The police last night arrested a Queens man after discovering dozens of containers of hazardous materials at his home yesterday afternoon. One canister was marked ''Sarin Gas,'' but officials said they did not know if it actually contained the powerful nerve gas used in a terrorist attack in the Tokyo subway in 1995.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: E-Z Pass Shouldn't Be So Hard to Get
description: To the Editor:

title: Deutsche Bank Sets Fund for Irregularities
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. said today that it set aside 1.2 billion marks, or $710 million, last year to reimburse customers and pay potential fines arising from the previously disclosed irregularities by a fund manager at its Morgan Grenfell Asset Management subsidiary.

title: U.S. Rebuffed in Global Proposal For Eavesdropping on the Internet
description: In a setback for the Clinton Administration that demonstrates the difficulty of setting global policies for the Internet, the leading industrial nations have declined to embrace a United States proposal to allow computer eavesdropping by the world's law enforcement agencies.

title: In Match to Land Sehorn, Falcons Have Next Move
description: Atlanta Falcons Coach Dan Reeves, in pursuit of the free-agent cornerback Jason Sehorn, told Sehorn's agents to come up with an offer they believed the Giants would not match. Well, they might have done just that. The question now is whether Reeves will accept it.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Names Health Panel

title: Stern Fines Calipari $25,000 for Insulting Reporter
description: An apology was not enough. David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, extended the normal scope of his responsibility today when he fined Nets Coach John Calipari an unprecedented $25,000 for the ethnic insult he yelled at the reporter Dan Garcia a week ago in a Mahwah, N.J., parking lot, calling him a ''Mexican idiot.''

title: Reconciling the Beauty With Its Dangers and The Deeds of the Family
description: Richard Wagner predicted that his music would drive men mad. It did, and it does. Other composers thrill, sadden, exalt, bore, irritate or amuse. Wagner arouses feelings that alarm us about ourselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEUSSE, CHRISTINA M. (NEE COLLINS)
description: BEUSSE-Christina M. (nee Collins), Tuesday, March 25, 1997, in Essex Fells, NJ; native of County Clare, Ireland; wife of the late Harry A. Beusse, beloved mother of Robert B. of Caldwell & Jacqueline A. of Essex Fells; dear sister of Kathleen Doyle of CA., & Patrick J. Collins of Scotland; dear grandmother of Claire M. Simmons, Raleigh, NC, Patricia A. Hughes, Millburn, NJ, Brian R. Beusse, Caldwell, NJ, Donna E. McLeod, West Caldwell, NJ, Barbara Davison, Caldwell, NJ and Thomas F.X. Beusse, Westport, CT; loving great-grandmother of Matthew and Kyle Simmons, Sarah, Emily and Gregory Hughes, Julia, Audrey and Megan McLeod, Amanda Rose and Patrick Stewart Beusse, and twins Erin and Ian Davison. Funeral Mass in Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Church, 28 Livingston Ave, Roseland, NJ on Easter Monday, March 31, 10 AM. Visiting in the Farmer Funeral Home, 45 Roseland Ave. (at Eagle Rock Avenue) Roseland, N.J., Saturday, 2-4, 7-9. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to The Sisters of the Holy Child Jesus, Rosemont College, Rosemont, PA. 19010.

title: Los Angeles Mayor, Profile Low, Rides High in Election Polls
description: Two weeks ago, in the sole face-to-face encounter of their desultory contest to be Mayor of Los Angeles, State Senator Tom Hayden repeatedly derided his popular incumbent opponent, Richard J. Riordan, as ''an invisible man'' and ''an invisible Mayor,'' unfit to be ''the leader of a global city.''

title: Joseph Frayman, Journalist, 85
description: Joseph Frayman, an editor and reporter in the London bureau of The New York Times for nearly 40 years, died on March 1 at Chase Farm Hospital in London. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZISSU, NELLIE
description: ZISSU-Nellie, in Paris, March 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Benedict, devoted mother of Adrienne (Daniele Paoli) and Marianne (Charles Stone), and adored grandmother.

title: Europeans Shut the Door on Turkey's Membership in Union
description: Turkey's campaign to join the European Union within the next few years was dealt what appeared to be a fatal blow today when Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany asserted here that Turkey was far from the standard expected of new members.

title: Salvadoran Accused in Deaths of Americans Is Ordered Deported
description: A former Salvadoran guerrilla, who was resettled in the United States and paid thousands of dollars by the Central Intelligence Agency for his services as an informer, has been ordered deported to El Salvador for his role in the killings of six Americans there in 1985.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the detention of a suspect in a bombing that killed 19 Americans in Saudi Arabia last June misstated the date of the arrest in some editions. Authorities in Canada took the suspect into custody on March 18, not over the weekend.

title: Expulsion, or Jail?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Deal of The Day
description: There's a ''Grand Bargain'' just waiting to be struck that could finally reshape America's foreign-policy apparatus, pay off the U.S.'s overdue bills to the U.N. and pave the way for Senate ratification of a global treaty that will ban chemical weapons. We're talking about a big, big deal, and it's just sitting there, ready to be had. All it needs is for three leaders to show leadership: Commander in Chief Bill Clinton, Curmudgeon in Chief Jesse Helms and Republican in Chief Trent (Don't-Ask-Me-To-Do-Anything-Too-Hard) Lott.

title: Girardi Gets Turn To Play Big Brother
description: Whether it was backyard baseball, schoolyard football or even living-room checkers, Joe Girardi spent his childhood trying to be superior to his two older brothers. It is a natural story about the young sibling wanting to be big enough and talented enough to be accepted by the boys who ate dinner across from him.

title: Making Heaven From Pennies
description: AS her black limousine idled curbside one day last week, Christy Ferer was upstairs at the Dersh Feather and Trading Corporation on West 36th Street, embroiled in fierce negotiations over the cost of a bag of black plumes with an asking price of $4.25.

title: A Corked Bat? Well, Maybe
description: Now that Howard Johnson has retired, the question can be raised, and maybe answered, once and for all: did he cork his bats?

title: Another Blow to Hartford: Whalers to Leave, Rejecting Arena Offer
description: The Hartford Whalers, a hockey team whose losing record is matched only by its financial woes, rejected the state's offer of a new $147.5 million arena today and announced that they would leave Connecticut at the end of the season.

title: Hip Fractures Kill
description: To the Editor:

title: Standard & Poor's Threatens to Move Jobs to New Jersey
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, a fixture of New York City's financial industry, is threatening to move 2,000 jobs to a new waterfront office tower in New Jersey if the Giuliani administration does not grant the company special tax breaks and other incentives to remain in lower Manhattan, according to real estate executives and city officials.

title: Raines Pulls Left Hamstring
description: Tim Raines strained his left hamstring while running out a ground ball and left today's game with the Texas Rangers in the fifth inning. But the Yankee outfielder said he could play on Thursday if necessary and insisted that the injury would not cause him to be put on the disabled list.

title: Checker Cabs Make Their Last Stand in New York City
description: The father, the mother, the daughter and the tiny white Maltese dog barreled across 49th Street brimming with intent, waving at the bloated yellow taxi that seemed to have materialized from the mists of some golden age of cabs, yelling for it to stop, stop, just stop, please stop.

title: BLYTH TO BUY ENDAR FOR AS MUCH AS $45.5 MILLION
description: Blyth Industries agreed yesterday to acquire the Endar Corporation, a closely held fragrance maker, for as much as $45.5 million in stock. Blyth will exchange 1.1 million to 1.2 million common shares for Endar, giving the company a value of $41.7 million to $45.5 million based on yesterday's closing price of $37.875, up 87.5 cents. Blyth makes candles and home fragrances under the names Colonial Candle of Cape Cod, Partylite Gifts and Carolina Designs. Endar, which makes potpourri and incense under the Florasense brand, will operate from its Southern California headquarters as a Blyth unit.

title: Strong Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the final Broadway performance of ''Sunset Boulevard'' recounted an incident in Elaine Paige's curtain speech incorrectly. Though Ms. Paige seemed to introduce both her predecessors in the role of Norma Desmond in the Broadway production, Glenn Close and Betty Buckley, and the audience applauded warmly, only Miss Close was actually present.

title: Al Gore's Awkward China Trip
description: Al Gore did not look like a happy man in Beijing this week. At every turn Mr. Gore seemed to run into the White House's 1996 fund-raising abuses, and he seemed uncertain whether to flee the connection or confront it. In the end he awkwardly did some of both, making clear that the Clinton Administration was not sure exactly how to conduct relations with China in the shadow of the scandal. That is cause for worry in a year when China figures to be at the center of American diplomatic activities.

title: 'Acts of God' Taken Out Of Arkansas Relief Bill
description: The Arkansas House of Representatives relented today and agreed with Gov. Mike Huckabee that tornados, floods and earthquakes are ''natural causes,'' not ''acts of God.''

title: New Jersey Board Revokes Approval of 2 Independent Schools
description: Reversing a decision by the state's Education Commissioner, New Jersey's Board of Education withdrew approval today for two of the 18 independent public schools scheduled to open in the fall under a new state law. The board said that plans for the schools were too uncertain and that they might impose too great a financial burden on local school districts.

title: Women Who Use Estrogen Reduce Cardiac Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy's Trial Of Century May Last That Long
description: A Mafia turncoat, testifying under Government protection, drones on from behind a white screen. Journalists doodle in their notebooks. Even the 78-year-old defendant -- Giulio Andreotti, seven times Prime Minister of Italy -- seems more stooped than usual as he takes his seat in a high-security courtroom usually reserved for crime bosses and terrorists.

title: Subway Rider Slashed in Face On Busy Train
description: Shortly after saying, ''Excuse me'' to a fellow passenger who jostled him on a crowded subway train, a Brooklyn man was slashed across the face by the passenger yesterday, leaving him with a wound that required 23 stitches, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERSTATE HOTELS CO., Pittsburgh, a hotel management company, purchased the Chicago Embassy Suites Hotel from the Chicago-based Koar-Shaw Limited Partnership for about $67 million.

title: Giuliani Sues Government Over Benefits for Immigrants
description: Joined by an unlikely coalition of legal allies, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani filed suit yesterday against the Federal Government, seeking to overturn provisions of the new welfare law that cut off benefits to legal immigrants.

title: Gore in China: Still No Break in the Political Wall
description: After two days of talks with China's Communist Party leaders, Vice President Al Gore said tonight that despite domestic political pressures that are vexing Chinese-American relations, the Clinton Administration is determined to ''strengthen and broaden'' its bonds with the People's Republic.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the animated movie ''Cats Don't Dance'' misidentified the cat on the left. It was Sawyer, not Darla Dimple.

title: A Misstep Off the Court Is Followed by Many More on It
description: The women were supposed to be a follow-up act to the Lipton's main event today, an afternoon quarterfinal between top-seeded Pete Sampras and Hendrik Dreekmann, another of the young Germans intent on stepping into Boris Becker's shoes as soon as the oft-injured superstar vacates them. But Dreekmann's own shoes failed to carry him safely from a restaurant to his hotel Tuesday night, and he woke up with a sprained ankle that forced him to withdraw from his big match. Jana Novotna and Iva Majoli thus became the main event inside the sizzling stadium.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Jackson's 28 Points Lift Nets
description: It was an unveiling of sorts. Everyone knew the real Jim Jackson was under that Nets jersey somewhere, waiting to burst out. And tonight, he revealed his best game since the team's nine-player trade with the Dallas Mavericks, scoring 28 points as the Nets eased by the Philadelphia 76ers, 123-105, at Continental Arena.

title: G.O.P. Moderate in House Offers Compromise Plan on the Budget
description: A moderate Republican offered a compromise proposal today to balance the Federal budget and cut taxes, hoping to take advantage of tentative signals of flexibility issued last week by the White House and Congressional leaders.

title: Guilty Pleas in Credit Theft
description: During a two-month shopping spree last year, prosecutors say, a state trooper and his girlfriend used a fraudulently obtained American Express card to buy designer clothes, motorcycle equipment and a $7,600 diamond engagement ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, HENRY E. III
description: COE-Henry E. III. Holland Lodge #

title: Odom Is Player of Year
description: LAMAR ODOM, a 6-foot-9-inch guard who averaged 25 points, 15 rebounds, 8 assists and 3 steals a game this season for Redemption Christian Academy in Troy, N.Y., has been named Parade magazine's player of the year. Odom, who was named to the Parade all-America team last season, was one of three schoolboys from New York State voted to the team this year by college coaches, scouts and recruiters. The others were 6-8 ELTON BRAND of Peekskill High School (first team) and 6-7 RON ARTEST of LaSalle Academy in Manhattan (second team). Also on the second team of the 40-player roster, which will be published in Sunday's Parade, is ANTHONY PERRY of St. Anthony High School in Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEIZER, JANE
description: SCHWEIZER-Jane. The Members and Staff of Herzfeld & Rubin, P.C. express their profound sympathy to our colleague, C. Thomas Schweizer, and to his entire family at the passing of his beloved wife, Jane and trust that they will take comfort in their memory of their many happy years with her. Herzfeld & Rubin Herbert Rubin

title: Marching to a Different Percussionist
description: Lou Harrison will be 80 in May, but colleagues at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night moved the party up a month or so. Mr. Harrison, who was in New York to hear his own music, survives a dwindling generation of West Coast composers (Henry Cowell, Terry Riley, John Cage) who turned their backs on Europe and dipped their toes into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Criminal Immigrants Have Right to Hearing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYKIN, CHARLES
description: HAYKIN-Charles, 85, on Sun., March 23 in Margate, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Survived by wife, Evelyn, and children, Howard Haykin of NYC and Meryl Sherris of Coral Springs, FL. Teacher, administrator for 40 years in NYC Public Schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBB, BARBARA LOWRIE
description: GIBB-Barbara Lowrie, 88, passed away, March 25, 1997, at her home in Weybridge, VT. She was born in New York City on January 7, 1909, the daughter of Isabelle Forrest Lowrie and Charles N. Lowrie. She and her husband, Senator Arthur Gibb, moved to Vermont in 1951. She is survived by her husband, Senator Arthur Gibb; five children, Dwight Gibb of Seattle, Wash., Arthur Gibb, Jr. of Annapolis, Md., Lowrie Gibb, of Westport, Conn., Barbara Gibb Otsuka, of Middlebury, and Henry Gibb, of Denver, Colo., ten grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEIFFER, EDWIN L.
description: KEIFFER-Edwin L., artist, of Wakefield, RI, formerly of NYC and New Orleans. Husband of Elisabeth and father of Elizabeth McDonald of Wakefield; father of Joseph and Katharine Weiss of Manhattan; grandfather of four; brother of Esther Fisher of Washington, DC; stepson of Leonard R. Porter of Palo Alto, CA. Service at Church of the Ascension, Wakefield, R.I., April 19th, 1 PM.

title: Women-Owned Businesses
description: The number of businesses owned by women in New York City and the lower Hudson Valley has jumped by 68 percent since 1987, outpacing the 48 percent increase in the number of all firms for the same period, according to a study released today by the National Foundation for Women Business Owners, a nonprofit research group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, MAMIE R.
description: PHILLIPS-Mamie R., 72. Of NYC. Died Monday. Before retiring, she was Vice Principal at Harry S. Truman H.S. in the Bronx. She also worked for the NYC Road Runners Club. Funeral services will be held Thursday at Jenkins Funeral Chapel, 1893 Amsterdam Avenue, at 7 PM. Visiting Thursday 3-7PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIER, TOBY
description: SPIER-Toby. S/A/R Academy mourns the passing of our dear friend and long time supporter, mother of our graduates, Jonathan, Evan and Debbie Prince. May the entire family be spared further sorrow and find comfort in her memory. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Man Steals a Bus
description: An unemployed Egg Harbor man stole a New Jersey Transit bus from a garage in Orange yesterday, made a few passenger stops, then headed toward Atlantic County before he was chased and arrested, the authorities said.

title: Acceptance as Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street Shifts Focus To Earnings
description: Now that the Federal Reserve has raised its short-term interest rate target, Wall Street is turning its focus again to corporate earnings.

title: American Topics
description: For years they did it on the sly, lurking in their kitchens and feeling guilty about it. Then Norm Hankoff had an inspiration. While wolfing down tuna salad over his sink, using extra-strength potato chips as utensils, he decided it was time to remove the cloud over the table-impaired. He formed the International Association of People Who Dine Over the Kitchen Sink, and decreed the day after Thanksgiving to be Sinkie Day. In 1994, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was looking for an American chef, Mr. Hankoff sent a letter suggesting "an alternative style of dining." Mrs. Clinton's reply: a polite "No." But Mr. Hankoff suspects the president was privately intrigued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOORKA, RACHEL
description: SKOORKA-Rachel. On March 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Loving mother of Susan. Dear aunt of Bernard. Much love and rest in peace. Visiting this evening, 7-9 PM. Service Friday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Familiar History Meets Theater and Turns Into Epiphany
description: Just when you think it has been laid to rest, history -- or at least the part of history you've lived through -- rears up and seizes you by the throat. Bare facts are hard enough, let alone voices and images. To look back at yourself and the people you believed in and followed; to see the consequences of all you did wrong, even though (especially though) you were right about so much; to see what was lost through greed, vanity or plain old naivete: all of this can turn you to stone.

title: Inspired Knicks Win Their 50th
description: It began when Patrick Ewing leaped over the Detroit bench for a loose ball in the first quarter. Charles Oakley's jersey was splattered with blood after several lunges into the crowd.

title: No Free 'Skyboxes'
description: To the Editor:

title: India's Friendly Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk-Show Banishment Smacks of Papal Index
description: To the Editor:

title: London's BMP DDB Retools Media Unit
description: BMP DDB in London, the British agency of DDB Needham Worldwide, has reorganized its media services department under the separate name of BMP Optimum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HELENE
description: KATZ-Helene. The Social Work Department of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center is saddened by the loss of our dear colleague and friend, Helene Katz. Helene was held in esteemed by all who had the opportunity to work with her. She touched so many lives. We extend heartfelt condolences and wishes for healing to her family.

title: Democratic Leader Questions Fund-Raising Rules
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee today questioned the fairness and wisdom of two of the new restrictions on the party's campaign contributions from foreigners that were announced barely two months ago by President Clinton.

title: Big Board Fines D. H. Blair Firm
description: The D. H. Blair & Company brokerage firm was censured and fined $250,000 for failing to supervise brokers who had prompted numerous customer complaints with high-pressure sales tactics, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday about the concentration of wireless telecommunications companies around San Diego referred incorrectly to the 1996 financial results of one of the companies, Hughes Network Systems. It had revenue, not net sales, of $1 billion. The company does not report net sales, a figure that omits some sources of income included in revenue.

title: Greenspan's Whim
description: Why did Alan Greenspan raise interest rates? Because he could. Because two of the more independent members of the Federal Reserve Board, the pro-growth conservative Lawrence Lindsey and the moderate Janet Yellen, have departed. Because he has been under pressure from banks and bond traders for two years; why not throw them a bone? Because he knows the Clinton Administration will say and do nothing in protest. And, especially, because he can get away with it.

title: 2 Gossip Columnists Leave Daily News
description: Pete Hamill, the new editor of The Daily News, has begun remaking the staff. Yesterday, he accepted the resignations of A. J. Benza and Michael Lewittes, who have written the ''Hot Copy'' gossip column for four years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DR. OSCAR
description: GOLDBERG-Dr. Oscar, Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Irma for 57 years. Dedicated obstetrician and gynecologist. Devoted father of Nancy Sweder and Dr. Leslie Goldberg. Loving father-inlaw of Dr. Gerald Sweder and Zehava Goldberg. Adored grandfather of Danielle, Shelley, Lauren, & Michael. Dear brother of Hilda Jackere. Services Friday, March 28, at 12 noon. Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Head of Bankrupt Charity Fund Pleads No Contest in Fraud Case
description: After trying to blame phantom voices that he said gave him bad financial advice, the man accused of cheating universities and charities of more than $100 million pleaded no contest today to Federal charges of fraud and money laundering.

title: House Proud
description: FOR Mark Lender, who grew up in a poor neighborhood of Boston, nature always hovered a little out of reach. He wanted it closer.

title: No Headline
description: ''I had a teacher once who said that Italy was the

title: MOTOROLA WINS $1.5 BILLION CELLULAR CONTRACT
description: Motorola Inc. has won a contract said by analysts to be worth $1.5 billion or more to supply cellular phone equipment to the DDI Corporation and Nippon Idou Tsushin, an affiliate of the Toyota Motor Corporation. The two companies are building a nationwide wireless network in Japan, which is the world's fastest-growing cellular market. The contract gives a big lift to the code-division multiple-access technology that Motorola will use. The technology was developed by Qualcomm Inc. Motorola's shares climbed $2.1875, to $60.5625. Shares of Qualcomm rose $1.75, to $61.25, and shares of the DSC Communications Corporation, which will provide switches and software for the networks, rose 50 cents, to $23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SIDNEY O.
description: SHAPIRO-Sidney O., of Greenwich Village, 83, died March 25, 1997. The family warmly welcomes all those who knew him to join them, at home on West 12th Street any time between 1-5 PM this Saturday, 29 March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHAN, CAROLE
description: COHAN-Carole. On March 26, 1997. Deeply loved mother of Leslie, sister of Felice and friend to many. She was senior vice president at McCann-Erickson, N.Y. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Friday 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston St., N.Y. 10014. Memorial service to be announced.

title: What to Do When a Child Should Do Better but Can't
description: WHEN Henry was 6, his teacher called his mother to complain that the boy had talked back to her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, HAMILTON FISH
description: POTTER-Hamilton Fish, Jr. Of NYC and St. James, L.I. Suddenly on March 21, in Sun Valley, ID. Funeral service at 10 AM on Sat., March 29, at All Saints Episcopal Church, 230 E. 60 St, NYC. Burial after at St. James Episcopal Church, 490 N. Country Rd (25AEast), St. James, L.I., followed by a reception. In lieu of flowers, donations to either church or to ''Hamilton F. Potter '24 Scholarship Fund,'' Harvard College, 124 Mt. Auburn St, Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: Despite Fire, Electric Chair Is Defended In Florida
description: In a state with one of the highest number of inmates awaiting execution, a malfunctioning electric chair that caused a prisoner's mask to erupt in flames has drawn widespread condemnation from death penalty opponents but only cautious concern from officials reluctant to change the way Florida kills its criminals.

title: Daimler-Benz Rebounds With $1.7 Billion Profit
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. rebounded from a record loss in 1995 to a higher-than-expected profit of 2.8 billion marks ($1.7 billion) in 1996. The auto maker's net profit, compared with a loss of 5.7 billion marks ($3.4 billion) in 1995, was nearly 40 percent greater than most analysts had expected. Daimler attributed the increase in profit in part ''to the one-time effect of deferred taxes.''

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Easter Finery at Wave Hill

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's not every day you see a man wearing a cowboy hat, plaid shirt, green jeans and an oversize silver belt buckle walking around Central Park with the Mayor of New York.

title: In Plan to Cut L.I. Utility Rates, Biggest Savings Come Early
description: The state's plan to lower Long Island's electric rates delivers the greatest savings to consumers in the first few years, beginning as Gov. George E. Pataki campaigns for re-election next year. To do so, it raises the cost to consumers by more than $1 billion during the next 30 years.

title: Blood Sport II: Revenge of the Red Wings
description: On this long, bloody night, the two goalies were better at throwing punches than stopping pucks. Patrick Roy of Colorado and Mike Vernon of Detroit were only two of many combatants in a violent three-hour battle for Western Conference momentum as the Stanley Cup playoffs approach.

title: Ready to Focus, Gophers Show Up Early
description: The hoopla was just too much. Minnesota Coach Clem Haskins had to get his team out of town as quickly as possible. So, Haskins whisked his players away from Minneapolis yesterday to Indianapolis, where the din of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball championship countdown, the Final Four, is just now building.

title: Officer in Shooting Resigns
description: James Consalvo, the New Brunswick police officer who fatally shot a woman in September while trying to arrest her, resigned Monday, a day before his departmental disciplinary hearing was scheduled to begin, police officials said. The internal charges against Officer Consalvo were withdrawn once he agreed to leave the department by April 1.

title: U.S. Investigates Campaign Gift to Teamster Chief
description: Teamster officials said yesterday that a Federal grand jury in Manhattan was investigating whether a $95,000 contribution to the campaign of Ron Carey, the union's president, was an illegal kickback.

title: The New New Left
description: Is it possible that when the ascendant Newt Gingrich of '94 wrapped himself in the Leninist revolutionary rhetoric of the New Left, he wasn't kidding? Two years later -- as Mr. Gingrich slinks behind Al Gore to make nice to the Chinese -- it's becoming as easy to mistake the Republicans for McGovern Democrats as it is to mistake the Democrats for Rockefeller Republicans. Ideological cross-dressing, far from being a passing expedience concocted by Dick Morris and Bill Clinton for a re-election campaign, has turned into a bipartisan rage.

title: Visit Home Puts Lessons of Washington in Check
description: Senator Susan M. Collins is finding her first weeks of incumbency in Washington startling for the advice from more experienced political professionals that she had better start raising money now -- even before she has moved into a permanent Capitol office -- for a re-election bid in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNSTEIN, GERTRUDE
description: HORNSTEIN-Gertrude. The Hebrew Academy of Nassau County mourns the passing of Gertrude Hornstein, a gracious and beloved friend. She and her late husband, Moses Hornstein, pursued many philanthropic endeavors. Their magnanimity helped make many of the Hebrew Academy of Nassau County's dreams, and aspirations of other institutions, reality. Her love and devotion were always felt by family and friends. Gertrude Hornstein was a grand lady and she brings to a close an era never to be replicated. Our sincerest condolences to children Larry and Francine Hornstein and Judy and Eugene Goldman, grandchildern Meryl and Mark Nachbar, David Hornstein, Pam and Danny Fried, Jeff and Laurie Goldberger, Michael and Robin goldman, sisters Eve Ferster, Ann Holtzer, Jean Tierney, Helen, and Roslyn. Rabbi Moshe Gottesman, Dean Rabbi Yussie Lieber,Admin. Harvey S. Liebman, President Isaac Blachor, Chairman of Board

title: British Leave Hong Kong In Sour Kind of Grandeur
description: This summer brings Britain an emotive reminder of how the empire was supposed to end, the 50th anniversary of the independence of India, and the rude truth of how rancorously it is in fact ending -- the distressed return of Hong Kong to China.

title: As Value Falls, PBHG Funds Suffer a Wave of Redemptions
description: PBHG Funds, one of the best-performing mutual fund companies of the 1990's, has suffered shareholder redemptions of more than 6 percent of the company's assets in recent weeks, as the performance of its funds has dropped sharply.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Thursday about the breaking of a code meant to protect the privacy of calls made with the new digital generation of cellular telephones overstated the extent to which the code is used in wireless formats. One leading format, global system for mobile communications, or GSM, does not use the code that three computer security researchers cracked and is not affected by the security problem. Two other leading wireless formats -- code-division multiple access, or CDMA, and time-division multiple access, or TDMA -- use the code and therefore are affected.

title: Deaths at Season's Change Echo Earlier Suicides
description: Neither the identity of the victims in what appeared to be a mass suicide near San Diego nor the precise nature of their deaths was clear last night. But the incident inevitably prompted comparisons to a series of recent mass suicides by members of a small, socially isolated religious group that have occurred near the changes of the seasons.

title: Huge Indonesia Gold Strike May Have Been Exaggerated
description: In a stunning reversal of fortune, a tiny Canadian company that once said it had made the world's richest gold strike in the jungles of Indonesia conceded today that it had probably overestimated the size of its find.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, Tours and Lectures
description: Building Green

title: Hostetler Backup for O'Donnell?
description: Jeff Hostetler, who became expendable with the Raiders after they signed Jeff George, has a dilemma. He once led the Giants to a Super Bowl and is wrestling with the possibility of returning to Giants Stadium as a backup to the Jets' Neil O'Donnell.

title: Big Field for the Gotham
description: A traffic jam seemed to be developing yesterday for the Gotham Mile, which has become New York's first major prep race for horses trying to find running room on the road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECHLIN, LETITIA
description: ECHLIN-Letitia, on March 1, aged 85 years, in Mexico. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Francis A. Echlin. Loving mother of Vals Osborne of New York, Diana Gillam of London, and Johanna Echlin Bastian of Montreal. Cherished grandmother of Tony, Alessandra, Letitia, Luke, Jane, and Jason. A Memorial Fund has been established in her name, in support of theatre arts and environmental conservation. (212-727-7861).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, DAVID D.
description: WELLS-David D. Of Anniston, Alabama, March 15, Centre Island, Oyster Bay. Memorial service on March 31, at 11 A.M., St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, New York. Contributions to Oyster Bay Sailing Foundation, Box 720, Oyster Bay, New York 11771.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL PUTS AMERICAN STATES UNIT ON BLOCK
description: The Lincoln National Corporation is seeking a buyer for its American States Financial Corporation property and casualty insurance unit. Analysts said that selling American States could raise as much as $1.9 billion for Lincoln, of Fort Wayne, Ind., which sold a 17 percent stake in the Indianapolis-based unit to investors last May. American States shares gained $2.75, to $35, on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock of Lincoln, the eighth-largest publicly traded insurer ranked by assets, was down $1.25 a share at $56.625.

title: SHAREHOLDERS REJECT PLANNED FOREST PRODUCTS MERGER
description: Avenor Inc. shareholders voted yesterday to reject the company's proposed acquisition of Repap Enterprises Inc. Avenor's chief executive acknowledged that shareholders, more than 74 percent of whom voted against the transaction, were worried by the debt involved. Avenor would have paid about $380 million (Canadian) in stock and assumed $2.26 billion in Repap debt. Avenor said earlier that it had rebuffed a merger proposal by a third company, Domtar Inc., a packaging maker that said later that it remained interested in a possible three-way deal. The companies are based in Montreal.

title: Giving Away the Airwaves
description: The Clinton Administration, Congress and the Federal Communications Commission are about to make the already difficult job of balancing the Federal budget harder than it has to be. In just a few days, the F.C.C. is going to give away the first broadcast licenses for digital television to broadcasters for absolutely nothing. If the Government sold this new spectrum, it could be worth $12 billion to $70 billion.

title: When to Blame the Teachers
description: Failing public schools have little time to prove that they deserve public support, let alone the millions of additional dollars many educators say they need to do their jobs more effectively. It was with this in mind that the Philadelphia superintendent of schools, David Hornbeck, recently took control of two failing high schools and announced that three-quarters of the teachers would be transferred elsewhere for failing to improve student performance.

title: Commissioner Deals With Sensitive Issue In a Masterly Way
description: David Stern sent the right message yesterday.

title: Dancing to a Mighty Mighty Revival Revival
description: Good intentions reign with the Mighty Mighty Bosstones, who headlined a ska-punk triple bill at Webster Hall on Monday night. Their lyrics denounce racism, warn against drug use and praise determination, all in peppy tunes whose main job is to keep the audience dancing. On the ska circuit, fans party with a clear conscience.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Mental illness has become less and less a family secret. Today, MARY WALLACE, the wife of MIKE WALLACE, the correspondent on CBS's ''60 Minutes,'' will receive the first National Family Achievement Award from the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, a nonprofit group in Arlington, Va., and Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, EDWARD J.
description: SAGER-Edward J. March 25, 1997. A long employee of NY Library at Lincoln Center (Art & Theatre Department). Brother of Mary A. Sager, Emma O'Toole and the late Thomas J. Relatives and friends are invited to his viewing, Monday 9am, followed by funeral Mass 10am, Ascension of Our Lord Church. ''F'' & Westmoreland St, Philadelphia, PA. Interment Our Lady of Grace Cemetery. Donations to your favorite charity preferred.

title: West Bank Strife Spreads as Israel Awaits U.S. Mediator
description: Palestinians and Israelis traded rocks and rubber bullets for the seventh day in the West Bank today as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu awaited the arrival of Washington's Middle East mediator and pondered whether to bring the opposition Labor Party into his Government.

title: Lower Madison Avenue May Be Site of Two New Restaurants
description: Completing a $300 million renovation, the owner of a 29-story building at Madison Avenue and 24th Street is negotiating with two of New York's most acclaimed restaurateurs to open large restaurants there, people familiar with the talks said.

title: Quiet Community Is Home To Celebrities and the Rich
description: The Southern California town where yesterday's apparent mass suicide took place is one of the most affluent and bucolic towns in the United States, a sun-baked bastion of old money where the local real estate brokers like to say that there is a Mercedes in every garage and a horse in every barn.

title: Democratic Party Unable to Pay Debts From Last Year's Elections
description: The Democratic National Committee is in its most precarious financial position in decades, facing debts of $14.4 million and projected legal bills of $4 million in the next year alone, party officials said today.

title: Father-Daughter Motif, Times Three
description: As the current season dribbles into rerun time, the networks once again seem mired in ruts. Consider only CBS. In adventurous casting ploys, the network has brought back several leading men whose careers are rooted in television. Apart from Bill Cosby and Ted Danson on the sitcom front, there can be found in new drama formats Peter Strauss in ''Moloney'' (Thursdays at 9), Larry Hagman in ''Orleans''(now Fridays at 9) and Don Johnson in ''Nash Bridges'' (Fridays at 10). All have remarkably similar elements. None are breakout hits. One, possibly two, might survive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Movie Crew, Not Welcome In Brooklyn, Makes an Exit
description: A film crew, forced to shut down production Tuesday after being confronted by hundreds of Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn, moved to a location in Chinatown yesterday, city officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, THE HON. MARIE M.
description: LAMBERT-The Hon. Marie M. Former Surrogate Judge New York County. Beloved wife of the late Grady Lee. Loving mother of Gregory. Devoted sister of Gloria Diemer and Charles Courtright. Reposing Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 St., Saturday and Sun. 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection at St. Peter's R.C. Church, 16 Barclay St., Monday 10 A.M.

description: THE BIG PICTURE

title: Ex-Japanese Bureaucrat Admits Accepting Bribes
description: A former senior bureaucrat pleaded guilty today to accepting about half a million dollars in bribes in a case that has focused attention on corruption in Japan's Government.

title: 16 Countries And Still Speaking
description: FOR some people, the definition of a family outing is hauling a pack of Oscar Mayers and a bag of charcoal to the beach. But if you are intellectually ambitious, sophisticated New Yorkers -- like Richard Reeves, an author and syndicated political columnist, and his wife, Catherine O'Neill, a refugee advocate and founder of the Women's Commission for Women and Children Refugees -- you recruit your extensive family, including children from previous marriages, and take off for the great, global beyond.

title: U.S. Expels a Belarus Diplomat, and Warns of Repression There
description: The United States ordered the expulsion of a Belarus diplomat today in retaliation for what Washington called the ''unwarranted and unjustified'' ouster of an American diplomat monitoring an anti-Government march Sunday in Minsk, the capital of Belarus.

title: Whalers' Decision Gives Expansion Hopefuls a 2d Option
description: The Whalers' decision to leave Hartford after this season opens a second front in the feverish hunt by cities to join the National Hockey League.

title: Is This City Big Enough For Gardens And Houses?
description: A FEW weeks ago, two gardeners sat in the freezing sleet under a pergola in the Garden of the Golden Lions in central Harlem. They were grappling with the news that three community gardens on 121st Street, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and St. Nicholas Avenue, would have to close by the end of this month.

title: Philip Morris Names New No. 2 Officer
description: The Philip Morris Companies promoted its top international tobacco executive, William Webb, to chief operating officer yesterday, making him the prime candidate to succeed Geoffrey C. Bible as chairman and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTENBERG, SIDNEY
description: GUTTENBERG-Sidney. Beloved husband of 54 years of Rae. Loving brother of Roslyn Gladstein, Morris Berkowitz and Jean Karis. Cherished uncle and great-uncle. We will miss your wit, kindness and understanding.

title: When Money Counts
description: DESK chairs are rarely known for their sense of chic. But a chair that is practical and posture-supporting does not have to be style-bereft. Nor expensive. Attractive, affordable alternatives do exist. And a few can make the transition from office mate to home accent at a moment's notice.

title: Currents: New York Gift Show
description: THE New York Gift Show last month was a shopper's dream: 584,970 square feet of covetables for home and garden, mind and body, people and pets, purveyed by 2,800 exhibitors from around the world. It was open to the trade only, but many of the products are already trickling into stores.

title: Bulls Lose Rodman For Last 13 Games
description: Dennis Rodman will miss the remainder of the regular season with an injured left knee, the Chicago Bulls announced yesterday.

title: Criticizing Giuliani, Council Proposes a New Budget Strategy
description: The City Council's leadership staked out its first bargaining position yesterday in negotiations over the next budget, asserting that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's spending plan lacked imagination and underestimated the growth in tax revenues from Wall Street by $516 million.

title: Richard Marsh, 58, Cow-Disease Researcher
description: Richard F. Marsh, whose research in veterinary science at the University of Wisconsin at Madison led him to sound an alarm about the risks of mad cow disease a decade before the outbreak of the disease in Britain last year, died on Sunday at his home in Middleton, Wis. He was 58.

title: Clinton Names Panel to Draft Health Consumer Bill of Rights
description: President Clinton today appointed a 34-member advisory panel to draft a bill of rights for health care consumers and to assess the need for the Federal Government to regulate private health insurance plans.

title: Three big food companies, fast and otherwise, shuffle accounts worth nearly $200 million.
description: FOR the third time in a week, a number of big national advertisers have all changed agencies on the same day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABO, MILDRED CATHERINE
description: SABO-Mildred Catherine, passed away in California on March 23, 1997. Daughter of the late William Ronald and the late Susan Adelia Ronald. She was born in Brooklyn and lived in Lakewood, N.J. Employed at the Dime Savings Bank in Brooklyn until 1974. Wife of Eugene G. Sabo, predeceased by previous husband, Alfred E. Kayser. Survived by son William Ronald Jones and daughter in law, Beverly Ann Jones of San Francisco, sister Dorothy Hilziner and 3 grandchildren. Services Saturday 10:00 A.M. at D'Elia Funeral Home, Lakewoood, New Jersey.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Can a transit police officer suddenly become a television star?

title: Pictures Worth a Thousand Dollars
description: Tonight's ''Turning Point'' finds Robert Krulwich on the trail of photographers, a k a paparazzi, who are on the trail of the likes of Madonna, John F. Kennedy Jr. and Michael Jackson's wife. A really embarrassing picture could mean a windfall for the shooter.

title: Hearst to Buy Argyle TV In a Rare Public Venture
description: In a deal that furthers the consolidation of the television broadcasting business, the Hearst Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Argyle Television Inc., an owner of six stations, for $320 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ELEANOR WILSON
description: WALSH-Eleanor Wilson. Passed away on March 25th at the age of 86 in Palm Springs, CA. Mother of John and Patrick Walsh; Sister of Suzanne Wilson, Marjorie Wilson O'Neill and Frederick Wilson; Grandmother of Caroline, Laurie, Frederick, Anne and Peter Walsh. Born in Spokane, WA. to Frederick Wilson and Mabel Welch Wilson, she married John J. Walsh in 1937. While living in Mamaroneck, NY, from 1949 to 1978 she was a trustee of United Hospital in Port Chester, NY, for which she was a volunteer. She helped to establish the Westchester Classic Golf Tournament for the benefit of United Hospital. After the retirement of her husband as Vice Chairman of Walsh Construction Company of New York City, she moved to Palm Desert, CA. in 1978, where her husband died in 1983. Private services were held in Palm Desert.

title: Stanford Is Now the Favorite
description: When the Final Four of women's basketball begins at the Riverfront Coliseum, Stanford will be a strong favorite. Few people think the Cardinal (34-1) will have trouble with Old Dominion (33-1) in Friday night's semifinals and Tennessee (27-10) or Notre Dame (31-6) in Sunday night's final.

title: No Super-Babes
description: To the Editor:

title: Veba of Germany to Trade on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced its sixth German listing yesterday, as the electric utility Veba A.G. said its American depository receipts would start trading in October.

title: Support for a Throwback Military
description: Just a month ago, the Clinton Administration gave Colombia failing grades on its cooperation with counter-narcotics efforts and declared that Colombia was sending as much cocaine as ever northward. Nevertheless, the Administration is now proposing a $40 million package of aid to Colombia's police and military to fight drugs. This comes on top of at least $35 million in equipment and training the military is already scheduled to get this year. Last year the United States gave the Colombian military zero.

title: Rangers See Difference in Devils: Gilmour
description: Rangers Coach Colin Campbell is not often afforded the opportunity to do his scouting firsthand.

title: Man at Home Is Kidnapped
description: Gunmen wearing badges and using walkie-talkies kidnapped a man Tuesday in a carefully planned, drug-related attack, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Net Income Up 16.6%, To $2.3 Billion, at Nestle
description: Nestle S.A., the world's largest food and beverage maker, said yesterday that its net income had risen a better-than-expected 16.6 percent in 1996. Nestle's earnings reached a record 3.4 billion Swiss francs ($2.3 billion), up from 2.92 billion francs ($2 billion) a year earlier. It was the fifth increase in six years.

title: Can a Couple Find Luxury On Welfare?
description: GUY AND ANN LOUISE-JULIE live with their four children in a house that almost screams money, big and new.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, IRVING
description: KANE-Irving. The Board of Delegates, Officers and Staff of the Council of Jewish Federations mourn the passing of Irving Kane. From 1959-62, he led CJF as its President and in the ensuing years he continued to play an influential role as a member of our Executive Committee. We shall miss his wise counsel and guidance. Dr. Conrad L. Giles, CJF President Martin S. Kraar, CJF Exec. VP

title: Russell Is Ready for Whatever the Jets Throw His Way
description: Bill Parcells does not scare him, taking the bus was never beneath him and All-Pros are built just like him. The Jets have a draft choice waiting for them at the Big Man/Tall Man shop -- if they care to drop by -- and the shock is that the draft choice also dunks basketballs.

title: U.S. of Future: Grayer and More Hispanic
description: A new report by the Census Bureau documents explosive growth in the nation's Hispanic population and projects that by the year 2005, Hispanic Americans will surpass blacks as the country's largest minority.

title: 39 Men Found at San Diego Estate in Apparent Suicide
description: Sheriff's deputies responding to a call in a luxurious hillside community north of San Diego this afternoon discovered the bodies of at least 39 young men inside a million-dollar estate, the apparent victims of a mass suicide.

title: From the Bronx to Tallahassee, With Guts
description: Kerry Thompson smiled when someone suggested to him that there was something special about New York City point guards.

title: Chicago Neighborhood Reveals an Ugly Side
description: For the last few days, a parade of politicians and preachers have made their way to the bedside of a comatose 13-year-old black boy to pray for his recovery and for the city's soul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINER, BARBARA
description: KLEINER-Barbara, on March 26, 1997. Devoted wife of Jack and beloved mother of Robert, Michael and Richard. She brought happiness to everyone who knew her; and always knew where my brown shoes were. Funeral private.

title: With Questionable Future, 47th St. Photo Closes Doors
description: A landmark name in New York electronics retailing for 30 years, 47th Street Photo, has closed down, laid off its work force and may not reopen.

title: Francis J. McGee, 75, Tactician Who Taught Police How to Shoot
description: Francis J. McGee, a retired police lieutenant who spent more than two decades teaching New York's Finest how to shoot better by firing faster, died on March 3 at the home of his son, David, in Kirkland Hills, Ohio. He was 75 and had lived in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx.

title: With New Restrictions at Hand, U.S. Tries to Allay Fear Among Immigrants
description: Promising that there would be no mass deportations, Federal immigration officials yesterday outlined the complex, far-reaching requirements of a new law that are expected to make life harder for legal and illegal immigrants alike.

title: Berard's Goal Is Clincher
description: The Islanders entered tonight's game searching for any kind of an edge over Buffalo. Their three previous outings against the Sabres had proved fruitless, as Buffalo, the first-place team in the Northeast Division, won all three. But tonight, Buffalo was without its offensive catalyst, its designated tough guy and the best goaltender in the league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, MARCIA
description: EHRLICH-Marcia. On March 25, 1997. Loving wife of the late Dr. David. Loving & devoted mother of Roberta Elise and Suzanne Aronowitz. Grandmother or Lorraine and Ruth. Great-grandmother of Peri, and loving sister of Marvin and Lee. Services on Friday, 12 Noon, at Schwartz Bros Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: How much is the environment worth? A step toward answers.
description: HOW much, in dollars and cents, is the environment really worth?

title: INSIDE METRO
description: NEW YORK FIRM LOOKS ELSEWHERE -- Standard & Poor's is considering moving its offices to New Jersey, government and real estate executives say. Metro Business, B9.

title: A Troupe Discovers How to Be What It Is
description: The White Oak Dance Project, directed by Mikhail Baryshnikov, is presenting two programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Saturday night.

title: Albright Will Warm Up to Iraq if Hussein Goes
description: The United States is going to continue to try to isolate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and is ready to move quickly to develop normal relations with a successor, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today.

title: Payout Halts; Northeast Utilities Stock Falls
description: The stock of Northeast Utilities fell sharply yesterday after the company's announcement on Tuesday that it had suspended its dividend.

title: Vision Tests for Rail Engineers Vary, and May Deceive
description: The Federal standard for testing locomotive engineers for color-blindness is extremely simple, requiring that an engineer recognize and distinguish between the colors of signals. But the Government is silent on how railroads should test engineers' vision, and to fill that vacuum, many rail lines, including New Jersey Transit, have chosen tests that ophthalmologists say are not reliable.

title: Bridge
description: The best way for young players to make a mark in the tournament world is to do well in knockout team events, where they can expect to clash with experts vastly superior in experience and reputation. Doing just that in a seven-week period at the beginning of the year were John Ramos, Brady Richter, Scott Bieber and Mark Paltrowitz, all of Manhattan.

title: Yeltsin Tells Russians That Bending on the NATO Issue Paid Off
description: Answering critics who accuse him of capitulating to the West on NATO expansion, President Boris N. Yeltsin today defended his conciliatory stance at his summit meeting in Helsinki last week with President Clinton.

title: Durables Post Surprise Gain; 2d Big Month
description: In a show of unexpected strength, orders for big-ticket factory goods jumped sharply again in February, suggesting that the economy was gaining momentum as it began its seventh year of expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, JOHN BANCROFT
description: WEBSTER-John Bancroft. March 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Ursula Kreutzer Webster. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, Mar. 28, 3PM with service following at 6 PM. Interment Saturday, March 29, 1 PM.

description: In percent

title: Testing a Wider Concept of Sexual Harassment
description: There is no law against being an obnoxious tyrannical boss, even though thousands of employees probably have fantasized about one. But a growing number of women are now seeking to expand the reach of the Federal statute that prohibits employment discrimination in an effort to strike back at bosses who they contend have made their lives miserable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, NETTIE
description: STEINMAN-Nettie. Died peacefully on March 26. A leader in her community, she served as president of Hadassah, Manhattan Beach. Beloved mother of Robert and David. Grandmother of Peter and Jonathan. Great grandmother of Sam and Douglas. She will be greatly missed. Services Friday 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: France's Cowboys (Yup!) Fight for Their Range
description: Spring is barely here but its energy is already surging through the Camargue, France's large southern wetlands, where the Rhone meets the Mediterranean.

title: STAKES IN 5 CANADIAN SHOPPING CENTERS TO CHANGE HANDS
description: Cambridge Shopping Centers Ltd. agreed yesterday to sell its interests in five shopping centers to Ontrea Inc. for $229.4 million. Cambridge, a Toronto-based real estate company, said four of the centers -- Chinook Center in Calgary, Alberta; Intercity Shopping Center in Thunder Bay, Ontario; New Sudbury Center in Sudbury, Ontario, and Markville Shopping Center in Markham, Ontario -- are owned by it and Ontrea. The fifth, Bayshore Shopping Center in Ottawa, is owned by Cambridge and Ivanhoe III Inc. of Montreal. In a related transaction, Cambridge said Ivanhoe, which owns one-third of Bayshore, would exercise its right to purchase Ontrea's interest in the property, which would give Ivanhoe full ownership of Bayshore.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN AGREES TO BUY WYNDHAM
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. has agreed to buy the Wyndham Hotel Corporation for an estimated $640 million, a person familiar with the deal said yesterday. The transaction would allow Patriot American, which is based in Dallas, to rename its existing hotels as Wyndhams and eliminate franchise fees. It would also gain ownership of Wyndham's 23 upscale hotels and management of 73 more. Calls to the Dallas-based Wyndham were not returned. A spokeswoman confirmed Patriot American was ''exploring the purchase of a hotel brand and management company'' but would not identify the company. And Bloomberg News reported that Patriot had denied that it had reached an agreement with Wyndham. The Wall Street Journal reported in February that Patriot American was talking with Wyndham. The news sent Wyndham's stock price up from $25 to more than $31, but since then the stock has slipped. It closed at $27.75 yesterday, down 75 cents.

Henry Dreyfuss, the industrial designer, was the master mandala maker of the American century. Dreyfuss was an industrial designer at a time when industry was a state religion, a faith as yet unsullied by evidence of cultural and environmental degradation. ''Henry Dreyfuss Directing Design,'' a major show now at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, recalls a time when dialing the phone or setting the thermostat had the aura of ritual acts, tantamount to turning the prayer wheels of progress.

title: Son Sentenced in Killing
description: A Rockaway man who killed his mother on Mother's Day was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison.

title: CALIBER TO REVAMP DIVISION AND CUT 4,000 JOBS
description: Caliber System Inc. said yesterday that it would reorganize its Viking Freight Inc. division, which is based in San Jose, Calif., because of its steep losses. The move would result in the elimination of 4,000 jobs and a $150 million charge against previously reported 1996 earnings. As part of the reorganization, Caliber would sell its former Central Freight Lines unit and close its former Coles Express and Spartan Express units. Caliber will take unspecified additional charges in the first quarter of 1997, said Dina Gruey, a Caliber spokeswoman.

title: CHRONICLE

title: Another Group Switches on Frequency of Mammograms
description: Reversing its position, the National Cancer Institute said today that women in their 40's should have breast X-rays every one to two years.

title: Canadian Gold Stock Investors Strike It Poor
description: With much of the shine already off what had only weeks ago been considered one of the richest gold strikes in history, investors who had bought into Bre-X Minerals Ltd. and its elusive gold find in Indonesia took a beating today when the stock lost more than 80 percent of its value.

title: S.E.C. ASKED TO REVIEW GREAT WESTERN DEAL
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company said yesterday that it was asking the Securities and Exchange Commission to review the terms of Washington Mutual Inc.'s agreement to acquire the Great Western Financial Corporation. In a letter to regulators, Ahmanson said Washington Mutual cannot use the pooling-of-interest accounting method because it planned to repurchase shares on the open market in addition to buying treasury shares. First Bank System Inc. abandoned its proposed takeover of First Interstate Bancorporation last year after the S.E.C. said it could only use the pooling method if it suspended its stock buybacks. Wells Fargo & Company eventually acquired First Interstate. It was the latest move by Ahmanson in its hostile takeover bid for Great Western, which it began on Feb. 17. Great Western instead accepted a bid from Washington Mutual, which is based in Seattle.

title: As Scary Ailment Heals, Gatling Finds a Smile
description: A half smile on Chris Gatling's face revealed an upturn in his spirits, a sign that he knows the rest of his grin is slowly but surely going to come around.

title: AST and States in Used-Computer Accord
description: AST Research agreed today to stop selling used computers as new under a deal reached with 21 states.

title: Derby Hopefuls to Seek Turnaround in Gotham
description: Pulpit will not be there, and neither will Captain Bodgit. But 12 other 3-year-old colts will gather at Aqueduct tomorrow for the Gotham Stakes in a mass effort to race through the door to the Kentucky Derby that was left open two weeks ago when Captain Bodgit won the Florida Derby and destroyed the myth of Pulpit's invincibility.

title: From Bubble Gum To Bubble-Car Auction
description: In the years after World War II, a ravaged Germany had a desperate need for affordable transportation, and companies like BMW and Messerschmitt were eager to use their factories to build consumer products rather than implements of destruction. Thus was born a group of small-engined microcars, often known now as ''bubble cars'' in reference to their often-transparent roofs.

description: NERVE GAS RULED OUT -- Officials said that despite earlier concerns, they did not find nerve gas in a home in Queens. B3.

title: New Paths to Mideast Peace
description: With diplomacy stalled and civil violence spreading on the West Bank, the Clinton Administration has sent its Mideast mediator, Dennis Ross, back to the region. Once again he will try to revitalize the search for peace. Some imaginative new thinking is required to break the cycle of repeated crises.

title: South Africa's New Army Is All Soft and Cuddly
description: ''I'm sorry,'' said Lieut. Col. Charl de Klerk, just before the dawn departure from Pretoria for the General De Wet Training Center here. ''This isn't going to be the exciting stuff, like tanks and artillery. This is 'Hello, let me kiss you,' stuff.''

title: No Ego Trips Or Scandals. Just Champs.
description: MENTION sports in New York City, and the images that come to mind all too often are of whining millionaires, be they bilious owners or pampered players. So it is refreshing to be able to cast cynicism to the winds (at least for a moment) and talk about a group of young athletes who are what young athletes are supposed to be: talented, hard-working and -- best of all -- untouched by the ''show me the money'' madness that afflicts so many nominal amateurs, convinced the ability to stuff a ball into a hoop gives them rights to free Lamborghinis.

title: Protecting the Managed-Care Patient
description: President Clinton made an election-year promise to appoint a panel that would address consumer anxieties about the quality of medical care in an era of market-driven health plans. Whatever its purpose as a campaign ploy, the commission, appointed yesterday, could not come at a better time.

title: 14 Securities Executives Resign from ING Barings
description: ING Barings, the investment banking arm of ING Groep N.V., said yesterday that 14 securities executives in Asia had resigned, including the core of its lucrative Taiwan operation. The departures -- which follow the loss of 70 employees in Latin America and New York last summer -- reflect tighter management controls introduced by the Dutch bank since it rescued Barings, the failing British firm, in 1995.

title: Tourney's Remaining Teams Have Each Come a Long Way
description: In case any of the early arrivals had forgotten the importance of their destination, the signs downtown hold a reminder. ''The Road Ends Here,'' is the message repeated about as frequently as that old Final Four standby, ''I need tickets.''

title: VACATION BREAK TO BUY RESORTS FOR $122.8 MILLION
description: Vacation Break USA Inc. scaled back its purchase of a rival time-share resort developer, Berkley Group, to buy just the company's resorts for $122.8 million in stock and cash. The company also said it would soon settle a complaint by attorneys general in five states who said Vacation Break had violated consumer protection laws. Vacation Break stock plunged after the complaint was disclosed. Henry Cairo, chief financial officer, said the lower stock price played a part in the reorganized Berkley transaction. Vacation Break said it would now pay 8.7 million shares and $19 million in cash.

title: Harold Osrow, 80; Built a Much Better Broom
description: Harold Osrow, an entrepreneur who couldn't leave well enough alone until he was satisfied he had made it better, cheaper or more convenient, died on March 20 at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. A resident of Dix Hills, L.I., he was 80 and had been chairman of Osrow Products, the company he founded to produce an array of novel household items he had helped tinker into being.

title: Great Expectations
description: Really provident rural residents are already at work preparing next winter's woodpile. Perhaps it's an unwritten rule of the season: Stack next winter's wood before you dig this summer's garden. Or perhaps the splitting and stacking of wood is tied chronologically to the rising of sap in the sugar maples and the sudden, almost furtive appearance of sap buckets hanging in the woods.

title: Marina Fire On City Island Mars the Calm Of Community
description: Spring looked as though it would be a season of renewal at the Kretzer Boat Works in the Bronx, a weather-beaten marina on the bay side of City Island.
