description: Sleepers

title: Another Brooklyn Diner
description: The Brooklyn Diner, the theme restaurant on West 57th Street, is being cloned outside Manhattan. But the new diner will bypass the borough to which it pays homage and will instead open this fall in Westbury, L.I.

title: Trashy Chic Goes West And Finds Rodeo Drive
description: Halle Berry plays Barbie in ''BAPS,'' which casts her as a gold-toothed waitress from Georgia whose idea of upward mobility is going to Beverly Hills. She looks like a million bucks even when done up trashily enough to set off a metal detector. With Ruth Carter's bright, booty-hugging wardrobe for Ms. Berry one of the film's main comic assets, ''BAPS'' does show that the star can be as funny as she is gorgeous (very). But it's still a weak and condescending comedy with too many implicit kinks for its squeaky-clean tone.

title: Rights Group Suspects Yugoslav Army May Have Chemical Arms
description: A prominent human-rights group suggested today that the Serb-dominated Yugoslav Army may still possess huge stores of chemical weapons. Researchers for the group, the Human Rights Watch Arms Project, issued a December 1993 report in which a Croatian general, a former senior officer in Yugoslavia's chemical weapons program, described how tons of chemicals needed for making nerve gas were moved into Serbia soon after the breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991.

title: One Modern Misogynist Extracting His Revenge
description: The sweet nothings with which a man woos a woman are, in Neil LaBute's tremendously gutsy first feature, exactly that: nothing. The lacerating Mr. LaBute envisions a courtship ritual that is pure cruelty, at least on the part of an aggrieved white-collar worker named Chad (Aaron Eckhart). The implicit power politics of his sterile corporate world have made Chad shockingly bitter in ways that this unflinching, sharply written film articulates with brilliant ferocity. Now he wants a victim who can feel his pain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELMAN, FRED
description: SPIELMAN-Fred. The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers records with sorrow the passing of our distinguished composer member, Fred Spielman, in New York City on March 21, 1997. Marilyn Bergman President and Chairman, ASCAP

title: Surging Devils Give the Rangers a Taste of Reality
description: When Ranger fans get into their wishful thinking mode, one of their fervent hopes is that the Blue Shirts will meet the Devils in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Ivory Soap Moves To Grey Advertising
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would move the account of Ivory soap and a new product, Ivory Moisture Care soap, from Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York to Grey Advertising in New York. The shift of the account, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million, ends 76 years of Saatchi & Saatchi and a predecessor agency, Compton, handling Ivory in North America.

title: Morgan Stanley Earnings Up 15.8% in First Quarter
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 15.8 percent in the three months ended Feb. 28, a particularly buoyant period in securities markets.

title: In the Hunt for Answers, Only Questions Arise
description: It is a season of signs and wonders, of comets and lunar eclipses, of the vernal equinox and the holiest days on the Christian calendar.

title: For Friends in Their 20's, No Coffee or Laugh Track
description: No, the six black friends hanging out together in a Boston apartment over a Thanksgiving weekend, watching television, drinking beer and smoking ''blunts'' (hand-rolled tobacco and marijuana cigarettes), are not waiting for Godot, although it sometimes feels that way. The characters in their 20's who inhabit ''Black and White and Red All Over'' are caught up in a wave of black-on-black violence that is receiving sporadic coverage on a local television station. Exactly how they are connected to these events is revealed only in bits and pieces as the story unfolds. Even by the end of the movie, much is still unexplained.

title: UConn's Coach, Wolters Honored
description: Connecticut, the nation's top-ranked team in women's basketball, was eliminated Monday night from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, but it continued to pick up individual honors today.

title: Hingis Breaks a Sweat, Then Breaks Novotna
description: She showed some touches of petulance, some touches of brilliance, and finally, one hour and 50 overheated minutes into what seemed an interminable fight, she showed Jana Novotna the door by rifling an ace, the first and only ace of their semifinal bout, at match point.

title: Brooklyn Rabbi Is Accused Of Stealing Grant Money
description: A corruption case involving a politically connected Brooklyn social-services group widened yesterday when a former top official was charged in the theft of hundreds of thousands of dollars of Government funds that had been awarded to the group.

title: COCA-COLA EXPECTS RISE IN WORLDWIDE SALES
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it expected worldwide case sales to rise from 7 percent to 8 percent in the first quarter compared with the corresponding period a year ago. The Atlanta-based soft drink giant also said it expected worldwide gallon sales to rise from 5 percent to 6 percent in the three months ending on Monday. North American case sales in the quarter were expected to rise from 6 percent to 7 percent, and gallon sales were projected to increase from 1 percent to 2 percent. Strong growth was also forecast for Africa, where case volume was expected to rise from 9 percent to 10 percent while gallon sales were expected to increase from 22 percent to 23 percent. Shares of Coca-Cola fell $1.25, to $57.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Brodeur Won't Let Rangers Off Hook
description: If there were any lingering effects from the costly, soft goal Martin Brodeur let skip in off his catching glove late Tuesday night in the Devils' one-goal loss to the Flyers, they did not linger very long.

description: A Los Angeles gang that along with its archrivals imposed a more vicious brand of urban terror on the streets of Los Angeles in the 1980's has made inroads into New York City's jails and in some cases, on the streets, law enforcement officials and experts said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUGH, HARRY R. JR.

He is survived by three daughters: Georgia Pugh Howard, Priscilla Pugh Kirkpatrick, and Louise Pugh Smith, and one brother, William Pugh. title: An ABC Executive Returns to the Evening News

title: Chairwoman Named At Ogilvy & Mather
description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York said yesterday that Shelly Lazarus, chief executive, would assume the additional position of chairwoman. The appointment, which had been expected, will take effect on April 30. Ms. Lazarus, 49, will succeed Charlotte Beers, who has served as chairwoman since 1992 and served as chief executive from 1992 until Ms. Lazarus was promoted to that position in September. Ms. Beers, 61, who had a five-year contract with Ogilvy's parent, the WPP Group, will take the title of chairwoman emeritus, working with Ogilvy clients and senior executives of Ogilvy and WPP.

title: Some Players Revert To Tactics of Ice Age

First came the announcement Wednesday that the Whalers are leaving Hartford -- a sad event for fans in Connecticut but an inevitable and desirable market decision for an aggressive business that has outgrown some smaller cities.

description: To the Editor:

description: Law enforcement officials and several Government agencies are investigating an array of business practices at the nation's largest health care company, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, which runs about 350 hospitals and treats 125,000 people a day.

description: Congress is closed until early next month. But union organizers have been busier than ever this week, prowling the corridors of the Capitol for votes, votes from police officers.

title: Now There's No Who There
description: President Clinton's use of the phrase ''mistakes were made'' in relation to his fund-raising scandals marked the return of a dogged political staple: the disclaimer aided by the passive voice.

title: U.A.W. WORKERS AT INDIANA G.M. PLANT RATIFY PACT
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that the United Automobile Workers had ratified the agreement that ends a 13-day strike at the company's pickup truck plant in Fort Wayne, Ind. Strikers will return to work on Tuesday. Under the agreement, G.M. will hire 276 workers, the union said. The new workers will be placed ''in well-defined, specific positions that will allow the Fort Wayne plant and G.M. to remain competitive,'' a G.M. spokesman, Tom Beaman, said. The new workers, though full time, will be used mainly to fill in for people who are on vacation, in training or otherwise temporarily absent, Mr. Beaman said.

title: Marathoner Gets Probation
description: Dick Beardsley, the former marathon champion from Minnesota who became addicted to pain medication and was arrested for forging doctor's prescriptions last September, was sentenced yesterday to a maximum of five years' probation and 240 hours of community service in lieu of a 30-day jail term.

title: Rule Adopted To Prohibit Secret Tests On Humans
description: President Clinton has established new rules meant to preclude any more Government-financed secret experiments on unwitting human subjects using radioactive, chemical or other dangerous materials, the White House announced today.

title: Growing Gap Between Old Allies Creates New Obstacles for Haiti
description: Less than three years after the United States sent troops here to restore democracy, a bitter and widening dispute between supporters of the country's two most powerful political leaders has broken apart the American-backed ruling coalition and brought the Haitian Government to a virtual standstill.

title: Misfit Korean Teen-Agers Battle Shame and Fear
description: Life is certainly not easy for social misfits in any culture. But ''Three Friends'' suggests that to be young and different in South Korea can be a profoundly alienating experience. This melancholy movie looks deeply into the lives of three high school graduates who have failed their college entrance exams and find themselves dangerously adrift.

While it was the first N.C.A.A. title in basketball won by a New York City team since 1950, it was not the first N.C.A.A. championship of any kind during that period. Several other colleges have won national titles in other sports during that time, including St. John's University in soccer last December.

title: LASALLE RE HOLDINGS TO REPURCHASE SHARES
description: LaSalle Re Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy back 3.7 million of its common shares for $27 to $30 a share, or a total of about $100 million. The company is buying the shares through a Dutch auction, under which shareholders offer to sell shares to the company, and state the minimum price they will accept. The company will accept tenders for 3.7 million shares, assuming that many are offered, at the lowest price necessary to buy all of the shares. LaSalle, a reinsurance company based in Hamilton, Bermuda, said the offer expires on April 25, unless extended. On Thursday, LaSalle stock closed at $28.75 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: An On-Line Valentine: Some Chatter, Please
description: With perspiration cresting in the hollow of his neck, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine walked off a practice field and into his office and immediately flipped open his laptop computer. He jabbed at the keyboard with a finger, and his machinations produced a familiar, scratchy noise.

title: How a Popular Product Can Fray Relations With Small Merchants
description: As Ty Inc. scrambles to meet the demand for Beanie Babies, the hottest toy on the market, some of the small specialty retailers that sell the stuffed animals say they are the ones smarting from the company's growing pains.

title: Murder Charge for 15-Year-Old In Slaying of 2 Brooklyn Youths
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested and charged with murder yesterday after he fatally shot two older teen-agers who had stolen a gold necklace from him at a party two weeks ago, the police said.

title: MERCURY FINANCE SETS SALE OF INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Mercury Finance Company, the troubled auto loan company, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its Lyndon Insurance Group unit to Frontier Insurance Group Inc. of Rock Hill, N.Y., for $92 million in cash. The company said representatives of Mercury Finance's creditors had expressed support for the agreement. The Lyndon unit, based in St. Louis, was acquired by Mercury in October 1995 from the ITT Corporation for $72.5 million. Subsequently, other smaller insurance operations were merged with Lyndon.

title: Paralyzed, Again, in Albany
description: For the 13th year in a row, New York State will start a new fiscal year next week without a budget and with a Governor and Legislature once again paralyzed by arguments over money. But the spectacle seems sorrier than ever, since the two sides cannot even agree on how far apart they are. An even sadder reality is that there is enough money available to finance a sensible compromise between Republicans and Democrats, if only there were leadership instead of posturing.

title: Deregulation Plan Outlined By Japanese
description: The Japanese Government today released a proposal for deregulation that is intended to lay the foundation for the liberalization of the nation's financial markets.

title: The China Syndrome
description: There are some guys worth traveling halfway around the world for. And then there are Al Gore and Newt Gingrich.

title: Belgian Company To Cut 6,500 Jobs
description: Belgacom, Belgium's national telephone company, said yesterday that it would cut 6,500 jobs, a quarter of its work force, as it slashes costs before the opening of the European Union's telephone markets to full competition in 1998. Belgacom, which currently employs about 26,000 people, will offer 6,500 workers early retirement and will move a further 6,000 as part of an overhaul to ''get prepared for increasing competition,'' according to a spokesman.

title: China Protests U.S. 'Leaks' on Contributions
description: The Chinese Government has made two official protests to the United States demanding that the Clinton Administration stop its officials from leaking ''hearsay'' to newspapers about what are alleged to be Chinese political contributions, Chinese and American officials said today.

title: Stopping Stalinism in Belarus
description: ''People have said to me, bring back a dictatorship, bring back Stalinist times,'' said Belarus's dictator, Aleksandr Lukashenko, on television this week. He seems to be doing his best. As the streets fill with thousands of protesters, he has responded by arresting opposition leaders, harassing Russian reporters who covered the protests and ejecting the executive director of the Belarus Soros Foundation and an American diplomat. Next Wednesday he is scheduled to meet with Boris Yeltsin, probably the only man who can stop him. This is the time for Mr. Yeltsin to press Mr. Lukashenko to change course.

description: There is rarely a moment of calm in the household of Sayed (Mahmoud Hemeida), a lusty Egyptian cabdriver who lives with his parents, sister and grandfather in a cramped Cairo apartment. Their romantic intrigues and peccadillos become the stuff of comedy in ''The Asphalt Kings,'' an irreverent examination of urban Egyptian family life that often reaches the decibel level of ''The Honeymooners.''

description: The earnest figures speaking to us from the videotape are haunting in their gentleness, their sincerity, their hapless desire to have us understand that they were not crazy people, not in the clutches of some messianic madman, not the least bit nervous about their freely made decision to commit collective suicide, or, as they would put it, leave the physical ''containers'' they had been wearing and ascend to the Level Above Human. Only the occasional glassy expression, the naive preachiness, the supportive tittering by some of the cultists hinted at the underlying pathology that led such seemingly bright and articulate people to a tragic misjudgment.

title: Middle-American Emptiness Only a Sandwich Can Fill
description: ''I smell gasoline,'' the suspicious husband, Matthew, announces in the opening scene of ''Easter,'' Will Scheffer's dark and poignant heartland drama at Naked Angels. Wilma, his wife, has just returned from town, in a wedding dress, no less, and Matthew is worried that she is up to her old tricks. She has already burned down a dozen churches in Oklahoma and Kansas, and all the warning signs point to another holy torching.

title: Mayor Orders State Auditors To Be Evicted
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered two municipal agencies to evict auditors who were working for State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday, following through on his pledge not to cooperate with audits of city programs conducted by Mr. McCall's office.

title: Viacom Scales Back Plans For New Blockbuster Stores
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it had reduced the number of Blockbuster video stores it planned to open this year to 600 from 800.

title: Snapple Is Just the Latest Case Of Mismatched Reach and Grasp
description: The Quaker Oats Company's $1.4 billion debacle with Snapple only proves that the well-trod merger road has been paved with unrealized synergies and executive hubris, experts in mergers and acquisitions say.

title: GATEWAY 2000 TO ADD AMIGA TECHNOLOGIES
description: Gateway 2000 Inc. has agreed to buy Amiga Technologies, whose Amiga computer was a PC multimedia pioneer a decade ago. Amiga retains a core group of fans, though the product never developed significant market share. Details were not disclosed. Gateway 2000 said its purchase of Amiga had been approved by a court-appointed administrator acting on behalf of Amiga. The company is owned by Escom A.G., based in Bochum, Germany, which filed for bankruptcy protection in July.

title: Let Ecologists Buy Federal Timber
description: Vice President Al Gore recently declared market economies ''a prerequisite for saving the global environment.'' Now the Clinton Administration has a chance to follow through by allowing environmental groups to buy Federal timber. Instead of logging the trees, conservationists would leave them standing.

title: Typical American Noises
description: Things are said famously these days. Other things are said arguably. Mrs. M. N. of Merchantville, N.J., is tired of it, and I don't blame her.

title: U.N. Backs Sending Troops To Restore Order in Albania
description: The United Nations Security Council tonight authorized the dispatch of a multinational force of thousands of soldiers to Albania to oversee relief efforts there and to encourage a return to order in a country mired in civil strife.

title: Police Officer Is Hurt At Brooklyn Checkpoint
description: A car whose driver was trying to avoid a vehicle checkpoint in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon struck a police officer who was working at the roadblock, breaking the officer's ankle, the police said.

title: Clinton Considers Pushing Election Panel on Soft Money
description: President Clinton is considering whether to petition the Federal Election Commission to use its regulatory power to forbid the large, unregulated donations to political parties that became so controversial in last year's Presidential and Congressional elections.

title: David C. Miller, 80, Physician And Colleague of Schweitzer
description: Dr. David C. Miller, who attended Albert Schweitzer late in the philosopher's life and who was a noted epidemiologist and leader of famine-relief and other humanitarian projects, died on Thursday at his home in Lavonia, Ga. He was 80.

For information contact: Quattlebaum-HollemanBurse Funeral Home, 1201 So. Olive Ave., West Palm Beach, FL.

What tonight's two-hour edition of ''Investigative Reports'' does offer is a short course in the use of hidden microphones by American Presidents since Franklin D. Roosevelt, complete with technical details and an arresting smattering of samples of what was picked up.

description: Diplomats and other guests nearly choked on their cocktails and stuffed grape leaves about halfway through a reception at the Greek Embassy here on Tuesday evening.

description: Perched on a windowsill in the cramped private office of State Representative Peter Hoe Burling are pictures of a beaming Bill Clinton and his heir apparent, Vice President Al Gore. description: Lael Tucker Wertenbaker, a journalist and author best known for ''Death of a Man,'' her harrowing book about her husband's death, died on Monday at her home in Keene, N.H. She was 87.

description: Extra surveillance on a busy street where a boy was killed in a hit-and-run accident this month has paid off for the police.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLAUSMAN, BERNARD
description: KLAUSMAN-Bernard. 10 years seems like 10 minutes. The tremendous void that you left in our lives can never be filled, but the wonderful memories of a gentle, caring man endure and we strive to emulate your memory. Your loving family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLMAN, MAURICE
description: MEHLMAN-Maurice, 92 years. Died March 28, 1997. Devoted husband to his late wife Rose. Father of Edith and Irwin Leshaw and Joseph and Ruth Mehlman. Proud grandfather of Jerome, Susan, Richard, Caroline, Benjamin and Alice. Great grandfather of Daniel, Donald, Kerri, Brian, David, Andrew, Shoshana, Peter and Aviva. Brother of Hyman. Teacher, Principal and Assistant Superintendent in the New York City school system for four decades. Founder and Charter Member of the Schoolman's Lodge of B'nai Brith (Brooklyn). Founder and President of the Maimonides Lodge B'nai Brith (North Miami Beach). Supporter of the Hillel Foundation, Brooklyn College and of the BBYO (B'nai Brith Youth Organization). He was, in life, a counselor to his family and friends and to the childen and colleagues with whom he worked. To the end, he was an inspiration and a teacher and will be remembered with affection and love. Services Sunday, 10AM, ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (Opp LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Devils Draftee Wins Hobey Baker Award
description: The Hobey Baker trophy, awarded to college hockey's player of the year, was presented today to Michigan's Brendan Morrison, who may someday play for the Devils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDER, HERMAN A.
description: LANDER-Herman A., 92, Sarasota, FL., died March 10, 1997. Mr. Lander came to Sarasota 27 years ago from Brooklyn, NY. A Foreign Trade Consultant, he was vice president of the Kane Import Corp. in New York. A former president of the Harvest Lodge, B'nai B'rith in New York, Mr. Lander was a member of M. Aurel Rosin Lodge in Sarasota and the New York regional Anti-Defamation League Committee. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree in Commerce from New York University. Survivors include his wife Freda E., two nieces, Judy Winkelstein and Sandra Sohcot of California and four grandnieces. Services and burial will be in New York at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to the M. Aurel Rosin Lodge 2004, B'nai B'rith, PO Box 5207, Sarasota, FL. 34277.

title: Good Merlot, and the Price Is Right
description: Not too long ago, it seemed only a matter of time before some Long Island producer would name one of his wines Folie de Grandeur. Loosely translated, that means ''putting on airs,'' which at $27 or $30 a bottle is what more than a few of the owners were doing.

title: Widow Finds a Husband And a Son Takes It Hard
description: Forming new families after death or divorce is never easy, even with the best of intentions, and the problem knows no geographic boundaries. A straightforward, well-acted and perceptive Iranian film called ''The Father'' addresses this problem with skill and insight against an exotic background.

title: Not an Extra for Schools
description: Lotteries in states like New Jersey are often billed as a bonanza for education. But, according to a recent study by two professors from Saint Mary's College in South Bend, Ind., lottery proceeds are used to replace, rather than augment, tax revenue that would otherwise be spent on education.

title: Sputtering Rangers Need to Get Rolling
description: The Rangers have been plagued by inconsistency all season.

title: I.R.A. Admits It Planted 2 Bombs in England
description: The Irish Republican Army acknowledged today that it had detonated two bombs on Wednesday in northwestern England.

title: Ship of Dreams Goes Under in Poland
description: The shipyard where Lech Walesa rallied the Solidarity movement lies deserted now, an icy wind whipping idle cranes and rattling the windows of the workshop where the labor leader worked as an electrician.

title: Quiet Desperation, Then Decisions, Decisions
description: Interlocking episodes and a bemused, deadpan vision shape the Chinese film ''Rain Clouds Over Wushan,'' which is directed with quirky promise and dry precision by Zhang Ming. Mr. Zhang echoes Jim Jarmusch with his bare, quotidian settings and with characters whose quiet desperation can give way to surprising flashes of tenderness and sly, tacit wit. The film's manner is impressively measured, but its progress can be very desultory. Events progress slowly, accompanied by pointedly mundane detail. The actors are often in the grip of stylized anomie.

description: A man working as a tree trimmer in Bloomfield lost one of his legs in a wood-chipping machine on Thursday, but was saved from further injury by his partner.

title: NPC INTERNATIONAL ACQUIRES 126 RESTAURANTS
description: NPC International Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired 126 restaurants from Pizza Hut Inc. for $56 million. NPC International, based in Pittsburg, Kan., is a restaurant franchisee. Pizza Hut is a unit of Pepsico Inc., based in Purchase, N.Y. In January, Pepsico announced plans to spin off its restaurants to shareholders by the end of the year. NPC is the world's largest Pizza Hut franchisee, with 544 restaurants and delivery kitchens in 14 states. The company also operates and franchises 182 Tony Roma's restaurants and the theme restaurant Famous For Ribs.

title: Bruguera's Play Insures Meltdown by Sampras

But Sampras couldn't handle the heat and surrendered today's semifinal match to the bare-headed, bold-minded Sergi Bruguera of Spain.

Suddenly, everything seemed all too real for Cathryn LeBright, who became a widow when her husband was gunned down outside his token booth in a Queens subway station early Monday morning.

Lambert, who campaigned for Manhattan Surrogate promising to ''clean up the citadel of patronage'' but who retired from the powerful judgeship 12 years later best known as a patronage queen, died on Tuesday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 76 and lived in Manhattan, where she practiced law.

title: Haskins Sees Own Image On the Court
description: CLEM HASKINS reminds me of my high school principal. In the middle of the day, when we changed classes and our voices became too loud, Mr. Miller's voice would cut through the din with a simple, chilling pronouncement: ''This is still Harlan High.'' Then the roundup would begin. We were a public school, but Mr. Miller had his own dress code: no sweatshirts, no blue jeans, no miniskirts, no dark glasses. He was strict. And respected.

title: Apocalypse Cow
description: Among the thousands of cattle vying for ribbons at the recent Dixie National Junior Livestock show in Jackson, Miss., were five Red Angus heifers owned by Clyde Lodt, 41, a rancher and Pentecostal minister. These animals face triple scrutiny. To livestock judges, they're simply beef on the hoof. To Lodt, a Christian with a deep attachment to the Holy Land, they might help feed a country he dearly loves: Israel. And to Rabbi Chaim Richman, who will travel from Jerusalem later this spring to visit Lodt's spread, one of them just may prove instrumental in the coming of the Hebrew Messiah. Uh, the what? Here's the scoop.

title: For the Fabulous Eggs, The Magic Only Grows
description: THE RUSSIAN JEWELER Peter Carl Faberge never publicized the exquisite Easter eggs that he made for clients in turn-of-the-century St. Petersburg. He shrouded their production in secrecy, even refusing to reveal to his royal patrons, Aleksandr III and Nicholas II, which tiny surprises he was concealing inside the eggs -- a thimble-size palace, perhaps, or a gilded carriage, or an entire train.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLAKOV, GEORGE I.
description: POLAKOV-George I., of cardiac arrest at 87. Born in Poland, British schools in Orient, law graduate Warsaw University, 5-language linguist, press columnist at 22. In U.S. war production precision die maker, W.W. II 5-stripe veteran (France, Germany). Toy manufacturer and designer, board member two industry associations, industry labor negotiator. After retirement at 70, volunteer teacher at school for emotionally speech-disabled children; chairman tenants association; mountain climber (Andes, Himalayas). Much exhibited world-roaming landscape photographer. Survived by daughter Irene Levy, son Michael, granddaughters Jennifer King and Pamela Levy.

title: Bill Seeks to Strengthen Consumer Credit Protection
description: New legislation could give the state's consumers some of the strongest credit protection in the country. The New Jersey Fair Credit Reporting Act would strengthen a similar Federal law passed in November, giving consumers greater access to their reports and increasing the penalties against credit companies that do not correct errors quickly.

title: Love Among the Loons
description: Ursula, the mysterious heroine of Frederic Tuten's soulful fictional homage to Vincent van Gogh, is a 19-year-old morphine-addicted photographer. In VAN GOGH'S BAD CAFE (Morrow, $20), she first glimpses the artist while taking a cure at a mental hospital in St. Remy, ''where educated and artistic loons mixed with loons of ordinary plumage.'' She's also ''a waif of time'' who leaves van Gogh after they become lovers, stepping through a crack in the wall of a cafe into the streets of Manhattan a hundred years later. Mr. Tuten (the author of three previous novels, most recently ''Tintin in the New World'') skillfully spins out parallel fantasies of van Gogh's final days, leading up to his suicide, and Ursula's adventures in today's East Village, which begin when she is taken in by the novel's narrator, a struggling photographer whom she approaches in search of a fix. Ursula's musings about modern life and her inevitable journey into punkdom and heroin addiction tend to be less absorbing than van Gogh's anguished inner flights between heaven and hell, which Mr. Tuten depicts in flamboyant and striking style. But ''Van Gogh's Bad Cafe'' is charged throughout with strange, sad magic, and even in its most rapturous moments manages to avoid cliches about artistic isolation and suffering. The watercolors and drawings by Eric Fischl that begin each chapter heighten the dreaminess of this jazzy meditation on the difficult commerce between art and life. Scott Veale

title: Rubdowns Are Fine. Then Again, They Can Get a Little Too Touchy.

title: Two Shows in London Look at Fashion Trends
description: Two London exhibitions survey fashion trends in Britain from the late 1930's to the present. At the Imperial War Museum, ''Forties Fashion and the New Look,'' on display until Aug. 31, concentrates on fashion of the late 1930's to the late 1940's. Clothing, posters, fashion journals, photographs and films show how fashion adapted to wartime shortages, including the period from 1941 to 1949 when clothes were rationed. Among the exhibits are uniforms, factory wear and evening wear. The exhibition also features examples of Hollywood fashion in the 1940's and the work of leading designers of the time. The Imperial War Museum on Lambeth Road, (44-171) 416 5000, is open daily. Admission is $7.50.

title: Swaggering in Death's Face Till the End
description: CHRISTOPHER WALLACE, The Notorious B.I.G., thought he had all the time in the world. His second album, ''Life After Death'' (Bad Boy/Arista), flaunts affluence with a leisurely swagger, all midtempo grooves and calmly arrogant raps. Calling himself ''richer than rich,'' the rapper from Brooklyn boasts about his condo, his platinum watch, his frequent-flier miles and his women, in a voice as husky as his 280-pound frame. At the same time, he insists that he has to watch his back and defend himself, guns blazing, against jealous rivals and predators. But he doesn't sound worried, and his guest rappers insist he'll be on top for years to come.

description: FOR most of the 20th century, Russia's Far East has been off limits to Americans. The closest part of Russia to the United States, Russia east of Siberia, seemed also the most forbidding. Among its sites: Magadan, port of entry to Stalin's Arctic gold mines; Sakhalin Island, home base to the Soviet fighter that shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007; and Vladivostok, a city closed to all Westerners when it was home port to the Soviet Pacific fleet.

title: Magnet Schools, Whether on Stage . . .
description: WE are going to start with a circulation stretch,'' said Cheryl Lynn Wirth, a dance teacher with the Regional Center for the Arts. Her class, a dozen teen-age girls from Bridgeport and its suburbs, was led through warm ups -- stretching and bending legs, shoulders and backs, facing a mirrored wall. ''Ready, arms opening on one.''

title: 'Freedom Fighter' Or Assassin?
description: To The Editor:

title: Cecile Rossant and Christian Niemitz
description: FOR the last five years, Cecile Rossant has lived abroad, first in Japan, where she worked as an architect for Arata Isozaki, and now in Berlin, where she freelances.

title: Not Your Average Bucolic Landscapes
description: DESPITE a pedestrian title, ''Current Perspectives on the Urban and Industrial Landscape,'' at the New Jersey State Museum, is an atmospheric, mood-filled reverie. Consisting of 39 paintings by six contemporary artists who work in New Jersey, Philadelphia and New York City, it was organized in a tidy manner by Patrick Malin and Emily Winslow as part of their studies in the museum professions graduate program at Seton Hall University.

title: To Rate Hospitals, She Dons a Wig and Practices Her Cough
description: TO anyone sitting in the emergency room of the hospital, Barbara Gerber looked like any other patient. She filled out forms, chatted with the triage nurse and plopped down in a chair to wait her turn.

title: Classic Ballet, International Sounds
description: TWO ensembles may be the highlights of the musical week in Jorgensen Auditorium, at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. On Thursday evening at 8, the Moscow Festival Ballet treats its audience to the classic ''Giselle.'' On Friday at 8, Fabio Mechetti leads the Syracuse Symphony in Barber's ''School for Scandal'' Overture, Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto (with Stephanie Chase as soloist) and Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique. For tickets to either event, call 860-486-4226.

title: In Stonemason's Hands, Work Becomes Folk Art
description: MANNY INGA, a stonemason, can identify a rock by the sound it makes when he drops it. Stones are his medium, and they speak to him through his senses. When he hauls 300-pound rocks from the ground to cut them, his fingers find the veins that will split straight when he hammers them. He scrutinizes the even slabs for their color and texture, arranging them in artistic patterns when he sets patios or builds walls. He learned his craft from his father in Ecuador, and his father learned from his father before him. Thanks to a demand for stone buildings among the county's well-to-do, Mr. Inga is prospering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHONBRUN, ARTHUR
description: SHONBRUN-Arthur. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Antkies Shonbrun. Survived by his loving wife Ruth Haber Shonbrun, his adoring children Lynn Stand, William Shonbrun and their spouses Lee Stand and Suzanne Shonbrun, stepdaughters Margie Haber, Lois Segel and Joan Kilberg, grandfather of Zoe Shonbrun and Larry and David Stand and his wife Lesley and great grandfather of Rachel Stand. Funeral to be held Tuesday, April 1, at New Mount Carmel Cemetery at 11 A.M.

title: Still Homeless, Just Harder to See
description: Josefina Castillo-Rubio, Eugene Hanley and Jeffrey Myers are neighbors in a small shantytown of plywood-and-tin shacks along a bluff above the East River, on the edge of the Hunts Point peninsula in the South Bronx.

title: The Suicides Next Door
description: As the network news shows were first airing the videotapes from Rancho Santa Fe on Thursday evening, I was sitting in a Broadway theater watching the actor Rip Torn declare how wonderful America is. Mr. Torn plays the role of Will Kidder, a can-do 63-year-old businessman in the can-do boom town of Houston, 1950, in Horton Foote's Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''The Young Man From Atlanta.'' Will tells anyone who will listen that he lives in the best house in the best city in the best country in the world.

title: Bookshelf
description: LOOK AT THE MOON. By May Garelick. Illustrated by Barbara Garrison. Mondo. $14.95. (Ages 7 to 11) The delicately tinted illustrations accompanying a thoughtful poem about the full moon that shines on scenes around the world are inked-collage collagraphs, highlighted with watercolor washes.

title: English Garden Events
description: The renowned Chelsea Flower Show, which has been chronicling changes in horticultural fashion for over 75 years, takes place in London from May 20 to 23. Twenty-four show gardens and 733 exhibitors will participate. Among this year's show gardens will be The Country Life magazine's centenary garden, designed by Rupert Golby to unite classic English country-house style with contemporary design; an Yves St. Laurent-sponsored garden designed by Madison Cox, and the Mughal Garden sponsored by the Maharaja of Jodhpur and designed by Anthony Lockwood to celebrate 50 years of Indian independence.

title: Nina Gardner, Francesco Olivieri
description: Nina Jessica Gardner, who monitors political and human rights developments in Zagreb, Croatia, for the Liaison Office of the United Nations, was married in Prague yesterday to Ambassador Francesco Olivieri, the Italian ambassador to Croatia. Deputy Mayor Karel Loucky of Prague officiated at the Old Town Hall.

title: Here's the Dirt: Repairs to Close Lawn
description: One of the city's great environmental success stories will cost downtown Manhattan residents recreational space this spring and summer, as the lawns at Battery Park City will close this week for months of restoration and repair. The reason, in part: the Hudson River has become too clean.

title: Fortysomething Mammograms: Still More Advice
description: Take seven studies of mammograms from several countries, with different designs and different criteria for selecting and evaluating the women who participated. Add three different panels of experts to evaluate the conflicting data. Ask each panel to decide whether women in their 40's should have regular mammograms. The result? Three different recommendations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, DONALD
description: GREENBERG - Donald, March 27th, 1997. A wonderful man, a wonderful friend. Beloved husband of Roslyn, father of Susan Lebow and Debbie Schneeman, brother of Jack L. Green, grandfather of Jaime, Allison, and Kasey. Services at The Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam, Sunday, March 30th, 11:15 AM.

title: Leslie F. Corbin, Paul J. Goldberg
description: Leslie Faith Corbin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Corbin of White Plains, was married last evening to Paul Jason Goldberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Goldberg of New York. Rabbi Murray Grauer performed the ceremony at the Hebrew Institute of White Plains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZULC, LEON
description: SZULC-Leon. Park East Synagogue Men's Club offer their deepest sympathies to their Board Member Massimiliano Szulc on the loss of his beloved father. May his soul be for a blessing. Allan Goldberg, President Herman Hochberg, Chairman

title: Jackie Kim And Harry Robins
description: Jackie Kim and Harry Robins, who are lawyers, were married on Friday. Mayor Gerald A. Calabrese of Cliffside Park, N.J., officiated there at the borough hall.

title: More Requirements For Golf Course
description: As a past member, and most recently chairman, of the East Hampton Planning Board, I would like to offer a minor correction and then a comment on your March 9 article on proposed golf courses $(''Plans for 4 Courses Splinter Towns''$).

title: The Beginnings Of a Far-Ranging Creative Revolt
description: THE CHOREOGRAPHERS who emerged from the pioneering and sometimes even shocking Judson Dance Theater performances at Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village in the 1960's were united in a desire to experiment and to reject conventional modern-dance forms. But they were never choreographically alike, and they have continued to go their own ways creatively.

title: What Walpole Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Working to the Beat of Many Different Drums
description: Junior Wedderburn becomes visibly uncomfortable when asked about steadily increasing sales for the handcrafted drums he and his partner make. The musician-turned-reluctant capitalist needs help from Clyde, his brother, fellow musician and business partner, to remember what prices they charge. Market-share, stock options and maximizing profits are alien concepts in the dingy, Crown Heights basement that is the factory for AV Drumworks Inc.

title: Swing Into Spring
description: 'I am blessed with the gift for flying the trapeze,'' declares Stephan Gaudreau, a wee, emphatic former circus performer from Montreal and a head teacher at the San Francisco-based School of Circus Arts, the nation's only open-to-the-public, overcome-your-woes trapeze class. Gaudreau promises students ''a total rush!'' and a ''cure'' for such interpersonal potholes as adolescent turmoil, midlife crisis, shyness, distorted body image and chain-smoking.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Like 'Mary Tyler Moore,' With Attitude and Accent
description: DON'T get her started about the apartment.

title: A Tiger Lurking In a Pussycat's Skin
description: To the Editor:

title: Katonah to Observe 100 Years of Rebirth
description: ONE HUNDRED years to the day, on April 5, Katonah, known as the town that would not drown, will begin a three-month celebration, commemorating its transformation from a doomed Katonah to a new Katonah.

title: The Days That Brought the Barrier Down
description: The old scout Clyde Sukeforth is 95 now, the last living link to the origin of Branch Rickey's ''noble experiment'' that baseball is celebrating this season, 50 years after Jackie Robinson joined the Brooklyn Dodgers as the first African-American player in modern major league history.

title: Mosaic Benches Face Unseating At Grant's Tomb
description: To some critics and many local residents, the colorful mosaic tile benches that snake around Grant's Tomb in Riverside Park at 122d Street are a pleasing example of folk art, a cherished expression of community involvement. But to some Civil War buffs and the National Park Service, which maintains the monument, they clash with the site and trivialize its historical significance.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: FYI 2

title: With Ewing Hurting, Van Gundy Plans Shake-Up
description: The short-term malady Patrick Ewing's pulled left triceps -- is expected to be healed within a week. The long-term problem -- inconsistent play over the last three weeks -- is far more troublesome to Jeff Van Gundy.

title: Can You Spare $1 Million?
description: Even as Democrats try to tamp down the furor over the party's fund-raising practices in the 1996 campaign, they now have to contend with new financial difficulties that could haunt the party in the 1998 campaign.

title: Carol L. Ziegler, Martin Minkowitz
description: Carol L. Ziegler, an associate dean at the Brooklyn Law School, was married last evening to Martin Minkowitz, a partner in Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, the New York law firm. Rabbi Sue Ann Wasserman performed the ceremony at the Mark hotel in New York.

title: Clinton vs. the First Amendment
description: At 10 a.m. on March 19, the nine justices of the United States Supreme Court walked to their leather chairs, which faced the attorneys before them. On one side of a podium were lawyers for a coalition of civil liberties and computer-industry groups prepared to argue that the Communications Decency Act signed into law by President Clinton last year violated the First Amendment. Standing on the other side, ready to defend the constitutionality of the law, were lawyers for Attorney General Janet Reno and, by extension, President Clinton himself.

title: Technology in the Front Seat at 4 Times Square
description: SINCE it is the major office building to go into construction in midtown Manhattan in the 90's, the structure being built at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway could be expected to include a few new technical wrinkles.

title: Internet Help After a Pregnancy Fails
description: ONE day last year, a woman called up Dr. Michael Berman's site on the World Wide Web and poured out her grief.

title: Matthew Katz and Sheryl Smith
description: Sheryl Smith, a daughter of Sandy and Dennis Smith of Springfield, N.J., was married on Thursday evening to Matthew Katz, the son of Joyce and Herbert Katz of Whitestone, Queens. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein officiated at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J.

title: 5 Years Later, View of City Turns Rosier
description: About five years ago, 60 percent of New Yorkers said that if it were up to them, they would move away. All that has changed. Today, New Yorkers see their city as safer, cleaner and more livable and are just as likely to want to stay as to go.

title: A Diaper Bag That Dare Not Speak Its Name
description: WHAT: A diaper bag that doesn't look like one, from the trendy purse designer Kate Spade.

title: Trading Their Prison Cells for Church Pews
description: The man in the purple robe who read the prayer of confession during Palm Sunday services at Church of Gethsemane was released from an Allentown, Pa. prison last May. A congregant who used the church's van to bring in worshipers from homeless shelters, served time in an Otisville, N.Y., correctional facility. And a deacon who helped prepare the sanctuary before service and counted the offering after, is a two-time offender who has spent time at both Riker's Island and Bedford Hills Correctional Facility.

title: Living It Up In Zermatt, At Least a Little
description: I HAD done this before -- come to Zermatt in high season to ski. That was six years ago, when I had a little saved up from a winter's work in a ski shop in Austria: Five days in Zermatt, at Easter, nearly wiped me out. I stayed then at the Bahnhof hotel, opposite the station where the little train rolls in from Visp and the parking lot at Tasch (Zermatt is car-free), in an upstairs dormitory, and was kept awake by French alpinists snoring heavily throughout the night. I was uncomfortable, but it was a revelation to discover that one could do Zermatt on the cheap: 20 francs a day for a bunk bed, pasta dinners cooked in the downstairs kitchen, and 200 francs in hand for the lifts.

title: Foreign Aid Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: The Day a Cult Shook a Tiny Town
description: This seaside town, a pastiche of lighthouses, tidal pools and cedar-shingled bed and breakfasts, does not look like the cradle of a U.F.O. cult.

title: Maurice Coreth, 67, Is Dead; Hunter Helped Save the Rhino
description: Count Maurice Coreth, an exuberant sportsman and swashbuckling adventurer whose love of big-game hunting led him to organize an acclaimed campaign to save the African rhinoceros from extinction, died in England on Feb. 11. He was 67 and the founder of Rhino Rescue, an organization credited with reversing an alarming decline in the animal's population.

title: No Need To Raise Rates Again
description: THE clear message of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate increase last week is that ''growth is bad,'' because it eventually fuels inflation. In my opinion, today's prosperity is good, and the folks at the Fed should stop worrying so much about inflation.

title: Talks on Water Meters And Rent Regulation
description: Spurred by legislative initiatives, organizers of the 10th Co-op and Condo Expo -- to be held May 9 at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan -- have scheduled seminars on rent regulation, water metering and lead disclosure among the 10 seminars scheduled for the day.

title: Homeira Ghiacy, Matthew Walter
description: Homeira Ghiacy, a daughter of Fatima and Raouf Ghiacy of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Matthew Martin Walter, the son of Barbara and Ronald Walter of Shrewsbury, N.J. The Rev. Henry Fehrin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Water's Edge Beach Club in Sea Bright, N.J.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: GROWING THROUGH THE UGLY

title: California Floodwaters Bring Prospectors, If Not Gold
description: For John Evans, who makes most of his living putting up drywall not far from this old mining outpost in the Sierra foothills, the secret of finding gold lies in seizing nature's fleeting clues to where the ore is hidden.

title: Mets' Irabu Offer Is 'Strong'
description: Officials from the San Diego Padres and the Mets are expected to speak again Sunday, as they continue to negotiate a deal for the Japanese pitcher Hideki Irabu.

title: New Radio Talker, Local Frequency
description: Yes, Anita Hill and Clarence Thomas were the undisputed stars of the ''He Said, She Said'' mini-series that hypnotized the nation in 1991. But the best cameo role? No contest. It belonged to John N. Doggett 3d.

title: The Man at the Piano, Playing a Supporting Role
description: DO not call Phillip Moll a collaborative pianist, please. It puts him in mind of French people who cooperated with the Nazis. In fact, since to accompany means to go along, and even to guide, it is not odd that Mr. Moll, who is among the most eminent performers in his field, likes to be thought of as a musical helmsman.

title: They Watch When TV Says 'Don't'
description: The latest study of television violence, which came out last week, shows that television or movie rating codes like PG-13 and R, or advisories like ''Parental discretion advised,'' actually entice children to watch.

title: A Final Twist for Suspects Who Posed as the Police
description: The fakes were out-faked, the police said.

title: A Visitor for James Earl Ray
description: The scene was surreal: a man who looks eerily like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. warmly shaking the hand of James Earl Ray and apologizing sheepishly for imposing on the prisoner's time. In fact, the King look-alike was Dexter Scott King, the youngest son of the slain civil rights leader. And after 15 minutes of chitchat with the man convicted of killing his father, Mr. King announced to Mr. Ray and the world that he and his family now believe that Mr. Ray is not responsible for Dr. King's assassination on April 4, 1968, in Memphis.

title: Under the Spotlight in China, Gore Lacked Luster
description: Vice President Al Gore is not known for daring improvisation.

title: A Loaf of Bread, a Ton of Cheese and Thou
description: No living poets appear in ''Very Bad Poetry,'' a new anthology by Kathryn Petras and Ross Petras to be published next month by Vintage Books, but that's not because the compilers feared asking permission. ''To some extent you need time to pass to say, 'Does this stand up -- as a really bad thing?' '' Ms. Petras said recently. ''It's like art. Or wine. Or cheese.'' James McIntyre, a 19th-century Canadian poet who easily made the cut, certainly knew cheese. He produced dozens of dairy-themed poems, including ''Prophecy of a Ten Ton Cheese'' and ''Ode on the Mammoth Cheese.'' His obsession seems tame, however, in the context of this volume, which also contains paeans to earwigs and dentistry. And even the mighty can be very bad, as in the worst of Wordsworth, excerpted below.

title: Criticisms on Criticisms Of Matrimonial Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen Greenfield, Kenneth Greenwald
description: Ellen Robin Greenfield, the marketing director at the Prescriptives division of the Estee Lauder Companies in New York, was married last evening to Kenneth Dana Greenwald, an associate at Parker Duryea Rosoff & Haft, a New York law firm. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: THE AGE BOOM
description: Imagine my delight when I read John Tierney's article on retiring in New York (''No Stairs, No Driving, No Tropical-Colored Pants''). As a former New Yorker, I had just returned from a long weekend in Manhattan, a trip made expressly to revitalize my suburb-subdued soul. Tierney provided just the ammunition I need to dent my husband's anti-New York armour. It made him laugh and acknowledge the possibility.

title: A Taste Of Portugal As O.D.U. Faces Vols
description: At age 14, Ticha Penicheiro was playing for the Portuguese women's national basketball team. At 16, she was the starting point guard. When Clarisse Machanguana and Mery Andrade were in their teens, they played in the Portuguese national league.

title: TANGLED WEB
description: Just two years ago Larry Hoover was hailed for creating 21st Century V.O.T.E., a political organization in Chicago for young black men, most of them members of Hoover's street gang, the Gangster Disciples. Meanwhile, the Government was secretly taping conversations that convinced it that V.O.T.E. was a crime front. On March 19, Hoover began his defense against drug and conspiracy charges, but he's also pressing his case on the World Wide Web. The ''United in Peace'' site is maintained by Wallace (Gator) Bradley, one of the few Hoover loyalists. Bradley deftly uses the medium to try to explain how Hoover was framed. A hypertext click takes browsers to a section where the conspiracy is to be dismantled. ''Lend me your imagination,'' it beckons hypnotically. ''Relax ... relax.''

title: Disaster? Was There a Disaster?
description: EVEN ALAN J. PAKULA, the veteran director who has seen his share of hard times on movie sets, does not shy away from the word ''disaster'' to describe some aspects of filming ''The Devil's Own'' last year.

title: Conservation Intertwines With Artifacts in Show
description: IN supermarkets, Job's-tears are listed on cartons of soy drinks as an ingredient. Those at the Lehman College Art Gallery here are the real, unprocessed thing: shiny, white seeds resembling beads, dotting reticules woven of strands cut from bark. This context suggests that the legendary sufferer has still another reason for weeping.

title: Islanders Are Making A Serious Playoff Run
description: People laughed when the Islanders talked about the playoffs. The only ones laughing now are the Islanders.

title: 'Dear Abby' Doesn't Live Here Anymore
description: MAN'S WORST FRIEND had a problem. A big problem. Years ago she had seduced a guy, then spurned him and later turned him in to the police as a possible stalker. Now he was dying of cancer. Should she write to him and make up? The question lay smoldering in the mailbag of Dan Savage, the author of the advice column Savage Love.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT PAGE 4

title: A Modern Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat Treats Hamas as Ally, Not Enemy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Back-Country Rusticity in Armonk
description: FROM outside, the Willow Inn has the ramshackle appearance of a back-country place, helter-skelter rooms added whenever an expanding family required more space.

title: Elms That Have Been Recruited in a Battle Against Development
description: The elm trees lining Washington Road in West Windsor Township have long been famous for their stately beauty. Since the trees were planted in 1920, they have grown into a canopy that makes a much-beloved gateway to Princeton. Now some of the elms and the road itself are threatened by the planned construction of a road project called the Millstone Bypass.

title: Mother Tongues
description: TEXACO By Patrick Chamoiseau. Translated by Rose-Myriam Rejouis and Val Vinokurov. 401 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $27.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 9 about Tequila, Mexico, misidentified the plant that is used to make tequila. The agave is a member of its own family, not the cactus family.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a benefit for Riverkeeper, an organization that helps protect the Hudson River from pollution, misstated the surname of two guests and omitted the location. The guests were Ann and Joseph Tonetti, not Tonettiaia. The scene was Windows on the World.

title: The West's Debt to Byzantium
description: Although not intended by its sponsors, and not noticed by most visitors, there is a fascinating political subtext to ''The Glory of Byzantium,'' the Metropolitan Museum's sumptuous new show about Byzantine culture at its peak, from the 9th century to the 13th. (The show ends in July.)

title: From Anatolian Turkey, Sophisticated Kilims
description: ASIA MINOR it was called, Anatolia it is today, a portion of Turkey that has given the world a high art in kilim, a form of flat weaving. Major exhibitions, staged first at the Textile Museum in Washington, D.C., in 1963, plus increased travel to the Middle East and Central Asia ultimately led to a fascination with Turkish village rugs.

title: The Welcome Opening of the Lily Season
description: THIS being Easter, lilies are out in profusion. The heavily scented white trumpets bearing the name of the celebration grace altars, pots of flowering plants decorate homes, and collections fill public plazas and commercial buildings.

title: Dina Hellerstein and Joshua Metzger
description: Dina Ruth Hellerstein, a litigation associate at the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, is to be married today to Joshua Eli Metzger, the manager of special projects at Prodigy, the on-line computer service in White Plains. Rabbi Jacob J. Schacter is to perform the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Whalers Say Their First Goodbye, to Rangers
description: The signs hanging from the mezzanine and above the portals said it all. The capacity crowd of 14,660 that showed up for today's matinee at the Civic Center -- the Whalers' first home game since the team's owner, Peter Karmanos, announced plans to move them out of Hartford at the end of the season -- had gathered to mourn the loss of their team.

title: Mortality Wears a Profitable, Noncyclical Edge
description: SOME investors may find the subject ghoulish, but the fact is the funeral business is alive and flourishing. Although its stocks are not markedly low-priced, and its revenues may be threatened by the cheaper option of cremation, the ''death care'' industry is now enjoying increasing demand and a wave of consolidations, all while retaining its enviable ability to raise prices.

title: A Resounding Shot, But Was It for Real?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mammograms for Younger Women
description: So now it is unanimous. The National Cancer Institute has joined the American Cancer Society and other medical groups in recommending routine mammograms for all women in their 40's. True, the groups differ on some details. The cancer institute recommends testing every year or two whereas the Cancer Society has just come out firmly for annual tests. Either way, the consensus now holds that there is no good reason for women in their 40's to avoid these potentially life-saving screening tests to detect breast cancer.

title: Grant Fizzles at a Housing Project
description: Two years ago, things looked good for the people of the Beach 41st Street Houses, a public development that had come to be known as the stereotypical social failure. Drug dealers were the major employers, criminals more prevalent than cops and hopelessness the companion of many schoolchildren, residents say.

title: Owners, Not Dogs, Are Problem at Dog Runs
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: Of Chains, Rods and Sections

title: A Joyful Noise on the Pier
description: WAKING UP is no problem. For nearly seven years, Soundra Usry Hollingsworth has been up at 5 A.M. every Sunday to broadcast ''Soundra and Friends,'' her 6:30 A.M. live gospel hour on WMGM-TV, Channel 40, in Wildwood.

title: Winds Shake Elkington's Firm Lead
description: Steve Elkington was cruising with a four-stroke lead in the Players Championship today, heading into his final two holes of the third round. Then his challengers got a break.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOVIN, ARNIE
description: SLOVIN-Arnie. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Associates, Ben-Gurion University mourn the loss of Arnie Slovin, beloved mother of our dear friend, Bruce Slovin. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Kenneth L. Tucker, President Kenneth M. Farber Executive Vice President Aron Bukspan Director for Development

title: Challenging the Boss and Living to Tell About It
description: IMAGINE you are a senior vice president of a large company. Two employees tell you that they believe their boss is embezzling from the company. Serious stuff. And who is their boss? The president of the company, who also happens to be your immediate boss.

title: Auto Makers Practice a New York Accent
description: BY no means is New York the automotive capital of the world, but for now the focus of the auto industry is indeed on the only American city where the word ''car'' is often preceded by ''subway.'' At press events last week marking the opening of the New York International Auto Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, several new products were displayed that are aimed specifically or largely at the nation's biggest urban area.

title: Michele Raynor, M.R. Littenberg
description: Michele Lynn Raynor and Michael Richard Littenberg, lawyers in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Judith Lewis performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in New York.

title: Daly Seen Drinking on Night Before He Withdrew
description: On Thursday, the night before he withdrew from the Players Championship after one round, John Daly spent the evening drinking at a trendy local nightspot.

title: A Comic Who Did Nothing, but Did It In a Hilarious Way
description: CHARLIE CHAPLIN WADDLED across the screen with a cane twirling at his side. Buster Keaton braved dangers through cockeyed ingenuity and eye-opening gymnastics. Harold Lloyd dangled from a clock tower high above a city street. Harry Langdon did next to nothing. But Harry Langdon?

title: Unexpected Zanzibar
description: AS a child, I flew my magic carpet to all sorts of strange places I couldn't imagine reaching any other way -- Katmandu, Beijing, Egypt, the Taj Mahal, Rhodes, even Zanzibar. Then one day in the early 70's, when I was staring out at the Indian Ocean from a lookout on Dar es Salaam harbor, a local standing next to me volunteered, ''Just over the horizon is Zanzibar, Madam. But you don't want to go there. It is very dirty.''

title: Bali Miller, Stuart Klawans
description: Bali Miller, a private dealer in modern and contemporary art in New York, and Stuart Klawans, the film critic for The Nation, were married last evening at the Hyatt Hill Country Resort in San Antonio. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Burton L. Visotzky, who introduced the couple.

title: L.I.R.R. Defends Parking Efforts
description: In the article ''L.I.R.R., Riders and Local Officials Square Off on Parking'' $(March 9$), I was surprised to read that the L.I.R.R. did not have a plan for parking expansion/improvements at stations and that some elected officials appear to be unaware of funding set aside to fund parking expansion.

title: All Aboard
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has introduced the R-142-A to replace cars like the R-26, which has been in use for 35 years, the average life of a subway car. The city's first subway car, made of wood and steel, was introduced in 1904 and operated until the 1940's. Since then, the MTA has used more than 19 kinds of subway cars. Test cars are used to evaluate new design elements before an entire fleet is ordered. Here is a look at three cars introduced over the years.

title: No Headline
description: ''The people who are in these roles are just people. They have families. They play jokes on themselves and others. They see irony. They're scared a lot of the time. They're not larger than life. They're like other people.''

title: The Faces of Hedda Nussbaum
description: As Hedda Nussbaum, in a red coat with faux-fur trim, met the press on the courthouse steps in Manhattan on March 10 to announce a legal victory giving herself and other battered women more time to sue their abusers, she dabbed her left eye with a tissue. Photographers caught the moment and news accounts suggested she was crying tears of joy. ''I knew they would say that,'' Nussbaum says with a hearty laugh two days later. In fact, that eye, which Joel Steinberg's fingers gouged more than a decade ago, ''weeps'' nearly all the time from an injured tear duct.

title: Lone Biker Founds Group to Aid Charity

title: Phone Line for Disabled Has Data on New York
description: This month, an international toll-free number for travelers with disabilities began providing accessibility information on more than 200 museums, theaters, hotels and restaurants in New York City. Operated by Hospital Audiences Inc., a nonprofit organization based in the city, the number -- (888) 424-4685 -- may be called from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Eastern time Monday to Friday. Callers will speak to a trained staff member who can provide detailed information based on a caller's disability and the date of the planned visit. Categories of information include the availability of museum touch-tours and performances that offer audio descriptions for the blind or sign-language interpretations for the deaf. Among the criteria by which hotels and restaurants are evaluated are price, restroom features and accessibility, presence of stairs and ramps, and height of pay telephones and water fountains. Information on public and private transportation for people with disabilities is also offered.

title: The Things That Were Caesar's
description: The wonder of the Roman Empire is not how much of it has vanished, but how much endures. From the Arch of Augustus guarding the Pennine Alps at Aosta and the Segovia aqueduct in Spain to the Library of Celsus at Ephesus in Asia Minor, the legacy of Roman splendor is still visible in the Mediterranean world, as ready to awe and intimidate us today as it did the populace of some recently subjugated province in the second century A.D. The photographs in ANCIENT ROME: History of a Civilization That Ruled the World (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $60) re-create a sense of the sights and vistas of the capital and its principal outposts, screening out most evidence of 20th-century life. Scenes from everyday life and fashion are captured with unexpected realism and detail on columns and mosaics and in a back view of a hairdo on a sculpture, while the faces of Caesar, the young Octavian, Nero and Caracalla glare up from the page with startling clarity, as weathered and lifelike as the monuments they accompany. ''Ancient Rome,'' with text and captions by the Italian scholars Fabio Bourbon and Anna Maria Liberati, is a book of small marvels and Ozymandian ironies, its lessons commemorated in the stillness of Petra, in the untarnished perfection of a gold-leaf necklace retrieved from Pompeii (''a town that never knew the fate of neglect and decadence suffered by others''), and in a wicked, elegant brazier found in Herculaneum, the three ithyphallic satyrs that form its legs looking as if they're performing ''Stop! In the Name of Love.'' David Walton

title: 'Mozart and Salieri' Planned on Two Stages

In a distinctive collaboration, next Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Paramount Center for the Arts in Peekskill, actors from Shakespeare and Company will stage Pushkin's ''Mozart and Salieri'' while Philharmonia Virtuosi provides a backdrop by playing of both composers. What should be a special evening will be topped off by a performance of Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 17 with Andrew Armstrong as soloist. The program will be repeated on April 19 at 8:30 P.M. at Purchase College. For reservations, call 739-2333 in Peekskill or 693-5595 in Purchase.

Here is an ideal introduction to a Broadway play for those who've never seen one. The direction is brilliant, with the inimitable Bette Davis at a peak as a ruthless matriarch. Herbert Marshall, Teresa Wright, Patricia Collinge, Charles Dingle, Dan Duryea and Richard Carlson round out the splendid cast. The added touch of young love enhances. description: MAYBE it was the play everyone had just seen, with its themes of regret, mortality, resignation. Maybe it was the setting, the staid upstairs rooms at the ''21'' Club. Or maybe it was the crowd, graying for sure, but not elderly so much as accomplished. The television journalist Morley Safer. The actress Elaine Stritch. The novelist E. L. Doctorow. You get the idea. Old enough to have something to look back on.

title: Legacy of a Hank of Hair
description: JOHN REZNIKOFF doesn't know what killed Marilyn Monroe 35 years ago, but he just might hold some important evidence.

title: Caterer Wants to See If Food Lures Fliers
description: For years, airlines have gradually offered fewer and smaller meals on their flights. Now, some passengers may start seeing more food.

title: New Orleans Lets The Mayhem Roll
description: NEW ORLEANS is no place to read a book. Vain as a cat about its airs and graces, the city gets miffed if you dare to tear your eyes away, even for one quiet hour, from its ravishing features. I can see it now, glaring at my bowed head. ''Look at me, girl! Don't you hear me talking at you? Pay attention, cher!'' I abandoned countless books in New Orleans, lured away by the dance music outside my window, before I finally got the message of this self-regarding city: ''If you must read, you must read of me.''

title: Stage Mothers Who Shatter The Stereotype
description: ''SING OUT, LOUISE!'' Mama Rose shouts during her daughter's audition in the musical ''Gypsy.'' It's a theatrical moment that Broadway has always cherished, but in Hollywood, where art imitating life spins on a continuous loop, no character type is quite so reviled as the stage mother. There she sits, utterly scorned, in the casting director's waiting room. She's the ''pushy one'' whose son has hair gelled into a complicated disarray, whose little girl is wearing too much mascara.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about mutual funds that invest heavily in financial-services stocks misstated the name of one of the biggest holdings of the Muhlenkamp Fund. It is Conseco Inc., not Conesco.

title: A Legendary Italian Garden
description: IT takes a moment to absorb the silence of Ninfa. You park your car in a sunny olive grove, buy your ticket and step through a stile onto a path of fine gravel. Then, immediately, you are in the legendary garden, immersed in nature, surrounded by the mystery of centuries-old ruins. Though Rome is only an hour's easy drive to the north and the fashionable beaches of Circeo are even closer, Ninfa seems a remote, happily isolated world.

description: Louisa Dette's reputation preceded her. Even before I entered sophomore English at Wayne Valley High School in northern New Jersey, I knew Mrs. Dette was one of those teachers whose course you absolutely had to take. She was tough, my sources told me, but fair.

Loving great-grandmother of Colin, Miranda, and Alexandre. Services Sunday 1pm at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORINCZI, GEORGE G.
description: LORINCZI-George G. In memory of our esteemed partner and colleague whose courage and brilliance was an inspiration to so many. His leadership in international law and his commitment to the development of Eastern Europe made him a central figure in the privatization of state enterprises in Hungary. In addition to founding our Budapest office, he was active in international relations and human rights advocacy. We pay tribute to his integrity, grace and unique character and extend our deepest sympathy to his children and grandchildren. The public memorial will be held on Thursday, April 3 at 2 PM at Cedar Lane Unitarian Church, 9601 Cedar Lane, Bethesda, MD 301-493-8300. Stroock & Stroock & Lavan LLP New York, Washington, Budapest, Boston, Los Angeles, Miami

title: New Directory Lists Special-Interest Tours
description: The Educated Traveler newsletter is offering a new publication, the Directory of Special Interest Travel. This 40-page guide, in the same magazine format as the six-year-old newsletter, lists 300 tours from 40 international operators ranging from Elderhostel to World Rail Travel Specialists to Idyll Ltd., which offers two-week apartment stays mostly in European villages and cities. Prices are not included.

title: When Gangstas Grapple With Evil
description: IN THE AFTERMATH OF the murder of Notorious B.I.G., we have heard the usual condemnations of the vulgarity and violence of gangsta rap, and perhaps rightly so, because the genre's glamorization of guns and gore is deeply unsettling. Still, amid all the attacks, one important dimension of gangsta rap has been overlooked, perhaps because it is hidden in plain sight. Rappers like Notorious B.I.G., Tupac Shakur, Snoop Doggy Dogg and Bone Thugs-n-Harmony have all grappled with one of the oldest, most vexing theological issues: the problem of evil.

title: A Car for the People Who Aren't Car People
description: It is a name that conjures sensuous images of waves rolling onto a California beach, of muscular surfers emerging from the ocean and of tanned bodies soaking up sun. None of which has anything to do with the 1997 Malibu, Chevrolet's new midsize sedan.

title: The Film Makers and the Abuser
description: Brian treglio lies on his stomach on a mat, part of a circle of troubled New York City youths in a theater group called Faces. He's about to go first in ''Intimate Moments,'' an exercise that the others know well: their leader, a social worker named Susan Montez, has often used it to draw them closer together, as well as to bring forth experience that is ''real'' -- heartfelt and serious -- on a subject of concern. The joke is that they've all done Intimate Moments so many times, people have started to cheat, to tell an intimate story for the second or third time.

title: Nursing Homes And Geriatric Care
description: The experience my family had with the Gurwin Geriatric Center was not reflective of the care and concern described in ''Gurwin Nursing Home Gets High Mark'' $(May 23$). My mother, who suffers from Parkinson's disease and multiple strokes, was refused admission to Gurwin on the grounds that she was not ''debilitated enough.'' This was a curious explanation since she is incontinent, cannot walk without assistance and is very confused most of the time. Having heard of Gurwin's outstanding reputation, I called them repeatedly, only to be told that my mother ''fell between the cracks.'' Later on, the hospital social worker assured me that the reasons for my mother's ''rejection'' from Gurwin were grounded in finances: Medicaid reimburses nursing homes at a higher rate for the most seriously incapacitated.

title: The Coyote Solution
description: Yes, the news media travel in predatory packs, like wolves. There was hardly a stir last June when one of the Watergate carnivores, Bob Woodward, reported that Vice President Gore had begged a lot of rich people for television money in 1995. The meatier morsel in Woodward's book was the First Lady's communion with Eleanor Roosevelt. Only after he chewed over Gore again during this year's feeding frenzy did the pack pounce on the Veep.

title: RISING PHONE BILLS ARE LIKELY RESULT OF DEREGULATION
description: Thirteen months after the telephone industry was deregulated in the name of free-market benefits for consumers, the public might soon see the first tangible result of competition: higher phone bills.

title: Heroin Is Proving a Growth Industry for Colombia
description: Black patches scarring verdant mountainsides that are strewn with burnt trees signal South America's latest inroad in the drug trade. It starts with peasants here clearing a few acres of forest to grow poppy flowers, and ends with heroin so pure it can be smoked or sniffed rather than injected.

Every summer scores of families pack into cars or subways to spend sultry days at the one-mile sliver of beach created when Robert Moses hauled fine sands of the Rockaways to Pelham Bay Park.

description: IT is a culinary fact of life that just when you think the Italian restaurant renaissance has peaked, another entry bobs up. Clemente's in Westport is the latest to join the multitude of establishments that proclaim themselves to be northern Italian. Its menu, though, seems to have as many of the southern Italian specialties we all grew up on (clams casino, scaloppine marsala, penne puttanesca) as more northerly ones. In fact, the menu is comfortingly familiar, with few surprises but a number of pleasures.

title: The Dark Side of Audubon's Era, and His Work
