title: I.R.S. R.I.P.
description: The I.R.S. has been estimating unpaid taxes for the past 20 years, and during that time unpaid individual income tax has mushroomed -- from $70 billion in 1985 to $80 billion in 1988 to $90 billion in 1992, which was the last time the I.R.S. bothered trying to figure out what was missing. Sixty billion dollars in underreported income, $13.8 billion in unfiled returns, $14.4 billion in illegal deductions, $100 million in something the I.R.S. calls (oddly) ''mass errors'': when you add it all up about 1 in every 6 dollars legally owed to the Federal Government never gets paid. Assuming no change in the trend, a bit more than $100 billion in individual income taxes will this year go unpaid. Viewed in this light, the $107 billion budget deficit is not a political problem. It's a collection problem.

title: Incest as a Selling Point
description: OEDIPUS blinded himself when he learned that he had slept with his mother. Moll Flanders, Daniel Defoe's much-wed 18th-century heroine, rejects happiness when she discovers that her third husband is her brother. The lovers of D. W. Griffith's ''A Baby's Shoe'' become priest and nun upon learning that they are siblings.

title: THE AGE BOOM
description: Excellent roundup on the positive side of living to an old age, but as St. Augustine wrote, audi partem alterum (hear the other side). I refer to the ailing superannuated, who far outnumber those in their 80's ''going on 50.''

title: 2 Officers Shot and 6 Are Hurt In Two Incidents in Brooklyn
description: Two police officers were shot and six other officers suffered minor injuries early yesterday morning in two incidents in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: THE AGE BOOM
description: I often long to talk with my mother, who died 20 years ago, at age 50 -- now more than ever, since I have become a mother myself. Your special issue gave me, in a sense, the opportunity to hear her voice again. The words and insights of her contemporaries were truly a gift to my soul.

description: AFTER Gov. John G. Rowland and his staff vacated the capitol and Legislative Office Building in Hartford last weekend, 475 high school students took over.

title: Visiting Musical Ghosts in Search of Answers
description: A CEMETERY IS A PLACE where memory overtakes the senses. It may be the memory of someone you loved or knew, or it may be the memory of someone in the deep past, of whom you have merely read or heard. A cemetery, in fact, compassionately blurs the boundary between those two ways of remembering. Someone you loved has taken up residence in the past: the immediate agony of loss is softened by the calm precision of the place. Conversely, someone you have never met, or someone you never could have met, becomes part of your present life: you have ''visited'' him or her, come as close as time and space will allow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSEN, MABEL R.
description: LIFSEN-Mabel R. Wife of Albert A. Lifsen, passed away on Friday, March 21, 1997, at Heartland Rehabilitation Center in Boca Raton, Florida, after a long illness. She was born on May 17, 1914, in New York City, the daughter of Fannie and Isidore Rothman. She was a 1978 graduate of Iona College, having returned to college to fulfill a lifelong dream, after raising two daughters, Marjorie and Isadora. She was active in Hadassah for many years and worked diligently on behalf of the State of Israel. Interment was on Monday, March 24, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, New York. She will be missed by family and friends.

title: Marie Lambert, 76; Ex-Surrogate Court Judge

Lambert, who campaigned for Manhattan Surrogate promising to ''clean up the citadel of patronage'' but who retired from the powerful judgeship 12 years later best known as a patronage queen, died on Tuesday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 76 and lived in Manhattan, where she practiced law.

title: THE AGE BOOM
description: Della Femina says that Madison Avenue has been slow on the uptake in marketing to seniors. Yet we need not worry for the advertising community. As the boomers age, consumer products will continue to provide focus for their identities. While the parents of boomers would grow their hair over their ears to hide a hearing aid, boomers will be wearing these devices with pride. I can imagine one 60-something peering into the ear of another to get a look at the brand and saying: ''Oh, you have the Sony Pro Series hearing system. I've heard that the frequency response is outrageous.''

title: This Music Befits a Saintly Legend
description: THE FATES LOOKED unkindly on Claude Debussy's incidental music to Gabriele d'Annunzio's ''mystery play,'' ''Le Martyre de Saint Sebastien.'' Six days before the play's premiere, at the Theatre du Chatelet in 1911, the Archbishop of Paris warned Roman Catholics to avoid it, calling its portrayal of a revered third-century martyr ''offensive to Christian consciences.'' As a result, some of the socially prominent stayed away.

title: Once-Crowded Library Doubles Its Volume
description: Not so long ago there was no more room for books at the City Island library. The shelves were stuffed to overflowing. Carts piled high with books formed snakes in the aisles of the shoebox-sized space. Though it pained her, the librarian began giving books to other branches.

title: Painting Maps As Wall Hangings
description: DURING the American Revolution, soldiers made maps of the Hudson Valley to mark the locations of their troops and fortifications. These days, Constance Brown and Julie Ruff paint maps of the same area to use as wall hangings.

title: Epic Proportions
description: Richard Attenborough's GANDHI (1982) is an epic told against a background of crowds, massacres and panoramas in the tradition of ''Ben-Hur'' and ''Lawrence of Arabia.'' But there the comparison ends. This is a straightforward story about the Indian political leader who used nonviolent resistance to end British rule. In the title role, Ben Kingsley gives a lively, searching performance that holds the film together as it covers nearly half a century of private and public turmoil. The small screen is kind, focusing the story on private moments that reveal the leader's humanity and wit in a movie that strives to be honest and inspiring. -- SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on HBO. Paula Schwartz

title: Fewer Blacks Follow Robinson's Baseball Lead
description: John Young comes from a generation of African-American athletes that was not only encouraged to dream big dreams by Martin Luther King, but was also shown the way by Jackie Robinson, whose breaking of baseball's color barrier was the first true integration of an American institution.

Last week Administration officials said the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, had rebuffed a White House request for classified information about purported efforts by China to influence American political figures.

title: . . . Or at Sea, Offering Scallops To the Sound

In spite of the cold, Mr. Patterson seemed eager to be out on the water. He was sporting a bright orange slicker, sunglasses and a wool hat pulled down over his ears but, he said, being on the boat was better than sitting in a classroom.

title: Back at Fort Dix, This Time for Health Care

description: MIME and acrobatic art ists and visual puns --flew fast and furiously across the Emelin Theater stage one morning recently, and the audience, largely deaf children from Westchester, was clearly enrapt.

title: Crime
description: I declare a moratorium. Just for today, let me not read about a serial killer who cannibalizes his victims, a cynical cop who quotes Kierkegaard, a private eye who attends A.A. meetings or a young mother who rescues a busload of blind babies from a religious maniac. So let's see what they're doing outside the mainstream.

title: Board Moving to Approve a Mall in Water Mill
description: DESPITE public outcry for the last six years about destroying the rural character of Water Mill, exacerbating the bottleneck of traffic in the hamlet and creating a haze of lighting at night, it appears that the Southampton Town Planning Board is about to approve the construction of a retail shopping complex on the north side of Montauk Highway called Water Mill Shops.

title: Yankee, Go Home. Send Cash.
description: THE President is in his customary place in the hotel bar, apparently inebriated and enjoying yet another pre-dinner drink, when he is asked about the United States. He frowns.

title: The Best in London
description: Anyone on an extended walking tour of London will want to note that the public bathrooms at the Tower Thistle Hotel have been voted the Best Hotel Loo of 1996-97 by the British Tourist Authority. The award is based not just on design (the hotel's restrooms, or loos in British slang, were recently renovated) but on how well cleanliness is maintained. The tourist authority's competition is in its ninth year.

title: An Auto Race Track's Last Lap
description: IN its heyday, the Bridgehampton Race Circuit drew 50,000 spectators on a weekend. Its challenging loops and curves made it world renowned until a local ordinance adopted in 1983 required race cars to be equipped with mufflers. That drove professional racers away and eroded track revenues.

title: Well Grounded at Shortstop
description: Alex Rodriguez sat in front of his locker in the Seattle Mariners' clubhouse one morning this spring, talking and absent-mindedly sucking on a lollipop.

title: Maryland Lawmakers Reject Increase in Tax on Cigarettes
description: The tobacco industry, which has endured some setbacks of late, won a victory this week in Maryland that had more to do with local politics than with national health issues.

title: THE AGE BOOM
description: How about rereading Jerry Della Femina's article ''When Will Madison Avenue Get It?'' and insisting on using ads with us, the elegant, interesting and witty ones. Don't even resort to the airbrush. Just let our laugh lines and worried-about-the-children wrinkles show through. We, too, look good in clothes from Ralph Lauren, the Gap, Liz Claiborne, etc. So educate the children who fear looking like us in the future.

title: The Wealth That Isn't?
description: ''Are You Worth More but Enjoying It Less?'' (March 2), by Jonathan Fuerbringer, discussed the debate over the wealth effect, the theory that consumers spend more simply because the value of their financial assets has risen. The article drew varied responses from readers.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Game of Better Chances
description: FAT CHANCE, a board game that challenges players to lose 20 pounds of ''lard. The game, developed by Ruth Pierce, a resident of Clinton, offers players two strategies: the quick but risky crash diet or the slow, steady healthy lifestyle. After years of roller-coastdieting, Ms. Pierce said: ''I saw how classic my own experience was and wanted to tap into the cultural phenomenon of diet and wight loss. At the same time, I came to feel that society places way too much emphasis on appearance and the scale; I wanted to make light of what is often a very heavy topic.''

title: The Issue Of Taxes And Selling
description: ON Feb. 2, this column examined some of the hazards for homeowners who sell their homes at a profit. The point was made that while most homeowners know they can defer paying taxes on profits by ''rolling over'' those profits into a more expensive replacement house within a two-year period. But they may not realize that renting out part of the house -- or using part for a home office -- can expose part of their profit to taxation immediately.

title: Eastern Parade
description: The Asian influence has been reinterpreted for contemporary day and evening fashion by designers in New York and Paris. The most successful of the new chinoiserie are variations by Prada on the classic Chinese cheongsam (above and inset right), with bamboo-leaf motifs embroidered on satin. Many women are following the example of Joyce Ma (top far right, in long black coat), the owner of fashion boutiques in Hong Kong. Some women choose vibrantly colored and embroidered Chinese robes (bottom right); others wear designs inspired by the traditional kimono. Even shoes are mixing East and West, like the strap-tied pumps (center) set on mirrored clogs.

title: Equality Is More Than 'Ordinary Business'
description: LAST November, news organizations reported allegations of outrageous racial discrimination by executives at Texaco. Previously, Shoney's and Denny's, two family restaurant chains, were rocked by discrimination lawsuits. Just last month, Publix Supermarkets, the big grocery-store chain, agreed to pay $81.5 million to settle accusations of sex discrimination. Mitsubishi Motors is still grappling with the negative fallout from sexual harassment accusations. In today's America, it is truly extraordinary that these problems still occur.

title: Fighting the Drug War With Boomerangs
description: EVER since the Nixon Administration, Washington has been pressing Mexico to crack down on its marijuana and poppy fields. The results have been mixed, and now, over the last decade or so, something more pernicious has occurred.

title: Back in the Kitchen, Post-'Picket Fences'
description: NOT THAT LONG AGO, Kathy Baker's mother called to urge her to play lighter roles. ''I want you to do comedy,'' Lany Baker said. ''You're so good at it. Why don't you just tell everybody?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONEHILL, BETTY
description: STONEHILL-Betty. March 22. Survived by husband Raymond; daughters, Ann Stonehill and Janet Mondshein;, sister, Marjorie Salter and two grandchildren.

title: Paintings That Take the Long (and High) View of the Landscape
description: LANDSCAPE painting has always been a meeting of art and geography. In the works of Spelman Evans Downer, the geography is unusually overt. Mr. Downer, who lives and paints in Jersey City, works from maps, aerial photographs and satellite images to produce what he calls portrayals of ''the landscape as it really is, our human environment interacting with the natural one.'' The way to present this perspective, he says ''is to see it from above.''

title: Credit Cards' Hazards Abroad
description: ADVICE on consumer protection often favors using a credit card for purchases: if things go wrong, conventional wisdom holds, there is an extra layer of protection because the buyer can protest if goods are not received and ask that the charge be removed. But using a credit card overseas, which is helpful because it provides the bank-to-bank rate of exchange at the time the transaction is processed, also has its hazards, as two readers' experiences show.

title: More Trees Scheduled To Be Cut at Airport
description: UNDER a recently released environmental study, the county's plan to improve conditions for small planes at the county airport here identifies 1,001 trees considered obstructions that should either be removed or trimmed.

title: A Quiet SoHo Troupe Makes a Raid Uptown

description: MAYBE you meant to file your tax return early this year, to get that big refund you're due. But with two weeks left before April 15, does it still pay to speed things up? To send in the return by Fed Ex, say, or to file it electronically?

title: White Plains Spending From Official's View
description: As a longtime resident and current vice president of the White Plains School Board, I feel compelled to respond to the letter $(March 2$) written by Roselyn Katz. It is time to put some myths about White Plains schools to rest. Our salary scales are not the highest in the area by far, and in our current contract, newly hired teachers are being paid $1,500 less than they otherwise would have been entitled to for their first year. Our current teacher contract gave a salary increase of 1 percent in the first year and 11 percent over four years, not 14.75 percent. Our average teacher salary is dropping due to the retirements of longtime experienced staff members and their replacements by new teachers at lower salaries. In the 25 years that I have lived here, our school taxes have increased over 10 percent twice (1991 and 1993). Our tax increases in the recent past have been caused by a huge dip in the commercial tax base in White Plains as a result of the high office vacancy rate downtown.

title: Studying Bosnia's U.S. 'Prisoners of Peace'
description: In a major psychological study of the effect on soldiers of the peacekeeping mission in Bosnia, the United States Army is finding that the combat readiness, morale and effectiveness of the troops appears to plummet after six months of duty.

Equally mysterious, the street address generally given in guidebooks offers no means of entry -- unless you're prepared to pole-vault over a 10-foot wall, or shinny up a rusting picket on a padlocked iron gate.

title: When Contrarian Funds Don't Cushion the Blow
description: INVESTORS looking for safety in funds designed to zig when the market zags are bound to be disappointed these days.

title: For Survivors of Suicide, Questions and Lies
description: MY favorite among the young training doctors who came around to practice their poking on me 20 years ago while I recovered from an operation was a friendly, chubby urologist who made enough of an impression for me to write down his name. Harry Reiss. In my hospital notes, I described him as very smart, needing a shave, willing to listen and needing to tuck in his shirttail. He was different enough from his snappy, know-it-all colleagues to lead me to imagine he would either become a leading researcher in the field or go begging for referrals. I never considered he might kill himself at 43.

title: STORM TOSSED
description: 1. The Tornado Debris Project in Norman, Okla., tracks the flight history of debris snatched by tornadoes. 2. Why? To help emergency managers prepare for the aftermath of a hit on, say, a warehouse full of medical waste. Tracking research shows, for example, that most debris falls to the left of a tornado's path. 3. Alert scavengers have recovered full cans of soda, parking tickets and the paperwork from a Mary Kay beauty analysis. 4. This project's distance record is 137 miles, held by a canceled check that flew from Wisconsin to Michigan in 1996. 5. In 1915, pre-project, a check flew 225 miles from Stockton, Kan., to Winnetoon, Neb. -- still the all-time record. 6. Checks are important because they're ''durable and traceable,'' says John T. Snow, the project's director. ''And people collaborate by storing lots of them in attics.''

title: Unsettling Visions Of the Erotic
description: THERE ARE TWO WAYS OF LOOKING AT THE sexually obsessed characters who drift through David Cronenberg's ''Crash,'' combing the highways for car accidents like vampires on the prowl for juicy necks to bite. You could view these famished fetishists for whom a slab of scar tissue or a fresh wound is erotic as numbed-out pleasure seekers who are so jaded that they can be aroused only by sex that is intimately associated with violence and death. Or you could view them as die-hard romantics bravely trying to reclaim sex as a sacred rite in a culture that has commercialized eroticism to the point of banality.

description: PRAYERS AND A PARADE -- Christians filled churches for Easter celebrations yesterday, and revelers crowded Fifth Avenue for the annual parade (bunnies welcome), left. Page B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DASSIN, MIRIAM
description: DASSIN-Miriam. On March 30, 1997. Beloved wife of Gerald. Loving mother of Lev. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., today, Monday, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Ella Maillart, a Swiss Writer and Adventurer, Is Dead at 94
description: Ella Maillart, a Swiss sportswoman, adventurer, travel writer and photographer who defied convention, hardship and international borders to explore forbidden territory and forbidding terrain, died on Thursday in her mountain chalet in Chandolin, Switzerland. She was 94.

title: Ellis Island Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: Ultimate Reward for a Vol Guard's Comeback
description: KERRI STRUG? Big deal. Crummy little ankle sprain. One Olympic vault, landing on a mat. Had to be carried around by her coach for what seemed like a month.

title: Hamilton F. Potter, 68, Lawyer Who Represented Leading Banks
description: Hamilton Fish Potter Jr., a lawyer who specialized in banking, died March 21 in Sun Valley, Idaho. Mr. Potter, a resident of New York City, was 68.

title: Workers Prefer the Money, Not Comp Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Reese Helped Change Baseball
description: The white boy was 13 or 14 years old, and his brother was about 16, when, with dusk descending on that summer day in Louisville, Ky., in the early 1930's, the older boy shouted a racial slur at six black kids, telling them, ''Get off this street!'' With that, the six black kids took chase after the white boys, and the two white kids ran with everything they had and made it safely home.

title: Boy Wakes to Gunfire, Finds Couple Shot in Bed
description: After waking up to the sound of gunshots early yesterday morning, an 8-year-old Queens boy found his mother and her boyfriend shot and critically wounded in their bed, the police said. The shootings occurred around 5:30 A.M. in a ground-floor apartment on 38th Street in Astoria, Queens. The boy ran next door and asked a neighbor to call the police.

title: The More the Knicks Wobble, the Less Tolerant Van Gundy Gets
description: The Knicks made Jeff Van Gundy's job tougher, so their coach got tougher as well.

title: Citizen Shell
description: A quarter-century ago, businesses argued that protecting the environment was not their job. Few American companies would say so today. A similar change may be developing in corporate attitudes about human rights. Companies are increasingly recognizing that their actions can affect human rights, and that respecting rights can be in their business interest.

title: Brazen Robber Upsets a Church on Its Holiest Day
description: A masked man walked into St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens, where 2,200 people were attending Easter morning Mass yesterday, went down to the basement, menaced a priest with what he said was a gun and stole more than $600 in donations that had been collected during Holy Week.

title: Women's Killers Are Very Often Their Partners, A Study Finds
description: More women in New York City are killed by their husbands or boyfriends than in robberies, disputes, sexual assaults, drug violence, random attacks or any other crime in cases where the relationship between the murderer and victim is known.

title: CUNY Critics Should Blame Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. John Peatman, A Radio Analyst, 92
description: Dr. John Gray Peatman, a statistician who studied audience reaction to early radio broadcasts and was a professor of psychology at City College for several decades, died on March 9 at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 92.

title: Will Owners Reprimand Calipari?
description: Today's regularly scheduled meeting involving the Nets' ownership could veer from the usual agenda when the topic gets around to Coach John Calipari.

title: Small Town Fights Big City to Gain Own Identity
description: From her wooden dock, Mary Clark can look down a surging tidal creek to see the land that once bore cotton for her husband's forefathers.

title: Man Shot to Death in Diner
description: A man was shot and killed inside a diner in Paterson yesterday evening, the police said.

title: Fred Spielman, Songwriter, 90
description: Fred Spielman, a songwriter who worked in Tin Pan Alley and Hollywood, died on March 21 at his home in New York City. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, CHARLES
description: SIMON-Charles. Of Greenwich, CT, formerly of Rye, NY, on March 29, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Peggyann. Loving father of Christine S. Coats of Greenwich, CT, Kathleen S. Graham of Harrison, NY, Scott S. Simon of New Canaan, CT, Patricia A. Simon of Louisville, KY, and Michael J. Simon of London, England. Dear brother of Mary Ellen White of NYC, William E. Entombment Laurel Grove Cemetery, Totowa, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Hospice Unit Fund of the Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perry Ridge Rd, Greenwich, CT 06830. For informaiton call the William H. Graham Funeral Home in Rye.

title: Andrew Valuchek, Democratic Liaison And Publisher, 85
description: Andrew J. Valuchek, a former publisher of foreign-language papers in New York who served for many years as a Democratic Party liaison to ethnic groups and foreign visitors to Washington, died on March 16 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 85 and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: A New Point Guard Brings Quick Success
description: Rupp Arena was packed, and the Kentucky Wildcats' fans smelled blood. This was the hour and the game that everyone in blue and white had anticipated. South Carolina. Retribution and revenge.

title: The Roman Catholic Church gets mixed reviews on its foray into advertising's big issues.
description: THE Pope's getting into advertising?'' said one ad executive with a laugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, DORIS ANN
description: WARNER-Doris Ann. On March 29, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late Joseph Leroy Warner and Ann Christine Moran Warner. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, March 31, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. For further information, call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500.

title: U.S. SURVEYS FIND FARM WORKER PAY DOWN FOR 20 YEARS
description: Despite decades of efforts to improve the lot of American farm workers, wages for the nation's more than two million farm laborers have trailed stubbornly behind inflation for the past 20 years, making it hard for many of them to afford adequate housing and other necessities.

title: Otto John, 88, Bonn Official At Center of Counterspy Mystery
description: Otto John, a high West German official who was at the center of a mysterious cold war episode, died on Wednesday in a sanitarium in Innsbruck, Austria. He was 88 and lived at Igls outside Innsbruck.

title: A molecular biologist receives protection for discoveries that could be millions of years old.
description: TWO years ago Raul J. Cano, a prominent molecular biologist, published evidence that he had brought back to life a microorganism that had been lifted from the stomachs of ancient bees preserved in amber over millions of years.

title: Sifting Memories For Clues on Cult
description: As coroners were finishing autopsies of the 39 members of the Heaven's Gate cult who committed suicide, those who died were remembered around the country.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: It's Wildcats Seeking to Dethrone Wildcats
description: First came the Unforgettables, the 1992 Kentucky Wildcats, a team remembered best for the heartbreak it suffered when its season ended barely short of a spot in the Final Four. Then there were the Untouchables, the 1996 national champions, a monument to Coach Rick Pitino's ability to acquire a remarkable collection of talent and manage powerful young egos.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about the Transamerica Corporation's settlement of a class action suit misstated the effect on the company's earnings of discounts it offered on some insurance policies as part of the settlement. Transamerica said the discounts, which it valued at $135 million, would not reduce its earnings.

title: Deal May Save Reservoir
description: Since 1899, Clark residents have sunbathed, fished and gone birdwatching along the edges of the Robinson's Branch Reservoir. Since a dam on the reservoir was declared unsafe in 1993, however, the Middlesex Water Company has threatened to drain the reservoir rather than fix the dam for $1.4 million.

title: Franklin C. Salisbury Dies at 86; Aided Cancer and Rocket Studies
description: Franklin Cary Salisbury, a lawyer and entrepreneur who promoted scientific advances in cancer research and rocketry, died on March 12 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 86 and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: Albania Envoy Accuses Italy in Sinking of Refugee Boat
description: Senior Albanian officials today accused the Italian Navy of causing the deaths of dozens of Albanian refugees on Friday when one of its vessels rammed and sank a boat in which the Albanians were fleeing their homeland.

title: Government Shouldn't Rule on Internet Content
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDNER, HARVEY
description: BIDNER-Harvey. Designer, inventor, pioneer and holder of numerous patents. Devoted husband of Jean. Beloved father of Michael and Robin. Adored son of Ida. Loving brother of Ruth Newman. Dear father-in-law of Andrew Lachow and Michelle. Cherished grandfather of Sam. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Sacramento Charity's Success Puts It at Odds With City Council
description: It is sometimes hard for people here to remember now, but it was not long ago that Loaves and Fishes was being hailed as a model among groups that help the homeless, a scrappy, creative private agency that city officials loved to praise.

title: The Bell Tolls for Oslo
description: The Arab-Israeli peace process is in such dire straits today because for the first time it is threatened not by extremists, but by the very leaders who are supposed to be doing the negotiating. The enemies are all inside the tent, and they are Benjamin Netanyahu, Yasir Arafat, Bill Clinton and just about every Arab leader.

title: Martin Atlas, 82; Led Charity Group
description: Martin Atlas, a retired tax lawyer, real estate executive and former president of the Cafritz Foundation, a leading benefactor of the arts, education and social programs in Washington, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, PATRICIA MORRIS
description: BERNSTEIN-Patricia Morris. On March 29, 1997. Beloved wife of Sumner Bernstein. Devoted mother to Nancy Quitoni and son-in-law Louis and the late James Bernstein and daughter-in-law Joan. Also survived by four loving grandchildren, Vivian, Charles, Katherine and Ashley, and three adoring sisters, Ray, Dorothy and Helen, and sister-in-law Anita. Memorial service to be held Monday, 1 PM, at the Ferncliff Cemetery Chapel in Hartsdale, NY. For further information, contact the Harrison Funeral Home, 914835-0284. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Nestle Unit Shuffles Accounts
description: The Perrier Group of America in Greenwich, Conn., a unit of Nestle S.A., has reassigned the accounts of several brands of bottled water. Billings were not disclosed.

title: A Tale of Innocence Betrayed, in a Stylized Mode
description: The Moscow Festival Ballet, directed by Sergei Radchenko, might look like still another new touring company from the former Soviet Union intent on earning hard currency with an all too familiar repertory.

title: A Litany of Ifs and Maybes for Mets
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine considers every question deliberately, as if pondering an eight-page menu at a restaurant, and even if he produces an answer, he almost always includes a qualifier.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GHERARDI, DR. LINDA BUCH
description: GHERARDI-Dr. Linda Buch, March 31, 1996. One year since you left us. We love you so. Your are deeply remembered and sorely missed by all. Your Loving Family

title: Guiding Journeys Through Ancient Text
description: The rabbi was heading east on the Massachusetts Turnpike, a stack of Torahs in his back seat, the full moon out his window. It was three weeks before Passover, and he was talking about the Passover story: the meaning of the exodus from Egypt, the four questions, the importance of joy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On April 10, the photographer RICHARD AVEDON, the soprano BEVERLY SILLS and the businessman EDGAR BRONFMAN JR., along with about 1,000 other prominent New Yorkers, are planning to be principals in New York City schools. They will be part of the Principal for a Day program, which was started in 1994 by former Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines to invite prominent New Yorkers to spend one day in a school to share their experience and expertise with the students and to gain a personal understanding of how the public schools work and what problems they face.

title: South of the Border, a Cab Ride Can Really Cost
description: Like many neighbors, Mexico and the United States have their share of disputes.

title: Municipal Courts Are Linked
description: After 12 years of work, New Jersey has completed a computer linkup that connects the state's 537 municipal courts with one another, with the state court system's central database and with Federal, state and local law enforcement agencies, The A.P. reported yesterday. The computer network gives the municipal court judges, who hear six million cases a year, easy access to a defendant's record of convictions, pending charges and outstanding warrants.

title: Agents, but Not So Secret Anymore
description: In the annals of international spookery, has there ever been a cadre of spies that has been so thoroughly exposed as the Central Intelligence Agency? The revelations have become a kind of burlesque show: as the trappings of secrecy fall away, the nation gets a peek at everything that was supposed to be private.

title: Clay Sculpture Is Mistaken for Bomb
description: Russell R. Kucinski is not a terrorist, he says. And the object on the front seat of his car -- made of modeling clay, watch parts, wires and paper towel tubes painted red -- was a sculpture for an art class at Rutgers University. But it looked enough like a bomb to New Brunswick police to prompt them to evacuate 30 residents in a three-block area for three hours on Saturday and charge Mr. Kucinski, 19, with ''creating a hazardous or physically dangerous condition.''

title: Despite Devastating Losses, the Gardner Museum Is Rebounding
description: Inside the door of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, the remembered fragrance is there: the rich, humid perfume of damp earth and the hothouse orchids in the four-story glass-roofed courtyard. Instantly, memories of childhood visits come flooding back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREELEY, TIRZAH
description: GREELEY-Tirzah. Beloved wife of Charles. Devoted mother of Tamara and David. Cherished sisterin-law of Leon and Olga Grilli, adored aunt, great-aunt, cousin and friend. Service Tuesday, 10 AM, at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont. Contributions may be made to Larchmont Hadassah or Larchmont Temple.

title: Sewage Closes Clam Beds
description: About 2,500 acres of commercial clam beds were closed yesterday after a water main break spewed thousands of gallons of untreated sewage into Lakes Bay, officials said. It was not clear yesterday how long the ban would last, and officials did not know how many clammers were affected, nor the extent of harm to wildlife in the bay, which is on the inland side of the barrier island that includes Ventnor and Atlantic City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORINCZI, GEORGE G.
description: LORINCZI-George G. In memory of our esteemed partner and colleague whose courage and brilliance was an inspiration to so many. His leadership in international law and his commitment to the development of Eastern Europe made him a central figure in the privatization of state enterprises in Hungary. In addition to founding our Budapest office, he was active in international relations and human rights advocacy. We pay tribute to his integrity, grace and unique character and extend our deepest sympathy to his children and grandchildren. The public memorial will be held on Thursday, April 3 at 2 PM at Cedar Lane Unitarian Church, 9601 Cedar Lane, Bethesda, MD 301-493-8300. Stroock & Stroock & Lavan LLP New York, Washington, Budapest, Boston, Los Angeles, Miami

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIALKOW, MILTON
description: FIALKOW-Milton. Of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Muriel. Loving father of Howard and Donald. Devoted brother to David. A warm, kind man, deeply loved and respected by all who knew him. Our lives can never be the same without him. He will be greatly missed.

title: Health Care Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: Speedy Recovery by Ewing Helps Cure What Ails Knicks
description: In the 24 hours before today's game, Patrick Ewing took anti-inflammatory drugs, strapped ice packs to his left arm and hooked himself up to an electric-stimulation machine. His pulled left triceps almost completely healed, he suddenly felt spry and agile enough to dunk maliciously on Horace Grant in front of a national television audience.

title: DEATHS AT RALLY RATTLE CAMBODIA
description: Cambodia's hard-won but increasingly tenuous democracy was shaken today by a grenade attack that killed or wounded scores of people at an opposition political rally in the center of the capital.

title: Computers Turn Design On Its Prototypical Ear
description: The Pfaltzgraff Company could not have produced a machine-made china plate that looked like a handmade wicker basket without a computer program that mimicked how a weaver would pinch the wicker strands.

title: For Starters, Yankees Think They're Solid
description: There is the class leader, the shy prodigy, the class clown, the former prodigy and the enigmatic pupil. These are the five personalities who make up the Yankees' starting rotation, five pitchers who entered the classroom this spring with question marks. If grades were awarded, each would receive an A.

title: Boggs Gets Stitches Near Left Eye
description: Wade Boggs received more than 40 stitches today after a ball hit him over his left eye just before the start of the Yankees' final exhibition game.

title: Choreography Looks Absurd (But That's Its Intention)
description: It's fortunate that ''Take 3'' concluded Fresh Tracks, the program that several choreographers offered on Tuesday night at Dance Theater Workshop. If this dance had opened the evening, everything that followed might have looked absurd.

title: Searching for Solace in the Hope of the Resurrection
description: The Rev. H. L. Harvey's rich baritone reverberated off the nave's Corinthian columns and the tall stained-glass windows in brown and green at the New Friendship Baptist Church here this morning, as he spoke of Easter's significance to Christians: the death and resurrection of Jesus.

title: Tim Johnson, Concert Promoter, 65
description: Tim Johnson, a concert promoter, producer and former owner of the Ballroom, a popular New York cabaret, died on March 14 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in Manhattan.
